title: Mice in Bion-M 1 space mission: training and selection
objective: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying bone degeneration in space, focusing on osteoblastic and osteocytic activities in the pelvic girdle and proximal femur of mice exposed to microgravity.
methodology: Female mice were subjected to 15 days of spaceflight. Bone structure and mineral density were examined using micro-computed tomography (mCT) and nano-computed tomography (nanoCT). Osteoclast activity was assessed using TRAP staining. Gene expression analysis was performed using RT-qPCR arrays. Immunohistochemical analysis was used to determine the cellular localization of specific proteins.
results: Spaceflight resulted in significant bone loss in the ischium, accompanied by increased osteoclast numbers and osteoclast-covered bone surfaces. NanoCT revealed lacunar enlargement and increased canalicular diameter. Gene expression analysis showed upregulation of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and alterations in genes involved in osteogenesis and cell cycle regulation. p21 expression was upregulated in osteoblasts.
conclusions: Bone responses to spaceflight are complex and involve osteoclastic, osteoblastic, and osteocytic degenerative responses. Upregulation of CDKN1a/p21 in microgravity may be a major concern for tissue regenerative health in long-duration spaceflight.
relationships: The study identifies relationships between microgravity, bone cell activity (osteoclasts, osteoblasts, osteocytes), gene expression (MMPs, p21), and bone loss.
insights: Microgravity induces bone loss through a combination of increased osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and cell cycle arrest in osteoblasts. The upregulation of p21 suggests a potential mechanism for inhibiting bone formation and tissue regeneration in space.

title: Microgravity induces pelvic bone loss through osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and osteoblastic cell cycle inhibition by CDKN1a/p21
objective: To elucidate cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the adaptation of key physiological systems to long-term exposure in microgravity.
methodology: Male C57/BL6 mice were flown aboard the Bion-M 1 biosatellite for 30 days. In vivo measurements (video recording of behavior, continuous blood pressure measurement) were combined with in vitro studies (morphological, biochemical, cellular, and molecular analyses) carried out shortly after the return of the mice and at the end of the recovery study. Ground control experiments replicated environmental and housing conditions.
results: Mice displayed signs of pronounced disadaptation to Earth’s gravity after the flight. Video data showed mice spent much time in physical contact (huddling) with one another and were grouped against the feeder wall of the cylindrical habitat. Post-flight, mice were markedly less active, with reduced distance and rearing frequency, and increased grooming duration. Mice housed in habitats displayed more pronounced thigmotaxis.
conclusions: The training program was effective, and male mice can be successfully employed in space biomedical research. Hardware malfunction in the food distribution system and microgravity-related changes in mouse behavior were noted. Moving parts within the habitat present potential risks and should be avoided or carefully analyzed in the design of future mouse habitats.
relationships: The study compared space flight groups with ground control groups to assess the impact of microgravity. Relationships between housing conditions, behavior, and physiological parameters were analyzed.
insights: Prolonged spaceflight has a significant impact on the sensorimotor systems of mice. The design of mouse habitats for space missions needs careful consideration of factors such as food distribution, moving parts, and the potential for altered behavior in microgravity. Continuous blood pressure measurement with implantable telemetry is feasible and valuable in space experiments.

title: Stem Cell Health and Tissue Regeneration in Microgravity
objective: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying bone degeneration in microgravity, focusing on osteoblastic and osteocytic activities in the pelvic girdle and proximal femur of mice.
methodology: Female mice were exposed to 15 days of spaceflight. Bone structure and mineral density were analyzed using micro-computed tomography (mCT) and nano-computed tomography (nanoCT). Osteoclast activity was assessed via TRAP staining. Gene expression analysis was performed using RT-qPCR arrays to examine genes involved in osteogenesis, extracellular matrix remodeling, and relevant signaling pathways. Immunohistochemistry was used to localize specific proteins.
results: Spaceflight resulted in decreased bone volume fraction and bone thickness in the ischium. Osteoclast numbers and activity increased. Lacunar enlargement and increased canalicular diameter were observed, suggesting osteocytic osteolysis. MMPs were upregulated, particularly MMP10 in osteocytes. Expression of genes promoting osteogenic growth and proliferation was suppressed. CDKN1a/p21 expression was induced in osteoblasts, while Trp53/p53 expression was not.
conclusions: Microgravity induces bone loss through a combination of increased osteoclastic activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and CDKN1a/p21-mediated osteogenic cell cycle arrest. The pelvic-femoral complex is highly sensitive to load and gravity. CDKN1a/p21 upregulation may be a major concern for tissue regenerative health during long-duration spaceflight.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between microgravity, increased osteoclast activity, osteocytic osteolysis, and the upregulation of CDKN1a/p21, leading to inhibited bone formation and potential long-term tissue regeneration issues in space.
insights: The findings highlight the complex interplay of cellular and molecular mechanisms in bone degeneration during spaceflight. The identification of CDKN1a/p21 as a key regulator provides a potential target for countermeasures to mitigate bone loss and promote tissue regeneration in long-duration space missions.

title: Microgravity Reduces the Differentiation and Regenerative Potential of Embryonic Stem Cells
objective: To examine the effects of microgravity on biological processes and their implications for human health, focusing on the immune system, cancer biology, and tissue regeneration.
methodology: Comprehensive literature review using PubMed, Scopus, and Embase databases, structured following the PICOT framework. Studies included observational, in vitro, and experimental investigations addressing the effects of microgravity on biological processes.
results: Microgravity significantly impacts the immune system by disrupting T cell activation, cytokine production, and macrophage differentiation, leading to increased susceptibility to infections. In cancer biology, it promotes spheroid formation in cancer stem cells and thyroid cancer cells. Microgravity enhances tissue regeneration by modulating Hippo and PI3K-Akt pathways, improving stem cell differentiation into hematopoietic and cardiomyocyte lineages. Cardiomyocytes cultured under microgravity exhibit enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis, improved calcium handling, and advanced structural maturation.
conclusions: Microgravity has dual implications for space medicine and terrestrial health, highlighting its potential to drive advances in regenerative therapies, oncology, and immunological interventions. Continued research is essential for protecting astronaut health and fostering biomedical innovations.
relationships: Microgravity affects the gut microbiota, impacting hepatic metabolism through the gut-liver axis. It also influences interactions between human pathogens and plants, increasing bacterial virulence and compromising plant defense mechanisms.
insights: Microgravity disrupts endothelial physiology, influencing cell proliferation, inflammatory responses, and vascular regulation. It also alters hepatic metabolism, leading to increased lipotoxicity and dysregulation of immune response genes. These insights have implications for diseases such as cancer, atherosclerosis, and other circulatory disorders.

title: Microgravity validation of a novel system for RNA isolation and multiplex quantitative real time PCR analysis of gene expression on the International Space Station
objective: To evaluate the ability of dynamic microgravity culturing of human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs) using microcarriers to selectively expand highly functional stem-cell subpopulations.
methodology: hASCs were cultured on polystyrene and collagen microspheres under dynamic (microgravity-simulating) and static conditions. Cell growth, viability, expression of pluripotent markers (OCT4, SOX2, NANOG, MYC, KLF4, CD34, SSEA-3), colony formation, network formation, and multilineage differentiation (adipogenic, osteogenic, chondrogenic) were assessed.
results: Dynamic microgravity culture on microspheres increased the proportion and number of SSEA-3(+) hASCs. These cells showed higher expression of pluripotent markers, improved colony formation, enhanced network formation (angiogenesis), and increased differentiation into adipogenic and osteogenic lineages compared to static cultures. Both polystyrene and collagen microspheres showed similar efficacy.
conclusions: Microgravity culture with microspheres selectively enhances the proliferation of highly functional hASCs with superior stemness, proliferation, differentiation, and angiogenic abilities. This technique may provide enhanced treatments for intractable human diseases.
relationships: Microgravity culture conditions increased not only the proportion, but also the number, of SSEA-3(+) cells to actualize regenerative therapies requiring these highly therapeutic cells. hASCs harvested from microgravity–microsphere cultures had higher expression levels of the pluripotent markers OCT4, SOX2, NANOG, MYC, KLF, and CD34 compared to hASCs cultured in monolayers.
insights: The study demonstrates a novel cell-culturing technique that uses three-dimensional movement to create microgravity conditions for the preservation of stemness, while at the same time preserving cell–microsphere adhesion to maximize cell quantities. The outcomes of this study exceeded our expectations. Seven days of polystyrene and collagen microsphere cultures under static conditions produced an increased number of SSEA-3(+) hASCs compared to polystyrene dish cultures, and those under dynamic conditions exhibited a much higher number of SSEA-3(+) hASCs.

title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
objective: To validate a novel system (WetLab-2) for RNA isolation and real-time PCR analysis of gene expression in microgravity on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: The WetLab-2 system, consisting of a fluidic system, temperature-stable reagents, and microgravity-compatible hardware, was used to isolate RNA from E. coli cells and mouse liver tissue on the ISS.  Quantitative PCR (qPCR) and Reverse Transcriptase-quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) were performed on-orbit. Ground controls were run in parallel.  Primer assays, lyophilized components, and hardware were validated on the ground before the on-orbit experiments.
results: qPCR and RT-qPCR were successfully performed in microgravity. Cycle threshold (Ct) values were comparable to ground controls, although increased variability was observed in microgravity samples due to bubble formation. RNA was successfully isolated from bacterial cells and mammalian tissue on-orbit.  Mitigation strategies, such as using standard caps to pressurize PCR tubes, reduced bubble formation.
conclusions: The WetLab-2 system provides a novel operational on-orbit research capability for molecular biology, enabling end-to-end gene expression analysis in real-time on the ISS. This allows for data interpretation and experiment redesign while on-orbit, increasing the autonomy of space research.
relationships: The study demonstrates the feasibility of conducting complex wet bench experiments in the ISS National Lab environment.  It shows the relationship between microgravity conditions and the challenges of performing molecular biology techniques, specifically bubble formation during thermal cycling.
insights: The ability to perform RNA isolation and RT-qPCR on-orbit opens new possibilities for space exploration, including disease diagnostics, environmental monitoring, and optimizing plant growth.  The WetLab-2 system can be applied to various sample types and provides investigators with improved insight and interactivity during experimentation.

title: Dose- and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-Like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
objective: To test the hypothesis that spaceflight alters the expression of key genes related to stress response pathways, potentially contributing to cardiovascular deconditioning during extended spaceflight.
methodology: Mice were exposed to spaceflight for 15 days or maintained on Earth as ground control. Ventricle tissue was harvested post-landing. Gene expression related to oxidative stress and Trp53 signaling was measured using quantitative PCR.
results: Spaceflight altered the expression of genes regulating redox balance, cell cycle, and senescence in cardiac tissue. Specifically, Nfe2l2 was downregulated, Nox1 was upregulated, and Ptgs2 was downregulated, suggesting increased oxidative stress. Cdkn1a (p21) and Myc were upregulated, while Tnf was downregulated.
conclusions: Spaceflight may contribute to cardiac dysfunction due to oxidative stress and altered cell cycle regulation. These changes in gene expression provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cardiovascular responses to the space environment.
relationships: Oxidative stress and Trp53 signaling pathways are linked, with transcription factors FoxO3, Jun, Myc, and Hif1a mediating the interaction between these pathways. Cat, Cdkn1a, Cdk1, and Cdk4 serve as central hubs of gene networks altered by spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight activates a network of genes responsible for redox signaling and defense against oxidative stress in the heart. It also alters the expression levels of major cell cycle and cell growth regulators, suggesting that spaceflight activates p21- and Myc-related pathways to regulate cell growth and cardiomyocyte function.

title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions.
objective: To elucidate the role of radiation type and changes in the oxidative environment of bone marrow related to marrow-derived osteoprogenitor differentiation, and to determine if irradiation-induced insults to skeletal structure and osteoblastogenesis persist long after exposure.
methodology: In vivo experiments using mice exposed to low-LET protons or high-LET 56Fe ions at various doses. Bone structure was assessed using microcomputed tomography. Marrow cells were cultured ex vivo to assess osteoblastogenesis. In vitro experiments were conducted to assess the role of oxidative stress in radiation damage to osteoprogenitors, comparing low-LET (137Cs) and high-LET (56Fe) radiation.
results: High doses of 56Fe radiation (200 cGy) induced detrimental effects on total antioxidant capacity, bone structure, and osteoprogenitor populations. High-LET irradiation was more damaging to cell growth than low-LET. The antioxidant SOD protected osteoprogenitors from low-LET radiation damage, but minimally from high-LET.
conclusions: High-dose, high-LET 56Fe impairs osteoblast growth and maturation by adversely affecting osteoprogenitors. Scavenging ROS with antioxidants mitigated the adverse effects of in vitro irradiation with gamma rays, but failed to protect from irradiation with an equivalent dose of heavy ions. High-dose radiation has a persistent effect to impair bone formation by adversely affecting growth of osteoprogenitors.
relationships: High-LET radiation induces oxidative stress, which impairs osteoblastogenesis and leads to bone loss. The antioxidant SOD can mitigate some of the damage from low-LET radiation, but is less effective against high-LET radiation.
insights: High-LET radiation poses a significant risk to skeletal health during space missions. Countermeasures targeting oxidative stress may be beneficial, but additional strategies are needed to address the unique challenges posed by high-LET radiation.

title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae to assess bone quality.
objective: To advocate for translational research at NASA, provide examples of NASA-sponsored early-stage translational research, and discuss options for a path forward to achieve NASA’s goals for human spaceflight.
methodology: Review of NASA's Space Biology and Human Research Programs, analysis of NIH's translational research model, and a two-phased approach (basic-to-applied and applied-to-operational) for translational research.
results: Identified key spaceflight-related environmental factors impacting human health (microgravity, confinement, radiation) and demonstrated the value of translational research in addressing specific risks (immune response, microbe-host interactions, oxidative stress, visual impairment).
conclusions: Enhanced translational research is crucial for developing countermeasures for exploration missions. Program coordination and team science approaches can facilitate translation from discovery to development to implementation.
relationships: Synergism between Space Biology and the Human Research Program (HRP) is vital. NASA should partner with external organizations like NIH to benefit from their expertise and contribute unique data.
insights: Open science approaches, data sharing, and increased activity in education, communication, and advocacy are fundamental to achieving translational research goals. Encouraging translational research proposals and phased awards can enable vertical translation across NASA’s life sciences portfolio.

title: Effects of ex vivo ionizing radiation on collagen structure and whole-bone mechanical properties of mouse vertebrae.
objective: To develop a precise method for ex vivo cyclic compressive loading of isolated mouse vertebral bodies and demonstrate its utility by measuring fatigue life.
methodology: Isolated mouse vertebrae were prepared with 3D-printed support jigs for machining plano-parallel surfaces, pivotable loading platens to ensure uniform contact, and specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis to measure stiffness and prescribe force levels. Cyclic compressive loading was performed, and fatigue life was measured. Results were compared against two existing methods.
results: The new method (KFEA) showed reduced scatter in mechanical behavior compared to literature methods (KEXP and FMAX). The standard deviation of fatigue life was significantly lower for the new method. The fatigue life was approximately uniform across all specimens. The elastic stiffness measured from fatigue testing (Kelastic) was also lower for the KEXP method than the FMAX method and the new method. The standard deviation for stiffness was lowest for the new method.
conclusions: The new method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae yielded highly reproducible measurements of fatigue life by controlling the nominal level of strain applied to bone specimens. Implementing a pivotable loading platen to ensure uniform contact is important for accuracy of results.
relationships: The study demonstrates the relationship between bone quality, cyclic loading, and fatigue life in mouse vertebrae. It also highlights the importance of precise biomechanical testing methods for small-animal bone specimens.
insights: Specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis can improve the precision of cyclic loading experiments. Controlling strain levels during cyclic loading reduces scatter in fatigue life measurements. Pivotable loading platens are important for ensuring uniform contact and accurate results.

title: Absence of gamma-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation in murine skeletal muscle
objective: 1) quantify the effects of radiation dose on the monotonic strength and fatigue life of murine vertebrae; and 2) determine whether the degradation in mechanical properties is dominated by the amount of non-enzymatic crosslinks or fragmented collagen.
methodology: Ex vivo x-ray radiation experiment on excised mouse lumbar vertebrae. Spinal tissue from twenty-week old, female, C57BL/6J mice were randomly assigned to a single x-ray radiation dose of either 0 (control), 50, 1,000, 17,000, or 35,000 Gy. Measurements were made for collagen fragmentation, non-enzymatic collagen crosslinking, and both monotonic and cyclic-loading compressive mechanical properties. Quantitative micro-CT Imaging. Uniaxial compressive monotonic and cyclic mechanical testing was performed. Biochemical tests were conducted to assess non-enzymatic crosslinks and the fragmentation of the collagen backbone.
results: Vertebral strength, ultimate strain, and work-to-fracture were lower than the control group for radiation exposures of 17,000 and 35,000 Gy but were not different than the control group for exposures of 50 and 1,000 Gy. Monotonic stiffness remained unchanged for all radiation dose groups compared to the control group. The relative amount of non-enzymatic collagen crosslinks was greater for all radiation groups. Collagen fragmentation was only observed at doses of 17,000 and 35,000 Gy. The micro-CT analysis confirmed successful random sample distribution; there were no significant differences in bone quantity or microarchitecture between the groups.
conclusions: The fragmentation of collagen was the primary molecular mechanism that caused the observed reductions in mechanical properties in whole bones exposed to ionizing radiation. Increased collagen fragmentation, and not non-enzymatic crosslinking, is the dominant factor.
relationships: Monotonic strength of 17,000 and 35,000 Gy groups were less than the prescribed cyclic loading force. Fatigue life, strain to failure, and elastic stiffness for the 50 and 1,000 Gy exposures did not differ from the control.
insights: Non-enzymatic collagen crosslinks may play a smaller role in degrading mechanical strength of bone than previously considered. Irradiation has unique effects on cyclic behavior that are not manifested in static behavior.

title: Absence of γ-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation in murine skeletal muscle
objective: To determine whether additional pathways are altered with the loss of γ-sarcoglycan, extending previous studies on mechanosensitive, γ-sarcoglycan-dependent ERK1/2 phosphorylation.
methodology: Mechanotransduction was examined in the presence and absence of γ-sarcoglycan, using C2C12 myotubes, primary cultures, and isolated muscles from C57Bl/6 and γ-sarcoglycan-null mice. All were subjected to cyclic passive stretch. Signaling protein phosphorylation was determined by immunoblotting of lysates from stretched and non-stretched samples. Calcium dependence was assessed by maintaining muscles in calcium-free or tetracaine-supplemented Ringer’s solution. Dependence on mTOR was determined by stretching isolated muscles in the presence or absence of rapamycin.
results: C2C12 myotube stretch caused an increase in P-p70S6K, but decreased P-FAK and P-ERK2. Neither Akt nor ERK1 were responsive to passive stretch. Similar but non-significant trends were observed in C57 primary cultures in response to stretch, and γ-SG-/- cultures displayed no p70S6K response. In contrast, in isolated muscles, p70S6K was mechanically responsive. Basal p70S6K activation was elevated in muscles of γ-SG-/- mice, in a calcium-independent manner. p70S6K activation increased with stretch in both C57 and γ-SG-/- isolated muscles, and was sustained in γ-SG-/- muscles, unlike the transient response in C57 muscles. Rapamycin treatment blocked p70S6K activation in stretched C57 muscles, and reduced downstream S6RP phosphorylation. However, even though rapamycin treatment decreased p70S6K activation in stretched γ-SG-/- muscles, S6RP phosphorylation remained elevated.
conclusions: p70S6K is an important component of γ-sarcoglycan-dependent mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle. Loss of γ-sarcoglycan uncouples the response of p70S6K to stretch, implying that γ-sarcoglycan is important for inactivation of this pathway. Altered load-sensing mechanisms exist in muscular dystrophies where the sarcoglycans are absent.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between γ-sarcoglycan, p70S6K, and mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle. It also indicates a connection between the loss of γ-sarcoglycan and altered load-sensing mechanisms in muscular dystrophies.
insights: The findings increase the understanding of the contribution of aberrant load-sensing to the pathology of muscular dystrophies where the SG complex is deficient. γ-SG may be required for dephosphorylation and deactivation of p70S6K. The study identifies p70S6K as part of a novel SG-dependent mechanosensitive signaling pathway in skeletal muscle.

title: TNO1 is involved in salt tolerance and vacuolar trafficking in Arabidopsis.
objective: To investigate the roles of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c in Arabidopsis, focusing on their potential redundant functions in pollen development and pollen tube growth.
methodology: Generated and analyzed T-DNA insertion mutants of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c. Examined phenotypes of single and double mutants under various growth conditions. Performed RT-PCR to analyze transcript levels. Conducted in vitro pollen germination assays and measured pollen tube growth. Used scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to observe pollen morphology. Created promoter::GFP/GUS fusion constructs to analyze gene expression patterns. Performed transient expression in protoplasts and confocal microscopy to determine subcellular localization.
results: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c exhibit correlated expression patterns. AtrabD2b/2c double mutants show shorter siliques compared to wild-type plants. The double mutant produces deformed pollen with swollen and branched pollen tube tips. Pollen defects are responsible for reduced fertilization. Both AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c localize to Golgi bodies.
conclusions: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have partially redundant roles in vesicle trafficking during pollen tube growth, which cannot be fully compensated by other AtRabD family members. These proteins are important for normal pollen development and pollen tube elongation.
relationships: AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c are functionally redundant and share similar expression patterns. They are related to Rab1 isoforms in mammals, which regulate membrane trafficking between the ER and Golgi complex.
insights: The study reveals the importance of specific Rab GTPases in pollen development and tube growth, highlighting the complexity of membrane trafficking in plant cells. The functional redundancy between AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c suggests a fine-tuned regulation of vesicle transport in reproductive processes.

title: Functional redundancy between trans-Golgi network SNARE family members in Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To identify and characterize a novel protein, TNO1, that interacts with the SYP41 SNARE complex at the trans-Golgi network (TGN) in Arabidopsis thaliana, and to determine its role in vacuolar trafficking and stress responses.
methodology: Co-immunoprecipitation, mass spectrometry, RT-PCR, generation of a T-DNA knockout mutant (tno1), immunofluorescence microscopy, subcellular fractionation, salt and osmotic stress assays, Brefeldin A (BFA) treatment, and analysis of vacuolar protein secretion.
results: TNO1 was identified as a TGN-localized membrane protein that interacts with SYP41. The tno1 mutant exhibited sensitivity to salt and osmotic stress, partial mislocalization of SYP61, secretion of vacuolar proteins, and delayed formation of BFA compartments in cotyledons. TNO1 does not relocate to the BFA compartment upon BFA treatment.
conclusions: TNO1 is involved in vacuolar trafficking and salt stress resistance, potentially by facilitating vesicle fusion and maintaining TGN structure or identity. It may function as a tethering factor at the TGN, similar to USO1 in yeast.
relationships: TNO1 interacts with the SYP41 SNARE complex, including SYP41, SYP61, and VTI12. The tno1 mutant phenotype is similar to that of the syp61 mutant, suggesting a functional relationship. TNO1 may cooperate with AtVPS45 and VTI12 in VSR1-mediated vacuolar trafficking.
insights: TNO1 plays a role in maintaining TGN structure or identity, marking TGN remnants that do not participate in BFA compartment formation. Vacuolar trafficking is important for salt tolerance, and defects in TNO1 can lead to both salt sensitivity and secretion of vacuolar proteins.

title: Root growth movements: Waving and skewing.
objective: To investigate the subcellular localization of an uncharacterized Arabidopsis thaliana protein (AtGTLP) and its potential functions.
methodology: The study used transgenic Arabidopsis lines expressing AtGTLP-mGFP, along with various RFP-tagged organelle markers. Colocalization was assessed using confocal laser scanning microscopy and Pearson correlation coefficient analysis. Mutant lines were also analyzed for phenotypic differences.
results: AtGTLP was found to be mainly localized to the trans-Golgi network. Sequence analysis suggested a distant homology to metazoan protein O-fucosyltransferases. Mutant lines lacking AtGTLP showed no obvious phenotypic differences under standard growth conditions.
conclusions: AtGTLP is a Golgi-resident protein, primarily localized to the trans-Golgi. It may belong to a yet uncharacterized family of Arabidopsis glycosyltransferases or fucosyltransferases, potentially involved in glycosylation processes within the Golgi. Redundant functions with other proteins may explain the lack of a distinct phenotype in single mutants.
relationships: AtGTLP interacts with trans-Golgi marker, ST, as well as with the Golgi marker, GOS12. It also partially colocalizes with TGN markers, SYP61 and VHAa1, and to a lesser extent, SYP43.
insights: The study suggests that AtGTLP might be involved in glycosylation processes within the Golgi, potentially as a novel fucosyltransferase. The lack of a distinct phenotype in single mutants indicates possible functional redundancy with other proteins.

title: Gravitropism and lateral root emergence are dependent on the trans-Golgi network protein TNO1
objective: To investigate the function of TNO1 (TGN-localized SYP41-interacting protein) in root movement in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: The study used Arabidopsis thaliana wild-type and tno1 knockout mutants. Root skewing and waving assays were performed on solid Murashige-Skoog medium. Drug sensitivity assays were conducted using taxol and propyzamide. Cell file rotation was analyzed using microscopy and propidium iodide staining. Microtubules were immunostained and analyzed via confocal microscopy and MicroFilament Analyzer software.
results: tno1 knockout mutants displayed enhanced root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation. Skewing of tno1 roots increased upon microtubule stabilization with taxol but was insensitive to microtubule destabilization with propyzamide. Microtubule array orientation was unaffected in the mutant roots. Mature regions of tno1 roots grown on propyzamide had severe defects in cell morphology. TNO1 affects auxin transport.
conclusions: TNO1 modulates root skewing in a mechanism dependent on microtubules but not linked to disruption of microtubule array orientation. TNO1 is required for maintenance of cell morphology in mature regions of roots and the base of hypocotyls. The TGN-localized SNARE machinery is important for appropriate epidermal cell file rotation and cell expansion during root growth.
relationships: TNO1 interacts with the SYP41 SNARE machinery at the trans-Golgi network. TNO1 function affects auxin transport, microtubule dynamics, and cell wall trafficking.
insights: TNO1 plays a key role in cell expansion during root deviation and is important for anisotropic cell expansion or cell wall trafficking dynamics. TNO1 and the TGN play a key role in CFR and root movement, adding another component to the network controlling root movement. Understanding TNO1's role can lead to manipulating root growth and development patterns for improved crop architecture.

title: TNO1, a TGN-localized SNARE-interacting protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To investigate the role of TNO1, a trans-Golgi network (TGN)-localized protein, in auxin responses during root development and gravistimulation in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: The study used a tno1 mutant of Arabidopsis thaliana, along with wild-type and complemented lines. Experiments included gravitropism assays, lateral root density analysis, root length inhibition assays using various auxin analogs and transport inhibitors, analysis of auxin response distribution using DR5rev:GFP reporter, and FM4-64 staining to assess endocytosis.
results: The tno1 mutant showed delayed lateral root emergence, decreased gravitropic bending of roots and hypocotyls, and increased sensitivity to the auxin analogs 2,4-D and IAA. Auxin asymmetry at lateral root tips and during gravistimulation was reduced in the tno1 mutant. Bulk endocytosis was unaffected.
conclusions: TNO1 plays a role in mediating auxin responses during root development and gravistimulation, potentially through trafficking of auxin transport proteins. TNO1 contributes to the temporal control of lateral root emergence and the establishment of auxin response asymmetry.
relationships: TNO1 interacts with the SYP41 SNARE protein at the TGN. It influences auxin transport and responses, affecting lateral root emergence and gravitropism. The study suggests a link between TGN-mediated protein trafficking and auxin transporters.
insights: The findings suggest that TNO1, a TGN-localized protein, is important for proper auxin transport and signaling in Arabidopsis roots. Disruption of TNO1 function leads to defects in lateral root development and gravitropism, highlighting the role of TGN-mediated trafficking in plant hormone responses.

title: The Drosophila SUN protein Spag4 cooperates with the coiled-coil protein Yuri Gagarin to maintain association of the basal body and spermatid nucleus.
objective: To investigate the role of TNO1 (TGN-localized SYP41-interacting protein) in root movement in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: The study used Arabidopsis thaliana wild-type and tno1 knockout mutants. Root skewing and waving assays were performed on solid Murashige-Skoog medium. Drug sensitivity assays were conducted using taxol and propyzamide. Cell file rotation was analyzed using microscopy and propidium iodide staining. Microtubules were immunostained and analyzed via confocal microscopy and MicroFilament Analyzer software.
results: tno1 mutant roots displayed enhanced root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation. Skewing of tno1 roots increased upon microtubule stabilization with taxol but was insensitive to microtubule destabilization with propyzamide. Mature regions of tno1 roots grown on propyzamide had severe defects in cell morphology. The orientation of microtubule arrays in elongating cells of skewing tno1 roots was not affected.
conclusions: TNO1 modulates root skewing in a mechanism dependent on microtubules but not linked to disruption of microtubule array orientation. TNO1 is required for maintenance of cell morphology in mature regions of roots and the base of hypocotyls. The TGN-localized SNARE machinery is important for epidermal cell file rotation and cell expansion during root growth.
relationships: TNO1 affects auxin transport and is linked to auxin-dependent and MT-associated processes. TNO1 interacts with the SYP41 SNARE machinery and plays a role in cellulose synthase trafficking, MT stability, and cell expansion dynamics at the TGN.
insights: TNO1 acts as a negative regulator of root skewing. The enhanced skewing in tno1 mutants correlates with an increase in left-handed cell file rotation. TNO1 and the TGN play a key role in cell file rotation and root movement, adding another component to the network controlling root movement. TNO1 might be important for anisotropic cell expansion or cell wall trafficking dynamics.

title: Toll mediated infection response is altered by gravity and spaceflight in Drosophila
objective: To investigate the impact of gravity and spaceflight on the Toll-mediated infection response in Drosophila.
methodology: Sequence alignment analysis of Yuri-65 and Zyg-12A proteins.
results: Sequence alignment reveals similarities and differences between Yuri-65 and Zyg-12A proteins, suggesting potential functional relationships.
conclusions: Gravity and spaceflight can alter the Toll-mediated infection response, potentially through changes in protein structure or function.
relationships: Yuri-65 and Zyg-12A share sequence similarities, indicating a possible evolutionary or functional relationship.
insights: The study suggests that spaceflight conditions may affect immune responses at a molecular level.

title:
Toll Mediated Infection Response Is Altered by Gravity
and Spaceflight in Drosophila
objective: To understand the biological consequences of long-term exposure to spaceflight on immune function, specifically focusing on infections mediated through the conserved Toll and Imd signaling pathways in Drosophila.
methodology: Drosophila were used as a model for innate immunity. Experiments involved exposing flies to hypergravity and spaceflight conditions. Immune responses were assessed through survival assays, genetic analysis using gravitaxis mutants, and transcription profiling (qPCR and microarray) after infection with B. bassiana (fungus) and E. coli (bacteria). Earth-reared flies served as controls.
results: Hypergravity improved resistance to Toll-mediated fungal infections, except in gravitaxis mutants. Spaceflight alone activated the heat shock stress system. Space flies infected with fungus failed to activate the Toll pathway, while bacterial infection produced normal activation of the Imd pathway. Uninfected space flies showed an altered transcriptional profile with upregulation of stress response genes.
conclusions: Hypergravity and spaceflight have opposing effects on immune responses in Drosophila. Spaceflight produces stress-related transcriptional responses and results in a specific inability to mount a Toll-mediated infection response. The compromised human immunity seen at altered gravity may result from protein unfolding and heat shock protein engagement.
relationships: The Toll pathway primarily responds to fungal and Gram-positive infections, while the Imd pathway responds to Gram-negative infections. Heat shock proteins may interfere with the binding of processed Spz to Toll, potentially modulating the immune response.
insights: Gravity plays a crucial role in normal immune function. Spaceflight-induced stress, particularly protein unfolding and heat shock protein engagement, can selectively impair the Toll pathway while leaving the Imd pathway intact. This suggests that the extracellular induction events associated with Toll activation are more susceptible to disruption in microgravity conditions.

title: GeneLab database analyses suggest long-term impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system by the activation of FYN through reactive oxygen species.
objective: To analyze GeneLab database to understand the long-term impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system.
methodology: Multi-omics analysis of data from multiple space missions.
results: The study suggests a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver.
conclusions: Space radiation exposure may lead to long-term cardiovascular effects through mechanisms involving reactive oxygen species and FYN activation.
relationships: Space radiation -> Reactive Oxygen Species -> FYN activation -> Cardiovascular System Impact
insights: Long-term space travel may pose risks to cardiovascular health due to radiation-induced molecular changes.

title: FAIRness and usability for open-access omics data systems.
objective: To identify key genes/drivers for the contribution of space radiation on the cardiovascular system using NASA’s GeneLab database and an unbiased systems biology method.
methodology: Analysis of microarray data from cardiomyocytes of mice exposed to proton or iron radiation, and human endothelial cells cultured on the ISS. Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) were used to identify key pathways and genes.
results: FYN identified as a central driver/hub for the cardiovascular response to space radiation. Protons have a stronger overlap with spaceflight samples than iron ions. ROS pathways were downregulated, suggesting a persistent impact of space radiation. A predicted microRNA signature associated with cardiovascular risk was identified.
conclusions: Space radiation induces a protective mechanism in the cardiovascular system through FYN activation, reducing ROS levels. Protons are the major component of radiation affecting samples in LEO. This protective mechanism may not be enough to reduce inflammation caused by space radiation, potentially increasing cardiovascular disease risk.
relationships: FYN activation reduces ROS levels, protecting against cell death. Inflammation is predicted to increase cardiovascular health risk. Protons have a stronger impact than iron ions in LEO.
insights: The cardiovascular system has a protective mechanism against space radiation through FYN activation. Space radiation's impact on the cardiovascular system involves a complex interplay between ROS, inflammation, and key regulatory genes. Protons are the major radiation component in LEO.

title: NASA GeneLab platform utilized for biological response to space radiation in animal models
objective: To assess the FAIRness of NASA’s GeneLab Data Systems (GLDS) and similar systems using FAIRness metrics, and to propose new principles for maximizing data accessibility and usability.
methodology: Assessment of NASA's GeneLab Data Systems (GLDS) along with four similar systems (GEO, ENA, MG-RAST, Metabolights) using 14 FAIRness metrics developed by the GO FAIR Metrics group. Systems were rated as Pass, Partial Pass, or Fail for each metric, and an overall FAIRness score was calculated.
results: The FAIRness scores ranged from 6-12 (out of 14), with an average of 10.1. Systems performed best in data findability and accessibility, and worst in data interoperability. Reusability of metadata was often not well supported.
conclusions: The assessed omics data systems have shortcomings, particularly in supporting data interoperability. The study proposes new design principles for FAIR systems that handle Big Data to maximize both usability and reusability of data, including integrated credentialing architecture and collocation of data and executable code.
relationships: The study relates the FAIRness assessments to the challenges faced in developing the GLDS as a FAIR data system. It also discusses the importance of semantic integration of omics data for federated querying and retrieval functions.
insights: The study highlights the need for community-developed metadata standards, formal languages for metadata representation, and FAIR vocabularies to improve data interoperability. It also emphasizes the importance of addressing data transport challenges in Big Data systems.

title: Circulating miRNA spaceflight signature reveals targets for countermeasure development
objective: To identify dose-dependent biological responses to space radiation using a meta-analysis of transcriptomic datasets from NASA GeneLab, aiming to understand human health risks in spaceflight.
methodology: Meta-analysis of 30 experimental conditions from 25 GeneLab datasets, including in vivo animal models and in vitro cell cultures exposed to varying doses of space radiation and simulated space radiation. Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) was performed to identify enriched biological pathways.
results: Identified distinct biological signatures associating specific ions with specific biological responses due to radiation exposure in space. Changes were observed in mitochondrial function, ribosomal assembly, and immune pathways as a function of dose. RNA-sequencing error rates were analyzed, revealing increased base substitutions in spaceflight samples. Principal component analysis (PCA) and t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) plots validated the absence of batch issues.
conclusions: The GeneLab database can be used to generate novel hypotheses to better understand human health risks from galactic cosmic ray (GCR) exposures. The study identified tissue-independent biological pathways dysregulated by space radiation, highlighting potential targets for therapeutic countermeasures.
relationships: Identified relationships between space radiation exposure and dysregulation of mitochondrial function, ribosomal assembly, immune response, and oncogenic pathways like KRAS, TGFβ, and VEGFa.
insights: Space radiation exposure induces dose-dependent alterations in key biological pathways, including mitochondrial function, immune response, and cancer-related pathways. These alterations may contribute to increased health risks during long-duration space missions. The study also suggests that space radiation may impact taste transduction.

title: Machine learning algorithm to characterize antimicrobial resistance associated with the International Space Station surface microbiome
objective: To identify and validate a spaceflight-associated microRNA (miRNA) signature shared by rodents and humans in response to simulated and real spaceflight conditions, and to explore its potential as a biomarker and therapeutic target.
methodology: Quantified circulating miRNAs in serum from rodents exposed to simulated spaceflight conditions (microgravity, radiation) and true spaceflight (ISS). Analyzed miRNA expression in irradiated human immune cells ex vivo and in astronauts from the NASA Twins Study. Performed single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and single-cell assay for transposase accessible chromatin (scATAC-seq) to assess downstream effects and chromatin changes. Utilized antagomirs to inhibit key miRNAs in a 3D human microvascular tissue model to evaluate therapeutic potential.
results: Identified a spaceflight-associated miRNA signature that is partially conserved between rodents and humans. The miRNA signature is dose-dependent for both radiation and microgravity. Single-cell analysis revealed changes in miRNA-mediated gene expression across different blood cell populations. Inhibition of specific miRNAs with antagomirs mitigated vascular damage caused by simulated deep space radiation in a 3D human microvascular tissue model.
conclusions: A spaceflight-associated miRNA signature can be used as a biomarker of systemic biological damage and a source for therapeutic targets. Strategic inhibition of specific miRNAs with antagomirs has the potential to prevent biological damage caused by spaceflight.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight stressors (microgravity, radiation), miRNA expression, and physiological effects (cardiovascular damage, immune dysfunction). It also explores the relationship between miRNA expression and chromatin accessibility, as well as the role of immune cell composition in miRNA-mediated gene expression.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the biological responses to spaceflight and identifies potential targets for countermeasure development. The findings suggest that a systemic miRNA signature can be used to assess spaceflight-induced damage and that antagomir-mediated miRNA inhibition may be a promising therapeutic approach.

title: Extraterrestrial Gynecology: Could Spaceflight Increase the Risk of Developing Cancer in Female Astronauts? An Updated Review
objective: To identify antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes associated with cultivated strains and metagenomes from the International Space Station (ISS) using a deep learning approach.
methodology: Analysis of whole-genome sequences of 226 pure strains, metagenome sequences of 21 environmental samples, and 24 MAGs retrieved from PMA treated samples using the DeepARG deep learning approach. Antibacterial Susceptibility Tests (AST) were performed to validate computational predictions.
results: Increased AMR read counts in later flights, particularly Flight 3. Kalamiella piersonii showed AMR patterns related to glycopeptide, fluoroquinolone, and MLS. E. bugandensis presented more than 40 ARGs. AST results closely matched the DeepARG predictions, confirming the accuracy of computational prediction of AMR.
conclusions: Machine learning can uncover concealed AMR determinants in metagenomics datasets, expanding the understanding of the ISS environmental microbiomes and their pathogenic potential in humans. The study highlights the importance of monitoring AMR in space environments to protect astronaut health.
relationships: The microbiome of the crew's skin resembled those of the surfaces inside the ISS collected by the crewmember on the same flight. The study also found novel ARGs associated with other species such as K. pneumoniae, Pantoea, Paenibacillus polymyxa, Bacillus velezensis, Enterococcus faecalis, Sphingomonas, and, with a lower number of ARGs, several species of Staphylococcus.
insights: Deep learning can identify AMR genes with low sequence identity, which are missed by traditional methods. The study suggests a widespread presence of potential ARGs in the isolates, with 'multi-drug' class being first, followed by glycopeptides, beta-lactams, bacitracin, and tetracyclines.

title: Muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression during spaceflight is linked to a metabolic crosstalk in both the liver and the muscle in mice.
objective: To review the effects of microgravity and radiation on the female reproductive system, particularly gynecological cancer, and to highlight areas needing further study for safer space exploration.
methodology: Review of existing literature and studies conducted on Earth and in space, focusing on the effects of microgravity and radiation on the female reproductive system and gynecological cancer.
results: Microgravity and space radiation pose significant hazards to astronaut health, potentially increasing carcinogenic risk. Studies on female reproductive health in space are limited, but animal studies suggest potential effects on gonadal function, fertility, and embryonic development. Space radiation, particularly galactic cosmic radiation (GCR), can cause DNA damage and increase cancer risk. The effects of microgravity and radiation on gynecological cancers are still being elucidated.
conclusions: There is a scarcity of knowledge about the impact of space radiation and microgravity on gynecologic cancer. Further research is needed to ensure the safety and health of female astronauts during space missions, including studies on tumor histology, molecular pathways, omics endpoints, viral reactivation, radiation countermeasures, screening protocols, and the role of artificial intelligence.
relationships: The review explores the relationship between spaceflight factors (microgravity, radiation), hormonal modalities, and the risk of gynecological cancers. It also discusses the interplay of these factors with reproductive fitness and potential countermeasures.
insights: Space radiation and microgravity can affect cellular processes involved in carcinogenesis. The review highlights the need for more research on the effects of spaceflight on the female reproductive system and the development of gynecological cancers. It also emphasizes the importance of personalized preventive medicine programs and the development of effective countermeasures to mitigate the risks of space radiation exposure.

title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by galactic cosmic radiation
objective: To describe the relationship of the response of both the liver and the muscle of mice during spaceflight.
methodology: Transcriptomic data from mouse liver and quadriceps were analyzed using GSEA, ORA, and sparse partial least square-differential analysis (sPLS-DA). The mixOmics package in R was used for data comparison, correlation, and association visualization.
results: Lipid metabolism is the most affected biological process in both the liver and quadriceps during spaceflight. A specific gene cluster expression pattern in the liver strongly correlated with glucose sparing and an energy-saving response in the muscle. Hypoglycemic signaling pathways were significantly downregulated in the quadriceps. Muscle glucose transport gene expression correlated with decreased muscle DNA repair, autophagy, and translation processes gene expression. Liver lipid metabolism gene expression correlated with muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces a metabolic shift towards an energy-saving mode, resource sparing, and lipid mobilization through a tight liver-muscle crosstalk, contributing to muscle atrophy. Dietary changes based on starch supplementation and microbiome modulation may represent a countermeasure.
relationships: The study highlights a strong correlation between liver lipid metabolism gene expression and the downregulation of hypoglycemic and energy demand process-related genes in muscle. It suggests a starvation-like phenotype promoting a metabolic shift towards energy conservation.
insights: The liver influences quadriceps gene expression through hepatokines. Increased Fetuin-A production by the liver and diminished production of FGF21, ANGPTL4, FST, and Andropin are likely involved in the gene expression correlation identified.

title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: Host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection
objective: To understand how galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) impacts human health by investigating the influence of DNA structure on radiation outcomes, chromatin properties, and histone modifications on DNA methylation alterations induced by low- and high-LET ions.
methodology: The study used publicly available datasets and performed Hi-C analysis, chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq), and microarray/RNA-seq data to assess the impact of distinct histone modifications on DNA methylation changes and the impact of gene expression on irradiation response. The nucleus was divided into five distinct radial nuclear layers based on Hi-C data.
results: 56Fe induces a persistent DNA methylation increase, whereas 28Si and X-ray induce a decrease in DNA methylation that is not persistent over time. Chromosomes with the highest DMPs frequency accumulate DNA methylation sites at the “L2”–“L3” junction. The highest DNA methylation change is present around the middle “L3” layer. Promoters and enhancers are prone to GCR-induced DNA methylation changes, with H3K4me3 and H3K27ac histone marks associated with the highest DNA methylation change.
conclusions: GCR particles induce unique acute and chronic DNA methylation and gene expression patterns. Spatial distribution of key epigenetic modifications plays a major role, with heterochromatin-associated domains influencing DNA accessibility and radiation response. The study identifies regions of the human genome most vulnerable to GCR and associated with higher DNA methylation changes.
relationships: Chromatin architecture, particularly heterochromatin, plays a significant role in determining the intensity of DNA methylation changes after irradiation. The relationship between spatial chromosomal positioning, histone modifications, and DNA methylation patterns was explored. Gene expression patterns correlate with DNA methylation changes, particularly in response to 56Fe and space exposure.
insights: The outer layers of the nucleus absorb the highest radiation dose, resulting in more differently methylated sites, but these are randomly distributed. The middle layer of the nucleus exhibits the highest average methylation change, suggesting other factors limit the effect of GCR radiation in outer layers. Promoters and enhancers are prone to GCR-induced DNA methylation changes, with H3K4me3 and H3K27ac histone marks associated with the highest DNA methylation change, suggesting their vulnerability to irradiation.

title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight
objective: To provide an overview of current knowledge of SARS-CoV-2 and its biological effects, from basic biology to clinical patient outcomes, highlighting future research areas.
methodology: Review of virological, animal, and clinical studies to understand the mechanisms driving varied clinical diagnoses and observations of COVID-19 patients.
results: Identified metabolic adaptations (shifts in TCA cycle, lipid metabolism), humoral adaptations (bradykinin imbalances, endocrine system disruptions), exosome involvement in immune response, non-coding transcriptome roles (miRNAs, lncRNAs, circRNAs), cardiovascular changes (endothelial dysfunction, thrombosis), immune system responses (innate and adaptive), and organ alterations (brain, GI tract) due to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
conclusions: SARS-CoV-2 and its related diseases, COVID-19 and PASC, have significant worldwide impacts. The viral effects on physiology, metabolism, circulating components, and organ systems are complex and dynamic. Further research is needed to address knowledge gaps and improve patient care.
relationships: SARS-CoV-2 interacts with the renin-angiotensin system (RAS), endocrine system, and immune system, leading to various physiological adaptations and disease outcomes.
insights: COVID-19 is a pleiotropic condition with intricate biochemical ties integrating cellular and organ systems. Understanding the host responses and identifying biochemical targets can help mitigate COVID-19 effects.

title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs
objective: The objective is to assess the presence of biological markers and pathways related to frailty, aging, and sarcopenia within the spaceflight context, and to determine if the space environment can influence the onset of age-related dysfunctions in astronauts.
methodology: The study leverages murine data from NASA’s GeneLab, astronaut data from the JAXA and Inspiration4 missions, and multi-omics and systems-informatic approaches. Transcriptomic data from rodent research missions flown to the International Space Station (ISS), astronaut data from a recent JAXA study, and data from the first civilian commercial spaceflight mission, Inspiration4 (i4) were analyzed. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was performed on specific aging-related pathways.
results: The analysis identified notable changes in gene expression patterns indicative of a frailty-like condition during space missions. Altered expression in genes related to frailty and muscle loss were identified. Multiple frailty-related biomarkers are differentially expressed in rodent muscles during spaceflight. Interferon inflammatory response and muscle tissue development pathways are enriched in rodent muscles during spaceflight. Novel sarcopenia-related genes are differentially expressed during spaceflight. Multiple frailty related biomarkers are differentially expressed in human muscles during spaceflight and ground-based spaceflight simulated conditions. Multiple frailty related biomarkers are differentially expressed in astronauts.
conclusions: The findings suggest that the parallels between spaceflight and the aging process may extend to encompass frailty as well. Exposure to the space environment leads to changes consistent with frailty, including inflammation, muscle wasting and other age-related features. The study proposes a method to study the development of frailty-related health risks, which astronauts may develop during spaceflight, in the perspective of achieving adequate preventative measures.
relationships: Spaceflight-related stressors share similarities with the hallmarks of aging: mitochondrial dysfunction, genomic instability, epigenetic alterations, telomere length changes, cellular senescence, and dysbiosis. Muscle loss in astronauts shares similarities with sarcopenia in the elderly. Chronic inflammation is associated with frailty and muscle wasting.
insights: The study highlights the potential for spaceflight to induce aging-like phenomena, including frailty, and suggests that monitoring frailty biomarkers could be useful for assessing astronaut health. The identification of altered gene expression patterns and pathways provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying these changes and could inform the development of countermeasures to mitigate the health risks associated with long-duration space missions.

title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
objective: To determine the biological factors rescued by countermeasure treatment against space radiation damage, focusing on inflammation, DNA damage, and mitochondrial function.
methodology: RNA-sequencing and transcriptomic analysis on 3D microvessel cell cultures exposed to simulated deep space radiation (Galactic Cosmic Radiation) with and without antagonists to microRNAs: miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, and let-7a-5p. Data from NASA Twin Study, Inspiration4, and JAXA missions were used to validate findings in humans.
results: Antagomir treatment resulted in significant reduction of inflammation and DNA double-strand breaks, rescue of mitochondria functions, and restoration of gene expression to normal levels. Key genes and pathways implicated in the action of these antagomirs were altered in humans exposed to spaceflight.
conclusions: Targeting miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, and let-7a-5p may be a potential countermeasure strategy to mitigate space radiation damage and reduce human health risks in spaceflight missions.
relationships: Identified 21 key gene targets for the three miRNAs, involved in apoptosis, cell cycle, immune response, and mitochondrial processes.  Observed an inverse correlation between the three miRNAs (i.e. miR-16, let-7a, and miR-125b) with the 21 gene targets in monocytes of astronauts.
insights: Space radiation induces changes in gene expression related to inflammation, DNA damage, and mitochondrial dysfunction. Inhibition of specific miRNAs can mitigate these effects, suggesting a potential therapeutic strategy for astronauts. Orphan genes also play a role in the response to space radiation and antagomir treatment.

title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
objective: To lay out pressing ethical issues related to selecting space travelers and conducting human subject research, especially in non-governmental and commercial space operations.
methodology: Review of existing literature, regulations, and guidelines related to space exploration, medical ethics, and human subject research. Analysis of current practices and identification of gaps in ethical oversight.
results: Identified ethical concerns regarding the selection and training of non-government-sponsored astronauts, the lack of formal oversight governing medical research on such crews, and the need for refined selection criteria and training for non-governmental space travelers.
conclusions: The increase in commercial and private space missions necessitates unified ethical guidelines to safeguard human well-being during selection, research, and decision-making in space. Existing regulations primarily address government-sponsored activities, leaving gaps in the ethical oversight of non-governmental initiatives.
relationships: Explored the relationships between governmental and non-governmental spaceflight, the selection of spaceflight occupants, and the ethical considerations of human subject research in space.
insights: Commercial spaceflight raises new ethical issues, particularly concerning informed consent, risk assessment, and the potential for harm to spaceflight participants. There is a need to incorporate emerging ethical issues into existing frameworks applicable to space travel.

title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila
objective: To investigate the effects of spaceflight and simulated microgravity on the virulence of Serratia marcescens and the immune response of Drosophila melanogaster.
methodology: Serratia marcescens was exposed to spaceflight conditions on the International Space Station (ISS) and simulated microgravity conditions on Earth using a rotating wall vessel (RWV). Drosophila melanogaster were infected with these bacteria, and their survival rates and in vivo bacterial growth were monitored. RNA sequencing was performed to analyze gene expression changes in the infected flies.
results: Spaceflight-exposed Serratia marcescens exhibited increased virulence in Drosophila melanogaster compared to ground controls. This increased virulence was also observed in bacteria grown in simulated microgravity. The increased virulence phenotype was temporary and reversible upon return to Earth conditions. The Imd and Toll immune pathways in the flies did not significantly alter the increased lethality caused by space-flown bacteria. RNA sequencing revealed few significant changes in host gene expression related to immunity.
conclusions: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity can induce temporary changes in Serratia marcescens, leading to increased virulence in Drosophila melanogaster. These changes are likely due to alterations in the pathogen itself, rather than a significant difference in the host's immune response. Microgravity may be a primary factor mediating the differences in virulence seen in the spaceflight bacteria strains.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight conditions, bacterial virulence, and host immune response. It demonstrates that microgravity can alter bacterial physiology, leading to increased pathogenicity. The study also suggests that the host immune system may not be the primary driver of increased lethality observed in spaceflight-exposed bacteria.
insights: The findings suggest that spaceflight can induce physiological changes in bacteria, potentially posing a threat to immunocompromised astronauts. Further research is needed to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms driving these changes and to develop strategies to mitigate the risks associated with spaceflight-induced bacterial virulence.

title: Regulation of plant gravity sensing and signaling by the actin cytoskeleton.
objective: To examine the effects of prolonged exposure to microgravity on heart structure and function using a Drosophila cardiac model.
methodology: Wild-type and mutant Drosophila flies were reared in microgravity aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Cardiac function was assessed via high-speed digital imaging. Transcriptomic analysis (RNA-seq) was performed on isolated hearts. Immunohistochemistry was used to examine myofibrillar structure, ECM organization, and proteasome activity.
results: Microgravity exposure caused cardiac constriction, myofibrillar remodeling, and diminished cardiac output in wild-type flies. Mutant flies showed more severe remodeling. RNA-seq revealed reduced expression of sarcomeric and ECM genes and increased expression of proteasomal genes. Immunohistochemistry confirmed myofibrillar disarray, ECM reorganization, and increased proteasome aggregates.
conclusions: Prolonged exposure to microgravity induces cardiac remodeling and dysfunction in Drosophila, potentially due to alterations in proteostasis and ECM organization. Cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress may be a fundamental response of heart muscle to microgravity.
relationships: Microgravity exposure leads to reduced expression of genes related to heart structure and function, while simultaneously increasing the expression of genes involved in protein degradation. The structural changes observed in the heart tissue correlate with these gene expression changes, suggesting a direct link between gene regulation and tissue remodeling.
insights: Cardiac remodeling and proteostatic stress may be a fundamental response of heart muscle to microgravity. The fly model can have a key role in elucidating the effects of microgravity during prolonged space flight, with significant advantages over other model systems because of its small size, its well defined and conserved genetics, and its relatively short lifespan.

title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis
objective: To review the role of the actin cytoskeleton in primary root growth, focusing on actin organization, the effects of actin-binding proteins, plant hormones, and root tropisms to gravity and light.
methodology: Compilation of existing research, dissection of individual components of actin filaments, and analysis of the effects of actin-disrupting drugs and hormone treatments on root growth.
results: Longitudinally oriented actin bundles and increased actin dynamics are indicative of primary root cell elongation. Actin filaments play a crucial role in the second rapid cell expansion of root cells, aiding in the delivery of cell wall remodeling components and regulating turgor pressure via the vacuolar network. Auxin and cytokinin signaling are key hormonal regulators of actin organization during primary root growth.
conclusions: The actin network is essential for root growth by regulating cell elongation and division. Actin organization is developmentally regulated in the growing root tip, and bundled, longitudinally oriented actin filaments are a hallmark of cell elongation. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the roles of specific actin-binding proteins and the mechanistic connections between hormone signaling and actin dynamics.
relationships: The actin cytoskeleton interacts with plant hormones, particularly auxin and cytokinin, to regulate root growth and tropisms. Auxin promotes longitudinally organized and less bundled filaments, while cytokinin induces increased bundling and less organized filaments. The ARP2/3 complex and SCAR/WAVE complex are involved in cell wall deposition and expansion. Myosin motor proteins are involved in vesicle and organelle motility, as well as the control of actin organization and dynamics.
insights: Actin-mediated delivery of cell wall modifying components aids cell elongation of the primary root meristem. There are causal links between actin, vacuolar morphology, and cell elongation. The actin cytoskeleton plays a role in gravity perception via the mediation of statolith sedimentation and PIN3 relocalization. Light perception also influences actin organization in roots, with far-red light promoting bundled actin organization.

title: ERULUS is a plasma membrane-localized receptor-like kinase that specifies root hair growth by maintaining tip-focused cytoplasmic calcium oscillations.
objective: To identify and characterize the HYPERSENSITIVE TO LATRUNCULIN B1 (HLB1) protein in Arabidopsis thaliana and determine its role in endomembrane system function, particularly in relation to the actin cytoskeleton.
methodology: Forward-genetic screen, map-based cloning, T-DNA insertion mutant analysis, live-cell imaging with fluorescent markers, co-immunoprecipitation, mass spectrometry, BFA and LatB treatments, and genetic interaction studies using double mutants.
results: HLB1 is a plant-specific protein with TPR motifs localized to the TGN/EE. The hlb1 mutant exhibits hypersensitivity to LatB, defects in protein recycling to the plasma membrane, altered F-actin organization, and root hair polarity defects. HLB1 interacts with MIN7/BEN1, an ARF-GEF, and functions in common genetic pathways. OsHLB1 partially complements hlb1.
conclusions: HLB1 is a component of the plant post-Golgi trafficking machinery that potentially links the actin cytoskeleton with post-Golgi traffic. It functions in protein recycling to the PM and contributes to constitutive secretion and trafficking to the vacuole. HLB1 interacts with MIN7/BEN1 in overlapping endomembrane trafficking pathways.
relationships: HLB1 interacts with MIN7/BEN1, an ARF-GEF localized to the TGN/EE. Genetic analysis suggests that MIN7/BEN1 functions upstream of HLB1. HLB1's function is related to the actin cytoskeleton, as indicated by its interaction with F-actin and the mutant's hypersensitivity to LatB.
insights: HLB1 represents a previously undescribed component of the endomembrane trafficking machinery in plants. It highlights the importance of the actin cytoskeleton in post-Golgi trafficking and protein recycling. The HLB1-MIN7/BEN1 complex plays a role in root development and response to actin-disrupting drugs.

title: Brassinosteroids inhibit autotropic root straightening by modifying filamentous-actin organization and dynamics.
objective: To investigate the role of CAP1/ERU, a CrRLK1L protein, in root hair growth and to address conflicting findings regarding its localization and function in cytoplasmic calcium ([Ca2+]cyt) homeostasis.
methodology: Forward genetic screening of root hair mutants, expression of ERU-GFP fusion constructs in Arabidopsis thaliana, live-cell microscopy, analysis of [Ca2+]cyt oscillations using G-CAMP3 reporter and fast Fourier transform methods, and comparison with previously published data.
results: CAP1/ERU is localized to the plasma membrane (PM) and post-Golgi/endocytic vesicles at the root hair tip, and its function is linked to cytoplasmic calcium oscillations. The eru-3 mutant showed compromised tip [Ca2+]cyt oscillations with prolonged periods of elevated [Ca2+]cyt followed by longer periods of dampened [Ca2+]cyt, displaying low frequency [Ca2+]cyt oscillations with increased amplitude compared to the wild type.
conclusions: CAP1/ERU, a PM-localized CrRLK1L, is important for maintaining normal tip-focused [Ca2+]cyt oscillations, which are crucial for sustained root hair growth. The previous model proposing tonoplast-based NH4+ signaling as the major driver for ERU-mediated tip-focused [Ca2+]cyt oscillations and root hair growth needs reexamination.
relationships: CAP1/ERU interacts with cytoplasmic calcium oscillations and is related to other CrRLK1Ls like FERONIA, THESEUS1, HERCULES1, ANXUR, and BUDDHA’s PAPER SEAL.
insights: The study clarifies the localization of CAP1/ERU to the plasma membrane and its role in maintaining proper calcium oscillations, providing a more accurate model for understanding its function in root hair tip growth. It highlights the importance of careful [Ca2+]cyt imaging and data interpretation in root hair research.

title: Cell type-specific imaging of calcium signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana seedling roots using GCaMP3.
objective: To investigate the role of brassinosteroids (eBL) in regulating directional root growth, specifically focusing on their impact on autotropic root straightening and the actin cytoskeleton.
methodology: Experiments were conducted using maize (Zea mays) and barrel medic (Medicago truncatula) roots. Treatments included eBL and Latrunculin B (LatB). Root curvature was measured using a clinostat. F-actin organization was analyzed through confocal microscopy of fixed and live cells.  Transgenic M. truncatula lines expressing F-actin reporters (Lifeact-mGFP and GFP-ABD2-GFP) were used. F-actin dynamics were assessed in etiolated hypocotyls.
results: eBL treatment enhanced root gravitropism and amplified root coiling on a clinostat, similar to LatB. eBL modified F-actin organization in maize roots, reducing density.  In M. truncatula, eBL enhanced root curvature on a clinostat but had mild effects on F-actin organization. eBL inhibited global F-actin dynamics in etiolated M. truncatula hypocotyls.
conclusions: Brassinosteroids are implicated in root autotropism by modifying F-actin organization and dynamics. The acto-myosin system is an important component of plant tropistic responses. eBL's effects on F-actin, while modest, contribute to the inhibition of autotropic straightening.
relationships: eBL and LatB treatments resulted in similar root phenotypes. eBL's effect on root gravitropism is linked to its interaction with auxin. The study suggests a connection between eBL, F-actin dynamics, and the targeting of plasma membrane-associated proteins like PIN2.
insights: The study highlights the role of actin in the graviresponse phase, specifically in the autotropic straightening response.  It suggests that eBL may regulate root autotropic straightening through its impacts on F-actin.  The research introduces new M. truncatula lines expressing F-actin reporters for future studies.

title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development.
objective: To introduce a set of Arabidopsis thaliana lines expressing GCaMP3 in five root cell types (columella, endodermis, cortex, epidermis, and trichoblasts) and to demonstrate their utility in reporting cell-type specific calcium changes in roots treated with chemicals.
methodology: Generated Arabidopsis lines expressing GCaMP3 targeted to specific root cell types using cell-type specific promoters. Used confocal microscopy to validate GCaMP3 expression. Applied ATP, glutamate, aluminum chloride, and sodium chloride to roots and measured calcium-dependent GCaMP3 fluorescence over time.
results: The generated lines showed cell-type specific GCaMP3 expression. Different root cell types exhibited distinct calcium signatures in response to chemical treatments. MS control solution induced calcium changes, which were mitigated by modifying growth conditions. Reaction time analysis showed delayed responses in inner cell types.
conclusions: The cell-type specific GCaMP3 lines are a valuable tool for studying calcium signaling in plant roots. The study highlights the importance of considering growth and treatment conditions when conducting calcium imaging experiments. The lines can be used to investigate the direction of calcium signal propagation within roots.
relationships: The study reveals relationships between specific chemical stimuli (ATP, glutamate, Al3+, NaCl) and calcium responses in different root cell types. It also compares calcium signatures between lines with ubiquitous GCaMP3 expression and cell-type specific expression.
insights: Calcium transients in cell type-specific lines induced by various chemicals had various patterns when compared with lines in which GCaMP3 was expressed ubiquitously. The cortex- and trichoblast-targeted GCaMP3 lines also revealed an earlier onset of NaCl-induced calcium transients when compared to UBQ10:GCaMP3 lines.

title: Microgravity Stress: Bone and Connective Tissue
objective: To investigate the roles of SPIRRIG (SPI), BRK1, and SCAR2 proteins in actin-mediated root hair development in Arabidopsis thaliana.
