methodology: Live cell microscopy, mutant analysis, and fluorescent protein tagging were used to observe the spatial and temporal localization of SPI, BRK1, and SCAR2 during root hair development. Brefeldin A (BFA) treatment was used to investigate endomembrane dynamics. Genetic crosses were performed to generate plants expressing multiple fluorescent markers.
results: SPI localizes to the tips of rapidly elongating root hairs and is transported via post-Golgi compartments. SPI maintains root hair tip-focused F-actin. BRK1 and SCAR2 are molecular determinants of the root hair initiation domain (RHID). SPI is required for the depletion of BRK1 as root hairs transition to tip growth.
conclusions: SPI mediates root hair tip growth by maintaining the tip-focused fine F-actin meshwork. BRK1 and SCAR2 are molecular determinants of the RHID, specifying the position of root hair emergence. SPI contributes to the stability of BRK1 during the transition from root hair initiation to rapid tip growth.
relationships: SPI, W/SC, and actin have functional relationships during root hair development. SPI might modulate BRK1 via protein degradation pathways.
insights: SPI is a root hair tip-enriched BEACH domain-containing protein. SPI mediates root hair tip growth by maintaining the tip-focused fine F-actin meshwork. BRK1 and SCAR2 are molecular determinants of the RHID. SPI contributes to the stability of BRK1 during the transition from root hair initiation to rapid tip growth.

title: Impact of microgravity and lunar gravity on murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel
objective: To investigate the impact of three different gravitational loadings (microgravity, lunar gravity [1/6 g], and 1 g) on the behavior, bone, thymus, and spleen of mice housed for 25–35 days in the International Space Station.
methodology: C57BL/6J male mice were housed in the International Space Station under microgravity, artificial 1g, or artificial 1/6g (lunar gravity) conditions for 25-35 days. Behavioral tests (righting reflex, rotarod), micro-computed tomography of femurs, plasma analysis (TRAP, osteocalcin), histological analysis (HE staining, immunohistochemistry), and RNA-sequencing of bone, thymus, and spleen tissues were performed.
results: Lunar gravity partially recovered bone density reduction and microgravity-induced gene expression changes in bone and thymus. Organ-specific variations in responsiveness to gravity were observed. Lunar gravity suppressed histological changes in the thymus. Spleen weight and structure were preserved under lunar gravity.
conclusions: Lunar gravity can partially mitigate the adverse effects of microgravity on bone and immune systems in mice during spaceflight. The responsiveness to gravity varies among different organs, suggesting a molecular-level gravity threshold for maintaining a healthy state during space travel.
relationships: Microgravity induces bone loss, thymus atrophy, and changes in spleen gene expression. Lunar gravity partially reverses these effects in bone and thymus, while spleen appears less affected. Osteoblast and osteoclast activity are influenced by gravity levels. Gene expression related to cell migration and cell cycle in the thymus is altered by gravity.
insights: The study highlights the importance of understanding the effects of varying gravitational forces on different organ systems during spaceflight. Lunar gravity offers some protection against microgravity-induced damage, but the optimal gravity threshold for maintaining health needs further investigation. Organ-specific responses to gravity suggest complex regulatory mechanisms at the molecular level.

title: Manipulating the permeation of charged compounds through the MscL nanovalve.
objective: To determine the oligomeric state of SaMscL (S. aureus MscL) in the cell membrane and to understand how it can exist in a non-pentameric subunit organization as resolved by X-ray crystallography.
methodology: Disulfide-trapping strategy in bacterial membranes, crosslinking experiments of purified EcoMscL and SaMscL, sedimentation equilibrium analytical ultracentrifugation (SE), and size exclusion chromatography multi-angle light scattering (SEC-MALS). Detergent exchange experiments were also performed.
results: SaMscL channels in vivo are predominantly pentameric. SaMscL is a pentamer when solubilized in Triton X-100 and C8E5 detergents. LDAO detergent induces a shift to a tetrameric oligomerization. The stoichiometric shift induced by detergents is reversible.
conclusions: The physiologically active SaMscL oligomer in vivo is a pentamer. Purification in detergents can cause a reorganization of the SaMscL channel’s oligomeric state. SEC alone is insufficient to evaluate the usefulness of a particular detergent for the study of membrane proteins; SEC-MALS and/or analytical ultracentrifugation should be correlated with in vivo experiments.
relationships: The study clarifies the relationship between the oligomeric state of SaMscL and the detergents used for solubilization. It also relates the in vivo findings with previous crystallographic studies, highlighting potential artifacts introduced by detergent use.
insights: Detergents can alter the subunit stoichiometry of membrane protein complexes in vitro, emphasizing the importance of in vivo assays to establish a membrane protein’s true functionally relevant oligomeric state. The tetrameric SaMscL structure may reflect a strained closed state due to improper oligomerization rather than an expanded intermediate state.

title: The oligomeric state of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance shows no variance in vivo.
objective: To investigate the behavior of the truncated mechanosensitive channel of large conductance (MscL) under varying membrane potentials.
methodology: Electrophysiological measurements using all-points histograms to analyze currents at different voltages.
results: G26C MscL treated with MTSET+ exhibits spontaneous opening and infrequent closing. At membrane potentials of 20 mV, 15 mV, 0 mV, and -20 mV, G26C MscL is predominantly in a fully open state. At membrane potentials above 25 mV and below -25 mV, full openings are observed but may be obscured by substates.
conclusions: The truncated MscL channel's open state is voltage-dependent, with full openings favored at specific membrane potentials.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between membrane potential and the open probability of the MscL channel.
insights: MTSET+ modification of G26C MscL induces spontaneous channel opening, suggesting a role for this residue in channel gating.

title: Three routes to modulate the pore size of the MscL channel/nanovalve
objective: To evaluate the role of the C-terminal region of S. aureus MscL in its oligomeric state within native membranes using an in vivo disulfide-trapping technique.
methodology: In vivo disulfide trapping was performed on full-length and C-terminal truncated constructs of S. aureus MscL with cysteine mutations.  Osmotic shock was applied in the presence of copper phenanthroline.  Samples were analyzed via SDS-PAGE and western blot. Electrophysiology (patch-clamp) was used to assess channel function in native membranes under varying redox conditions.
results: S. aureus MscL exists predominantly as a pentamer in vivo, regardless of C-terminal truncation length.  Disulfide trapping experiments confirmed this.  Electrophysiological data showed that full-length and truncated channels respond similarly to changes in redox potential, suggesting similar structure and function in native membranes.
conclusions: The C-terminal domain of S. aureus MscL plays a critical role in the oligomeric state of the protein only when solubilized in detergent. In vivo, the C-terminal helical bundle does not detectably affect pentameric assembly. Detergents can cause rearrangements of protein complexes, highlighting the importance of in vivo oligomeric state assessment.
relationships: The study compares the oligomeric state of MscL orthologs (E. coli, M. tuberculosis, and S. aureus). It relates the observed oligomeric states to previous crystal structures and detergent solubilization methods. It also relates channel activity to redox potential.
insights: Detergent solubilization can alter the oligomeric state of membrane proteins, potentially leading to inaccurate structural interpretations. Assessing the oligomeric state in vivo provides a more accurate representation of the protein's native structure and function. The C-terminal domain's influence on oligomerization is context-dependent, being significant in detergent but not in native membranes.

title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
objective: To investigate the function and stability of the cytoplasmic bundle (CB) of the MscL channel and to explore routes for modulating the channel's pore size and conductance for potential nanodevice applications.
methodology: The study used a combination of techniques including site-directed mutagenesis, electrophysiology (patch-clamp recordings), Western blotting, and calcein efflux assays on liposomes reconstituted with mutant MscL proteins.  Mutations, deletions, disulfide crosslinking, and heavy metal coordination were used to modify the TM2/CB linker region of the MscL channel.
results: The study demonstrated that the CB of MscL is stable even upon channel opening. Deletions within the TM2/CB linker led to decreased channel conductance. Disulfide crosslinking and heavy metal coordination within the TM2/CB linker also decreased channel conductance, with heavy metal coordination being reversible.  A triggered nanovalve with a smaller pore size was engineered by combining specific mutations.
conclusions: The stability of the CB allows for engineering the MscL nanovalve to have a smaller pore size and conductance by modifying the TM2/CB linker. This can be achieved through deletions, cross-linking, or heavy metal coordination, providing versatile routes for engineering MscL sensors for potential nanotech devices.
relationships: The study reveals the relationship between the structure of the MscL channel, particularly the TM2/CB linker region, and its function in terms of conductance and pore size. It demonstrates how modifications to this linker region can systematically control the channel's properties.
insights: The MscL channel can be engineered into a triggered nanovalve with adjustable pore size and conductance. Modifying the cytoplasmic linker offers control over the channel's properties, making it more versatile for nanodevices, such as drug-release systems and microchip devices. The ability to reversibly modulate conductance via heavy metal coordination provides a means for 'resetting' microchip devices.

title: The MscS and MscL families of mechanosensitive channels act as microbial emergency release valves
objective: To determine how the N-terminal helix (S1) and the region of TM2 near the cytoplasmic interface (TM2ci) interact in the MscL channel complex, and study how these interactions change as the channel opens.
methodology: Screened 143 double-cysteine mutants of E. coli MscL for their efficiency in disulfide bridging using an in vivo assay. Interesting candidates were further studied by patch clamp to observe channel activity under different redox potentials.
results: Interactions between S1 and TM2ci domains are efficient. The double mutant M12C/N103C showed high multimer formation and was locked in a closed conformation when disulfide bridging occurred. I3C/I96C stabilized in a sub-conductive state under oxidizing conditions. Mutants I3C/K97C, I3C/N100C and E6C/K101C also showed stabilization in a sub-conductive state upon oxidation.
conclusions: The study suggests a model consistent with a concerted motion of the S1 domain and TM2ci during the closed to open transition in E. coli MscL. S1 serves as a stabilizer for the twisting and turning of the pore-forming first transmembrane domain.
relationships: S1 interacts with TM2ci. The proximity of the S1 and TM2ci regions is obvious in the closed M. tuberculosis MscL structure. Upon gating the S1 helix slides along the cytoplasmic membrane, where it can interact with residues further up in the membrane portion of TM2 because of the tilting of this latter domain.
insights: MscL senses tension in the membrane, specifically changes within the lateral pressure profile. Both transmembrane domains tilt within the membrane, and TM1 rotates in a corkscrew fashion. The findings are consistent with the model of S1 maintaining its association with the cytoplasmic side of the membrane and thus serving as a stabilizer for the pore-forming TM1.

title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
objective: To compare and contrast the MscS and MscL mechanosensitive channel families, discuss their potential physiological roles, and review data underlying current models for their structure and function.
methodology: Review and comparison of existing literature, including electrophysiology, biochemistry, genetics, and structural biology data. Analysis of bacterial adaptation to osmotic stress and the role of MS channels in maintaining cell integrity.
results: MscS and MscL channels act as emergency release valves, jettisoning cytoplasmic solutes to prevent lysis during hypoosmotic shock. MscS homologues are diverse, while MscL is highly conserved. MscL appears to be a last-ditch effort for survival.
conclusions: Both MscS and MscL fulfill major roles in protecting cell integrity. The precise structural changes associated with the open and transition states of these channels remain fertile ground for technology development.
relationships: MscS and MscL are related families of mechanosensitive channels. MscL can be redundant with MscS channels in protecting against osmotic shock. Mutations affecting the hydrophobic seal of MscS alter channel tension sensitivity.
insights: MscL's conserved nature could be exploited for developing broad-spectrum antimicrobials. Bacterial mechanosensitive channels can be utilized for the delivery of peptides and other membrane-impermeable compounds.

title: Evidence for extensive horizontal gene transfer from the draft genome of a tardigrade
objective: To identify structural features underlying functional differences between MscL channels from different species by generating chimeras and determining their kinetics and threshold of activation.
methodology: Generated chimeras of E. coli and S. aureus MscL proteins, exchanged protein domains, subdomains, and individual amino acids. Used electrophysiological techniques (excised, inside-out patches from E. coli giant spheroplasts) to measure single-channel openings, kinetics, and mechanosensitivity. Site-directed mutagenesis was used to further investigate the role of specific residues.
results: The periplasmic region of the channel, particularly a residue at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface (I49 in E. coli, F47 in S. aureus), plays a major role in both the open dwell time and threshold of activation (mechanosensitivity). Specific mutations at this site altered channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity, correlating with the hydrophobicity of the substitutions.
conclusions: A single amino acid at the periplasmic end of TM1 acts as a 'clasp knife spring,' influencing the resistance and stability of channel opening and closing. The hydrophobicity and steric shape of this residue, along with the periplasmic loop, define channel mechanosensitivity and kinetics.
relationships: The periplasmic loop of Eco-MscL confers short channel openings and that of Sa-MscL defines long openings. In contrast, the relatively conserved TM1/periplasmic lipid interface (44–49) influenced channel kinetics in an opposite manner with that from Eco-MscL effecting long open dwell times, and that from Sa-MscL generating short open dwell times.
insights: Protein-lipid interactions at the TM1/periplasmic loop interface are crucial for MscL channel function. Hydrophobic residues at this site generally lead to longer open times and decreased mechanosensitivity, suggesting a balance between the energy barrier for channel opening and the stability of the open state.

title: Reply to Bemm et al. and Arakawa: Identifying foreign genes in independent Hypsibius dujardini genome assemblies
objective: To correct a data deposition footnote in a previously published paper regarding the Hypsibius dujardini genome assembly.
methodology: The authors updated the genome assembly used in their paper and made it available on GitHub.
results: An updated version of the genome assembly was made available.
conclusions: The correction ensures that researchers have access to the correct genome assembly used in the original study.
relationships: This correction relates to the original publication concerning extensive horizontal gene transfer in the tardigrade Hypsibius dujardini.
insights: Ensuring accurate data deposition is crucial for reproducibility and further research in genomics.

title: Tardigrades Use Intrinsically Disordered Proteins to Survive Desiccation.
objective: To assess the robustness of the finding of extensive horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in the Hypsibius dujardini genome, addressing concerns about contamination.
methodology: The study used three different approaches: (i) employing the horizontal gene transfer (HGT) index, (ii) identifying genes that align to prokaryotic but not eukaryotic sequences, and (iii) identifying a base level of HGT by defining 'class C' genes. The researchers compared their initial genome assembly with independently generated assemblies, filtering approaches, and genomic/RNAseq read coverage.
results: Analysis of independent H. dujardini assemblies revealed that 3.8–7.1% of genes appear foreign based on the HGT index. Examination of genes with prokaryotic but not eukaryotic alignments identified 164–384 genes. Class C genes ranged from 2.5% to 4.6%. Foreign genes were often found on scaffolds with tardigrade genes and showed robust coverage from multiple sequencing efforts.
conclusions: The data suggests that H. dujardini likely has an elevated level of foreign genes, most likely acquired by HGT rather than being artifacts of remaining contaminants. The level of HGT inferred is higher than in most animals tested.
relationships: The study addresses concerns raised by other research groups regarding the initial findings of extensive HGT. It acknowledges discrepancies and discusses the impact of different filtering methods and assembly versions.
insights: While different methods yield varying estimates, the presence of foreign genes in independent assemblies suggests genuine HGT. The study highlights the importance of considering multiple lines of evidence and the potential for new sequencing technologies to refine genome assemblies.

title: Desiccation of Hypsibius exemplaris
objective: To investigate the potential of tardigrade secretory-abundant heat soluble (SAHS) proteins from Hypsibius exemplaris and Ramazzottius varieornatus to protect diverse biological structures from desiccation-induced damage.
methodology: Recombinant expression of SAHS proteins, desiccation assays with liposomes and bacterial cells (E. coli and Rhizobium tropici), enzyme (lactate dehydrogenase) inactivation assays, circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy to analyze protein secondary structures, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging, and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to study structural changes upon desolvation. Structural bioinformatic analysis was also performed, comparing SAHS proteins with fatty acid-binding proteins.
results: SAHS proteins protect liposomes from fusion and enhance desiccation tolerance of E. coli and Rhizobium tropici upon extracellular application. SAHS proteins undergo structural changes under dehydration, shifting from a beta-sheet to an alpha-helical structure. Molecular dynamics simulations suggest a model where SAHS proteins may undergo a structural transition upon desiccation, destabilizing the beta-sheet structure. SAHS proteins were comparable to BSA in protecting enzymes from desiccation.
conclusions: SAHS proteins protect membrane-containing structures (liposomes and bacteria) against desiccation-induced disruption. The structural transition of SAHS proteins, from beta-sheet to alpha-helical, may contribute to their protective function. SAHS proteins have potential applications as stabilizing molecules for preservation of cells and agricultural microbes.
relationships: SAHS proteins share structural similarity to fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs), possessing a large internal cavity. The amino acid sequences within the cavity are variable, suggesting they may not bind a specific ligand but are filled with water or variable solutes.
insights: SAHS proteins may act as deformable packing material, preventing other biological structures from deforming or rupturing during desiccation. The diversity of SAHS proteins in tardigrades may be important for desiccation protection, allowing for a gradual protective process rather than a sudden phase transition.

title: The biology of tardigrade disordered proteins in extreme stress tolerance.
objective: To correct errors in the caption of Figure 7 in the original publication regarding the representation of CAHS, MAHS, SAHS, EtAHS alpha, EtAHS beta, and MRE11 proteins.
methodology: A correction notice was published outlining the errors in the original figure caption.
results: The corrected caption specifies the correct color representation for each protein: CAHS in red, MAHS in purple, SAHS in green, EtAHS alpha in yellow, EtAHS beta in pink, and MRE11 in blue.
conclusions: This correction ensures the accuracy of the figure caption and maintains the integrity of the published research on tardigrade protein families and their role in extremotolerance.
relationships: The correction clarifies the relationship between specific protein families (CAHS, MAHS, SAHS, EtAHS alpha, EtAHS beta, MRE11) and their visual representation in Figure 7 of the original study.
insights: The correction highlights the importance of accurate data representation in scientific publications and the commitment to maintaining the version of record.

title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
objective: To explore the functionality of CAHS proteins by analyzing their role in aggregation and tolerance to hyperosmotic stress in mammalian cells, and to investigate the subcellular localization of anhydrobiosis-related proteins in R. varieornatus induced by hyperosmotic stress.
methodology: Live cell imaging was used to examine the subcellular localization of CAHS and LEA proteins in response to hyperosmotic stress. HeLa cells were transfected with plasmids expressing mEGFP-fused CAHS1, CAHS3, CAHS8, CAHS12, LEAM, and MAHS proteins.  Cells were subjected to hyperosmotic stress using sorbitol or NaCl in a microfluidic chamber, and observed using a spinning disk confocal microscope. Cell viability and cytotoxicity assays (WST-1 and LDH) were performed to assess osmotic stress resistance. AlphaFold2 was used to predict the structure of CAHS proteins.
results: Expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 tended to enhance the resilience to hyperosmotic conditions. CAHS proteins formed different aggregation patterns under hyperosmotic conditions: CAHS1 formed granules and filamentous structures, CAHS3 showed fibrous structures, CAHS8 accumulated at the nuclear membrane, and CAHS12 underwent decomposition in the nucleus. LEAM and MAHS localized to mitochondria, and their localization did not substantially change under hyperosmotic stress. Overexpression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 conferred tolerance to hyperosmotic stress in HeLa cells.
conclusions: CAHS proteins demonstrate reversible aggregation upon hyperosmotic stress in HeLa cells, exhibiting granular and filamentous structures. Expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 conferred resistance to sorbitol-induced hyperosmotic stress. These results suggest a potential use of CAHS proteins as cryoprotectants and provide insights into the mechanism of desiccation tolerance in R. varieornatus.
relationships: CAHS proteins share some similarities with LEA proteins. LEAM and MAHS proteins improve the hyperosmotic tolerance of human cells, possibly by acting as mitochondrial protectants.
insights: The varying modes of aggregation and localization patterns of different CAHS paralogs upon hyperosmotic stress suggest that these paralogs serve differentiated functions rather than for mere redundancy. The rapid aggregation and disassembly processes of CAHS proteins mirror the relatively fast induction and recovery of tardigrade anhydrobiosis.

title: Partial weight suspension: A novel murine model for investigating adaptation to reduced musculoskeletal loading.
objective: To develop a new rodent model of partial weight suspension (PWS) and to study musculoskeletal adaptation to Mars gravity levels (38% Earth gravity). The hypothesis was that partial weight bearing would replicate key features of full unloading adaptation, including reduced bone formation rate, muscle mass, bone mass, and bone strength.
methodology: A novel partial weight suspension (PWS) system was developed for mice, allowing for tunable weight bearing between 10% and 80%. Ten-week-old female BALB/cByJ mice were subjected to Mars-analog suspension (38% weight bearing) for 21 days and compared with age-matched controls (100% weight bearing). Ground reaction forces (GRF) were measured using a force plate. Bone microarchitecture was assessed using microcomputed tomography (μCT). Biomechanical properties were evaluated using three-point bending. Histomorphometry was performed on tibial sections.
results: The PWS system successfully maintained mice in partial weight-bearing conditions with minimal stress. Mars-analog loading resulted in significantly lower muscle mass (-23% gastrocnemius), reduced trabecular bone volume (-24% at the distal femur), decreased cortical thickness (-11% at the femoral midshaft), and impaired biomechanical properties (-27% ultimate moment). Bone formation indexes were decreased, while resorption parameters remained largely unchanged.
conclusions: The novel PWS model is a valuable tool for studying musculoskeletal adaptation to reduced loading environments. Three weeks of Mars-analog loading led to significant musculoskeletal deterioration in mice, including decreased muscle mass and bone density. This model can be used to investigate countermeasures against bone loss in spaceflight, bed rest, and other catabolic states.
relationships: Partial weight bearing leads to musculoskeletal deterioration, mimicking effects of spaceflight and disuse osteoporosis. The study highlights the relationship between mechanical loading and skeletal maintenance. The model allows for exploration of the relationship between gravitational loading and adaptive processes in bone and muscle mass.
insights: The study provides insights into the musculoskeletal effects of chronic partial weight bearing, relevant to both aerospace physiology and clinical conditions. The PWS system allows for controlled investigation of the effects of varying degrees of weight bearing on bone and muscle. The findings suggest that even partial weight bearing can have significant effects on musculoskeletal health.

title: Partial reductions in mechanical loading yield proportional changes in bone density, bone architecture, and muscle mass
objective: To investigate the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) during desiccation in tardigrades and to assess the involvement of bioprotectants in anhydrobiotic survival.
methodology: The study used the eutardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis as a model organism. ROS production was analyzed in coelomocytes using a fluorescent probe. RNA interference (RNAi) was used to disrupt the function of genes encoding antioxidant enzymes (glutathione peroxidase, glutathione reductase, glutathione transferase, catalase, and superoxide dismutase), aquaporins (aquaporins 3 and 10), and trehalose-6-phosphate synthase. Motility of tardigrades was evaluated after desiccation and rehydration.
results: Desiccation induces a significant increase in ROS production in tardigrade storage cells. Targeting the glutathione peroxidase gene compromised survival during drying and rehydration. Targeting genes encoding glutathione reductase and catalase indicated that these molecules play roles during rehydration. Aquaporins 3 and 10 are involved during rehydration. Trehalose-6-phosphate synthase targeting did not significantly affect animal motility.
conclusions: Anhydrobiosis causes a significant increase in ROS production, leading to oxidative stress in tardigrades. Desiccation tolerance depends on the synergistic action of different molecules. Glutathione peroxidase plays a crucial role in desiccation tolerance. Aquaporins are involved in rehydration. Trehalose is not the only molecule involved in desiccation tolerance.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between oxidative stress, antioxidant defenses, and desiccation tolerance in tardigrades. It also shows the interplay between different bioprotectants in ensuring survival during anhydrobiosis.
insights: The findings suggest that tardigrades employ a complex strategy involving multiple molecules to combat the stresses of desiccation. The study provides insights into the specific roles of antioxidant enzymes and aquaporins in the anhydrobiotic process.

title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
objective: To explore musculoskeletal adaptation along the continuum of loading between disuse and normal weight bearing using the partial weight suspension (PWS) model. The primary question was whether variable PWB differentially influences muscle atrophy and bone loss, hypothesizing a linear relationship between weight bearing and bone/muscle loss.
methodology: Skeletally mature female mice were subjected to partial weight bearing (PWB) at 20%, 40%, or 70% of body weight, or hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 21 days. Control groups included fully loaded mice with and without a harness. Bone and muscle adaptation were assessed using DXA, μCT, mechanical testing, and muscle mass measurements. Gait kinematics were measured at different weight-bearing levels. Fecal corticosterone metabolites (FCM) were measured to assess adrenocortical activity.
results: Bone and muscle changes were generally proportional to the degree of unloading in PWB groups. Total body and hindlimb bone mineral density, calf muscle mass, trabecular bone volume of the distal femur, and cortical area of the femur midshaft were linearly related to the degree of unloading. Even a load reduction to 70% of normal weight bearing was associated with significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy. HLU resulted in greater muscle atrophy than PWB at 20%, but similar or slightly better bone outcomes.
conclusions: The PWS model is effective in applying controllable, reduced, long-term loading that produces predictable adaptive changes in muscle and bone. Bone and muscle loss are linearly related to the degree of unloading. Even a load reduction to 70% of normal weight bearing is associated with significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy. Hindlimb unloading is not equivalent to 0% PWB, and the PWB and HLU models are functionally different.
relationships: A strong correlation (r = 0.75) was found between gastrocnemius mass and percent change in hindlimb BMD across all groups. Within the PWB groups, muscle and bone outcomes showed a strong dependence on the degree of PWB, with most variables decreasing monotonically with decreasing weight bearing.
insights: The study suggests that the physiological window of normal strain stimulus (lazy zone) for bone adaptation may be narrower than previously proposed. Extended minor reductions in physical activity may cause proportionate degrees of bone loss. The PWS model offers advantages in preserving normal gait kinematics and strain distribution, making it a valuable tool for studying regional differences in bone's sensitivity to mechanical signals.

title: Spaceflight Activates Lipotoxic Pathways in Mouse Liver
objective: To assess the potential of electrical impedance myography (EIM) as a marker of muscle fiber atrophy and bone deterioration by evaluating the effects of spaceflight or hind limb unloading (HLU) on mouse gastrocnemius muscle.
methodology: Two experiments were conducted: (1) mice flown on the space shuttle for 13 days versus earthbound controls, and (2) mice undergoing HLU for 13 days versus controls. EIM measurements were performed on ex vivo gastrocnemius muscle. Quantitative microscopy and areal bone mineral density (aBMD) measurements of the hind limb were also conducted.
results: Reductions in the multifrequency phase-slope parameter were observed in both spaceflight and HLU groups compared to controls. This parameter correlated with muscle fiber size in the spaceflight group and hind limb aBMD in both groups. Mice exposed to spaceflight had a smaller average muscle fiber cross-sectional area compared to controls. HLU mice had lower muscle mass compared to controls.
conclusions: EIM may serve as a useful tool for assessing muscle disuse secondary to immobilization or microgravity. Alterations in electrical impedance of mouse muscle occur after exposure to spaceflight and HLU, correlating with muscle fiber size and hind limb aBMD.
relationships: EIM phase-slope parameter correlates positively with muscle mass in HLU study. EIM phase-slope parameter correlates with muscle fiber size across the spaceflight and ground control animals. Hind limb aBMD correlates with the phase-slope parameter in both studies.
insights: Spaceflight and HLU induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle. EIM alterations likely reflect changes to the composition and structure of muscle tissue, including reductions in muscle fiber size. EIM changes correlate with meaningful measures, including muscle fiber size and hind limb aBMD.

title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
objective: To analyze liver datasets from mice flown aboard the International Space Station (ISS) to determine the effects of space stressors on lipid metabolism.
methodology: Analysis of three liver datasets from two mouse strains (C57BL/6 & BALB/c) flown on the ISS. Oil Red O staining, transcriptomic analysis by RNA-sequencing, and quantitative proteomic analysis were performed on liver tissues.
results: Abnormal lipid accumulation was observed in space-flown mice. Transcriptomic analysis revealed affected pathways related to increased lipid metabolism. Proteomic analysis showed changes in lipid-related proteins. Glucagon (GCG) and Insulin (INS) were identified as key upstream regulators.
conclusions: Activation of lipotoxic pathways results from space stressors alone, occurring across various genetic backgrounds. Prolonged changes in these pathways may lead to liver disease.
relationships: Spaceflight induces changes in lipid metabolism in the liver, potentially leading to non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Circadian clock pathways are also upregulated, impacting lipid function.
insights: Spaceflight-induced liver damage warrants further investigation at the human level. The study identifies potential risks to astronauts related to liver health during long-term space travel.

title: Treatment With a Soluble Bone Morphogenetic Protein Type 1A Receptor (BMPR1A) Fusion Protein Increases Bone Mass and Bone Formation in Mice Subjected to Hindlimb Unloading
objective: To test the effects of a soluble murine BMPR1A-fusion protein (mBMPR1A-mFc) on disuse-induced bone loss caused by hindlimb unloading (HLU) in mice.
methodology: Adult female C57BL/6J mice were subjected to 21 days of hindlimb unloading (HLU) or cage control (CON). Mice were assigned to four groups: CON-VEH, CON-mBMPR1A-mFc, HLU-VEH, and HLU-mBMPR1A-mFc. mBMPR1A-mFc was administered subcutaneously twice per week. Bone mineral density (BMD) was measured using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (pDXA). Bone microarchitecture was assessed using microcomputed tomography (mCT). Bone strength was evaluated using three-point bending tests. Histomorphometry was performed to assess bone formation and resorption.
results: HLU led to a decline in leg BMD, whereas mBMPR1A-mFc treatment prevented this decline. mBMPR1A-mFc treatment led to greater trabecular bone volume, trabecular thickness, and cortical thickness in both HLU and CON groups. HLU-mBMPR1A-mFc mice had greater failure load compared to HLU-VEH. mBMPR1A-mFc treatment led to greater mineralizing surface and mineral apposition rate, resulting in higher bone formation rate. mBMPR1A-mFc-treated mice had similar osteoblast surface but lower osteoclast surface than VEH-treated animals.
conclusions: Treatment with the soluble BMPR1A fusion protein may be useful for maintenance of skeletal integrity in the setting of disuse-induced bone loss by increasing bone formation and reducing bone resorption.
relationships: mBMPR1A-mFc binds to BMP2 and BMP4, preventing downstream signaling. It inhibits dickkopf-1 (Dkk1) expression in osteoblasts to activate canonical Wnt signaling to promote bone formation. It also reduces receptor activator of NF-kB ligand (RANKL) expression in osteoblasts, resulting in decreased bone resorption.
insights: Inhibiting BMP2/4 signaling via treatment with the soluble BMPR1A fusion protein led to increased bone mass and improved bone microarchitecture by increased bone formation rate and decreased osteoclast surface. This suggests that the anabolic effect of mBMPR1A-mFC treatment was retained despite continuous HLU.

title: Proteomic and phosphoproteomic characterization of cardiovascular tissues after long term exposure to simulated space radiation
objective: To identify novel mechanosensitive pathways that respond to mechanical unloading in cortical bone of mice using RNA sequencing (RNAseq) and NanoString technologies.
methodology: Female mice underwent hindlimb unloading (HLU) or normal weightbearing for 7 days. RNA was extracted from femoral cortical bone and analyzed using RNAseq and NanoString to identify differentially expressed genes. Gene set enrichment analysis was performed to identify relevant biological processes.
results: RNAseq identified several differentially expressed genes after HLU, including genes related to Wnt signaling and cell metabolism. NanoString confirmed alterations in transcripts associated with Wnt signaling, cell metabolism, and extracellular matrix proteases. Specifically, Scd1, Pfkfb3, Fzd4, Mmp3, Sfrp2, Sfrp4, Mmp13, Bmp4, Timp1, Npy and Spp1 were upregulated in cortical bone isolated from hindlimb unloaded mouse. No downregulated genes were detected.
conclusions: Mechanical unloading of cortical bone alters the expression of genes involved in cell metabolism, mitochondrial function, and Wnt signaling. These findings suggest novel mechanosensitive pathways that may be responsible for disuse-induced bone loss.
relationships: Hindlimb unloading leads to altered gene expression in cortical bone, affecting pathways like Wnt signaling and cell metabolism. These changes may contribute to bone loss observed in conditions of reduced mechanical loading.
insights: The study identifies potential therapeutic targets for preventing bone loss associated with microgravity, spinal cord injury, or extended bed rest by elucidating mechanosensitive pathways in bone.

title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
objective: To investigate the long-term effects of simulated space radiation on cardiovascular tissues by performing a quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics analysis of heart tissue and plasma from mice exposed to Galactic Cosmic Ray (GCR5-ion).
methodology: Quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics analysis of heart tissue (proteome and phosphoproteome) and plasma (proteome only) from mice exposed to GCR5-ion. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was used to assess the perturbation of canonical pathways. Western blot analysis and immunofluorescence staining were performed to validate protein expression patterns and inflammation markers.
results: Differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) were identified in heart and plasma. In the heart proteome, pathways related to inflammation were upregulated, while pathways related to cell cycle/transcription and mitochondrial functions were downregulated. In the plasma proteome, inflammatory processes were downregulated. Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) were elevated in the myocardium of GCR5-ion irradiated mice.
conclusions: Exposure to simulated space radiation results in long-lasting changes in the proteome, potentially leading to acute and chronic health issues such as cardiac dysfunction. Sustained inflammation and NET formation are major pathways driving the biological responses to space radiation in the heart.
relationships: Single exposure to GCR5-ion leads to long-lasting proteomic changes that can potentiate acute and chronic health issues for astronauts, such as late cardiac dysfunction. Inflammation and NETs are related to increased heart stiffness and decreased systolic heart function.
insights: Space radiation induces long-term cardiovascular changes, including inflammation and NET formation, which may contribute to cardiac dysfunction. These findings highlight the need for further research to understand the mechanisms behind these changes and develop countermeasures to protect astronauts' cardiovascular health during long-term space missions.

title: Morphology of the Utricular Otolith Organ in the Toadfish, Opsanus tau
objective: To investigate the adaptive changes in the vestibular system of land snails (Helix lucorum) exposed to 30 days of near weightlessness during spaceflight, and their readaptation upon return to Earth.
methodology: The study involved exposing land snails to 30 days of microgravity aboard the Bion-M1 satellite. Post-flight snails were compared to four control groups: a naive group, a starvation group, a dark control group, and a gravity overloading group. Behavioral studies (gravitaxis, tentacle withdrawal), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of statocysts, transcriptome analysis of statocysts (RNA sequencing), and electrophysiological studies of the statocyst reflex arc were conducted.
results: Post-flight snails exhibited a shorter duration of the T0 phase of gravitaxis, and retracted their tentacles to a lesser degree compared to control groups. Transcriptome analysis revealed differential expression of genes related to neuropeptides, neurotransmitter receptors, and cell signaling. Electrophysiological studies showed an increased statocyst response to vestibular stimulation in post-flight snails. The statocyst response of early post-flight snails was significantly larger than that of late post-flight and overload snails.
conclusions: The vestibular system of land snails undergoes adaptive changes in response to spaceflight, including alterations in behavior, gene expression, and neural activity. The increased sensitivity of statoreceptors after spaceflight is likely due to neural plasticity within the statocyst itself or in central circuits. Readaptation to normal gravity occurs within approximately 20 hours after landing.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between gravity, the vestibular system, and adaptive changes in behavior and neural function. It also explores the connection between statocyst sensory neurons and command neurons for defensive withdrawal behavior.
insights: The findings suggest that the vestibular system is highly adaptable to changes in gravity, and that neural plasticity plays a key role in this adaptation. The study also provides insights into the mechanisms underlying space motion sickness and the readaptation process following spaceflight. The unpaired sensory neuron at the anterior pole of the statocyst drives the increase in response to head down tilt.

title: Influence of Magnitude and Duration of Altered Gravity and Readaptation to 1g on the Structure and Function of the Utricle in Toadfish, Opsanus tau.
objective: To describe the structure of the utricle in the adult oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau, as a model vertebrate species, and to provide a morphological basis for concurrent and subsequent studies of the physiological responses of the otolith organ under normal and novel gravitational conditions.
methodology: Light, scanning, and transmission electron microscopy techniques were applied to visualize the sensory epithelium, its neural innervation, and its synaptic organization. Afferent nerve fibers were visualized following labeling with biocytin, and light microscope images were used to make three-dimensional (3-D) reconstructions of individual labeled afferents to identify dendritic morphology with respect to epithelial location. Digital mosaics and serial sections were analyzed using specialized software for reconstruction and analysis of afferent morphology and synaptic organization.
results: The utricle in toadfish consists of a utricular duct continuing anteriorly and widening to become the utricular recess. The utricular macula, containing hair cells, lies largely in a two-dimensional plane except in the anterior curvature and the lacinium. The macula is organized into three zones: striola, medial extra-striola, and lateral extra-striola, each with different hair cell densities and afferent innervation patterns. Utricular afferents supplying the medial extra-striolar macula had the greatest complexity of their dendritic arborizations. Synaptic bodies were observed within hair cells at the hair cell-afferent synapse.
conclusions: The organization of the toadfish utricle is similar in the broad sense to other species. Hair cell polarization is highly organized, with deviations in the lacinium. Hair cell density varies in three distinct zones. The complexity of dendritic trees differs among vestibular nerve afferents supplying the three regions of the macula. A tight coupling between hair cells and afferents is seen, with afferents targeting subsets of hair cells and the contacted hair cell distributing all or nearly all of its synaptic bodies to one afferent.
relationships: The study reveals relationships between hair cell density, afferent innervation patterns, and synaptic organization within different regions of the utricular macula. It also highlights the connection between the structural organization of the utricle and its potential functional responses to gravitational changes.
insights: The detailed morphological description of the toadfish utricle provides a foundation for understanding the impact of altered gravity on the neurovestibular system. The findings suggest that synaptic reorganization and changes in afferent sensitivity may be key adaptive mechanisms in response to altered gravitational environments. The study also reveals a highly structured organization with specific targeting of afferent processes by hair cells.

title: Organization of the ER-Golgi interface for membrane traffic control.
objective: To characterize the physiology of utricular afferents to applied accelerations in the oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau, under varying gravity conditions and to correlate afferent sensitivity with hair cell-afferent complexes.
methodology: Extracellular recordings were made from utricular afferents in toadfish. Fish were exposed to normal gravity (1 g), hypergravity (HG) via centrifugation (2.24 g or 1.12 g) for varying durations (1-32 days), and recovery periods in 1 g after HG exposure. Afferent responses to translational and tilt stimuli were measured using a custom-built acceleration testing device. Serial electron microscopy was used to reconstruct hair cells in 3D and quantify synaptic body counts.
results: Utricular afferents exhibited an initial increase in sensitivity (Smax) after 3-4 days of HG exposure, followed by a decrease after 16-32 days. The Smin/Smax ratio remained consistent across experimental conditions. Horizontal canal afferent responses were unaffected by HG exposure. Efferent Vestibular System (EVS) stimulation generally increased afferent firing rate and reduced response sensitivity. Synaptic body counts in hair cells did not correlate with afferent sensitivity changes.
conclusions: Utricular afferents undergo adaptive changes in response to altered gravity, characterized by an initial hypersensitivity followed by hyposensitivity. These changes are not directly correlated with synaptic body counts. The EVS may play a role in modulating afferent activity, but its specific contribution to adaptation remains unclear. The readaptation from HG exposure might mimic the process of adaptation to microgravity.
relationships: Transfer from 1 g to HG imparts profound effects on gravitational sensitivity of utricular afferents and the accompanying transfer from the HG back to the 1 g resembles in part (as an analog) the transfer from 1 g to the micrograms.
insights: The utricle undergoes continuous plasticity based on the magnitude of the prevailing gravity. The organism's response to transitions in gravity is not simply a step increase or decrease, but varies with time of exposure to the new level of force.

title: IRE1: ER stress sensor and cell fate executor.
objective: To discuss how the ER–Golgi interface and COPII-mediated trafficking varies in different species, focusing on plant and mammalian systems as examples of adaptation to meet differentiated eukaryotic cell needs. The ultimate goal is to understand the regulatory mechanisms that control protein and lipid trafficking in the early secretory pathway.
methodology: The review compares the ER–Golgi interface across different systems, particularly mammalian and plant cells, highlighting fundamental elements and distinct organization. It examines models for COPII carrier-mediated trafficking from the ER in mammalian cells (separated ER and Golgi with an intermediate compartment) versus plant cells (closely associated ER and Golgi with high mobility).
results: The organization of the ER–Golgi interface varies greatly across species. Plants and some yeast have a compact ER and Golgi organization, while animal cells have a pleomorphic intermediate compartment. The distribution of COPII budding sites, transport vesicles, and dependence on cytoskeletal components also vary. The ER–Golgi interface can adapt to accommodate variations in COPII carrier size and number based on cargo dimensions and quantity.
conclusions: A conserved core machinery transports biosynthetic cargo forward in the early secretory pathway, balanced with retrieval routes that maintain the ER and Golgi compartments. Diversity in eukaryotic cell types and functions generates variety in the organization of the ER–Golgi interface. Each trafficking step provides multiple opportunities for regulation that could influence vesicle and organelle size and shape. The influence of cargo and cellular architecture are key drivers of interface organization.
relationships: COPI and COPII are required for bidirectional membrane trafficking between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi. COPII operates in the anterograde pathway from the ER, and COPI functions in the retrograde route from the Golgi. The integrity of the anterograde traffic route depends tightly on the homeostasis of the retrograde pathway.
insights: The ER–Golgi interface is a dynamic and adaptable system, with variations in organization reflecting cellular specialization and the types of cargo being transported. Understanding the molecular basis for observed membrane structures and dynamics is tightly coupled with function. Future studies should integrate cellular regulatory networks with the core machinery to understand how the ER–Golgi interface is maintained under changing conditions.

title: Inter-regulation of the unfolded protein response and auxin signaling.
objective: To provide an updated scenario of the IRE1 signaling model, discuss emerging IRE1 sensing mechanisms, compare IRE1 features among species (plants and mammals), and outline future directions in UPR research.
methodology: Review of existing literature and research on IRE1-dependent UPR, focusing on recent discoveries and advancements in the field. Comparative analysis of IRE1 signaling pathways in different species.
results: IRE1 is identified as a master regulator in cell fate determination under ER stress. IRE1 signaling is persistent during ER stress and can trigger diverse signaling pathways. IRE1 monitors cellular homeostasis beyond protein-folding status in the ER. Convergent and divergent features of IRE1 exist between plants and mammals.
conclusions: IRE1 activities are coordinated at a systemic level to cope with dynamic secretion activity. Plant IRE1 mutants enable in vivo analyses to reveal its roles in organ growth, pathogen defense, and abiotic stress responses. The UPR network can be built in intact organisms using plants as a model system.
relationships: IRE1 interacts with various proteins (UPRosome components) that are also involved in apoptosis, indicating a close relationship between IRE1 activity and apoptosis activation. IRE1's activity is also linked to circadian rhythms and lipid homeostasis.
insights: IRE1 is not simply a positive regulator of cell survival but an administrator/executor of cell fate determination under ER stress. IRE1 monitors cellular homeostasis beyond the protein-folding status in the ER. The type of misfolded protein might be critical for determination of UPR signaling outputs.

title: Endoplasmic reticulum-shape and function in stress translation
objective: To identify the regulatory connection between the unfolded protein response (UPR) and auxin signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana, exploring how the UPR regulates auxin signaling to coordinate secretory activities and physiological responses.
methodology: Biochemical, molecular biology, and genetic analyses, including RT-qPCR, immunoblotting, confocal microscopy, root inhibition assays, and free IAA analysis, were performed on wild-type and mutant Arabidopsis seedlings under ER stress induced by tunicamycin (Tm) or dithiothreitol (DTT).
results: ER stress down-regulates auxin sensors and transporters. An Arabidopsis mutant of the ER stress sensor IRE1 exhibits defects in the auxin response and levels. ER-localized auxin transporters, including PIN5, are required for UPR activation. The ire1 pin5 triple mutant enhances defects of UPR activation and auxin homeostasis in ire1 or pin5.
conclusions: The plant UPR has evolved a hormone-dependent strategy for coordinating ER function with physiological processes. IRE1 has a specific role in hormonal signaling. ER-based auxin homeostasis is important for UPR activation, suggesting that plants have evolved an organism-specific strategy to maintain balance between stress adaption and growth regulation.
relationships: The UPR regulates auxin signaling, and ER-based auxin homeostasis influences UPR activation. IRE1 and PIN5 functionally interact in the UPR and auxin response. TIR1/AFBs play a negative role in UPR target gene induction.
insights: ER-localized auxin transporters play a crucial role in UPR activation, suggesting a previously uncharacterized cellular function for auxin as a signaling molecule that connects subcellular compartments and maintains cellular homeostasis in plants. The study highlights the importance of ER auxin biology in plant physiology.

title: Galactose-depleted xycoglucan is dysfunctional and leads to dwarfism in Arabidopsis
objective: To summarize current knowledge on endoplasmic reticulum (ER) dynamics and architecture, its association with other organelles, and its role in stress translation and adaptation in plants.
methodology: Review of existing literature and research on the endoplasmic reticulum in plants, focusing on its structure, function, and interactions with other cellular components.
results: The ER plays a versatile role in the cell, acting as a gateway to the secretory pathway and adapting to abiotic and biotic stress. Its dynamics are influenced by myosin motor proteins, and it interacts with other organelles like Golgi bodies and vacuoles. The ER is also crucial for protein synthesis and quality control, initiating adaptive responses to environmental stress.
conclusions: The ER functions as an intracellular stress sensory organelle, initiating and regulating adaptive responses to environmental stress. Understanding the molecular basis of these processes is relevant for sustainable crop production.
relationships: The ER interacts with the actin cytoskeleton, Golgi bodies, peroxisomes, mitochondria, and vacuoles. It communicates with the nucleus to maintain cellular homeostasis under stress conditions. The ER also plays a role in plant immunity and can be targeted by viruses.
insights: The ER's ability to sense stress and initiate adaptive responses is crucial for plant survival. ER stress can lead to unfolded protein response (UPR) and ER-associated degradation (ERAD) to eliminate misfolded proteins. When stress is excessive, programmed cell death (PCD) may ensue.

title: Unfolded protein response in plants: one master, many questions.
objective: To investigate the effects of galactose-depleted xyloglucan on plant growth and development in Arabidopsis thaliana, and to identify structural features responsible for xyloglucan dysfunction.
methodology: Genetic analysis of Arabidopsis mutants (mur3, xxt1, xxt2, xxt5, xlt2) including creating double and triple mutants. Biochemical characterization of xyloglucan structure using 1H-NMR spectroscopy, MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry, and HPAEC-PAD. Immunolocalization and glycome profiling to analyze cell wall composition and polysaccharide secretion. Confocal microscopy to observe endomembrane organization. Plant growth analysis at different temperatures.
results: Galactose-depleted xyloglucan in mur3 mutants leads to dwarfism, curled leaves, and intracellular polysaccharide aggregates. Eliminating xyloglucan or increasing galactosylation restores normal growth. The severity of the phenotype correlates with the extent of xyloglucan galactosylation. Overexpression of XLT2 or knockout of XXT2/XXT5 suppresses the dwarf phenotype. Temperature affects the growth of mur3 plants and the catalytic activity of the mutated MUR3 protein.
conclusions: Dysfunctional xyloglucan, specifically xyloglucan deficient in galactose, disrupts plant growth and development. The presence of this dysfunctional xyloglucan has a greater impact than the absence of xyloglucan altogether. Altering xyloglucan side chain structure disturbs diverse cellular and physiological processes.
relationships: The study reveals relationships between xyloglucan structure, cell wall assembly, endomembrane organization, and plant growth. It highlights the importance of galactosylation in xyloglucan function and its impact on various cellular processes.
insights: The findings suggest that the extent of xyloglucan galactosylation is a major factor determining plant growth and development. Dysfunctional xyloglucan can lead to aggregation and aberrant interactions with other wall polymers, disrupting cell wall remodeling and polysaccharide secretion. The mur3 mutants provide a valuable model for understanding the complex interplay between cell wall biosynthesis, structure, and plant physiology.

title: Vesicles versus Tubes: Is Endoplasmic Reticulum-Golgi Transport in Plants Fundamentally Different from Other Eukaryotes?
objective: To discuss recent discoveries in plant UPR, highlighting conserved and unique features compared to yeast and metazoans, and to address open questions regarding plant ER stress management.
methodology: Review and synthesis of existing literature on UPR in plants, yeast, and metazoans, focusing on the IRE1 signaling pathway and bZIP transcription factors.
results: Plant UPR shares conserved features with other eukaryotes, such as IRE1-mediated splicing of bZIP transcription factors. However, plants exhibit unique features, including plant-specific membrane-tethered transcription factors and diversification of IRE1 signaling through RIDD and miRNA cleavage. Multiple IRE1 isoforms and bZIPs contribute to stress defense, with functional specialization among them.
conclusions: Significant progress has been made in understanding the plant UPR, but fundamental questions remain. Further research into the temporal and spatial complexity of UPR regulation will support biotechnological applications to improve plant productivity and stress resistance.
relationships: The UPR intersects with hormone-regulated growth, defense, and resistance to hostile environments. Key components include IRE1, bZIP transcription factors (bZIP60, bZIP28, bZIP17), AGB1 (beta subunit of heterotrimeric G-protein complex), and NAC transcription factors.  AtBiP constrains AtbZIP28 to the ER.
insights: Plant UPR relies on both conserved and unique strategies for ER stress defense. Diversification of IRE1 signaling and the involvement of multiple bZIP transcription factors allow for fine-tuning of the UPR in response to specific stress conditions. ER network integrity and lipid composition affect IRE1 signaling.

title: Pectin methylesterification impacts the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth.
objective: To examine whether endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-Golgi transport in plants is fundamentally different from other eukaryotes, focusing on the controversy of vesicle versus tubular transport mechanisms.
methodology: Review and analysis of existing literature, including electron microscopy studies, live-cell imaging, and super-resolution microscopy, with contributions from multiple plant cell biologists presenting divergent opinions.
results: The review highlights conflicting evidence regarding the presence and role of COPII vesicles in ER-Golgi transport in plants. Some evidence supports tubular connections, while other data suggests vesicles are involved. Super-resolution microscopy reveals dynamic interactions between ER exit sites (ERESs) and Golgi, suggesting a 'hug-and-kiss' mechanism for cargo transfer.
conclusions: No consensus was reached regarding the primary mechanism of ER-Golgi transport in plants. The authors suggest that future research should combine ultra-rapid freezing techniques with selective membrane staining and high-resolution three-dimensional scanning electron microscopy to resolve the controversy.
relationships: Focuses on the relationship between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi apparatus in plant cells, examining the mechanisms of protein and membrane transport between these two organelles.
insights: The plant ER/Golgi interface is uniquely organized such that ERESs move together with associated Golgi stacks. The secretory-units model suggests ERESs facilitate ER export to the Golgi at a Golgi-facing surface that is relatively static. The hug-and-kiss mechanism ensures efficient and safe transfer of cargo.

title: Reduced Chloroplast Coverage genes from Arabidopsis thaliana help to establish the size of the chloroplast compartment
objective: To investigate how changes in cell-wall plasticity, achieved by manipulating pectin methyltransferases (CGR2 and CGR3), affect carbon assimilation, leaf respiration, and overall plant growth through their effects on leaf area growth and mesophyll structure. Also, to understand the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth.
methodology: Analysis of Arabidopsis plants with altered levels of pectin methylesterification via manipulation of CGR2 and CGR3 genes. Measurements of leaf and plant growth, gas exchange, cell wall composition, and anatomical studies of leaf mesophyll. Growth modeling was used to estimate carbon partitioning.
results: Increased pectin methylesterification (CGR2OX) resulted in larger leaves and enhanced plant growth. Reduced methylesterification (cgr2/3) resulted in smaller leaves with densely packed mesophyll cells, limiting CO2 diffusion. Plant growth was enhanced in CGR2OX but decreased in cgr2/3. Variations in plant growth were due to differences in carbon partitioning, not photosynthetic rate per unit leaf area. CGR2OX partitioned more carbon to leaf area growth, while cgr2/3 partitioned more to leaf mass per unit area (LMA).
conclusions: Pectin methylesterification, mediated by CGR2 and CGR3, affects mesophyll architecture, carbon accumulation, carbon partitioning, leaf and plant growth, and the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth. Cell wall plasticity is a key factor influencing photosynthetic processes in land plants.
relationships: Pectin methylesterification influences carbon partitioning between leaf area growth and LMA, thereby regulating the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth. Changes in cell wall plasticity due to changes in pectin composition influence carbon partitioning between leaf area growth and LMA.
insights: The degree of pectin methylesterification affects the size and density of mesophyll cells, which in turn influences CO2 diffusion and photosynthetic efficiency. Carbon partitioning to leaf area growth, rather than area-based photosynthesis, is a primary determinant of overall plant growth. Cell wall plasticity plays a crucial role in modulating photosynthetic processes.

title: Maintaining the factory: The roles of the unfolded protein response in cellular homeostasis in plants.
objective: To investigate the mechanisms that determine the proportion of cellular volume devoted to chloroplasts in Arabidopsis thaliana and to identify genes involved in this process.
methodology: A screen for plastid-to-nucleus signaling mutants was performed. Mutant alleles were cloned and characterized through sequencing, T-DNA insertion analysis, immunoblotting, and chlorophyll measurements. Double, triple, and quadruple mutants were created to assess gene interactions. Chloroplast ultrastructure was examined using microscopy, and live-cell imaging was used to analyze chloroplast distribution. The REC1 protein's subcellular localization was determined using YFP fusion and herbicide treatments.
results: REC1, REC2, and REC3 genes were identified as homologs of FRIENDLY, found only in photosynthetic organisms. REC1 localizes to the cytosol and nucleus. Mutants exhibited reduced chloroplast coverage, chlorophyll deficiencies, and altered chloroplast distribution. Overexpression of REC1 increased chloroplast coverage. Amitrole treatment caused REC1 to be excluded from the nucleus.
conclusions: REC1, REC2, REC3, and FRIENDLY promote proper chloroplast morphology, function, and size, linking mesophyll cell size increases to chloroplast compartment size. The trafficking of REC1 between the nucleus and cytosol may be regulated by signals activated by the inhibition of cell expansion or chloroplast dysfunction. These genes may contribute to the engineering of C4 photosynthesis into C3 plants.
relationships: The REC gene family interacts to regulate chloroplast size and function. REC1 plays a more significant role than REC2, REC3, or FRIENDLY. The interaction between REC genes and cell expansion is crucial for maintaining proper chloroplast compartment size.
insights: The size of the chloroplast compartment is regulated by extraplastidic mechanisms involving the REC gene family. REC1's nucleocytoplasmic partitioning is influenced by chloroplast function and cell expansion. Manipulating these genes could lead to improved photosynthetic efficiency in crops.

title: NADPH oxidase activity is required for ER stress survival in plants.
objective: To review recent findings exploring molecular mechanisms that support efficient unfolded protein response (UPR) in plants, focusing on how the UPR integrates energy availability, plant production needs, and environmental conditions.
methodology: Review of existing literature and recent advancements in the field of UPR in plants, with a focus on studies in Arabidopsis thaliana.
results: The review highlights the roles of IRE1, bZIP60, and bZIP28 as key regulators of the UPR, and discusses their involvement in ER quality control, stress responses, and plant development. It also explores the involvement of other transcription factors like ANAC062, ANAC103 and ANAC089.
conclusions: The UPR plays a crucial role in maintaining ER homeostasis and enabling downstream processes related to stress adaptation and defense. The UPR responds to various signal transduction cascades, including those involving reactive oxygen species, and its functions extend beyond canonical stress responses to influence plant physiology.
relationships: The UPR is functionally connected to plastid metabolic dysfunction, oxidative stress, hormone signaling (SA, cytokinin, auxin), and epigenetic modifications (COMPASS complex). IRE1 interacts with bZIP60 and bZIP28. bZIP28 interacts with NF-Y transcription factors. ANAC089 interacts with PAS1.
insights: The plant UPR is a complex network that integrates energy availability, plant production needs and environmental conditions. Plant-specific components and mechanisms contribute to the UPR's diverse roles in plant growth, development, and stress responses. Further research is needed to fully understand the molecular mechanisms underlying UPR activation and its integration with other signaling pathways.

title: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
objective: To explore the functional connection between reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the unfolded protein response (UPR) in plants, specifically investigating the role of RBOHD and RBOHF in ER stress.
methodology: Experiments included in situ superoxide detection using NBT staining, H2O2 quantification using Amplex Ultra Red, qRT-PCR to measure gene transcript levels, and phenotypic analyses of Arabidopsis mutants (rbohd rbohf, ire1a ire1b, bzip60 bzip28) under ER stress conditions (tunicamycin treatment).
results: ER stress induces the accumulation of superoxide and H2O2, dependent on RBOHD and RBOHF activity. UPR regulators influence RBOHD and RBOHF expression during adaptive UPR. RBOHD and RBOHF are necessary for recovery from short-term and chronic ER stress and contribute to preventing ER stress-induced cell death.
conclusions: NADPH Oxidases-produced ROS exert a positive role on the ability of the plant to overcome ER stress. RBOHD and RBOHF are important positive contributors to UPR adaptation in plants, differently from the mammalian cell system.
relationships: RBOHD and RBOHF activity is required for ER stress-induced O2− and H2O2 production. The integrity of UPR signaling is required for maintaining homeostatic levels of RBOH expression during ER stress. RBOHD and RBOHF contribute to maintain UPR signaling homeostasis during ER stress.
insights: Unlike in metazoans, NADPH Oxidase-produced ROS are beneficial to overcome ER stress in plants. Homeostasis of NADPH Oxidase activity is required to maintain an effective UPR. In ER stress conditions, the production of ROS is antagonized by IRE1 and the bZIP60/bZIP28 transcription factors.

title: Reanalysis of the Mars500 experiment reveals common gut microbiome alterations in astronauts induced by long-duration confinement
objective: To understand how plants respond to spaceflight stress by examining the significance of the unfolded protein response (UPR) in Arabidopsis thaliana during the SpaceX-CRS12 mission to the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Comparative transcriptome profiling was performed on wild-type Arabidopsis and UPR-defective mutants during the SpaceX-CRS12 mission. Plants were cultivated in orbit and on Earth under controlled conditions. RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) was used to analyze gene expression changes. Statistical analyses and Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment were performed to identify biological pathways.
results: Orbital culture significantly altered the expression of stress-related genes compared to ground control. While gene expression varied in UPR mutants on the ground, it was largely similar across genotypes in spaceflight. Spaceflight resulted in an increase of total RNA. Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified, with WT having the largest number. Upregulated DEGs were more numerous than downregulated DEGs. K-means clustering analysis revealed variations in DEGs between genotypes were primarily due to variable expression in ground control samples.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces the activation of signaling pathways that compensate for the loss of UPR regulators in the control of downstream transcriptional regulatory networks. The UPR plays a partial role in regulating transcriptional reprogramming in space compared to ground control. bZIP60 has functions independent of IRE1 and bZIP28. The UPR does not have a broad involvement in the response to spaceflight.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between the unfolded protein response (UPR) and plant adaptation to spaceflight. It examines the roles of IRE1, bZIP28, and bZIP60 in regulating gene expression under microgravity-associated conditions.
insights: Spaceflight-induced transcriptional responses mitigate the need for gene-regulatory networks controlled by UPR sensors. Media contact could induce R/FR light signaling in the dark. bZIP60 and bZIP28 may have antagonistic interactions related to control of abscisic acid signaling or water deprivation responses.

title: High atomic weight, high-energy radiation (HZE) induces transcriptional responses shared with conventional stresses in addition to a core "DSB" response specific to clastogenic treatments
objective: To reanalyse data from the Mars500 experiment to identify common gut microbiome alterations in astronauts induced by long-duration confinement.
methodology: Reanalysis of 16S rRNA gene amplicon data from early (days 7-45) and late (days 420-520) faecal samples of six astronauts using improved bioinformatics technology and a common data normalisation strategy. Differential abundance analysis was performed using DESeq2.
results: Identification of 408 exact sequence variants (ESVs), including 213 shared by all astronauts. Thirty-two ESVs were significantly differentially abundant over time, including depletion of keystone resistant starch degrading, anti-inflammatory and insulin sensitivity-associated species, and enrichment of yet-to-be-cultured bacteria. 49 species were shared between astronauts and their habitat.
conclusions: Long-duration confinement significantly alters the gut microbiome of astronauts, with depletion of beneficial species and enrichment of unknown bacteria. These alterations are consistent with intestinal inflammation and disruption of glucose metabolism observed in astronauts. There are extensive interactions between the gut and environmental microbiomes.
relationships: Observed microbiome changes are consistent with intestinal inflammation, increased faecal calprotectin levels, moderate insulin resistance and lean body mass loss reported in Mars500 astronauts over the 520 days of confinement.
insights: The study highlights the potential deleterious impact of long-term confinement on microbiome health and the importance of understanding complex microbiome interactions in influencing human health during long-duration spaceflight. The identification of significant species-level microbiome alterations which align with astronaut symptoms connects the Russian, European, Chinese and now Canadian Space Agency Mars500 studies.

title: Genomic stability in response to high versus low linear energy transfer radiation in Arabidopsis thaliana
objective: To correct an oversight regarding the accession number for the microarray dataset associated with a previous study on the transcriptional responses of Arabidopsis thaliana to high-energy radiation.
methodology: This is a corrigendum, so it refers back to the original study which used microarray analysis to examine gene expression changes in Arabidopsis thaliana exposed to high atomic weight, high-energy (HZE) radiation.
results: The correct accession number for the microarray data is GSE61484.
conclusions: The correction of the accession number does not affect the scientific conclusions of the original article.
relationships: The study builds upon previous research investigating the effects of radiation on plant genomes and transcriptional responses to stress.
insights: Accurate data deposition is crucial for reproducibility and data sharing in scientific research. This correction ensures that the microarray data is properly linked to the original publication.

title: Genomic stability in response to high versus low linear energy transfer radiation in Arabidopsis thaliana
objective: To understand the genetic requirements for resistance to high versus low LET radiation by exposing Arabidopsis thaliana mutants to either 1GeV Fe nuclei or gamma radiation and comparing effects on germination and seedling growth.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana mutants were exposed to high-LET (HZE) and low-LET (gamma) radiation. Root growth was measured, and a sectoring assay was used to test for loss of heterozygosity (LOH) using an albino marker gene. Relative biological effectiveness (RBE) was calculated.
results: HZE radiation has a roughly 3:1 relative biological effectiveness (RBE) compared to gamma radiation in inhibiting primary root growth. Genomic instability, measured by loss of heterozygosity, was greater in seeds exposed to HZE particles than in those exposed to gamma rays. DNA repair-deficient lines (lig4 and ku80) exhibited decreased genomic stability. The relative importance of ATM and ATR differed in response to HZE versus gamma radiation.
conclusions: The complexity of DNA damage induced by radiation plays a role in DNA repair efficiency and accuracy. C-NHEJ is important in repairing both simple and complex DSBs. The relative importance of ATM versus ATR shifts in response to HZE versus gamma radiation, suggesting that HZE radiation leads to an increase in ssDNA.
relationships: ATM and ATR function synergistically in response to IR-induced DNA damage. LIG4 and KU80 are important components of NHEJ and maintain genomic stability following exposure to IR.
insights: High-LET radiation induces more complex DNA damage than low-LET radiation, leading to increased genomic instability. The cell's response to different types of radiation varies, with ATR playing a more important role in responding to the complex damage induced by HZE particles.

title: Cytoskeleton structure and total methylation of mouse cardiac and lung tissue during space flight.
objective: To present a solution for collecting, analyzing, and classifying the altered gravity environments experienced during parabolic flights, and to validate this solution.
methodology: Data was collected during a Boeing 727-200F flight with 20 parabolas using a commercially available accelerometer. Acceleration data was filtered and analyzed using change point detection to identify different phases of flight. A metric independent of accelerometer orientation (Euclidean norm of the accelerometer axes) was used.
