Flight periods were classified into 'parabola', 'hypergravity', and 'other' based on duration and g level.
results: The methodology enabled unsupervised classification of all phases of flight. The system characterized g levels and durations achieved for 20 parabolas. Parabola durations averaged 19.5 seconds at 0 g. The g levels achieved were 0.041 g (0 g) and 0.159 g (lunar g). Both Mars parabolas achieved 0.356 g.
conclusions: The presented solution provides a consistent and open-source approach to quantifying gravito-inertial accelerations during parabolic flights. The data and analysis methods are publicly available to facilitate future parabolic flight research and can be adapted for suborbital flights or drop tower studies.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between the duration of parabolas and the g-levels achieved, with higher g-levels associated with longer durations.
insights: The research highlights the importance of open access to raw data and data processing details to improve the validation and refinement of processing algorithms in parabolic flight research. It also emphasizes the need to understand the accuracy and limitations of parabolic flights as a means to simulate space environments.

title: Toward countering muscle and bone loss with spaceflight: GSK3 as a potential target
objective: To evaluate the protein and mRNA expression levels of cytoskeletal proteins in cardiac and lung tissue of mice after a 37-day spaceflight, and to analyze total DNA methylation levels and their regulation.
methodology: C57Bl6/J mice were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days. Cardiac and lung tissues were collected and analyzed for protein and mRNA levels of cytoskeletal proteins using gel electrophoresis, immunoblotting, and quantitative PCR. Total DNA methylation levels were determined using restriction analysis. Control groups included basal, vivarium, and ground control mice.
results: No significant changes were observed in the cytoskeletal protein content in cardiac and lung tissue. However, mRNA expression levels of associated genes were significantly changed. Total DNA methylation was increased in both cardiac and lung tissue in the flight group. The mRNA content of cytosine demethylase Tet2 was significantly decreased in the flight group.
conclusions: Long-duration spaceflight induces changes in mRNA content and total genome methylation in mouse cardiac and lung tissue, without altering cytoskeletal protein content. Decreased Tet2 mRNA content may contribute to increased total methylation levels. Early period of readaptation may be more damaging than space flight itself.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between spaceflight, changes in gene expression, increased DNA methylation, and the potential impact on cytoskeletal protein regulation. It also highlights the differences between biomaterial fixed under space flight conditions versus after landing, suggesting that early readaptation to Earth's gravity can cause structural changes in the cells.
insights: The experiment is the first in the history of human space exploration with the unique opportunity to fix mouse biomaterial under space flight conditions. Comparing these results with the results obtained after the BION-M Biosatellite No. 1 flight of the same length, a number of deductions can be made regarding the structural changes in the cells as a result of the early period of readaptation to Earth’s gravity.

title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ leak and this cannot be counteracted with BuOE treatment
objective: To investigate the effects of spaceflight on murine muscle and bone GSK3 content and activation status, and to assess the impact of muscle-specific GSK3 inhibition on muscle size, strength, and bone mineral density under simulated microgravity.
methodology: Muscle and bone samples were obtained from mice exposed to spaceflight for 30-37 days across multiple missions (BION-M1, RR1, RR9, RR18). GSK3 content, phosphorylation, and muscle fiber type were analyzed. A muscle-specific GSK3 knockdown (GSK3mKD) mouse model was used to assess the effects of GSK3 inhibition on muscle and bone during hindlimb suspension (HLS) to simulate microgravity. Bone mineral density (BMD) was measured using DXA scans. Muscle contractility was assessed using an Aurora Scientific contractile apparatus. Western blotting was used to quantify protein expression.
results: Spaceflight reduced GSK3b content in soleus muscles, accompanied by a shift from slow-to-fast fiber types. Muscle-specific GSK3 knockdown increased soleus muscle size, myogenic signaling, and preserved muscle strength during HLS. GSK3mKD also increased tibia bone mineral density (BMD) and lumbar spine BMD, associated with increased FNDC5 in muscle.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters GSK3 content and activation in murine muscle and bone. Inhibiting GSK3 before muscle unloading, via muscle-specific Gsk3 deletion, can increase muscle mass, myogenic signaling, and preserve muscle force production. Muscle-specific Gsk3 deletion may also help maintain bone mass. Targeting GSK3 may offer musculoskeletal protection during spaceflight.
relationships: Inhibition of GSK3 in muscle promotes an oxidative fiber type shift and increases PGC-1a content, which can promote the expression and release of FNDC5 and irisin. Irisin, a myokine secreted from muscle, can positively impact bone mass and strength, even in the face of HLS. Muscle-specific Gsk3 knockdown increased FNDC5 in muscle while also increasing BMD in the tibia and lumbar spine, highlighting a muscle-to-bone connection that would likely be activated with whole-body GSK3 inhibition through pharmacological means.
insights: Targeting GSK3 could represent a viable mitigation strategy against the musculoskeletal declines seen with spaceflight. Pharmacological inhibitors such as lithium (Li), which is an already FDA-approved drug, could be used to achieve GSK3 inhibition before and during spaceflight. Low-dose lithium supplementation augments myogenic differentiation and fusion, which could have implications for spaceflight.

title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties
objective: To investigate whether treatment with the antioxidant BuOE could attenuate muscle atrophy and SERCA dysfunction in the murine soleus muscle following 35 days of spaceflight.
methodology: Soleus muscles were obtained from male mice from the RR-18 mission, including ground control, vivarium control, and a flight group housed on the International Space Station for 35 days. Mice were treated weekly with BuOE or saline. SERCA ATPase activity was assessed using an enzyme-linked spectrophotometric assay. Western blotting was performed on muscle homogenate to assess protein content for SERCA1a, SERCA2a, total and phosphorylated RYR, 4-HNE, SOD, SLN, NNAT, and PLN. Statistical analysis was performed using a two-way ANOVA with Tukey’s post-hoc test.
results: Spaceflight significantly reduced the soleus:body mass ratio and significantly increased SERCA’s ionophore ratio (SR Ca2+ leak) and 4-HNE content, none of which could be rescued by BuOE treatment. BuOE treatment increased SERCA’s apparent affinity for Ca2+. Spaceflight increased SERCA1a and SERCA2a protein content. Spaceflight tended to reduce SOD content and increase p-RYR. Spaceflight caused reductions in SLN, increases in NNAT, and reductions in PLN.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces significant soleus muscle atrophy and SR Ca2+ leak that cannot be counteracted with BuOE treatment, despite increases in SERCA's affinity for Ca2+. Future studies aimed at reducing Ca2+ leak or increasing SERCA activation could reveal SERCA and Ca2+ handling as viable targets to counteract weakness and atrophy observed with spaceflight.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy is related to Ca2+ dysregulation, specifically increased SR Ca2+ leak. Increased RONS contribute to SERCA dysfunction. BuOE, while increasing SERCA's affinity for Ca2+, was unable to counteract the effects of spaceflight on muscle atrophy and SR Ca2+ leak.
insights: Targeting SERCA and Ca2+ handling may be a viable strategy to counteract muscle weakness and atrophy observed with spaceflight. Further investigation into the sources of RONS production and alternative therapeutics is needed.

title: Inter-agency perspective: Translating advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments
objective: To identify changes in neonatal and adult human cardiovascular progenitor cells (CPCs) in response to spaceflight that impact signaling, development, and stemness, and to characterize the divergent response of these cell types to spaceflight.
methodology: Clonal lines of neonatal and adult human CPCs were cultured aboard the International Space Station (ISS) for 12 days. Changes in gene and microRNA expression were measured using microarray analysis and RT-PCR. Cell cycling, migration, and endothelial-like tube formation assays were performed. Data were analyzed to identify significant differences between spaceflight-exposed and ground control CPCs.
results: Spaceflight induced changes in microRNA expression, targeting extracellular matrix interactions and Hippo signaling. In neonatal CPCs, genes related to mechanotransduction were downregulated, while cytoskeletal genes and non-canonical Wnt ligands were upregulated. Neonatal CPCs exhibited increased expression of early developmental markers and enhanced proliferative potential. Both neonatal and adult CPCs showed increased expression of DNA repair genes and enhanced migration. Neonatal CPCs showed a reduced ability to form endothelial-like tubes.
conclusions: Spaceflight exerts broad effects on the developmental status, proliferative potential, and migratory ability of CPCs, with age-dependent variations. Neonatal CPCs exhibit increased expression of early developmental markers, enhanced proliferative potential, and increased migratory capacity. Cytoskeletal modifications resulting from reduced mechanotransduction impart improved migratory and adhesion capabilities regardless of age. Recapitulating spaceflight-induced signaling events using clinorotation may represent an avenue for ongoing studies.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced changes in microRNA expression are related to Wnt signaling, cytoskeletal regulation, cardiovascular development, integrin function, extracellular proteins, and Hippo signaling. The study also highlights the relationship between Tbx expression and the engraftment and function of CPCs following transplantation. There is a relationship between let-7 over-expression and reduced proliferative potential.
insights: Spaceflight induces a pre-cardiac mesoderm gene expression profile in neonatal CPCs. Both spaceflight and 2D clinorotation readily alter the developmental properties of neonatal CPCs, possibly through reduced mechanotransduction. The secretome of adult CPCs exhibits a greater number of proteins related to anti-proliferation, pro-apoptosis, and senescence, while the secretome of neonatal CPCs exhibits higher levels of telomerases as well as proteins related to cell cycle, proliferation, and anti-apoptosis.

title: Genomic and functional characterization of Enterococcus faecalis isolates recovered from the International Space Station and their potential for pathogenicity
objective: To translate advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments, focusing on protecting humans from radiation injury.
methodology: Review of existing research, inter-agency collaborations, co-sponsoring scientific meetings, co-funding research, and involvement through inter-agency grant/contract review teams and working groups. Analysis of preclinical models, biomarker identification, and data mining/analytics.
results: Identified several terrestrial-based radiation injury prevention products in routine clinical use or undergoing testing that could address the health needs of humans in space and vice versa. Highlighted the importance of MCM development and biomarker identification for both acute and long-term effects of radiation.
conclusions: Careful coordination between funding agencies and scientists has enabled the advancement of approaches useful for both NIH and NASA needs. Continued collaboration will ensure that products with the greatest promise are studied across all agencies’ mission-specific requirements.
relationships: Strong collaborations between NASA, NCI, and NIAID are crucial for leveraging investments and expertise in radiation research. Partnerships with NIH programs exploring therapeutics for normal tissue injuries will provide new approaches to be considered for astronaut health in a radiation environment.
insights: Repurposing licensed products with multiple uses for space crew is desirable to minimize mass. Products with known long-term safety profiles, such as nutraceuticals, antibiotics, analgesics, and anti-hypertensives, are appropriate selections for further study. Understanding regulatory compliance is essential for successful product development.

title: Evaluation of in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight.
objective: To determine the risk posed by Enterococcus faecalis to residents within the International Space Station (ISS) by assessing if they represent pathogenic lineages commonly associated with infections or commensals shed into the environment.
methodology: Genomic data analyses were coupled with phenotypic characterization of E. faecalis isolates recovered onboard the ISS. Antibiotic resistance, desiccation tolerance, and pathogenicity were assessed using the C. elegans model. Pangenomic and phylogenetic analyses were performed, and comparative genomic analysis included MLST, plasmid detection, virulence factor detection, and CRISPR-Cas system analysis. Minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) of antibiotics were determined by broth microdilution. Desiccation survival was assessed by monitoring cell viability over three weeks. Pathogenicity was assessed using nematode killing assays.
results: ISS isolates exhibited varying degrees of antibiotic resistance, with some showing tetracycline resistance mediated by an acquired tetW/N/W gene. Desiccation tolerance was similar between ISS isolates and reference strains. In the C. elegans model, ISS isolates showed varying levels of pathogenicity, with some being less able to kill C. elegans than others. PathogenFinder predicted all ISS isolates as potential human pathogens, with scores higher than known clinical isolates.
conclusions: While genomic analysis alone is insufficient for accurate pathogenicity assessment, combining it with phenotypic characterization provides a framework. The ISS environment selects for intrinsically rugged species like E. faecalis, but there's no strong evidence for enhanced environmental persistence. Continued microbial monitoring and pathogen identification are important due to the potential for antibiotic resistance spread.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between the genomic characteristics of Enterococcus faecalis isolates from the ISS and their potential pathogenicity and environmental survival. It also examines the relationship between spaceflight conditions and the selection of antibiotic-resistant strains.
insights: The study highlights the need for improved methods to distinguish between pathogenic and commensal strains of E. faecalis. It suggests that monitoring for high-level aminoglycoside resistance and subsequent sequencing could provide near real-time information for crew regarding the need for additional decontamination procedures. The research also emphasizes the importance of combining genomic and culture-based analyses for a more accurate representation of the ISS microbiome.

title: Identification of critical host mitochondrion-associated genes during Ehrlichia chaffeensis infections
objective: To evaluate in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight and test the hypothesis that the receptor expression for M-CSF, c-Fms, was reduced.
methodology: Mouse bone marrow cells were differentiated in the presence of recombinant macrophage colony stimulating factor (rM-CSF) during the flight of space shuttle STS-126. Flow cytometry was used to assess molecules on cells, and gene microarray was performed to analyze RNA.
results: Significant differences were found in the number of macrophages that developed in space compared to controls on Earth. Changes were observed in the distribution of cells expressing CD11b, CD31, F4/80, Mac2, Ly6C, and c-Fos. There were no changes in c-Fms expression. Transcript levels suggested increased proliferation of bone marrow macrophages after 14 days of space flight. Space flight also influenced genes of the coagulation pathway.
conclusions: Space flight can impact the in vitro development of macrophages from mouse bone marrow cells, affecting cell proliferation, phenotype, and gene expression. The increased proliferation was not associated with a concomitant increase in glucose use, suggesting cells do not have to work as hard to grow in space. The changes do not appear to be from decreases in the surface expression of the receptor for M-CSF.
relationships: Space flight affects cells by inducing broad physiological changes and/or it can have direct gravitational impacts on the cells themselves. There is a strong correlation in expression between Csfr and Runx1.
insights: Space flight has a significant impact on murine bone marrow macrophages in vitro, leading to increased cell proliferation and changes in the pattern of expression of cell-surface differentiation antigens. The most interesting revelation of the IPA analysis of the transcriptional array of bone marrow macrophage differentiation in space was the broad impact of space flight on the coagulation pathway.

title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites in adult Drosophila melanogaster.
objective: To identify host genes that contribute to the replication of Ehrlichia chaffeensis, an obligate intracellular bacterium causing human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME).
methodology: Microarray analysis was performed on Drosophila melanogaster S2 cells to compare host gene transcript levels between permissive and nonpermissive conditions for E. chaffeensis growth. Mutant fly lines were screened for their ability to support Ehrlichia replication.  qRT-PCR was used to confirm bacterial load.  THP-1 cells were used to silence the human UCK2 gene.
results: Ten fly lines carrying mutations in the genes CG6479, separation anxiety, chitinase 11, CG6364 (Uck2), CG6543 (Echs1), withered (whd), CG15881 (Ccdc58), CG14806 (Apop1), CG11875 (Nup37), and dumpy (dp) had increased resistance to infection with Ehrlichia. Seven of these genes (san, Cht11, Uck2, Echs1, whd, Ccdc58, and Apop1) encoded proteins that had mitochondrial functions or could be associated with proteins with mitochondrial functions. Silencing of the human UCK2 gene affected E. chaffeensis replication in human macrophages. CPEC treatment increased E. chaffeensis infection. Cytosine treatment increases E. chaffeensis infection.
conclusions: Drosophila melanogaster can be used to investigate host factors important for E. chaffeensis replication.  Ten genes were identified that contribute to the replication of E. chaffeensis in vivo. Seven genes encode proteins that have mitochondrial functions. The uridine kinase must be essential to providing substrates for E. chaffeensis, because it cannot be provided by the de novo synthesis pathway. The clustering of mitochondria adjacent to morulae in E. chaffeensis-infected macrophages supports the hypothesis that it has physiological relevance.
relationships: Seven genes (san, Cht11, Uck2, Echs1, whd, Ccdc58, and Apop1) encode proteins that have mitochondrial functions, serve as substrates in the mitochondria, or are associated with proteins with mitochondrial functions. Cht11 is orthologous to the Chitinase 11 gene of Tribolium castaneum. whd gene was originally associated with uridine kinase. Echs1 in Drosophila is an ortholog of the ECHS1 gene in humans and other mammals. san is an ortholog of the human NAA50 gene. CG15881, or Ccdc58, is an ortholog of the human gene known as coiled-coil domain-containing protein 58 (CCDC58). CG14806 or Apopt1 has no known function in Drosophila. Uck2 (CG6364) is orthologous to the mammalian UCK2 gene with the molecular function of a uridine kinase.
insights: Mitochondrial function is critical for E. chaffeensis replication. The uridine/cytidine salvage pathway is required for E. chaffeensis replication. UCK2 has the potential to be a target for chemotherapy. E. chaffeensis may inhibit mitochondrial activity to inhibit the generation of mitochondrially produced oxidative products that would be harmful to the bacteria.

title: Development and characterization of two porcine monocyte-derived macrophage cell lines.
objective: To investigate where Ehrlichia chaffeensis replicates in arthropods, focusing on tissue-specific inactivation of Uck2 and san genes in Drosophila melanogaster.
methodology: Using the UAS-GAL4 RNAi system, F1 flies were generated with tissue-specific silencing of Uck2 or san. Bacterial replication was quantified using qRT-PCR. Survival rates of flies were monitored post-infection.
results: Silencing Uck2 or san in hemocytes or fat body resulted in poor E. chaffeensis replication and increased fly survival. Silencing in eyes, wings, or salivary glands did not impact susceptibility or bacterial replication. Significant transcript reduction of Uck2 or san was observed in RNAi flies.
conclusions: E. chaffeensis replicates within the hemocytes (insect homolog of mammalian macrophages) and the fat body (liver homolog of mammals) in Drosophila. Uck2 and san genes are required for in vivo E. chaffeensis replication.
relationships: E. chaffeensis exhibits a tropism for monocytes and macrophages in vertebrates. Hemocytes are the arthropod host equivalent of macrophages, and the fat body is functionally equivalent to the mammalian liver. Signaling between hemocytes and the fat body may coordinate the immune response.
insights: The tissue tropism of E. chaffeensis for phagocytic cells may have arisen approximately 600 million years ago. Understanding tissue targets in arthropods may aid in drug design and RNAi therapeutics for tick- and arthropod-borne diseases.

title: Understanding macrophage differentiation during space flight: The importance of ground-based experiments before space flight
objective: To identify dual-acting natural compounds that exhibit antiviral and anti-inflammatory activities against African swine fever virus (ASFV).
methodology: Screening a library of 297 natural, anti-inflammatory compounds to identify candidates that protected Vero cells against ASFV-induced cytopathic effect (CPE). Virus yield reduction, virucidal, and cell cytotoxicity experiments were performed on positive hits. Lead compounds were further characterized in dose-dependent assays, time-of-addition, time-of-removal, virus entry, and viral protein synthesis assays. The antiviral effects of the lead compounds on mitigating virulent ASFV infection in porcine macrophages (PAMs) were also tested, and the ability to inhibit pro-inflammatory cytokine production was assessed by ELISA.
results: Five compounds inhibited ASFV-induced CPE by greater than 50%. Tetrandrine and berbamine exhibited high levels of anti-ASFV activity, inhibiting early stages of ASFV infection and infection of PAMs by the virulent ASFV Arm/07 isolate. Both compounds reduced the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines during ASFV infection in PAM cells, with tetrandrine having a greater and more sustained anti-inflammatory effect than berbamine.
conclusions: Dual-acting natural compounds with antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties hold promise as preventative and therapeutic agents to combat ASFV infection by simultaneously inhibiting viral replication and reducing virus-induced cytokine production.
relationships: Tetrandrine and berbamine inhibit ASFV infection by blocking virus entry, disrupting viral attachment and internalization into host cells. They also reduce the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6, in ASFV-infected macrophages.
insights: Berbamine and tetrandrine possess dual inhibitory activities: potent antiviral activity against ASFV, primarily through disrupting viral entry mechanisms; and significant inhibition of virus-induced pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Tetrandrine exhibits particularly robust antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties.

title: Bone marrow leptin signaling mediates obesity-associated adipose tissue inflammation in male mice.
objective: To investigate the role of leptin signaling in bone marrow-derived cells in obesity-associated adipose tissue inflammation and insulin resistance in male mice.
methodology: Radiation chimeric C57BL/6J mice were generated, reconstituted with either leptin receptor-deficient (db/db) or wild-type (WT) bone marrow, and challenged with a high-fat diet (HFD) for 16 weeks. Body weight, adiposity, gene expression in adipose tissue, macrophage phenotype, and insulin sensitivity were assessed.
results: Mice with db/db bone marrow (WT/db) had lower body weight and adiposity compared to WT/WT mice. Gonadal adipose tissue in WT/db mice showed reduced expression of inflammatory genes (Tnfa, Il6, Ccl2) and fewer crown-like structures. Macrophages in WT/db mice exhibited an anti-inflammatory phenotype (MGL1+/CCR2-). WT/db mice also showed greater insulin sensitivity.
conclusions: Disrupted leptin signaling in bone marrow-derived cells attenuates the proinflammatory conditions that mediate metabolic complications of obesity. Leptin plays a role in regulating obesity-associated systemic inflammation and may contribute to the phenotypic switch of ATMs from anti-inflammatory (M2) to proinflammatory (M1) in vivo.
relationships: Leptin signaling in bone marrow-derived cells influences adipose tissue inflammation, macrophage polarization, and insulin sensitivity in the context of high-fat diet-induced obesity. The absence of leptin receptor signaling in white blood cells led to reduced weight gain and adiposity and improved insulin sensitivity.
insights: Leptin signaling in bone marrow is a novel mechanism involved in the regulation of obesity-associated systemic inflammation. Targeting leptin signaling in bone marrow-derived cells could be a potential therapeutic strategy for managing obesity and related metabolic complications.

title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
objective: To investigate macrophage colony stimulating factor-dependent macrophage differentiation from mouse primary bone marrow cells in vitro, in preparation for a space flight experiment.
methodology: Two in vitro culture systems, the Techshot Cell Cult Bioreactor and the BioServe Fluid Processing Apparatus (FPA), were used. Bone marrow cells were cultured in these devices in different orientations (vertical and horizontal) at 37°C. Macrophage recovery, size, granularity, and expression of differentiation markers (F4/80, Ly6G, Mac-2, c-fms) were assessed using flow cytometry. Gene expression analysis was performed using Affymetrix Mouse Genome 430 2.0 array.
results: Macrophage recovery was significantly higher from FPAs incubated in the horizontal orientation compared to vertical. The Techshot bioreactor showed highest macrophage recovery when rotated in the horizontal plane. Cell surface phenotype varied depending on whether macrophages differentiated in FPAs or bioreactors. Cells proliferated more in space compared to ground-incubated cells. Significant shifts were observed in the distribution of cells expressing CD31, Ly6C, CD11b, F4/80, Mac-2, and c-fos in cells differentiated in space flight compared to ground controls. Several genes in the M-CSF/c-fms pathway were up or down regulated in space-flight samples.
conclusions: Culture outcomes are highly dependent on the culture device and its orientation. Space flight alters macrophage differentiation, proliferation, and gene expression. Preflight verification tests are crucial for validating culture systems and interpreting space flight data.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between culture device orientation, macrophage differentiation, and gene expression. It also demonstrates the impact of space flight on macrophage behavior and the importance of ground-based experiments for validating space flight data.
insights: The orientation of culture devices significantly impacts cell recovery and phenotype. Space flight induces changes in macrophage proliferation, cell surface molecule expression, and gene transcription. Understanding the culture system is essential for accurate interpretation of space flight data. The M-CSF/c-fms pathway is significantly affected during macrophage differentiation in space.

title: Validation of methods to assess the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in tissues obtained from mice on the International Space Station.
objective: To create a continuous macrophage cell line to allow for investigation of the leptin receptor's (LepR) impact on macrophage function.
methodology: Immortalized bone marrow cells from leptin receptor-deficient mice (db/db) by culturing them with recombinant mouse macrophage colony stimulating factor for 6 months, followed by limiting dilution cloning. Characterized the resulting DB-1 cell line using qRT-PCR, flow cytometry, cell cycle analysis, chromosome staining, cytokine secretion assays, and phagocytosis assays. Migration assays were performed using both peritoneal WT and DB-1 macrophages.
results: Established a leptin receptor-deficient macrophage cell line (DB-1) that is diploid, has a normal chromosome complement, and lacks the long isoform of the leptin receptor. DB-1 cells exhibit macrophage-like morphology, express MAC-2, and demonstrate phagocytic activity similar to primary macrophages. DB-1 cells respond to IFN-c stimulation by increasing Nos2 transcript levels and secrete nitrite. DB-1 macrophages did not respond to the chemotactic signals from adipocyte conditioned media or leptin.
conclusions: The DB-1 cell line is a valuable tool for studying the link between leptin and innate immune function. It exhibits phenotypic and functional properties characteristic of primary macrophages, while lacking a functional leptin receptor, making it useful for investigating the impact of LepR on macrophage function.
relationships: Leptin plays a key role in immune system regulation. Leptin induces diapedesis of monocytes and macrophages through an epithelial layer in vitro and the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines from both cell types. Obesity is associated with an increase in inflammatory macrophage recruitment to the expanding fat mass.
insights: DB-1 cells are in the macrophage lineage with high MAC2 expression, lower expression of F4/80 and low levels of Ly6C. DB-1 macrophages are responsive to IFN-c and LPS stimuli. The lack of the leptin receptor in DB-1 cells directly impacts their responsiveness to leptin-mediated chemotaxis.

title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing
objective: To validate methods for assessing the immunoglobulin gene repertoire in mouse tissues, specifically in the context of spaceflight limitations, and to develop a bioinformatic workflow for analyzing Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) data of antibody repertoires.
methodology: RNA was extracted from spleen samples of C57BL/6J mice using different preparation methods (cells, whole tissue, size-selected tissue).  RNA sequencing libraries were constructed and sequenced using Illumina MiSeq. A bioinformatics workflow was developed using CLC Genomics Workbench, NCBI databases, and IMGT High-V Quest for data cleaning, mapping, and analysis of V, D, and J gene usage, CDR3 assembly, and mutation assessment.  The workflow was validated by comparing MiSeq data to existing murine antibody repertoire studies and by comparing reference mapping to whole genome mapping.
results: Size selection of RNA yielded the highest number of antibody sequences. V-gene segment usage was similar among cell, tissue, and size-selected treatment groups. D1-1 was the most frequently discovered D-gene segment. JH2 was the most frequently used J-gene segment. IgM was the most abundant heavy chain constant region. The tissue and size selected treatment groups contained most of the common CDR3s. Reference mapping and whole genome mapping showed strong correlation.
conclusions: Whole tissue preparations yield comparable results to single-cell suspensions for antibody repertoire analysis. Size selection improves the number of Ig reads. The developed bioinformatics workflow is effective for characterizing NGS data of Ig repertoires. The study provides a foundation for future research on immune responses during spaceflight.
relationships: The study compares different tissue preparation methods (cells, tissue, size-selected) and their impact on Ig sequence recovery. It also compares reference mapping and whole genome mapping techniques for analyzing sequencing data. The findings relate to the impact of spaceflight on the immune system and the challenges of sample collection and analysis in microgravity.
insights: The study demonstrates that reliable antibody repertoire analysis can be performed using whole tissue samples, which is crucial for spaceflight experiments where single-cell suspensions are difficult to obtain. Size selection enhances Ig sequence recovery. The validated bioinformatics workflow provides a valuable tool for analyzing NGS data of antibody repertoires in various research settings.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
objective: To characterize the antibody repertoire from pooled splenic tissue of unimmunized adult female C57BL/6J mice using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) without amplification of antibody transcripts, providing a non-primer biased view of the antibody repertoire.
methodology: High-throughput sequencing of antibody transcripts from pooled splenic RNA of unimmunized mice. RNA extraction, size selection, and Illumina MiSeq sequencing were performed. Bioinformatics analysis included sequence cleaning, mapping to V-gene segments, identification using IMGT High-V Quest, and statistical analysis using GraphPad and R.
results: Identified over 90,000 heavy-chain and over 135,000 light-chain immunoglobulin sequences. Individual V-, D-, and J-gene segment usage was uniform among the three mouse pools. The repertoire of individual B-cell CDR3 amino acid sequences in each mouse pool was highly varied. Skewing in the V-gene segments was detected depending on chromosomal location. D1-1 gene segment was the most common, and IgM was the most commonly identified constant region.
conclusions: This study presents a unique, non-primer biased glimpse of the conventionally housed, unimmunized antibody repertoire of the C57BL6/J mouse. An RNASeq approach without amplification can provide an accurate assessment of V-gene use as well as a snapshot of the CDR3 present in the population; and helps validate this as a reasonable scientific approach.
relationships: VH-gene usage between pools was well correlated. Vκ usage between pools was correlated, although not as highly as VH. IgH gene segment recombination frequency correlated with gene segment abundance. Pairing of Vκ families with Jκ appeared random, however, certain Vκ families preferentially paired with specific Jκ-gene segments.
insights: The antibody repertoire exhibits diversity resulting from recombination of germline genes, imprecise V(D)J recombination, and somatic mutations. Repertoires can serve as a snapshot of the immune-system status and have been used to explore host defense to infectious disease, cancer, autoimmune disease, and early disease detection. The data provides a comparative foundation when looking at host response to antigen and has been used to isolated therapeutic antibodies.

title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing.
objective: To characterize the impact of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin (Ig) repertoire of unimmunized mice flown on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: High-throughput sequencing (HTS) of splenic RNA from C57BL/6 mice flown on the ISS and ground controls. Bioinformatic analysis using IMGT HighV-Quest tool to assess gene segment usage, combinations, CDR3 composition, and mutation analysis.
results: Individual Ig gene segment usage was similar between ground control and flight animals. Gene segment combinations and CDR3 sequences were highly varied. No significant differences were found in D-, JH- or Jκ-gene segment usage and IgH constant region usage between ground and flight animals. CDR3 length in IgH was highly varied, but no significant difference between ground and flight animals.
conclusions: A short trip to and stay on the ISS does not significantly affect the recombinatorial processes that lead to diverse Ig repertoires in mice. However, differences might be observed during active immunization or in younger mice.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between spaceflight and the adaptive immune response, specifically focusing on the B-cell repertoire and immunoglobulin diversity.
insights: Spaceflight does not appear to significantly alter the B-cell repertoire in unimmunized mice under the conditions tested, suggesting the immune system's fundamental recombination processes remain largely unaffected by short-duration space travel. Further research is needed to assess the impact of spaceflight on the Ig repertoire during active immunization or in younger, more recombinatorily active mice.

title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
objective: To compare unamplified sequencing results from the splenic heavy-chain repertoire in the mouse to those processed through two commercial applications and to examine the impact of sample preparation as part of our effort.
methodology: RNA was extracted from the spleens of C57Bl/6J mice. Unamplified total RNA (TRNA) was sequenced. Commercial sample preparations using mRNA were also used with different reverse transcriptases (AMV vs MMLV) and primer templates (oligo-dT or random hexamer). Bioinformatic analysis was performed using IMGT and KSU pipelines. Statistical analyses included paired T-tests and coefficient of determinations.
results: Unamplified data detected more V-gene segments than amplified data. mRNA starting material yielded more total transcriptional reads than TRNA. High correlation in V-gene sequences detected among technical replicates in Com1 and Com2 data. The KSU data set detected all but one of the highest frequency CDR3 sequences.
conclusions: Sequencing of unamplified splenic RNA provides a realistic snapshot of the total splenic B cell repertoire. Unamplified data sets produced from an RNASeq allow for further data mining, eliminate as much primer bias as possible and provides an accurate representation of the repertoire. A good understanding of the bioinformatics work flow and reporting of the methodology is critical.
relationships: Comparison of amplified and unamplified data sets to assess the comparability of different sequencing methodologies on the B cell repertoire.
insights: Unamplified RNA sequencing captures a representative sample of the splenic B cell repertoire, detecting more V-gene segments and a high percentage of high-frequency CDR3s compared to amplified methods. While amplified data provides more CDR3 depth, unamplified RNASeq allows for further data mining and minimizes primer bias.

title: Effects of skeletal unloading on the bone marrow antibody repertoire of tetanus toxoid and/or CpG treated C57BL/6J mice.
objective: To evaluate the preclinical safety and efficacy of TAK-754, an AAV8-based gene therapy vector designed for hemophilia A treatment, in mice.
methodology: The study involved in vivo experiments using FVIII knockout mice, transgenic human FVIII mice, and hemostatically normal mice. TAK-754 was administered intravenously, and various assays were performed to assess FVIII activity, hemostatic efficacy, biodistribution, toxicity, and integration site analysis.
results: TAK-754 demonstrated dose-dependent increases in plasma FVIII activity and reduced blood loss in FVIII KO mice. Long-term FVIII expression was observed in transgenic human FVIII mice. Biodistribution studies showed predominant detection of the vector in the liver. No significant adverse effects were observed in toxicity studies. Integration site analysis revealed minimal vector integration.
conclusions: TAK-754 exhibits a favorable preclinical efficacy and safety profile, supporting its potential as a gene therapy for hemophilia A. The vector demonstrates efficient liver transduction, sustained FVIII expression, and minimal genotoxicity risk in mice.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between TAK-754 dosage and FVIII activity levels, as well as hemostatic efficacy. It also explores the relationship between vector biodistribution and liver transduction. The study further investigates the relationship between vector integration and potential genotoxicity.
insights: The study provides insights into the design and evaluation of AAV-based gene therapies for hemophilia A. It highlights the importance of vector optimization, liver-specific expression, and immunogenicity considerations. The findings contribute to the understanding of AAV vector behavior and potential clinical applications.

title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of TAK-754, an AAV8-based human factor VIII (FVIII) vector, for gene therapy in hemophilia A patients.
methodology: FVIII knockout mice, immunologically tolerant transgenic human FVIII mice, and male C57BL/6J mice were administered TAK-754. Plasma FVIII activity, blood loss, toxicology, biodistribution, and integration sites were assessed.
results: TAK-754 showed a dose-dependent increase in plasma FVIII activity and a decrease in blood loss in FVIII knockout mice. Long-term and stable FVIII expression was observed in immunologically tolerant transgenic human FVIII mice. Biodistribution profiling showed predominant detection in the liver with minimal vector integration.
conclusions: TAK-754 demonstrates a good safety and efficacy profile for gene therapy in hemophilia A. Preclinical studies support its further development.
relationships: Dose-dependent increase in FVIII activity correlated with a decrease in blood loss. F8 RNA levels mirrored F8 DNA levels. FVIII immunogenicity increased with initial high-level AAV-FVIII protein expression.
insights: Codon optimization and CpG depletion in the F8 transgene minimize immunogenicity risk. AAV8 capsid demonstrates preferential tropism for the liver. TAK-754 is maintained episomally and poses a low genotoxicity risk.

title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
objective: To analyze the antibody repertoire diversity across multiple experiments examining the effects of spaceflight on the antibody repertoire after vaccination and to test the hypothesis that antibody diversity can be altered by physiological adaptation (spaceflight, simulated spaceflight, and/or immune responses).
methodology: Analysis of five datasets from four experiments using rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices to measure diversity. Datasets included normal mouse spleen RNA, Center for the Advancement of Science in Space (CASIS) spleen RNA (spaceflight experiment), Tetanus Ab response developed in space (TARDIS) spleen and bone marrow RNA (AOS model), and hypervaccination pooled spleen and bone marrow RNA. Bioinformatics processes included cleaning sequences, mapping to V-gene segments and IgH loci, and identifying CDR3 amino acid sequences.
results: A trend toward lower antibody repertoire diversity as a result of spaceflight was observed, but not in the physiological model of microgravity in either the spleen or bone marrow. Bone marrow repertoire showed a reduction in diversity after vaccination. Differences in Shannon indices were detected between experiments and tissues. No pattern of CDR3 usage was detected across the experiments. Bone marrow had lower diversity than the spleen. No clustering or significant principal components emerged from PCA analyses. A single CDR3 (CARGAYW) was found in every animal spleen dataset.
conclusions: Subtle alterations in antibody repertoire diversity occur in response to experimental and environmental challenges. Trends or significant reduction in diversity occur in response to hindlimb suspension and TT vaccination in the bone marrow. A reduced diversity is also found in the bone marrow as compared with the spleen. There is significant individual-to-individual CDR3 uniqueness, suggesting that an animal’s antibody repertoire is quite unique, even in a highly inbred animal.
relationships: Spaceflight may lead to a reduction in antibody diversity. The bone marrow antibody repertoire is less diverse than the spleen. TT vaccination reduces diversity in bone marrow.
insights: The study suggests that spaceflight and vaccination can influence antibody repertoire diversity, with the bone marrow being more sensitive to these changes than the spleen. The unique antibody repertoire of each individual animal highlights the importance of diversity in immune responses.

title:
Effects of spaceﬂight aboard the International Space Station
on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
objective: To determine the effects of long-term spaceflight on the estrous cycle and ovarian function in female mice, and to assess the impact on endocrine status.
methodology: Adult female mice were exposed to 37 days of spaceflight in microgravity on the International Space Station. Ovarian tissues and vaginal wall tissues were collected and analyzed for RNA, steroid levels, and estrous cycle staging. Control groups were maintained on Earth under similar conditions. Quantitative RT-PCR was used to analyze gene expression.
results: The proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle did not differ significantly between baseline, vivarium, and flight mice, while habitat control mice exhibited greater numbers in diestrus. Ovarian tissue steroid concentrations indicated no differences in estradiol across groups, while progesterone levels were lower in habitat and flight compared to baseline females. Spaceflight had no demonstrable effect on gene expression of key enzymatic steps of steroidogenesis or mitochondrial cholesterol uptake expression.
conclusions: Female mice exposed to extended periods of microgravity exhibit estrous cyclic activity, suggesting that they can either continue or regain estrous cycle activity during extended microgravity exposure. Analysis of the vaginal wall provides a robust methodology that can indicate the estrous stage, and thus the endocrine status of the animal at the moment of sacrifice.
relationships: Spaceflight microgravity impacts numerous physiological systems, including the reproductive system. Ovarian steroid hormones play a significant role in regulating physiological functions. Estrous cycle staging can be influenced by various environmental factors.
insights: Long-term spaceflight does not appear to disrupt estrous cyclicity in mice. Vaginal wall analysis is a reliable method for determining estrous stage in spaceflight studies. Tissue preservation methods are critical for RNA quality in spaceflight experiments.

title: Spaceflight promotes biofilm formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
objective: To explore how phosphate concentration, carbon source, oxygen availability, and motility affect the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in modified artificial urine media during spaceflight.
methodology: Pseudomonas aeruginosa was cultured during spaceflight in a fluid processing apparatus (FPA) with modified artificial urine media (mAUM) under varying conditions of phosphate concentration, carbon source (citrate or glucose), and oxygen availability (using gas exchange inserts). Cell density was measured using flow cytometry (FCM). A motility mutant was also tested. Ground controls were run in parallel.
results: Spaceflight increased the final cell density of P. aeruginosa when grown with low phosphate and low oxygen availability. Increasing either phosphate or oxygen availability minimized the difference between spaceflight and normal gravity. No significant difference was observed between motile and non-motile strains. Microscopy did not show aggregation of cells.
conclusions: Differences in P. aeruginosa final cell densities observed between spaceflight and normal gravity are due to an interplay between microgravity conditions and the availability of substrates essential for growth. Microbes grown under nutrient-limiting conditions are likely to reach higher cell densities under microgravity conditions than they would on Earth.
relationships: Microgravity conditions, nutrient availability (phosphate, oxygen), bacterial growth, cell density, motility.
insights: Microgravity appears to allow cells to grow better with limited resources compared to similar conditions on Earth, highlighting the need for ongoing studies of how these effects may affect crew health during long-term spaceflight.

title: GeneLab: Omics database for spaceflight experiments
objective: To examine the role of microgravity on microbial biofilm formation by comparing biofilm formation during spaceflight and normal gravity.
methodology: Cultured Pseudomonas aeruginosa during two Space Shuttle Atlantis missions (STS-132 and STS-135) using specialized hardware (fluid processing apparatus - FPA). Biofilms were formed under static conditions at 37°C for 72 hours using modified artificial urine media (mAUM). Ground controls were conducted in parallel. Viable cell counting and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) were used to quantify biofilm formation and architecture.
results: Spaceflight increased the number of viable cells, biofilm biomass, and thickness relative to normal gravity controls. Biofilms formed during spaceflight exhibited a column-and-canopy structure not observed on Earth. Flagella-driven motility was essential for the formation of this biofilm architecture during spaceflight. Increased oxygen availability minimized gravitational effects on biofilm formation.
conclusions: Spaceflight affects biofilm formation by P. aeruginosa, leading to increased biofilm production and a novel column-and-canopy architecture. Flagella-driven motility plays a key role in this architecture. Altered biofilm formation during spaceflight may have detrimental impacts on long-term spaceflight missions due to increased biofouling and microbially-induced corrosion.
relationships: Flagella-driven motility is crucial for the unique biofilm structure observed in space, similar to its role in mushroom-shaped biofilms on Earth under hydrodynamic conditions. Oxygen availability influences biofilm formation, with increased oxygen minimizing the differences between spaceflight and normal gravity conditions.
insights: The microgravity environment and resource availability significantly influence bacterial biofilm formation. The unique biofilm morphology observed in microgravity suggests that bacteria can adapt to non-terrestrial environments in ways that warrant further investigation.

title: NASA GeneLab: Interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
objective: To develop a standardized consensus pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments and make the processed data publicly available.
methodology: The GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline (RCP) includes quality control (FastQC, MultiQC), read trimming (TrimGalore), mapping (STAR), quantification (RSEM), and differential gene expression calculation/annotation (DESeq2). The pipeline processes data with and without ERCC spike-in normalization.
results: The RCP provides consistently processed data, including quality control metrics, mapped reads, gene counts, and differential gene expression results. Downstream analysis using processed data from select samples from RNAseq datasets hosted on GeneLab showed similarities and differences in gene expression between studies, allowing for novel conclusions about the effects of spaceflight.
conclusions: The GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline (RCP) facilitates the analysis of spaceflight multi-omics data by providing a standardized and transparent data processing method. The RCP enables data reproducibility and encourages cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects resulting from the spaceflight environment.
relationships: The pipeline integrates data, metadata, and biospecimens to fully utilize archived NASA Life Sciences data. It allows easier cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects that result from the spaceflight environment, independent of confounding factors.
insights: The RCP allows for the identification of differentially expressed genes and pathways affected by spaceflight. The pipeline also provides intermediate data files for users to perform custom analyses. The availability of processed data facilitates downstream analyses and allows for the identification of consistent gene expression changes across different spaceflight experiments.

title: Comprehensive multi-omics analysis reveals mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact
objective: To collect, curate, and provide access to omics data from biospecimens flown in space or exposed to simulated space stressors, maximizing their utilization and enabling the exploration of molecular network responses to space environments.
methodology: The GeneLab database collects genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic data from spaceflight and ground simulation experiments. Data processing standardization involves adopting community-derived standards for metadata and data processing. A new GeneLab Application Programming Interface (API) supports tools for the visualization of processed omics data.
results: The GeneLab database houses data from studies representing investigations of spaceflight experimental factors, including gravity level, ionizing radiation, circadian disruption, and atmospheric pressure, for a variety of biological organisms. Approximately half the studies are from experiments conducted in space, and the other half from ground-based environments. The database includes studies of protein expression, whole genome sequencing, metabolite profiling, metagenomics, epigenomics and epitranscriptomics.
conclusions: The GeneLab project aims to bring together a community of scientists to generate novel hypotheses and make valuable scientific discoveries using the data in the GeneLab database. The software architecture designed by GeneLab and its strategies around data and metadata harmonization will enable the development of the next generation of space risk models.
relationships: The GeneLab database connects to intramural and extramural systems through its API. It leverages the ISA experiment model for tagging data files with metadata and supports the linkage of data values. It collaborates with the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA).
insights: Mitochondrial stress is identified as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact. The growing amount of omics data and the guidelines from NASA emphasizing data submission to GeneLab are exciting developments for modellers. GeneLab plans to utilize machine learning algorithms and artificial intelligence (AI) to maximize the usage of its data, especially in the context of modelling and extrapolation to human risks.

title: A New Era for Space Life Science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
objective: To reveal the molecular etiologies of changes imposed on human physiology by spaceflight.
methodology: A multi-omics, systems biology analytical approach using biomedical profiles from fifty-nine astronauts and data from NASA’s GeneLab derived from hundreds of samples flown in space, to determine transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic responses to spaceflight. Analysis of human cell models, mouse tissues, and data from the NASA Twin Study.
results: Significant enrichment for mitochondrial processes, as well as innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, circadian rhythm, and olfactory functions. Altered mitochondrial function and DNA damage in urine and blood, indicating mitochondrial stress as a consistent phenotype of spaceflight. Spaceflight effects were more evident in isolated cells than whole organs. The liver undergoes more differential gene and protein expression changes than other organs.
conclusions: Systemic shifts in mitochondrial function occur in spaceflight, impacting innate immunity, lipid metabolism, and gene regulation. Mitochondrial dysregulation is a central hub for space biology. These findings can guide new interventions and studies to increase the viability of long-term human-crewed space missions.
relationships: Mitochondrial changes likely impact processes such as innate immunity, lipid metabolism, and gene regulation in both mice and humans. Muscle loss may relate to increased metabolic flux changes in spaceflight for the mouse liver versus muscle. Cardiovascular disease is linked to mitochondrial dysfunction through proteostasis failure related to lipid accumulation and ROS activity. Immune dysregulation is strongly influenced by the cell cycle.
insights: Spaceflight induces mitochondrial stress in multiple organisms. Increased oxidative stress and mitochondrial stress were implicated in causing androgenetic alopecia. The potential of targeting G protein-coupled receptor signaling as a spaceflight countermeasure should be investigated further. Countermeasures focused on re-establishing the mitochondrial function will also recuperate the proteostasis condition.

title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
objective: To enhance guidelines between space biologists globally, develop countermeasures for safe and effective crewed space missions, adapt plants and microbes for nutrient sources and bioregenerative life support, and limit pathogen infection.
methodology: Established ISSOP (International Standards for Space Omics Processing), an international consortium of scientists. Analyzed space omics experiments on model organisms (animals, plants, microbes) using epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metagenomics, and metabolomics. Integrated data from NASA GeneLab and other sources. Considered factors like hardware, sample collection, and preservation methods.
results: Identified challenges in space omics experiments, including limitations in space, time, and finances; hardware and housing issues; inconsistencies in sample collection and preservation; and the need for improved data curation and distribution. Showed substantial transcriptional differences in ground control rodents when only the habitat was changed. Highlighted the importance of reliable 1g controls and the need for consistent metadata collection.
conclusions: Improved standardization and communication at the international level are crucial for optimal extraction of actionable scientific insights from space omics data. ISSOP can develop space omics recommendations across individual assays and organisms. Careful standardization of space omics data may pave the way for cell space atlases and precision spaceflight medicine.
relationships: Explored relationships between spaceflight factors (radiation, microgravity, isolation) and biological responses in model organisms. Examined the impact of hardware and sample processing methods on omics data. Investigated the connection between spaceflight-induced changes and terrestrial diseases.
insights: Spaceflight presents unique technical and biological challenges for omics experiments. Standardization of sample processing and metadata normalization are essential for data harmonization and knowledge gain. International collaboration is necessary to address the complexities of space omics and develop effective countermeasures for crewed space exploration.

title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceﬂown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
objective: To integrate spaceflight transcriptomic data with terrestrial biomedical knowledge to identify physiological changes and potential health hazards associated with space travel.
methodology: Integrated NASA GeneLab transcriptomic datasets from six studies into the Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine (SPOKE).  Used gene expression data to generate gene-specific Propagated SPOKE Entry Vectors (PSEVs).  Compared node rank distributions between Ground vs. Baseline, Space vs. Baseline, and Space vs. Ground conditions using Welch's t-test to identify significant SPOKE nodes.
results: Identified significant SPOKE nodes related to space travel, including space motion sickness, regulation of blood vessel diameter, taste receptor complex, Vitamin D metabolism, and sympathetic nervous system.  Analysis revealed dysregulation of pathways related to apoptosis, cell metabolic process, and cell membrane integrity in multiple tissues.
conclusions: Integrating spaceflight transcriptomic data with a knowledge graph like SPOKE can effectively identify potential human physiological changes and health hazards associated with space travel by linking gene expression changes to higher-order phenotypes.
relationships: Identified relationships between differentially expressed genes and key SPOKE nodes, revealing potential pathways and mechanisms underlying spaceflight-related health risks.
insights: The study demonstrates the utility of knowledge graphs for translating molecular changes observed in spaceflight experiments to clinically relevant phenotypes, suggesting potential targets for countermeasures and personalized risk assessment for astronauts.

title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
objective: To develop a standardized pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments and to make space-relevant multi-omics data more accessible and reusable.
methodology: A consensus pipeline was developed including quality control (FastQC, MultiQC), read trimming (TrimGalore), mapping (STAR), quantification (RSEM), and differential gene expression calculation/annotation (DESeq2). The pipeline was applied to RNA-seq datasets from spaceflight experiments.
results: The pipeline processes RNA-seq data, providing quality control metrics, mapping reads to the reference genome, quantifying gene expression, and identifying differentially expressed genes. The processed data and intermediate files are made publicly available.
conclusions: The standardized RNA-seq consensus pipeline (RCP) facilitates the analysis of spaceflight multi-omics data, promoting transparency, reproducibility, and cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects resulting from the spaceflight environment.
relationships: The pipeline integrates data, metadata, and biospecimens from various spaceflight experiments. It allows for cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects that result from the spaceflight environment, independent of confounding factors.
insights: The RCP provides consistently processed data, making space-relevant multi-omics data more accessible and reusable. It supports easier analysis of space-relevant data and allows easier cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects that result from the spaceflight environment.

title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos
objective: To elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain by integrating single-cell multiomics (transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) with spatial transcriptomics.
methodology: Single-nucleus multiomics (RNA and ATAC sequencing) and Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) were performed on brain tissue from female mice exposed to spaceflight and ground control mice. Data was analyzed using Seurat, Signac, Harmony, and other bioinformatics tools. Ligand-receptor interaction analysis, motif analysis, and spatial pattern analysis were also conducted.
results: Spaceflight induced alterations in neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission, particularly affecting the cortex, hippocampus, striatum, and neuroendocrine structures. Astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction were observed. Spaceflight-induced changes in the brain exhibited similarities with neurodegenerative disorders, marked by oxidative stress and protein misfolding. Metabolic pathway analysis indicated spaceflight-mediated inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters gene expression associated with neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and neuronal development in multiple brain regions, resembling neurological aging and neurodegeneration. Combined spatial transcriptomics and single-cell analysis are relevant techniques for future space biology research.
relationships: Ligand-receptor interaction analysis revealed interactions between astrocytes and neurons, suggesting spaceflight-mediated effects on astrocyte functions. Spatial pattern analysis using MISTy revealed changes in signaling pathways associated with individual cell types and their local neighborhood.
insights: Spaceflight-mediated disruption of neurogenesis, neuronal development, and synaptogenesis, including dopaminergic synapse formation in the striatum, may be a systemic impairment. Changes in circadian gene expression are consistent with circadian disruption as a major biological response to spaceflight. Similarities between spaceflight and some terrestrial CNS conditions suggest potential repurposing of anti-aging and neuroprotective therapeutics.

title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
objective: To highlight the role of the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) in providing accessible space-related biological and biomedical data and to promote open science practices within NASA.
methodology: The article is a commentary that describes the OSDR, its data standardization efforts, and its impact on space biology and biomedical research. It references specific articles and initiatives enabled by OSDR, including data from the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission.
results: The OSDR has successfully curated and standardized a wide array of space biological, space health, and mission telemetry data, making it findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR). This has enabled advanced analytics and groundbreaking discoveries in space biology and biomedical health.
conclusions: Open Science practices, facilitated by the OSDR, are crucial for advancing space exploration and improving human health on Earth. Collective efforts and open data drive substantial scientific progress, merging cosmic exploration with tangible benefits.
relationships: The OSDR collaborates with a large scientific community, including citizen scientists and NASA divisions like the Biological and Physical Sciences (BPS) Division and the Human Research Program (HRP). It also supports initiatives like the Transform to Open Science (TOPS) program.
insights: Open Science and data standardization, integrated with AI, can maximize the value of limited spaceflight data, leading to advancements in both space exploration and human health. The OSDR serves as a model for data sharing and collaborative scientific discovery.

title: NASA GeneLab derived microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens organisms in altered gravitational conditions.
objective: To provide a guide for accessing and analyzing Inspiration4 (I4) mission data in the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) and to facilitate research on the impact of commercial space travel on human physiology.
methodology: The study utilizes data from the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission, which includes omics and clinical assays from civilian astronauts. The data is accessed through the NASA OSDR, using programmatic access via GLOpenAPI. The analysis involves differential expression analysis and pathway enrichment visualization using tools like DESeq2 and fgsea.
results: Analyses of the I4 mission data have revealed insights into the interplay between space stressors and the immune system, cell-specific responses to spaceflight, rapid microbial interchange of the crew, and changes in the skin of astronauts. Enrichment analysis demonstrates pathway changes in post-flight samples compared to pre-flight conditions.
conclusions: The I4 mission data provides a valuable resource for understanding the effects of spaceflight on the human body. The open access of these datasets in the NASA OSDR provides a unique opportunity for the scientific community to further unlock profound insights into the consequences of space travel on the human body. This work sets a precedent for space agencies to establish comprehensive, post-mission health monitoring programs.
relationships: The study compares human spaceflight effects to previously characterized spaceflight consequences in model organisms. It also integrates multi-modal data, such as blood datasets, to unveil deeper connections between different biological responses.
insights: The integration of artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) in the analysis of biomedical data from the I4 mission holds great promise for uncovering patterns, correlations, and anomalies that might otherwise remain hidden. The establishment of standardized data formats, uniform units of measurement, ontological frameworks, and comprehensive metadata fields is imperative to ensure the seamless integration of new data types into a repository and to enhance the capacity for cross-study biological analyses.

title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA space life sciences data
objective: To review the effects of microgravity and other spaceflight environmental factors on Homo sapiens and Mus musculus, focusing on experiments conducted in actual or simulated microgravity to determine affected functionalities at the gene, cellular, or organ levels.
methodology: The study involved a review of microarray studies and datasets housed in the NASA GeneLab repository. Data was filtered by assay type (microarray), tissue, factor, and organisms (Mus musculus or Homo sapiens). Differential gene expression comparative meta-analysis was performed on the musculoskeletal system. Pearson correlation coefficients were calculated between gene counts in different datasets from the same tissue type. Data preprocessing and differential expression analysis procedures were conducted using the R programming language.
results: The review found that altered gravity environments cause physiological alterations to musculoskeletal, immune, cardiovascular, vestibular, integumentary, and nervous systems in both mice and humans. Specific effects included changes in muscle metabolism, bone formation, inflammatory response, T-cell activation, stem cell differentiation, and cell cycle disruption. Comparative meta-analysis highlighted overlap and reproducibility in differentially expressed genes within musculoskeletal tissues of each species, but limited overlap between species. Correlation analysis showed higher coefficients between datasets with subjects of the same sex under similar experimental conditions.
conclusions: Altered gravity environments induce multiple physiological changes in mammals. The musculoskeletal system shows some consistent gene expression changes within species, but human and mouse responses have limited overlap. Further research is needed to identify which differentially expressed gene signatures from Mus musculus are truly reflective of Homo sapiens response to altered gravity.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight conditions (altered gravity, radiation) and physiological changes in mammals, particularly focusing on gene expression changes in various tissues. It also explores the correlation between different experimental conditions and gene expression patterns.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of microgravity on mammalian physiology, emphasizing the importance of open science data repositories like NASA GeneLab. It also suggests potential targets for countermeasures to mitigate the negative effects of spaceflight on astronaut health.

title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice.
objective: To recognize the 30-year anniversary of data access through ALSDA and the 10-year anniversary of GeneLab, highlighting NASA's efforts in open science and data sharing for space biology research.
methodology: Review of NASA's space life sciences research programs, including ALSDA and GeneLab, and their evolution into the Open Science Data Repository (OSDR). Analysis of data collection, archiving, and standardization efforts.
results: The integration of ALSDA and GeneLab into OSDR has improved data accessibility and reusability. The OSDR hosts over 500 studies across all life forms, with curated metadata and accessible data files. The Analysis Working Group (AWG) ecosystem has expanded, contributing valuable insights to OSDR.
conclusions: A paradigm shift has occurred in modern space biosciences, where reliable data reuse is essential. NASA OSDR plays a leading role in this shift through a strong open science program. The OSDR is committed to expanding its data through collaborations and leveraging AI to enhance accessibility and reproducibility.
relationships: ALSDA and GeneLab merged to form the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR). OSDR collaborates with space agencies, institutions, and companies. GeneLab serves as the omics repository for the European Space Agency’s SciSpacE research program.
insights: Open and FAIR data are paramount for supporting scientific collaboration and gaining new knowledge in space biology. The integration of ALSDA and GeneLab has improved data accessibility and reusability. AI can enhance accessibility and reproducibility while streamlining data ingestion and interpretation.

title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice
objective: To determine how the lack of caveolae impacts lymphatic function, specifically fluid and macromolecule transport.
methodology: Lymphatic transport was measured in mice lacking caveolin-1 (CavKO) and mice with a LEC-specific Cav1 gene deletion (LyCav). Quantitative microlymphangiography, permeability assays, and collecting vessel contractility studies were performed in vivo and ex vivo.
results: Lymphatic architecture was largely unchanged in both CavKO and LyCav mice. Lymphatic conductance and permeability to 70kDa dextran were significantly higher in both CavKO mice and LyCav mice. Transport within the lymphatic system to the sentinel node was significantly reduced. Isolated collecting vessel studies identified significantly reduced phasic contractility when lymphatic endothelium lacks caveolae. Inhibition of nitric oxide synthase partially restored ex vivo vessel contractility.
conclusions: Macromolecule transport across lymphatics is increased with loss of caveolae, yet phasic contractility is reduced, resulting in reduced overall lymphatic transport function. Lymphatic caveolar biology is a key regulator of active lymphatic transport functions.
relationships: Caveolae are involved in multiple processes that control various aspects of lymphatic function. Deletion of Cav-1 has a dichotomous effect on different regions of the lymphatic network. Fluid or macromolecule uptake may be increased in the initial, peripheral lymphatic capillaries, but there is a downstream impairment of collecting vessel intrinsic capabilities when caveolae are absent.
insights: Caveolae play a role in cellular endo- and exocytosis, mechanosensing, and receptor localization that are particularly enriched in adipocytes and endothelial cells. Caveolae are involved in multiple process that control various aspects of lymphatic function. The intrinsic contraction rate and amplitude of lymphatic collecting vessels thus appears to be in part dependent on lymphatic endothelial cell caveolar functions.

title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
objective: To determine the similarities and differences between microbial communities and their growth under elevated moisture conditions in occupied spaces on Earth and the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Dust samples from the ISS and Earth-based residential homes were collected and incubated under varying equilibrium relative humidity (ERH) conditions (50%, 85%, and 100%). DNA was extracted, sequenced using Illumina MiSeq, and analyzed using the QIIME2 bioinformatics pipeline to identify fungal and bacterial taxonomy. Statistical analyses were performed to compare microbial diversity and abundance.
results: Fungal and bacterial communities differed significantly between Earth and ISS dust. Earth samples showed higher diversity compared to ISS samples. Under elevated moisture conditions, fungal communities in ISS dust changed more rapidly, with Aspergillus becoming dominant. Bacterial diversity was also significantly different, with Earth samples showing higher richness.
conclusions: The microbiome of dust from Earth is more diverse than that of the ISS. These community differences result in changes in microbial growth upon exposure to moisture. Understanding these differences is important for maintaining a healthy indoor microbiome on spacecraft, promoting crew health, spacecraft integrity, and planetary protection, especially with the advent of commercial space stations.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between moisture levels and microbial growth, and how different environmental conditions (Earth vs. ISS) influence microbial community composition. It also suggests a link between microbial diversity and potential health impacts.
insights: Microbial communities in the ISS are less diverse and more susceptible to changes in moisture conditions compared to Earth-based environments. This suggests that controlling moisture and understanding microbial responses are crucial for maintaining healthy indoor environments in spacecraft.

title: Aging and estrogen status: A possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
objective: To predict fungal growth in dust from the International Space Station (ISS) under varying moisture conditions using the time-of-wetness framework.
methodology: Dust samples from ISS vacuum bags were incubated at varying equilibrium relative humidity (ERH) levels (50-100%) for 2 weeks.
