Fungal and bacterial concentrations were quantified using qPCR. Microbial communities were analyzed using Illumina MiSeq sequencing. Scanning electron microscopy was used to visualize microbial growth. Total soluble organic carbon was also measured.
results: Increased fungal concentration was associated with elevated ERH conditions. Significant fungal growth occurred at 80-100% ERH. Bacterial concentration increased significantly at 90-100% ERH. Active fungal growth was observed at 85% and 100% ERH. Total soluble organic carbon significantly reduced after incubation at 100% ERH. Fungal growth predictions varied based on maximum ERH, with activation-limited growth at elevated conditions (85% ERH) and deactivation-limited growth at saturated conditions (100% ERH). Microbial diversity changed as ERH conditions altered.
conclusions: Moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded upon to include other spacecraft environmental factors. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can help better protect astronaut health, fortify spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection.
relationships: Elevated relative humidity facilitates rapid microbial growth, especially for fungi. The time-of-wetness framework can be applied to model fungal growth under varying ERH conditions. Fungal community composition differed by ERH condition. Moisture also impacted sample diversity.
insights: Even short exposures to varying elevated relative humidity can facilitate rapid microbial growth and microbial community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. The time-of-wetness framework can be used to model fungal growth in ISS dust. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can help better protect astronaut health, fortify spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection as human activity increases in low-Earth orbit, the moon, Mars, and beyond.

title: Chronic skeletal unloading of the rat femur: mechanisms and functional consequences of vascular remodeling.
objective: To determine whether modifications in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur are associated with changes in trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) with altered estrogen status in young and old female rats.
methodology: Young and old female rats were divided into groups with varying estrogen levels (intact, ovariectomized (OVX), OVX plus estrogen replacement). PNA endothelium-dependent vasodilation was assessed in vitro using acetylcholine. Trabecular bone volume of the distal femoral metaphysis was determined by microCT. The effects of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors on vasodilation were also evaluated.
results: In young rats, vasodilation was diminished by OVX and restored with estrogen replacement, corresponding with similar modifications in BV/TV. In old animals, vasodilation was unaffected by OVX but enhanced with estrogen replacement, with parallel changes in BV/TV. Vasodilation was correlated with BV/TV in old animals with low endogenous estrogen.
conclusions: Estrogen has parallel effects on vascular endothelial function and BV/TV, suggesting a coupling mechanism linking endothelium-dependent vasodilation to bone remodeling. In young rats, lowering circulating estrogen through ovariectomy impairs endothelium-dependent vasodilation and diminishes trabecular bone volume in the femur. Estrogen replacement following ovariectomy maintains and enhances both endothelium-mediated vasodilation and trabecular bone volume in young and old animals, respectively.
relationships: A strong correlation was found between estrogen-induced alterations in endothelium-mediated vasodilation and changes in trabecular bone volume in both young and old rats. In animals with low estrogen levels, a significant relationship between peak endothelium-dependent vasodilation and trabecular bone volume in the femur was observed.
insights: The study suggests a vascular coupling mechanism in bone, where bone vascular endothelial function is coupled to bone remodeling activity. Endothelial function and bone mass are related, even without the influence of estrogen.

title: Differential effects of aging and exercise on intra-abdominal adipose arteriolar function and blood flow regulation.
objective: To determine the effects of aging and exercise training on adipose tissue (AT) blood flow during exercise and the associated vasoconstrictor responses of AT-resistance arteries.
methodology: Young and old male Fischer 344 rats were divided into sedentary and exercise-trained groups. Blood flow was measured at rest and during exercise using radionuclide-tagged microspheres. Vasoconstrictor responses to norepinephrine (NE) and phenylephrine (PE) were assessed in isolated AT-resistance arteries. Myogenic vasoconstrictor responses were determined by increasing intraluminal pressure.
results: In old sedentary rats, AT blood flow increased during exercise, while it decreased in young sedentary rats. α-adrenergic and myogenic vasoconstriction were diminished in old sedentary rats. Exercise training improved vasoconstriction in old rats and normalized AT blood flow responses during exercise. Exercise training resulted in a similar AT hyperemic response between age groups during exercise and was associated with enhanced myogenic and α-adrenergic vasoconstriction of AT-resistance arteries from the OET group relative to OSed.
conclusions: Aging impairs the ability to modulate AT blood flow during exercise due to diminished vasoconstriction of AT arteries. Exercise training can augment vasoconstriction of AT arteries and mitigate age-related alterations in the regulation of AT blood flow during exercise.
relationships: Aging is associated with decreased vascular resistance in adipose tissue during exercise. Exercise training can improve vascular function in aged adipose tissue.
insights: The inability to properly regulate blood flow in adipose tissue with age may contribute to reduced exercise capacity. Exercise training can restore proper blood flow regulation in adipose tissue, potentially improving overall cardiovascular health in older individuals.

title: Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice.
objective: To determine the effects of microgravity on intrinsic vasomotor properties of mesenteric arteries and veins from mice flown on space shuttle missions, and to examine whether reductions in vasoconstrictor responsiveness persist after landing.
methodology: Mesenteric arteries and veins were isolated from female mice flown on space shuttle missions and ground-based control mice. Vasoconstrictor responses were evoked in arteries via norepinephrine (NE), potassium chloride (KCl), and caffeine, and in veins through NE across a range of intraluminal pressures. mRNA levels for ryanodine receptors were also analyzed.
results: Spaceflight diminished the magnitude and rapidity of mesenteric artery vasoconstriction to NE, KCl, and caffeine. Spaceflight also reduced arterial ryanodine receptor-3 mRNA levels. In mesenteric veins, there was diminished constriction to NE after flight. The impaired vasoconstriction persisted 1 day post-spaceflight but normalized after 5 days. Maximal diameter of mesenteric veins tended to be larger in the spaceflight mice.
conclusions: Spaceflight impairs vasoconstriction in mesenteric arteries and veins, potentially through a ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular Ca2+ release mechanism. These vascular changes could compromise the maintenance of arterial pressure during orthostatic stress upon return to Earth.
relationships: The impaired vasoconstriction is linked to reduced ryanodine receptor mRNA levels, suggesting a mechanism involving intracellular calcium handling. The study connects spaceflight-induced vascular changes to the clinical problem of orthostatic hypotension in astronauts.
insights: Microgravity induces a hyporesponsiveness of resistance arteries and veins to adrenergic stimuli. The dysfunction of vaso- and venoconstrictor mechanisms within the splanchnic vasculature likely plays a fundamental role in the altered hemodynamics during exercise and orthostasis upon return to Earth.

title: Spaceflight-induced alterations in cerebral artery vasoconstrictor, mechanical, and structural properties: Implications for elevated cerebral perfusion and intracranial pressure
objective: To determine whether chronic skeletal unloading alters femoral bone and marrow perfusion and vascular resistance during reloading, and whether changes in bone blood flow during reloading are associated with structural remodeling of the femoral principal nutrient artery (PNA).
methodology: Six-month-old male Sprague-Dawley rats were subjected to 7 or 14 days of hindlimb unloading (HU) or served as weight-bearing controls. Bone perfusion was measured following 10 minutes of reloading. Histomorphometry was used to determine PNA media wall thickness and maximal diameter. Arterial shear stress and circumferential wall stress were calculated.
results: Femoral perfusion was lower in the distal metaphyseal region of 7-day HU rats and in multiple regions of 14-day HU rats during reloading. Vascular resistance was higher in all regions of the femur in 14-day HU rats during reloading. Intraluminal diameter and medial wall thickness of PNAs from 14-day HU rats were smaller than those of controls. Decreases in both shear stress and circumferential stress occurred in the PNA with HU, later returning to control levels with reductions in PNA maximal diameter and wall thickness.
conclusions: Chronic skeletal unloading attenuates the ability to increase blood flow and nutrient delivery to bone and marrow with immediate acute reloading, due in part to a remodeling of the bone resistance vasculature. The remodeling of bone resistance arteries appears to be driven by alterations in mechanical forces within the arterial vasculature that were induced during the unloading treatment.
relationships: Skeletal unloading decreases long bone blood flow and impairs the ability of the vasculature to augment bone and marrow blood flow upon reloading. This diminished hyperemic response results from elevations in vascular resistance and is associated with remodeling of the resistance vasculature. Arterial remodeling maintains shear stress and circumferential wall stress through decreases in maximal diameter and medial wall thickness.
insights: Prolonged skeletal disuse impairs the ability of the vasculature to augment bone and marrow blood flow upon reloading, potentially leading to bone ischemia during reloading or physical activity. The structural narrowing of resistance arteries could limit bone and marrow blood flow capacity.

title: Exercise training augments regional bone and marrow blood flow during exercise.
objective: To evaluate the risk of visual acuity impairments associated with spaceflight and identify potential causes and countermeasures.
methodology: Review of existing long-duration flight data, ocular, cardiovascular, and central nervous system adaptations, and ground-based analog studies (bed rest, parabolic flight).
results: Identified a subset of crewmembers experiencing visual performance decrements, cotton-wool spot formation, choroidal fold development, optic-disc edema, optic nerve sheath distention, and/or posterior globe flattening. These changes define the visual impairment/intracranial pressure (VIIP) syndrome. Increased intracranial pressure is a leading hypothesis.
conclusions: Microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift and commensurate changes in physiology play a significant role in VIIP. Venous congestion in the brain and/or eye may be a unifying pathologic mechanism. Enhanced occupational monitoring and further research are needed.
relationships: Ocular, cardiovascular, and central nervous systems are evaluated to understand the risk of developing VIIP syndrome. Increased intracranial pressure, localized ocular changes, decreased venous compliance, and alterations in cerebrospinal fluid dynamics are proposed to explain visual acuity and structural changes.
insights: Astronauts are exposed to microgravity and cephalad-fluid shift, and both symptomatic and asymptomatic astronauts have exhibited optic nerve sheath edema. There is a high probability that all astronauts have idiopathic intracranial hypertension to some degree, and that those susceptible have a high likelihood of developing either choroidal folds or optic-disc edema.

title: Effects of Skeletal Unloading on the Vasomotor Properties of the Rat Femur Principal Nutrient Artery
objective: To determine whether exercise training improves hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow distribution at rest and during exercise in rats.
methodology: Male Sprague-Dawley rats were divided into exercise-trained (ET) and sedentary (SED) groups. The ET group underwent treadmill training for 10-12 weeks. Blood flow to different regions of the femur, tibia, and fibula was measured at rest and during low-intensity exercise using the reference sample microsphere method.
results: Exercise hyperemia (increased blood flow) was observed in the femoral diaphysis of ET rats during exercise. While exercise hyperemia occurred in 3 of 9 hindlimb bone regions in SED rats, it occurred in 7 of 9 regions in ET rats. Body mass was greater in SED animals than in ET animals.
conclusions: Exercise training increases generalized hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow during physical activity. This may augment medullary pressure and bone interstitial fluid flow, benefiting bone integrity.
relationships: Exercise training enhances endothelium-dependent vasodilation in bone resistance arteries. Increased bone blood flow during exercise may generate osteogenic signals via paracrine effects and/or augmentation of bone interstitial fluid flow.
insights: Regular exercise can improve bone health by increasing blood flow to bones and bone marrow, potentially leading to better bone remodeling and strength.

title: Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms in the ZDF rat.
objective: To evaluate the risk of visual impairment and intracranial pressure (ICP) changes in astronauts due to microgravity exposure during spaceflight.
methodology: Review of existing long-duration flight data, spaceflight physiology, ocular evidence, cardiovascular adaptations, and central nervous system adaptations. Analysis of astronaut medical data, including ophthalmic examinations, MRI scans, and lumbar punctures. Examination of ground-based analogs such as bed rest studies and parabolic flights.
results: Fifteen long-duration astronauts experienced visual and anatomical changes, including optic-disc edema, globe flattening, choroidal folds, and hyperopic shifts. Some astronauts exhibited elevated ICP. Microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift is suspected to play a significant role. Ocular, cardiovascular, and central nervous system changes were observed. Elevated CO2 levels and high sodium diet may contribute. Exercise may have a mitigating effect.
conclusions: Microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift and related physiological changes are likely contributors to visual impairment and intracranial pressure alterations in astronauts. Further research is needed to address knowledge gaps and develop effective countermeasures. Individual susceptibility, genetic factors, and environmental factors may play a role.
relationships: Identified relationships between cephalad fluid shifts, venous congestion, intracranial pressure, intraocular pressure, and visual changes. Also explored the relationship between cardiovascular adaptations, central nervous system adaptations, and ocular health in the context of spaceflight.
insights: The study highlights the complex interplay of factors contributing to VIIP syndrome. It suggests that a combination of physiological changes, environmental factors, and individual predispositions may increase the risk of visual impairment and intracranial pressure alterations during long-duration spaceflight. Further research is needed to develop targeted countermeasures and identify astronauts at higher risk.

title: Spaceflight on the Bion-M1 biosatellite alters cerebral artery vasomotor and mechanical properties in mice
objective: To determine whether skeletal vascular control mechanisms are altered during the progression of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in the Zucker diabetic fatty (ZDF) rat, and to determine the effects of frank T2DM on hindlimb bone and marrow blood flow and vascular conductance.
methodology: In vitro and in vivo experiments using lean and obese ZDF rats at pre-diabetic, short-term diabetic, and long-term diabetic stages.  Vascular responses of the femoral principal nutrient artery (PNA) were assessed via acetylcholine, sodium nitroprusside, potassium chloride, and norepinephrine. Bone and marrow perfusion were measured using radiolabeled microspheres. Peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT) was used to measure bone mineral density.
results: Few adverse effects of the pre-diabetic and short-term diabetic conditions were observed on the vasodilator or vasoconstrictor properties of the femoral PNA. With long-term diabetes, the PNA shifted toward a more pro-vasoconstrictor phenotype, evidenced by decreased endothelium-dependent and -independent vasodilation, enhanced noradrenergic and myogenic vasoconstrictor responsiveness, and decreased passive mechanical distensibility. Bone and marrow blood flow and vascular conductance were impaired with long-term T2DM. Femur BMD was positively associated with endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the femoral PNA.
conclusions: Long-term diabetes induces a pro-vasoconstrictor phenotype in the bone resistance vasculature, leading to decreased bone and marrow blood flow and vascular conductance. This impairment of the bone circulation may contribute to bone loss during the progression of T2DM.
relationships: Endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the femoral PNA is positively associated with femur BMD in pre-diabetic, short-term diabetic, and long-term diabetic states. Decreased bone blood flow and vascular conductance are associated with the progression of T2DM.
insights: The study highlights the importance of vascular health in maintaining bone health, particularly in the context of T2DM.  Impairment of the bone circulation may be a key factor contributing to osteopenia in chronic T2DM.

title: Apollo Lunar Astronauts Show Higher Cardiovascular Disease Mortality: Possible Deep Space Radiation Effects on the Vascular Endothelium
objective: To investigate the potential link between deep space radiation exposure during Apollo lunar missions and increased cardiovascular disease mortality in astronauts.
methodology: Analysis of existing mortality data from Apollo lunar astronauts, combined with physiological evidence and consideration of spaceflight-induced cardiovascular adaptations and potential radiation effects.
results: Apollo lunar astronauts exhibit a higher incidence of cardiovascular disease mortality compared to non-lunar astronauts. This may be linked to deep space radiation exposure affecting the vascular endothelium.
conclusions: Deep space radiation exposure may contribute to increased cardiovascular disease risk in astronauts. Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms and develop countermeasures.
relationships: Explores the relationship between spaceflight, radiation, cardiovascular health, intracranial pressure, and visual impairment.
insights: Microgravity-induced fluid shifts, altered carbon dioxide metabolism, and high sodium intake may contribute to visual impairment and intracranial pressure changes during spaceflight. Exercise and pharmaceutical treatments could potentially counteract these effects.

title: Effects of age and exercise training on coronary microvascular smooth muscle phenotype and function
objective: To determine the effects of age and exercise training on contractile function and phenotype of vascular smooth muscle in coronary arterioles of rats.
methodology: Young and old rats were subjected to exercise training or remained sedentary. Contractile responses, smooth muscle proliferation, and contractile protein expression were assessed in isolated coronary arterioles using techniques such as immunohistochemistry, immunoblotting, and vasoconstrictor response evaluation.
results: Age impaired contractile function in coronary arterioles, shifting smooth muscle to a secretory phenotype with proliferation. Expression of SM1 decreased, while phospho-histone H3 and rpS6 increased. Exercise training improved contractile responses, reduced smooth muscle proliferation and rpS6 expression, and increased SM1 expression in aged rats.
conclusions: Age-induced contractile dysfunction and phenotypic shift of coronary arteriolar smooth muscle contribute to impaired coronary blood flow. Exercise training can restore contractile responsiveness and a younger smooth muscle phenotype.
relationships: Aging is related to decreased contractile function of coronary arterioles and a shift towards a secretory, synthetic phenotype. Exercise training is related to reversing these age-induced changes, restoring contractile function and a younger phenotype.
insights: Late-life exercise training can reverse age-related decline in coronary microvascular function by restoring contractile function and reversing the phenotypic shift of vascular smooth muscle cells in coronary arterioles. Adiponectin signaling may play a role in these changes.

title: Impact of Spaceflight and Artificial Gravity on the Mouse Retina: Biochemical and Proteomic Analysis.
objective: To determine whether mortality rates due to cardiovascular disease (CVD) and other causes of death differ in non-flight astronauts, astronauts in low Earth orbit (LEO), and Apollo lunar astronauts; and to determine the long-term effects of simulated weightlessness and space-relevant total-body irradiation on vascular responsiveness in mice.
methodology: A retrospective cohort study was conducted on deceased astronauts, categorizing them into non-flight, LEO, and Apollo lunar groups. Mortality rates due to CVD, cancer, accidents, and other causes were compared. Additionally, mice were subjected to simulated weightlessness (hindlimb unloading) and/or total body irradiation (56Fe ions) to assess vascular function.
results: Apollo lunar astronauts showed a significantly higher mortality rate due to CVD compared to non-flight and LEO astronauts. Simulated space radiation impaired endothelium-dependent vasodilation in mice, mediated through reduced nitric oxide signaling and increased reactive oxygen species.
conclusions: Deep space travel may pose a greater risk to cardiovascular health than previously estimated, potentially due to exposure to galactic cosmic rays. Space radiation induces long-lasting vascular dysfunction, potentially leading to atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
relationships: Exposure to space radiation is associated with increased cardiovascular mortality in Apollo lunar astronauts. Simulated space radiation impairs vascular function in mice. Weightlessness does not appear to have a sustained effect on vascular endothelial cell dysfunction.
insights: The study suggests that the unique radiation environment of deep space, particularly exposure to HZE particles, may contribute to increased cardiovascular risk. The findings highlight the need for further research into the long-term cardiovascular effects of space travel and the development of countermeasures to mitigate these risks.

title: Simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct neurovascular and structural remodeling of skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries in the rat
objective: To investigate the effects of spaceflight on oxidative stress and apoptosis in retinal endothelial cells and to identify spaceflight-induced changes in protein expression profiles in mouse ocular tissue. Also, to determine whether artificial gravity (AG) during spaceflight could mitigate any detrimental effects of microgravity on the retina.
methodology: Nine-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were launched to the ISS for a 35-day mission under microgravity (µg) or artificial gravity (µg + 1 g) conditions. Habitat control (HC) and vivarium control mice lived on Earth. Ocular tissue was assessed using immunocytochemical analysis (TUNEL assay), immunohistochemistry (4-HNE), and proteomics (LC/MS). Protein expression profiles were analyzed using Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA).
results: Spaceflight induced significant apoptosis in retinal endothelial cells in the µg group compared to all other groups. Proteomic analysis showed alterations in key pathways responsible for cell death, cell repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress in µg mice compared to HC animals. Artificial gravity provided some protection against these changes.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells and changes in proteomic profiles, potentially leading to tissue injury and neurodegeneration. Artificial gravity can mitigate some of the effects of weightlessness during spaceflight.
relationships: Spaceflight conditions induce oxidative stress-related signaling pathways. Cap-Gly domain containing linker protein 2 (CLIP2) was significantly down-regulated in both µg and µg + 1 g groups. Methyl-CpG-binding protein 2 (MECP2) had the highest fold changes in ﬂight mice (µg group) compared to HC.
insights: The study provides evidence that spaceflight induces retinal apoptosis of vascular endothelial cells and changes in retinal protein expression related to cellular structure, immune response and metabolic function, and that artificial gravity (AG) provides some protection against these changes. These retinal cellular responses may affect blood–retinal barrier (BRB) integrity, visual acuity, and impact the potential risk of developing late retinal degeneration.

title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina
objective: To test the hypothesis that hindlimb unloading (HU) exerts diverse effects on the neurovascular density, structural properties, and functional vasoconstrictor responsiveness of skeletal muscle and cutaneous feed arteries in the rat forelimb and hindlimb regions, simulating microgravity.
methodology: Male Wistar rats were subjected to HU for 2 weeks. Skeletal muscle arteries (deep brachial and sural) and skin arteries (median and saphenous) were examined in vitro using wire myography or isobaric perfusion and glyoxylic acid staining to assess structural and functional properties.
results: HU increased lumen diameter and vasoconstrictor responsiveness in forelimb skeletal muscle arteries but decreased these properties in hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries. Cutaneous vasculature showed smaller changes. HU diminished sympathetic nerve density and impaired vasoconstriction induced by sympathetic nerve stimulation in hindlimb cutaneous arteries, while increasing sensitivity to vasoconstrictors.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity differentially affects skin and skeletal muscle arteries in the hindlimb. Functional alterations in skeletal muscle arteries result from direct effects of physical forces, while changes in cutaneous arteries are governed by the effect of transmural pressure on sympathetic innervation. These adaptations could underlie weaker arterial vasoconstriction during sympathetic nerve activation and reduced vascular resistance following a return to Earth.
relationships: HU induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries. Hyper-sensitivity of the saphenous artery to vasoconstrictors appears to result from the shortage of trophic sympathetic influence. HU impaired sympathetically induced arterial vasoconstriction, consistent with the decreased sympathetic constrictor response in humans following space flight.
insights: The complexity of vascular adaptations to simulated microgravity is greater than previously described, with alterations occurring differentially between and within body regions. These changes are functionally related to physical alterations in sympathetic nerve density and gross structural remodeling of resistance arteries, highlighting the importance of mechanical forces and sympathetic control in vascular adaptation to altered gravitational environments.

title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina
objective: To determine whether spaceflight induces epigenomic and transcriptomic reprogramming in the mouse retina and alters the epigenetic clock.
methodology: Mice were flown for 37 days on the International Space Station. Retinas were isolated, and DNA methylome and transcriptome were determined by deep sequencing. Differentially methylated genes (DMGs) and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified and analyzed.
results: Spaceflight induced significant DNA methylation changes and decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock. A large number of genes were differentially methylated, with fewer differentially expressed genes at the transcriptome level. Several biological pathways involved in retinal diseases were significantly altered.
conclusions: Spaceflight impacts the retina at the epigenomic and transcriptomic levels, and such changes could be involved in the etiology of eye-related disorders among astronauts. Retinal cell homeostasis was disrupted during spaceflight, impacting genes related to oxidative stress, inflammation, mitochondrial function, tissue remodeling, fibrosis, and angiogenesis.
relationships: Identified differentially methylated genes (DMGs) and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between spaceflight and ground control mice. Integration analysis of genes regulated at both transcription and DNA methylation levels revealed that the genes involved in ECM and focal adhesion were the main regulatory targets in the retinas by spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight decelerated the epigenetic clock in the mouse retina, suggesting an activation of remodeling or compensatory pathways. The study provides new insights into the visual impairment due to long-duration spaceflight.

title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
objective: To examine the morphological development of otolith vestibular receptors in quail, focusing on epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation during development.
methodology: The study used Japanese quail embryos and adults. Techniques included scanning electron microscopy (SEM), immunohistochemistry, neural tracing with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and biotinylated dextran amine (BDA), and anatomical reconstructions. Macular growth was measured using video microscopy. Hair cell planar polarity and density were determined from SEM micrographs. Apoptosis was assessed using the TUNEL method. Statistical analyses included ANOVA and Pearson correlations.
results: Otolith maculae epithelial areas increased exponentially during embryonic development. Hair cell density maturation rates were faster in striolar regions compared to extrastriolar regions. Stereocilia polarization was initiated early, with reversal zones forming at E8. Programmed cell death increased significantly at E14. Three afferent types (calyx, dimorph, bouton) exhibited specific regional distributions in the adult utricle. Bouton afferents develop first, followed by dimorph and then calyx afferents.
conclusions: Type II hair cells develop first, followed by type I hair cells. Planar cell polarity patterns migrate during embryogenesis to reach an adult topographic form. Bouton afferents develop first, with calyceal terminals forming later on dimorph afferents, and true calyx afferents appearing last. The regional distribution of afferent terminals in the adult quail utricle is similar to that reported for pigeons.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between hair cell development, stereocilia polarization, and afferent innervation patterns in the vestibular system. It also suggests a possible trans-differentiation process where bouton fibers develop into dimorph units, and some dimorph fibers further differentiate into calyx afferents.
insights: The development of vestibular otolith receptors involves a complex interplay of cellular proliferation, programmed cell death, and differentiation. Hair cell polarization and afferent innervation patterns are established early in development and undergo significant changes before reaching their adult form. The findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the formation of functional vestibular circuits.

title: Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals
objective: To characterize canal-otolith convergence onto single non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex (VNC) of pigeons using simple motion stimuli.
methodology: Extracellular recordings were obtained from single neurons in the vestibular nuclei of alert pigeons during sinusoidal rotational and translational stimuli. Earth-vertical axis (EVA) rotations were used to characterize neural responses to canal inputs. Linear translations were used to characterize responses to otolith inputs. Earth-horizontal axis (EHA) rotations were used to characterize responses to combined canal and otolith stimulation. Data analysis involved fitting sinusoidal functions to stimulus feedback and firing rate data to evaluate neural sensitivity and phase.
results: Convergent neurons in the VNC were sensitive to both rotational and linear translational motion. Canal-related spatial preferences were more closely related to behavior than to canal afferents. Convergent canal- and otolith-related responses were spatially aligned, such that both response components would be maximally stimulated by EHA rotation around the same axis. However, the sensitivity and phase values predicted for these inputs during EHA rotation were not matched.
conclusions: Convergent neurons in the pigeon VNC exhibit spatial alignment between canal and otolith inputs, but the sensitivity and phase values are mismatched. Linear summation of canal and otolith inputs does not accurately predict the net response to EHA rotation, suggesting nonlinear integration of these inputs. This study suggests that the functional role of otolith signals in pigeons is to cooperate with primarily canal-driven reflexes.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between canal and otolith inputs in the vestibular system and their contribution to compensatory eye and head movements during motion.
insights: The spatial alignment of convergent inputs in NEM neurons suggests a mechanism for integrating canal and otolith signals to enhance gaze stability during rotation relative to gravity. The mismatched sensitivity and phase values, along with the nonlinear integration of inputs, indicate a complex processing of vestibular information in the brainstem.

title: Simulated Microgravity Enhances Oligodendrocyte Mitochondrial Function and Lipid Metabolism
objective: To investigate the role of the L-type CaV1.2 voltage-gated calcium channel in regulating OPG expression in the middle and inner ear, and its effect on bone modeling and auditory/vestibular function.
methodology: Utilized Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mutant mice to increase Ca2+ signaling in auditory ossicles and otic capsule. Assessed morphology via μCT and histology. Measured gene expression (Opg, Rankl, Alpl, Runx2, Sp7) using RT-qPCR. Evaluated auditory function via Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) and vestibular function via open field and rotarod tests.
results: Increased Ca2+ signaling via CaV1.2TS resulted in thicker auditory ossicles and otic capsules with increased bone mass. μCT confirmed bone thickening and narrowed cavities. Histology showed excessive bone and reduced osteoclasts. Opg mRNA expression was upregulated, while Rankl remained unchanged. ABR testing revealed hearing loss, and behavioral tests indicated impaired vestibular function.
conclusions: Ca2+ influx through CaV1.2 regulates auditory ossicle and otic capsule development. Excessive Ca2+ influx causes hearing and balance deficits due to abnormal bone growth, potentially mediated by altered OPG levels and osteoclast activity. This suggests a role for CaV1.2 in otosclerosis.
relationships: CaV1.2 regulates OPG expression, which affects osteoclast activity and bone remodeling in the ear. Increased Ca2+ signaling through CaV1.2TS inhibits osteoclastogenesis via the OPG/RANKL/RANK pathway, leading to increased bone formation and reduced bone resorption.
insights: Modulating Ca2+ signaling via CaV1.2 in auditory ossicles and the otic capsule regulates osteoclastogenesis and bone remodeling. The findings suggest a potential therapeutic target for otosclerosis and other bony disorders of the ear, potentially linking to the effects of fluoride on calcium homeostasis.

title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
objective: To determine how simulated microgravity impacts energy and lipid metabolism in oligodendrocytes (OLs).
methodology: Cultured human oligodendrocytes (OLs) in simulated microgravity (sim-μG) using a 3D-clinostat and compared them to cultures in normal gravity (1G). Measured mitochondrial respiration (OCR), glycolysis (ECAR), and analyzed the secretome for changes in metabolites using mass spectrometry.
results: Sim-μG enhanced mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis in OLs. The secretome of OLs in sim-μG showed increased levels of citrate, aconitate, fumarate, and malate, suggesting increased TCA cycle flux. Lipid synthesis was also enhanced, with increased levels of fatty acids, cholesterol, and complex lipids like phosphatidyl ethanolamine.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity enhances energy production and lipid metabolism in oligodendrocytes, potentially preserving and enhancing metabolic reactions required for membrane synthesis and myelinogenesis. This suggests that microgravity could be used to produce OLs faster and in adequate numbers for cell replacement therapies.
relationships: Simulated microgravity elicits higher respiration rates in human OLs. Lipid synthesis is enhanced by simulated microgravity. OLs in sim-μG require more energy than in 1G.
insights: Microgravity induces significant changes in OL metabolism, enhancing both energy production and lipid synthesis. This may be beneficial for myelin formation and could have implications for treating myelin deficiencies. The study also suggests that the absence of gravity presents a unique opportunity to gain new insights into basic neural development and function.

title: Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight
objective: To determine how the space environment influences human-induced pluripotent stem cell-derived NSCs, their biology, and their ability to differentiate into neurons.
methodology: Human NSCs, derived from induced pluripotent stem cells, were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 39.3 days.  Two types of experiments were performed: (1) active experiments where the medium was changed during spaceflight with BrdU incorporation to measure proliferation, and (2) passive experiments where cells remained in the same medium for the duration of the flight.  Upon return, cells were analyzed for stemness markers, proliferation (BrdU incorporation), metabolic activity (oxygen consumption and glycolysis), and ability to differentiate into neurons via electrophysiological recordings.
results: NSCs in space proliferated and maintained their stemness. They exhibited higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis compared to ground controls, indicating a higher metabolic state.  Space-flown NSCs retained the ability to differentiate into immature neurons, displaying small capacitance, high input resistance, and incipient action potentials. Spontaneous synaptic activity was not apparent, suggesting immaturity.
conclusions: Microgravity does not prevent human NSCs from proliferating and maintaining their stemness.  The increased energy metabolism observed in space-flown NSCs may contribute to visual impairment and intracranial pressure syndrome in astronauts. Microgravity may offer a strategy to increase neural cell numbers for cell replacement therapies.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between microgravity, NSC proliferation, energy metabolism, and potential neurological issues in astronauts. It also highlights the potential of microgravity as a tool for expanding neural cell populations for therapeutic purposes.
insights: Human NSCs respond to the space environment by maintaining their stemness and proliferative capacity, coupled with increased metabolic activity.  This response may have implications for astronaut health and offers potential for novel cell-based therapies for neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space
objective: To correct an error in Figure 10 of a previous publication regarding the expression of transferrin (Tf) and GPDH in GC-OLPs and SPC-OLPs under microgravity conditions.
methodology: The study involved microscopic analysis of GC-OLPs and SPC-OLPs, focusing on the expression and localization of Tf and GPDH. Statistical significance was assessed by one-way ANOVA.
results: An error in the legend of Figure 10 was identified, where 'Fer' (ferritin) was incorrectly used instead of 'Tf' (transferrin). The corrected figure shows that GC-OLPs expressed Tf in their cytoplasm and co-expressed GPDH. SPC-OLPs expressed Tf in their nuclei and weakly expressed GPDH, primarily in cells undergoing karyokinesis or cytokinesis. In the GC group, 34% co-expressed both markers, while 51% expressed transferrin alone, and 41% expressed GPDH only. In the case of SPC-OLPs, only 58% co-expressed Tf in the nucleus and cytoplasmic GPDH.
conclusions: The correction of the figure legend does not affect the scientific conclusions of the original publication. The corrected data clarifies the expression patterns of Tf and GPDH in OLPs under microgravity conditions, highlighting differences between GC-OLPs and SPC-OLPs.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between microgravity and the expression of specific markers (Tf and GPDH) in oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OLPs). It also explores the relationship between the maturation stage of OLPs (GC vs. SPC) and their marker expression patterns.
insights: The correction provides a more accurate representation of the experimental findings, emphasizing the importance of precise labeling and data representation in scientific publications. The study suggests that microgravity may influence the maturation and marker expression of OLPs, with potential implications for understanding neurological conditions and spaceflight-related health issues.

title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
objective: To investigate the impact of space microgravity (SPC-µG) on neural stem cells (NSCs) and determine its consequences on neural and cognitive functions, particularly focusing on cell division abnormalities.
methodology: Human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived NSCs were exposed to space microgravity (SPC-µG) on the International Space Station (ISS) for 39.6 days. Ground control NSCs were maintained under similar conditions on Earth. Time-lapse microscopy was used to observe and quantify cell division abnormalities, including incomplete cell division (ICD) and multi-daughter cell division (MDCD). The secretome (secreted medium) from space-flown cells was collected and applied to naïve NSCs to assess its effects. Immunofluorescence was performed to examine the expression of NSC markers (Nestin and Tubulin).
results: SPC-µG exposure resulted in enhanced proliferation of NSCs but also a statistically significant increase in abnormal cell divisions (ACD), including ICD and MDCD, particularly two weeks post-flight. Naïve NSCs treated with the secretome from space-flown NSCs also exhibited similar abnormalities in cell division. Immunofluorescence showed altered expression of Nestin and Tubulin in SPC-µG exposed NSCs.
conclusions: Space microgravity induces cellular effects that increase abnormalities in single-cell division in NSCs. The secretome produced by SPC-NSCs appears to mediate these effects, suggesting the involvement of secreted factors. These findings highlight potential health risks associated with long-term space travel, including increased susceptibility to neurological disorders and cancer.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between space microgravity, altered NSC behavior (proliferation and abnormal cell division), and potential health risks for astronauts. It also suggests a link between the secretome of space-flown NSCs and the observed cellular abnormalities.
insights: Space microgravity can significantly impact neural stem cell division, potentially leading to genomic instability and increased cancer risk. The secretome of space-flown cells plays a crucial role in mediating these effects. Further research is needed to identify the specific molecules in the secretome responsible for the observed abnormalities and to develop countermeasures to protect astronauts' health during long-term space missions.

title: Metabolomics profile of the secretome of space-flown oligodendrocytes.
objective: To examine the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight and to study the secretome of OLPs exposed to space microgravity (SPC-OLPs) and compare it with ground control (GC) cells, in order to understand the causes of intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) in astronauts.
methodology: Time-lapse microscopy was used to examine OLP behavior after space flight. Proteomic analysis was performed on the secretome of space-flown OLPs and compared to ground control cells. Neural stem cells were obtained from human induced pluripotent stem cells and converted to OLPs. OLPs were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 38 days. Upon return, cell proliferation, cytokinesis, and autophagy were studied. Mass spectrometry was used to analyze the secretome proteomic profile.
results: Space-flown OLPs showed increased proliferation compared to ground control cells, with a subpopulation exhibiting a much faster cell cycle. A small percentage of space-flown OLPs displayed autophagy. Proteomic analysis of the secretome revealed upregulation of heat shock protein 90 alpha/beta (HSP-90αβ) and secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine (SPARC) in space-flown OLPs.
conclusions: Space flight enhances both proliferation and autophagy in OLPs. Upregulation of HSP-90αβ and SPARC in the secretome of space-flown OLPs may play a role in modulating cell proliferation and autophagy, potentially as a compensatory mechanism. These changes may contribute to intracranial hypertension in astronauts.
relationships: Microgravity impacts OLP development, potentially contributing to ICP and VIIP in astronauts. HSP90αβ and SPARC are related to the behavior of space-flown OLPs, as well as to autophagy. SPARC induces endoplasmic reticulum stress, which leads to autophagy.
insights: The study provides insights into the effects of space flight on OLPs and suggests potential targets for mitigating intracranial hypertension in astronauts. Microgravity-induced changes in OLPs, including increased proliferation and autophagy, may persist upon return to Earth. Understanding the regulation of genes involved in proliferation and autophagy could lead to countermeasures for astronauts.

title: Metabolomic profiling of the secretome from human neural stem cells flown into space.
objective: To determine how space microgravity impacts the metabolomics profile of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) and to identify gravitational-sensitive molecules.
methodology: Human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived OLPs were cultured and flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 26 days. The secretome was collected and analyzed using ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (UHPLC/MS). Statistical analysis was performed to compare the metabolomic profiles of space-flown OLPs (SPC OLPs) with ground control OLPs (1G OLPs) and the culture medium alone.
results: Space-flown OLPs exhibited increased glutamate and energy metabolism. The secretome of SPC OLPs showed elevated levels of lactate, citrate, aconitate, alpha-ketoglutarate, succinate, fumarate, and malate compared to 1G OLPs. SPC OLPs also secreted more glutamate and glutamine. Post-flight, SPC OLPs displayed significantly increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis.
conclusions: Microgravity induces changes in the metabolic pathways of OLPs, including enhanced glutamate production and energy requirements. These changes do not appear to be deleterious and the cells remain functional. These findings suggest potential targets for addressing OLP maturation in myelin disorders.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between microgravity, OLP metabolism, and potential implications for neurological disorders like multiple sclerosis. It also connects energy metabolism and glutamate production in OLPs with their developmental stage.
insights: Space microgravity affects the metabolomic profile of OLPs, leading to increased energy demand and altered glutamate metabolism. These changes may contribute to maintaining OLPs in an immature state. Understanding these metabolic adaptations could provide insights into developing therapeutic strategies for myelin-deficient CNSs.

title: Strategies, research priorities, and challenges for the exploration of space beyond low-Earth orbit
objective: To ascertain gravity-sensitive small molecules secreted by neural stem cells (NSCs) after short-term exposure to space microgravity (µG) and to understand the adaptive changes that Central Nervous System (CNS) cells experience in a µG environment.
methodology: Human-induced pluripotent stem cell-derived NSCs were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 3 days. The secretome (conditioned culture medium) was collected and analyzed using metabolomics. Random Forest Analysis (RFA), Principal Component Analysis (PCA), and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis (HCA) were performed to identify and compare the metabolic profiles of space-flown NSCs (SPC-NSCs) and ground control NSCs (GC-NSCs).
results: Space-flown NSCs exhibited increased glycolysis, augmented pyruvate and glycerate levels, activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine, increased synthesis of NADH, and formation of polyamine spermidine compared to ground controls. A total of 221 biochemicals were identified with significantly different levels of expression between the NSCs-SPC and NSCs-GC secretomes.
conclusions: Microgravity induces a stress response in NSCs, leading to increased energy production through glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and amino acid catabolism, as well as increased spermidine production potentially related to autophagy. These adaptive mechanisms may help NSCs cope with the stress imposed by low gravity.
relationships: Microgravity affects the metabolic activity of neural stem cells, increasing their energy demands and triggering stress response mechanisms. These changes are interconnected, with glycolysis, the TCA cycle, BCAA catabolism, and NADH synthesis all contributing to increased energy production. Spermidine production suggests a link to autophagy, a cellular process involved in stress response and homeostasis.
insights: The study provides insights into the metabolic adaptations of neural stem cells in response to the space environment. The findings suggest that microgravity induces a stress response that leads to increased energy production and autophagy-like behavior. This information is valuable for understanding the potential impact of long-duration space travel on the central nervous system and for developing strategies to mitigate these effects.

title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
objective: To identify critical research gaps related to human behavior and performance in altered gravity and space, and to provide a roadmap for future space programs.
methodology: Literature review, expert working groups, community consultation, and analysis of previous spaceflight research and analog studies.
results: Identification of key neurobehavioral challenges associated with spaceflight, the need to consider sex as a biological variable, the use of integrative omics technologies, and the importance of understanding the neural representation of gravity. Also, the identification of four major future roadmaps including Behavioral Health & Performance, Human Physiology, Pharmacological Countermeasures, and Integrative Countermeasures.
conclusions: Addressing knowledge gaps related to neurobehavioral performance during space missions is critical for successful future exploration. Collaborative strategies across agencies and researchers are needed to foster an integrative approach.
relationships: The central nervous system (CNS) is affected by spaceflight stressors, leading to adaptations in brain structure and function. Visuo-spatial abilities and time evaluation are crucial for spatial relationships and operations. The vestibular system plays a role in brain plasticity and cognitive performance.
insights: Spaceflight research in neurocognitive science has benefits for the population on Earth, including insights into aging-related diseases and the development of innovative treatment strategies.

title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit.
objective: To discover proteomics changes that characterize the physiological adaptation of Arabidopsis to the spaceflight environment, specifically comparing proteomics of roots and leaves between plants grown in space and on Earth. A secondary goal was to examine proteomics based on samples preserved in RNAlater, a method widely used in ISS spaceflight biology research.
methodology: Arabidopsis seedlings from three GFP lines were grown on the ISS for 12 days and preserved in RNAlater.  Proteins were extracted from roots and leaves, digested, labeled with iTRAQ tags, and analyzed by mass spectrometry. Data was processed using ProteinPilot and Proteome Discoverer software, and functional annotation was assigned using Blast2GO suite and the Arabidopsis functional catalog. Statistical analysis (Fisher's test) was used to determine differences in protein abundance between spaceflight and ground control samples.
results: Over 1500 proteins were identified in root and leaf samples.  256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins showed statistically significant differential abundance in spaceflight samples compared to ground controls.  Only 41 differentially abundant proteins were shared between roots and leaves. Functional analysis revealed distinct patterns between leaves and roots, with leaves showing upregulation of stress/defense, photosynthesis, and translation-related proteins, and roots showing increased abundance of proteins related to cofactor metabolism and oxidative stress responses.
conclusions: Plants engage specific metabolic responses to accomplish physiological adaptation to spaceflight, and this response differs among organs (roots vs. leaves). RNAlater-preserved plant tissue can be used for broad-scale proteomics analysis of Arabidopsis spaceflight responses. Cell wall modifications, potentially governed by auxin signaling, may be a general and recurring metabolic adaptation in plants during spaceflight.
relationships: Comparison of proteomic data with previous gene expression studies showed a positive correlation between transcript and protein expression levels for a subset of genes.  Interaction network analysis of cell wall-related proteins revealed functional relationships among spaceflight-differential proteins involved in cell wall interactions and metabolism.
insights: Spaceflight induces organ-specific proteomic changes in Arabidopsis. Cell wall remodeling and auxin signaling are key processes affected by spaceflight.  Proteomics and transcriptomics data show some correlation, but regulatory processes involved in translation, localization, modification, and protein degradation play a substantial role in controlling protein expression.

title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways.
objective: To determine whether gravity has a direct role in establishing the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in primary roots of Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Examined spaceflight green fluorescent protein (GFP)-reporter gene expression in roots of transgenic lines of Arabidopsis thaliana (pDR5r::GFP, pTAA1::TAA1–GFP, pSCR::SCR–GFP to monitor auxin and pARR5::GFP to monitor cytokinin). Plants on the ISS were imaged live with the Light Microscopy Module (LMM) and compared with control plants imaged on the ground. Preserved spaceflight and ground control plants were examined post flight with confocal microscopy.
results: The distribution of auxin in the gravity-sensing portion of the root is not dependent on gravity. Spaceflight appears benign to auxin and its role in the development of the primary root tip, whereas spaceflight may influence cytokinin-associated processes. Plants in the microgravity of spaceflight establish an auxin distribution that is indistinguishable from that of a vertical orientation on Earth. The distribution of cytokinin was different in spaceflight as compared with ground control roots; plants on orbit showed a more restricted distribution of ARR5::GFP expression compared with ground controls.
conclusions: Auxin distributions of the primary root are not gravity dependent, even though these distributions are key to gravity responses. The auxin signaling system in roots was present in plants as a developmental system before evolving additional roles in gravity responses. Cytokinin may play a larger role in altered root growth strategies in the absence of gravity experienced during spaceflight.
relationships: Auxin and cytokinin exhibit different patterns of distribution between the spaceflight and ground environments. Cytokinins are counterpoints to auxin, including in the cross-talk among the root zones that plays a role in gravity responses.
insights: The study demonstrates the value of conducting experiments on the ISS to remove gravity from the environment and examine its role in fundamental biological processes. The findings challenge the assumption that gravity is essential for establishing auxin distribution in plant roots.

title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana
objective: To identify genes associated with root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana through transcription microarrays, comparing gene expression profiles of different ecotypes (WS and Col-0) under varying tilted growth conditions.
methodology: Arabidopsis ecotypes WS and Col-0 were grown at different angles (Agp 45°, 135°, and 90° as control). Root morphology was quantified. RNA was extracted from roots, and gene expression profiles were analyzed using microarrays. Differentially expressed genes were identified and validated using qRT-PCR. Data was normalized using RMA algorithm. Gene networks were visualized using GeneMANIA.
results: Identified 11 highly probable skew gene candidates (HPSGC) involved in processes like sugar transport, salt signaling, and response to darkness. WS roots skew significantly more than Col-0 roots at Agp 135°. Transcriptome comparisons revealed 92 candidate genes involved in skewing. Overlap of skew gene candidates narrowed the set to 16 genes.
conclusions: Environmental sensing pathways (salt, sugar, hormones, darkness) may drive root skewing behavior. The identified HPSGC are associated with environmental sensing upstream of physical growth differences. Further studies are needed to elucidate specific pathways and molecular mechanisms contributing to root skewing.
relationships: Root skewing is related to environmental interaction, touch responses, and gravitropic set-point angle. Hormone related pathways and processes are among the candidates, such as ethylene involvement in root waving and auxin and tryptophan biosynthesis in both skewing and waving. The cytoskeleton is also involved in skewing and waving.
insights: Root skewing is influenced by multiple genes and pathways, including hormone signaling, cell wall modification, and environmental responses. The study highlights the importance of considering both genetic and environmental factors in understanding root growth patterns.

title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?
objective: To characterize the T-DNA insertion sites within the DREB2A and LOX1 gene regions of the Arabidopsis mutant line SALK_084889 and analyze the expression levels of these genes under normal and stress conditions.
methodology: DNA-PCR and Sanger sequencing were used to identify T-DNA insertion sites. Quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) was used to analyze DREB2A and LOX1 expression levels in SALK_084889 and wild-type Arabidopsis (Col) under normal, drought, and heat stress conditions. Drought and heat tolerance were assessed by observing survival rates after stress treatments.
results: The T-DNA insertion was located in the 3' UTR of DREB2A and the promoter of LOX1 in SALK_084889. DREB2A expression was not downregulated under normal conditions but was affected in roots under drought. LOX1 was significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. SALK_084889 showed altered drought and heat tolerance compared to the wild type.
conclusions: The T-DNA insertion in SALK_084889 affects the expression of DREB2A and LOX1, leading to altered drought and heat responses. This provides valuable information for mutation analysis of these genes.
relationships: DREB2A is a key regulator of drought and heat response in Arabidopsis. LOX1 plays a critical role in lipid peroxidation. The T-DNA insertion in SALK_084889 disrupts the normal expression patterns of these genes, affecting the plant's ability to respond to stress.
insights: Characterization of T-DNA insertion lines like SALK_084889 is crucial for understanding gene function and stress response mechanisms in Arabidopsis. The altered expression of DREB2A and LOX1 in this mutant line highlights their importance in drought and heat tolerance.

title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T- DNA insertion line SALK_063500
objective: To determine if portions of the plant spaceflight response can be genetically removed without causing loss of spaceflight survival or increased stress responses.
methodology: Compared the spaceflight transcriptome responses in the root tips of two Arabidopsis ecotypes, Col-0 and WS, as well as that of a PhyD mutant of Col-0, grown with ambient light on the ISS and in darkness. RNAseq transcriptome profiling was used to measure the impact of the environment by manipulating the genotype of the plant.
results: PhyD plants displayed a significantly reduced spaceflight transcriptome response compared to Col-0 in ambient light. The WS genotype showed an even simpler spaceflight transcriptome response. In the dark, the WS genotype mounted a larger transcriptome response than Col-0. Root length was not significantly different among genotypes grown on orbit.
conclusions: Much of the plant response to spaceflight is potentially non-adaptive, as gene expression responses could be genetically eliminated without compromising growth in space. There is no fundamental spaceflight response that characterizes plant physiological adaptation; the adaptive response depends on the plant's genotype and the specific environment. Cell wall remodeling appears to be a requirement or unavoidable consequence of spaceflight physiological adaptation.
relationships: The experiment described here examined the influence of genotype on the physiological adaptation to spaceflight as measured by gene expression patterns.
insights: Genetic manipulation can produce varieties that are better adapted to growth in spaceflight through the elimination of unnecessary responses. Responses to novel environments may include signals that are inappropriately activated or misinterpreted, and these inappropriate responses can be genetically eliminated without adverse consequences.

title: Utilization of single‚Äêimage normalized difference vegetation index (SI‚ÄêNDVI) for early plant stress detection
objective: To characterize the phenotype of the Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_063500, specifically focusing on the effects of the T-DNA insertion on gene expression, silique development, and pollen tube germination.
methodology: The study involved DNA-PCR to confirm the T-DNA insertion, Quantitative Realtime PCR (qPCR) to examine gene expression levels, observation and measurement of plant phenotypes (silique length and seed fill), and pollen tube germination assays (in vitro and in vivo). Statistical analyses (t-tests, ANOVA) were used to compare data between wild type (Col-0) and the SALK_063500 line.
results: The T-DNA insertion in the SALK_063500 line was found within the AT1G05290 gene. Homozygous T-DNA alleles were unattainable. Heterozygous plants showed reduced AT1G05290 expression and an aberrant silique phenotype, attributed to a reduced rate of pollen tube germination.
conclusions: The T-DNA insertion in SALK_063500 affects the expression of AT1G05290, leading to observable phenotypic changes in silique development and pollen tube germination. This suggests a role for AT1G05290 in pollen development and potentially male fertility in plants.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between the T-DNA insertion in the AT1G05290 gene, reduced gene expression, and the observed silique and pollen tube germination phenotypes. Reciprocal crosses were used to further investigate the inheritance of the silique phenotype.
insights: The characterization of the SALK_063500 line provides insights into the function of the AT1G05290 gene in pollen development and its potential role in male sterility. This information can be valuable for future research in plant reproductive biology and genetic engineering.

title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.
objective: To refine and validate a single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) imaging system for early plant stress detection in controlled environments, comparing leaf reflectance in visible and near-infrared light spectrums.
methodology: The SI-NDVI imaging system, using a modified camera with specific light filters, was used to assess plant responses to stress before visual detection. Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were subjected to salt stress, and Eruca sativa plants were treated with ammonium nitrate. Images were analyzed using Fiji image processing software and Microsoft Excel to create false color images and quantitative graphs to detect plant stress.
results: Stress was detected in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings within 15 minutes of salinity application using SI-NDVI analysis, before stress was visible. Stress was also observed during ammonium nitrate treatment of Eruca sativa plants within 6 hours, before visual detection. Quantitative image analysis showed a decrease in pixels with high color index values in stressed plants compared to control plants.
conclusions: SI-NDVI imaging allows for early detection of plant stress before it is apparent to the human eye. It is a cost-effective and user-friendly alternative to traditional dual-image NDVI or hyper-spectral imaging, making it suitable for indoor farming and high-throughput screening.
relationships: The SI-NDVI method relates changes in spectral reflectance to plant health, enabling early detection of stress responses. The study establishes a relationship between SI-NDVI scores and the onset of stress in plants exposed to salinity and ammonium nitrate.
insights: SI-NDVI imaging can be used to optimize controlled environment agriculture by enabling early intervention to mitigate stress. The method can be applied to various plant stressors, species, and growth mediums, improving the success of controlled greenhouse or laboratory growing efforts.

title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To compare RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) to microarrays in characterizing genes relevant to spaceflight using small root sections of Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana roots were sectioned into Zone 1 (0.5 mm; root cap and meristematic zone) and Zone 2 (1.5 mm; transition, elongation, and growth-terminating zone). Differential gene expression in each zone was compared using RNA-Seq and microarrays. Gene ontology (GO) analysis was performed on differentially expressed genes.
results: Both microarrays and RNA-Seq were applicable to small samples. A total of 4180 genes were differentially expressed between Zone 1 and Zone 2. RNA-Seq identified 771 unique genes and 19 novel transcriptionally active regions not detected by microarrays. Microarrays detected some spaceflight-relevant genes missed by RNA-Seq. RNA-Seq was more efficient in detecting a greater number of significantly changed genes compared to the microarray.
conclusions: Single root tip subsections can be used for transcriptome analysis using either RNA-Seq or microarrays. Both techniques provided novel information. RNA-Seq may miss some spaceflight-relevant changes in gene expression. The study outlines strategies for handling molecular analyses of very small samples that require preservation in remote locations.
relationships: Zone 2 was enriched with genes involved in secondary growth metabolic processes, such as response to stimulus, cell elongation, differentiation, root hair development, and maturation. Zone 1 was enriched with genes involved in primary growth metabolisms like cellular components, cell cycle, and DNA metabolism.
insights: RNA-Seq provides information on isoforms, coding DNA sequences, and transcription start sites, offering a more comprehensive view of gene expression compared to microarrays. Some spaceflight-relevant genes with low expression levels may be better detected by methods other than RNA-Seq.

title: Spaceﬂight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana
objective: To examine differential splicing associated with spaceﬂight by analyzing the spaceﬂight-induced transcriptome, focusing on genes that undergo alternative splicing.
methodology: Re-examined RNA sequence data from the APEX03 spaceﬂight experiment, collected from two Arabidopsis thaliana ecotypes at two seedling stages grown onboard the International Space Station and ground controls. Used presence/absence variation analysis to identify expression-level differences in alternatively spliced isoforms between spaceﬂight and ground controls, followed by analysis of significant differential alternative splicing.
results: Identified alternative splicing isoforms with expression-level differences between spaceflight and ground control samples in both ecotypes and developmental stages. Fewer genes undergo differential alternative splicing in the Col-0 ecotype compared to WS. Little overlap in the identity of genes alternatively spliced in response to spaceflight between the two ecotypes.
conclusions: This study provides evidence of a role for alternative splicing in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment. It represents the first observation of transcriptome-wide spaceflight-induced alternative splicing in plants and any living organism exposed to microgravity.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight conditions and changes in gene expression through alternative splicing. It also explores the relationship between different Arabidopsis ecotypes and their splicing responses to spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight triggers unique transcriptional responses in plants, and alternative splicing plays a role in adapting to the spaceflight environment. Different plant ecotypes exhibit varying alternative splicing patterns in response to spaceflight, suggesting genetic factors influence adaptation mechanisms.

title: Root skewing-associated genes impact the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To determine the biomass production of various crops grown in the EDEN ISS space greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 season, and to test subsystems, technologies, operation procedures, plant health monitoring devices and plant cultivation for future space missions.
methodology: 26 different crops were grown on a 12.5 m2 cultivation area in the EDEN ISS Mobile Test Facility (MTF) in Antarctica. The MTF consists of an airlock/cold-porch, service section, and Future Exploration Greenhouse (FEG). Environmental conditions were controlled, including LED lighting, temperature, humidity, and CO2 concentration. Data on edible and inedible biomass production were collected for each crop. The nutrient delivery subsystem adjusted the irrigation water’s pH and EC value. The light spectrum mainly consisted of blue and red light. The light intensity varied between 300 and 600 µmol/(m2∗s).
results: The EDEN ISS MTF produced approximately 268 kg of fresh edible biomass during the 286-day operational phase. The most productive crops were cucumbers (67 kg), lettuces (56 kg), leafy greens (49 kg), and tomatoes (50 kg). The overall yearly productivity was 27.4 kg/m2, equal to 0.075 kg/(m2∗d).
conclusions: The EDEN ISS project demonstrated the feasibility of producing a significant amount of fresh food in a space-analog environment. The data collected can be used to improve simulation models for space greenhouses, for cultivar selection, and for the Crop Readiness Level evaluation method.
relationships: The biomass production dataset can be used to improve simulation models for space greenhouses. It can also be used for cultivar selection and is a valuable contribution to the recently developed Crop Readiness Level evaluation method for crop candidates for space greenhouses.
insights: The EDEN ISS project's approach to working with a compromise climate, where all crops are grown simultaneously, is more realistic for near-term space greenhouses. The food production in the 2018 season was higher than expected, indicating the potential for efficient food production in controlled environments.

title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity.
objective: To elucidate the contribution of two skewing- and cell wall-associated genes in Arabidopsis to root behavior and gene expression patterns in spaceflight, and to assess whether interruptions of different skewing pathways affect the overall spaceflight-associated process.
methodology: The Advanced Plant Experiments-03-2 (APEX-03-2) spaceflight study was conducted on the International Space Station (ISS). Arabidopsis thaliana wild-type and mutant lines (spr1 and sku5) were grown for 4 and 8 days in the Veggie hardware under constant lighting. Root growth morphologies were observed, and gene expression profiles were analyzed using RNA-Seq to measure the complexity of spaceflight acclimation. Ground controls were performed at Kennedy Space Center (KSC) using Veggie hardware within the ISS Environmental Simulator (ISSES) chamber.
results: The spr1 mutant showed enhanced leftward skewing in spaceflight compared to ground controls. The sku5 mutant did not show enhanced skewing in spaceflight. The spr1 mutant required fewer differentially expressed genes (DEGs) for spaceflight acclimation than its wild type, while sku5 showed considerably more DEGs than its wild type. Germination rates were repressed in FLT sku5 relative to GC sku5, and to FLT WS.
conclusions: The two skewing pathways highlighted by SKU5 and SPR1 differentially affect the mechanisms used by plants to physiologically acclimate to spaceflight. The spr1 mutation enhances spaceflight physiological adaptation, while the sku5 mutation initiates a more complex, deeper, and more stress-related response to spaceflight. Lipid raft nanodomains of the plasma membrane and their associated GPI-APs play important roles in spaceflight physiological adaptation.
relationships: SPR1 reinforces rightward root growth, while EB1b negatively regulates thigmotropism and positively regulates gravitropism. SKU5 may impact the spaceflight response via the regulation of meristematic competence and cell cycle progression. ABA signaling inhibits TOR, promoting autophagy to allow for stress tolerance acquisition.
insights: Root skewing in spaceflight appears to be an inherent feature of many Arabidopsis ecotypes, even in conditions lacking both light and gravity. The spaceflight environment imposes secondary environmental stresses due to the disruption of fluid movement, and any processes influenced by convection, such as gas exchange and temperature redistribution. The intensity of the differential gene expression response may be considered a measure of the metabolic cost of adapting to that environment.

title: Host-microbe interactions in microgravity: assessment and implications.
objective: To investigate the effect of extended microgravity on articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC) in mice, assessing cartilage degradation after 30 days of spaceflight.
methodology: Articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC) from mice exposed to 30 days of microgravity were analyzed. Histological analysis, including proteoglycan and collagen II staining, was performed. Gene expression analysis was conducted on both AC and SC samples to identify differentially expressed genes.
results: Flight AC showed degradation with loss of proteoglycan staining and reduced mRNA expression of cartilage matrix proteins. Sternal cartilage showed no breakdown. Gene expression profiles differed between AC and SC. Overall histological scores suggested more cartilage degradation in flight samples.
conclusions: Weight-bearing articular cartilage is negatively affected by the unloading of microgravity, while minimally loaded sternal fibrocartilage is not. Maintaining physiological loading on AC during spaceflight may minimize AC damage.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between biomechanical loading and cartilage health, showing that changes in loading conditions due to microgravity can lead to cartilage degradation in load-bearing tissues.
insights: The differential response of articular and sternal cartilage to microgravity suggests that cartilage adapts to its normal biomechanical environment. Microgravity-induced joint pathology could compromise flight crew mobility and accelerate joint degradation.
