title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
objective: To assess the impact of microgravity on the normal physiological and genetic responses of both pathogenic and mutualistic host-microbe associations, and to understand microbial fitness in microgravity conditions to maintain a healthy homeostasis between humans, plants, and their respective microbiomes during spaceflight.
methodology: Review of existing literature and experimental data on the effects of spaceflight and simulated microgravity environments (clinostats, rotating wall vessels) on host-microbe interactions, including studies on pathogenic bacteria (Salmonella typhimurium, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa), mutualistic symbiosis (Euprymna scolopes-Vibrio fischeri), and plant-microbe interactions (nitrogen-fixing bacteria and leguminous plants).
results: Microgravity induces various physiological changes in pathogenic microbes, including altered growth rates, increased membrane integrity, differential secondary metabolite production, elevated genetic material transfer rates, and increased biofilm formation. In the squid-vibrio symbiosis, microgravity delays hemocyte trafficking and accelerates light organ morphogenesis. In plants, microgravity increases susceptibility to pathogens, but initial colonization and cell-cell communication in rhizobia-legume symbioses are not impaired.
conclusions: Spaceflight-induced stresses, including microgravity, can significantly impact the stability and resilience of host-microbe interactions. Understanding these effects is critical for maintaining the health of astronauts and plants during long-term space missions. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying these changes and to develop strategies for maintaining a healthy microbiome in space.
relationships: The review highlights the complex relationships between hosts (animals and plants) and their associated microbes, emphasizing the importance of these interactions for host health and disease resistance. It explores how microgravity can disrupt these relationships, potentially leading to increased susceptibility to pathogens or altered symbiotic interactions.
insights: Astronauts and other eukaryotic hosts should be considered as metaorganisms, whose crosstalk and interactions with their microbes at the genetic and cellular level have redefined our definition of health and disease. The microbiome is a hotspot for genetic transfer, facilitating the exchange of antibiotic resistance, food digestion and nutrient metabolism genes that may provide the microbe a competitive advantage within the host community. Understanding the nature and frequency of such events, as well as the overall stability of the microbiome under microgravity conditions, will not only help elucidate how microgravity alters this dynamic microbial landscape but will help enable the formation of new strategies for maintenance and potential restoration of the healthy microbiome during spaceflight.

title: Symbiotic organs shaped by distinct modes of genome evolution in cephalopods.
objective: To define how symbiont-induced changes of the brush border are induced in early development and how they interface with the daily rhythms of the symbiosis. Also, to determine the feature(s) of the symbiont that trigger(s) brush-border remodelling.
methodology: Ultrastructural analyses using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to quantify microvilli along epithelial apical surfaces. Manipulation of environmental light cues and juvenile symbiotic state. Experiments with wild-type and mutant *Vibrio fischeri* strains. Exposure to *V. fischeri* MAMPs (LPS and TCT). Electron-microscopy immunocytochemistry using a polyclonal antibody generated to *V. fischeri* LPS. Quantification of microvillar density and cellular swelling.
results: Effacement of the crypt epithelial brush border occurs daily around dawn in juveniles and persists throughout the life of the host. The trigger for this effacement is the light cue of dawn and is independent of symbiosis. The increase in microvillar density at dawn in juveniles requires *V. fischeri* colonization, but is not dependent on the level of colonization or luminescence capacity of the symbionts. This increase in density is induced by phosphorylated lipid A.
conclusions: The remodelling of the crypt brush borders begins in juvenile animals and this activity requires influences from both an environmental light cue and interaction with the microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) of symbiont cells. The squid-vibrio symbiosis displays a profound daily rhythm.
relationships: The study explores the symbiotic relationship between the squid *Euprymna scolopes* and the bacterium *Vibrio fischeri*, focusing on the interaction at the brush border of the squid's light organ.
insights: The daily effacement of the brush border may be related to convergence of the light organ with the eye. Phosphorylated lipid A is required for the developmental increase in brush-border microvillar density. Outer membrane vesicles contain MAMPs and that host cells take up these vesicles.

title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
objective: To understand the processes influencing the origin of specialized symbiotic organs by sequencing and analyzing the genome of Euprymna scolopes, a model cephalopod.
methodology: Sequencing and analysis of the E. scolopes genome using shotgun and long-range linkage sequencing methods. Genome annotation was guided by transcriptomic libraries. Microsynteny detection algorithm was implemented.
results: The E. scolopes genome revealed large-scale genomic reorganization compared to other bilaterian genomes. Distinct evolutionary signatures were found within the light organ (LO) and the accessory nidamental gland (ANG). The LO evolved through subfunctionalization of genes expressed in the eye, while the ANG was enriched in novel, species-specific orphan genes.
conclusions: The study provides evidence for different patterns of genomic evolution contributing to functional novelty in symbiotic organs. Genome reorganization and expansion of repetitive elements resulted in a unique genomic architecture. The LO and ANG evolved through different mechanisms, with gene duplication in the LO and taxon-specific genes in the ANG.
relationships: The light organ (LO) of E. scolopes has a monospecific association with Vibrio fischeri. The accessory nidamental gland (ANG) contains a bacterial consortium. The study compares E. scolopes to Octopus bimaculoides.
insights: Symbiotic organs within a single host can originate by different evolutionary mechanisms. The LO evolved through subfunctionalization of genes expressed in the eye, indicating a deep evolutionary link between these organs. The ANG was enriched in novel, species-specific orphan genes suggesting these two tissues originated via different evolutionary strategies.

title: Emergence of novel cephalopod gene regulation and expression through large-scale genome reorganization
objective: To examine the impact of low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) on the release of lipopolysaccharides (LPS) and outer-membrane vesicles (OMVs) by Vibrio fischeri, and to assess the overall physiology of the symbiont when cultivated under microgravity-like conditions.
methodology: Vibrio fischeri cultures were grown in high-aspect ratio vessels (HARVs) under LSMMG and normal gravity conditions. LPS release was measured using the Limulus Amebocyte Lysate (LAL) endotoxin assay and the Purpald assay. Bacterial motility was assessed using microscopy and soft-agar assays. OMV production was examined using nanoparticle tracking analysis. Cell membrane integrity was evaluated by exposing cells to polymyxin B, sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), and Triton X-100, and assessing cell growth and viability.
results: LSMMG conditions increased the shedding of bacterial LPS and associated OMVs into the surrounding media. The size of the OMV particles released during LSMMG was larger than gravity controls. Flagellar motility in V. fischeri accounted for most of the overall OMV production, but was not necessary for increases in LPS shedding under LSMMG conditions. The cell membranes of V. fischeri cells were more susceptible to disruption when cultivated under modeled microgravity conditions.
conclusions: Symbiotic microbes display significant physiological changes under modeled microgravity conditions, leading to a change in the release of microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) known to affect host biology, which may have implications on host-microbe interactions. Increased LPS shedding and altered OMV production under LSMMG may reflect changes in membrane integrity and stress responses.
relationships: The study focuses on the symbiotic relationship between Vibrio fischeri and the Hawaiian bobtail squid, Euprymna scolopes, and how microgravity affects this interaction. LPS and OMVs released by V. fischeri induce apoptosis in the squid's light organ, a process that is altered under LSMMG conditions.
insights: Microgravity-like conditions can alter host-microbe relationships at the physiological level. Understanding these changes is critical for maintaining microbiome homeostasis during spaceflight and for long-term host health. The study provides a framework for exploring specific interactions and responses between animals and their associated microbes in space.

title: Modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression and caspase activity in the squid-vibrio symbiosis
objective: To understand the extent of genome reorganization in coleoid cephalopods and its impact on genome biology and evolution, focusing on the model species Euprymna scolopes (Hawaiian bobtail squid).
methodology: Chromosomal conformation capture (Hi-C), open chromatin profiling (ATAC-seq), comparative genomics across 25 animal species, and expression data analysis were used to reconstruct the regulatory landscape and identify microsyntenic blocks.  3D modeling based on Hi-C interaction matrices was performed.
results: Coleoid cephalopod genomes have undergone extensive restructuring, leading to the emergence of novel, tightly linked gene clusters (microsyntenies) associated with cephalopod innovations. These microsyntenies correspond to topological compartments with distinct regulatory structures and contribute to complex expression patterns, particularly in the nervous system. Novel cephalopod microsyntenies have distinct spatial properties from conserved metazoan microsyntenies.
conclusions: Large-scale syntenic reorganization has impacted cephalopod genomes, leading to the gain of cephalopod-specific microsyntenies associated with compact topological regions and a distinct mode of gene regulation. These microsyntenies are crucial contributors to the emergence of novel cephalopod expression domains and organismal innovations.
relationships: The study reveals relationships between microsyntenies and topologically associating domains (TADs), showing that conserved metazoan microsyntenies tend to be localized towards the center of TADs, while new cephalopod microsyntenies are more evenly distributed.  Novel microsyntenies are more likely to form tight interaction regions.
insights: The emergence of microsyntenies associated with cephalopod innovations (MACIs) was instrumental to cephalopod nervous system evolution.  The regulatory sequences of novel microsyntenies are often located within the introns of genes within the same microsyntenic cluster, suggesting a bystander model of gene regulation.

title: In vitro generation of mechanically functional cartilage grafts based on adult human stem cells and 3D-woven poly(epsilon-caprolactone) scaffolds
objective: To examine the effects of simulated microgravity on the beneficial association between Euprymna scolopes and Vibrio fischeri, focusing on bacteria-induced apoptosis in the squid light organ.
methodology: Cultured Euprymna scolopes with Vibrio fischeri in High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs) under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) and gravity control conditions. Measured gene expression using NanoString nCounter assay, caspase activity with Caspase-Glo assays, and quantified apoptosis via acridine orange staining. Used protease inhibitors to assess caspase involvement.
results: LSMMG increased transcription of genes associated with both receptor-mediated and stress-induced apoptosis. Pro-death caspase transcripts increased under LSMMG. Caspase activity was higher in symbiotic animals under LSMMG. Inhibitors mitigated the LSMMG-associated increase in apoptosis.
conclusions: Modeled microgravity can cause perturbations to normal apoptotic pathways in animals. The normal, bacteria-induced apoptosis in the squid light organ is mediated in part by caspases that exhibit increased activity under LSMMG. The LSMMG-associated increase of caspase activity can be pharmacologically mitigated with inhibitors.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between microgravity, bacterial symbiosis, and apoptosis in the context of animal physiology. It shows how microgravity can alter the normal bacteria-induced development of host tissues by affecting apoptotic pathways.
insights: The research suggests that external stresses like modeled microgravity can disrupt normal apoptotic pathways in animals. Understanding these disruptions is crucial for maintaining crew health during long-duration spaceflight. The ability to modulate cell life and death and identify mitigation targets has therapeutic potential for preventing perturbations of animal-microbe homeostasis.

title: Chondrogenesis and mineralization during in vitro culture of human mesenchymal stem cells on three-dimensional woven scaffolds
objective: To produce mechanically functional tissue engineered cartilage from adult human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSC) and three-dimensionally (3D) woven poly(ε-caprolactone) (PCL) scaffolds in 21 days in vitro. Also, to study the effects of scaffold structure, culture vessel, and medium composition on construct properties.
methodology: hMSCs were seeded onto 3D-woven PCL scaffolds and cultured in static dishes or oscillating bioreactors with different media compositions (with/without serum and chondrogenic additives). Mechanical testing (confined and unconfined compression), histological analyses (Safranin-O staining, immunostaining for collagen types I and II), and biochemical assays (DNA, collagen, GAG) were performed to assess construct properties.
results: Tightly woven PCL scaffolds cultured in bioreactors approached the mechanical properties of normal articular cartilage. Bioreactors enhanced collagen content and matrix homogeneity. Chondrogenic additives without serum promoted GAG production and early collagen II expression. Scaffold structure significantly impacted aggregate and Young's moduli.
conclusions: Functional cartilage tissue can be engineered from hMSCs and 3D-woven PCL scaffolds within 21 days. Tightly woven scaffolds and bioreactor culture enhance mechanical properties and tissue development. Chondrogenic differentiation is accelerated by chondrogenic additives without serum.
relationships: Scaffold structure impacts mechanical properties; bioreactor culture enhances collagen content and homogeneity; serum inhibits chondrogenesis; chondrogenic additives promote chondrogenesis.
insights: The study demonstrates the feasibility of engineering functional cartilage tissue using a combination of hMSCs, 3D-woven PCL scaffolds, bioreactor culture, and optimized media composition. The findings highlight the importance of scaffold structure, culture conditions, and media composition for cartilage tissue engineering.

title: Microbiome metadata standards: Report of the National Microbiome Data Collaborative's workshop and follow-on activities.
objective: To test the hypothesis that culture duration and medium additives can individually and interactively influence structure, composition, biomechanics, and gene expression in engineered skeletal tissues generated using human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) and 3D woven poly(e-caprolactone) (PCL) scaffolds.
methodology: Bone marrow hMSCs were suspended in collagen gel, seeded on 3D woven PCL scaffolds, and cultured for 1, 21, or 45 days under chondrogenic and/or osteogenic conditions. Structure, composition, biomechanics, and gene expression were analyzed using histological stains, microcomputerized tomography, biochemical assays (DNA, glycosaminoglycans, calcium, alkaline phosphatase activity), biphasic mechanical testing, and real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
results: In chondrogenic medium, cartilaginous tissue formed by day 21, and hypertrophic mineralization was observed at the interface with the scaffold by day 45. Glycosaminoglycan, hydroxyproline, and calcium contents, and alkaline phosphatase activity depended on culture duration and medium additives. The 45-day constructs exhibited mechanical properties on the order of magnitude of native articular cartilage. Gene expression was characteristic of chondrogenesis and endochondral bone formation. In contrast, osteogenic medium produced limited osteogenesis.
conclusions: Long-term culture of hMSCs on 3D scaffolds resulted in chondrogenesis and regional mineralization at the interface between engineered cartilage and the scaffold. These findings merit consideration when developing grafts for osteochondral defect repair.
relationships: Culture duration and medium additives significantly influenced chondrogenesis and/or osteogenesis by hMSCs in the context of a scaffold with appropriate mechanical properties. Mineralization was colocalized in areas where hyaline-like cartilage matrix was also deposited.
insights: The study demonstrated that culture duration and medium additives significantly influenced chondrogenesis and/or osteogenesis by hMSCs in the context of a scaffold with appropriate mechanical properties. The study opens up new possibilities for osteochondral tissue engineering. By providing different concentrations of oxygen and/or growth factors on the upper and lower surfaces of hMSC-based constructs, it may be feasible to maintain cartilaginous tissue on one side, while inducing bone formation on the opposite side.

title: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions
objective: To correct the article byline and affiliation line in the original publication regarding microbiome metadata standards.
methodology: This is an author correction, indicating a review and correction of previously published information.
results: The article byline and affiliation line have been corrected as specified in the correction notice.
conclusions: This correction ensures the accuracy of author and affiliation information in the original publication.
relationships: This correction relates to the field of microbiome research and data standardization.
insights: Accurate metadata is crucial for reproducibility and proper attribution in microbiome research.

title: Asparagine biosynthesis as a mechanism of increased host lethality induced by Serratia marcescens in simulated microgravity environments
objective: To explore murine gut microbiota and host gene expression in the colon and liver after 29 and 56 days of spaceflight using multiomics, in order to understand how these interactions contribute to spaceflight pathology.
methodology: Species-resolved 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing and de novo co-assembled WMS were employed to capture metagenomic changes in the murine gut microbiome associated with spaceflight. Intestinal and hepatic transcriptomics were then used to assess the associated gene expression response of mice to spaceflight. Four treatment groups were used: FLT_LAR (29 days spaceflight), GC_LAR (ground control for FLT_LAR), FLT_ISS (56 days spaceflight), and GC_ISS (ground control for FLT_ISS).
results: Spaceflight increased total body weight in mice. Metagenomics revealed significant changes in microbiome species, including relative reductions in bile acid and butyrate metabolizing bacteria. Functional prediction indicated over-representation of fatty acid and bile acid metabolism, extracellular matrix interactions, and antibiotic resistance genes. Host gene expression described corresponding changes to bile acid and energy metabolism, and immune suppression.
conclusions: Host-gut microbiome interactions during spaceflight are likely to underlie widespread changes to host physiology which could pose a risk to health. Spaceflight-associated changes in bacteria linked to bile and fatty acid metabolism were identified, coinciding with substantial changes to gene expression at the host-gut microbiome interface.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced microbiome alterations could have been recognized and influenced changes in clock gene expression. Changes in the extracellular matrix are shaped by microbiota. The gut-liver axis is extensively disrupted.
insights: Spaceflight leads to an alteration in bile acid metabolism in the intestine which would lead to bile acid suppression of hepatic Cyp7A1 and accumulation of cholesterol or hypercholesterolaemia. Spaceflight is associated with immune suppression and widespread tissue remodelling at the host-gut microbiome interface in mice. There is hepatic accumulation of cholesterol, characteristic of glucose and lipid metabolic dysruption.

title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station.
objective: To retrieve near full-length genomes from metagenomes generated from ISS environmental samples and perform in-depth functional and phylogenetic analyses.
methodology: Metagenomic sequencing reads from ISS environmental samples were assembled using metaSPAdes and metaWRAP. Resulting MAGs were analyzed for phylogenetic affiliation, functional pathways, antimicrobial resistance, and virulence characteristics. Fungal genomes were assembled using ANVIO. Comparative phylogenetic analysis was performed to identify ISS-specific evolution. Gene-based AMR and biofilm formation studies were conducted.
results: 46 MAGs were assembled, identifying 18 bacterial species, including novel species Kalamiella piersonii and Methylobacterium ajmalii. Four fungal genomes were assembled. Phylogenetic analyses showed ISS-specific evolution in five bacterial species. Genes related to cell membranes were enriched. AMR genes were prevalent in Enterobacter bugandensis. Biofilm and quorum sensing genes were analyzed.
conclusions: The study reconstructed genomes to enable researchers to study the evolution of genomes under microgravity and low-dose irradiation compared to the evolution of microbes on Earth. The Pantoea/Kalamiella strains may be more susceptible to microgravity changes. ISS genomes exhibit strong evidence for ISS-specific bacterial evolution. SNP changes in MAGs and ISS genomes might be an adaptation strategy in AMR and biofilm formation in microbes.
relationships: Comparative analyses of MAGs and whole-genome sequences of related ISS isolates and their type strains were characterized to understand the variation related to the microbial evolution under microgravity.
insights: Microbial virulence increases in microgravity, and AMR gene sequences of MAGs were compared with genomes of respective ISS isolates and corresponding type strains. The study provides insights into the ecology and evolution of biosafety level 2 microorganisms in space.

title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station
objective: To characterize Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T, establish it as a novel species (Cohnella hashimotonis), determine its phylogenetic placement within the Cohnella genus, and explore its functional traits.
methodology: Isolation of bacteria from ISS surfaces, whole-genome sequencing (Illumina and Nanopore), phylogenetic analysis (16S rRNA, gyrB, pangenome), phenotypic and chemotaxonomic characterization, comparative genomic analysis, and metagenomic read mapping.
results: Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T is a novel species, Cohnella hashimotonis, phylogenetically related to C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli.  It possesses unique genomic traits, including genes for carbohydrate and amino acid transport and metabolism. It does not appear to be a dominant member of the ISS microbiome.  It exhibits specific phenotypic characteristics, including growth temperatures, pH, NaCl tolerance, and fatty acid profiles.
conclusions: Cohnella hashimotonis is a novel species likely introduced to the ISS as a plant commensal. Its ability to survive in extreme ISS conditions and its close relation to rhizosphere bacteria make it a promising candidate for plant-growth-promoting consortia in future space experiments.
relationships: The novel species Cohnella hashimotonis is closely related to Cohnella rhizosphaerae and Cohnella ginsengisoli, all of which are associated with plant tissue or the rhizosphere environment.
insights: Cohnella hashimotonis possesses genes related to heme oxygenase and bacteriophytochrome, suggesting potential stress response mechanisms. It also exhibits CAZyme profiles indicative of plant symbiosis and potential applications in processing plant phenolic compounds.

title: Biocontrol in built environments to reduce pathogen exposure and infection risk.
objective: To retrieve near full-length genomes from metagenomes generated from International Space Station (ISS) environmental samples and perform in-depth functional and phylogenetic analyses.
methodology: Metagenomic sequencing reads from ISS environmental samples were processed and assembled using metaSPAdes and metaWRAP pipelines.  Resulting metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were evaluated using CheckM for completeness and contamination.  Phylogenetic analyses were conducted to identify bacterial and fungal species.  Functional analyses, including antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and virulence characteristics, were performed.  A co-assembly-based strategy using ANVIO was employed for eukaryotic genome assembly. Comparative phylogenetic analysis was performed to investigate evolution of ISS microorganisms.
results: 46 MAGs were assembled, identifying 18 bacterial species, including one novel genus/species combination (Kalamiella piersonii) and one novel bacterial species (Methylobacterium ajmalii). Four fungal genomes were also assembled. Phylogenetic analyses showed ISS-specific evolution in some bacterial species. Genes related to cell membranes were enriched. Variations in AMR and virulence genes were characterized. Comparative analyses revealed relatively high levels of identity shared across genomes of the ISS isolates and MAGs, when compared against their type strain genomes. ISS genomes (isolates and MAGs) are always monophyletic.
conclusions: Good quality bacterial and fungal MAGs were generated from ISS environmental samples. Novel microbial species were identified. ISS genomes exhibited a monophyletic phylogeny, suggesting a shared common ancestor and ISS-specific bacterial evolution. SNP changes in MAGs and ISS genomes might be an adaptation strategy in AMR and biofilm formation in microbes. Enterobacterial species are more subjective to microgravity changes.
relationships: Comparative analyses of MAGs and whole-genome sequences of related ISS isolates and their type strains were characterized to understand the variation related to the microbial evolution under microgravity. The Pantoea/Kalamiella strains have the maximum single-nucleotide polymorphisms found within the ISS strains examined.
insights: The reconstructed genomes will enable researchers to study the evolution of genomes under microgravity and low-dose irradiation compared to the evolution of microbes here on Earth. The study provides insights into the microbial ecology of built environments, particularly in extreme conditions like those found on the ISS, and highlights potential adaptation mechanisms of microorganisms in response to spaceflight.

title: Extracellular nucleotides elicit cytosolic free calcium oscillations in Arabidopsis.
objective: To review the current understanding of microbial ecology in built environments and propose strategies to translate that knowledge into effective biocontrol of antibiotic-resistant pathogens.
methodology: The review synthesizes findings from observational studies, laboratory experiments, and intervention studies focusing on the built environment microbiome. It covers techniques like high-throughput sequencing (16S rRNA, ITS genes), metagenomics, qPCR, and metabolomics. It also discusses genome-scale metabolic modeling to understand microbial activity.
results: Observational studies show that built environments are colonized by diverse microbial communities influenced by factors like building materials, occupants, and cleaning practices. Hospital environments show selection pressure for antimicrobial resistance genes. Laboratory studies reveal microbial interactions and survival strategies under built environment conditions. Intervention studies suggest that biocontrol strategies, particularly using Bacillus species, can reduce pathogen abundance and AMR genes.
conclusions: Biocontrol strategies, especially those involving Bacillus species, show promise in reducing pathogen exposure and AMR in built environments. However, the mechanisms of action need further investigation. Factors like application methods, humidity, nutrient availability, and surface material type influence the effectiveness of biocontrol. Further research is needed to optimize biocontrol strategies and understand their long-term impacts.
relationships: The review explores relationships between microbial communities, building materials, cleaning practices, and occupant health. It highlights the potential for beneficial interactions between biocontrol bacteria and the native surface microbiome, as well as competitive exclusion of pathogens. It also discusses the impact of harsh cleaning agents on biocontrol effectiveness.
insights: The built environment microbiome is a complex ecosystem that can be manipulated to reduce pathogen exposure and AMR. Biocontrol strategies, particularly using Bacillus species, show promise, but their effectiveness depends on various factors. Further research is needed to optimize biocontrol strategies and understand their long-term impacts on microbial communities and human health. Emerging technologies like 3D printing offer new opportunities for engineering microbially active building materials.

title: Calcium, mechanical signaling, and tip growth
objective: To investigate the role of extracellular purine nucleotides, abscisic acid (ABA), and L-glutamate in regulating plant development, defense, and stress responses through plasma membrane calcium channels in Arabidopsis thaliana roots.
methodology: The study used Arabidopsis thaliana root epidermal protoplasts expressing aequorin to measure cytosolic free calcium levels.  Roots were exposed to wounding, hyperosmotic stress, ABA, L-glutamate, and ADP. ATP levels were measured using a luciferin/luciferase assay.  Ion fluxes were measured using extracellular vibrating K+-selective microelectrodes.
results: Exogenous ABA and L-glutamate caused ATP accumulation around Arabidopsis roots. ADP induced cytosolic calcium elevation in root epidermal protoplasts. Wounding, hyperosmotic stress, and sodicity stress resulted in ATP accumulation around excised roots. L-glutamate caused transient ATP accumulation. ADP promotes net Ca2+ influx, while ATP promotes influx up to a certain concentration, above which Ca2+ efflux is promoted.
conclusions: Extracellular purine nucleotides, ABA, and L-glutamate can regulate plant cell growth and stress responses by influencing plasma membrane calcium channels and ATP release.  ADP elicits calcium-based responses distinct from ATP.  The effects of extracellular ATP on growth may depend on the levels of ROS production and channel activation.
relationships: ABA inhibition of root growth may involve ATP release and sensing upstream of NADPH oxidases and PERKs, resulting in inhibitory Ca2+ influx. Extracellular glutamate perception upstream of ATP release could be mediated by GLR channels. ATP activation of root epidermal plasma membrane Ca2+-permeable channels can be prevented by applying dithiothreitol (DTT) as a reductant.
insights: Extracellular ATP acts as a signaling molecule in plants, influencing calcium fluxes and regulating various physiological processes. The study highlights the complex interplay between different signaling pathways involving purine nucleotides, calcium, and other signaling molecules in plant roots.

title: Gravitropism and mechanical signaling in plants.
objective: To elucidate the mechanism by which ethylene signaling controls gravitropic growth in rice roots and to investigate the role of mechanosensing in this process.
methodology: The study involved isolating a rice mutant (crw1) with defective root gravitropism in hydroponics but normal growth in soil.  Genetic mapping, CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, physiological assays (auxin distribution, ROS measurement, calcium signaling), and molecular biology techniques (RNA-seq, Y2H, EMSA, ChIP-qPCR) were used to identify the causative gene and downstream signaling components.  Mechanical resistance was applied using agar and foam pellets to assess its impact on gravitropism.
results: The crw1 mutant phenotype is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in OsCRW1/OsEBF1, leading to overaccumulation of OsEIL1/2 and amplified ethylene signaling. This results in increased ROS production, impaired root cap stability, disrupted auxin distribution due to mislocalization of OsPIN2, and defective gravitropism.  Gentle mechanical resistance rescues the phenotype by suppressing OsEIL1/2 accumulation in a calcium-dependent manner.
conclusions: The study reveals a molecular module (OsCRW1-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS) that connects ethylene signaling to gravitropism in rice roots.  Root cap mechanosensing limits excessive ethylene signaling, safeguarding gravitropic growth.  Calcium signaling is essential for mechanosensing-mediated rescue of gravitropism by inhibiting the OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS module.
relationships: Ethylene signaling interacts with auxin signaling and ROS production to regulate root gravitropism.  OsCRW1/OsEBF1 negatively regulates ethylene signaling by targeting OsEIL1/2 for degradation.  OsEIL1/2 activates the transcription factor OsERF82, which promotes ROS production.  Mechanical resistance antagonizes ethylene signaling through calcium signaling, which inhibits OsEIL1/OsEIL2 accumulation.
insights: Ethylene's effect on root gravitropic growth is tightly regulated by OsCRW1 and mechanosensing.  Gentle mechanical resistance, sensed by the root cap, is sufficient to rescue defective gravitropism caused by excessive ethylene signaling.  This mechanosensing involves calcium signaling that inhibits the ethylene signaling module.  Natural variation in OsCRW1 expression may contribute to differences in root gravitropism among rice accessions.

title: Salt stress-induced Ca2+ waves are associated with rapid, long-distance root-to-shoot signaling in plants.
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying root gravitropism in rice, focusing on the role of ethylene signaling and mechanosensing.
methodology: The study used a combination of genetic, molecular, biochemical, and physiological approaches. This included mutant screening, gene cloning (using MutMap), CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, transcriptomic analysis (RNA-seq), yeast two-hybrid assays, bimolecular fluorescence complementation, western blotting, electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA), chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP)-qPCR, fluorescence imaging (confocal microscopy), and various plant growth assays under different conditions (hydroponics, soil, agar plates) with chemical treatments.
results: A rice mutant (crw1) exhibiting root coiling in water but not in soil was identified. The causative gene, OsCRW1/OsEBF1, encodes an F-box protein involved in ethylene signaling. Loss of function of OsCRW1 leads to overaccumulation of OsEIL1/2, increased expression of OsERF82, and elevated ROS production in the root tip. This results in a smaller root cap, asymmetric auxin distribution, and impaired gravitropism. Gentle mechanical resistance rescues the root coiling phenotype in a calcium signaling-dependent manner by limiting the accumulation of OsEIL1/2.
conclusions: The study reveals a molecular module (OsCRW1-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS) connecting ethylene signaling to gravitropism in rice roots. Root cap mechanosensing plays a crucial role in limiting excessive ethylene signaling, thereby safeguarding gravitropic growth. Mechanical resistance enhances calcium signaling, which inhibits the OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS module, restoring root cap structure, auxin distribution, and gravitropism.
relationships: Ethylene signaling interacts with auxin signaling to regulate root gravitropism. OsCRW1 interacts with OsEIL1 and OsEIL2, promoting their degradation. OsEIL1/2 act on OsERF82, which regulates ROS production. Mechanical resistance and calcium signaling antagonize ethylene signaling. ROS accumulation disrupts auxin distribution and root cap stability.
insights: The balance between ethylene and auxin signaling is critical for proper root gravitropism. Mechanosensing acts as a safeguard against excessive ethylene signaling, ensuring stable root growth in soil. Calcium signaling plays a key role in mediating the effects of mechanosensing on ethylene signaling. The OsCRW1-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS module provides a potential target for manipulating root architecture in rice.

title: Gravitropic signaling in plants
objective: To visualize how Ca2+ might act in local and systemic signaling in plants under abiotic stress, specifically salt stress, and to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind rapid, systemic signaling.
methodology: Generated Arabidopsis plants expressing a cytoplasmic Ca2+ sensor (YCNano-65). Applied various abiotic stresses (H2O2, touch, NaCl, cold shock) locally to root tips. Monitored Ca2+ changes using confocal microscopy. Used pharmacological inhibitors (LaCl3, Ruthenium Red) to block Ca2+ wave transmission. Employed qPCR to analyze transcript abundance of stress-related genes in shoots and roots. Used TPC1 mutants to test the role of the vacuolar ion channel. Measured Na content using inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. Assessed seedling survival and chlorophyll content under salt stress.
results: Local salt stress induced a Ca2+ increase that propagated shootward through cortical and endodermal cell layers at approximately 400 μm/s. This Ca2+ wave triggered systemic molecular responses in shoots, including increased transcript levels of stress-related genes. The long-distance Ca2+ signaling was dependent on the vacuolar ion channel TPC1. Blocking the Ca2+ wave with LaCl3 inhibited systemic molecular responses. TPC1 overexpression increased salt stress resistance.
conclusions: Plants possess a rapid stress signaling system based on Ca2+ waves that propagate through defined cell types to rapidly transmit information between distant sites within the organism. The Ca2+ wave serves as a long-distance signal that triggers systemic responses to local salt stress. The vacuolar ion channel TPC1 plays a crucial role in the propagation of the Ca2+ wave and contributes to whole-plant stress tolerance.
relationships: The Ca2+ wave system is related to other proposed systemic signaling systems such as membrane depolarization or ROS-dependent events. TPC1 may be posttranslationally regulated by ROS, suggesting a point of interaction between the ROS and Ca2+-dependent systemic signaling systems.
insights: The study reveals a previously unreported plant-wide signaling system based on the rapid, long-distance transmission of Ca2+ waves. This system provides a new mechanism for the rapid integration of activities throughout the plant body in response to localized stress.

title: Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion enhances amyloplast dynamics in Arabidopsis zigzag1 hypocotyls.
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying root gravitropism in rice, focusing on the role of ethylene signaling and mechanosensing.
methodology: The study involved isolating and characterizing a rice mutant (crw1) with root coiling in hydroponics but normal growth in soil. Methods included: mutant screening, map-based cloning, CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, physiological assays (root growth, gravitropism, auxin distribution, ROS detection), molecular biology techniques (RNA-seq, Y2H, BiFC, EMSA, ChIP-qPCR), and mechanical resistance experiments using agar and foam pellets. Calcium signaling was investigated using a Ca2+ reporter and channel blockers.
results: The crw1 mutant was found to have a loss-of-function allele for OsCRW1/OsEBF1, leading to overaccumulation of OsEIL1/2 and amplified ethylene signaling. This resulted in smaller root caps, asymmetric auxin distribution, and defective gravitropism in water. The OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module was identified as a key regulator of reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, which impaired root cap stability and OsPIN2 localization. Gentle mechanical resistance rescued the root coiling phenotype in a calcium-dependent manner by limiting the accumulation of OsEIL1/2.
conclusions: The study revealed a molecular pathway (OsCRW1-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS) connecting ethylene signaling to gravitropism in rice roots. Mechanosensing in the root cap plays a critical role in limiting excessive ethylene signaling, thereby safeguarding gravitropic growth. Calcium signaling is required for mechanosensing to inhibit the OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS module.
relationships: Ethylene signaling, auxin distribution, reactive oxygen species (ROS), calcium signaling, mechanosensing, root gravitropism.
insights: Root gravitropism is regulated by a complex interplay between ethylene signaling, auxin transport, ROS homeostasis, and mechanosensing. OsCRW1/OsEBF1 acts as a key regulator of ethylene signaling, and mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling provides a mechanism to fine-tune ethylene responses and maintain proper root growth in varying soil conditions. The OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 module is a critical link between ethylene signaling and ROS production, impacting root cap stability and auxin distribution.

title: A ROS-assisted calcium wave dependent on AtRBOHD and TPC1 propagates the systemic response to salt stress in Arabidopsis roots
objective: To investigate the role of vacuoles and amyloplast dynamics in shoot gravitropism in Arabidopsis seedlings using live-cell imaging.
methodology: Live-cell imaging using vertical stage microscopy, Lugol staining, confocal microscopy, centrifuge microscopy for hypergravity experiments, gravitropism assays, and cytoskeleton inhibitor treatments were used to analyze amyloplast sedimentation and vacuole morphology in wild-type and mutant Arabidopsis seedlings.
results: Amyloplast sedimentation is restricted to young endodermal cells below the apical hook. The zig-1 mutant exhibits fragmented vacuoles that trap amyloplasts, restricting their movement. Hypergravity does not displace amyloplasts in zig-1. Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion releases amyloplasts in zig-1. Local wortmannin application to the top of hypocotyls enhances gravitropism in zig-1. Loss of VTI11 function impairs endoplasmic reticulum organization. Cytoskeleton-independent mechanisms mediate vacuole and amyloplast association. Wortmannin enhances graviresponse through dynamic transvacuolar strand formation.
conclusions: Vacuole morphology and dynamics play a crucial role in amyloplast sedimentation and gravitropism in Arabidopsis shoots. The fragmented vacuoles in zig-1 restrict amyloplast movement, contributing to the agravitropic phenotype. Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion restores amyloplast sedimentation and enhances gravitropism. The cytoskeleton is not directly involved in tethering amyloplasts to vacuoles.
relationships: Vacuole morphology affects amyloplast movement and gravitropism. VTI11 is required for proper vacuole fusion and amyloplast sedimentation. Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion restores amyloplast sedimentation and enhances gravitropism. The cytoskeleton is not directly involved in tethering amyloplasts to vacuoles. ER-vacuole interactions are critical for organelle structure.
insights: The study identifies the upper hypocotyl endodermis as the gravisensing tissue and highlights a novel tight interaction between the vacuolar membrane and amyloplasts. Vacuole membrane remodeling may be involved in regulating the association of vacuoles and amyloplasts during graviperception.

title: ROS, calcium and electric signals: Key mediators of rapid systemic signaling in plants
objective: To investigate the mechanisms behind the plant-wide transmission of stress-induced Ca2+ waves, focusing on the salt-induced wave in roots, and to determine if a calcium-induced calcium-release (CICR) mechanism is sufficient to explain the observed wave velocity.
methodology: Mathematical modeling using the fire-diffuse-fire model was employed to analyze Ca2+ wave propagation. Experimental validation included pharmacological treatments (ascorbate, DPI) and analysis of Arabidopsis mutants (AtrbohD, TPC1) using confocal ratio imaging and measurements of extracellular ROS with OxyBurst Green-BSA.
results: A simple CICR mechanism relying on TPC1-dependent Ca2+ efflux and diffusion is unlikely to account for observed wave velocities. However, a ROS-assisted CICR mechanism, involving ROS production by RBOHD to couple between cells, can support the observed velocities. Blocking ROS production slowed Ca2+ wave propagation. Extracellular ROS increases accompanied the Ca2+ wave.
conclusions: Plant systemic signaling in response to salt stress is supported by a ROS-assisted calcium-induced calcium-release mechanism involving ROS production by AtRBOHD and Ca2+ release dependent on the vacuolar channel TPC1. This model explains the observed Ca2+ wave speeds and the effects of various inhibitors and mutations.
relationships: The study highlights the interaction between ROS and Ca2+ signaling pathways in plant systemic signaling. It demonstrates the involvement of AtRBOHD in ROS production, TPC1 in Ca2+ release, and the interplay between apoplastic ROS and cytosolic Ca2+ in wave propagation.
insights: The propagation of stress-induced calcium waves in plants is more complex than a simple calcium-induced calcium-release mechanism. ROS play a critical role in assisting and accelerating this propagation, suggesting a tightly coordinated signaling network involving both calcium and reactive oxygen species.

title: Real-time In Vivo Recording of Arabidopsis Calcium Signals During Insect Feeding Using a Fluorescent Biosensor
objective: To determine the tissues in Arabidopsis where RBOHD expression is vital for systemic ROS signaling in response to local high-light (HL) stress.
methodology: Complemented the rbohD mutant with binary vectors driving RBOHD expression using its native promoter or tissue-specific promoters (epidermis, mesophyll, bundle sheath, xylem parenchyma, phloem).  Used whole-plant live ROS imaging (dichloroﬂuorescein oxidation) to image local and systemic changes in ROS levels.  Also measured ZAT12 gene expression and systemic acquired acclimation (SAA).
results: RBOHD expression in xylem parenchyma or phloem is essential for systemic ROS signaling and ZAT12 expression in response to local light stress.  Complementation with xylem parenchyma- or phloem-specific promoters restored light stress-driven SAA to the rbohD mutant. RBOHD and RBOHF cooperate to drive local and systemic ROS signaling at the vascular bundles during light stress. Lack of RBOHD blocked the spread of a systemic ROS wave response.
conclusions: RBOHD expression in phloem and xylem parenchyma cells is required for transmitting the ROS wave during the systemic response of Arabidopsis to light stress.  The ROS, calcium, electric, and hydraulic waves are potentially integrated in these tissues. Vascular bundles serve as the central rapid systemic signaling super highway of plants.
relationships: RBOHD and RBOHF cooperate in driving whole-plant ROS production during the systemic response to local light stress. GLR3.3 (phloem) and GLR3.6 (xylem parenchyma) are required for electric signals and calcium wave propagation, suggesting RBOHD/RBOHF function is required for coupling ROS, calcium, and electric waves.
insights: Systemic signaling during stress involves a complex interplay of ROS, calcium, electric, and hydraulic signals mediated through the vascular system.  RBOHD and RBOHF play key roles in ROS production and signaling within specific vascular tissues, contributing to systemic acclimation.

title: Orchestrating rapid long-distance signaling in plants with Ca2+ , ROS, and electrical signals
objective: To develop a repeatable method for measuring plant calcium signals during insect feeding using a fluorescent calcium biosensor, specifically focusing on the interaction between Arabidopsis thaliana and the green peach aphid Myzus persicae.
methodology: Detached leaves from Arabidopsis plants expressing the GCaMP3 calcium biosensor were floated in water. Aphids were introduced to the leaves, and fluorescence microscopy was used to monitor calcium dynamics before, during, and after feeding. The resulting images were analyzed to quantify fluorescence changes at the feeding site and in systemic regions of the leaf.
results: A localized, rapid elevation of cytosolic calcium concentration ([Ca2+]cyt) was observed around the aphid feeding site within minutes of settling. No systemic [Ca2+]cyt elevations were detected in other regions of the leaf. The area and speed of the calcium signal at the feeding site were quantified.
conclusions: The study demonstrates a method for visualizing and quantifying early plant responses to insect feeding, specifically a localized calcium elevation. This method can be used to further investigate the molecular and physiological characteristics of plant-insect interactions and plant responses to biotic stress.
relationships: The study focuses on the interaction between Arabidopsis thaliana and Myzus persicae, demonstrating how plants respond to biotic stress caused by insect feeding through calcium signaling.
insights: The localized calcium elevation is one of the first plant responses to insect feeding. The method allows for the molecular characterization of these signals and can be adapted to study other biotic and abiotic stresses, as well as different plant tissues and species.

title: Glutamate triggers long-distance, calcium-based plant defense signaling.
objective: To understand how plants rapidly transmit signals over long distances in response to environmental stresses, focusing on the roles of reactive oxygen species (ROS), calcium ions (Ca2+), and electrical signals.
methodology: Review of existing literature and experimental evidence on plant cell-to-cell communication, systemic signaling pathways, and the roles of ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals in stress responses. Analysis of genetic and molecular data related to key signaling components like RBOHD, TPC1, and GLR channels.
results: Identified ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals as key components of a rapid signaling network that enables plants to respond systemically to local stimuli.  The review highlights the importance of plasmodesmata (PD) in cell-to-cell communication and discusses potential mechanisms for signal propagation through both symplastic and apoplastic pathways.  It also suggests that a general priming signal may be followed by stimulus-specific signals for tailored responses.
conclusions: Rapid systemic signaling in plants involves a complex interplay of ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals, potentially acting as a priming mechanism for stress-specific responses.  The specificity of the systemic signal depends on its ability to elicit protective responses in unaffected tissues. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the integration of these signals and their role in plant acclimation and defense.
relationships: The study highlights the interconnectedness of ROS, Ca2+, and electrical signals in plant systemic signaling.  It also discusses the relationship between these rapid signals and slower mobile messengers like jasmonic and salicylic acids.  The review emphasizes the synergistic relationships between the initial priming signaling wave and stress-specific signals.
insights: The review suggests that plants may utilize a general stress message to rapidly prepare tissues for upcoming challenges, followed by more specific signals for tailored responses.  The ROS-responsive transcription factor ZAT12 is identified as a potential marker for transcript-level systemic activation and a clue to a general priming mechanism.  The study proposes that complex regulatory loops govern both the general priming events of systemic response and associated stimulus-specific changes.

title: Test of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome: A discovery environment to explore multiple plant biology spaceflight experiments.
objective: To identify and characterize the role of Glutathione (GSH) as a signaling molecule in plant defense responses, specifically in triggering long-distance calcium-based defense signaling events.
methodology: Genetic screening of an Arabidopsis hairpin RNA library, mutant analysis (pad2-1, glr3.3, glr3.6), measurements of phytohormone levels (JA, JA-Ile), calcium imaging using GCaMP3 reporter lines, transcriptome profiling (RNA-seq), gene expression analysis (qRT-PCR), and molecular docking simulations.
results: GSH was identified as a critical signaling molecule that triggers long-distance calcium-based defense signaling. A GSH-deficient mutant (pad2-1) showed attenuated defense signaling despite high glutamate levels. GSH application induced systemic calcium waves and defense gene expression. GLR3.3, a glutamate receptor-like protein, was found to be required for GSH-triggered calcium propagation.
conclusions: GSH acts as a wound signal that depends on GLR3.3 to trigger long-distance calcium-based defense signaling in plants. This signaling pathway activates JA biosynthesis and regulates plant defense responses, suggesting a conceptual parallel in GSH-mediated signal transmission across different kingdoms of life.
relationships: GSH relies on GLUTAMATE RECEPTOR-LIKE 3.3 (GLR3.3) to trigger long-distance calcium-based defense signaling events in plants. GSH and Glu may bind to different domains of GLR3.3 for activating ion channel activity and triggering leaf-to-leaf, calcium-based plant defense signaling.
insights: GSH induces distinct [Ca2+]cyt transmission patterns in systemic leaves. The spread of systemic [Ca2+]cyt triggered by GSH is preferentially initiated from marginal veins and rapidly transmitted to the mid veins, whereas Glu mediated [Ca2+]cyt transmission mainly propagated from mid veins to marginal veins.

title: Tonoplast-localized Ca2+ pumps regulate Ca2+ signals during pattern-triggered immunity in Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To develop a database (TOAST) that aggregates and visualizes plant spaceflight omics-level data from multiple repositories, applies a uniform set of analytical steps, and makes visualization of massive datasets accessible for interactive comparisons between experiments.
methodology: Developed the Test Of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome (TOAST) database using Qlik database management software. Integrated publicly available spaceflight transcriptomics datasets from NASA's GeneLab, NCBI-GEO, and CATdb. Re-indexed datasets using Entrez gene identifiers. Reanalyzed microarray data using R-studio codes and RNAseq data using CyVerse and iDEP R-Shiny application. Incorporated Gene Ontology (GO), SUBA4 subcellular locale database, and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) databases. Developed a web interface with interactive dashboards and volcano plots for data visualization.
results: TOAST database includes transcriptomics data from Arabidopsis thaliana and rice, along with limited proteomic and epigenomic data. The database allows for comparisons between different spaceflight experiments, including those using different species, tissues, and growth conditions. TOAST confirmed previously published inferences regarding spaceflight-imposed stress responses, such as oxidative stress. TOAST analyses suggest changes to mitochondrial function as likely shared responses in many plant spaceflight experiments.
conclusions: The TOAST database provides a data-rich environment to explore commonalities and differences in plant responses to spaceflight and related environments. It facilitates hypothesis generation for future experimental testing. The TOAST architecture is biological kingdom agnostic and can be extended to facilitate data exploration across various biological systems analyzed in spaceflight.
relationships: Identified relationships between gene expression patterns and spaceflight conditions, including microgravity, radiation, and hardware. Highlighted the connection between spaceflight and oxidative stress responses, particularly the "high light early" signature. Revealed potential links between spaceflight and changes in mitochondrial function. Demonstrated cross-species conservation of certain transcriptional responses to spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight induces oxidative stress responses in plants, even in the absence of high light levels. Mitochondrial function is altered in plants experiencing spaceflight, potentially due to hypoxia or other spaceflight-related stressors. Certain transcriptional responses to spaceflight are conserved across different plant species, suggesting fundamental biological mechanisms at play.

title: The fast and the furious: Rapid long-range signaling in plants.
objective: To explore how the two tonoplast-localized pumps, ACA4 and ACA11, impact flg22-dependent Ca2+ signaling and related defense responses in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Monitored cytoplasmic Ca2+ dynamics in aca4/11 plants expressing the ratiometric, genetically encoded, fluorescent protein-based Ca2+ sensor YC-Nano65. Used confocal ratio imaging to follow changes after flg22 addition with single-cell resolution. Measured transcript levels of PTI marker genes via qPCR. Assessed pathogen resistance by flood-inoculating seedlings with Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato DC3000. Relocalized ACA8, a plasma membrane pump, to the tonoplast and assessed its ability to rescue aca4/11 phenotypes.
results: The double-knockout aca4/11 exhibited increased basal Ca2+ levels and Ca2+ signals of higher amplitude than wild-type plants. Elevated temperature suppressed lesion formation and flg22-dependent Ca2+ signals in aca4/11. Relocalization of ACA8 to the tonoplast rescued the growth and lesion phenotype of aca4/11, as well as the altered Ca2+ signaling.
conclusions: Tonoplast-localized Ca2+ pumps are critical for the proper maintenance of Ca2+ dynamics in innate immune responses. Ca2+ transport across the tonoplast by an ACA is the critical feature for this signaling system, but may not require regulatory circuits specifically tailored to Ca2+ pumps normally targeted to this location. The Ca2+ signaling system of pumps and channels shows features of resilience and compensation.
relationships: ACA4 and ACA11 are linked to the regulation of Ca2+ dynamics during pattern-triggered immunity (PTI). ACA8, when relocalized to the tonoplast, can compensate for the loss of ACA4 and ACA11 function. Elevated temperature attenuates PTI-related Ca2+ dynamics.
insights: Tonoplast-localized Ca2+ pumps play an important role in regulating both response to the PAMP flg22 and in the induction of PTI. The basic core pumping activity of these transporters appears robust enough to work in varied cellular locations. The Ca2+ homeostatic system appears flexible enough to integrate heterologous pumping activity into a system capable of supporting normal Ca2+-based signaling activities.

title: Rad-Bio-App: A discovery environment for biologists to explore spaceflight-related radiation exposures
objective: To understand the rapid, long-distance signaling mechanisms in plants, focusing on electrical signals, ROS, and hydraulic waves.
methodology: Review of existing literature and experimental findings on plant signaling pathways, including studies on Mimosa pudica, Venus flytrap, and Arabidopsis.
results: Identified key components involved in rapid systemic signaling, including ion channels (GLRs, CNGCs, K+ channels), H+ pumps, ROS production (RBOHs), and the role of the vacuole (TPC1). Demonstrated the involvement of these components in responses to stimuli like wounding, high light stress, and pathogen attack.
conclusions: Plants utilize a complex network of electrical, chemical, and hydraulic signals for rapid communication and coordination of responses to environmental stimuli. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the molecular mechanisms and interactions between these signaling pathways.
relationships: Electrical signals (APs and VPs) are linked to ion fluxes across the plasma membrane, with roles for vacuolar ion channels and intracellular GLRs. ROS waves are dependent on RBOHD and RBOHF and interact with Ca2+ dynamics. Hydraulic signals may also contribute to rapid systemic communication.
insights: Systemic signaling involves a multifaceted approach, with multiple signaling networks potentially tuned to specific stimuli. The vasculature serves as a highway for these signals, operating in concert with hydraulic communication. Organelles like the ER and vacuole play important roles in propagating these events.

title: The vacuolar H+/Ca transporter CAX1 participates in submergence and anoxia stress responses.
objective: To develop a web-accessible database (Rad-Bio-App) that imports radiation metadata from experiments archived in NASA’s GeneLab data repository, allowing users to explore these experiments in the context of their radiation exposure and other metadata.
methodology: The Rad-Bio-App was built using the Qlik database management software. Radiation data was aggregated from NASA’s GeneLab data repository and other sources (RaD-X high-altitude balloon mission, CRaTER, the RAD, the LRD and on Apollo missions), manually curated, and linked through the Qlik software engine to provide a searchable relational database. The app provides customizable interactive representations of datasets, allowing for their presentation as a simple graphical user interface built around data-centric dashboards. Data filters are incorporated allowing the user to rapidly narrow searches and comparisons by e.g., organism, radiation type, or mission.
results: The Rad-Bio-App provides an interactive graphical interface through which investigators can visualize, filter, and compare radiation dosimetry and other metadata across the GLDS. It allows users to develop filtered, curated lists of omics datasets within the GeneLab data repository, that can then be explored for predicted radiation-related responses. The app includes several dashboards that simplify access to particular kinds of radiation data along with visualization and filtering tools.
conclusions: The Rad-Bio-App is a data mining visualization tool that enables the rapid identification of omics datasets deposited in the NASA GeneLab data repository, which are relevant for a specific spaceflight radiation scenario or specific characteristics of radiation exposure. It links to GeneLab datasets, making it straightforward to extract processed gene expression tables from GeneLab to identify common pathways that may be modified by specific radiation environments. As more researchers enter datasets into GeneLab, the Rad-Bio-App should become an increasingly powerful tool to help accelerate assessment of the effects of Space radiation environments on living entities.
relationships: The Rad-Bio-App capitalizes on the FAIRness standards and rich data curation of the GLDS. It complements the data visualization portal on the GeneLab website by extending the range and details of the searchable radiation metadata and providing an interactive ability to apply quantitative filters simultaneously across all datasets.
insights: Space radiation induces more deleterious effects in tissues than similar doses of ionizing radiation on Earth. The effects of exposure to space radiation can lead to a wide array of cellular and microenvironment effects such as chronic inflammation, tissue degeneration, and impaired nerve function. Different species exhibit varying degrees of radiation tolerance, and within a species, radiation response is modulated by an individual’s genetics. The Rad-Bio-App can help identify space radiation conditions currently not being simulated on the ground.

title: Meta-analysis of the space flight and microgravity response of the Arabidopsis plant transcriptome
objective: To clarify the role of CAX genes in anoxia tolerance using a seedling survival assay and to identify molecular and physiological processes influencing anoxia tolerance.
methodology: Seedlings of Arabidopsis were exposed to anoxic conditions, and survival was monitored. Chlorophyll loss was measured. RNA-sequencing and proteomic analyses were performed to identify changes in gene expression and protein abundance. Cytosolic calcium levels were measured using a calcium biosensor.
results: cax1 mutants were more tolerant to anoxic conditions and submergence. cax1 showed reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. Transcriptomic and proteomic analysis revealed changes in transcripts and proteins for Ca transport and numerous signaling pathways. cax1 changed the amplitude and duration of Ca signals during reoxygenation.
conclusions: CAX1 expression is detrimental to anoxic conditions and submergence. cax1 has adaptations to endure anoxia stress, including altered expression of ROS, HRGs, and temperature perception genes; changes in light and carbohydrate metabolism; and altered Ca signaling. The cax1-mediated anoxia tolerance is caused by extensive changes in both metabolism and signaling.
relationships: CAX1 negatively impacts low oxygen tolerance. ERF-VII transcription factors are involved in low oxygen tolerance. Ca signaling plays a role in plant sensing of external signals.
insights: Altered tonoplast H+/Ca transport impacts an array of biological processes associated with anoxia. The loss of high-capacity low-affinity Ca transport caused by disruption of CAX1 led to numerous changes in gene expression and protein abundance.

title: Meta-analysis of the space ﬂight and microgravity response of the Arabidopsis plant transcriptome
objective: To compare transcriptomic analysis of Arabidopsis thaliana spaceflight experiments to understand plant response to altered gravity, hardware influence, and increased radiation exposure.
methodology: Re-analyzed 15 Arabidopsis thaliana spaceflight experiments from NASA’s GeneLab data repository using a standardized computational pipeline (microarray or RNA-seq).  Developed a metadata matrix to select studies with high similarity scores based on experimental design elements (plant age, flight hardware). Pairwise factor correlation analysis was performed by inspection of the Matrix in Supplementary Data 1 and manually scoring factors that are similar between different pairs of studies, assigning a value of 1 for each factor shared between a pair and a value of zero if that factor was different.
results: Analysis type (microarray vs. RNA-seq) and environmental/hardware conditions significantly confound plant reactions to spaceflight.  Confirmed spaceflight-related changes in cell wall processes and oxidative stress. Revealed conserved spaceflight-triggered changes in expression of the cold response gene COLD RESPONSIVE 78 (COR78) and shifts in ion transport processes.  Identified choice of flight hardware and assay technique as factors imposing greater differences than spaceflight treatment.
conclusions: The metadata matrix allows researchers to explore plant biology transcriptomic data from spaceflight studies and better understand factors impacting comparisons between datasets.  Comparisons across different transcriptome monitoring technologies (RNA-seq versus microarray) should be performed with great care as differences in the technology used can impose greater variation on results than the biological treatment (spaceflight versus ground control); (2) environmental conditions and hardware-related constraints in the experimental design produce smaller but also important differences that can confound interpretation of the spaceflight versus ground control comparisons; (3) when these factors are controlled for, comparisons across the breadth of spaceflight-related Arabidopsis experiments reveal alterations in general responses to environmental stresses, photosynthesis, and other elements of primary and secondary metabolism.
relationships: Identified relationships between experimental design (hardware, lighting) and gene expression patterns. Highlighted the importance of considering batch effects in meta-analyses. Revealed connections between spaceflight responses and stress responses, photosynthesis, and metabolism.
insights: Spaceflight induces stress-related responses in plants, impacting fundamental aspects of plant function.  Choice of hardware and assay technique can significantly influence results.  The plastid may be a key site of spaceflight-induced responses.  HSP101 and COR78 are potential core markers of the spaceflight response in BRIC hardware experiments.

title: Ionizing Radiation Stimulates Expression of Pro-Osteoclastogenic Genes in Marrow and Skeletal Tissue
objective: To determine if low-to-moderate doses of ionizing radiation accelerate postpubertal loss of microarchitectural integrity in bone over time.
methodology: Male mice were irradiated with varying doses of gamma radiation (1, 10, or 100 cGy) or sham-irradiated. Microcomputed tomography was used to quantify microarchitecture of cancellous bone. Bone marrow cells were cultured to assess osteoblast and osteoclast differentiation potential.
results: Irradiation at 100 cGy caused a decline in trabecular number and connectivity density, and an increase in trabecular spacing, resembling normal microarchitectural changes expected during aging. Lower doses (1 cGy or 10 cGy) had no discernible effect. Bone marrow cell differentiation potential was unaffected by radiation.
conclusions: A moderate dose of gamma radiation accelerates changes in trabecular microarchitecture, similar to skeletal aging. Age-related microarchitectural changes precede bone loss. Bone marrow-derived osteoblast progenitors and osteoclast precursors are not affected by low-to-moderate doses of gamma radiation.
relationships: Ionizing radiation at 100 cGy (but not at 1 cGy or 10 cGy) appeared to accelerate structural changes in the murine skeleton, expected also to occur during progressive, post-pubertal aging in humans prior to the onset of type II osteoporosis.
insights: The study suggests that age-related microarchitectural changes in bone precede overt declines in cancellous bone volume. Mature cells of the osteoblast and osteoclast lineage, rather than progenitors, are responsible for the near-term microarchitectural changes triggered by gamma radiation.

title: Preservation of Multiple Mammalian Tissues to Maximize Science Return from Ground Based and Spaceflight Experiments
objective: To understand the mechanisms behind radiation-induced bone resorption by examining the temporal expression of key genes and proteins involved in osteoclastogenesis and bone resorption following exposure to ionizing radiation.
methodology: Male mice were exposed to gamma rays or heavy ions. Serum, marrow, and mineralized tissue were harvested at different time points. Bone microarchitecture was assessed using microcomputed tomography. Gene expression was measured using qRT-PCR. Serum tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b (TRACP 5b) levels were measured to assess bone resorption.
results: Irradiation caused a prompt and persistent rise in the expression of Rankl within marrow cells. Expression of other pro-osteoclastic cytokines also increased. The ratio of Rankl/Opg in marrow increased. Radiation exposure increased a serum marker of bone resorption and led to cancellous bone loss.
conclusions: Total body irradiation caused temporal elevations in the concentrations of specific genes expressed within marrow and mineralized tissue related to bone resorption, including select cytokines that lead to osteoclastogenesis and elevated resorption, likely accounting for rapid deterioration of cancellous microarchitecture.
relationships: Nfe2l2 expression was strongly correlated with Nfatc1, Csf1, Tnf, and Rankl expression, suggesting a link between oxidative stress response and osteoclastogenesis.
insights: Radiation exposure induces a pro-resorptive state in cancellous tissue, leading to net bone loss. This is associated with increased osteoclast numbers and resorbing surfaces. The study identifies key cytokines and molecular pathways involved in radiation-induced bone loss, providing potential targets for therapeutic intervention.

title: Hindlimb Unloading: Rodent Analog for Microgravity
objective: To optimize methods for sample recovery and maximize science return from rodent experiments, relevant to both ground-based and spaceflight studies. This includes determining the impacts of tissue harvest time post-euthanasia, preservation methods, and storage duration on RNA quality and enzyme activities in liver and spleen. Also, to develop methods for dissecting multiple tissues after long-duration storage in situ.
methodology: Tissues from mice were dissected and preserved at various time points post-euthanasia and stored at -80°C for up to 11 months. Some tissues were recovered from frozen carcasses stored at -80°C for up to 7 months. RNA quantity and quality were assessed by measuring RIN values using a Bioanalyzer. Hepatic enzyme activities (catalase, glutathione reductase, and GAPDH) were also measured.
results: Fresh tissues collected up to one hour post-euthanasia and stored up to 11 months at -80°C showed minimal adverse effects on RNA quality in livers and RNAlater-preserved spleens. Liver enzyme activities were similar to controls. Tissues dissected from frozen carcasses stored for up to 7 months at -80°C had variable results depending on the tissue. RNA quality of liver, heart, and kidneys were minimally affected after 6-7 months of storage, while RNA degradation was evident in small intestine, bone, and bone marrow when collected from carcasses frozen for 2.5 months.
conclusions: Protocols developed for spaceflight experiments support the retrieval of high-quality samples for RNA expression and some protein analyses, despite delayed preservation post-euthanasia or prolonged storage. Many additional tissues for gene expression analysis can be obtained by dissection even following prolonged storage of the tissue in situ at -80°C. These findings are relevant to both ground-based experiments with constrained sample collection and spaceflight experiments with on-orbit sample recovery.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between tissue harvest time, preservation methods, storage duration, and RNA/enzyme quality. It also highlights the impact of these factors on different tissue types.
insights: The study provides insights into optimizing tissue preservation protocols for both ground-based and spaceflight experiments. It demonstrates that delayed preservation and prolonged storage do not necessarily compromise sample quality, especially when using appropriate preservation methods like RNAlater and controlled freezing. Specific tissues, like spleen, liver, heart, and kidney, are more resilient to prolonged storage than others, such as small intestine and bone marrow.

title: Redox Signaling and Its Impact on Skeletal and Vascular Responses to Spaceflight
objective: To elucidate artery-specific and cell type-specific molecular signatures, identify key cell sub-clusters, assess intercellular communication networks, and identify important transcription factors in rat carotid and femoral arteries under simulated microgravity conditions.
methodology: Single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) was performed on carotid artery (CA) and femoral artery (FA) cells from rats subjected to 3 months of hindlimb unloading (HU) and compared to control rats. Clustering analysis, cell type annotation, subclustering, functional enrichment analysis (GO, KEGG, GSVA), pseudotime trajectory analysis, cellular communication analysis (CellChat), cell cycle analysis, and transcription factor (TF) analysis (SCENIC) were conducted.
results: Identified 10 major cell types (ECs, SMCs, fibroblasts, macrophages, B cells, T cells, dendritic cells, neutrophils, neurons, and stem cells) and 23 cell clusters. Observed a reduction in SMC fraction in HU-CA and HU-FA compared to controls, and a higher percentage of ECs in HU-CA. Identified artery-specific differentially expressed genes between control and HU groups in ECs and SMCs. Sub-clustering analysis revealed distinct gene expression profiles for EC and SMC sub-clusters. Cellular communication analysis highlighted the role of fibroblasts and SMCs in intercellular communication changes. TF analysis identified key TFs responsible for vascular cell heterogeneity and alterations in transcription during HU.
conclusions: This study provides a comprehensive single-cell compendium of the vascular remodeling process in rats under simulated microgravity. The identification of region-specific and artery-specific transcriptomic changes contributes to a more comprehensive understanding of the vascular remodeling process. The study highlights the importance of fibroblasts and immune cells, as well as the sub-clusters within the major arterial cell types, in the intricate biological processes at play under simulated microgravity.
relationships: The study reveals complex relationships between different cell types in the arteries, particularly between SMCs and fibroblasts, and how these relationships are altered under simulated microgravity. It also highlights the role of intercellular communication and transcription factors in mediating these relationships.
insights: Simulated microgravity induces significant changes in the cellular composition and gene expression profiles of rat carotid and femoral arteries. Fibroblasts play a crucial role in vascular remodeling. Endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndoMT) may contribute to endothelial impairment. The study provides insights into the mechanisms underlying arterial remodeling in microgravity conditions.

title: Influence of social isolation during prolonged simulated weightlessness by hindlimb unloading
objective: To review the current understanding of how microgravity and radiation impact the mammalian skeleton and vasculature, focusing on redox signaling, oxidative stress, and tissue dysfunction.
methodology: Review of existing literature and experiments from spaceflight and ground-based models (primarily rodent hindlimb unloading) examining the effects of microgravity and radiation on skeletal and vascular health.
