results: Spaceflight and its analogs (hindlimb unloading) induce oxidative stress and damage in various tissues, leading to musculoskeletal and vascular dysfunction. This involves altered redox status, increased ROS/RNS production, and downregulation of antioxidant defenses.  Vascular function is critical for skeletal health, and impairments in vascular function contribute to bone loss.  Cellular defenses against oxidative damage, particularly NRF2, SOD1, and Catalase, are important for preserving skeletal and vascular health.
conclusions: Oxidative damage is linked to tissue dysfunction resulting from spaceflight factors. Countermeasures targeting excess ROS may moderate the radiation stress response of bone cells. Further research is needed to determine whether oxidative damage mediates or results from progressive tissue degeneration during spaceflight and to assess the potential of antioxidant-based countermeasures.
relationships: Microgravity and radiation promote ROS generation in bone vasculature, creating an imbalance favoring peroxynitrite over NO production, lowering NO bioavailability, diminishing endothelium-dependent vasodilation, and disrupting bone circulation coupling with bone remodeling. Vascular perfusion and skeletal function are coupled, with impaired re-vascularization in response to bone injury observed in spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight-induced bone loss and vascular dysfunction are linked to oxidative stress and impaired redox signaling.  Antioxidant-based countermeasures may be effective in mitigating these effects, but careful consideration must be given to their potential impact on essential ROS signaling events.  Long-term studies are needed to fully understand the health risks associated with extended space missions and the latent effects on the cardiovascular system and bone marrow stem cells.

title: Validation of a new Rodent experimental System to investigate consequences of Long Duration Space Habitation
objective: To determine the contribution of social isolation to tissue responses to hindlimb unloading (HU), a model for simulating weightlessness, and to develop a refined HU system allowing social housing of mice.
methodology: A 30-day HU experiment was conducted on adult female mice, comparing singly and socially housed animals. Musculoskeletal, immune, and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis responses were evaluated. Microcomputed tomography (µCT) was used to analyze bone structure, flow cytometry for white blood cell analysis, and ELISA for corticosterone levels.
results: HU led to musculoskeletal deficits regardless of social environment. However, immune and HPA axis responses were differentially impacted. HU reduced % CD4+ T cells in singly housed mice only. HU increased adrenal gland mass in socially housed mice, while social isolation increased adrenal gland mass in normally loaded controls. HU elevated plasma corticosterone levels in both singly and socially housed mice.
conclusions: Musculoskeletal responses to simulated weightlessness are similar regardless of social environment, but adrenal and immune responses differ. Combined stressors can mask select responses to HU. The social environment can differentially impact some aspects of the HPA axis in response to HU.
relationships: Social isolation can be a confounding factor for interpreting experimental outcomes from both rodent spaceflight and ground-based studies. The HPA axis interacts with the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis. Tight regulation of the HPA axis is critical for the maintenance of tissue health, including the immune system.
insights: The study highlights the importance of considering social environment in HU studies. Facilitating social interactions can potentially mitigate some spaceflight-induced immune impairments. The availability of both single and social housing HU models can facilitate studies that aim to distinguish the effects of social interactions on the HPA axis and immune system, thereby expanding the utility of the HU model for studying how the spaceflight environment impacts organ systems.

title: Skeletal tissue regulation by catalase over-expression in mitochondria
objective: To establish new capabilities for conducting reliable and reproducible long-duration rodent experiments in space with on-orbit sample collection, minimizing chronic stress responses and avoiding confounding variables associated with returning to Earth.
methodology: Two separate studies were conducted with a total of 20 mice: a NASA Validation study and an ISS National Lab Experimental study. Mice were launched to the International Space Station (ISS) and resided in microgravity for 21/22 or 37 days. Animal health and behavior were monitored by daily video. Samples were dissected on-orbit or after return to Earth from frozen carcasses. Tissue samples were analyzed for gene expression, enzyme activities, and RNA quality.
results: Mice appeared healthy throughout the mission. Spaceflight increased animal activity. Mice exposed to 37 days of spaceflight displayed elevated liver mass and select enzyme activities. Soleus muscle showed atrophy. RNA and enzyme activity levels in tissues recovered on-orbit were of acceptable quality.
conclusions: The study established a new capability for conducting long-duration experiments in space with on-orbit sample recovery. Habitation on-orbit did not provoke a chronic stress response. The hardware system and operations were further developed to support the return of living animals to Earth, enabling the study of the entire cycle of long-duration space travel.
relationships: Spaceflight leads to muscle atrophy, changes in organ weights (thymus, liver), and alterations in enzyme activity. The method of tissue collection/preservation may affect results obtained. Physiological accommodation to the spaceflight environment entails at least a two-phase process: an initial acute phase and a long-duration phase.
insights: Long-duration spaceflight experiments with rodents are feasible with on-orbit sample collection. The study provides insights into the physiological changes that occur in response to spaceflight, including muscle atrophy, changes in organ weights, and alterations in enzyme activity. Further research is needed to understand the long-term effects of spaceflight on the body.

title: Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria mitigates changes in hippocampal cytokine expression following simulated microgravity and isolation.
objective: To clarify whether mitochondrial dysfunction could trigger disuse-induced muscle atrophy also in a fast muscle, the gastrocnemius.
methodology: Experiments were performed on mice with hindlimb unloading (HU) for 3, 7, and 14 days.  Measurements included assessment of muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA), myosin heavy chain (MHC) isoform content, Western blot analysis for protein expression, OxyBlot analysis for protein carbonylation, gene expression analysis by RT-PCR, hydrogen peroxide quantification, and OXPHOS capacity in permeabilized muscle fibers.
results: HU resulted in gastrocnemius atrophy. The antioxidant defense system reacted to the initial ROS increase. Mitochondrial fusion was impaired in gastrocnemius muscle. Energy stress activated the protein degradation pathway through AMPK activation. Elevated muscle PGC-1α completely preserved muscle mass by preventing the activation of catabolic systems.
conclusions: A metabolic program can play a major role in triggering disuse muscle atrophy in both slow and fast muscles. In gastrocnemius, the primary phenomenon is a down-regulation of pro-fusion proteins, which causes energy stress and induction of atrogenes through AMPK activation. Compounds inducing PGC-1α expression could be useful to treat and prevent muscle atrophy.
relationships: Down-regulation of pro-fusion proteins leads to mitochondrial dysfunction and AMPK activation. AMPK activation leads to the activation of FoxO, which induces the transcription of genes encoding proteins involved in protein degradation via both the autophagy and the ubiquitin proteasome pathways.
insights: PGC-1α levels higher than basal are necessary to increase pro-fusion proteins, thus preventing gastrocnemius muscle atrophy during disuse.

title: Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria mitigates changes in hippocampal cytokine expression following simulated microgravity and isolation
objective: To determine the effects of isolation and simulated microgravity, alone or combined, on the inflammatory cytokine milieu of the hippocampus in mice, and to investigate the role of mitochondrial reactive oxygen species (ROS) in these responses.
methodology: Adult female wild-type and MCAT (mitochondrial catalase-overexpressing) mice were subjected to simulated microgravity via hindlimb unloading (HU) for 30 days, with single or social housing. Cytokine protein expression in the hippocampus and plasma was analyzed. Oxidative damage was assessed by measuring 4-HNE adduct levels. Plasma corticosterone levels were also measured.
results: Isolation and simulated microgravity each regulated a distinct set of cytokines in the hippocampus. Their combined effects were not additive. Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria protected against isolation- and/or simulated microgravity-induced changes in cytokine expression. Isolation increased oxidative damage in the hippocampus. Simulated microgravity upregulated IL-20 in plasma, an effect mitigated by catalase overexpression. Isolation affected Eotaxin and MDC levels in plasma. Corticosterone levels were generally higher in social groups compared to single-housed groups.
conclusions: Isolation and simulated microgravity induce distinct changes in hippocampal cytokine expression, with mitochondrial ROS playing a key role in mediating these responses. Antioxidant-based approaches may mitigate CNS risks associated with long-term space exploration, bedrest, and isolation on Earth.
relationships: Mitochondrial ROS signaling is implicated in neuroinflammatory responses to spaceflight stressors. Isolation can alter aspects of CNS immune signaling and lead to increased oxidative damage in the CNS. Cytokine responses to spaceflight stressors in the hippocampus versus circulation were discrete. Increased plasma corticosterone levels were observed in social housed mice even as plasma levels of an oxidative damage marker and a subset of inflammatory cytokine protein levels in the hippocampus generally decreased.

title: Novel Organelles with Elements of Bacterial and Eukaryotic Secretion Systems Weaponize Parasites of Drosophila
objective: To characterize the function and tissue-specific requirements of the t6A biosynthesis pathway in Drosophila melanogaster, focusing on the Kae1 protein.
methodology: Isolation and characterization of Drosophila kae1 mutants through EMS mutagenesis. Biochemical assays (primer extension, LC-MS/MS) to assess t6A modification levels. Genetic complementation tests in yeast. Microscopic analysis of tissues and cells. Generation of somatic clones in imaginal discs using FRT80 system. RNAi-mediated knockdown of kae1 in specific tissues.
results: Identification of an allelic series of kae1 mutants in Drosophila, showing varying degrees of t6A reduction. Drosophila Kae1 and its partners can complement yeast t6A mutants. kae1 mutants exhibit aberrant hematopoietic development, including lymph gland overgrowth and lamellocyte overproduction.  kae1 is essential for imaginal disc development but not throughout the larval CNS. Mitotic cells are more sensitive to kae1 loss than non-proliferating cells.
conclusions: The t6A modification pathway is conserved in metazoans and is essential for normal development in Drosophila. The requirement for t6A varies depending on the tissue and cell type, with mitotic cells being more sensitive to its loss. Kae1 plays a role in tumor suppression in larval hematopoietic tissue.
relationships: The study reveals connections between t6A modification, cell proliferation, and hematopoietic development in Drosophila. It also suggests potential links between t6A, SUMO, and the cell cycle.
insights: The research highlights the tissue-specific requirements of a general regulatory factor and the utility of the Drosophila model for understanding the roles of t6A modification during animal development and disease. It also suggests that mitochondrial Qri7 might contribute to the remaining t6A in kae1 mutants.

title: A combined computational strategy of sequence and structural analysis predicts the existence of a functional eicosanoid pathway in Drosophila melanogaster.
objective: To investigate the composition and function of virus-like particles (VLPs) produced by Leptopilina heterotoma (Lh), a parasitoid wasp that infects Drosophila melanogaster, and to compare them to VLPs from other wasp species.
methodology: Proteomic analysis of Lh VLPs, comparison of protein sequences to other organisms, structural modeling of VLP proteins, and functional predictions based on sequence similarities and structural features. Microscopy techniques were used to visualize VLPs and their effects on host cells.
results: Lh VLPs lack viral structural proteins but are rich in eukaryotic microvesicular proteins. They contain a diverse set of proteins, including eukaryotic proteins, immunity-associated proteins, and novel sequences. Some Lh VLP proteins share similarities with bacterial secretion system proteins. A key protein, p40, shows structural similarities to bacterial T3SS proteins.
conclusions: Lh VLPs represent a new class of extracellular organelles with mixed prokaryotic/eukaryotic properties, termed Mixed Strategy Extracellular Vesicles (MSEVs). These vesicles likely play a role in immune suppression and virulence during wasp parasitism of Drosophila. The presence of prokaryotic-like proteins suggests a possible evolutionary link between MSEVs and bacterial secretion systems.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between parasitoid wasps and their Drosophila hosts, focusing on the role of VLPs in mediating the interaction. It also highlights the evolutionary relationships between eukaryotic and prokaryotic protein secretion systems.
insights: VLPs produced by parasitoid wasps are not viruses but rather complex organelles with a diverse array of proteins. These organelles may have evolved through horizontal gene transfer or other mechanisms, and they play a crucial role in the wasp's ability to suppress the host's immune system. The discovery of prokaryotic-like proteins in VLPs suggests a possible evolutionary link between eukaryotic and prokaryotic protein secretion systems.

title: Immune suppressive extracellular vesicle proteins of Leptopilina heterotoma are encoded in the wasp genome.
objective: To identify potential eicosanoid biosynthesis pathways in Drosophila melanogaster using computational sequence and structural analysis, challenging the view that insects lack such pathways.
methodology: A combined computational strategy of sequence and structural analysis was used. This included iterative sequence searches (PSI-BLAST, DELTA-BLAST, JACKHMMER), structural modeling (HHpred, MODELLER, LOMETS, I-TASSER), and domain analysis (Pfam, InterPro, CDART, Uniprot). Candidate Drosophila enzymes were selected based on sequence identity, domain architecture, structural conservation, and presence of functional residues. Models were validated using ProSa, ProQ2 and MODFOLD4 servers.
results: The study identified several candidate Drosophila enzymes with structural similarity to mammalian eicosanoid synthesis enzymes. Eight high-confidence matches (CG1742, CG4086, CG6084, CG10602, CG6461, CG6154, CG12013, CG18585) shared at least 30% sequence identity, similar overall folds, and conserved functional residues. Several mid-range and distant candidates were also identified, including potential cyclooxygenase orthologs (CG4009, CG6969, CG7660). No lipoxygenase ortholog was found.
conclusions: The study suggests that D. melanogaster may possess a functional eicosanoid synthesis pathway, challenging the current view. The identified candidate enzymes share structural similarities and conserved functional residues with mammalian enzymes. Further experimental studies are needed to validate the exact roles and physiological context of these enzymes.
relationships: The study focuses on the relationship between mammalian and Drosophila melanogaster enzymes involved in eicosanoid synthesis. It explores sequence and structural similarities to identify potential orthologs in Drosophila.
insights: The research provides insights into the potential existence of eicosanoid pathways in insects, which were previously thought to be absent. It highlights the importance of using advanced computational methods to identify divergent orthologs and suggests that D. melanogaster could be a valuable model organism for studying eicosanoid signaling and inflammation.

title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model.
objective: To describe additional proteins in the Mixed Strategy Extracellular Vesicles (MSEV) proteome of Leptopilina heterotoma (Lh) and examine their relationship with polydnaviruses (PDV) and other viral proteins, and to determine whether MSEV genes are encoded in the wasp genome.
methodology: The study involved analyzing previously undescribed open reading frames (ORFs) from the Lh 14 MSEV proteome in the context of published female abdominal and whole-body Lh 14 transcriptomes.  Various bioinformatics tools such as BLAST2GO, InterProScan, Conserved Domain Search (CDD), GhostKOALA algorithm, and FunRich algorithm were used for annotation and enrichment analyses.  Genomic DNA was extracted from Lh males and females, and DNA libraries were prepared and sequenced using Illumina HiSeq 4000. De novo assembly of reads and scaffolding of contigs was performed using ABySS 2.2 and Platanus-allee.  Whole-body transcriptome sequencing and de novo assembly of Lh transcripts were also performed using Trinity v2.5. PCR and sequencing were used to verify gene structure predictions.
results: The analysis identified 246 additional proteins from the L. heterotoma MSEV proteome.  A combined analysis reinforced the idea that the MSEV proteome is enriched in exosomal proteins.  De novo genomic assembly and analyses revealed that a majority (375/407; approximately 90%) of the MSEV proteins are encoded in the wasp genome. Transcriptomic analysis validated the expression of MSEV genes. No strong evidence was found to support a viral origin of MSEVs, although viral hits were possible.
conclusions: The study provides a clearer understanding of the nature of MSEVs, suggesting that specialized extracellular vesicles transfer wasp virulence factors and other parasite proteins into Drosophila host cells. The results strongly suggest that MSEVs are encoded in the wasp nuclear genome. The cellular nature of Lh vesicles is likely shared by closely related wasps. The study suggests that MSEVs have a viral origin, but the analysis is limited by the fragmentation of the genome.
relationships: The study focuses on the host-parasite relationship between Leptopilina heterotoma wasps and Drosophila melanogaster. The research explores how the wasp's MSEVs, containing virulence factors, interact with and suppress the host's immune system to facilitate successful parasitism. The study also examines the evolutionary relationships between MSEVs and viral proteins, as well as the genomic organization of MSEV genes within the wasp genome.
insights: MSEVs are complex structures encoded in the wasp genome and enriched in exosomal proteins. They transfer virulence factors into Drosophila host cells. The MSEV proteome contains proteins involved in immune suppression, vesicle trafficking, and other cellular processes. The study suggests that MSEVs may have a viral origin, but further research is needed to confirm this hypothesis. The findings provide a foundation for future studies on the functional roles of MSEV proteins and their impact on host-parasite interactions.

title: A parasitoid wasp of Drosophila employs preemptive and reactive strategies to deplete its host's blood cells
objective: To investigate the effects of spaceflight and simulated microgravity on the virulence of Serratia marcescens and its impact on the immune response of Drosophila melanogaster.
methodology: Serratia marcescens was exposed to spaceflight conditions on the International Space Station (ISS) and simulated microgravity using a rotating wall vessel (RWV).  Drosophila melanogaster were infected with space-flown, simulated microgravity-treated, and ground control bacteria. Fly survival, in vivo bacterial growth, and gene expression were analyzed.
results: Spaceflight-exposed Serratia marcescens exhibited increased virulence in Drosophila melanogaster compared to ground controls. This increased virulence was reversible upon subculturing the bacteria under normal gravity conditions. Simulated microgravity also increased bacterial virulence.  The increased virulence was associated with increased bacterial growth within the host.  Host gene expression analysis revealed few significant changes in immune-related genes.
conclusions: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity can increase the virulence of Serratia marcescens in Drosophila melanogaster. The increased virulence is likely due to changes in the pathogen itself, rather than a significant alteration in the host's immune response. Microgravity may be a primary factor mediating the observed virulence differences.
relationships: The study demonstrates a host-pathogen interaction between Drosophila melanogaster and Serratia marcescens, influenced by spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions. It explores the relationship between bacterial virulence, host immune response, and environmental factors.
insights: Spaceflight can induce temporary physiological changes in bacteria, leading to increased virulence. Microgravity appears to be a key factor in these changes.  The study highlights the importance of understanding how spaceflight affects microbial virulence and host-pathogen interactions to protect astronaut health during long-duration space missions.

title: A parasitoid wasp of Drosophila employs preemptive and reactive strategies to deplete its host’s blood cells
objective: To understand how Leptopilina heterotoma (Lh) extracellular vesicles (EVs) interact with cells of the larval hemolymphatic system after infection, focusing on the lymph gland's role in cellular immunity.
methodology: Drosophila genetics, cell-specific markers, and SSp40 staining (as a proxy for Lh EV localization) were used to study the host-parasite interaction. Experiments involved infecting Drosophila larvae with Lh and Lb wasps, followed by immunohistochemistry and confocal microscopy to observe EV distribution and effects on lymph gland cells.
results: Lh EVs are distributed throughout the Drosophila larval lymphatic system, associating with ECM proteins, entering the dorsal vessel lumen, and some cardiomyocytes. Lh infection disassembles the posterior signaling center (PSC). Lymph gland hemocytes phagocytose Lh EVs via Rab5-mediated endocytosis. Lh EVs negatively impact phagolysosomal organization in macrophages. Rab5 suppresses proliferation and maintains macrophage fate.
conclusions: The lymph gland plays a crucial role in cellular immunity by phagocytosing Lh EVs. Lh EVs proactively block encapsulation by disrupting the PSC and damaging the endomembrane system of macrophages, leading to their apoptosis. These findings highlight the complex interplay between the wasp's virulence strategies and the host's immune responses.
relationships: Lh EVs interact with ECM proteins of the lymphatic system, enter the dorsal vessel lumen, and some cardiomyocytes. They disrupt the PSC and are phagocytosed by macrophages via Rab5-dependent endocytosis. Lb infection, in contrast, triggers lamellocyte differentiation and does not distort LAMP-positive compartments.
insights: Lh EVs target the lymph gland to disrupt cellular immunity. The PSC plays a structural role in EV trafficking. Rab5-mediated phagocytosis is a key anti-parasite response. Lh EVs damage late endocytic compartments, promoting lysosomal leakage. The study reveals a previously unappreciated phagocytic role of the lymph gland in cellular immunity.

title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids.
objective: To compare the effects of the International Space Station (ISS) environment on healthy and chronically inflamed fruit fly hosts, examine the development of endoparasites in the ISS, and study if parasite virulence is affected in space.
methodology: Two fruit fly strains (healthy control and a mutant with chronic inflammation) were sent to the ISS along with parasitoid wasps. Survival rates were scored, and RNA sequencing was used to analyze gene expression in both flies and wasps. Lymph gland morphologies were examined, and virulence assays were performed.
results: Spaceflight compromised the survival of healthy control flies but not the chronically inflamed mutant flies. Inflammation-related genes were activated in both fly strains. Tumor burden increased in the space-returned chronically inflamed strain. Parasitoid development was largely unaffected by spaceflight, with only modest changes in virulence gene expression. Mutant wasps with novel wing color and shape were isolated post-flight.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions exert unexpected and differential effects on Drosophila strains. Metazoan parasites can develop normally in space, retaining their infection strategies. The isolation of mutant wasp lines will advance our understanding of wasp genomics, genetics, and host-parasite biology. The effects of spaceflight on individuals of distinct genetic backgrounds may not necessarily be straightforward to predict.
relationships: The study examines the host-parasite relationship between Drosophila melanogaster and Leptopilina heterotoma in the context of spaceflight, focusing on immune responses and virulence.
insights: Spaceflight can have complex and strain-specific effects on organisms. While it can compromise the survival of healthy organisms, it may not significantly affect those with pre-existing conditions like chronic inflammation. Parasites can adapt to the space environment and maintain their virulence, posing a potential threat to astronauts' health during space missions.

title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
objective: To compare the effects of spaceflight on healthy and immune-compromised fruit flies, examine parasitoid development in space, and study if parasite virulence is affected by space conditions.
methodology: Examine the development of Drosophila melanogaster infested with parasitoid wasps that journeyed to and back from the International Space Station (ISS). RNA sequencing was used to analyze gene expression in adult flies. Tumor number and size were scored to examine tumor development. Cellular immunity was assessed by exposing larvae to wasps and computing a tumor-encapsulation score.
results: Spaceflight compromised the survival of healthy fruit flies but not immune-compromised flies. Inflammation-related genes were activated in space in both fly strains. Tumor burden increased in space-returned tumor-bearing mutants. Parasitoids appeared more resilient than fly hosts. Visible mutations affecting wing shape, color, and ovipositor integrity were identified in the progeny of space L. heterotoma.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions exert unexpected and differential effects on Drosophila strains. Spaceflight activates the expression of immune genes and increases inflammatory tumor burden. Parasitoid wasps can develop normally in space, retaining their infection strategies. Radiation in space can lead to germline mutations in parasites.
relationships: The study focuses on the host-parasite relationship between Drosophila melanogaster and parasitoid wasps, specifically Leptopilina heterotoma and Leptopilina boulardi. It examines how spaceflight affects the immune response of the host and the virulence of the parasite.
insights: Spaceflight can have complex and unpredictable effects on biological systems, with different genetic backgrounds responding differently to the space environment. The immune system is significantly affected by spaceflight, and parasites can adapt and even mutate in response to space conditions. These findings have implications for astronaut health and the potential for long-term space colonization.

title: Simultaneous exposure of cultured human lymphoblastic cells to simulated microgravity and radiation increases chromosome aberrations
objective: To compare the effects of the International Space Station (ISS) environment on healthy control flies and flies with chronic inflammation (CI), examine the development of endoparasites in the ISS, and study if parasite virulence is affected in space.
methodology: Two fly strains (healthy and CI) were sent to the ISS along with parasitoid wasps. Survival rates of flies and wasps were scored. Gene expression analysis (RNA-Seq) was performed on adult flies and larvae to identify differentially expressed genes. Tumor development in flies was scored. Venom activity of wasps was assessed. Mutant wasps were isolated and characterized.
results: Spaceflight compromised the survival of healthy flies but not CI flies. Inflammation-related genes were activated in both fly strains. Tumor burden increased in space-returned CI flies. Spaceflight did not significantly impact wasp survival or virulence gene expression. Mutant wasps with altered wing color and shape were isolated post-flight.
conclusions: Spaceflight has differential effects on flies depending on their genetic background. Metazoan parasites can develop normally in space, retaining their infection strategies. Continued analysis of such systems will be important to help establish multigenerational studies and to obtain a fine-grained understanding of the long-term effects of space on diverse organisms.
relationships: The study examines the relationship between Drosophila melanogaster and parasitoid wasps, focusing on how spaceflight affects their interactions, including host immunity and parasite virulence. It also explores the relationship between gene expression changes and observed phenotypes in both hosts and parasites.
insights: Spaceflight can alter host-parasite interactions, with potential implications for astronaut health. The study highlights the importance of considering genetic background when assessing the effects of spaceflight on organisms. It also suggests that metazoan parasites may be more resilient to spaceflight than their hosts.

title: Genes required for survival in microgravity revealed by genome-wide yeast deletion collections cultured during spaceflight.
objective: To analyze the frequencies of chromosome aberrations (CA) in cultured human lymphoblastic TK6 cells exposed to X-ray or carbon ion under simulated microgravity (µG) conditions, and to assess the combined effects of radiation and µG on cell survival and CA.
methodology: Cultured human lymphoblastic TK6 cells were simultaneously exposed to X-ray or carbon ion irradiation under simulated µG using a 3D clinostat. Cell survival was assessed immediately after irradiation. Chromosome aberrations were analyzed 24 hours post-irradiation using fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). Statistical analyses, including Fisher’s exact test and logistic regression, were performed to determine the significance of observed differences.
results: Simultaneous exposure to radiation and µG resulted in a higher frequency of both simple and complex types of chromosome aberrations compared to radiation exposure alone. C-ion irradiation induced more complex CA than X-ray irradiation at the same cell survival fraction dose. Logistic regression analysis indicated that both radiation dose and gravity significantly contributed to total chromosome exchanges.
conclusions: Exposure to radiation under simulated microgravity increases chromosome aberrations in human lymphoblastic TK6 cells, suggesting that space radiation risk assessments based on 1G conditions may underestimate astronauts' potential health risks. The combined effects of ionizing radiation and µG are more than additive, increasing the risk of CA during long space flights.
relationships: The study builds upon previous research on the effects of space radiation and microgravity on cells, particularly focusing on DNA damage and repair mechanisms. It relates to the broader field of space biology and the assessment of astronaut health risks during long-duration space missions. The findings corroborate existing models of radiation risk uncertainties.
insights: The study highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of microgravity and space radiation when assessing astronaut health risks. It suggests that ground-based experiments under 1G conditions may not accurately reflect the biological effects of space radiation. Further research is needed to investigate the underlying mechanisms of increased chromosome aberrations under simulated microgravity and to develop effective countermeasures.

title: Physical Forces Modulate Oxidative Status and Stress Defense Meditated Metabolic Adaptation of Yeast Colonies: Spaceflight and Microgravity Simulations
objective: To identify the metabolic and genomic pathways affected by spaceflight using yeast deletion collections and to compare the effects of spaceflight to those of known stressors and drugs.
methodology: The homozygous and heterozygous yeast deletion collections were grown in spaceflight and ground control conditions, with and without hyperosmolar sodium chloride. Strain fitness was assessed by quantifying barcode abundance using next-generation sequencing. Gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis was performed to identify biological processes significantly affected by spaceflight. The effects of spaceflight were compared against a database of drug effects on yeast to identify concordant mechanisms of perturbation.
results: In spaceflight, the homozygous deletion collection revealed the importance of processes linked to mitochondria, while the heterozygous collection highlighted genes involved in regulating translation and ribosomal RNA transport. Both homozygous and heterozygous collections highlighted DNA repair. With the addition of NaCl, the homozygous collection also revealed the importance of RNA-related processes including ribosome assembly and biogenesis and mRNA processing and decay, as well as modification of tRNAs. Spaceflight effects showed high concordance with the effects of DNA-damaging agents and changes in redox state.
conclusions: Spaceflight has subtle but significant effects on core cellular processes, including growth control via RNA and ribosomal biogenesis, metabolism, modification, and decay pathways. DNA repair and replication, response to pH signaling, control of gene expression, and mitochondrial function are also significantly affected. DNA and RNA damage are major ground-based analogs of spaceflight stress, likely due to radiation exposure. Increased glutathione S-transferase activity and changes in redox state are also implicated.
relationships: Spaceflight stress is related to DNA damage and redox state changes. The addition of salt stress potentiates the DNA-damaging effects of spaceflight, possibly via the induction of reactive oxygen species (ROS). The effects of spaceflight are similar to those of nucleotide analogs and DNA-damaging agents.
insights: Spaceflight induces DNA and RNA damage, affecting core cellular processes. Countermeasures targeting DNA repair, redox balance, and mitochondrial function may mitigate the negative effects of spaceflight on cellular health. The study provides a platform for conducting full genome environmental screens in spaceflight.

title: Effects of space flight on mouse liver versus kidney: Gene pathway analyses.
objective: To systematically examine the effects of true microgravity versus common microgravity simulations, and nutrient rich media versus nutrient poor media, on major mechanistic mediators including shear stress promoters, reactive oxygen species, and apoptosis in yeast colonies.
methodology: Giant yeast colonies were cultured in true microgravity (spaceflight) and simulated microgravity (rotation and random positioning) on both nutrient-rich (YPD) and nutrient-poor (YE) media. Gene expression (using eGFP fusion protein expression clones), cell death (necrosis and apoptosis via PI and Annexin V staining), and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production were measured using flow cytometry. Stress promoter dependence was assessed by comparing eGFP signal of parent strains to clones with Msn4 or Sfp1 promoter deletions. Statistical analysis included ANOVA and Tukey’s test.
results: Microgravity increased both select reactive oxygen species and stress defense genes (INO1, TRR1, SSA4) independent of media type. SSA4 expression increased in flight and was Sfp1-dependent. RPL34B increased in flight with Msn4 dependence on YE media. Cell death by necrosis and apoptosis increased in flight. Rotating wall vessel and random positioning models showed different effects compared to spaceflight, indicating distinct stimuli.
conclusions: True microgravity induces unique cellular responses in yeast colonies compared to simulated microgravity, particularly regarding ammonia signaling, stress defense, and cell death. The rotating wall vessel and random positioning models induce distinct forces. Physical methods can manipulate yeast colony redox, apoptosis, and stress defense status, offering insights into drug action, cell aging, and colony differentiation.
relationships: Ammonia signaling is increased when generated ammonia cannot convect away from the colonies. Increased expression of the stress defense dependent SSA4 gene is consistent with lack of oxygen availability and carbon dioxide accumulation as these gasses are also affected by the lack of convection. Cell death was greatly increased by deletion of either of the stress responsive promoters Msn4 or Sfp1.
insights: Spaceflight provides a unique suite of stimuli with distinct set of responses. The forces induced by random positioning and rotation are distinct. The ability of physical methods to manipulate yeast colony redox, apoptosis, and stress defense status is important at multiple levels of organismal biology.

title: Yeast in Space
objective: To determine genome-wide gene expression changes in kidney and liver tissue from mice flown in space for 12 days versus ground-based controls, and to test if common gene expression pathways are activated in multiple tissue types in response to spaceflight stimuli.
methodology: Gene array analysis (Affymetrix hybridization) was performed on kidney and liver tissue from mice flown in space versus ground controls. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) and Cytoscape/ClueGO were used to identify gene clusters and interactions.
results: Liver and kidney tissues showed similar gene responses to spaceflight. Both tissues overexpressed genes in cellular responses to peptides, hormones, and nitrogen compounds; apoptosis and cell death; fat cell differentiation; and negative regulation of protein kinase. Tissue-specific changes were also identified, including T cell activation in the liver and changes in peptide binding and amino acid catabolism in the kidney.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces both tissue-specific and shared tissue-common responses in liver and kidney. Common responses include overexpression of genes related to cellular responses, apoptosis, fat cell differentiation, and protein kinase regulation. CYP4A1 and Cdkn1a were significantly overexpressed in both liver and kidney tissues in space.
relationships: The study confirms previous findings on liver tissue from mice flown in space, such as altered insulin response, impaired management of reactive oxidation, dysregulated lipid metabolism, and altered protein kinases. It also confirms changes previously observed in kidney gene pathways during spaceflight, including apoptosis and cellular response to peptides.
insights: Spaceflight induces complex stress responses affecting gene expression in multiple organs. Common gene pathways are upregulated in both liver and kidney, suggesting shared mechanisms of adaptation to the space environment. Tissue-specific changes highlight the unique responses of each organ to spaceflight stimuli.

title: Endocrine Effects of Space Flight
objective: To report a clinical case of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus albidus and review related literature, focusing on diagnosis and treatment.
methodology: A case report of a patient with C. albidus meningitis is presented. A literature review was conducted using PubMed, Medline, and Web of Science databases to identify relevant cases of CNS infections caused by C. albidus and related species. Keywords related to fungus, human infection, CNS, meningitis, cryptococcus, and related species were used.
results: A 25-year-old female patient with a history of glioma resection was diagnosed with C. albidus meningitis. The patient was treated with liposomal-AmB and 5-fluorocytosine for 6 weeks. After treatment, the patient's condition improved, and no yeast was isolated from CSF samples. A literature review identified 9 cases of CNS infections caused by C. albidus or related species.
conclusions: Using ideal bodyweight to calculate the dose of liposomal-AmB for obese patients with C. albidus meningitis is both efficacious and safe. Leukemia and cancer are important risk factors for these infections, and headache is the most frequent symptom. Identification of fungal pathogens requires rRNA sequence analysis. AmB-based treatment should be the first choice, guided by susceptibility testing.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between C. albidus infections and risk factors such as immunocompromised status, leukemia, cancer, exposure to bird excrement, contact with animals, and surgery. It also examines the relationship between antifungal treatment and patient outcomes.
insights: CNS infections of C. albidus are uncommon but associated with high mortality rates. Accurate identification of fungal pathogens is crucial for effective treatment. Liposomal-AmB, dosed based on ideal body weight, combined with 5-fluorocytosine, is a safe and effective treatment for C. albidus meningitis in obese patients.

title: Role of shear stress on renal proximal tubular cells for nephrotoxicity assays
objective: To evaluate the three-dimensional clinostat simulated microgravity effect on mouse models, focusing on the central nervous system and cognitive function.
methodology: Eighteen mice were divided into three groups: control, survival box, and clinostat + survival box. Behavioral tests, femur micro-CT, brain transcriptomics, serum metabolomics, and fecal microbiomics were performed. Statistical analysis included Two-way ANOVA followed by post-hoc tests.
results: Clinostat-treated mice showed decreased activity, altered gait, enhanced fear memory, bone loss, immune/endocrine changes in brain transcriptome, and altered metabolic pathways in serum and gut microbiota. 3D clinostat treatment significantly reduced mice activity and exploratory desire. There were no statistically significant differences in learning and memory. Prolonged exposure to the 3D clinostat had a notable impact on the vestibular balance system. The 3D clinostat seemed to induce a trend towards increased sensitivity to fear behavior and enhanced fear memory. Both SB and CS group of mice exhibited significant bone loss compared to the MC group, with a notable decrease in bone volume and trabecular number, as well as a significant increase in trabecular pattern factor and trabecular separation. 3D clinostat may primarily affect immune and endocrine-related signaling pathways. The CS group exhibited significant upregulation of serum metabolites. The Bacteroides and Turicibacter were significantly reduced in the CS group compared to both the SB and MC groups.
conclusions: The model closely mimics spaceflight-induced transcriptome changes, suggesting its value in studying microgravity-related neurological alterations and highlighting the need for attention to emotional changes in space. The 3D clinostat model demonstrates a closer resemblance to the brain transcriptome expression profiles observed in spaceflight animals, thereby offering a novel and invaluable research tool for simulating microgravity effect on Earth.
relationships: The 3D clinostat model appears to more closely mimic the gene expression changes seen in real spaceflight, particularly in terms of immune and endocrine-related pathways. The CS and FL models demonstrated a convergent alteration in three KEGG signaling pathways: GnRH signaling pathway, Neuroactive ligand-receptor interaction, and Ovarian steroidogenesis, as well as eight common differential genes. The HU model demonstrates a heightened sensitivity to alterations in cerebral blood flow, rendering it an appropriate choice for investigating notable cognitive shifts following return from spaceflight, while the 3D clinostat model is more likely to focus on subtle cognitive changes caused by adaptation to microgravity in space, which may be related to vestibular function and spatial orientation.
insights: Simulated microgravity effect induced by the 3D clinostat triggered noteworthy transformations within the central nervous system. This model has the potential to serve as a valuable tool for investigating cognitive changes associated with microgravity environments, while also offering new insights into the potential mechanisms underlying spaceflight-related health risks. Microgravity may have a more pronounced impact on emotional and motivational states than on cognitive functions, highlighting the need for further research into the psychological well-being of astronauts during extended missions.

title: Bone hemodynamic responses to changes in external pressure.
objective: To evaluate the nephrotoxic effects of rheological factors of low-osmolar contrast media (LOCM) and iso-osmolar contrast media (IOCM) using a kidney-on-a-chip platform.
methodology: Human renal proximal tubule epithelial cells (RPTEC) were cultured in a three-dimensional microfluidic culture platform (kidney-on-a-chip) under bidirectional fluid shear stress. RPTEC were treated with LOCM (iopromide) and IOCM (iodixanol) at varying iodine concentrations and shear-stress conditions. Cell viability, fluid dynamics, and signaling pathways (Erk1/2, Akt) were assessed.
results: LOCM showed a dose-dependent cytotoxic effect under static and low-to-moderate shear stress conditions, significantly higher than IOCM. High shear stress reduced cell viability in IOCM. The high viscosity of IOCM slowed fluid flow and augmented fluid shear stress. LOCM inhibited Erk1/2 phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner, while IOCM did not significantly alter signaling molecule expression.
conclusions: Viscosity-induced nephrotoxicity plays a vital role under high shear-stress conditions. The kidney-on-a-chip model reliably reflects in vivo situations. Under high-shear-stress conditions, IOCM caused renal tubular cell damage comparable to LOCM, decreasing the urine flow rate and exposing cells to high shear-stress for a longer duration.
relationships: Increased viscosity of contrast media contributes to tubular cell damage through flow-derived stresses such as tubular stretching, increased shear stress, and transmural pressure. High viscosity of IOCM is associated with increased tubular pressure, prolonged CM retention, and subsequent decreased GFR and hypoxia.
insights: The study suggests an alternative in vitro model of CIN using a three-dimensional proximal tubule-on-a-chip. The risk of CIN may not differ significantly between IOCM and LOCM in patients with CKD under high shear-stress conditions. The kidney-on-a-chip microfluidic platform could be a potential alternative in vitro model, which can provide easier control of various physical parameters.

title: The Effect of Different Concentrations of Epinephrine in Otoendoscopic Surgery on Surgical Field Clarity: A Double-Blind, Randomized Study
objective: To compare the effect of subcutaneous injection of different concentrations of epinephrine/physiological saline into the external auditory canal (EAC) under general anesthesia in otoendoscopic surgery on surgical field clarity and hemodynamics.
methodology: A double-blind, randomized controlled trial (RCT) was conducted on 168 patients undergoing otoendoscopic surgery under general anesthesia. Patients were randomized to receive different concentrations of epinephrine/physiological saline injection (1:5000, 1:10,000, 1:20,000, or 1:40,000) into the junction of bone and cartilage at the posterior wall of the EAC during surgery. Surgical field clarity was assessed with a grading scale and tympanic membrane flap flipping time. Hemodynamic changes were monitored by clinical parameters of blood pressure, heart rate, and ST segment of ECG.
results: There were no statistically significant differences in surgical field clarity grade and tympanic membrane flap flipping time among the four concentration groups. Epinephrine injection did cause an increase in hemodynamic parameters when compared with baseline. Higher concentration groups (1:5000 and 1:10,000) had a more significant and long-lasting effect on hemodynamics compared to lower concentration groups (1:20,000 and 1:40,000).
conclusions: Four concentration groups of topical epinephrine injection in otoendoscopic surgery have the same effect on surgical field clarity. For the stability of patients’ hemodynamics, the use of concentrations with minimal impact on hemodynamics, ranging from 1:20,000 to 1:40,000, is recommended.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between different concentrations of epinephrine and their impact on surgical field clarity and hemodynamic stability during otoendoscopic surgery.
insights: The study suggests that lower concentrations of epinephrine (1:20,000 to 1:40,000) are preferable in otoendoscopic surgery as they provide similar surgical field clarity with minimal impact on patients' hemodynamics.

title: Fifteen days of microgravity causes growth in calvaria of mice
objective: To compare quantitative measures of lumbar spine anatomy, health, and biomechanics in astronauts before and after 6 months of microgravity exposure on board the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Prospective longitudinal study of six astronauts. 3T magnetic resonance imaging and dynamic fluoroscopy of the lumbar spine were collected before and after a 6-month spaceflight. Outcome measures were compared using paired t-tests and regression analyses.
results: Supine lumbar lordosis decreased. Active flexion-extension range of motion decreased for the middle three lumbar discs. Multifidus and erector spinae changed variably between subjects, with most experiencing a decrease in functional cross-sectional area and cross-sectional area. Changes in multifidus functional cross-sectional area strongly correlated with changes in lordosis and active flexion-extension range of motion. Disc water content did not differ systematically. Subjects with pre-flight end plate irregularities had post-flight lumbar symptoms.
conclusions: Multifidus atrophy, rather than intervertebral disc swelling, associated strongly with lumbar flattening and increased stiffness. These changes, combined with evidence of pre-flight vertebral end plate insufficiency, may elevate injury risk for astronauts upon return to gravity loading. Results have implications for deconditioned spines on Earth.
relationships: Multifidus atrophy is associated with decreased lumbar lordosis and intersegmental ROM. Pre-existing spinal pathology may increase the risk for post-flight symptoms.
insights: Microgravity primarily influences active spine stabilizers, and multifidus atrophy plays a key role in post-flight lumbar spine changes. Maintaining multifidus health during spaceflight may reduce the risk of post-flight symptoms and injury.

title: Altered disc compression in children with idiopathic low back pain: an upright magnetic resonance imaging backpack study
objective: To evaluate the remodeling of skull bones due to actual microgravity, compare the adaptation of non-loaded bones to actual microgravity versus simulated microgravity, and quantify these changes based on mineral content and bone volume.
methodology: Seven mice were exposed to 15 days of microgravity on the STS-131 mission, while eight littermates served as ground controls. Calvariae were imaged on a micro-computed tomography scanner. Bone volume (BV), cross-sectional thickness (CsTh), and tissue mineral density (TMD) were determined.
results: Microgravity exposure caused a statistically significant increase in BV of the space flight group compared to the ground control group. CsTh demonstrated a trend of increase. TMD was similar between the two groups.
conclusions: Microgravity induces adaptive changes in calvarial bones that do not normally bear weight. Fluid shifts accompanying microgravity may initiate bone remodeling independent of skeletal loading.
relationships: Weight-bearing bones lose more bone than non-weight-bearing bones in microgravity. Increased BMD in skull bones along with mineral loss in bones of the lower axial and appendicular skeleton.
insights: Head-ward fluid shifts in microgravity may cause bone remodeling in non-weight-bearing bones. Hindlimb unloading and bed rest can serve as valid models for simulating microgravity.

title: Spaceflight-induced bone loss alters failure mode and reduces bending strength in murine spinal segments.
objective: To analyze the lumbar spine’s response to backpack loads with upright MRI in children with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) and compare their results to previously published data from normal children under the same conditions. The hypothesis is that typical backpack loads will have a different effect on the lumbar spine of normal and ILBP children.
methodology: A repeated measures design was used, imaging fifteen pediatric and adolescent patients with ILBP using a 0.6T upright MRI scanner while supine and standing wearing 0 kg, 4 kg, and 8 kg backpacks. IVD height, lumbar lordosis, lumbar coronal deformity, and pain score were recorded after each condition and compared using ANOVAs. Generalized least squares models were used to compare variables between ILBP and normal subjects.
results: In ILBP children, 4 kg and 8 kg backpacks compressed the L5-S1 IVD relative to upright with no load. Subjects experienced increasing pain with increasing load. Load had no effect on lumbar lordosis or lumbar coronal deformity. Compared to normal children, ILBP children experienced significantly less disc compression at T12-L1 to L4-5, less lumbar lordosis, and more pain with increasing load.
conclusions: In ILBP children, increasing backpack load compresses only the L5-S1 IVD. Compared to normal children, ILBP children experience less lumbar IVD compression, less lumbar lordosis, and more pain due to increasing load, suggesting altered mechanisms for load tolerance in ILBP children.
relationships: Increasing backpack load was positively associated with disc compression at L1-L2, L4-L5, and L5-S1. Pain positively correlated with backpack load.
insights: Children with ILBP may alter the distribution of backpack load from the IVDs to the surrounding paraspinal musculature, leading to muscle fatigue and subsequent pain. Physical therapy aimed at paraspinal muscle strengthening may normalize back pain with loading and redistribute the load to the IVDs.

title: Spaceflight-associated vascular remodeling and gene expression in mouse calvaria.
objective: To quantify the bending properties of tail discs from mice with or without microgravity exposure and to determine the location of failure in spinal segments.
methodology: Caudal motion segments from mice returned from a 30-day spaceflight mission and ground controls were subjected to four-point bending until failure. Histology was used to determine failure location, and micro-computed tomography (μCT) was used to quantify bone properties.
results: Spaceflight significantly shortened the nonlinear toe region of the force-displacement curve and reduced bending strength. Flight mouse spinal segments tended to fail within the growth plate and epiphyseal bone, while controls tended to fail at the disc-vertebra junction. Spaceflight significantly reduced vertebral bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness.
conclusions: Vertebral bone loss during spaceflight may degrade spine bending properties and contribute to increased disc herniation risk in astronauts. The shift in failure location from the endplate junction in controls to the growth plate in flight mice suggests a weakening of the growth plate and epiphyseal bone due to microgravity.
relationships: Bending properties were positively correlated with bone quality parameters such as bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness. Specifically, displacement at failure increased with bone volume fraction and bone mineral density, and toe region displacement increased with trabecular thickness.
insights: The study provides evidence that spaceflight-induced bone loss weakens the spine, altering its bending properties and increasing the risk of disc herniation. This suggests that countermeasures focused on preventing bone loss during spaceflight and limiting bending movements upon return to Earth could be beneficial for astronauts.

title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: Effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress.
objective: To examine spatial and temporal calvarial vascular remodeling and gene expression in mice related to microgravity exposure, comparing spaceflight (SF) and ground control (GC) cohorts.
methodology: Examination of parasagittal capillary numbers and structures in calvaria from mice using isolectin-IB4 vessel marker. Analysis of pro-angiogenic (VEGFA) and pro-osteogenic gene expression using quantitative RT-PCR.
results: Vessel diameter reduces significantly in mice exposed to 15 days of spaceflight. Capillarization increases in SF mice compared to GC mice. VEGFA gene expression increased 15-fold while BMP-2 gene expression increased 11-fold in flight mice compared to GC.
conclusions: Angiogenesis may be important in the regulation of pathological bone growth in non-weight bearing regions of the body. Short-duration microgravity-mediated bone restructuring has implications in planning effective countermeasures for long-duration flights and extraterrestrial human habitation.
relationships: Linkage between vascular morphology and gene expression in spaceflight conditions suggests angiogenesis regulates bone growth in non-weight bearing regions.
insights: Calvarial bone and vascular remodeling occurs in response to skeletal unloading and cephalad fluid shifts in microgravity. Skull vasculature and bone act as sensors for gravity and fluid shifts.

title: Effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism and signal persistence in flax roots.
objective: To identify factors involved in the adaptation of Mycobacterium marinum to the low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) stressful environment and determine how LSMMG alters mycobacterium physiology.
methodology: Two strains of M. marinum (1218R and LHM4) were grown in high aspect ratio vessels (HARVs) using a rotary cell culture system subjected to LSMMG or normal gravity (NG). Bacterial growth, size, transcriptome changes (RNA-Seq), and resistance to stress (hydrogen peroxide, gamma radiation, pH 3.5) were assessed after short (~40 h) and long (4 days + ~35 h) exposure times.
results: M. marinum exposed to LSMMG transitioned from exponential phase earlier than the NG culture. They were more sensitive to hydrogen peroxide but showed no change in resistance to gamma radiation or pH 3.5. RNA-Seq detected altered transcript levels for several genes under LSMMG. LSMMG induced a reduction in translation, a downregulation of metabolism, an increase in lipid degradation, and increased chaperone and mycobactin expression. Sigma factor H (sigH) transcript was induced by LSMMG after both short and long exposure times.
conclusions: LSMMG may simulate a nutrient-deprived environment similar to that found within macrophage during infection. SigH is implicated in the M. marinum LSMMG transcriptome response. Fluid dynamics in cultures under microgravity or LSMMG are different from NG cultures, generating a local nutrient-deprived condition.
relationships: Transcriptome data suggests that M. marinum grown under LSMMG exhibit similar stress responses as LSMMG-grown Pseudomonas aeruginosa, but have transcriptional, translational, and metabolic alterations similar to spaceflight-exposed P. aeruginosa.
insights: The study provides insights into the adaptation mechanisms of waterborne mycobacteria to microgravity conditions, which is relevant to astronaut health and spacecraft environment during long space flights. The findings suggest potential targets for drug development or disinfection strategies.

title: Oxygen dependency of germinating Brassica seeds.
objective: To investigate the memory capacity of the root gravisensing system in flax seedlings as a function of angular velocity and to separate mechanostimulation from gravistimulation.
methodology: Flax seedlings were reoriented horizontally for varying durations (5, 10, 15 min) and then clinorotated at different speeds (0.5 to 5 rpm) either vertically or horizontally. Root growth and curvature were monitored using video imaging and analyzed over time.
results: Vertical clinorotation reduced root growth by approximately 7%, while horizontal clinorotation did not affect it.  Curvature in horizontally clinorotated roots increased with increasing speed of rotation, but decreased in vertically clinorotated roots. The gravity signal persisted for about 2 hours, and the gravitropic signal saturated after 10 minutes of reorientation.
conclusions: Angular velocity and direction of clinorotation influence the graviresponse mechanism in roots. The gravity signal persists for approximately 2 hours, and a 10-minute reorientation is sufficient to saturate the gravitropic signal. Differences in curvature between vertical and horizontal clinorotation provide opportunities to identify processes that contribute to differential elongation.
relationships: Mechanostimulation modifies the magnitude of the graviresponse but does not affect memory persistence. The rate of clinorotation affects the assessment of the gravitropic system. Auxin redistribution and PIN protein relocalization may play a role in signal persistence.
insights: Plants exhibit a short-term memory of gravity stimulation, lasting approximately 2 hours. This memory is influenced by mechanostimulation and the direction/speed of clinorotation. The saturation of the gravity signal coincides with amyloplast sedimentation. Vertical clinorotation inhibits the formation of lateral auxin gradients.

title: Desiccation mitigates heat stress in the resurrection fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides
objective: To investigate the impact of different hydro-, halo-, and osmo-priming agents on seed germination indices, seedling performance, and physio-biochemical attributes of cauliflower subjected to high salt stress.
methodology: Cauliflower seeds were subjected to hydropriming, halopriming (NaCl), and osmopriming (thiourea, polyethylene glycol (PEG), and proline) treatments. Seeds were immersed in solutions for 12 hours, then dried. Germination and growth parameters were measured under saline conditions (100 mM NaCl). Photosynthetic attributes, protein, proline, and MDA content were also estimated. Statistical analysis included ANOVA, Tukey HSD test, cluster analysis, and PCA.
results: Salt stress significantly reduced seed germination metrics. Priming treatments, especially with PEG, improved germination and growth parameters under salinity. Correlation analysis revealed relationships between germination traits. PCA showed that PEG treatments had increased germination indices. Cluster analysis grouped priming treatments based on their effectiveness. Priming increased protein and proline content and reduced MDA content. Photosynthetic pigments were better preserved in primed seedlings.
conclusions: Hydro-, halo-, and osmo-priming strategies improve germination indices and morpho-physiological traits of cauliflower under salt stress. Proline accumulation lowers MDA levels and alleviates lipid peroxidation, while increasing total soluble protein and photosynthetic pigments. Priming accelerates germination, synchronizes growth, and activates metabolites under high NaCl levels. Simple priming treatments can improve cauliflower crop performance.
relationships: Germination traits exhibited statistically significant associations. RGP was substantially linked with RVI, RRL, and RSL. The RGI showed a correlation with RSL and RVI. A significant correlation was also found between RSL and RSDW.
insights: Seed priming is an effective method to mitigate stress-induced formation of MDA and reactive oxygen species. Lipid peroxidation was reduced in a dose-dependent and priming agent-specific manner by application of the priming treatment compared to stressed seedlings.

title: Transcription profile of auxin related genes during positively gravitropic hypocotyl curvature of Brassica rapa.
objective: To evaluate the biochemical responses of dry and hydrated fronds of Pleopeltis polypodioides to heat stress by assessing photosynthetic and metabolic activities, levels of stress molecules, activities of antioxidative enzymes, membrane stability, and fatty acid profile.
methodology: Isolated Pleopeltis fronds were subjected to heat treatment (24h in darkness) in both dehydrated and hydrated conditions. Photosynthetic performance was assessed by measuring chlorophyll fluorescence and quantum yield. Membrane permeability was deduced from conductivity of water in which fronds were submersed. Metabolic activity was assessed via resazurin reduction. Hydroperoxide and lipid peroxide content were measured using FOX assays. Catalase activity and glutathione consumption were also determined. Fatty acid analysis was performed using gas chromatography.
results: Dried fronds curled tighter with increasing temperature. Exposure to 55°C resulted in patchy browning, and 65°C caused complete discoloration after rehydration. Hydrated fronds showed browning at temperatures > 40°C. Photosynthetic performance (Ft and Qy) decreased with higher temperatures, with Qy being a better indicator of heat stress. Electrolyte leakage increased significantly at temperatures ≥ 40°C. The hydroperoxide content of dried fronds increased gradually with temperature, while fully and partly submersed fronds showed highest values at 35°C. Catalase activity declined with increasing temperatures. Fatty acid composition changed with temperature and hydration, with linolenic acid being the dominant fatty acid.
conclusions: Dehydration protects Pleopeltis polypodioides from heat damage, with dried fronds tolerating up to 55°C, while hydrated fronds are limited to 40°C. Heat stress causes oxidative stress, membrane damage, and changes in fatty acid composition. The study illustrates the adaptability of this epiphytic fern to cope with environmental stress.
relationships: Heat stress induces changes in morphology, cellular functions, metabolism, and gene expression. Desiccation and heat induce changes in cell wall and frond shape. Discolorations of hydrated fronds indicate stress beyond thermal tolerance, leading to chloroplast or chlorophyll degradation. Electrolyte leakage indicates cell membrane damage and ion efflux. The extent of unsaturation correlated with peroxidation.
insights: The study highlights the importance of desiccation tolerance in the resurrection fern Pleopeltis polypodioides. The data indicate that > 40°C causes heat stress in Pleopeltis fronds. The difference in heat tolerance between hydrated and dried fronds indicates that dehydration protects Pleopeltis from heat damage. The study further illustrates the adaptability of this epiphytic fern to cope with environmental stress.

title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: Results from a space experiment.
objective: To investigate the role of auxin in positive and negative hypocotyl curvature of Brassica rapa by examining the transcription of PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, and ARG1 in curving tissue.
methodology: The transcription levels of PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, and ARG1 were compared in vertically and horizontally reoriented hypocotyls of Brassica rapa using tissue extraction and Solid Phase Gene Extraction (SPGE). Ubiquitin (UBQ1) transcription level was used as a reference.  The hypocotyls were dissected into two parts (left/right for vertical controls and upper/lower for horizontally oriented seedlings). Samples obtained after 48 h did not include tissue samples as the tissue size after 48 h of additional growth exceeded the extraction capacity. The apical two mm of the root tip were removed using a scalpel and used as additional reference tissue.
results: Transcription of PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, and ARG1 varied during the graviresponse. PIN3, IAA5, and ARG1 were downregulated along the top flank but upregulated in the bottom tissue. PIN1 transcription did not change during the first four hours but after 11 h of reorientation increased in the lower flank and decreased along the upper flank. After 48 h, the transcription expression was reversed, i.e., transcription was upregulated in the upper flank and downregulated in the lower flanks.
conclusions: Basal hypocotyl curvature depends on auxin-mediated processes and involves the same genes for downward or upward curvature that were found to be involved in root curvature. The expression trend for auxin-related genes in positively gravitropic hypocotyl curvature reverses when the hypocotyls begin to develop negative gravitropism.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between auxin transport, gene expression, and the gravitropic response in Brassica rapa hypocotyls, suggesting a conserved mechanism between root and hypocotyl curvature.
insights: The spatio-temporal changes in gene regulation during hypocotyl curvature indicate an auxin-based regulation of positive and negative hypocotyl curvature. SPGE allows for mRNA profiling at high spatial resolution that is useful for the determination of transcriptional responses to physiological stimuli in plants.

title: Lipid rafts and plant gravisensitivity.
objective: To investigate the effects of high gradient magnetic fields (HGMF) and weightlessness on plant growth and metabolism, specifically focusing on the role of amyloplasts in gravisensitivity.
methodology: Brassica rapa seeds were grown in space and on Earth (static and clinorotation) with and without HGMF. Seed germination, root curvature, and amyloplast size were measured. Transcription analysis of 16 genes related to growth, metabolism, auxin, and stress was performed using qPCR.
results: HGMF induced curvature in roots, but substantial curvature also occurred without magnetic gradients, likely due to hydrotropism. Amyloplast size in root tips increased under weightlessness and decreased under clinorotation. Transcription analysis showed that weightlessness and clinorotation affected the expression of genes related to starch metabolism, particularly AMY1.
conclusions: Plants perceive weightlessness and adjust their metabolism, specifically starch production in gravity-perceiving cells. HGMFs can induce curvature, but hydrotropism is also a significant factor. The size and mass of amyloplasts are regulated by the extent of gravitational and mechanical stimulation, influencing gravisensitivity.
relationships: Weightlessness leads to increased amyloplast size and enhanced gravisensitivity. Clinorotation (enhanced mechanostimulation) leads to reduced amyloplast size through enhanced amylase transcription. HGMFs can induce curvature, but the effect is less pronounced than the effects of weightlessness and clinorotation on amyloplast metabolism.
insights: Plants adapt to weightlessness by increasing amyloplast size, suggesting a mechanism for enhanced gravisensitivity in space. Clinorotation, as a surrogate for space research, may lead to incorrect interpretations due to its mechanostimulatory effects. Starch metabolism plays a key role in plant responses to gravity and mechanical stimuli.

title: Expression and characterization of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS in Xenopus laevis oocytes
objective: To assess available data on plant lipid rafts as possible triggers of changes in cell activities in response to changes in mechanical stimulation and unloading.
methodology: Review of existing literature, analysis of lipid raft composition and behavior under clinorotation using techniques like filipin and laurdan staining, transmission electron microscopy.
results: Lipid rafts from the root cell membrane of pea seedlings grown under slow horizontal clinorotation appear as thin tapes enriched with cholesterol and saturated fatty acids. Clinorotation increases cholesterol content and density of lipid rafts. Filipin staining shows increased cholesterol content and clustering of microdomains under clinorotation. Laurdan staining indicates higher rigidity of cell membranes under clinorotation.
conclusions: Functional domains of membranes are critically important for signal integration and responses. Clinorotation enhances mechanostimulation, affecting cell metabolism and membrane permeability. Plant responses to gravity and mechanostimulation involve changes in lipid rafts, cytoskeleton organization, cell wall structure, and calcium signaling.
relationships: Lipid rafts link the cell membrane with the cytoskeleton, affecting cell polarization and signal transmission. Cholesterol influences actin cytoskeleton organization and cellular mechanotransduction. Lipid rafts are involved in cell signaling, membrane activities, and responses to gravity and mechanostimulation.
insights: Plant lipid rafts, defined as sterol-dependent ordered assemblies of specific lipids and proteins, play a crucial role in plant cell gravisensitivity. Changes in lipid raft composition and behavior under simulated microgravity conditions suggest their involvement in cellular responses to mechanical stimulation and unloading. Further research on lipid rafts and membrane functions is needed to understand the effect of gravity and mechanostimulation on basic cellular processes in biological systems.

title: United in Diversity: Mechanosensitive Ion Channels in Plants
objective: To investigate whether eukaryotic plasma membrane-localized MscS homologs form mechanosensitive channels and to compare their electrophysiological behavior with that of other MscS homologs, specifically focusing on Arabidopsis MSL10.
methodology: Heterologous expression and characterization of Arabidopsis MSL10 in Xenopus laevis oocytes using single-channel patch clamp electrophysiology. This involved injecting oocytes with MSL10 cRNA, excising membrane patches, and measuring channel activity in response to membrane stretch under various ionic conditions and in the presence of inhibitors.
results: MSL10 forms a mechanosensitive channel in the plasma membrane of Xenopus oocytes with a conductance of approximately 100 pS. The channel exhibits a moderate preference for anions and is reversibly inhibited by gadolinium ions. MSL10 demonstrates asymmetric activation/inactivation kinetics, closing at lower tensions than it opens.
conclusions: MSL10 provides a stretch-activated channel activity and is likely to represent the activity described in the root protoplasts of Arabidopsis. The electrophysiological characteristics of MSL10 provide insight into the evolutionary conservation of structure and function between MscS homologs.
relationships: MSL10 shares similarities with MSC1 and MscM in terms of unitary channel conductance, MSC1 in terms of ion selectivity, and MSC1 and MscS G113A/MscS 121A in terms of gating kinetics. MSL10 is likely to represent the activity described in the root protoplasts of a msl9-1;msl10-1 double mutant transiently expressing MSL10.
insights: The study suggests that MSL10 opening could lead to the depolarization of the cellular membrane via Cl− efflux, potentially activating other ion channels and participating in intercellular signaling. This indicates that some members of the MscS family may not only release osmolytes but also alter cell physiology.

title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes
objective: To define the role of S1P signaling and S1PR3 in somatosensory mechanoreceptors and to determine the molecular mechanisms by which S1P signaling in AM nociceptors regulates mechanical pain.
methodology: Genetic and pharmacological ablation of S1PR3, behavioral assays (von Frey, pinprick, radiant heat), in situ hybridization, immunohistochemistry, calcium imaging, electrophysiology (current clamp and voltage clamp), ex vivo skin-nerve recordings, and flow cytometry.
results: S1PR3 KO mice displayed a dramatic loss of mechanical sensitivity. Peripheral blockade of S1PR3 signaling or S1P production impaired mechanical sensitivity. S1PR3 is expressed in A mechanonociceptors and thermal nociceptors. S1P activates thermal nociceptors but not putative AMs. S1PR3 modulates KCNQ2/3 channels to regulate AM excitability. S1PR3 is required for nociceptive responses of high-threshold AM nociceptors. S1PR3 is required for inflammatory pain hypersensitivity.
conclusions: S1P signaling via S1PR3 is a key pathway that tunes mechanical pain sensitivity by modulating KCNQ2/3 channel activity in AM neurons. Baseline levels of S1P are necessary and sufficient for setting normal mechanical pain thresholds, while elevated S1P levels promote thermal, but not mechanical hypersensitivity.
relationships: S1P activates S1PR3, which leads to inhibition of KCNQ2/3 currents and promotes normal mechanical pain sensitivity. Diminished S1P or S1PR3 antagonism alleviates inhibition of KCNQ2/3, leading to mechanical pain hyposensitivity.
insights: S1PR3 is indispensable for normal function of AM nociceptors, including the adapting AM population, that innervates the epidermis and encodes noxious touch. S1PR3 signaling modulates KCNQ2/3 channels to regulate excitability of these A mechanonociceptors.

title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing
objective: To describe in detail the methods used for heterologous expression and characterization of bacterial and plant mechanosensitive channels in Xenopus oocytes, focusing on MscS from Escherichia coli and MSL10 from Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Heterologous expression of mechanosensitive channels (MSCs) in Xenopus oocytes, including frog surgery, oocyte isolation and preparation, in vitro RNA production and injection, and MSC electrophysiology using patch-clamp and pressure-clamp techniques.
