results: Characterization of MscS and MSL10 at the single-channel level, demonstrating the functionality of these channels when expressed in Xenopus oocytes. The endogenous MSCs present in the oocyte membrane can be effectively blocked or inactivated.
conclusions: Xenopus oocytes provide a valuable system for studying plant and bacterial mechanosensitive channels, allowing for detailed characterization of their electrophysiological properties.
relationships: The study builds upon previous research on endogenous MSCs in oocytes and utilizes techniques established for studying ligand- and voltage-gated channels. It also relates to the broader field of membrane protein expression systems.
insights: The oocyte system offers advantages for studying mechanosensitive channels, including low background ion channel activity, large cell size, and ease of handling. Careful attention to water quality and proper controls are crucial for successful experiments.

title: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex.
objective: To investigate the molecular and genetic pathways connecting plastid osmotic stress with cell differentiation at the shoot apex in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Analysis of Arabidopsis thaliana mutants (msl2 msl3) exhibiting constitutive plastid osmotic stress, including genetic crosses with other mutants (ahk2-2, p5cs1-4, aba2-1, gun1-9, abi4-1), microscopy (light, transmission electron, confocal), quantitative RT-PCR, hormone level measurements, ROS detection and quantification, and growth on various media with different supplements.
results: msl2 msl3 mutants develop callus at the shoot apex, associated with enlarged plastids, increased cytokinin levels, upregulation of WUSCHEL, downregulation of ARR7 and ARR15, and elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS). Callus formation requires the cytokinin receptor AHK2, ABA biosynthesis, GUN1, and ABI4. Preventing proline biosynthesis enhances callus formation and ROS accumulation.
conclusions: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the shoot apex through two non-redundant pathways: the cytokinin/WUSCHEL feedback loop and a retrograde signaling pathway involving ROS, ABA, ABI4, and GUN1. These pathways coordinate proliferation versus differentiation signals at the organellar level.
relationships: The cytokinin/WUS pathway and retrograde signaling control cell differentiation at the shoot apex. Plastid osmotic stress activates the CK/WUS feedback loop. ABA biosynthesis is not upstream of the CK/WUS feedback loop.
insights: Two-way communication between plastids and cell differentiation is essential to coordinate the developmental and functional state of the plastid with that of the cell within which it resides, and that it therefore necessarily involves multiple pathways.

title: Spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications within hair cells of the mammalian utricle.
objective: To investigate synaptic modifications in utricles from mice flown aboard a space shuttle mission, focusing on structural synaptic plasticity in different utricular regions after exposure to microgravity.
methodology: Immunohistochemistry and volumetric image analyses were used to quantify synapse distributions across representative utricular regions in specimens from mice exposed to spaceflight.  Synapses were identified as closely apposed pre- and postsynaptic puncta using anti-CtBP2 and anti-Shank1A.  Epithelia from horizontal semicircular canal cristae served as within-specimen controls, and utricles and cristae from Earth-bound cohorts served as experimental controls. Confocal microscopy was used for imaging and synapse quantification.
results: Synapse densities decreased in the medial extrastriolae of microgravity specimens compared with experimental controls, whereas they were unchanged in the striolae and horizontal cristae from the two conditions. Hair cell densities remained similar in both control and microgravity conditions.
conclusions: Structural plasticity was topographically localized to the utricular region that encodes very low frequency and static changes in linear acceleration, demonstrating the capabilities of utricular hair cells for synaptic plasticity in adapting to novel gravitational environments.  The synaptic modifications were induced by alteration in the static load acting on the region of the utricle that normally encodes static linear acceleration stimuli.
relationships: Spaceflight imposes a different sensory environment on the inner ear utricle. The medial extrastriola, associated with encoding static head position, showed decreased synapse density, congruent with decreased utricular function in astronauts post-spaceflight.  The findings suggest a 'use it or lose it' plasticity guideline, where reduced sensory activity leads to a reduction in synapses.
insights: Adult utricular hair cells can undergo synaptic modifications in response to altered gravitational environments.  Synaptic plasticity in medial extrastriola hair cells resulted from the loss of synaptic specializations. The study suggests potential mechanisms for inner ear rehabilitation by inducing synapse density increases in vestibular paresis.

title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration
objective: To understand how plants sense and respond to osmotic challenges, focusing on the molecular mechanisms involved in plant osmosensing and the signaling pathways activated by osmotic stress.
methodology: The study reviews existing literature and experimental evidence related to plant osmosensing, examining various models and mechanisms proposed for how plants perceive and respond to changes in water potential and osmotic balance. It considers the roles of plasma membrane proteins, ion channels, cell wall integrity, and organelle membranes in osmosensing.
results: The review highlights three general models for osmosensing in plant cells: osmotic imbalance across the plasma membrane, increased plasma membrane tension, and altered cell wall integrity. It discusses the involvement of histidine kinases, calcium channels, mechanosensitive channels, and receptor-like kinases in these processes. The study also describes downstream osmotic stress signaling pathways, including the accumulation of compatible solutes, induction of protective proteins, and the role of abscisic acid (ABA).
conclusions: Plant osmosensing is a complex process involving multiple mechanisms and signaling pathways. Key areas for future research include identifying the molecular components of the osmosensing apparatus, characterizing the signaling pathways upstream of ABA, and developing new assays to study plant adaptation to water-limited environments. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms by which plants perceive and respond to osmotic stress.
relationships: The review discusses the relationships between osmotic stress and various physiological responses in plants, including water uptake, turgor pressure, stomatal regulation, and cell expansion. It also explores the connections between osmosensing and other stress responses, such as drought tolerance and pathogen defense.
insights: Plants utilize diverse mechanisms to sense and respond to osmotic challenges, involving both direct perception of osmotic imbalance and indirect effects on cell membranes and walls. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for developing strategies to improve plant adaptation to water-limited environments and enhance crop productivity under drought conditions.

title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization.
objective: To determine the short-term effects of simulated microgravity on mesenchymal stem cell behaviors as a function of clinorotation speed.
methodology: Mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) were subjected to clinorotation at 0, 30, 60, and 75 rpm for 8 hours using a lab-on-chip clinostat system. Time-lapse microscopy was used to visualize cell morphology changes. Cytoarchitecture was assessed by actin and vinculin staining. Chemotaxis was examined using time-lapse microscopy of cells in NGF gradients.
results: Higher angular frequency during clinorotation inhibited cell spreading. Cells at 75 rpm remained viable and re-spread after clinorotation. Clinorotation did not alter migration patterns in elongated cells, but most clinorotated cells exhibited cell retraction, compromising motility.
conclusions: hMSCs respond to clinorotation by adopting more rounded morphologies. The angular frequency-dependence suggests that a cell’s ability to sense the changing gravity vector is governed by the rate of perturbation. Cells cultured in clinorotated chemotaxis chambers were generally less motile and exhibited retraction instead of migration.
relationships: The study demonstrates a relationship between clinorotation speed, cell morphology, and cell migration. Higher clinorotation speeds lead to more rounded cell morphologies and reduced cell motility. The cellular response to simulated microgravity appears to be dominant over chemotactic signals.
insights: hMSCs are sensitive to changes in the angular frequency of clinorotation, suggesting the existence of a gravisensing mechanism linked to cell spreading and cytoskeletal organization. The study highlights the importance of considering angular frequency in microgravity simulation experiments and its potential impact on stem cell regulation and applications.

title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer.
objective: To describe the sequential roles of FGF-2 in inducing gene expression and cell growth, and BMP-2 in gene expression and mineralization of bone.
methodology: Regulation of gene expression was determined using real-time RTPCR (qRTPCR). Cell proliferation was measured by thymidine incorporation or fluorescent analysis of DNA content in MC3T3E1 osteoblast-like cells. Photomicroscopy was used to identify newly mineralized tissue and fluorescence was used to quantify mineralization.
results: FGF-2 induced proliferation and expression of genes associated with proliferation and angiogenesis, while reducing gene expression associated with mineralization. BMP-2 stimulated expression of mineralization-associated genes but had little effect on growth-associated gene expression.
conclusions: FGF-2 plays a critical role in osteoblast growth in early fracture repair, while BMP-2 is instrumental in stimulating mineralization. FGF-2 has a de-differentiation effect (reduction of mineralization genes) and likely plays a key role in osteoblast proliferation.
relationships: FGF-2 down-regulates genes associated with mineralization while inducing genes associated with proliferation and angiogenesis. BMP-2 maintains the mineralizing RNA profile and increases expression of genes associated with mineralization.
insights: Bone formation during injury repair is a multi-step series of events modulated by an integrated cascade of gene expression that initially supports the proliferation stage, followed by the mineralization stage. FGF-2 and BMP-2 are required at different stages of bone repair.

title: To Infinity and Beyond! Human spaceflight and life science.
objective: To review the history of human spaceflight and its impact on life science, focusing on physiological changes observed in astronauts and potential countermeasures.
methodology: Review of literature on human spaceflights, including Apollo, Skylab, Spacelab Life Sciences-1, and the International Space Station (ISS). Analysis of physiological data collected from astronauts before, during, and after space missions. Examination of cellular and molecular studies related to the effects of microgravity.
results: Spaceflight induces several significant physiological changes, including fluid shift, space anemia (reduction of red blood cell mass), space osteoporosis (loss of bone density), and immunosuppression. Fluid shift leads to a decrease in plasma volume and erythropoietin levels. Bone loss occurs due to the lack of mechanical stress in microgravity. Immune function is impaired, with reduced T cell activation and potential reactivation of latent viruses.
conclusions: Gravity is essential for the normal function of several biological systems, including bone and immune cells. Spaceflight-induced physiological changes can have significant health implications for astronauts during long-duration missions. Further research into the underlying mechanisms of these changes may lead to new treatments for related diseases on Earth.
relationships: Microgravity induces bone loss by reducing mechanical stress, leading to decreased bone formation and increased bone resorption. Fluid shifts in space reduce plasma volume, which suppresses erythropoietin production and leads to space anemia. Spaceflight impairs T cell activation, potentially through altered signaling pathways and gene expression, contributing to immunosuppression.
insights: Understanding the physiological adaptations to spaceflight can provide insights into fundamental biological processes and potential therapeutic targets for diseases on Earth. Countermeasures such as exercise and pharmaceutical interventions are needed to mitigate the adverse effects of long-duration space missions. Future research should focus on the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying spaceflight-induced changes to develop effective preventive and therapeutic strategies.

title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer
objective: To examine the effects of lycopene and fish oil supplements versus placebo on the normal prostate microenvironment among men pursuing active surveillance for low-burden prostate cancer. The hypothesis was that lycopene or fish oil supplements would down-regulate insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) and cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) gene expression, respectively.
methodology: A 3-month randomized, double-blinded, clinical trial was conducted, comparing prostate tissue gene expression profiles (assessed by qRT–PCR) among men with favorable-risk prostate cancer receiving either 30 mg/day lycopene, 3 g/day fish oil, or placebo. 69 men were analyzed.
results: There was no significant difference in the change from baseline to 3 months in IGF-1 expression level between the placebo and lycopene arms (p = 0.93) nor in COX-2 expression between the placebo and fish arms (p = 0.99).
conclusions: Compared to placebo, a 3-month intervention with lycopene or fish oil did not significantly change IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression in the normal prostate micro-environment in men with low-burden prostate cancer. Further analysis of global gene expression profiles may shed light on the bioactivity and relevance of these nutrients in prostate cancer.
relationships: The study investigated the relationship between nutritional supplements (lycopene and fish oil) and the expression of genes (IGF-1 and COX-2) involved in prostate cancer pathways.
insights: The trial demonstrated the feasibility and safety of studying the effects of nutritional supplements on the prostate microenvironment in men with low-burden prostate cancer on active surveillance. The results indicated no decrease in the gene expression of IGF-I or IGF-1R with 3-month lycopene supplement compared with placebo and no evidence of a decrease in COX-2 gene expression for fish oil supplement versus placebo.

title: Effects of gravitational mechanical unloading in endothelial cells: association between caveolins, inflammation and adhesion molecules
objective: To investigate the role and mechanisms of invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells in lung disorder in BPD, focusing on their impact on alveolar type II epithelial cells (AEC II).
methodology: Utilized public datasets, clinical samples from preterm infants, a hyperoxia-induced BPD mouse model, and an AEC II-iNKT cells transwell co-culture system. Flow cytometry, RNA sequencing, ELISA, and western blot were employed to analyze cell populations, gene expression, and protein levels.
results: Increased NKT cells in peripheral blood of BPD patients. Hyperoxia exposure in mice led to increased iNKT cells in the lungs and abnormal lung development. Inhibition of iNKT cells alleviated lung abnormalities, while specific activation or adoptive transfer of iNKT cells aggravated lung disorders. Co-culture experiments showed iNKT cells promote AEC II ferroptosis under hyperoxia, accompanied by decreased expression of SP-C and T1α.
conclusions: Recruitment of iNKT cells in the lung may be an important cause of alveolarization disorder in BPD. Over-activated iNKT cells induce ferroptosis in AEC II, leading to AEC II dysfunction and contributing to the pathogenesis of BPD.
relationships: iNKT cells, AEC II, Ferroptosis, IL-17A, IL-6, CD1d, SP-C, T1α
insights: The study suggests a potential therapeutic target in BPD by modulating iNKT cell activity to prevent AEC II ferroptosis and promote normal alveolar development. IL-17A and IL-6 may play a role in iNKT cells promoting ferroptosis.

title: n-3 Polyunsaturated fatty acids supplementation in peripheral artery disease: the OMEGA-PAD trial
objective: To investigate the impact of gravitational mechanical unloading on endothelial cell (ECs) phenotype as determined by patterns of gene expression. Specifically, to assess whether cell morphology is involved in functions such as eNOS regulation, inflammation, and adhesion.
methodology: Human umbilical vascular endothelial cells (HUVECs) were exposed to 1-gravity environment or mechanical unloading (MU) for 24-48 hours, with or without periods of mechanical loading (ML). Gene expression was measured using qRT-PCR and flow cytometry. Cytoskeletal changes were assessed using immunofluorescence labeling. A mouse model of hindlimb suspension was used to simulate mechanical unloading in vivo.
results: MU led to a significant decrease in gene expression of adhesion molecules (ICAM-1, VCAM-1, E-Selectin) and pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-α). eNOS, Caveolin-1, and -2 expression were significantly increased with MU. Cell length and width decreased with MU. Mechanical loading reversed the changes triggered by MU. Hindlimb suspension in mice led to similar changes in eNOS, Caveolin-1, -2, IL-6 and E-Selectin expression in aortic endothelial cells.
conclusions: Gravitational mechanical unloading affects inflammatory and adhesion molecules expression in ECs towards an 'anti-inflammatory' phenotype. This is coupled with an increase in eNOS and caveolin gene expression. Changes in gene expression and morphology are tightly linked to gravitational mechanical forces, with a possible role for caveolins. Artificial gravity may improve the effects of microgravity.
relationships: Mechanical unloading alters the cytoskeleton of ECs, leading to disorganization of actin filaments. This may impair the transport of molecules, such as caveolins, to the plasma membrane. The changes in inflammation, adhesion molecules, eNOS, and caveolins are likely mediated through changes in the cytoskeleton.
insights: Microgravity may have a beneficial impact on the health of blood vessels by inducing an anti-inflammatory phenotype in endothelial cells. The findings suggest that manipulating cell phenotype using gravitational forces could be a potential therapeutic approach for cardiovascular diseases. The changes in vascular ECs could be involved in the overall changes in the immune system seen with spaceflight.

title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates
objective: To assess the effect of 3 months of high-dose oral n-3 PUFA supplementation on inflammation, endothelial function, and walking ability in patients with PAD.
methodology: Double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled trial. Patients with claudication received 4.4 g/d of fish oil or placebo for 3 months. Outcomes measured included high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels, the omega-3 index, endothelial function (flow-mediated vasodilation), walking impairment questionnaire, and a 6-min walk test. Plasma levels of specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs) were measured by liquid-chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry.
results: In patients treated with fish oil, the absolute mean omega-3 index significantly increased from baseline. There were significant increases in several pathway markers of SPM biosynthesis, including several mono-hydroxyeicosapentaenoic acids and mono-hydroxydocosahexaenoic acids. Significant increases were observed in the SPM lipoxin A5 and resolvin E3. No significant changes were found in high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, flow-mediated vasodilation, walking impairment questionnaire, or 6-min walk test in the fish oil group.
conclusions: Fish oil increases SPMs in plasma of patients with PAD. Further studies are required to determine whether these early changes translate to clinical improvements in patients with PAD.
relationships: N-3 PUFA supplementation increases the production of mediators of resolution of inflammation, specifically SPMs. SPMs orchestrate termination of inflammation and return to tissue homeostasis, potentially protecting against atherosclerosis, vascular injury, and PAD.
insights: High-dose n-3 PUFA supplementation results in significant increases in the omega-3 index and SPMs and their biosynthetic pathway markers in patients with PAD, suggesting a potential role in addressing an inflammation resolution deficit. The study provides evidence that patients with PAD are capable of utilizing EPA and DHA in endogenous enzymatic pathways that increase the production of SPMs.

title: Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation
objective: To investigate the impact of spaceflight on microRNA (miRNA) expression during T-cell activation.
methodology: Human leukocytes were stimulated with mitogens on board the International Space Station (ISS) with an onboard normal gravity control. Microarray analysis and quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) were used to analyze miRNA and gene expression. Bioinformatics tools were used to predict transcription factor locations.
results: miR-21 was significantly up-regulated during early T-cell activation in normal gravity, but this up-regulation was suppressed under microgravity conditions. Global microarray analysis showed significant suppression of 85 genes under microgravity compared to normal gravity. Several miR-21 target genes (EGR3, FASLG, BTG2, SPRY2, and TAGAP) were co-up-regulated with miR-21 in normal gravity.
conclusions: Spaceflight and microgravity regulate T-cell activation by altering miRNA expression, specifically miR-21. Gravity influences T-cell gene expression through both transcriptional promotion and translational blocking via noncoding RNA mechanisms. T-cell activation induces a sequence of gene expressions that is self-limited by miR-21.
relationships: miR-21 targets EGR3, FASLG, BTG2, SPRY2 and TAGAP. AP1 and NF-κB are key regulators of miR-21 gene induction and T-cell activation.
insights: Microgravity suppresses T-cell activation by dysregulating miR-21 expression. miR-21 may be involved in a previously unrecognized autoregulatory loop that limits the duration of normal T-cell activation. This self-limiting induction mechanism may be relevant to other growth processes and potentially to cancer.

title: Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines.
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying the improved and prolonged synthetic and metabolic functions of three-dimensional (3D) culture of hepatocytes compared to two-dimensional (2D) culture.
methodology: Primary mouse hepatocytes were cultured as monolayers on tissue culture dishes (TCD) or as 3D aggregates in rotating wall vessel (RWV) bioreactors. Global gene expression analyses (microarrays), ELISA assays for albumin, assays for Cytochrome P450 activity, Cyquant assays for cell number, and qRT-PCR were performed to compare the two culture methods. Promoter region analysis was also conducted to identify over-represented transcription factor binding sites.
results: Hepatocytes cultured in RWVs formed 3D aggregates with enhanced synthetic and metabolic functions (albumin secretion, CYP1A1 activity) compared to TCDs. Gene expression analysis revealed distinct gene expression profiles between the two culture methods. Genes upregulated in RWV cultures were enriched for hepatocyte-specific functions, with significant over-representation of hepatocyte nuclear factor 4α (Hnf4a) binding sites in their promoters. Hnf4a expression was significantly increased in RWV cultures, while mesenchymal and cytoskeletal genes were suppressed.
conclusions: 3D cell-cell interactions in RWV cultures are important for maintaining expression of Hnf4a, which in turn plays a key role in maintaining differentiated hepatocyte functions. Monolayer cultures on TCDs induce mesenchymal and cytoskeletal gene expression, which is suppressed in 3D aggregates.
relationships: Hnf4a is identified as a key regulator of hepatocyte-specific functions in 3D culture. The study highlights the importance of 3D cell-cell interactions in maintaining hepatocyte differentiation and function.
insights: The findings provide a basis for rational design of biomaterials that aim to optimize hepatocyte-specific functions for in vitro and in vivo applications by maximizing 3D cell-cell interactions and minimizing stiff 2D substrate contacts. 3D hepatocyte cultures are advantageous for applications where the differentiated state of hepatocytes is critical, such as drug toxicity studies and improving differentiation of hepatocyte-like cells from stem cells.

title: From cellular mechanotransduction to biologically inspired engineering: 2009 Pritzker Award Lecture, BMES Annual Meeting October 10, 2009.
objective: To explore the principles of cellular mechanotransduction and their application in biologically inspired engineering.
methodology: Review of mechanotransduction principles and examples of bioengineering applications.
results: Discussion of how cells sense and respond to mechanical forces, and how this knowledge can be used to design new biomaterials and devices.
conclusions: Mechanotransduction provides a powerful framework for developing biologically inspired engineering solutions.
relationships: Exploration of the relationship between cellular mechanics and tissue engineering.
insights: Understanding mechanotransduction can lead to innovative approaches in regenerative medicine and biomaterial design.

title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces
objective: To understand how cells sense and respond to mechanical signals at the molecular level and how this knowledge can be used to develop biologically inspired materials and devices for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
methodology: The study uses a combination of cell biology, engineering, and biophysics techniques, including laser nanosurgery, magnetic cytometry, microfluidics, and DNA origami, to investigate the role of tensegrity architecture in cell mechanics and mechanotransduction.
results: The study demonstrates that cells behave mechanically like tensegrity structures, with prestressed actomyosin filaments and compression-bearing microtubules. Integrins function as mechanoreceptors, transmitting mechanical forces across the cell surface and influencing intracellular biochemistry and gene expression. Cell shape and ECM mechanics regulate cell growth, differentiation, and motility.
conclusions: Cellular mechanotransduction is a fundamental process that enables cells to sense and respond to mechanical forces, influencing cell function and tissue development. Tensegrity architecture plays a critical role in this process, providing a mechanism for force transmission and mechanical integration between part and whole.
relationships: The study highlights the importance of cell-ECM interactions, integrin signaling, and cytoskeletal dynamics in mechanotransduction. It also emphasizes the role of RhoA, ROCK, and other signaling molecules in regulating cell shape, cytoskeletal tension, and cell fate.
insights: Mechanical forces are as important as chemicals and genes in regulating cell and tissue function. Engineering approaches can provide new insights into biological control and lead to the development of novel biomimetic technologies for medicine.

title: Sierra Nevada sweep: Metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere.
objective: To measure the relationship between environmental microorganisms and astronauts in spaceflight, assessing potential threats or benefits to astronaut health during long-term space missions.
methodology: Shotgun metagenomic sequencing was used to analyze microbial diversity in samples collected from eight defined ISS surface locations over six months. Skin, ear, mouth, nostril, and saliva samples were collected from a crewmember pre-flight, in-flight, and post-flight. The Livermore Metagenomics Analysis Toolkit was used for taxonomic classification.
results: Crewmember skin samples were more closely related to ISS surface samples than other crewmember samples. Propionibacterium was the most abundant bacterial genus in skin, ear, and on ISS surfaces. Saliva samples showed decreased species diversity during flight, with gradual recovery post-flight. The crewmember microbiome contributed significantly to the ISS surface microbiome.
conclusions: There is an exchange of microbial composition between crewmember skin and ISS surfaces. Spaceflight conditions impact the human microbiome, potentially causing dysbiosis. Monitoring microbial dynamics is crucial for future long-term space missions to forecast and respond to health impacts.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the astronaut's microbiome and the microbiome of the ISS. It shows that the skin microbiome of the astronaut is similar to the microbiome found on the surfaces of the ISS. The study also shows that the oral microbiome of the astronaut changes during spaceflight.
insights: The findings suggest that the ISS microbiome is influenced by the crewmembers inhabiting the station. The study also suggests that spaceflight conditions can alter the human microbiome, which could have implications for astronaut health. Further research is needed to understand the long-term effects of spaceflight on the human microbiome and the ISS microbiome.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
objective: To explore how airborne microbial patterns change with height above the Earth’s surface by analyzing bioaerosols collected at different altitudes.
methodology: NASA's C-20A aircraft was flown along flight paths over the US Sierra Nevada mountain range at four different altitudes. Bioaerosols were analyzed by metagenomic DNA sequencing and traditional culturing methods. A meteorological and atmospheric dispersion computer model was applied to the microbiological dataset.
results: The relative abundance of taxa changed significantly at each altitude sampled, and the diversity profile shifted across the two sampling days. The most proportionally abundant microbial genera varied by altitude. Viable Bacillus species were identified in the upper troposphere. Atmospheric modeling predicted potential downwind population exposures.
conclusions: Microbial abundance changes with height above the Earth’s surface. The study highlights the importance of control measurements in aerobiology studies. Long-range dispersal of viable bioaerosols may have agricultural and public health implications.
relationships: The study suggests a possible relationship between atmospheric samples and agriculture due to the abundance of certain bacteria. It also indicates that wastewater treatment facilities could be a contributing source of bioaerosols.
insights: The atmospheric microbiome is dynamically changing at each altitude. Vertical bioaerosol measurements can be made across the troposphere using sensitive molecular methods. Multipronged efforts may result in refined forecast models for winds carrying potentially disruptive pathogens.

title: Microbial tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station.
objective: To characterize the draft genomes of fungal strains isolated from surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS) as part of the Microbial Tracking-2 study.
methodology: Ninety-four fungal strains were isolated from ISS surfaces. Whole-genome sequencing was performed using the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform. Genomes were assembled using SPAdes, and quality was assessed with QUAST. Genus-level identification was performed using BLAST searches against the UNITE database. Species identification was performed using specific loci suitable for species recognition.
results: Draft genomes of 94 fungal strains, representing 10 ascomycetous and 1 basidiomycetous species, isolated from the ISS were assembled and characterized. The fungal species identified included Aspergillus unguis, Aureobasidium pullulans, Cladosporium cladosporioides, Cladosporium sphaerospermum, Fusarium annulatum, Fusarium veterinarium, Penicillium citrinum, Penicillium corylophilum, Penicillium palitans, Penicillium rubens and Rhodotorula mucilaginosa.
conclusions: Characterization of these fungal genomes will allow evaluation of microgravity adaption, risks to human health and spacecraft functioning, and biotechnological applications of fungi in space environments.
relationships: The study highlights the interactions between fungi, the space environment, astronaut health, and spacecraft integrity.
insights: The fungal isolates from the ISS represent a diverse collection of species with varying potential impacts on the space environment, including opportunistic infections, system biofouling, and potential biotechnological applications.

title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
objective: To analyze the surface microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) over time, focusing on microbial burden, species prevalence, changes in the microbiome and resistome, functional capabilities, and microbial interactions.
methodology: Sterile wipes were used to sample eight locations on the ISS across four flights. DNA was extracted from the wipes, treated with propidium monoazide (PMA) to assess viable cells, and analyzed using shotgun metagenomics sequencing. Culture analysis was also performed. Data was analyzed using various bioinformatics tools to determine microbial diversity, taxonomic profiles, antimicrobial resistance profiles, and co-occurrence patterns.
results: Bacteria dominated the ISS surface microbiome, with Staphylococcus sp. being the most represented bacterial species and Malassezia sp. the most represented fungal species. Temporal differences in microbial profiles and loads were observed across different flights, but no spatial differences were found. Twenty-nine antimicrobial resistance genes were detected, with multidrug and macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin resistance being the most prevalent. Co-occurrence analysis revealed strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera.
conclusions: The ISS surface microbiome is a complex and dynamic environment influenced by factors such as crew members and cleaning regimes. The stability of the resistome, even amidst changes in community composition, suggests functional redundancy. Microbial interactions, such as those between Aspergillus and Fusarium, may have implications for astronaut health and spacecraft integrity. The data can inform policies for future space missions to ensure an ISS surface microbiome that promotes astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
relationships: Strong microbial interactions were observed through co-occurrence analysis, predicting the likelihood of genera to co-inhabit a particular niche. Positive associations were found between Aspergillus and Fusarium, and Aspergillus and Staphylococcus. These interactions may have implications for astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
insights: The ISS surface microbiome is a unique built environment with a stable resistome and strong microbial interactions. Understanding these dynamics is crucial for ensuring astronaut health and spacecraft integrity during long-duration space missions. The study highlights the importance of microbial monitoring of food sources and the potential benefits of mixed microbial communities in preventing the formation of harmful biofilms.

title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response
objective: To identify key genes and repurposable drugs for treating skeletal muscle atrophy in spaceflight microgravity by applying machine learning algorithms to GeneLab datasets and constructing gene-disease and disease-drug networks.
methodology: Mining GeneLab datasets related to skeletal muscle atrophy, identifying regulatory relationships between gene pairs using Pearson correlation and Markov Blanket methods, constructing Gene Disease Knowledge Graph (GDKG) and Disease Drug Knowledge Graph (DDKG), and applying machine learning methods (Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, Graph Neural Network, and Graph Convolutional Network) for link prediction.
results: Identification of 473 significantly regulated genes from GeneLab datasets. The GCN method achieved the highest accuracy (96.11% for GDKG, 99.19% for DDKG) in link prediction. Predicted new gene-disease associations and ranked potential drugs for repurposing, including L-carnitine and thiamine.
conclusions: The study identified key genes involved in skeletal muscle atrophy that are also highly activated in other diseases. Machine learning algorithms, particularly GCN, can effectively identify potential drugs for repurposing to manage skeletal muscle atrophy in spaceflight microgravity. The constructed networks are scalable and can be expanded to include more datasets, genes, and drugs.
relationships: Identified relationships between skeletal muscle atrophy genes and diseases such as metabolic and neuromuscular diseases, cancer, and neurodegenerative diseases. Established links between diseases and potential drug treatments based on network analysis and link prediction.
insights: Genes overexpressed in skeletal muscle atrophy are also prioritized in other diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. L-carnitine and thiamine are potential nutrients that can be given as a dietary supplement countermeasure for skeletal muscle atrophy in spaceflight. The GCN method demonstrated the best performance with highest accuracies from ten-fold cross validation for link prediction in both the GDKG and DDKG.

title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response
objective: To understand how spaceflight affects human health by analyzing plasma cell-free RNA (cfRNA) in astronauts before, during, and after spaceflight, and to compare these findings with mouse data from a spaceflight mission with artificial gravity.
methodology: Liquid biopsies were performed on six astronauts residing on the International Space Station (ISS) for over 120 days. Plasma cfRNA was analyzed using RNA-sequencing. A mitochondrial DNA-enriched fraction associated with the scavenger receptor CD36 was identified using cell surface marker antibodies. Data was compared to mouse plasma cfRNA data from a previous JAXA mission using artificial gravity.
results: Mitochondrial dysregulation was confirmed in space. A mitochondrial DNA-enriched fraction was associated with CD36. RNA-sequencing of the CD36 fraction revealed tissue-enriched RNA species, suggesting plasma mitochondrial components originated from various tissues. Microgravity was linked to the observed mitochondrial responses. Specific molecular pathways affected by spaceflight were identified, including those related to reactive oxygen species (ROS) and the nervous system. Tissue-specific genes were detected in the cfRNA-seq data, indicating spaceflight-associated responses in non-blood tissues.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces changes in cfRNA profiles, including increased plasma mitochondrial components and decreased RNAs encoded by mucin genes. CD36-marked EVs contain mitochondrial components released into the plasma during spaceflight, indicating systemic metabolic stress responses. Tissue-specific RNAs identified space environmental responses in previously uncharacterized tissue types. These findings provide insights into previously uncharacterized tissue types and molecular processes in the human body affected by spaceflight.
relationships: Microgravity is linked to mitochondrial responses. There is a relationship between oxidative stress and altered blood-tissue barrier functions. The study suggests a potential correlation between neuro-inflammatory responses in the brain and retinal tissues.
insights: Cell-free nucleic acids are potential space-relevant biomarkers of psychosocial and physical stress, aging, metabolic disorders, and inflammation. Liquid biopsies could be useful to detect early molecular events associated with retina tissue damage. Mitochondrial dysregulation is a central feature that accelerates spaceflight health risks.

title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
objective: To investigate the effects of multiple hindlimb unloading (HLU) and reambulation (RA) cycles on body composition, lumbar bone mineral density, and muscle cross-sectional area in mice.
methodology: Adult male mice were subjected to one, two, or three cycles of 2 weeks of hindlimb unloading followed by 4 weeks of reambulation. Changes in adipose tissue, lean tissue, bone mineral density, and muscle cross-sectional area were longitudinally tracked using in vivo micro-CT. Ex vivo micro-CT was used to assess trabecular bone micro-architecture.
results: Multiple unloading cycles attenuated the change in adipose, lean, and bone tissue during the final unloading cycle. Total adipose tissue and vertebral bone mineral density recovered to control levels after reambulation, irrespective of the number of unloading cycles. Muscle cross-sectional area was lower in all unloaded groups compared to controls after reambulation. Loss of abdominal adipose tissue was associated with loss of bone mineral density.
conclusions: Multiple hindlimb unloading/reambulation cycles were not more detrimental to abdominal adipose, lean, and vertebral bone tissue than a single unloading period. Tissues can modulate their response to unloading based on previous unloading history. The lumbar vertebrae are more capable of recovering during reambulation periods than the peripheral skeleton.
relationships: A moderate association was found between the loss of bone and the loss of abdominal adipose tissue during unloading. No association was observed between the loss of abdominal lean tissue and the loss of bone.
insights: The study suggests that the body adapts to repeated unloading cycles, potentially reaching a basal level where further losses are attenuated. The differential recovery of lumbar vertebrae compared to the peripheral skeleton highlights the importance of considering the specific mechanical loading environment when designing countermeasures for bone loss.

title: Focal enhancement of the skeleton to exercise correlates to mesenchymal stem cell responsivity rather than peak external forces.
objective: To investigate the relationship between bone adaptation and mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) responsivity in growing mice subject to exercise, and to determine if skeletal adaptation to exercise correlates with load magnitude or MSC activity.
methodology: A mouse model was used where mice were subjected to treadmill running. Peak external forces generated by forelimbs and hindlimbs during quadrupedal locomotion were measured using a force plate. Bone structure was measured with μCT. Flow cytometry was used to quantify marrow-derived MSCs in the femur and humerus.
results: Peak external forces generated by forelimbs during locomotion were significantly higher than hindlimb forces. Exercise led to significant enhancements of diaphyseal bone areas and moments of area in the ulna, femur, and tibia, but not in the humerus or radius. Marrow-derived MSCs in the femur were more responsive to exercise-induced loads than humeral cells, with running significantly lowering MSC populations only in the femur.
conclusions: The ability of the progenitor population to differentiate toward osteoblastogenesis may correlate better with bone structural adaptation than peak external forces caused by exercise. Skeletal adaptation to exercise is site-specific and not solely determined by load magnitudes.
relationships: Exercise-induced bone adaptation is related to the responsivity of mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) rather than the magnitude of external forces. The study highlights a relationship between MSC activity in specific bones (femur) and bone structural enhancements due to exercise.
insights: The study suggests that the site-specificity of skeletal adaptation to exercise may be defined by regional variation in the mechanoresponsiveness of bone progenitor cells. The findings challenge the assumption that skeletal benefits of exercise are always proportional to load magnitudes.

title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
objective: To test whether high activity levels lead to more elliptical limb bone shafts and low activity levels lead to more circular shafts in mice.
methodology: Two experiments were conducted using mice. In the first, mice underwent treadmill exercise for 1 month. In the second, hindlimbs were unloaded for 1 month. Femoral mid-shaft structure was determined using lCT to measure Imax and Imin.
results: Exercise enhanced Imax and Imin but did not significantly increase the Imax/Imin index. Unloading stunted bone growth, diminishing Imax and Imin, but did not significantly decrease Imax/Imin.
conclusions: High- and low-activity lifestyles do not have the causal effects on the shaft bending strength index that are often assumed in anthropological analyses of human lower limb bone shaft structure. Caution is required when using the bone shaft bending strength index to reconstruct activity levels.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between physical activity (exercise and unloading) and bone shaft bending strength index (Imax/Imin).
insights: The bone shaft bending strength index may not be a reliable indicator of physical activity levels, as exercise and unloading did not significantly alter the index in mice.

title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.
objective: To determine if the directional application of low intensity vibrations (LIV) with respect to the plane of cell attachment differentially modulates mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) differentiation and cytoskeletal remodeling.
methodology: In vitro study using human bone marrow MSCs (hBMSCs) in 2D cell culture. Cells were subjected to horizontal (h-LIV) or vertical (v-LIV) LIV at varying frequencies (30 Hz or 100 Hz) and acceleration magnitudes (0.15 g or 1 g). Outcome variables included proliferation, differentiation, gene expression, cytoskeletal structure, and stiffness.
results: h-LIV was more effective at promoting MSC osteoblastogenesis, ALP activity, and mineralization compared to v-LIV. Gene expression of cytoskeletal and nucleoskeletal regulatory genes was increased to a greater extent by h-LIV. Cell stiffness was greater in cells exposed to h-LIV. 100 Hz LIV combinations were more potent than 30 Hz combinations, especially when combined with the lowest LIV magnitude (0.15 g).
conclusions: The structural configuration of the cytoskeleton plays a critical role in sensing and responding to low-level oscillatory mechanical signals. The direction of LIV application relative to the cell attachment plane significantly influences MSC differentiation and cytoskeletal remodeling.
relationships: LIV influences MSC fate selection by initiating mechanosensitive signaling pathways. The cell nucleus, mechanically integrated into the cell architecture via the LINC complex, participates in mechanosensing. h-LIV enhances gap junctional communication.
insights: The study emphasizes the importance of the cell's cytoskeletal and nucleo-cytoskeletal elements in transforming LIV signals into a biological response in human mesenchymal stem cells. Understanding these mechanisms may lead to effective mechanically based musculoskeletal treatments.

title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.
objective: To test muscle-bone interactions at the tissue and genetic level by quantifying changes in muscle and cortical bone morphology during hindlimb unloading and reambulation in a genetically heterogeneous mouse population.
methodology: 352 adult mice from a genetically heterogeneous population were subjected to 3 weeks of hindlimb unloading followed by 3 weeks of reambulation. Muscle and cortical bone morphology were assessed using in vivo micro-computed tomography (µCT). Genotyping and QTL mapping were performed to identify genetic regions associated with the mechano-response in muscle and bone. Statistical analysis included paired and unpaired t-tests, and correlations between muscle and bone variables were assessed.
results: During unloading, muscle area declined significantly, while cortical bone area showed a slight reduction. Reambulation led to an increase in muscle area and a recovery of cortical bone. One QTL was identified for muscle loss during unloading, and several QTLs were found for cortical bone changes. Correlations between changes in muscle and bone were generally low.
conclusions: The study suggests a lack of strong co-regulation between muscle and bone during unloading and reambulation in the genetically diverse mouse population. The findings indicate that the premise of a muscle-bone unit that co-adjusts its size during mechanical challenges may need to be reassessed.
relationships: Changes in muscle area were poorly correlated with changes in cortical bone area during both unloading and reambulation. The QTL for muscle changes during unloading did not overlap with QTLs for cortical bone, but shared common regions with trabecular bone QTLs.
insights: The study highlights the importance of genetic variations in the musculoskeletal response to mechanical signals. It suggests that molecular cross-tissue communication may not be solely driven by changes in muscle size. Mechanical interventions for musculoskeletal ailments may need to be optimized independently for bone and muscle.

title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation
objective: To evaluate the spatial and temporal effects of disuse from hindlimb unloading (HLU) on osteocyte apoptosis, receptor activator of NF-κB ligand (RANKL) expression, bone resorption, and loss in mouse femora, and to test whether osteocyte apoptosis was required to activate osteoclastic activity in cortical and trabecular bone.
methodology: C57BL/6J mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 5 or 14 days. Immunohistochemistry was used to identify apoptotic and RANKL-producing osteocytes in femoral diaphysis and distal trabecular bone. Micro-computed tomography (μCT) was used to determine the extent of trabecular bone loss. A pan-caspase apoptosis inhibitor, QVD, was used to inhibit osteocyte apoptosis.
results: HLU increased osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL production in both cortical and trabecular bone. Increases in osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL production preceded increases in bone resorption. QVD inhibited the HLU-triggered increases in osteocyte apoptosis, RANKL production, and activation of bone resorption. QVD prevented trabecular bone loss caused by HLU.
conclusions: Osteocyte apoptosis plays a central and controlling role in triggering osteocyte RANKL production and the activation of new resorption leading to bone loss in disuse.
relationships: Osteocyte apoptosis triggers viable, neighbor osteocytes to increase expression of the pro-osteoclastogenic cytokine receptor activator of NF-κB ligand (RANKL), thus activating focal resorption. The temporal and spatial coupling between osteocyte apoptosis and bone resorption after HLU strongly resemble that found in targeted remodeling of bone micro-damage and after estrogen loss.
insights: Insufficient mechanical loading in disuse states leads to a more global impairment of fluid-solute transport to and from osteocytes in the lacunar-canalicular system (LCS) and consequently a generalized metabolic stress on all osteocytes in non-loaded bones. The distribution of osteocyte apoptosis in the cortex in HLU was elevated in all anatomical regions of the femoral mid-diaphysis examined, a result that differs from the discrete, localized regions of osteocyte death found after estrogen withdrawal.

title: Macrophages inhibit Aspergillus fumigatus germination and neutrophil-mediated fungal killing.
objective: To understand how a pulse of hypergravity (HG) influences transcriptomic regulation of developmental processes in the embryoid body (EB) model, comparing embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and EBs with and without HG stimulation.
methodology: Mouse ESCs were cultured and induced to form EBs. Both ESCs and EBs were exposed to a 60-minute pulse of 50g hypergravity. Single-cell RNA sequencing was performed to analyze transcriptomic changes. Data was analyzed using CellRanger, Seurat, Monocle 2 and 3 to visualize data in tSNE and UMAP statistical methods.
results: A 60-min HG pulse resulted in minimal deviation in cell type assignment and transcriptomic signature from traditional static culture EBs. HG pulse EBs showed upregulation of genes related to multicellular development, mechanical signal transduction, and DNA damage repair. HG pulse increases EB growth markers in extra-embryonic tissue cell types and pre- and post-implant epiblasts. HG pulse increases transcriptomic signature of transitory cells.
conclusions: A pulse of gravity loading regulates stem cell self-renewal and differentiation by identiﬁcation of transcriptomic patterns in stem cells and developmental processes. HG pulse stimulation causes transition of cells through the early developmental program.
relationships: The study demonstrates that stem cells committed to a differentiation program are more sensitive to gravity-induced changes to their transcriptome. HG pulse stimulation causes transition of cells through the early developmental program.
insights: Gravity mechanostimulation can regulate ESC maintenance and EB development. Cells in early development maintain transitory phenotypes and have enhanced expression of germ layer lineage markers under HG pulse.

title: Contributions of spore secondary metabolites to UV-C protection and virulence vary in different Aspergillus fumigatus strains
objective: To investigate how immune mechanisms control Aspergillus fumigatus in immunocompetent individuals and whether the pathogenesis of different A. fumigatus strains varies.
methodology: Infection of larval zebrafish with A. fumigatus spores derived from two genetically diverse strains (Af293 and CEA10). Live imaging was used to visualize fungal growth and innate immune cell behavior.  Quantification of fungal killing, colony-forming units (CFUs), and immune cell recruitment were performed.
results: CEA10-derived strains are killed more effectively than Af293-derived strains in vivo. Macrophages form dense clusters around spores, inhibiting fungal germination. Germination drives fungal clearance through neutrophil-mediated killing. Myd88-mediated inflammatory activation is required for clearance of CEA10.
conclusions: Macrophages provide a protective niche for A. fumigatus spores by inhibiting germination, thereby reducing neutrophil recruitment and killing.  Faster-germinating strains are cleared more effectively due to neutrophil-mediated killing.
relationships: Macrophages inhibit spore germination, leading to reduced neutrophil recruitment. Neutrophils are more effective at killing germinated spores.  Myd88-dependent signaling is required for the inflammatory response to CEA10.
insights: The rate of fungal germination is a key determinant of the host immune response and fungal clearance. Macrophages play a dual role by both phagocytosing spores and inhibiting their germination, ultimately affecting the efficiency of neutrophil-mediated killing.

title: Contributions of spore secondary metabolites to UV-C protection and virulence vary in different Aspergillus fumigatus strains
objective: To investigate the role of melanin and other spore secondary metabolites (SMs) in protecting Aspergillus fumigatus isolates from UV-C radiation and their impact on virulence.
methodology: SM spore mutants of A. fumigatus strains (Af293, CEA17, IF1SW-F4) were subjected to UV-C radiation.  The virulence of DHN mutants was examined using a zebraﬁsh model of invasive aspergillosis.  Additional spore metabolites (fumiquinazoline, monomethylsulochrin, fumigaclavine) were examined for UV-C protective properties and virulence.  DNA repair mutants (ku70 and ku80) were also examined for UV-C sensitivity.
results: DHN-melanin mutants of clinical A. fumigatus strains (Af293 and CEA17) were more sensitive to UV-C than their wild-type strains, but the ISS-isolated strain (IF1SW-F4) was not. DHN-melanin was a virulence factor in CEA17 and IF1SW-F4 but not Af293. Fumiquinazoline showed UV-C-protective properties. Monomethylsulochrin deletion strain showed a slight increase in virulence.
conclusions: The roles of specific spore metabolites vary across Aspergillus isolates and by types of environmental stress. DHN-melanin protects some, but not all, A. fumigatus isolates from UV-C radiation. Fumiquinazolines are UV-C protectants in wild-type Af293. The involvement of spore SMs in virulence is strain-dependent.
relationships: DHN-melanin's role in UV-C protection does not correlate with its role in virulence across different A. fumigatus strains. The deletion of pksP in Af293 resulted in increased sensitivity to UV-C regardless of the akuA background, but the protective property of fumiquinazoline was masked in the ΔakuA background.
insights: Fungal spores contain secondary metabolites that protect them from abiotic and biotic stresses. Melanin's ability to protect spores from UV-C radiation or impact virulence varies among different isolates.  The discovery of radiation-protective small molecules may lead to novel safety measures for astronauts.

title: A novel phototropic response to red light is revealed in microgravity.
objective: To characterize the dappled mutant hemocyte phenotype and present the potential to study cytochrome b5 function by screening for compounds that affect the dappled hemocyte phenotype.
methodology: Molecular cloning and sequencing of the dappled gene, plasmid rescue, Northern blot analysis, RT-PCR, blood cell counts using hemocytometer, complementation tests, and analysis of transcription factor binding sites.
results: Identified dappled as a member of the cytochrome b5 family. Dappled mutants showed decreased CG2140 transcript levels. Heterozygosity of dappled increases plasmatocyte number. Expression of wild-type dappled in hemocytes rescued the melanotic phenotype and plasmatocyte increase. Curcumin enhances the melanotic phenotype.
conclusions: Dappled encodes a cytochrome b5, and its mutation affects hemocyte differentiation and number. Cytochrome b5 is critical for survival and normal function in hemocytes and other tissues. The dappled phenotype can be used as an in vivo assay for cytochrome b5 related effects of compounds.
relationships: Cytochrome b5 interacts with Traf6, an upstream activator of nuclear factor-kappaB. Dappled affects hormonal signaling of hematopoiesis. Hemocytes signal immune induction of the fat body.
insights: Cytochrome b5 plays a critical role in hemocyte development and function. The study provides a tractable genetic model for studying cytochrome b5 in blood cells and other tissues. Sex differences exist in the number of circulating blood cells in Drosophila.

title: Plant cell proliferation and growth are altered by microgravity conditions in spaceflight.
objective: To investigate the interaction between phototropic and gravitropic responses in Arabidopsis thaliana under varying gravity conditions, including microgravity and fractional gravity, and to characterize the phototropic responses to red and blue light.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were grown on the International Space Station (ISS) using the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS). Seedlings were exposed to different gravity conditions (microgravity, 0.1g, 0.3g, 0.5g, 0.8g, and 1g) and illuminated with red light, blue light, or red light followed by blue light. Seedling growth and curvature were measured using image analysis.
results: A novel positive blue-light phototropic response was observed in roots under microgravity, which was attenuated at 0.1g. Red-light pretreatment enhanced the blue-light phototropic response in roots. Positive phototropic curvature in roots exposed to red light decreased as gravity increased. Hypocotyls showed significant phototropic responses to light, but no significant effect from gravity. Seedling position relative to the light source significantly affected phototropic curvature.
conclusions: Microgravity reveals a novel blue-light phototropism in roots that is masked by gravity under normal Earth conditions. The interaction between gravitropic and phototropic responses differs for red and blue light. Repeating space experiments helps overcome technical issues and allows for new discoveries.
relationships: The study reveals a complex relationship between phototropism and gravitropism, where the direction of growth is an amalgamation of the two processes. The interaction between these responses is different for red and blue light, suggesting different underlying mechanisms. Cytosolic calcium levels may play a role in the interaction between gravity sensing and red-light phototropic response.
insights: Microgravity conditions can reveal plant responses that are not apparent under normal gravity. The threshold model for the blue-light-positive phototropic response suggests that gravity levels between 0g and 0.1g eliminate the response. The near-linear relationship between red-light phototropic response and gravity in roots suggests a potential antagonistic relationship with cytosolic calcium levels.

title: Phototropism of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity and fractional gravity on the International Space Station.
objective: To review transcriptomic studies of plants grown in spaceflights and ground-based microgravity simulators to understand adaptation mechanisms to the space environment, focusing on altered gravity and cosmic radiation.
methodology: Review of transcriptomic analyses from plants grown in spaceflights (ISS) and in different ground-based microgravity simulators (e.g., clinostats, random positioning machines). Analysis of gene expression changes at the global genome level (space omics) related to plant acclimation or adaptation.
results: Studies show common altered processes in plants grown under spaceflight conditions, including cell wall remodeling, oxidative stress, defense response, and photosynthesis. Red light plays a role in plant adaptation. Light regulation affects the expression of LAZY4, important in gravitropism. Upregulation of photosynthesis genes occurs even in etiolated plants in microgravity.
conclusions: Plants modify growth and development patterns in space, guided by gene expression profiles. Plasticity in plant genomes enables adaptation to altered gravity. Light and gravity are closely related in driving plant growth. Understanding these adaptive processes is key for successful space exploration strategies and plant cultivation in space.
relationships: Gravity and light are responsible for gravitropism and phototropism, respectively, and their regulatory effects on plant growth are closely related. The question of whether the deleterious effects of altered gravity could be compensated by light is critical for the success of plant culture in future human settlements on other planets.
insights: Plants exhibit plasticity in their genomes, enabling them to respond to unforeseen environmental conditions like gravity alteration. Gene redundancy contributes to this plasticity. The study of space omics reveals changes in gene expression related to plant acclimation and adaptation to survive, grow, and develop under altered gravity conditions.

title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
objective: To investigate the interaction between phototropic and gravitropic responses in Arabidopsis thaliana roots and shoots under varying gravity conditions and light qualities.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were grown on the International Space Station (ISS) in the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS) under microgravity and fractional gravity (0.1g, 0.3g, 0.5g, 0.8g, and 1g) conditions. Seedlings were exposed to white light initially, followed by unidirectional red or blue light, or a red light pretreatment followed by blue light. Seedling growth and curvature were measured using image analysis.
results: A novel positive blue-light phototropic response was observed in roots under microgravity, which was attenuated at 0.1g. Red-light pretreatment enhanced the blue-light phototropic response in roots. Positive red-light phototropic curvature in roots decreased with increasing gravity. Hypocotyls showed a positive phototropic response to blue and red light, with no significant gravity effect. Seedling position relative to the light source affected phototropic curvature.
conclusions: Microgravity reveals a blue-light phototropism in roots masked by gravity on Earth. Red-light pretreatment enhances blue-light phototropism. The interaction between gravitropic and phototropic responses differs for red and blue light. Spaceflight experiments are valuable for understanding plant tropisms.
relationships: The study reveals a complex relationship between light and gravity signaling in plant development.  Specifically, it demonstrates how gravity can mask certain phototropic responses, and how different light wavelengths interact with gravity to influence root and shoot growth direction.
insights: The findings suggest that plant roots have a more versatile directional response to light than previously thought, and that gravity plays a crucial role in modulating these responses.  Understanding these interactions is important for plant growth in space and potentially for optimizing plant growth on Earth.

title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity.
objective: To understand the interconnected growth phenomena of gravitropism and phototropism in plants, particularly in microgravity, and their effects on meristematic cells.
methodology: Review of existing literature and experiments, including those conducted in microgravity environments (Space Shuttle, International Space Station) and simulated microgravity (clinostat, free fall machines). Analysis of wild-type and mutant Arabidopsis plants.
results: Gravity and light influence plant development. Microgravity disrupts meristematic competence by uncoupling cell proliferation and cell growth. Light irradiation, especially red light, activates these processes. Auxin is a key mediator in these alterations. Spaceflight experiments reveal a novel positive phototropic response to red light in Arabidopsis hypocotyls.
conclusions: Light and gravity responses influence each other. Red light stimulation can potentially restore meristematic competence under microgravity. Further research is needed to understand the signaling mechanisms involved in plant tropisms and the effects of gravity and light on cell growth and proliferation for future space colonization efforts.
relationships: Gravitropism and phototropism are interconnected. Auxin plays a key role in both processes. Phytochromes mediate light responses. The cytoskeleton is involved in gravity transduction. Calcium signaling is affected by microgravity.
insights: Plants have evolved multiple gravisensing mechanisms. Light and gravity interact to modulate plant development. Microgravity provides a unique environment to study plant tropisms. Understanding these interactions is crucial for growing plants in space.

title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
objective: To investigate phototropism in Arabidopsis thaliana under varying gravity conditions (microgravity to 1g) and different light spectra (red and blue) to understand the interaction between phototropic and gravitropic responses.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings (wild type and phytochrome mutants) were grown in the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS) on the International Space Station (ISS). They were subjected to different gravity levels (microgravity, 0.1g, 0.3g, 0.5g, 0.8g, and 1g) and illuminated with red light, blue light, or a red light pretreatment followed by blue light. Seedling growth and curvature were measured using ImageJ software.
results: A novel positive blue-light phototropic response was observed in roots under microgravity, which was attenuated at 0.1g and absent at higher gravity levels. Red-light pretreatment enhanced the blue-light phototropic response. Positive root phototropic curvature was observed under red light, decreasing with increasing gravity. Hypocotyls showed significant phototropic responses to both red and blue light, with no significant gravity effect. Seedling position relative to the light source significantly affected phototropic curvature.
conclusions: Microgravity reveals a blue-light phototropism in roots masked by gravity on Earth. Red-light pretreatment enhances blue-light phototropism. The interaction between gravitropic and phototropic responses differs for red and blue light. Spaceflight experiments are valuable for understanding plant phototropic responses without the confounding effects of Earth's gravity.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between phototropism and gravitropism, showing how gravity influences the phototropic responses of roots and hypocotyls to different light wavelengths. It also investigates the interaction between red and blue light in eliciting phototropic responses.
insights: The study provides insights into the complex interplay between light and gravity in plant growth and development. It reveals that gravity can mask certain phototropic responses and that different light wavelengths elicit distinct phototropic responses under varying gravity conditions. The findings have implications for understanding plant adaptation to different environments, including space.

title: RNAseq analysis of the response of Arabidopsis thaliana to fractional gravity under blue-light stimulation during spaceflight
objective: To understand the effects of microgravity and spaceflight on gene expression and cell wall composition in plant development, specifically in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings.
methodology: Transcriptome analysis using microarrays (RMA, MAS5, PLIER normalization). Cell wall glycome profiling using ELISA with monoclonal antibodies. Comparison with two other experiments (BRIC-16-Reg and BRIC-16-DNA) conducted with similar hardware on the same mission (STS-131).
results: Expression changes in genes involved in hypoxia, heat shock responses, DNA repair, and cell wall structure were noted in spaceflight samples compared to ground controls. Glycome profiling showed differences in cell wall components. Limited overlap in differentially regulated genes was found among the three BRIC-16 experiments, but common functional categories (stress response, defense, auxin signaling, metabolic processes, cell wall modification) were identified.
conclusions: Downregulation of water stress response genes was a common theme in spaceflight. Differential regulation of genes associated with cell wall remodeling and stress responses occurred between spaceflight-grown and ground control plants. Differences in experimental conditions (genotypes, tissues used, analytical techniques) can lead to differing results even with the same hardware.
relationships: The study highlights the complex interplay between microgravity, gene expression, and cell wall modification in plants. It also emphasizes the importance of considering experimental variations when comparing spaceflight studies.
insights: Spaceflight induces changes in cell wall organization and stress responses in Arabidopsis seedlings. Water stress may be less pronounced in spaceflight compared to ground conditions. Organ-specific analysis (shoots vs. whole seedlings) provides a more detailed understanding of plant responses to spaceflight.

title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development
objective: To analyze the transcriptional response of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings to different partial gravity levels under blue-light stimulation during spaceflight on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana seeds were germinated and grown for six days under microgravity, several partial-g levels, and 1g, with blue light irradiation for the last 48 hours. RNA was extracted and analyzed using RNAseq. Transcriptomic analysis was performed using the HISAT2-Stringtie-DESeq pipeline. Differentially expressed genes were characterized using the GEDI tool, gene networks, and Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment.
results: Differential gene expression analysis revealed a limited number of differentially expressed genes across gravity conditions. The number of differentially expressed genes varied depending on the gravity level, with different GO groups affected at each level: light and photosynthesis under microgravity, general stress and hormone responses under low-g, and cell wall/membrane structure and function under Moon g-level.
conclusions: Root blue-light phototropism may reduce the gravitational stress response caused by the lack of gravitropism in microgravity. Competition among tropisms induces an intense perturbation at the micro-g level, showing an extensive stress response. Cell wall/membrane remodeling is detected at the interval from the Moon to Mars gravity, potentially related to graviresistance mechanisms.
relationships: The study investigates the interaction between phototropism and gravitropism in plants under varying gravity conditions, revealing how blue light stimulation can influence the plant's response to gravity.
insights: The transcriptional analysis suggests that plants adapt to reduced gravity conditions by modulating gene expression related to light perception, stress response, and cell wall/membrane structure. The findings highlight the complex interplay between different tropisms and their impact on plant development in space.

title: The importance of Earth reference controls in spaceflight-omics research: Characterization of nucleolin mutants from the Seedling Growth experiments
objective: To review and compare the strengths and weaknesses of microgravity analogs (clinostats, RPM, magnetic levitation) for studying plant growth and development relative to spaceflight experiments. Also, to consider reduced or partial gravity effects via spaceflight and analog methods.
methodology: Review and comparison of existing literature and experimental data on plant growth and development under various gravity conditions, including spaceflight, simulated microgravity using clinostats and random positioning machines (RPM), and magnetic levitation.
results: The fidelity of microgravity analog results relative to spaceflight depends on biological parameters and environmental conditions that cannot be fully simulated in ground-based studies. Clinostats, RPMs, and magnetic levitation each have their own advantages and limitations in simulating weightlessness or altered gravity conditions. Partial gravity studies in space and using analogs show promise for understanding plant biology at lunar and Martian gravity levels.
conclusions: Ground-based microgravity simulation devices can be useful tools, but significant differences exist between plants grown on these devices and those grown in spaceflight. Carefully controlled experiments are needed to systematically determine the conditions under which ground-based simulation can provide useful information and comparability with spaceflight experiments. The ISS provides unique facilities to compare effects observed in clinostats and other space simulators and to explore the effects of partial gravity on plant growth and development.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between gravity, plant growth, and various simulation methods. It also investigates the interaction between gravitropism and phototropism under different gravity conditions.
insights: Plant responses to gravity are complex and influenced by multiple factors, including the type of gravity environment (microgravity, partial gravity, simulated gravity), the specific plant species and tissue, and environmental conditions. Microgravity analogs can provide valuable insights, but their limitations must be carefully considered. Further research is needed to optimize ground-based simulation methods and to fully understand plant biology in space under different gravity levels.

title: Conducting plant experiments in space and on the Moon
objective: To understand plant adaptive responses to the space environment, particularly focusing on ribosome biogenesis and the effects of light and gravity on plant development.
methodology: Ground studies using Arabidopsis thaliana wild-type and nucleolin mutants (nuc1-2 and nuc2-2) exposed to different illumination regimes (red light and darkness) in a controlled environment mimicking spaceflight hardware.
results: Red light primarily activates genes involved in photosynthesis, cell wall modification, and stress response. The nuc1-2 mutant shows fewer differentially expressed genes compared to wild-type and nuc2-2, suggesting a reduced response to environmental stress. Darkness promotes genes involved in cell division and response to stimuli.
conclusions: The NUC1 protein is necessary for the red light stimulation of cell proliferation, while NUC2 plays a lesser role. NUC2 can partially compensate for the absence of NUC1 under stress conditions. Ground reference controls are crucial for interpreting spaceflight experiment results.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between light and gravity signals in modulating plant development, particularly in the context of spaceflight. It also investigates the interaction between NUC1 and NUC2 proteins in response to environmental cues.
