insights: Understanding the roles of nucleolin proteins (NUC1 and NUC2) in plant adaptation to spaceflight conditions can contribute to developing better crops for bioregenerative life support systems in future human space missions. Light can modulate the stress response and rescue wild-type transcriptional profiles in certain mutants.

title: Red light enhances plant adaptation to spaceflight and Mars g-levels.
objective: To study the effects of altered gravity conditions (simulated microgravity, partial gravity (Moon), and hypergravity) on the growth and morphology of Wolffia globosa, assessing its potential for space-based food production.
methodology: Wolffia globosa plants were subjected to simulated microgravity (using a Random Positioning Machine), simulated partial gravity (Moon, using a modified RPM program), and hypergravity (2g and 4g, using a large-diameter centrifuge). A control group was grown under normal gravity. Plant growth (Relative Growth Rate - RGR, Doubling Time - DT) and morphological traits (frond length, short side length, and their ratio) were measured and compared across treatments using image analysis and statistical methods (ANOVA and Tukey's post-hoc test).
results: Simulated microgravity resulted in a significantly lower RGR compared to the control. Hypergravity treatments showed a trend towards higher RGR, but the difference was not statistically significant. Frond length was greatest in the control group. Simulated microgravity resulted in the most elongated frond shape.
conclusions: Wolffia globosa is responsive to gravitational changes, with its growth and morphological adaptations being influenced by varying gravitational environments. Its adaptability to altered gravity conditions supports its potential use in space agriculture. The loss of gravity-sensing genes in related species may explain its adaptability.
relationships: Wolffia globosa exhibits adaptability to different gravitational conditions, making it a potential candidate for space agriculture. Its growth rate is affected by microgravity, but it still maintains a substantial RGR. Hypergravity may have a positive impact on growth. The morphology of the fronds is also influenced by gravity.
insights: Wolffia globosa's unique characteristics, including rapid growth, high nutrient content, and adaptability to altered gravity, make it a promising candidate for sustainable food production in space. Further research is needed to fully understand the genetic mechanisms underlying its response to gravity and to optimize its cultivation for space applications.

title: EUK-134 ameliorates nNOS¬µ translocation and skeletal muscle fiber atrophy during short-term mechanical unloading.
objective: To investigate the role of redox signaling in neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOSμ) translocation and muscle fiber atrophy resulting from short-term (54 h) hindlimb unloading in rats, using EUK-134, a cell-permeable mimetic of superoxide dismutase and catalase.
methodology: Fischer-344 rats were divided into ambulatory control, hindlimb-unloaded (HU), and hindlimb-unloaded + EUK-134 (HU-EUK) groups. The soleus muscle was analyzed using immunohistochemistry, immunofluorescence, Western immunoblot, and fiber-type analysis. Oxidative stress was assessed via 4-hydroxynonenal (4-HNE) levels. nNOSμ localization, FoxO3a phosphorylation, and Nox2 subunit expression were also evaluated.
results: EUK-134 mitigated unloading-induced muscle fiber atrophy and fiber-type shift from slow to fast. It also abolished nNOSμ translocation from the sarcolemma to the cytosol and mitigated dephosphorylation of FoxO3a. Hindlimb unloading elevated oxidative stress and increased sarcolemmal localization of Nox2 subunits, effects normalized by EUK-134. EUK-134 reduced muscle fiber atrophy primarily in Type I fibers but offered no protection in Type IIa and Type IIb/d fibers.
conclusions: Oxidative stress triggers nNOSμ translocation from the sarcolemma and FoxO3a dephosphorylation as an early event during mechanical unloading. Redox signaling may serve as a biological switch for nNOS to initiate morphological changes in skeletal muscle fibers. EUK-134, by mitigating oxidative stress, can ameliorate these unloading-induced changes.
relationships: Oxidative stress is linked to nNOSμ translocation, which in turn affects FoxO3a dephosphorylation and muscle fiber atrophy. EUK-134, by reducing oxidative stress, prevents nNOSμ translocation and subsequent downstream effects.
insights: nNOSμ translocation and subsequent FoxO3a dephosphorylation are redox-dependent events that play a critical role in the early stages of mechanical unloading-induced muscle atrophy. Targeting redox signaling with antioxidants like EUK-134 may offer a therapeutic strategy to mitigate muscle wasting during disuse.

title: MnSOD Overexpression Reduces Fibrosis and Pro-Apoptotic Signaling in the Aging Mouse Heart
objective: To understand how plants respond and adapt to extraterrestrial conditions, specifically focusing on the effects of light and gravity on plant development in spaceflight and at different gravity levels (micro-g, Mars-g, Earth-g).
methodology: Experiments conducted on the International Space Station (ISS) using the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS) with Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings. Different light regimens (white, red, blue) and gravity levels (microgravity, 0.1g, 0.3g, 0.5g, 0.8g, 1g) were applied. Transcriptomic analyses (RNA-seq), qPCR, confocal and electron microscopy were used to assess gene expression, cellular structure, and auxin distribution.
results: Microgravity disrupts meristematic competence, uncoupling cell proliferation and growth. Red light can partially revert gene reprogramming induced by microgravity. Blue light phototropism reduces gravitational stress. Mars gravity (0.3g) induces positive gravitropism in roots. Transcriptomic analysis reveals differential responses to microgravity and Mars gravity, with red light enhancing adaptive responses. Overexpression of plastid and mitochondrial genome in microgravity.
conclusions: Plants can acclimate/adapt to the space environment, and light (especially red light) can compensate for the lack of gravity. The gravity vector at the surface of Mars is sufficient to induce gravitropism. Mutants with attenuated stress responses may be advantageous for space colonization. Nuclear-organelle communication is altered in microgravity.
relationships: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development. Auxin plays a role in meristematic cell proliferation. Nuclear-organelle communication is crucial for plant adaptation to space environment.
insights: Optimizing plant growth in space requires understanding the interplay between light and gravity. Red light illumination can improve seedling viability in space. The selection of plant varieties for space culture should consider their genotypes and adaptive capabilities. Mars gravity offers a more adaptive environment than microgravity.

title: Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle.
objective: To test the hypothesis that overexpression of MnSOD (Sod2 Tg) would attenuate age-related remodeling in the heart, specifically reducing cardiac oxidative stress, fibrotic markers, and apoptosis.
methodology: Hearts were extracted from young and old wild-type and transgenic mice overexpressing the Sod2 (MnSOD) gene.  Left ventricle MnSOD protein levels, oxidative stress markers, fibrotic markers (collagen-I, TGF-β), and apoptosis markers (Bax, caspase-3 cleavage, TUNEL-positive staining, DNA fragmentation) were measured. Histology, immunofluorescence, oxidative stress marker assays, DNA fragmentation assays, TUNEL staining, and Western immunoblot analysis were performed.
results: MnSOD overexpression reduced oxidative stress (total hydroperoxides, 4-HNE, 8-isoprostane) in the left ventricle. Age-related cardiac remodeling and fibrosis were mitigated with reductions in extramyocyte space, collagen-I, and transforming growth factor-β. Pro-apoptotic markers Bax and caspase-3 cleavage were reduced, and apoptosis was mitigated in MnSOD Tg hearts compared with old wild-type.
conclusions: MnSOD elevation is protective against oxidative stress, fibrosis, and apoptosis in the aging heart.  Exercise-induced upregulation of MnSOD may be cardioprotective against fibrosis and apoptosis.
relationships: MnSOD overexpression attenuates age-induced elevation in extramyocyte space, collagen-I, and TGF-β1-positive staining. MnSOD overexpression protects against age-related increase of pro-apoptotic signaling (Bax, cleaved caspase-3) and apoptosis.
insights: Mitochondrial reactive oxygen species play a role in fibrosis in the aging heart. Part of the mechanism of exercise protection against age-associated fibrosis and remodeling in the aging heart may be attributed to inducibility of MnSOD.

title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise.
objective: To examine the effect of lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary wheel running exercise with caloric restriction on caspase-independent apoptosis in aging skeletal muscle. Also, to determine whether age-associated dysregulation of heat shock proteins is a potential protective mechanism against age-induced elevation of caspase-independent apoptotic signaling in skeletal muscle.
methodology: Male Fischer 344 rats were divided into 4 groups at 11 weeks: ad libitum feeding until 6 months (YAL); fed ad libitum until 24 months old (OAL); 8% caloric restriction to 24 months (OCR); wheel running + 8% caloric restriction to 24 months (OExCR). Nuclear and cytosolic fractions of plantaris muscle were analyzed for EndoG, AIF, HSP27, p-HSP27, HSP70, HSF-1 and HSP90 protein levels using Western immunoblot analysis.
results: Nuclear EndoG levels were significantly higher in OAL than in YAL, while caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction significantly attenuated age-induced increment in nuclear EndoG. HSP27 protein content and phosphorylation were significantly lower in OAL than in YAL, while HSP27 protein content was significantly higher in OCR and OExCR and p-HSP27 was significantly higher in OExCR compared with OAL, respectively. AIF and HSP70 were unaltered by caloric restriction or wheel running with caloric restriction in aging muscle.
conclusions: Caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction attenuate age-associated upregulation of EndoG translocation in the nucleus, potentially involved with HSP27 signaling. HSP27 upregulation and phosphorylation is a prime upstream candidate of caloric restriction- and exercise-induced protection against muscle apoptosis.
relationships: Mild caloric restriction and lifelong voluntary exercise with mild caloric restriction may attenuate muscle apoptosis in caspase-independent manner through EndoG signaling, and HSP27 upregulation and phosphorylation as a prime upstream candidate of caloric restriction- and exercise-induced protection.
insights: Long-term exercise and mild caloric restriction protect against age-related elevation of caspase-independent apoptotic signaling. Phosphorylation of HSP27 may be an upstream mechanism of protection for lifelong exercise against apoptosis and sarcopenia, which afflict aging populations.

title: The impact of SRT2104 on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and loss of muscle mass in hindlimb unloaded rats.
objective: To determine if lifelong mild caloric restriction (CR) and lifelong CR + voluntary wheel running (WR) could ameliorate disruption of membrane scaffolding and signaling proteins during aging, thus maintaining a healthy membrane environment in plantaris muscle fibers.
methodology: Fischer-344 rats were divided into four groups: 24-month old adults fed ad libitum (OAL); 24-month old on 8% caloric restriction (OCR); 24 month old 8% caloric restriction + wheel running (OCRWR); 6-month old sedentary adults fed ad libitum (YAL). Muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA) was quantified following Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining. Localization of dystrophin, α-syntrophin, and nNOS was examined via immunostaining. Protein content of membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, and annexin A2) and Nox2 subunits was measured using Western blot analysis.
results: Aging resulted in discontinuous membrane expression of dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins. Older muscle displayed decreased content of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS). OCR and OCRWR provided significant protection against age-related DGC disruption. Key membrane repair proteins were significantly increased in the OAL plantaris. Lifelong CR and CRWR interventions were effective at maintaining membrane repair proteins near YAL levels. OAL fibers also displayed reduced protein content of NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits. Loss of Nox2 subunits was prevented by lifelong CR and CRWR.
conclusions: Lifelong CR and WR are effective countermeasures against age-related alterations in the myofiber membrane environment. Lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary wheel running are interventions capable of partially preventing the age-associated decrease in plantaris muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA).
relationships: Aging is associated with reduced sarcolemmal integrity, increased sarcolemmal damage, and altered membrane redox environment, all of which are likely associated with the progression of sarcopenia. Lifelong CR and CRWR interventions mitigate the negative age-related alterations, providing a myofiber environment conducive for better overall muscle health and function.
insights: Habitual exercise maintains long-term homeostasis of the lipid membrane environment, linked to preservation of the DGC, and reduction of sarcopenia. The aging membrane environment may be unsuitable for normal response of Nox2 to contractions, whereas lifelong physical activity may act to preserve normal Nox2 complex structure via maintaining a healthy membrane environmental phenotype.

title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: Proof of concept.
objective: To determine if the SIRT1 activator, SRT2104, can rescue mechanical unloading-induced impairments in skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, modulate redox responses, and protect skeletal muscle mass during simulated microgravity.
methodology: Fischer-344 rats were divided into three groups: ambulatory controls (CON), hindlimb-unloaded for 10 days (HU), and hindlimb-unloaded treated with SRT2104 (SIRT). Mitochondrial function in rat gastrocnemius and soleus muscles were evaluated. Oxidative phosphorylation, electron transfer capacities, H2O2 production, and oxidative and antioxidant enzymes were quantified using high-resolution respirometry and colorimetry.
results: SRT2104 reduced integrative proton leak in unloaded gastrocnemius muscles. SRT2104 increased cytochrome c oxidase activity compared to the unloaded gastrocnemius, while citrate synthase trended higher in the SIRT soleus. Intrinsic O2 flux was increased by SRT2104 and FCR leak was reduced in unloaded gastrocnemius muscles. H2O2 flux and concentration increased with SRT2104 intervention, concomitant with an increase in superoxide dismutase in the gastrocnemius. SRT2014 significantly attenuated skeletal muscle atrophy during unloading.
conclusions: SRT2104 protects mitochondrial function in unloaded skeletal muscle, suggesting its potential to support healthy muscle cells in microgravity by promoting necessary energy production in mitochondria.
relationships: Mechanical unloading leads to skeletal muscle atrophy and mitochondrial dysfunction. Elevated ROS production contributes to atrophy. SIRT1 activation can mitigate these effects.
insights: SIRT1 activation preserves mitochondrial function and attenuates skeletal muscle atrophy during mechanical unloading, indicating its potential as a countermeasure against muscle wasting in spaceflight.

title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: proof of concept
objective: To test a bioreactor that uses initiation and cessation of cyclic, tensile strain to induce hypertrophy and atrophy, respectively, in murine skeletal muscle myotubes, simulating conditions of spaceflight and exercise.
methodology: C2C12 mouse lineage myoblasts were cultured and differentiated into myotubes on laminin-coated elastic membranes. Uniaxial cyclic stretch was applied using a StrexCell system (0.75 Hz, 12% strain, 60 min/day). Groups included quiescent controls, cyclic stretch for 2 or 5 days, and 2 days of cyclic stretch followed by 3 days of stretch cessation. Myotube diameter, anabolic markers (talin, Akt phosphorylation), and catabolic markers (IL-1ß, IL6, NF-kappaB p65, FoxO3a phosphorylation) were measured.
results: Cyclic stretch increased myotube diameter and elevated anabolic markers. Cessation of stretch led to decreased myotube diameter, reduced Akt phosphorylation, and increased catabolic/inflammatory markers. Calpain activity increased with cyclic stretch but decreased with stretch cessation. FoxO3a levels were elevated, and the proportion of dephosphorylated FoxO3a was upregulated when cyclic stretch was removed.
conclusions: Uniaxial cyclic stretch can induce myotube hypertrophy, while cessation of stretch induces atrophy, mimicking the effects of increased and decreased mechanical loading, respectively. The StrexCell system is a viable bioreactor for studying spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy and potential countermeasures.
relationships: Cyclic stretch increases anabolic markers (talin, Akt phosphorylation) leading to hypertrophy. Cessation of stretch increases catabolic markers (IL-1ß, IL-6, NF-kappaB p65, FoxO3a) leading to atrophy. Akt and FoxO3a signaling are inversely related, with Akt activation suppressing FoxO3a and vice versa.
insights: The study demonstrates the potential of a uniaxial stretch bioreactor to model skeletal muscle responses to mechanical loading and unloading, providing a valuable tool for spaceflight research and the development of countermeasures against muscle atrophy.

title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
objective: Characterize the microorganisms found in the returned Urine Processor Assembly (UPA) flex lines from the ISS and potentially identify the hosing positions as novel areas of interest for biofilm growth studies in the system.
methodology: Culture-dependent and culture-independent methods were used to identify bacteria and fungi in water samples from UPA95 and UPA115 flex lines. Genomic DNA was extracted, sequenced (Illumina and Nanopore), and analyzed. Environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM) was used to image biofilms. Biofilm assays, bacterial-fungal interaction studies, and hemolysis assays were performed to characterize the isolates.
results: Burkholderia, Paraburkholderia, and Leifsonia were identified. Fungal cultures identified Fusarium and Lecythophora. Hybrid de novo genome analysis identified B. contaminans and P. fungorum. Chromate-resistance gene clusters were identified. ESEM detailed fungal-bacterial biofilms. B. contaminans isolates demonstrated considerable biofilm formation and secondary metabolite gene clusters associated with quorum sensing, biofilm formation, antifungal compounds, and hemolysins.
conclusions: UPA flex lines are a unique ecological niche and novel area of biofilm growth within the Water Recovery System (WRS). Further investigation of these organisms and their resistance profiles will enable engineering controls directed toward biofilm prevention in future space station water systems.
relationships: The study highlights the interactions between bacterial and fungal species within the biofilms, including the production of antifungal compounds by some bacteria to inhibit fungal growth. It also explores the relationship between specific gene clusters and observed phenotypes like biofilm formation and hemolytic activity.
insights: The microbial community within the ISS water system is more diverse than previously understood, with unique adaptations to the space environment, including resistance to chromium. Biofilm formation is a significant concern, and the UPA flex lines represent a novel area for studying these biofilms. The genetic and phenotypic properties of the isolates provide valuable information for designing effective biofilm prevention strategies in future space missions.

title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceﬂight and Artiﬁcial Microgravity
objective: To develop and validate a computational model (CAMDLES) for simulating microbial communities in artificial microgravity devices, focusing on metabolite transport and growth.
methodology: CFD-DEM (Computational Fluid Dynamics-Discrete Element Method) was used to model biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in rotating wall vessel bioreactors (RWVs). Agent-based modeling was incorporated to study inter-species metabolite transport within microbial communities. Simulations were correlated with Monod dynamic parameters to predict relative growth rates.
results: The greatest difference between microgravity and an RWV or 1 g gravity was observed when species co-localized in dense aggregates. The model also investigated the influence of spatial distribution, product yields, and diffusivity on growth. CAMDLES simulations showed that in the low-population stage of metabolite exchange, planktonic growth was favorable. Later, as cross-feeding metabolites accumulated, planktonic growth rates approached a maximum level. Higher growth rates then only occurred when cells aggregated into either a densely packed bioﬁlm or a loose spherical aggregate.
conclusions: CAMDLES provides a framework for novel hypothesis generation and design of biological experiments with RWVs, coupling the effects of RWV size, rotation rate, and mass transport directly to bacterial growth in microbial communities. The model can be used to explore experimental variables and demystify inconsistencies seen in microbial communities between RWVs and microgravity.
relationships: The study focused on the interactions between microbial cells and their environments at relevant spatial scales, particularly the exchange of metabolites between species. The model simulated a community composed of two obligately cross-feeding bacterial species (Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica).
insights: Microgravity-induced alterations in the fluid environment are a major factor in the microbial experience of spaceflight. Computational modeling is needed to investigate how well ground-based microgravity simulation methods replicate that experience. The spatial structure of microbial communities significantly influences their ability to exchange metabolites and grow. RWVs generally amplify the spatial importance of this multispecies microbial community, leading to different aggregation sizes and population ratios.

title: Trimeric structure of (+)-pinoresinol-forming dirigent protein at 1.95 A resolution with three isolated active sites.
objective: To validate the Advanced Plant Habitat (APH) facility on the International Space Station (ISS) and demonstrate its ability to conduct fundamental plant research in microgravity.
methodology: A 7-week hardware validation test was conducted using the APH with Arabidopsis and wheat plants. The APH's ability to control environmental factors (light, humidity, CO2, temperature, and root zone moisture) was examined. Experiment profiles were executed to schedule environmental changes, photographic events, and experimental sequences. Gas exchange measurements were taken to assess canopy photosynthesis and respiration.
results: The APH successfully controlled environmental conditions and grew Arabidopsis and wheat plants in microgravity. The APH was able to measure gas exchange of plants from non-invasive gas exchange measurements. The APH ECS filter system successfully contained plant debris during harvest. The daily canopy photosynthetic rates measured in APH were compared to two wheat canopy photosynthetic experiments. The first is a wheat ground study conducted at a light intensity of 500 µmol m−2 s−1 using High Pressure Sodium (HPS) lamps. The second study is the 2002 PESTO spaceflight experiment conducted in the BPS using Cool White Fluorescent (CWF) lamps at a light intensity of 280 µmol m−2 s−1.
conclusions: The APH facility is fully operational and capable of conducting fundamental plant research in microgravity onboard the ISS. The APH has expanded the capabilities of spaceflight plant growth chambers both in the size of the growth area, the higher light intensities and increased spectral combinations possible, as well as in their ability to collect non-destructive data sets that can be used to measure plant growth during spaceflight.
relationships: The APH builds upon previous plant growth systems like ADVASC and BPS, incorporating lessons learned and improving capabilities. It complements Veggie, another plant growth facility on the ISS, by offering more comprehensive environmental control. The data collected will inform the development of Bioregenerative Life Support Systems (BLSS) for future space missions.
insights: The APH can accommodate two plant species requiring different optimum environmental conditions and with vastly different growth rates. The APH can measure plant responses to CO2 concentration and to light levels using non-destructive gas exchange techniques. The APH has expanded the capabilities of spaceflight plant growth chambers both in the size of the growth area, the higher light intensities and increased spectral combinations possible, as well as in their ability to collect non-destructive data sets that can be used to measure plant growth during spaceflight.

title: Reduced Arogenate Dehydratase Expression: Ramifications for Photosynthesis and Metabolism
objective: To determine the three-dimensional structure of the ()-pinoresinol-forming dirigent protein PsDRR206 and analyze its functional implications.
methodology: X-ray crystallography was used to determine the structure of PsDRR206 at 1.95 Å resolution. Molecular replacement was performed using a homology model. Computational docking studies were conducted to investigate substrate binding.
results: The PsDRR206 protein has a tightly packed trimeric structure with three putative substrate binding sites spatially far apart. Each monomer has an eight-stranded -barrel topology. The structure is similar to allene oxide cyclase (AOC).
conclusions: The trimeric DP structure suggests that each active site is isolated, implying a mechanism where a single active site binds two substrates to form the product. The protein's structure provides insights into stereoselective monolignol radical-radical coupling.
relationships: PsDRR206 shares structural similarities with AOC, suggesting a possible common ancestor. Conserved residues in DPs, but not AOCs, indicate their importance for substrate binding and activity specific to DPs.
insights: The study provides a structural basis for understanding how dirigent proteins control stereoselective phenoxy radical coupling in plants, offering potential targets for manipulating lignan biosynthesis.

title: New insights into lignification via network and multi-omics analyses of arogenate dehydratase knock-out mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana
objective: To investigate the effects of modulating arogenate dehydratase (ADT) activity on photosynthetic parameters and secondary metabolism in Arabidopsis thaliana mutants, and to understand the broader impact on plant metabolism.
methodology: Phenomics analysis was used to monitor photosynthetic performance and growth of wild-type and ADT knockout mutants. Metabolomics analyses using liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry were performed to quantify secondary metabolites. Real-time atmospheric monitoring mass spectrometry was used to evaluate net CO2 uptake rates.  Electrochromic shift measurements were used to measure proton motive force. Starch content was also measured.
results: Reduced ADT activity impaired photosynthetic ATP consumption, leading to increased ATP/ADP ratio, starch overaccumulation, and lower electron transport rates. Flavonoid, phenylpropanoid, lignan, and glucosinolate contents were reduced in ADT mutants, while galactolipids and apocarotenoids increased. No significant difference was found in respiration and carbon fixation rates between wild type and extreme ADT knockout mutants.
conclusions: Altered ADT activity and phenylalanine metabolism have profound effects on secondary metabolites and photosynthesis. Reduced metabolism through phenylalanine impacts photosynthetic electron transport due to impaired recycling of ADP + Pi. Metabolic engineering of lignin biosynthesis could be a viable strategy to improve biofuel crops, but further improvements in ATP consumption are needed.
relationships: Reduced carbon flux into Phe biosynthesis impairs ATP consumption, leading to starch accumulation. Higher starch accumulation is accompanied by lower linear photosynthetic electron flux. Reduced phenylpropanoid biosynthesis leads to reduced consumption of fixed carbon and ATP, impacting electron transport rates.
insights: Modulating ADT activity significantly alters carbon allocation and energy balance within the plant. The study reveals interconnected consequences for photosynthesis and secondary metabolism, suggesting that engineering one pathway alone may not be sufficient for improving certain traits and that further improvements of ATP consumption can be a follow-up approach to make ADT mutants an interesting model for the improvement of, for example, biofuel conversion efficiencies.

title: Functional consequences of radiation-induced oxidative stress in cultured neural stem cells and the brain exposed to charged particle irradiation
objective: Investigate how differential reductions in Arabidopsis arogenate dehydratases (ADTs) perturb overall plant systems biology using multiple Arabidopsis arogenate dehydratase (ADT) knock-out (KO) mutants, with phenotypes having variable lignin levels.
methodology: Integrated multi-omics analyses (metabolome, transcriptome, and proteome) of wild type (WT), single and multiple ADT KO lines were conducted. Transcriptome and proteome data were collapsed into gene ortholog (GO) data. Network analysis of enzymes correlated to stem lignin levels was performed.
results: Network analysis deduced the involvement of novel putative lignin related proteins or processes, including those associated with ribosomes, the spliceosome, mRNA transport, aminoacyl tRNA biosynthesis, and phosphorylation. Significant changes were detected in glucosinolate, α-linolenic acid, nitrogen, carotenoid, aromatic amino acid, phenylpropanoid, and photosynthesis-related metabolic pathways in ADT KO mutants. Putative carotenoid and galactolipid levels were generally increased, whereas many glucosinolates and phenylpropanoids were decreased in the KO mutants.
conclusions: Lignin biosynthesis regulation involves additional post-transcriptional and translational level processes. The findings identify new protein targets for further biochemical analysis and/or plant bioengineering, leading to more accurate depictions of lignin/phenylpropanoid biosynthesis models. Vascular plant lignin levels are not only controlled at the point of transcription but work together with modulating factors at a post-transcriptional and translational level.
relationships: There are strong ties between glucosinolates and phenylpropanoids, with lignin being synthesized in the phenylpropanoid pathway. Phytohormone indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), synthesized from Trp, can affect changes in growth, development and metabolism. Jasmonic acid (JA) levels have a strong relationship to lignin levels. JA-isoleucine and ROS production could form a negative feedback loop which can then repress each other’s production and influence lignin accumulation.
insights: ADT mRNA expression between ADT3, ADT4, and ADT5 seemed to be coordinated, as remaining ADTs in the ADT3/ADT4/ADT5 subgroup increased when other subgroup members were knocked out. Lignin levels may be in part regulated by a ribosome filter or “ribocode.” Lignin biosynthesis regulation may be associated with presence of specific ribosomal subunits involved in translation of lignin-biosynthesis-associated mRNA.

title: Exploration of space to achieve scientific breakthroughs
objective: To investigate the effects of low-dose charged particle irradiation on oxidative stress in neural stem and precursor cells and its correlation with cognitive impairment.
methodology: In vitro: Neural stem cells were exposed to low doses of charged particles (Fe ions). Oxidative stress was measured by quantifying reactive oxygen and nitrogen species (ROS/RNS) using fluorescent dyes. Cell survival and sphere formation were also assessed. In vivo: Mice were exposed to whole-body irradiation (c-irradiation or charged particles). Antioxidant levels and enzyme activities in the brain were measured. Cognitive function was assessed using novel object recognition (NOR) and Morris Water Maze (MWM) tests.
results: Low doses of charged particles caused acute and persistent oxidative stress in neural stem cells. Increased ROS/RNS levels were observed. Whole-body irradiation triggered a compensatory antioxidant response in the rodent brain. Low-dose irradiation impaired novel object recognition in mice.
conclusions: Exposure to low doses of charged particles causes persistent oxidative stress and cognitive impairment. Astronauts subjected to space radiation may develop a heightened risk for mission-critical performance decrements and long-term neurocognitive sequelae.
relationships: Oxidative stress is linked to cognitive impairment following exposure to charged particles. The study suggests a temporal coincidence between radiation-induced oxidative stress and cognitive dysfunction, indicating a potential link between altered redox metabolism in the central nervous system and functional behavioral outcomes.
insights: Even low fluences of charged particles can induce lasting changes in the redox state of neural stem cells, potentially impacting cognitive health. The study highlights the importance of considering the long-term neurological risks associated with space travel.

title: The Last Mile in Beta-Cell Replacement Therapy for Type 1 Diabetes: Time to Grow Up
objective: To address the challenges in scaling up beta cell replacement therapy for type 1 diabetes to make it widely accessible and economically feasible.
methodology: The paper uses an analogy to space exploration and the Quality by Design (QbD) framework to highlight the complexities of translating scientific breakthroughs into practical solutions. It emphasizes a patient-centered approach and considers scalability, administration, and interaction with the patient.
results: Islet transplantation has shown success in restoring insulin production, but it is limited by donor scarcity and immune rejection. Stem cell-derived beta-like cells show promise, but scaling up production and ensuring accessibility remain challenges. Gene and cell therapies for rare diseases have faced issues with unsustainable pricing.
conclusions: Beta cell replacement therapy needs a strategic shift towards scalability, accessibility, and economic feasibility. A Quality by Design approach, focusing on practical implementation and patient-centered design, is crucial. Collaboration between academic centers and the pharmaceutical industry is essential for broader dissemination.
relationships: The paper draws parallels between space exploration and biomedical research, highlighting the need for a unified, coordinated strategy. It also discusses the importance of regulatory alignment and economic sustainability in making cell-based therapies widely accessible.

title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
objective: Identify genes that show transcriptional abundance under the influence of spaceflight microgravity, particularly those influencing root growth and cell wall biosynthesis.
methodology: Mining GeneLab datasets (GLDS-7 and GLDS-120) for Arabidopsis thaliana transcriptomic data. Using graph-theoretic approaches (LASSO, Pearson correlation, and HITS algorithm) to infer gene regulatory networks (GRNs). Performing spectral analyses to reveal properties of spaceflight microgravity networks for different ecotypes.
results: Identification of hub genes significantly altered in spaceflight microgravity, mainly involved in cell wall synthesis, protein transport, response to auxin, stress responses, and catabolic processes. Network analysis highlighted five important root growth-regulating hub genes with the highest outdegree distribution in spaceflight microgravity networks. Genes encoding nucleotide-diphospho-sugar interconversion enzymes (NSE) showed higher transcriptional regulation in spaceflight microgravity and are involved in cell wall biosynthesis.
conclusions: Spaceflight microgravity induces unique transcriptional responses in Arabidopsis thaliana, particularly in genes related to cell wall biosynthesis and root growth.  Specific hub genes and metabolic phenotypes are identified that contribute to the plant's adaptation to the altered space environment. The WS ecotype in spaceflight has the highest transcriptional cost.
relationships: Identified regulatory relationships between hub genes and target genes in spaceflight microgravity, focusing on root growth and cell wall biosynthesis.  The study also compares gene expression patterns between different Arabidopsis ecotypes (WS, Col-0, and phyD mutant) under spaceflight and ground conditions.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying plant adaptation to spaceflight, particularly the role of specific genes and metabolic pathways in root growth and cell wall remodeling.  The findings suggest that manipulating certain genes can improve plant adaptation to spaceflight environments.

title: The Effect of spaceflight on mouse olfactory bulb volume, neurogenesis, and cell death indicates the protective effect of novel environment.
objective: To evaluate the impact of spaceflight on olfactory bulb (OB) volume and neurogenesis in mice, comparing mice flown on the Space Shuttle Atlantis with Earth-based control groups.
methodology: Female mice were divided into three groups: Vivarium (standard housing on Earth), AEM-Ground (housed in animal enclosure modules mimicking flight conditions on Earth), and AEM-Flight (housed in AEMs onboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis for 13 days). OB volume was measured using the Cavalieri method. Neurogenesis was assessed by quantifying doublecortin (DCX+) cells, and cell death was assessed by quantifying activated caspase-3 (AC3+) cells via immunohistochemistry and stereological methods.
results: AEM-Ground mice exhibited significantly larger OB volume, particularly in the granule cell layer (GCL) and glomerular layer (GL), and increased neurogenesis (more DCX+ cells) compared to Vivarium mice. AEM-Flight mice did not show this increase; their OB volume and neurogenesis were similar to Vivarium mice. AEM-Flight mice also showed a trend towards increased apoptosis (more AC3+ cells) compared to AEM-Ground mice. When accounting for OB subregional volume, AEM-Ground mice had significantly less apoptosis relative to Vivarium and/or AEM-Flight mice.
conclusions: The novel sensory environment provided by AEMs on Earth appears to promote OB volume and neurogenesis in mice by enhancing cell survival. Spaceflight seems to negate these positive effects, suggesting that factors present during space travel have opposing effects on OB size and neurogenesis. This indicates a potential strategy to preserve OB structure and function during future space missions.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between environmental factors (novel sensory input), neurogenesis, and cell survival in the olfactory bulb. It also reveals a complex interaction between the positive effects of a novel environment and the potentially negative effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system. The findings suggest that the AEM environment may act as a form of sensory enrichment, promoting cell survival and neurogenesis, while spaceflight conditions counteract these effects.
insights: The study provides insights into the plasticity of the olfactory bulb in response to environmental stimuli and the potential impact of spaceflight on brain structure and function. It suggests that providing a novel sensory environment during space missions could be a therapeutic strategy to counteract the negative effects of space travel on the CNS. Further research is needed to understand the specific factors involved and to assess the functional consequences of these changes.

title: Effects of low-dose rate Œ≥-irradiation combined with simulated microgravity on markers of oxidative stress, DNA methylation potential, and remodeling in the mouse heart
objective: Analyze the effects of low LET radiation on Arabidopsis found in low Earth orbit and the effects of two different types of IR on Arabidopsis: gamma photons and relativistic Fe nuclei.
methodology: Datasets from the GeneLab repository are mined. Gene regulatory network inferencing is performed using Pearson correlation. Causal relations are discovered using the Incremental Association Markov Blanket (IAMB) method. Network measures including spectral gap, girth, density, connected components, and Jaccard similarity are computed. Logistic regression is used for gene ranking.
results: Identified key gene players for cell wall biosynthesis and root growth in Arabidopsis in spaceflight.  Identified radiation-induced ATR/ATM hub genes in subnetworks. Detected genes significantly altered due to other spaceflight parameters that are not correlated with ATR/ATM genes. Flavonoid biosynthesis and carotene catabolic processes were identified.  The spectral gap measures are much higher for the HZE and γR subnetworks. The Jaccard similarity indices show the neighborhood similarity of radiation-induced ATR/ATM hub-genes.
conclusions: The DDR processes are intermixed with the regulation of critical functions necessary for the plant to adapt to the spaceflight environment. There is a significant difference in the regulation of these processes in a low radiation dose environment where ATR/ATM radiation-induced genes interact with many downstream genes, whereas in the very high HZE and γR radiation dose environment, the DDR processes are regulated chiefly by ATR/ATM genes.
relationships: Identified causal relationships between ATR/ATM radiation-induced genes and non-radiation-induced genes.  The MB causal relational subnetworks show the ATR/ATM genes related with genes that regulate root development, and plant growth, indicating that increased radiation tolerance by genetic activations may have a side effect on the plant growth.
insights: ATR/ATM radiation-induced genes respond to DNA damage and/or ionizing radiation in concert with non-radiation-induced genes that respond to other environmental stressors such as ROS, salt, light, heat, and water changes in spaceflight. Increased radiation tolerance by genetic activations may have undesired side-effects such as reduced yield.

title: Characterization of mouse ocular response to a 35-day spaceflight mission: Evidence of blood-retinal barrier disruption and ocular adaptations.
objective: To evaluate the impact of simulated microgravity and low-dose/dose-rate γ-irradiation on cardiac tissue, specifically assessing markers of oxidative stress, DNA methylation, inflammatory cell infiltration, and remodeling.
methodology: Female mice were exposed to hindlimb unloading (HU) to simulate microgravity, low-dose-rate γ-irradiation, or a combination of both for 21 days. Cardiac tissue was collected at 7 days, 1 month, 4 months, and 9 months post-exposure. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was used to measure oxidative stress and methylation markers. Immunoblot analysis was performed to determine protein content. Histology was used to assess inflammatory cell infiltration and collagen deposition. Real-time PCR was used to assess mRNA expression.
results: The combination of HU and γ-irradiation demonstrated the strongest increase in reduced to oxidized glutathione ratios 7 days and 1 month after treatment, but a difference was no longer apparent after 9 months. Inflammatory marker, CD-2 protein content was significantly decreased in all groups 4 months after treatment. No significant differences were observed in α-smooth muscle cell actin protein content, collagen type III protein content or % total collagen.
conclusions: Exposure to simulated microgravity and low-dose rate radiation decreases methylation potential of the heart. The hearts had mostly recovered from these two experimental conditions at late observation time points. Further research is needed with larger numbers of animals for a more robust statistical power to fully characterize the early and late effects of simulated microgravity combined with exposure to low-dose rate ionizing radiation on the heart.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between exposure to simulated microgravity and low-dose rate radiation, and decreased methylation potential and oxidative stress in the heart. The combined exposure to both factors appears to have a greater effect than either insult alone in the short term. There is also a relationship between the treatments and a decrease in T-lymphocyte infiltration.
insights: The heart may be more susceptible to oxidative insults and changes in methylation potential following exposure to simulated microgravity and low-dose rate radiation. The effects appear to be temporary, with the heart showing signs of recovery over time. The study highlights the need for further research to fully understand the long-term effects of space travel on cardiovascular health.

title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae.
objective: To characterize the effects of spaceflight on retinal vascular alterations and blood-retinal barrier (BRB) integrity, and to identify changes in protein expression profiles in mouse ocular tissue following spaceflight.
methodology: Ten-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 35 days. Intraocular pressure (IOP) was measured before and after the flight. Ocular tissues were collected for immunohistochemistry (IHC) and proteomics analysis. TUNEL assay was used to assess apoptosis. Expression of proteins related to BRB integrity (AQP-4, PECAM-1, ZO-1) was evaluated. Proteomics analysis was performed using LC/MS on an Orbitrap Fusion Tribrid mass spectrometer. Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) was used to identify significantly affected canonical pathways.
results: IOP was significantly lower in post-flight measurements in one eye. Apoptosis was significantly higher in the retina and retinal vascular endothelial cells of flight mice. Increased expression of AQP-4 and PECAM-1, and a tendency for decreased expression of ZO-1 were observed in flight mice. Proteomics analysis identified 485 significantly differentiated proteins, with alterations in pathways related to cell death, adhesion junction/tight junction signaling, calcium signaling, mitochondrial function, and metabolism.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells and photoreceptors, and alters the expression of proteins related to BRB integrity, suggesting a disruption of barrier function. Changes in protein expression profiles indicate that spaceflight induces changes in cellular organization, cell cycle, mitochondrial function, circadian clock, and oxidative stress in the retina. These findings suggest that astronauts may be at risk for retinal damage and late degeneration.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced changes in the retina are similar to those observed in diseases where the BRB is compromised, such as diabetes. The study suggests a link between spaceflight, BRB disruption, and potential ocular impairment. The results also highlight the limitations of using mice to study the effects of spaceflight on bodily function compared to rats, particularly regarding fluid shifts.
insights: The study provides evidence that spaceflight can lead to significant changes in the eye, including damage to the blood-retinal barrier and alterations in protein expression. These changes may contribute to the visual disturbances experienced by astronauts after long-duration spaceflight. Further research is needed to understand the long-term effects of spaceflight on the eye and to develop effective countermeasures to protect astronaut vision.

title: Spaceflight influences gene expression, photoreceptor integrity, and oxidative stress-related damage in the murine retina.
objective: To assess the long-term transcriptional effects of simulated spaceflight conditions (microgravity and low-dose γ-ray irradiation) on the mouse brain, focusing on gene expression and epigenetic modifications during readaptation.
methodology: Mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HLU) to simulate microgravity and/or low-dose γ-ray irradiation (LDR) for 21 days, followed by a 4-month readaptation period. Brain samples were analyzed using RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS) to identify changes in gene expression and promoter methylation.
results: Minimal gene expression and cytosine methylation alterations were observed after 4 months of readaptation in single treatment conditions (HLU or LDR). However, combined HLU+LDR exposure resulted in altered pathways involved in neurogenesis, neuroplasticity, neuropeptide regulation, and cellular signaling.
conclusions: Neurological readaptation following combined chronic LDR and HLU is a dynamic process involving pathways that regulate neuronal function and structure, potentially leading to late-onset neurological sequelae. Exposure to spaceflight-like conditions may lead to mild, long-term neurological consequences, while readaptation is an active process involving neuroplasticity and repair.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between simulated spaceflight conditions, gene expression changes in the brain, and potential long-term neurological effects. It also explores the interplay between microgravity and radiation exposure in inducing these changes.
insights: The combination of simulated microgravity and low-dose radiation has a more significant impact on brain gene expression than either condition alone. Readaptation involves active neuroplasticity and repair processes, suggesting potential targets for mitigating neurological risks associated with spaceflight.

title: Evaluating ocular response in the retina and optic nerve head after single and fractionated high-energy protons
objective: To determine whether spaceflight alters gene expression profiles and induces oxidative damage in the retina of mice exposed to the space environment for 35 days aboard the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Adult male mice were flown aboard the ISS for 35 days. Ground control mice were maintained on Earth under identical conditions. Ocular tissues were collected for analysis. RNA sequencing, immunofluorescence assays, and micro-computed tomography (MicroCT) were performed to analyze gene expression, protein levels, retinal structure, and oxidative stress.
results: Spaceflight caused changes in gene expression related to visual and RNA regulation pathways. Genes associated with retinitis pigmentosa were differentially expressed. Differentially expressed transcription factors hinted at changes in chromatin organization. Retinal tissue thickness decreased, and oxidative stress and cone photoreceptor damage increased after spaceflight.
conclusions: The space environment induces a distinct gene expression signature in the retina, enriched for genes related to visual perception, RNA processing, and responses to the space environment. Spaceflight may create unique epigenetic events and differential RNA splicing, leading to retinal damage and potentially accelerating retinal degeneration. Compensatory mechanisms are activated in response to oxidative stress, and the circadian rhythm of the retina is altered.
relationships: Spaceflight induces oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in the retina, similar to the Earth-analog disease retinitis pigmentosa. Changes in chromatin architecture during spaceflight can influence the accessibility of genes and regulatory elements in the genome, potentially driving changes in gene expression and cellular behavior.
insights: Long duration space missions require evaluation of compensatory mechanisms and countermeasures to mitigate retinal damage caused by spaceflight. Supplementation with certain minerals and vitamins, especially vitamin A, may delay disease progression. Further research is needed to understand the mechanism of spaceflight-induced oxidative stress on retinal damage and to separate disease-causing changes in gene expression from compensatory changes.

title: Characterization of gene expression profiles in the mouse brain after 35 days of spaceflight mission.
objective: To investigate the effects of whole-body high-energy proton exposure at a single dose on apoptosis, oxidative stress, and blood-retina barrier (BRB) integrity in the retina and optic nerve head (ONH) region, and to compare these radiation-induced effects with those produced by fractionated doses.
methodology: Six-month-old C57BL/6 male mice were either sham irradiated or received whole-body high energy proton irradiation at an acute single dose of 0.5 Gy or 12 equal dose fractions for a total dose of 0.5 Gy over twenty-five days. At four months following irradiation, mice were euthanized and ocular tissues were collected for histochemical analysis, including TUNEL assay, immunostaining for 4-Hydroxynonenal (4-HNE), Aquaporin-4 (AQP-4), Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule (PECAM-1), and Zonula Occludens-1 (ZO-1).
results: Significant increases in the number of apoptotic cells were documented in the mouse retinas and ONHs that received proton radiation with a single or fractionated dose. Enhanced immunoreactivity for oxidative biomarker, 4-HNE, was observed in the retina and ONH following single or fractionated protons, with more pronounced changes observed with a single dose of 0.5 Gy. A significantly increased expression of AQP-4 was observed in the retina following a single dose exposure compared to controls. There was also a significant increase in the expression of PECAM-1 and a decrease in the expression of ZO-1 in the retina.
conclusions: Exposure to proton radiation of 0.5 Gy induced oxidative stress-associated apoptosis in the retina and ONH, and changes in BRB integrity in the retina. The study also revealed differences in BRB biomarker distribution between these two regions, suggesting that the cellular response in the retina and ONH may be differentially regulated in acute or hyperfractionated dose schedules.
relationships: Proton radiation induces oxidative stress and apoptosis, leading to changes in BRB integrity. Single and fractionated doses have differential effects on these parameters in the retina and ONH.
insights: Low-dose proton radiation can induce significant changes in oxidative stress, apoptosis, and BRB integrity biomarkers in the mouse retina. The ONH may be more susceptible to radiation-induced damage due to its distinct BRB properties compared to the retina.

title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity.
objective: To characterize changes in gene expression in mouse brain tissue after spaceflight, focusing on inflammation, neuronal function, growth, metabolism, and stress responses.
methodology: Ten-week-old male C57BL/6 mice were flown to the International Space Station for 35 days. Brain tissues were collected post-flight and analyzed using NanoString technology to evaluate gene expression profiles. Differentially expressed genes and affected pathways were identified using statistical analysis.
results: Significant changes in gene expression were observed in flight mice compared to ground controls. Genes related to neuronal function, neuronal cell support, immune function, and cellular growth/stress were significantly altered. Pathways associated with cellular stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and metabolism were also affected. Downregulation of genes important for oligodendrocyte differentiation and myelin sheath maintenance was observed. Immune reactions were significantly altered, potentially impacting neuronal function.
conclusions: Exposure to the spaceflight environment induces significant changes in gene expression and signaling pathways related to neuronal function, immune regulation, growth, and metabolic function. Dysregulation of inflammatory responses, T-cell responses, and microglia signaling may impact brain structure and function, potentially leading to chronic neuroinflammation.
relationships: Spaceflight conditions (microgravity, radiation) induce neuroinflammation, affecting neuronal function and immune response. Altered gene expression impacts pathways related to cellular stress, apoptosis, and metabolism. Downregulation of genes for oligodendrocyte differentiation and myelin maintenance suggests potential long-term neurodegeneration.
insights: Spaceflight-induced neuroinflammation involves complex interactions between neuronal function, immune response, and cellular stress pathways. The observed gene expression changes suggest potential long-term effects on brain morphology and organism behavior. Further research is needed to investigate the specific brain regions and cell types affected by spaceflight conditions.

title: Evidence of spaceflight-induced adverse effects on photoreceptors and retinal function in the mouse eye.
objective: To understand the longitudinal effects and underlying mechanisms of low-dose ionizing radiation (IR) exposure and hindlimb unloading (HLU; an analog for microgravity) on the murine retina.
methodology: Multi-omics analysis of a NASA GeneLab dataset. Mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading and/or gamma irradiation for 21 days, followed by retinal analysis at 7 days, 1 month, or 4 months post-exposure. Transcriptomic (RNA-seq) and epigenomic (RRBS) retinal profiles were compared to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs) and differentially methylated loci/regions (DML/DMRs). Biological processes were analyzed using GSEA and ORA.
results: Significant differential expression was identified in eight out of nine comparisons between experimental groups and controls. The number of DEGs peaked at 7 days for HLU or IR alone and at 1 month for HLU+IR. Nine DEG were common between the HLU-only and IR-only groups at 7 days. The 1-month HLU + IR group showed the highest total number of DML and DMR. Hypermethylation was more frequent than hypomethylation in all exposure groups. 23 genes showed changes in expression and methylation.
conclusions: Spaceflight hazard analogs (radiation and microgravity) induce changes in gene expression and DNA methylation in the murine retina, impacting biological processes related to retinal function and potentially ocular health. Wnt signaling pathway is perturbed. Murine models can provide an understanding of molecular mechanisms and pathways contributing to ocular function as a response to analogs for spaceflight stressors.
relationships: Identified genes and biological processes shared or exclusive to different exposure conditions (HLU, IR, HLU+IR) and post-exposure time points (7 days, 1 month, 4 months). Highlighted the interplay between radiation and microgravity analogs on retinal response. Compared results with the NASA Twins Study, finding discordance in Notch3 and Lrg1.
insights: The study suggests that combined stressors (radiation and microgravity) can induce complex retinal responses, further regulated by factors such as radiation type, post-exposure duration, and tissue type. The findings provide a basis for developing mitigation strategies to reduce spaceflight-related ocular health risks.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the brain
objective: To characterize acute oxidative damage in ocular structure and retinal function after exposure to spaceflight, and to evaluate the efficacy of an antioxidant in reducing spaceflight-induced changes in the retina.
methodology: Ten-week-old adult C57BL/6 male mice were flown aboard the ISS on Space-X 24 over 35 days. Mice received weekly injections of a superoxide dismutase mimic (BuOE). Ground control mice were maintained on Earth under identical conditions. Intraocular pressure (IOP) and retinal function (ERG) were measured before and after the flight. Immunoﬂuorescence evaluation was used to assess retinal oxidative stress and apoptotic cell death.
results: Spaceflight induced oxidative stress in the retina and apoptotic cell death. ERG data showed decreased amplitudes of a- and b-waves compared to ground controls, indicating impaired photoreceptor and retinal function. Body weights were similar among flight groups before launch and after splashdown, but habitat control groups gained weight post-flight.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions induce oxidative stress in the retina, leading to photoreceptor cell damage and retinal function impairment. Antioxidant treatment (BuOE) showed some protective effects by decreasing the level of the oxidative stress biomarker, but did not fully mitigate the spaceflight-induced retinal functional change.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced oxidative stress is related to photoreceptor damage and retinal function impairment. Increased oxidative damage correlates with abnormal ERG recordings. Apoptotic mechanisms are involved in retinal cell death.
insights: Spaceflight has adverse effects on retinal health, potentially leading to long-term vision problems for astronauts. Antioxidant countermeasures may offer partial protection, but further research is needed to fully understand and mitigate these risks.

title: Routine omics collection is a golden opportunity for European human research in space and analog environments.
objective: To investigate the influence of gravity on position sense using different measurement methods (two-arm matching, one-arm pointing, and one-arm repositioning) during parabolic flight.
methodology: Twelve participants performed three position sense tasks (two-arm matching, one-arm pointing, and one-arm repositioning) during parabolic flights, which induced periods of hypergravity (1.8G), microgravity (0G), and normal gravity (1G).  Arm position errors were recorded and analyzed using repeated measures ANOVA.
results: For matching, errors increased significantly in hypergravity and decreased in microgravity compared to normal gravity. For pointing, errors also increased significantly in hypergravity, but the decrease in microgravity was not significant. Repositioning showed no significant changes in errors across different gravity conditions. Pointing errors were generally larger than matching errors.
conclusions: Gravity influences position sense when measured by matching or pointing, but not by repositioning. This suggests that different methods of measuring position sense rely on different underlying mechanisms. Matching and pointing rely on muscle spindles, while repositioning relies more on central processing.
relationships: Muscle spindle activity is linked to gravity-dependent changes in position sense. Joint torque influences the joint receptor component of the position signal. Central processing plays a significant role in position sense, particularly in repositioning tasks.
insights: Different methods of measuring position sense involve fundamentally different underlying processes.  Position sense relies on both peripheral afferent signals and a central repository of spatial information.  The study highlights the importance of specifying the measurement method used when studying position sense, especially in altered gravity conditions.

title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level.
objective: To consider the practicality and scientific return of different sampling methods and omic types in the context of human spaceflight and analog environments. To appraise ethical and legal considerations pertinent to omics data derived from European astronauts and spaceflight participants (SFPs).
methodology: Review and analysis of existing literature, consideration of sampling methods, omic data types, ethical and legal challenges, and discussion of potential solutions for a routine omics collection program.
results: Identified key considerations for implementing a routine omics program, including AI readiness of data, selection of omic assays, sampling time points, and ethical/legal challenges. Proposed solutions for data storage, sharing, and processing.
conclusions: Routine application of multiomics approaches to European human subjects in spaceflight and analog environments presents a golden opportunity to improve understanding of health in space, risk quantification, and occupational health through personalized medicine approaches. European consensus is needed on data storage, datasets to collect, and enabling open science while protecting personal data.
relationships: Explores the relationships between omic data, physiological changes, and environmental factors in spaceflight. Discusses the potential for correlating omic-derived molecular changes with performance metrics to uncover molecular drivers of physiological change.
insights: A routine omics collection program could elucidate key molecular drivers behind spaceflight health issues, leading to improved risk quantification and approaches to spaceflight occupational health. Pre-flight genomic screening holds potential in developing personalized medicine approaches to risk assessment and countermeasures. Discoveries obtained using human-research-derived omics data could benefit health on Earth.

title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of Naganishia kalamii sp. nov. and Cystobasidium onofrii sp. nov. from Mars 2020 mission assembly facilities.
objective: To review the current and prospective landscape of single-cell to subcellular resolution spatial omics technologies and analysis tools for research and clinical applications, focusing on technologies enabling investigation of cells at the cellular and subcellular level (less than 10 μm).
methodology: The review covers targeted (probe- or antibody-based) and transcriptome-wide (NGS-based) spatial omics approaches, including microscopy and NGS platforms. It discusses multiplexed RNA FISH methods using spectral and temporal barcoding. It also examines spatial barcoding methods and emerging approaches in spatial genomics, metabolomics, metagenomics, and epigenomics.
results: The review highlights available technologies that allow subcellular capture of molecular entities in cells, as well as their technical specifications. It also shows that spatial omics technologies enable a deeper understanding of cellular organizations and interactions within a tissue of interest.
conclusions: Spatial omics technologies have matured, providing a deeper understanding of cellular states and functions. Integration strategies across different molecular classes and the development of analysis packages are crucial for increasing the usage and application of these technologies. The field promises to fuel new discoveries for infectious disease, tumor oncology, and basic science applications.
relationships: Spatial omics technologies enable the study of cell-cell interactions and ligand-receptor analyses, defining neighborhoods or domains of tissue microenvironment. They also allow researchers to locate interactions at the genomics, cellular, and organismal level.
insights: Spatial omics technologies offer unparalleled depth and richness of data, leading to spatially intact single-cell profiles. Developments in probe chemistry, image acquisition, and commercialization are transforming spatial omics technologies into a commonplace technique. Efforts to introduce three-dimensional, deep-slide scanning, and time series data collection will reveal novel cellular architectures and entirely new domains of biology.

title: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts with immune, cfDNA, mitochondrial, and telomere length changes during short duration spaceflight
objective: To characterize two novel yeast species using a polyphasic taxonomic approach and assess their UV-C resistance.
methodology: Colony morphology, microscopic features, and physiological properties were combined with MLSA phylogeny (seven loci) and WGS analysis. UV-C resistance was evaluated by exposing yeast cells to different radiation doses and counting colony-forming units.
results: Naganishia kalamii and Cystobasidium onofrii were identified as novel species. Genomic analysis revealed genes associated with dehydration, desiccation stress-response, and UV resistance. N. onofrii exhibited higher UV-C resistance compared to N. kalamii.
conclusions: NASA cleanrooms can house various microbes, including UV-C resistant yeasts. MLSA and WGS are needed for precise identification. The presence of cold-adapted yeasts in SAFs has implications for future missions to icy moons. Genomic analysis reveals potential for survival in harsh conditions.
relationships: Naganishia kalamii is closely related to N. albida, while Cystobasidium onofrii is distantly related to C. benthicum.
insights: The study underscores the extreme, oligotrophic conditions of meticulously maintained NASA cleanrooms, which could potentially house various microbes, including significant yeast species. Traditional yeast identification methods are deemed inadequate, highlighting the need for more precise techniques like MLSA and WGS, particularly for complex genera like Naganishia.

title: Molecular and physiologic changes in the SpaceX Inspiration4 civilian crew
objective: To guide researchers on accessing and analyzing SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission data in the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) to understand the impact of commercial space travel on human physiology.
methodology: The study uses multi-modal, longitudinal assessments of biological measurements from four civilian astronauts during the I4 mission. It leverages data from omics and clinical assays available in the NASA OSDR, accessed programmatically through GLOpenAPI. The data includes direct RNA sequencing, single nuclei ATAC-seq and RNA-seq, metagenomics/metatranscriptomics, spatial transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolic and immune panels, and clinical blood profiling.
results: Analyses of the I4 mission data have revealed insights into the interplay between space stressors and the immune system, cell-specific responses to spaceflight, rapid microbial interchange among the crew, and changes in the skin of astronauts. The data also allows for comparison of human spaceflight effects to those previously characterized in model organisms.
conclusions: The I4 mission data provides a valuable resource for understanding the effects of spaceflight on the human body. Open access to these datasets in the NASA OSDR enables the scientific community to further investigate the consequences of space travel on human health. This work sets a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs and informs future mission planning and health risk mitigation strategies.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight stressors and various biological responses in the human body, including immune system changes, cell-specific adaptations, and microbial interactions. It also emphasizes the connection between omics data and clinically significant endpoints derived from medical data.
insights: The integration of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the analysis of biomedical data from the I4 mission holds great promise for uncovering patterns, correlations, and anomalies that might otherwise remain hidden. Standardized data formats and comprehensive metadata fields are crucial for seamless integration of new data types and cross-study biological analyses.

title: Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to spaceflight and high-altitude climbing
objective: To evaluate the feasibility of collecting biological and behavioral data from a civilian crew during spaceflight, examine their responses to short-duration orbital spaceflight, and build a biomedical database.
methodology: Multi-omic profiling (WGS, RNA sequencing, proteomics, metabolomics, etc.) of blood, saliva, skin samples collected pre-flight, in-flight, and post-flight.  Point-of-care vertical flow immunoassay (VFI) for IgM and CRP. Handheld ultrasound imaging of bladder, jugular vein, and eye.  Cognitive tests and mood surveys.  Ocular misalignment measurements.
results: Broad molecular changes observed across multiple biological layers, including epigenetic changes, telomere elongation, and immune signaling changes. Viral reactivation was detected.  Point-of-care VFI showed operational robustness in space, but reagent stability was affected. Ultrasound imaging showed no jugular vein flow anomalies.  Ocular misalignment patterns differed between astronauts who experienced space motion sickness and those who did not.  Cognitive performance was largely unaffected, though some slowing was observed.  Heart rate and heart rate variability changes were noted.
conclusions: Short-duration spaceflight induces similar biological signatures as long-duration flights. Civilian crews can conduct scientific experiments in space with minimal risk. Point-of-care diagnostics are feasible but require stable reagents.  Ocular misalignment may be related to space motion sickness.  Cardiovascular and cognitive effects are modest but show inter-individual variability. Data from this mission will serve as a foundation for future space physiology studies.
relationships: The study relates spaceflight to changes in the human body at anatomical, cellular, physiological and cognitive levels. It also relates the findings to previous studies of astronauts in both short- and long-duration spaceflight.
insights: Short-duration civilian spaceflights offer a unique opportunity to study the earliest phases of human adaptation to space.  Multi-omic profiling and point-of-care diagnostics are valuable tools for monitoring astronaut health.  Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms underlying space motion sickness and individual differences in response to spaceflight.

title: Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
objective: Investigate the role of telomeric RNA (TERRA) in the DNA damage response (DDR) induced by spaceflight and radiation, and to understand its involvement in telomere maintenance.
methodology: The study used RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) data from astronauts during spaceflight and high-altitude climbers, in vitro radiation exposure of human U2OS (ALT) cells, simulated microgravity experiments, RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization (RNA-FISH), and a telomere-specific endonuclease targeting system (EN-T).
results: Increased abundance of TERRA transcripts was observed during spaceflight and high-altitude climbing. Simulated microgravity alone did not induce TERRA increases. In vitro, ionizing radiation increased TERRA foci in U2OS cells. The EN-T system confirmed TERRA recruitment to telomeric DSB sites, particularly in G2-phase cells.
conclusions: TERRA plays a role in the telomeric DDR in response to space radiation and oxidative stress. It is recruited to telomeric DSB sites, forming protective TERRA:telomeric DNA hybrids, potentially facilitating homologous recombination-dependent elongation in G2 as a means of restoring functional telomeres.
relationships: TERRA interacts with telomeric DNA to form hybrids, potentially facilitating telomere repair. It also interacts with proteins involved in DNA damage response and recombination.
insights: Spaceflight and high-altitude climbing induce telomere elongation and ALT-like activity, with TERRA playing a role in the telomeric DDR. TERRA may also facilitate repair via increased mobility and/or serving as a scaffold for recruitment of required repair machinery.

title: Longitudinal multi-omics analysis of host microbiome architecture and immune responses during short-term spaceflight
objective: To investigate the impact of short-duration spaceflight on the skin's molecular and physiological characteristics.
methodology: Skin biopsies were collected from Inspiration4 crew members before and after a 3-day mission. Multi-omics assays including spatial transcriptomics, single-cell RNA/ATAC-seq, and metagenomics/metatranscriptomics were performed to assess gene expression, microbial composition, and immune changes across different skin regions.
results: Post-flight samples showed upregulation of genes related to inflammation and KRAS signaling across all skin regions. Specific cellular responses, including altered interferon responses, DNA damage, epithelial barrier disruptions, and T-cell migration, were observed. Microbial shifts in skin swabs and immune cell activity in PBMCs were also linked to epithelial disruption.
conclusions: Short-duration spaceflight induces changes in skin tissue, including inflammation, KRAS signaling activation, epithelial barrier disruption, and immune system modulation. These changes are associated with microbial shifts and may have implications for skin health during space missions.
relationships: Observed relationships between skin gene expression, microbiome composition, and immune cell activity, suggesting a complex interplay between these factors in response to spaceflight.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying skin changes during spaceflight, highlighting the importance of KRAS signaling, immune responses, and microbial interactions. These findings may inform the development of countermeasures to protect astronaut skin health during future space missions.

title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
objective: To characterize the microbiome architecture of short-term spaceflight and its relationship to host immune response.
methodology: Longitudinal, multi-omic (metagenomics, metatranscriptomics, single-cell immunome) sampling study of the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. Analysis included short-read alignment, de novo assembly, and statistical modeling to identify microbial and immune shifts.
results: Significant bacterial, viral, and gene-level microbiome shifts were observed during short-term spaceflight. Native microbiome shifts were highly correlated with host immune changes, particularly in the oral microbiome. Strain sharing occurred between crew members and the spacecraft environment, especially on skin surfaces.
