conclusions: Spaceflight induces shifts in the microbiome that are correlated with changes in the host immune system. These changes may be influenced by factors such as cohabitation, diet, and immune alterations. Further research is needed to determine the causality of microbe-immune associations.
relationships: Identified relationships between host immune cell expression, body site, and microbial features, with oral bacteria showing metatranscriptomic associations across all immune cell types. Viruses in the skin microbiome were associated with natural killer cells and monocytes.
insights: Spaceflight creates a unique environment that alters the human microbiome and its interaction with the immune system. The study provides data and methods to map the axes of host-microbe-environment interaction, which can be tested and modulated in future studies.

title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
objective: To examine the developmental expression of haemoglobin over time and space using multi-omic datasets from NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE study, and the Inspiration4 mission, and to understand the effects of spaceflight on globin gene regulation and erythropoiesis.
methodology: Multi-omic analysis of blood samples from astronauts in the NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE study, and Inspiration4 mission. RNA-seq data was analyzed to assess globin gene expression, transcription factor activity, and miRNA levels. Statistical analyses included DESeq2 for differential expression, PCA for sample separation, and various bioinformatics tools for data processing and visualization.
results: Spaceflight resulted in a downregulation of globin genes, confirming space anaemia. Key erythropoiesis genes were perturbed, with some upregulated and others downregulated. An adult-to-fetal globin switch was observed. Post-flight recovery involved upregulation of globin genes and erythropoiesis-related factors. Specific miRNAs showed altered expression patterns during and after spaceflight.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces an adult-to-fetal globin switch and perturbs erythropoiesis, contributing to space anaemia. The observed changes in gene expression and miRNA levels suggest potential mechanisms for adaptation to the space environment and recovery post-flight. Future studies should directly measure fetal haemoglobin levels to validate these findings.
relationships: Identified relationships between spaceflight, globin gene expression, erythropoiesis, and the adult-to-fetal globin switch. Showed correlations between specific gene expression patterns and the space anaemia phenotype. Linked miRNA expression changes to globin gene regulation and erythropoiesis.
insights: The microgravity environment may elicit mechanisms behind the developmental globin gene switch model. Space anaemia might occur as a combination of direct haemolysis coupled with reduced overall production of new, mature erythroid cells. The study provides insights into potential countermeasures for space anaemia and the broader implications of space omics research.

title: Single-cell analysis identifies conserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
objective: To characterize the immune response in astronauts during spaceflight by generating single-cell, multi-omic, cell-free RNA (cfRNA), biochemical, and hematology data.
methodology: Longitudinal analysis of single-nucleus gene expression (snRNA-seq), chromatin accessibility (snATAC-seq), and single-cell T/B cell antigen receptor sequences from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Integration with clinical profiles, biochemical profiling, FACS, and microbiome changes. Comparison with NASA Twins Study, GeneLab mouse transcriptomes, and simulated microgravity PBMCs.
results: Identified a 'spaceflight signature' of gene expression characterized by enrichment in oxidative phosphorylation, UV response, immune function, and TCF21 pathways. Observed upregulation of FOXP3 in T cells, suppression of MHC class I genes, and infection-related immune pathways associated with microbiome shifts. High elevation spaceflight induces production of cytokine signatures (IL-6, IL-10, ENA-78). CD14 monocytes showed the highest number of DARs and DEGs at R + 1, yet CD4 T and CD8 T cells were the least perturbed.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces conserved and distinct immune disruptions. The data details a roadmap for potential countermeasures to preserve astronaut health. The study highlights the importance of monitoring immune system changes during spaceflight and identifies potential targets for countermeasures.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced immune dysregulation mirrors monocyte dysregulation, infection phenotypes, TCF21, and FOXP3 regulation. Microbiome shifts may drive a portion of the immune response to spaceflight.
insights: Sex-dependent differences exist in response to spaceflight, with males appearing more affected. Radiation is a likely larger driver of cellular responses than microgravity. Potential drugs and supplements were identified that could reverse the effects of spaceflight on the immune system.

title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank
objective: To understand how short-term exposure to simulated microgravity impacts the human peripheral blood mononuclear immune system at single-cell resolution and to identify potential countermeasures.
methodology: Single-cell RNA sequencing of human PBMCs exposed to simulated microgravity using a Rotating Wall Vessel (RWV) with and without TLR7/8 agonist stimulation. Validation experiments included bulk RNA sequencing, meta-transcriptome analysis, NicheNet analysis, super-resolution microscopy, G-LISA assays, ELISA, Luminex assays, and intracellular flow cytometry. Data was compared against datasets from mice and crewmembers in LEO (ISS, Inspiration Four mission, JAXA Cell-Free Epigenome study, and the Twins study). Machine learning was used to identify compounds that map to altered genes.
results: Simulated microgravity alters the transcriptional landscape of immune cells, inducing inflammatory aging-like changes and reactivation of latent viruses. It dampens NK cell and T cell responses while increasing monocyte inflammatory parameters. Multiple pathways are altered, including those related to the cytoskeleton, interferon signaling, pyroptosis, and heat-shock. Active GTP-bound Cdc42 levels are elevated. Both IFNα and IFNγ secretion are reduced with TLR7/8 stimulation. Quercetin can reverse most abnormal pathways.
conclusions: Microgravity alters forces sensed by immune cells, leading to changes in the actin cytoskeleton and nuclear receptor signaling, coupled to changes in core pathways such as mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress. These changes contribute to reduced oxidative phosphorylation and associated basal inflammatory processes, as well as reduced viral sensing pathways, associated reduced interferon responses and altered pyroptosis capability. Quercetin can reverse many of the altered transcriptional signatures elicited by simulated microgravity on the immune system.
relationships: Microgravity induces inflammatory changes in innate immune cells while impairing T cell and NK cell functionality. The cytoskeleton plays a key role in immune dysfunction. Reduced interferon signaling is linked to reactivation of latent viruses. Quercetin can reverse many of the altered transcriptional signatures elicited by simulated microgravity on the immune system.
insights: Short-term simulated microgravity induces aging-like inflammatory changes in immune cells and can trigger latent pathogen activation. The cytoskeleton is a critical orchestrator of immune cell function in microgravity. Quercetin shows promise as a countermeasure to mitigate the adverse effects of microgravity on the immune system.

title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
objective: To create a comprehensive clinical and multi-omic resource from commercial and non-commercial astronaut cohorts to understand the effects of spaceflight on the human body and to accelerate precision aerospace medicine.
methodology: Multi-omic profiling (genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, microbiome) of biospecimens collected from astronauts before, during, and after spaceflight missions (SpaceX Inspiration4, NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE study). Data analysis included differential gene expression analysis, pathway enrichment analysis, and comparisons across missions and cell types.
results: Short-duration spaceflight induces broad-ranging molecular changes, including elevated cytokines, telomere elongation, and gene expression changes related to immune activation, DNA damage response, and oxidative stress.  Many markers return to baseline within months, but some proteins, genes, and cytokines are activated only during the recovery period. Distinct RNA fingerprints of spaceflight were identified, including changes in spatially resolved transcriptomics in skin, cfRNA profiles, and RNA modifications.
conclusions: The study provides a comprehensive resource for understanding the molecular effects of spaceflight on the human body. Short-duration spaceflight results in dynamic molecular changes, with a recovery profile that reverses differential gene expression in key biological pathways. These findings offer insights into health-restoring mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets for mitigating the effects of spaceflight.
relationships: Identified relationships between spaceflight and changes in gene expression, immune response, telomere length, and RNA modifications.  Observed correlations between gene expression and chromatin accessibility.  Found connections between specific pathways and cell types in response to spaceflight.
insights: The study highlights the importance of multi-omic profiling for understanding the complex effects of spaceflight.  It reveals that even short-duration spaceflight can induce significant molecular changes and that the recovery period is characterized by distinct biological processes.  The data suggest potential targets for interventions to mitigate the health risks of spaceflight.

title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
objective: To profile the spaceflight secretome (plasma proteome and metabolome, and EVP proteome) of astronauts before and after a 3-day spaceflight to reveal biological changes.
methodology: Profiling plasma proteins, metabolites, and extracellular vesicles/particles (EVPs) from the SpaceX Inspiration4 crew at three pre-flight and three post-flight timepoints. Differential and pathway enrichment analysis of the proteome and metabolome. Comparison of secretome and transcriptomic profiles from single-nuclei PBMC and whole-blood RNA-seq. Validation using TBARS assay, EVP immune cell marker profiling, Western blots, and ELISA.
results: Significant differences in coagulation, oxidative stress, and brain-enriched proteins were observed. Most EVP DAPs recovered within six months, but plasma DAPs remained perturbed. Proteomic alterations correlated with peripheral blood mononuclear cells. Lipid peroxidation was increased immediately post-flight. Upregulation of antioxidant proteins and altered metabolic profiles were observed in plasma and EVPs.
conclusions: Even short-duration spaceflight can disrupt human physiology, leading to changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation. The study identifies spaceflight biomarkers that can guide countermeasure development. The secretome profiling provides a minimally invasive approach to monitor crew health.
relationships: Oxidative stress and immune dysregulation were commonly observed molecular changes post-flight. Antioxidant enzymes (PRDX1, PRDX2, PRDX6, SOD1, CAT, GCLC) and metabolites (inosine, taurine) were increased post-flight. Immune cell markers were decreased, while anti-inflammatory molecules (inosine, purines, GABA) were increased. Brain-related signatures were increased in the secretome after spaceflight, potentially indicating blood-brain barrier disruption.

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
objective: To propose the development of a human cell atlas under spaceflight environmental conditions as an openly available, global resource for foundational space life science research and to consider the ethical, cultural, and legal challenges intrinsic to human space omics.
methodology: Review and perspective based on existing literature, NASA Twins Study, space omics efforts in Japan, Europe, United States, Canada, China and Russia, and the International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP).
results: Identified potential benefits of precision space healthcare through standardized omics data, including improved safety of human health during long-term spaceflight. Highlighted the importance of understanding drug and micronutrient metabolism in space, and the potential for personalized medicine approaches based on individual genetic predispositions.
conclusions: Routine standardized omics with consenting participants during spaceflight could permit precision space healthcare and a Human Cell Space Atlas. Numerous ethical, cultural, and legal challenges would need to be carefully surmounted from global viewpoints.
relationships: Explored relationships between micronutrients, macronutrients, pharmaceuticals, omics, and various spaceflight environmental factors. Emphasized the need for rigorous standardization of space omics data and metadata to disentangle factors linked to preventable diseases during spaceflight.
insights: Spaceflight induces physiological and molecular changes that may not always be health-related. Precision healthcare in space could be tailored to individual characteristics, promoting the health of diverse participants. Standardized space omics collection and metadata normalization are crucial for successful human space omics discipline.

title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
objective: To identify molecular changes in skin health during spaceflight and develop countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.
methodology: Analysis of murine transcriptomic datasets, biochemical profiles of astronauts, human transcriptomic datasets from blood and hair samples of astronauts, and skin and blood samples from the Inspiration4 mission.  QLattice symbolic regression modeling was used to construct models involving combinations of synergistic genes which map from the gene expressions to spaceflight status.
results: Identified key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation as potential drivers for skin health risks during spaceflight.  Observed alterations in genes associated with skin barrier function and collagen formation.  Found evidence of organism's ability to re-adapt back to Earth via post-flight re-tuning of gene expression.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces gene regulatory changes, mitochondrial dysregulation, and DNA damage in the skin.  The study highlights the potential for developing countermeasures to manage dermatological issues and optimize astronaut performance during future missions.  Exercise countermeasures may improve skin health.
relationships: Identified synergistic effects between pairs of genes, revealing putative disequilibria of dependent processes.  Observed correlations between gene expression changes in rodent skin and astronaut data.
insights: Spaceflight-induced skin issues are linked to changes in genes related to DNA damage, skin barrier health, and mitochondria.  Molecular alterations observed in spaceflown mice and astronaut skin data show similarities with molecular effects associated with drugs like tretinoin and tamoxifen.

title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
objective: To investigate the effects of microgravity and galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) on kidney function and structure during extended space missions.
methodology: Integrated pan-omic analysis (epigenomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, metagenomic), clinical chemistry, and morphometry on samples from spaceflight-exposed mice and humans, simulated microgravity rats, and simulated GCR-exposed mice.
results: Spaceflight induces: increased urinary excretion of metabolites and electrolytes that are risk factors for nephrolithiasis, renal transporter dephosphorylation, nephron remodeling (expansion of distal convoluted tubule size but loss of overall tubule density), and renal damage and dysfunction when exposed to simulated GCR.  Microbiome changes were mixed, with some changes expected to confer a protective profile against nephrolithiasis and others tending to contribute to increased risk.  Pathway analysis showed an over-representation of Aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis and arginine biosynthesis metabolic pathways.
conclusions: Spaceflight, particularly long-duration missions, poses significant risks to kidney health, including increased risk of kidney stone formation, structural remodeling of the nephron, and potential for irreversible renal damage due to GCR exposure. Tubular remodelling in microgravity may be a primary event that causes subsequent dysregulation of serum and urine electrolyte homeostasis.
relationships: Microgravity and GCR synergistically affect bone mineral density loss. Arterial stiffness and CKD are strongly associated, and it is thought that one begets the other in a positive feedback loop.  Spaceflight places the kidney in a position whereby it must choose whether to defend renal perfusion or the health of its microvasculature.
insights: Renal remodelling in microgravity (possibly related to the cephalad fluid shift) may be a primary event that causes subsequent dysregulation of serum and urine electrolyte homeostasis.  The increased risk for nephrolithiasis in space has been historically attributed to the negative impact of microgravity on bone mineral density.  The kidney is a key microvascular end-organ and microvascular disease appears to be one of the main consequences of GCR exposure.

title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
objective: To examine the effects of spaceflight on insulin and estrogen signaling pathways in multiple tissues of rodents and humans.
methodology: Transcriptomic (RNA-seq) and proteomic analyses were performed on tissues from mice flown to the International Space Station (ISS) and on blood and skin samples from astronauts before, during, and after spaceflight. Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) were used to identify affected pathways.
results: Spaceflight induced changes in insulin and estrogen signaling in both rodents and humans. In mice, the liver was the most affected organ, showing inhibition of insulin and estrogen receptor signaling, leading to insulin resistance and hepatic steatosis. Muscle tissue also showed significant changes. In humans, insulin signaling linked genes were dysregulated during and after spaceflight, with alterations in lipid metabolism, hormone regulation, and immune system pathways. Sex differences were observed in skin samples.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters insulin and estrogen signaling pathways, impacting metabolism and potentially leading to comorbidities. Further research is needed to understand the effects on reproductive hormone synthesis and actions, and to develop personalized healthcare strategies for space travel.
relationships: The study highlights the interconnectedness of insulin and estrogen signaling in maintaining metabolic homeostasis and the potential for spaceflight-induced disruptions to these pathways. It also suggests a link between mitochondrial dysfunction and alterations in insulin and estrogen signaling.
insights: The findings suggest that disrupted insulin and estrogen signaling may contribute to hepatic steatosis, muscle atrophy, and other metabolic changes observed during spaceflight. Personalized healthcare strategies, including genomic data analysis, are essential for mitigating these risks in future space missions.

title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: Spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants
objective: To review published alleles naturally found in human cohorts that have a likely protective effect, linked to decreased cancer risk and improved bone, muscular, and cardiovascular health, and to explore how these mechanisms could translate into improved health recommendations for crew members during deep space missions.
methodology: Review of published literature on human alleles with protective effects, focusing on their relevance to aerospace medicine and potential for improving health countermeasures in space. Analysis of omics technologies and their application in mitigating spaceflight-induced physiological deconditioning. Examination of human cohorts, including individuals with rare phenotypes, families with protective attributes, and isolated populations adapted to extreme environments.
results: Identified alleles related to radiation tolerance (TP53), hematopoiesis (EPOR), bone density (LRP5), and immune function (HLA alleles and cytokines) as relevant for spaceflight. Highlighted the potential of omics-based nutrition, exercise, and lifestyle recommendations to optimize health in space. Showed that spaceflight can elicit stressful and adaptive physiological responses, impacting various systems and increasing risks like cancer and bone demineralization.
conclusions: Omics technologies offer a promising component for improving prospective health countermeasures in space. Basic research into the protective mechanisms of identified alleles may translate into improved therapeutic compound discovery and better-informed health recommendations for space explorers and those working in challenging conditions on Earth. Comprehensive aerospace healthcare programs should integrate both omics information and traditional protective measures.
relationships: Identified relationships between specific alleles and protective mechanisms, such as LRP5 mutations leading to high bone density and EPOR mutations increasing oxygen transport capacity. Explored connections between dietary habits, genetic variants, and health outcomes, including the potential of plant polyphenols to activate SIRT1 and counteract space-induced inflammation.
insights: Spaceflight poses unique health challenges, including radiation exposure and microgravity-induced bone demineralization. Omics data analysis can further discover and improve countermeasures by considering individual genetic predispositions. Ethical considerations are crucial in the application of allelic information for optimizing precision healthcare in space, ensuring fairness and avoiding discriminatory practices.

title: Growth chambers on the International Space Station for large plants
objective: To correct an omission in the Acknowledgement section of a previously published article regarding funding support.
methodology: The authors issued a correction to the original article, adding the missing funding information.
results: The Acknowledgement section of the original article was updated to include the US Army Medical Research Command award (W81XWH2110402) that supported L.I.G.
conclusions: The correction ensures the accuracy and completeness of the funding information associated with the research.
relationships: This correction relates to the original publication and its funding sources.
insights: Accurate and complete acknowledgement of funding sources is crucial for transparency and proper attribution in scientific publications.

title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station
objective: To determine whether growing wheat in outer space affects the weight and basic parameters of the grain, and whether this leads to increased asymmetry of the kernel and distortion of the starch composition.
methodology: Wheat kernels of the Super Dwarf cultivar were grown on the International Space Station (ISS) in the Lada growth chamber and compared to control wheat grown in a similar chamber under terrestrial conditions. Kernel parameters (weight, area, length, width, roundness, depth), starch granule characteristics, and aleurone layer cell dimensions were measured and compared. Hyperspectral imaging was used to analyze spectral profiles and calculate NDVI indices.
results: Wheat grown on the ISS had significantly smaller kernels by weight, area, length, and width. The length of type A starch granules in filled kernels from the ISS was significantly longer than in kernels from the ground experiment. The width of the aleurone layer cells in mature kernels from the ISS was significantly smaller. No significant differences in fluctuating asymmetry were found. Hyperspectral analysis showed similar spectral profiles between ISS and ground control kernels.
conclusions: Growing wheat in space resulted in smaller kernels and alterations in starch and aleurone layer composition. The phototropic responses of plants are likely the main factor preventing drastic gravitational responses in space. Further research is needed to optimize growth conditions and select cultivars better adapted to space environments.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between spaceflight conditions (primarily microgravity) and wheat kernel characteristics, including size, shape, starch composition, and aleurone layer structure. It also investigates the correlation between kernel asymmetry and various morphological parameters.
insights: The findings suggest that while wheat can be grown in space, the resulting kernels exhibit some differences compared to those grown on Earth. These differences may be related to stress responses, water availability, or tissue hypoxia during seed formation. Optimizing growth chamber conditions and selecting appropriate cultivars are crucial for improving the quality of space-grown wheat.

title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.
objective: To determine the effects of International Space Station (ISS) and Veggie environmental conditions on the microbiological and nutritional quality of Veggie-grown lettuce intended for crew consumption.
methodology: Red romaine lettuce was grown in Veggie plant growth chambers on the ISS and compared with ground-grown plants under similar environmental conditions. Multiple plantings were grown and harvested using single or sequential harvests. Food safety was determined by heterotrophic plate counts, isolate identification, and molecular characterization using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS). Leaves were analyzed for elemental composition, phenolics, anthocyanins, and Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC). Statistical analysis was performed to compare data.
results: Flight and ground tissues showed some differences in total counts for bacteria and yeast/molds. Bacterial and fungal isolate identification and community characterization indicated variation in the diversity of genera between leaf and root tissue. Flight and ground tissue showed differences in Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn content and total phenolic levels, but no differences in anthocyanin and ORAC levels. No target human pathogens were detected.
conclusions: Leafy vegetable crops can produce safe, edible, fresh food to supplement the astronauts’ diet, and provide baseline data for continual operation of the Veggie plant growth units on ISS. The Outredgeous variety of lettuce grown in Veggie was safe for human consumption from a microbiological perspective. Chemical analysis provided evidence of significant changes in elemental and antioxidant content which may be an important factor to consider for nutritional value in future, long duration, exploration missions.
relationships: The study explores the relationships between space environment, plant growth, microbial communities, and nutritional content of lettuce. It also investigates the interactions between different types of microorganisms and their impact on plant health.
insights: The study provides insights into the feasibility of growing safe and nutritious food in space, the impact of space environment on plant physiology and microbiology, and the potential for using space-grown crops to supplement astronaut diets. It highlights the importance of understanding the complex interactions between plants, microbes, and the environment in space-based agriculture.

title: Auxin: Shape matters.
objective: To identify genetic factors contributing to plant responses to cadaverine by examining natural variation in root length sensitivity to exogenous cadaverine.
methodology: Quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis using Arabidopsis thaliana accessions, recombinant inbred lines (RILs), near-isogenic lines (NILs), microarray analysis, RT-PCR, qRT-PCR, and transgenic complementation.
results: Arabidopsis accessions exhibit varying root length responses to cadaverine. A QTL on chromosome 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine. ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 (OCT1) expression levels correlate with cadaverine sensitivity. oct1-1 mutants show increased cadaverine sensitivity.
conclusions: OCT1 plays a key role in root growth responses to cadaverine. Differences in OCT1 expression contribute to the varying cadaverine root length responses in Cvi and Ler accessions. Other genes likely contribute to the variation in cadaverine sensitivity among Arabidopsis accessions.
relationships: OCT1 expression levels correlate with cadaverine resistance. Reduced OCT1 expression confers increased cadaverine sensitivity. The ability of OCT1 to affect the cadaverine response may depend on the genetic background.
insights: Cadaverine affects Arabidopsis root morphology, and natural variation in this response is partly due to varying expression levels of OCT1. This work contributes to understanding how polyamines contribute to development and mediate stress responses.

title: Gravity signaling in flowering plant roots
objective: Evaluate the effect of a commercial formulation of 2,4-D on the structure of freshwater microbial communities under different exposure conditions using microcosms.
methodology: Manipulative laboratory experiment with microcosms filled with water from clear and organic turbid systems. Microcosms were exposed to seven concentration levels of 2,4-D. Physical, chemical, and biological parameters were analyzed after 7 days. Statistical analyses were performed to determine significant differences.
results: The impact of AsiMax 50® seemed to be greater in the turbid system. Total abundance of living micro + nano phytoplankton showed a significant increase at lower concentrations in the turbid system. Micro + nano phytoplankton decreased in species richness and abundance at higher herbicide concentrations in both systems. The abundance of heterotrophic bacteria increased at the highest 2,4-D concentration in the clear system. Photosynthetic picoplankton experienced more pronounced changes in the turbid system.
conclusions: The degree of water turbidity affects the response of freshwater populations exposed to 2,4-D. Variations in the essential constituents of microbial food chains can produce major functional changes, affecting the whole dynamics of a freshwater ecosystem. Species exhibit different behavior when growing in a community, highlighting the importance of using community-scale approaches in ecotoxicological studies.
relationships: Significant correlations were found between chlorophyll a concentration and the percentage contribution of micro + nano phytoplankton, PEuk, and PE-Pcy in the turbid system. Taxa were more significantly and positively intercorrelated in the turbid system than in the clear system.
insights: 2,4-D may mimic hormonal function. The presence or absence of auxin pathways in different species could be determinant for the whole community response. The differential absorption and/or utilization of 2,4-D by certain species may indirectly affect the total abundance of others. The sensitivity of Chlamydomonas sp. to 2,4-D detected in the clear system was probably masked in the turbid one by Staurastrum sp. growth.

title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
objective: To investigate the mechanism by which ethylene signaling controls gravitropic growth in rice roots, focusing on the role of COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1).
methodology: The study used a combination of genetic, molecular, and physiological approaches, including mutant screening, gene cloning, CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, RNA-seq, yeast two-hybrid assays, bimolecular fluorescence complementation, western blotting, electrophoretic mobility shift assays, chromatin immunoprecipitation, and live cell imaging.
results: The rice mutant *crw1* exhibits root coiling in hydroponic culture but normal gravitropic growth in soil. *crw1* is a loss-of-function allele for the EIN3-binding F-box protein OsCRW1/OsEBF1, leading to overaccumulation of OsEIL1 and OsEIL2 and amplified ethylene signaling. OsEIL1/2 act on the ethylene response factor OsERF82, which regulates the transcription of genes involved in the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Overaccumulation of ROS in the root tip leads to premature loss of the root cap structure, impaired polar localization of OsPIN2 and auxin distribution, resulting in severely impaired gravitropism. Mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling restores gravitropism in soil-grown plants.
conclusions: The study identified the molecular module of OsCRW1 (OsEBF1)-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS that connects ethylene signaling to gravitropism in rice roots. Root cap mechanosensing limits excessive ethylene signaling, safeguarding gravitropic growth of rice roots. Gentle mechanical resistance enhances the degradation of OsEIL1/OsEIL2 and thus dampens the excessive ethylene signaling in *crw1*, leading to rescue of the root coiling phenotype. The rescue of root gravitropism in *crw1* by gentle mechanical resistance requires Ca2+ signaling in the root cap.
relationships: Ethylene signaling interacts with auxin signaling and mechanosensing to regulate root gravitropism. OsCRW1 interacts with OsEIL1 and OsEIL2, promoting their degradation. OsEIL1 and OsEIL2 act on OsERF82, which regulates ROS production. ROS accumulation disrupts auxin distribution by impairing OsPIN2 localization.
insights: Ethylene's effect on root gravitropic growth is tightly regulated. Root cap mechanosensing plays an unexpected role in limiting excessive ethylene signaling, thereby safeguarding gravitropic growth of rice roots. The OsCRW1-OsEIL1/OsEIL2-OsERF82-ROS module is critical for connecting ethylene signaling to gravitropism in rice roots. Natural variation in OsCRW1 expression contributes to differences in root coiling phenotypes among rice accessions.

title: Low-speed clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings triggers root tip curvatures that are reminiscent of gravitropism.
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanisms governing the regulation of root growth by cadaverine in Arabidopsis thaliana, specifically focusing on the cadaverine hypersensitive 3 (cdh3) mutant.
methodology: Forward genetic screen of EMS-mutagenized Arabidopsis plants to identify mutants with altered root growth on cadaverine-containing media.  Characterization of the cdh3 mutant through backcrossing, whole-genome sequencing, transformation-rescue experiments, chemical rescue experiments with biotin and biotin pathway intermediates, in vitro enzyme assays, gene expression analysis (qRT-PCR), protein analysis (Western blots), lipid profiling by tandem mass spectrometry.
results: The cdh3 mutation, identified as an A662T amino acid change within the BIO1 catalytic pocket of the BIO3-BIO1 gene, enhances primary root growth sensitivity to cadaverine. Cadaverine inhibits BIO3-BIO1 enzymatic activity, leading to decreased biotin synthesis and reduced biotinylation of ACCase subunit BCCP1, resulting in decreased accumulation of triacylglycerides.  The cadaverine-induced inhibition of root growth can be rescued by supplementation with biotin and biotin-pathway intermediates downstream of BIO1.
conclusions: Cadaverine modulates primary root growth by inhibiting biotin synthesis through direct inhibition of the BIO3-BIO1 enzyme. This inhibition leads to decreased biotinylation of BCCP1, affecting fatty acid synthesis and overall lipid composition. The study suggests that cadaverine may function to divert a plant’s resources from growth to defense responses.
relationships: Cadaverine inhibits biotin synthesis, affecting ACCase and lipid composition. Biotin supplementation rescues cadaverine's effects. OCT1 and PAO4 are involved in the cadaverine-response pathway, functioning upstream or parallel to biotin.
insights: Cadaverine acts as a natural DAPA synthase inhibitor in Arabidopsis. Biotin deficiency results in decreased primary root growth and cell death in the elongation zone. Cadaverine's effect on biotin synthesis may be a mechanism for plants to shift resources from growth to defense under stress conditions.

title: New device for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms
objective: To investigate the root curvature response to low-speed clinorotation using Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings as models and to understand the effects exerted by low-speed clinorotation on root growth behavior and their connections with gravitropism.
methodology: Vertically grown Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings were subjected to low-speed clinorotation in darkness. Root tip reorientation was measured. Mutants with defects in gravity sensing and signal transduction were used.  DII-VENUS auxin reporter and PIN3-GFP were used to analyze auxin distribution and PIN3 relocalization.
results: Low-speed clinorotation triggers directional root tip curvature dependent upon the orientation of the seedlings and the polarity of rotation. Mutations affecting early steps of gravity signal transduction interfere with the clinostat effect. The speed of clinorotation impacts the clinostat effect. Low-speed clinorotation triggers the formation of an asymmetric auxin gradient across the root tip. Brachypodium distachyon accessions are differentially responsive to low-speed clinorotation.
conclusions: Gravitropism contributes to the clinostat effect on root growth direction under low-speed clinorotation. The findings have implications for understanding root gravisensitivity.  Clinorotation can be used as a method to evaluate root gravitropism.
relationships: Low-speed clinorotation leads to PIN protein relocalization in the statocytes, auxin gradient formation along the root tip, and curvature response. The levels of PIN3 relocalization and steepness of the lateral auxin gradient triggered by 0.2 RPM clinorotation were not as strong as those established upon direct gravistimulation.
insights: The first half-turn of clinorotation provides sufficient directional information to polarize the root cap statocytes. Genetic background and environmental conditions affect root tip curvature responses to clinorotation.  Clinorotation can be used to identify molecular mechanisms that contribute to variability in gravitropism using genome-wide association studies.

title: Sigma S-dependent antioxidant defense protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli against the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin
objective: To develop and validate a high-throughput method for screening the viability of flow biofilms using a microfluidic device (BioFlux) and fluorescence measurements.
methodology: A microfluidic device (BioFlux) was used to grow flow biofilms of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1. Biofilms were treated with antibiotics (gentamicin, tobramycin, ciprofloxacin, or enrofloxacin) or bleach. Viability was assessed using GFP-expressing bacteria and propidium iodide (PI) staining, followed by fluorescence measurement with a plate reader and fluorescence microscopy. Static biofilms were used for comparison and validation of the method.
results: The BioFlux device allowed for controlled growth and treatment of flow biofilms. The GFP-PI fluorescence method correlated well with colony counting for static biofilms, validating its use for viability assessment. Antibiotics and bleach caused dose-dependent killing of flow biofilms. The quinolones (ciprofloxacin and enrofloxacin) were the most effective antibiotics. The BacLight method overestimated viability at low antibiotic concentrations compared to the GFP-PI method.
conclusions: The BioFlux device, combined with GFP-PI fluorescence measurement, provides a reliable and high-throughput method for screening the viability of flow biofilms. This method can be used to assess the effectiveness of antimicrobial agents against biofilms. The BacLight method is less accurate at low antibiotic concentrations.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between antibiotic concentration and biofilm viability, demonstrating the effectiveness of different antibiotics against Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms. It also highlights the importance of using appropriate methods for assessing biofilm viability, as the BacLight method can overestimate viability at low antibiotic concentrations.
insights: The BioFlux device offers a significant advantage for studying biofilms due to its high-throughput capabilities and precise control over flow conditions. The GFP-PI method is a reliable alternative to the BacLight method for assessing biofilm viability, especially at low antibiotic concentrations. The study provides insights into the effectiveness of different antibiotics against biofilms and the importance of using appropriate methods for assessing biofilm viability.

title: Sigma S-Dependent Antioxidant Defense Protects Stationary-Phase Escherichia coli against the Bactericidal Antibiotic Gentamicin
objective: To elucidate the role of Sigma S (s) in bacterial antibiotic resistance, specifically against gentamicin (Gm) in stationary-phase Escherichia coli.
methodology: The study used genetic reporter assays, proteomic analysis, and mutant strains of E. coli to assess the impact of s and antioxidant defenses on gentamicin sensitivity.  ROS levels were measured using HPF and Amplex Red.  In vivo studies were conducted using a mouse model of urinary tract infection.
results: Loss of s in stationary-phase E. coli increased sensitivity to gentamicin.  Gm generated more reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the s mutant.  Antioxidant N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) decreased drug lethality, particularly in the mutant. Disruption of antioxidant defense or the pentose phosphate pathway increased oxidative stress and killing by Gm. In a mouse model, the rpoS mutant of uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) was more sensitive to Gm.
conclusions: Gentamicin kills stationary-phase bacteria by generating oxidative stress, in addition to its established mode of action. Targeting the antioxidant defense of E. coli can enhance gentamicin's efficacy.
relationships: Sigma S regulates the general stress response in E. coli, which protects against various stresses.  Antioxidant proteins like SodA/SodB and KatE/SodA, and pentose phosphate pathway proteins Zwf/Gnd and TalA, contribute to ROS decomposition and gentamicin resistance.
insights: Stationary-phase bacteria exhibit different physiological characteristics compared to exponential-phase cells, impacting their response to antibiotics.  Oxidative stress plays a significant role in gentamicin-mediated killing of stationary-phase E. coli, suggesting new targets for enhancing antibiotic effectiveness.

title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
objective: To describe the processes of plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair across mechanosensitive tissues, with a particular emphasis on comparing and contrasting repair mechanisms and downstream signaling to better understand the role of PMD in skeletal mechanobiology. Also, to explore the implications of PMD-related mechanisms for disease and potential therapeutic applications.
methodology: Review of existing literature on plasma membrane disruptions (PMD) in various mechanosensitive tissues, focusing on repair mechanisms and downstream signaling pathways. Comparison and contrasting of PMD processes across different cell types, with emphasis on bone cells.
results: PMD formation and repair are fundamental biological responses to cell injury, involving a series of cytoplasmic components, including membranes, the cytoskeleton, and repair proteins. PMD have been detected in various tissues including skin, epithelial cells, endothelial cells, neurons, myocytes and bone cells. PMD initiate mechanotransduction signaling cascades, coordinate inflammatory mediators, release secondary messengers, and recruit repair machinery.
conclusions: PMD are a key mechanosensation mechanism in the processes by which mechanosensitive mammalian cells detect and respond to mechanical loading in their environment. PMD formation and repair may represent a novel mechanosensation pathway in bone and a target for modifying skeletal adaptation signaling in osteocytes, such as strategies aimed at improving bone mechanosensitivity with aging.
relationships: PMD formation and repair are related to mechanotransduction, cell signaling, calcium signaling, ATP release, and the activity of various proteins such as calpains, annexins, and growth factors. PMD are also related to diseases such as muscular dystrophy, traumatic brain injury, and bone aging.
insights: The rate of PMD repair can affect downstream cellular signaling. PMD-induced release of bFGF from endothelial cells promotes proliferation either in the wounded cell or in adjacent non-wounded neighboring cells. PMD formation and repair-related mechanisms may underlie some of the changes in bone mechanobiology with aging.

title: Salivary Gland Protein Expression after Bion-M1 and Space Shuttle STS-135 Missions
objective: To determine if the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland are affected by microgravity and the spaceflight environment.
methodology: Tissues from female mice flown on Space Shuttle missions STS-131 and STS-135, and from male mice flown on the Russian Bion-M1 biosatellite were examined using transmission electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry. Quantitative immunogold labeling was used to assess protein expression.
results: Morphologic changes were not apparent in the submandibular gland of female mice. No significant changes in protein expression occurred in female mice flown for 13-15 days. In male mice, increased labeling for salivary androgen binding protein alpha, epidermal growth factor, and nerve growth factor was seen after 30 days in space.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters secretory protein expression in the submandibular gland. The sex of the animals and the length of the flight may affect the response. Individual salivary glands respond differently to spaceflight. Saliva is a useful biofluid for monitoring the physiology and health of astronauts.
relationships: Spaceflight affects the expression of specific proteins in the submandibular gland, with differences observed based on the duration of the flight and the sex of the animal. The parotid and submandibular glands respond differently to spaceflight.
insights: Changes in salivary protein levels may serve as indicators of physiological changes in astronauts during long-term spaceflights. Microgravity specifically upregulates the expression of salivary androgen-binding protein alpha in male mice after 30 days in space.

title: Response of the mouse sublingual gland to spaceflight.
objective: To determine if the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland is affected by microgravity and the spaceflight environment.
methodology: Examination of submandibular gland tissues from female mice flown on US space shuttle missions (STS-131 and STS-135) for 15 and 13 days, respectively, and from male mice flown on the 30-day Russian Bion-M1 biosatellite. Techniques included transmission electron microscopy, light and electron microscopic immunohistochemistry, and immunogold labeling. Ground control mice were used for comparison.
results: Morphologic changes were not apparent in the submandibular gland of female mice. No significant changes in protein expression occurred in female mice flown for 13-15 days. In male mice, increased labeling for salivary androgen binding protein alpha (SABPα) in acinar cell secretory granules, and epidermal growth factor (EGF) and nerve growth factor (NGF) in granular convoluted duct cell granules was observed after 30 days in space.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters secretory protein expression in the submandibular gland. The sex of the animals and the length of the flight may affect the response. Individual salivary glands respond differently to spaceflight. Saliva is a useful biofluid for monitoring the physiology and health of astronauts.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced microgravity affects the expression of SABPα, EGF and NGF in male mice submandibular glands. The parotid and submandibular glands respond differently to spaceflight, with the parotid gland showing increased autophagy and apoptosis, while the submandibular gland shows changes in protein expression without significant morphological alterations.
insights: Longer spaceflights (30 days) have a more pronounced effect on protein expression in male mice submandibular glands compared to shorter flights (13-15 days) in female mice. Microgravity specifically upregulates SABPα expression in male mice after 30 days in space. Changes in saliva protein levels may be useful for monitoring astronaut health during long-term spaceflights.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the mouse submandibular gland
objective: To determine structural changes in the mouse sublingual gland using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), to determine cellular distribution and expression of selected sublingual gland proteins by immunohistochemistry (IHC), and to compare these changes to those observed in the parotid gland following spaceflight.
methodology: Adult female mice were flown on space shuttle missions (STS-131 and STS-135) for 13-15 days. Sublingual salivary glands were collected from flight and ground control mice. Samples were prepared for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to assess structural changes and immunohistochemistry (IHC) to determine the cellular distribution and expression of mucin (Muc19), parotid secretory protein (PSP), demilune cell and parotid protein (DCPP), and the type II regulatory subunit of protein kinase A (PKA-RII). Quantitative analyses of immunogold labeled micrographs were performed to determine protein expression levels.
results: No significant differences were observed in the ultrastructure of sublingual mucous cells, serous cells, or duct cells between flight and ground control mice. Immunohistochemistry showed intense reactivity for mucin in mucous acinar cells and PSP, DCPP, and PKA-RII in serous demilune cells. PSP expression was significantly increased in the glands of STS-131 flight mice compared to ground control mice, but decreased in STS-135 flight mice. DCPP labeling was slightly decreased in both flight groups. PKA-RII labeling density was increased in STS-131 mice but decreased in STS-135 mice.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions induce changes in protein expression in mouse sublingual glands. The response of salivary glands to spaceflight varies among different glands, cell types, and secretory proteins. The age of the mice may influence the protein expression response. Changes in salivary proteins may lead to development of non-invasive methods to assess the physiological status of astronauts.
relationships: The parotid glands of the same mice showed structural changes (autophagy, apoptosis) that were not observed in the sublingual glands, suggesting differences in the genetic makeup and metabolic functions of the two glands. The expression of PSP, PKA-RII, and mucin was greater in the glands of mice from STS-131 than in those from STS-135, highlighting the difference in response of the parotid and sublingual glands to spaceflight.
insights: Microgravity and the spaceflight environment have little or no effect on sublingual gland mucin expression. PSP expression was significantly increased in the sublingual glands of flight mice from STS-131, but was decreased, although not significantly, in flight mice from STS-135. The difference in ages of the mice on the two flights may be related to the different responses and in particular to the significant difference in PSP labeling densities between the two flights.

title: Reactivation of Latent Epstein-Barr Virus: A Comparison after Exposure to Gamma, Proton, Carbon, and Iron Radiation
objective: To elucidate how lunar gravity (1/6 g) changes mRNA expression patterns in the salivary gland of mice, focusing on the submandibular glands.
methodology: Mice were exposed to lunar gravity (1/6 g) using a multiple artificial gravity research system (MARS) during space flight on the International Space Station. Submandibular glands were collected two days after landing. mRNA expression was analyzed using microarrays and immunoﬂuorescence staining was performed to evaluate protein expression.
results: Lunar gravity induced the expression of the salivary amylase gene Amy1, but not Aqp5 and Ano1 (water secretion regulators). Genes involved in the exocrine system, such as Vamp8 and small G proteins (Rap1 and Rab families), were upregulated under lunar gravity. Microarray analysis revealed that the expression increases with significance were more seen in acinar cells.
conclusions: Lunar gravity upregulates salivary amylase secretion via Rap/Rab signaling and exocytosis via Vamp8. Amy1 is a potential candidate marker for stress regulation in salivary glands in the lunar gravity environment.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between lunar gravity, salivary gland function, and the expression of specific genes involved in protein secretion. It suggests that changes in gravity can induce qualitative changes in salivary secretion function.
insights: The findings suggest that the space environment induces changes in salivary secretion function, potentially as a response to stress. The upregulation of Amy1 and related genes indicates a specific adaptation of the salivary glands to lunar gravity. Mechanosensitive ion channels were downregulated, possibly as a mechanism to restore fluid balance.

title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
objective: To study the effect of different types of radiation on the activation of lytic gene transcription and reactivation of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in a latently infected cell line.
methodology: In vitro experiment using Akata cells (an EBV-producer line) exposed to 137Cs gamma rays, 150-MeV protons, 600 MeV/n carbon ions, and 600 MeV/n iron ions at doses of 0.1, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 Gy.  Measurements included cell viability, cell size, EBV lytic RNA transcripts, and EBV viral load.
results: All radiation types induced EBV transcription as early as four days post-treatment. Gamma radiation generally produced the highest rates of viral reactivation. High-energy particles resulted in a second peak of transcription at later times.  Viral loads were noticeably higher than controls at all post-irradiation time points.
conclusions: Different types of radiation induce EBV lytic gene transcription and reactivation in a latently infected cell line, even in the absence of the immune system. Gamma rays were more effective than protons, carbon ions, and iron ions in inducing latent virus reactivation, challenging the commonly used RBE value for protons.
relationships: Radiation exposure can lead to the reactivation of latent viruses, potentially exacerbated by decreased immunity during spaceflight. The type of radiation and its track structure influence the extent of viral reactivation. Viral reactivation occurs within days, while radiation carcinogenesis usually takes months or years.
insights: Radiation of latently infected cells alone is a major contributor to the reactivation of herpes viruses. Understanding the molecular events involved in viral reactivation can provide insights into radiation-induced human diseases associated with EBV, and may have implications for radiotherapy treatment.

title: The cyclic nucleotide-gated channel CNGC14 regulates root gravitropism in Arabidopsis thaliana.
objective: To examine how the salivary microbiome changes as a result of spaceflight and whether there is a microbiome signature that may influence viral reactivation in humans.
methodology: Saliva samples were collected from 10 astronauts pre-flight, in-flight, and post-flight. 16S rRNA gene sequencing was used for microbiome analysis, and qPCR was used to measure viral titers of EBV, HSV, and VZV.
results: Streptococcus was the most abundant organism in saliva, with its diversity decreasing during spaceflight. Proteobacteria and Fusobacteria increased during flight, while Actinobacteria decreased. Certain genera (Catonella, Megasphera, Actinobacillus) were detected during flight but absent pre-flight in some subjects. Positive correlations were found between certain bacteria (Gracilibacteria, Absconditabacteria, Abiotrophia) and viral titers, while negative correlations were observed with others (Oribacterium, Veillonella, Haemophilus). Microbiome richness correlated positively with EBV viral titers.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters the salivary microbiome, and specific bacterial signatures correlate with viral reactivation. Further research on these organisms could lead to mitigation strategies to prevent disease during space missions.
relationships: The study identifies correlations between specific bacterial genera and viral reactivation, suggesting potential protective or promoting roles. For example, Oribacterium, Lachnoanaerobaculum, Haemophilus, Johnsonella, and Stomatobaculum show an inverse correlation with EBV copy number, suggesting a protective role. Conversely, Gracilibacteria and Abiotrophia show positive correlations with EBV viral load.
insights: The salivary microbiome is dynamic during spaceflight, and changes in its composition may influence viral reactivation. Targeting specific bacteria or their metabolites could be a strategy to maintain astronaut health during long-duration space missions. The study also suggests that a personalized approach to astronaut microbiome management may be necessary.

title: Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections
objective: To investigate the molecular actors involved in the establishment of the longitudinal surface pH zonation in Arabidopsis roots, focusing on the alkaline domain around the transition zone.
methodology: The study employed an improved method for visualizing and quantifying root surface pH using Fluorescein-5-(and-6)-Sulfonic Acid, Trisodium Salt (FS).  Mutant lines with altered auxin transport, perception, and response were analyzed.  Immunolocalization, pharmacological treatments, and genetic manipulations were used to assess the roles of AHA ATPases, auxin transporters (AUX1, PIN2), and components of the rapid auxin response pathway (AFB1, CNGC14). Root gravitropism and penetration through artificial obstacles were also tested.
results: The Arabidopsis root shows distinct acidic and alkaline root surface pH domains. The alkaline domain in the transition zone is not directly determined by AHA activation or localization but requires AUX1-mediated auxin influx. The components of the rapid auxin response pathway steer the transition zone root surface pH. The AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module facilitates root navigation.
conclusions: The alkaline surface pH domain originates from a constant rapid auxin response driven by the AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module. This response enables the roots to rapidly react to gravity vector changes and to adjust the root tip growth direction. The longitudinal surface pH zonation is not solely based on the activity and abundance of PM AHA H+ ATPases, but instead, the alkaline domain in the transition zone is driven by AUX1-mediated auxin influx and AFB1 signaling.
relationships: The alkaline domain at the transition zone depends on AUX1-mediated auxin influx. Without auxin influx, the root shows a linear acidification gradient from the root tip to the maturation zone. The rapid auxin response pathway, specifically AFB1 and CNGC14, steers the pH profile of the root during normal steady-state growth by controlling the alkaline domain in the transition zone. The TIR1 canonical signaling pathway contributes to the overall increase of root surface pH upon auxin treatment.
insights: The study reveals that the alkaline domain in the transition zone of Arabidopsis roots is a site of constant rapid auxin response, triggered by internal auxin fluxes mediated by AUX1 and PIN2 transporters. This dynamic response enables the root to quickly regulate its growth direction, particularly in the soil environment.

title: Persistent NF-Œ∫B activation in muscle stem cells induces proliferation-independent telomere shortening
objective: To measure telomere length in skeletal muscle stem cells (MuSCs) using cryosection muscle quantitative fluorescent in situ hybridization (CRYO MuQ-FISH).
methodology: Skeletal muscle cryosections are prepared and subjected to CRYO MuQ-FISH. Telomere length is assessed on a single-cell level using Telometer software, normalizing telomere intensity to DAPI or centromere intensity. The protocol involves skeletal muscle preparation, embedding, sectioning, CRYO MuQ-FISH, image collection, and analysis.
results: The protocol enables the measurement of telomere length in MuSCs within their native environment. Telomere outputs include total sum intensity and mean intensity per nucleus. The method is compatible with archival samples and can be adapted to examine telomere lengths in other muscle-resident cell types and tissues.
conclusions: CRYO MuQ-FISH is a reliable method for assessing telomere length in MuSCs, providing insights into cellular dysfunction in diseased conditions. It offers advantages over other methods by preserving the tissue environment and allowing for single-cell level analysis.
relationships: Telomere length reduction in MuSCs is associated with chronic muscle injury conditions, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy, leading to a more severe disease phenotype.
insights: The CRYO MuQ-FISH protocol can be applied to various tissue types and species, making it a versatile tool for telomere length assessment in different biological contexts. Normalization to centromere intensity can be used if DAPI staining is inconsistent.

title: Piezo1 regulates the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscles via orchestration of stem cell morphological states.
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanisms contributing to MuSC-specific telomere shortening in chronic injury conditions, particularly in the context of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).
methodology: Flow cytometry, MuQ-FISH, qRT-PCR, in-silico analysis of gene promoters, immunofluorescence staining, two-photon microscopy, creatine kinase assay, grip test, in-cell western, myoblast culture and shRNA knockdown, telomere-induced foci (TIF) assay, uCT imaging, functional measurements of muscle contractility.
results: Persistent activation of NF-κB leads to telomere shortening in MuSCs under chronic injury conditions, independent of proliferation. This involves Ku80 dysregulation and increased DNA damage, specifically on telomeres, resulting in MuSC loss and skeletal muscle regenerative failure. MuSC-specific NF-κB activation exacerbates dystrophic muscle defects. Downregulation of Ku80 alone reduces telomere length in MuSCs.
conclusions: Persistent NF-κB activation in MuSCs leads to Ku80 dysregulation, predisposing these cells to premature telomere shortening and an increased number of TIFs, ultimately contributing to the severe dystrophic skeletal muscle phenotype. Maintaining telomere length of MuSCs could boost their regenerative ability in disease-related chronic injuries such as DMD.
relationships: NF-κB activation is linked to telomere shortening via Ku80 dysregulation. Telomere shortening leads to increased DNA damage and stem cell exhaustion. NF-κB activation exacerbates the dystrophic phenotype in mdx mice.
insights: The study identifies a previously unrecognized role of NF-κB in regulating MuSC dysfunction by affecting telomeres, a key event during the progression of DMD. It also demonstrates a proliferation-independent mechanism of NF-κB to drive MuSC-specific telomere shortening.

title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length.
objective: To investigate how the sensing protein Piezo1 regulates the regenerative capacity of skeletal muscles via orchestration of stem cell morphological states.
methodology: Generated a Pax7EGFP reporter mouse to visualize muscle stem cells (MuSCs) in unperturbed mouse muscles. Used two-photon microscopy to assess MuSC structural complexity and performance within their natural environment. Pharmacologically activated Piezo1 and generated Piezo1 conditional MuSC knockout mice. Performed intramuscular notexin injury on control and Piezo1MuSC-KO mice and imaged their muscles by two-photon microscopy.
results: Quiescent MuSCs exhibit variability in protrusions within their natural environment. MuSC protrusions are dynamically regulated upon skeletal muscle injury, with cells with fewer protrusions primed to proliferate immediately following injury. Piezo1 regulates the morphological heterogeneity of MuSCs and is required for proper transition of MuSC subtypes during regeneration. Dystrophic muscles exhibit dysregulated MuSC subtypes, with lower Piezo1 levels and longer, more complex protrusions. Activation of Piezo1 restores MuSC subtype distribution in dystrophic muscles.
conclusions: MuSCs have protrusions that establish their stem cell state, and Piezo1 is necessary for their transition toward more activated stem cell forms, such as the ones that are impaired in diseased conditions. Piezo1 plays a critical role in regulating the morphological heterogeneity of MuSCs, maintaining the regeneration potential of skeletal muscles in both healthy and diseased states.
relationships: Piezo1 defines MuSC subtypes and coordinates the MuSC transition toward cells with less protrusions in homeostasis and regeneration. In muscular dystrophy, protrusion length is aberrantly regulated, Piezo1 levels are low, and the number of cells with few protrusions is reduced. Pharmacological reactivation of Piezo1 ameliorates the aberrant morphology of diseased MuSCs and boosts muscle regeneration in dystrophic mice.
insights: Quiescent MuSC populations represent a collection of morphologically heterogeneous states with different functional capabilities. Piezo1 is essential for maintaining MuSC states and regulating protrusion length and cell shape in both homeostatic and dystrophic muscles. Reactivation of Piezo1 in dystrophic muscles restores protrusion length, better regulates MuSC heterogeneity, and promotes proper function during repetitive injuries.

title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length
objective: To measure telomere length in resident skeletal muscle cells of mice experiencing spaceflight-like conditions (irradiation and hindlimb suspension) and to assess telomere length changes following a recovery period.
methodology: Mice were subjected to hindlimb suspension (HLS) to mimic microgravity and whole-body irradiation (IR) to simulate cosmic radiation. Telomere length was measured in muscle stem cells (MuSCs), myonuclei, and endothelial cells using CRYO MuQ-FISH. Expression of telomerase (TERT) and ALT-related genes (ATRX, DAXX) were assessed using qRT-PCR and immunohistochemistry. Telomerase activity was measured by TRAP assay.
results: Combined HLS and IR resulted in telomere lengthening in MuSCs and myonuclei, but not in endothelial cells. Telomere lengthening was not reversed after a 2-week recovery period. Telomerase activity was low, suggesting an alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) mechanism. Downregulation of ATRX and DAXX transcripts in HLS + IR muscles suggests engagement of ALT-related pathways.
conclusions: Spaceflight-like conditions (HLS + IR) induce telomere lengthening in muscle cells, potentially through ALT mechanisms. Telomere lengthening was not reversed by reloading. These findings suggest that spaceflight may affect telomere dynamics in muscle cells, which may have implications for astronaut health.
relationships: Hindlimb suspension and irradiation exposure lead to telomere elongation in muscle stem cells and myonuclei. The telomere lengthening is associated with the downregulation of Atrx and Daxx, suggesting a possible link to Alternative Lengthening of Telomeres (ALT) mechanisms. Telomere length changes in muscle cells differ from those observed in blood cells during spaceflight.
insights: The study suggests that spaceflight conditions can induce telomere lengthening in muscle cells through ALT mechanisms, which may have implications for astronaut health. Further research is needed to understand the long-term effects of these changes and to develop countermeasures to mitigate any potential risks.

title: Transcriptional and Hormonal Regulation of Gravitropism of Woody Stems in Populus.
objective: To examine the accumulation of flavonols in guard cells and the role of flavonol accumulation in controlling the levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS).
methodology: Using a flavonol-specific dye (DPBA) and a reporter construct (CHS:GUS), localized accumulation of flavonols and expression of the gene driving their synthesis were visualized in guard cells. Mutants lacking flavonols (tt4-2) were used to demonstrate dye specificity and the effect of flavonols on ROS status and stomatal aperture. Ethylene induction of flavonol synthesis was examined, and the effects on stomatal aperture were assessed. LC-MS was used to quantify flavonols.
results: Flavonols accumulate specifically in guard cells, but not pavement cells. The tt4-2 mutant showed no flavonols. Flavonol accumulation affects ABA-induced stomatal closure. Elevated ethylene levels increase flavonol accumulation. ROS accumulation is affected by flavonol concentrations; tt4-2 showed increased ROS, while ethylene-treated plants showed decreased ROS. Stomatal closure is modulated by ethylene levels.
conclusions: Flavonols suppress ROS levels within guard cells, modulating stomatal aperture. Ethylene regulates flavonol levels in guard cells. Elevated ethylene increases flavonol accumulation, decreasing ROS levels and the rate of stomatal closure. Flavonols act as antioxidants in guard cells, modulating the dynamics of stomatal aperture.
relationships: Ethylene induces flavonol accumulation, which reduces ROS concentrations and decreases the rate of ABA-induced stomatal closure.  A ROS-independent pathway for ABA-induced stomatal closure may also exist.
insights: Guard cell function is integral to plant adaptation to a changing environment. Flavonols play a crucial role in modulating ROS concentrations within guard cells, influencing stomatal dynamics and plant responses to environmental cues.

title: Endosidin2 targets conserved exocyst complex subunit EXO70 to inhibit exocytosis
objective: To identify key regulatory mechanisms involved in negative gravitropic responses in woody stems, focusing on graviperception, auxin transport, and the roles of auxin, gibberellic acid (GA), and the ARBORKNOX2 (ARK2) transcription factor.
methodology: Experiments were conducted on Populus trees, including wild-type and transgenic lines with altered ARK2 expression. Methods included time-lapse video analysis of gravibending, histological analysis of tension wood, immunolocalization of PIN3 auxin transporter and arabinogalactan proteins (FLAs), XET activity visualization, GUS reporter assays for auxin response, polar auxin transport measurements, RNA sequencing, and weighted gene correlation network analysis (WGCNA).
results: Graviperception likely occurs in specialized cells within the woody stem containing starch-filled amyloplasts and expressing PIN3. Gravistimulation leads to PIN3 relocalization toward the ground, influencing auxin transport. GA stimulates fiber production and gravibending, with effects sensitive to ARK2 levels. Transcriptome analysis revealed a massive reprogramming of gene expression in opposite wood. Gene coexpression network analysis identified modules associated with wood phenotypes, GA response, and ARK2 binding.
conclusions: The study identifies key regulatory mechanisms in woody stem gravitropism, including graviperception cells, PIN3-mediated auxin transport, and interacting roles for auxin, GA, and ARK2. Lateral auxin transport is an early graviresponse, triggering differential xylem tissue development. GA stimulates fiber production, with effects modulated by ARK2. Opposite wood undergoes significant gene expression reprogramming during gravitropism.
relationships: Auxin transport is influenced by PIN3 localization in response to gravity. GA potentiates auxin responses and interacts with ARK2 to regulate fiber development. ARK2 influences the expression of genes involved in cell wall development and hormone-related functions.  FLA gene expression is differentially regulated by GA in different wood types and ARK2 genotypes.
insights: Woody stems perceive gravity directly via specialized cells.  Lateral auxin transport is a key early event in gravitropism.  GA and ARK2 play interacting roles in regulating wood formation.  Opposite wood is not merely a passive responder but undergoes active gene expression changes.  Fiber production can be genetically decoupled from cell wall maturation.

title: A conditional mutation in SCD1 reveals linkage between PIN protein trafficking, auxin transport, gravitropism, and lateral root initiation.
objective: To examine the composition of plasma membrane proteins in Arabidopsis seedlings after inhibition of the ES2-targeted exocyst complex, and to identify additional proteins that are transported through the exocyst complex.
methodology: Plasma membrane enrichment from Arabidopsis roots treated with Endosidin2 (ES2), followed by quantitative proteomic analysis using mass spectrometry. Live imaging of GFP-tagged plasma membrane proteins in root epidermal cells using laser scanning confocal microscopy.
results: Identified 145 plasma membrane proteins with significantly reduced abundance following short-term ES2 treatments, indicating they are candidate cargo proteins of exocyst-mediated trafficking. Gene Ontology analysis showed these proteins play diverse functions in cell growth, cell wall biosynthesis, hormone signaling, stress response, membrane transport, and nutrient uptake. Confocal imaging confirmed the reduced abundance of PIN2, BRI1, and FER at the plasma membrane after ES2 treatment.
conclusions: The plant exocyst complex mediates constitutive dynamic transport of subsets of plasma membrane proteins during normal root growth, essential for plant growth and environmental adaptation. The exocyst complex plays essential roles for growth and adaptation by mediating constitutive transport of proteins with diverse functions to the plasma membrane.
relationships: The exocyst complex interacts with PIN auxin transporters, brassinosteroid receptor, and cellulose synthase complexes. ES2 binds to the EXO70A1 subunit of the exocyst complex and inhibits its function.
insights: The exocyst complex mediates transport of proteins in both conventional and unconventional trafficking pathways. The abundance of some plant plasma membrane proteins was reduced by more than 50%, indicating that the half-time of turnover of these proteins is less than 2 h.

title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 1: Intracellular overdrive for SARS-CoV-2 infection.
objective: To investigate the dynamics of auxin transport targeting and how reversible changes in protein targeting control auxin transport and dependent processes using a temperature-sensitive scd1-1 mutant in Arabidopsis roots.
methodology: The study utilized a temperature-sensitive scd1-1 mutant of Arabidopsis.  Experiments involved growing seedlings at permissive (18°C) and restrictive (25°C) temperatures, temperature shift assays, IAA transport assays (pulse-chase and shootward), DR5-GFP reporter analysis for auxin-induced gene expression, gravitropic response assays, and localization studies of PIN proteins using fluorescent protein fusions and confocal microscopy. FM4-64 staining and colocalization analysis with endosomal markers (ARA6, ARA7, VHA1, SYP61, SNX1) were performed to characterize endomembrane compartments.
results: The scd1-1 mutant exhibited impaired root elongation, reduced lateral root formation, delayed gravitropic curvature, and altered gravity-directed asymmetric pDR5-GFP expression at the restrictive temperature (25°C). Both shootward and rootward IAA transport were impaired. PIN1 and PIN2 showed altered localization, accumulating in endomembrane bodies at 25°C, which colocalized with FM4-64, ARA7, and ARA6.
conclusions: The conditional scd1-1 mutant, with a defect in a RAB-GEF, exhibits altered localization of PIN2, leading to its accumulation in late endosomal/prevacuolar compartments. This disruption of PIN2 protein localization precedes reductions in auxin transport and changes in auxin transport-dependent physiological processes. SCD1 is needed for lateral root development between days 2 and 6.
relationships: SCD1 affects PIN1 and PIN2 targeting, with selectivity towards these proteins compared to PIN3, ABCB19, and AUX1. PIN2 colocalizes with ARA7 and ARA6 Rab-related GTPases in late multivesicular endosomes.  Altered PIN2 trafficking precedes changes in auxin transport and gravitropism.
insights: The study provides direct evidence that the targeting machinery, which disrupts PIN2 protein localization, precedes reductions in auxin transport and changes in auxin transport-dependent physiological processes. The ability to reversibly manipulate lateral root development revealed the critical time point when SCD1 and auxin transport are needed for lateral root development.

title: Changes in nuclear shape and gene expression in response to simulated microgravity are LINC complex-dependent.
objective: To provide insight into SARS-CoV-2 infection and intracellular host responses, including targets, pathways, networks, biological processes, and functional adaptations to viral invasion.
methodology: Review of existing literature and research on SARS-CoV-2, including patient samples, organoids, cell studies, and non-human animal studies.
