results: SARS-CoV-2 infection triggers a cascade of intracellular adaptations, remodeling networks from transcription to metabolism and signal transduction, shifting the host cell into a viral replication system. The virus targets multiple organs and cell types, with varying expression influenced by ACE2-receptor levels and related entry factors. Metabolic adaptations include dysregulation of calcium signaling, increased mitochondrial ROS production, and a shift towards glycolysis.
conclusions: COVID-19 is a pleiotropic condition with viral insults and cellular metabolic adaptations differing based on cell type, genotype, and environmental influences. Future research should focus on mechanisms of viral entry, protein machinery capture, host genetics impact, effects on glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation, and mitochondrial adaptations.
relationships: The virus interacts with ACE2 receptors for cell entry, disrupts calcium homeostasis, manipulates intracellular signaling pathways (PI3K/AKT, interferon, TGF-β, TLR, NF-κB), and alters mitochondrial function. These interactions lead to immune evasion, inflammation, and metabolic shifts.
insights: SARS-CoV-2 reprograms the human host machinery by interfering with signaling pathways that regulate DNA repair, immune response, transcription, metabolism, cell cycle, and apoptosis. Understanding these processes is crucial for developing effective therapeutic interventions.

title: Growth of Carnobacterium spp. from permafrost under low pressure, temperature, and anoxic atmosphere has implications for Earth microbes on Mars
objective: To investigate whether the LINC complex mediates cellular responses to a simulated microgravity environment, focusing on changes in nuclear shape and gene expression.
methodology: MCF 10A breast epithelial cells, both wildtype and engineered to disrupt LINC complex function (using doxycycline-inducible SS-HA-SUN1L-KDEL), were exposed to simulated microgravity (SMG) using a 3-D clinostat. Nuclear morphology was monitored using confocal microscopy. RNAseq analysis was used to characterize differential gene expression in cells exposed to SMG versus 1G controls.
results: Nuclear shape changes in response to SMG depend on the LINC complex.  Disruption of the LINC complex affected patterns of gene expression.  Several genes associated with cytokines and chemokines were significantly altered, including VEGFA. The focal adhesion associated genes TLN2 and SERPINE1 were upregulated, while the ECM genes TIMP3 and LAMA5 were down-regulated.
conclusions: The LINC complex plays an important role in regulating nuclear morphology and gene expression in breast epithelial cells exposed to SMG. Mechanical forces imposed through altered gravity likely act through LINC complex-related transduction events to modulate nuclear shape and patterns of gene expression, especially of genes associated with the cytoskeleton, cell adhesion, and other mechanical features of the cell.
relationships: The LINC complex connects the cytoskeleton to the nuclear surface, influencing nuclear shape and gene expression.  Changes in nuclear shape are linked to alterations in gene expression patterns.  The cytoskeleton reorganizes in microgravity, impacting nuclear shape.
insights: The mechanosensitivity of nuclear shape to external stimuli strongly depends on the SUN1-Nesprin linkage in the nuclear envelope provided by the LINC complex. LINC-dependent genes are up- and down-regulated in response to SMG, suggesting a complex interplay of signaling and time in the LINC mediated modulation of these genes.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi Strain WN1359T (DSM 27470T)
objective: To investigate the ability of terrestrial microorganisms, specifically those from Siberian permafrost, to grow under conditions simulating the Martian environment (low temperature, low pressure, anoxic atmosphere).
methodology: Microbes were isolated from Siberian permafrost samples and cultured under low-temperature, low-pressure, and anoxic conditions. 16S ribosomal DNA analysis was used to identify the isolates. Growth kinetics of the isolates and Carnobacterium type strains were quantified under different conditions.
results: Six bacterial strains capable of growth under simulated Mars conditions were isolated and identified as species of the genus Carnobacterium. All Carnobacterium species tested were capable of growth under low-PTA conditions, but exhibited different growth patterns under varying environmental conditions.
conclusions: Microbial communities from Siberian permafrost contain organisms capable of growing under conditions of low temperature, low pressure, and anoxic CO2-dominated atmosphere, suggesting permafrosts are promising locations for isolating microbes that can survive in Martian-like conditions.
relationships: The permafrost isolates were closely related to Carnobacterium species isolated from Arctic and Antarctic environments. The study also compared the growth patterns of permafrost isolates with those of Carnobacterium type strains under different environmental conditions.
insights: The discovery of terrestrial bacteria that can inhabit cold, low-pressure, anoxic environments has implications for extremophile biology, astrobiology, the search for extraterrestrial life, and planetary protection. Permafrosts seem to be promising locations for the isolation of microbes capable of growth under cold, anoxic, and hypobaric conditions such as are encountered on Mars.

title: Exposure of Bacillus subtilis to low pressure (5 kilopascals) induces several global regulons, including those involved in the SigB-mediated general stress response
objective: To determine the complete genome sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain WN1359, isolated from Siberian permafrost.
methodology: The genome was sequenced using the PacBio SMRT system. Initial reads were error-corrected, and a single scaffold was assembled using Celera assembler. The assembly was refined using the PacBio RS_Resequencing module. Open reading frame prediction and annotation were performed using the RAST pipeline.
results: The chromosome has 2,347,813 bp with 35.26% GC content. Five plasmids were detected. 2,152 protein-encoding ORFs were identified, with 79% assigned to a known function. 74 tRNAs and 8 rRNA operons were also detected.
conclusions: The complete genome sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain WN1359 was determined and analyzed, providing insights into its genetic makeup.
relationships: Carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain WN1359 was isolated from Siberian permafrost and is capable of growth under cold, anoxic, CO2-dominated, low-pressure conditions.
insights: The genomic information can be used to investigate the molecular basis of the organism's response to simulated Martian conditions and its adaptation to extreme environments.

title: Resistance of Bacillus subtilis Spore DNA to Lethal Ionizing Radiation Damage Relies Primarily on Spore Core Components and DNA Repair, with Minor Effects of Oxygen Radical Detoxification
objective: To study the global low pressure (LP) response of Bacillus subtilis cells by comparing the transcriptome of cells grown under normal atmospheric pressure and a nearly inhibitory LP.
methodology: Transcription microarray experiments were performed on Bacillus subtilis cells grown under normal atmospheric pressure (~101 kPa) and low pressure (5 kPa). Total RNA was extracted, labeled, and analyzed using a custom microarray. Beta-galactosidase assays were used to confirm the expression of a SigB-dependent reporter gene under LP conditions. Competition experiments were conducted to assess the fitness of a sigB knockout mutant under LP.
results: Exposure to 5 kPa resulted in altered levels of 363 transcripts belonging to several global regulons. The SigB-mediated general stress response (GSR) regulon was highly upregulated. Induction of the ctc-lacZ reporter gene fusion confirmed the SigB-dependent GSR induction by LP. Inactivation of sigB did not significantly alter fitness at either normal or low pressure.
conclusions: Bacillus subtilis senses and responds to LP stress by activating several regulons, including the SigB-mediated GSR. The GSR is induced at pressures below 10 kPa. The SigB-mediated GSR does not seem to be required for growth at 5 kPa, suggesting other stress-related genes might be necessary.
relationships: The SigB-mediated GSR is induced by low pressure, similar to other stresses like ethanol, heat, and salt. Low pressure also induces anaerobic response regulons (ResD, Fnr, Rex) and transition state regulators (AbrB/Abh, CodY, Rok, Spo0A, SigH).
insights: Low pressure induces a general stress response in Bacillus subtilis, suggesting a mechanism for adaptation to hypobaric environments. The lower limit of pressure for significant decreases in growth rate and colony size in bacteria is around 10 kPa, which also corresponds to the pressure at which the GSR is induced in B. subtilis.

title: Cultivation of Staphylococcus epidermidis in the human spaceflight environment leads to alterations in the frequency and spectrum of spontaneous rifampicin-resistance mutations in the rpoB gene
objective: To study the roles of core components, DNA repair mechanisms, and oxidative stress response in Bacillus subtilis spore resistance to ionizing radiation.
methodology: Spores of various B. subtilis strains with mutations in genes related to core components (SASP, DPA, core water content), DNA repair (NHEJ, AP endonucleases), and oxidative stress response (MrgA, KatX, SodA) were exposed to X-rays, protons, and high-energy charged iron ions. Spore survival was determined by colony-forming ability.
results: Spores deficient in DNA repair (NHEJ, AP endonucleases) or protection by SASP, DPA, and decreased core water content were significantly more sensitive to ionizing radiation. Oxygen radical detoxification played a minor role. Synergistic radioprotective effects of specific SASP types were identified.
conclusions: DNA repair via NHEJ and AP endonucleases is crucial for spore resistance to ionizing radiation. Spore core components like SASP, DPA, and core dehydration also contribute to radioprotection. Oxidative stress detoxification has a limited impact.
relationships: The study establishes relationships between spore core components, DNA repair mechanisms, and oxidative stress responses in determining the resistance of Bacillus subtilis spores to different types of ionizing radiation.
insights: Spore DNA is a major target of lethal ionizing radiation damage. Protection of dormant spore DNA and efficient DNA repair during germination are key to spore survival. The relative importance of different protective mechanisms varies depending on the type of radiation.

title: Experimental Evolution of Bacillus subtilis
objective: To investigate the effect of the human spaceflight environment on the growth and frequency of mutations to antibiotic resistance in Staphylococcus epidermidis.
methodology: Cultivated S. epidermidis in the International Space Station (ISS) and in ground controls (GCs). Measured viable counts and frequency of mutation to rifampicin (Rif) resistance. Sequenced the rpoB gene to identify mutations.
results: S. epidermidis exhibited lower viable counts but a higher frequency of mutation to Rif resistance in space compared to ground controls. The spectrum of mutations in the rpoB gene leading to RifR was altered in ISS isolates compared to GCs.
conclusions: The human spaceflight environment induces unique physiologic stresses on growing bacterial cells, leading to changes in mutagenic potential and antibiotic resistance.
relationships: Spaceflight environment -> altered bacterial physiology -> increased mutation rate -> antibiotic resistance.
insights: Spaceflight can alter the antibiotic resistance profiles of bacteria, potentially leading to the emergence of resistant strains in crew members. Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for long-term human space habitation.

title: Cultivation in space flight produces minimal alterations in the susceptibility of Bacillus subtilis cells to 72 different antibiotics and growth-inhibiting compounds
objective: To investigate whether wild Bacillus strains from two distinct lineages can evolve heat tolerance in their vegetative cells through experimental evolution and to identify the genetic mechanisms underlying their adaptations.
methodology: Experimental evolution was conducted on six wild Bacillus strains (Bacillus cereus and Bacillus subtilis) by exposing them to gradually increasing temperatures (from 43°C to 47°C over 90 days) and a constant temperature of 37°C. Growth kinetics, genome sequencing, and mutation analysis were performed to assess thermal adaptation strategies and genetic changes.
results: B. subtilis lineages showed a greater capacity to survive and adapt to increasing temperatures compared to B. cereus. Some B. subtilis lines grew successfully at up to 49°C. Convergent mutations were observed in genes involved in c-di-AMP synthesis, crucial for potassium transport, implicating this chemical messenger in heat tolerance.
conclusions: Bacillus strains exhibit limited thermal adaptation, with lineage-specific outcomes and trade-offs. Genetic background plays a critical role in shaping adaptive responses. Mutations in genes regulating c-di-AMP synthesis uncover its role in thermal tolerance. The findings raise concerns about bacterial communities' resilience to climate change and potential cascading effects on biogeochemical cycles and ecosystem stability.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between genetic background, phenotypic plasticity, and the ability of bacteria to adapt to thermal stress. It also reveals the connection between c-di-AMP synthesis, potassium transport, and heat tolerance in Bacillus strains.
insights: The study provides insights into the evolutionary constraints and potential pathways for bacterial adaptation to extreme heat, emphasizing the importance of genetic background and the role of c-di-AMP in thermal tolerance. It also warns about the potential vulnerability of bacterial communities to climate change and the need for further research to predict and mitigate its impacts on ecosystems.

title: Alterations in the Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB Gene after Cultivation in the Human Spaceflight Environment
objective: To measure the resistance of space- versus Earth-grown bacterial cells to a large battery of antibiotics to test the hypothesis that antibiotic resistance becomes enhanced during space flight.
methodology: Bacillus subtilis cells were cultivated in spaceflight microgravity on the International Space Station (FL) and at Earth-normal gravity (GC). The susceptibility of FL and GC samples was compared to 72 antibiotics and growth-inhibitory compounds using the Omnilog phenotype microarray (PM) system. Standard broth dilution assays were also used to determine the IC50s for a selection of antibiotics.
results: PM screening identified 9 compounds with statistically significant differences in FL versus GC samples. FL samples showed increased resistance to enoxacin, 6-mercaptopurine, and trifluoperazine, while GC samples showed increased resistance to lomefloxacin, nalidixic acid, penimepicycline, rolitetracycline, manganese(II) chloride, and cesium chloride. However, broth dilution assays showed no statistically significant differences in IC50s between FL and GC samples for any of the 10 antibiotics tested.
conclusions: Space flight causes only minimal alterations in the phenotypic response of B. subtilis cells to antibiotic susceptibility. The study does not support the notion that space flight increases the antibiotic resistance of microorganisms.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between spaceflight conditions and antibiotic resistance in bacteria. It investigates how microgravity and other spaceflight factors may influence the susceptibility of Bacillus subtilis to various antibiotics and growth inhibitors.
insights: The study suggests that the spaceflight environment does not significantly enhance antibiotic resistance in Bacillus subtilis. However, it acknowledges that other factors, such as the choice of growth media and culture conditions, may influence the response of microorganisms to spaceflight. Further research is needed to understand the complex interplay between the host, the microbe, and the antibiotic in the spaceflight environment.

title: Mechanotransduction in Prokaryotes: A Possible Mechanism of Spaceflight Adaptation
objective: To investigate the effect of Bacillus subtilis exposure to the human spaceflight environment on growth, mutagenic frequency, and spectrum of mutations to rifampicin resistance (RifR).
methodology: B. subtilis cells were cultivated in Biological Research in Canister-Petri Dish Fixation Units (BRIC-PDFUs) on two separate missions to the International Space Station (ISS), BRIC-18 and BRIC-21, with matching asynchronous ground controls. Growth was measured. Nucleotide sequencing of the RifR regions of the rpoB gene from RifR mutants was performed.
results: No statistically significant difference in either growth or in the frequency of mutation to RifR was found in either experiment. However, nucleotide sequencing of the RifR regions of the rpoB gene from RifR mutants revealed dramatic differences in the spectrum of mutations between flight (FL) and ground control (GC) samples, including two newly discovered rpoB alleles in the FL samples (Q137R and L489S).
conclusions: Exposure to the human spaceflight environment causes unique stresses on bacteria, leading to alterations in their mutagenic potential. Understanding microbial evolution in space is crucial to better cope with wide-ranging challenges, from biofilm formation to biocorrosion of materials to alterations in the human microbiome.
relationships: Mutations in rpoB have been shown to cause Rif-independent physiological effects in a wide range of bacterial species, including activation of cryptic metabolic capabilities, alterations in the susceptibility to other classes of antibiotics, or production of various secondary metabolites.
insights: The spaceflight environment can elicit specific spectra of mutations in B. subtilis. The mutations at Q137R and L489S were identified only in FL samples and have never before been observed in B. subtilis rpoB. These mutations may provide enhanced evolutionary fitness in the spaceflight environment itself.

title: Analysis of interactions of Salmonella type three secretion mutants with 3-D intestinal epithelial cells.
objective: To determine whether growth under differing selective pressures contributes to differences in the spectra of mutations in Bacillus subtilis.
methodology: Competition assay utilizing next-generation sequencing to quantify the fitness of multiple rpoB alleles in a mixed culture simultaneously. Population frequencies of 18 rpoB alleles were compared in mixed cultures grown in LB and SMMAsn media.  Pairwise competition experiments, assessments of exponential growth rates and lag times were also conducted.
results: Significant differences in the fitness of Rifampin-resistant (Rifr) mutant rpoB alleles were found in each medium. In LB, the wild-type allele dominated, whereas in SMMAsn, the H482N mutant became the dominant allele. Pairwise competition experiments confirmed these results.  The A478D mutant in LB acquired a secondary mutation (I528V) that increased its fitness.
conclusions: The fitness impacts of rpoB alleles vary in different environments. Growth rate is a poor proxy for relative fitness. Compensatory mutations in rpoB can recover fitness costs. The wild-type rpoB allele was most fit in nutrient-rich LB medium, while the H482N variant was most fit in minimal SMMAsn medium.
relationships: Mutations in rpoB, which confer rifampin resistance, can provide a fitness advantage or increased growth rate in the environment from which they were isolated. Changes in global gene expression are likely the cause of changes in fitness observed with mutations in rpoB.
insights: The study highlights the deficiencies of growth or metabolic metrics of monocultures as a sole measure of relative fitness and demonstrates the role of compensatory mutations in rpoB to recover fitness cost.  The environment plays a crucial role in dictating changes in the spectra of mutations.

title: Organotypic 3D cell culture models: using the rotating wall vessel to study host-pathogen interactions.
objective: To elucidate the role of Salmonella Type Three Secretion Systems (T3SSs) in the early stages of human enteric salmonellosis using a 3-D organotypic model of human colonic epithelium.
methodology: Infection of 3-D human colonic epithelium models (HT-29 cells grown in Rotating-Wall Vessels) and traditional monolayers with various Salmonella mutants (single, double, and triple T3SS knockouts). Assessment of bacterial invasion, intracellular localization, and growth via gentamicin protection assays, immunofluorescence microscopy, and confocal imaging. Identification of different epithelial cell types (M-cells, enterocytes, Paneth cells) within the 3-D aggregates and assessment of Salmonella targeting.
results: Salmonella can invade 3-D intestinal cells independently of all known Salmonella T3SSs (SPI-1, SPI-2, and flagellar T3SS). T3SS mutants exhibit reduced invasion levels compared to wildtype Salmonella. No preferential targeting of M-cells by Salmonella or T3SS mutants. T3SSs are required for substantial intracellular bacterial growth within 3-D cells.
conclusions: Salmonella invasion into 3-D intestinal cells does not require T3SSs, suggesting an alternative invasion mechanism. T3SSs contribute to a more productive invasion and are essential for intracellular replication. The 3-D model mimics in vivo observations of Salmonella infection more closely than traditional monolayer models.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between Salmonella T3SSs and their role in invasion and intracellular growth within human intestinal epithelial cells. It also investigates the interaction of Salmonella with different intestinal cell types (M-cells, enterocytes, and Paneth cells).
insights: The study challenges the prevailing paradigm that SPI-1 T3SS is essential for Salmonella invasion of intestinal epithelial cells. It highlights the importance of using in vivo-like models to study host-pathogen interactions and reveals a potential alternative invasion mechanism employed by Salmonella.

title: Induction of attachment-independent biofilm formation and repression of Hfq expression by low-fluid-shear culture of Staphylococcus aureus
objective: To establish and characterize 3D tissue models from oral and cervical cells for studying HPV host-pathogen interactions.
methodology: Two complementary methods were used: (1) growing primary human epithelial cells on a dermal equivalent (collagen and fibroblasts) at the liquid-air interface for organotypic raft cultures, and (2) using a rotating wall vessel (RWV) bioreactor with collagen-coated microbeads for 3D cellular aggregates.
results: The methods successfully generated 3D tissues from oral and cervical cells, mimicking morphological and biochemical aspects of in vivo tissue. These tissues were used for microscopic visualization, scanning-electron microscopy, and large-omics studies.
conclusions: The established 3D tissue models provide reliable and reproducible platforms for studying epithelial biology, the HPV life cycle, and host-pathogen interactions, addressing limitations of 2D monolayer cultures.
relationships: The 3D tissue models recapitulate the complexity of full-thickness epithelium, preserving cellular architecture and responding to external stimuli in ways that mimic the in vivo microenvironment. HPV infection is intricately linked to the differentiation status of the infected tissue and cells.
insights: These 3D models allow researchers to study how HPV (or other pathogens) interact with physiologically relevant tissues, and how the nature of the infected tissue (i.e., cervix or tonsillar crypts) plays a critical role in HPV-host interactions.

title: Induction of Attachment-Independent Bioﬁlm Formation and Repression of hfq Expression by Low-Fluid-Shear Culture of Staphylococcus aureus
objective: To determine the effect of low-fluid-shear culture on methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) and elucidate impacts on cellular responses, such as bioﬁlm formation, and to evaluate key regulators to determine the potential of a universally conserved response(s) to this environmental parameter.
methodology: S. aureus strains were cultured in rotating-wall vessel bioreactors (RWV) under low-fluid-shear (LSMMG) and control conditions. Cellular responses were evaluated through ESEM imaging, antibiotic resistance assays, growth profiles, carotenoid extraction, oxidative stress assays, whole-blood killing assays, microarray analysis, and quantitative reverse transcription-PCR.
results: Low-fluid-shear culture promoted attachment-independent bioﬁlm formation, increased antibiotic resistance, decreased growth, reduced carotenoid production, and enhanced susceptibility to oxidative stress and killing by human whole blood. Microarray analysis identified 17 upregulated genes involved in metabolic processes and stress response. Hfq expression was downregulated.
conclusions: S. aureus responds to a low-fluid-shear environment by initiating a bioﬁlm/colonization phenotype with diminished virulence characteristics. The downregulation of Hfq suggests a conserved response to fluid shear among prokaryotes. This response could potentially benefit S. aureus within the gastrointestinal tract and possibly other mucosal host sites, where it would experience low levels of fluid shear.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between low-fluid-shear conditions, biofilm formation, decreased virulence, and the downregulation of Hfq in S. aureus. It also highlights the potential role of the intestine as a site for S. aureus colonization and biofilm formation.
insights: Low-fluid-shear conditions, similar to those found in the intestine, trigger S. aureus to form biofilms and reduce virulence. This suggests that S. aureus may colonize the low-fluid-shear environment in the mucosa near the surface of epithelial cells, establishing a biofilm phenotype. The study identifies potential targets for intervention to prevent S. aureus colonization and infection.

title: Evaluation of microorganisms cultured from injured and repressed tissue regeneration sites in endangered giant aquatic Ozark Hellbender salamanders.
objective: To characterize the ydcI gene (STM1625) in Salmonella Typhimurium, focusing on its role in bacterial biology and the function of its protein product.
methodology: The study employed various methods including gene expression analysis (RT-PCR, LacZ assays), protein purification, gel shift assays, stress resistance assays (osmotic, thermal, acid), tissue culture invasion assays, macrophage survival assays, biofilm formation assays, and low fluid shear studies using a rotating-wall vessel bioreactor. Mutant strains were constructed using lambda Red recombination.
results: The ydcI gene is conserved across Gram-negative bacteria, is expressed in S. Typhimurium and other species, and is autoregulated. YdcI encodes a DNA-binding protein that binds specifically to its promoter region. A ydcI mutant showed reduced acid stress resistance. Induction of ydcI increased S. Typhimurium invasion of intestinal epithelial cells and promoted biofilm formation.
conclusions: The ydcI gene encodes a DNA-binding transcriptional regulator involved in bacterial stress resistance and potentially virulence. It is part of the rpoS regulon and plays a role in host cell interactions and biofilm formation. The study provides a foundation for further analysis of the YdcI protein and its role in prokaryotic biology.
relationships: The ydcI gene is part of the rpoS regulon. Induction of ydcI did not increase invasion by a SPI-1 strain, suggesting that ydcI possibly acts through the SPI-1 pathway for increased invasion.
insights: The YdcI protein negatively autoregulates its expression. YdcI may alter the expression of genes involved in SPI-1 type III secretion-mediated invasion of nonphagocytic cells or other genes in specific interactions with epithelial cells. The ydcI gene is not required for the low fluid shear phenotypes tested as part of this study.

title: Transcriptional and proteomic responses of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 to spaceflight conditions involve Hfq regulation and reveal a role for oxygen.
objective: To investigate the microbial communities associated with injured and regenerating tissues of the endangered Ozark Hellbender salamander to identify potential causes of their population decline.
methodology: Microbial cultures were taken from injured and uninjured tissues of Ozark Hellbenders. Samples were cultured on different media (blood agar, mannitol salts, Sabouraud's dextrose agar) to isolate and identify bacteria and fungi. Biochemical analysis and DNA sequencing were used for identification.
results: Common environmental flora were found in both injured and uninjured tissues. Opportunistic pathogens, including Aeromonas hydrophila, Granulicatella adiacens, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and various Pseudomonas species, were isolated only from injured tissues. Fungal isolates included Penicillium, Fusarium, and Cladosporium. Biofilm-forming organisms were also identified.
conclusions: The presence of opportunistic pathogens in injured tissues suggests a potential link to the decline in Ozark Hellbender populations. Multiple factors, including habitat degradation, introduced species, and suppressed immune function, may contribute to increased susceptibility to infection and impaired regeneration.
relationships: The study highlights the complex interplay between environmental factors, microbial communities, and the health of the Ozark Hellbender. Habitat degradation and introduced species may introduce pathogens or increase injury rates, while suppressed immune function may exacerbate infections.
insights: The decline in Ozark Hellbender populations is likely multifactorial, involving a combination of environmental stressors, opportunistic pathogens, and impaired immune function. Further research is needed to identify specific causative mechanisms and environmental factors contributing to the decline.

title: New insights into the bacterial fitness-associated mechanisms revealed by the characterization of large plasmids of an avian pathogenic E. coli
objective: To characterize the global transcriptional and translational responses of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 to the microgravity environment of spaceflight and assess whether spaceflight could induce virulence traits in P. aeruginosa, identifying conserved pathways with spaceflight-grown S. Typhimurium.
methodology: P. aeruginosa PAO1 was cultured in spaceflight and on the ground using a fluid-processing apparatus (FPA). RNA extraction, labeling, and Affymetrix GeneChip analysis were performed to analyze transcriptional responses. Proteins were identified using multidimensional protein identification technology (MudPIT) analysis and tandem mass spectrometry.
results: Spaceflight conditions induced 52 genes and downregulated 115 genes in P. aeruginosa PAO1. Hfq, an RNA binding protein, was identified as a key regulator. Genes involved in anaerobic metabolism were upregulated, while those involved in purine and pyrimidine metabolism, fatty acid biosynthesis, oxidative phosphorylation, and ribosome synthesis were downregulated. Several virulence factors, including lectins LecA and LecB, chitinase, and rhamnolipid-encoding gene rhlA, were induced.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions activated pathways in P. aeruginosa that are involved in the in vivo infection process. Hfq is a main transcriptional regulator in the spaceflight response of P. aeruginosa, representing the first transcriptional regulator commonly involved in the spaceflight responses of different bacterial species. The experimental setup and oxygen availability play a crucial role in the observed transcriptional differences.
relationships: The study compared gene expression profiles of P. aeruginosa with S. Typhimurium under spaceflight conditions, finding a significant overlap in downregulated genes. It also compared the spaceflight response of P. aeruginosa with its response to low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG), identifying similarities and differences in gene regulation.
insights: Spaceflight induces anaerobic metabolism and virulence factors in P. aeruginosa. Hfq plays a central role in the bacterial response to spaceflight. The study highlights the importance of considering experimental setup and oxygen availability when studying bacterial responses to microgravity.

title: Lack of norovirus replication and histo-blood group antigen expression in 3-dimensional intestinal epithelial cells
objective: To fully sequence and analyze the DNA of plasmids pChi7122-2, pChi7122-3, and pChi7122-4 of APEC strain x7122, and to evaluate the contribution of these plasmids, as well as plasmid pChi7122-1, either individually or in combination, in bacterial interaction with a model human intestinal epithelial cell line, bile and acid resistance, biofilm formation, and growth in iron-restricted medium and in the presence of different carbon sources. Also, to determine the effect of different host strain backgrounds on plasmid-associated phenotypes.
methodology: The study involved sequencing and analyzing plasmids from APEC strain x7122.  In vitro experiments were conducted using APEC derivative strains and E. coli K-12 strains with various plasmid combinations.  These strains were tested for biofilm formation, bile and acid tolerance, interaction with 3-D cultures of intestinal epithelial cells, and growth in different media.  PCR was used to assess the presence of specific genes in various E. coli strains.  Bioinformatic analysis was used to predict protein structures and functions.
results: The sequences of plasmids pChi7122-2, pChi7122-3, and pChi7122-4 were determined. pChi7122-2 encodes an ABC iron transport system (eitABCD) and a putative type IV fimbriae. pChi7122-4 is a cryptic plasmid. pChi7122-2 contains a gene cluster predicted to encode sugar catabolic pathways, similar to those found in Salmonella.  Plasmids influenced biofilm formation, bile and acid tolerance, and interaction with intestinal epithelial cells, with the effects varying depending on the plasmid combination and host strain background.  pChi7122-1 and pChi7122-2 were involved in bile resistance, while pChi7122-3 was involved in acid tolerance.  Different O-LPS structures also affected biofilm formation.
conclusions: The study revealed new insights into the genetic and phenotypic mechanisms that ExPEC may use for their persistence and survival in stressful conditions.  The plasmids pChi7122-2 and pChi7122-3 contain genes that could be important in the fitness and persistence of APEC x7122. Large plasmids were involved in bile resistance and acid tolerance. Multiple factor-driven biofilms expressed at different temperatures could have distinct functions. The genotypic and phenotypic analysis of plasmid-derivative strains of an ExPEC model strain x7122 revealed new insights into the mechanisms of fitness of ExPEC and their diversity.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between plasmids, bacterial fitness, and environmental conditions. It shows how different plasmids and their combinations can affect bacterial survival and virulence. It also demonstrates the importance of host strain background and temperature in determining the effects of plasmids on bacterial phenotypes.  The study also reveals potential zoonotic risks associated with APEC strains.
insights: The presence of specific plasmids can significantly impact the fitness and survival of ExPEC strains.  The ability of ExPEC to form biofilms, resist bile and acid, and utilize different carbon sources is influenced by plasmid content and environmental factors.  The study suggests that understanding the mechanisms of plasmid-mediated fitness is crucial for developing strategies to prevent and treat ExPEC infections. The discovery of sugar utilization pathways similar to Salmonella in E. coli plasmids suggests potential horizontal gene transfer and adaptation to different hosts.

title: Conservation of the low-shear modeled microgravity response in Enterobacteriaceae and analysis of the trp genes in this response.
objective: To investigate the replication of Norwalk virus (NV) in a 3-dimensional (3-D) organotypic model of human intestinal epithelium derived from the human embryonic intestinal epithelial cell line INT-407, and to determine the cause of cytopathic effects (CPE) observed in a previous study.
methodology: The study used a 3-D intestinal model derived from INT-407 cells. NV was purified from stool specimens and used to infect the 3-D cultures. Viral RNA levels were measured by qRT-PCR. Immunofluorescence microscopy was used to detect viral proteins and histo-blood group antigens (HBGA). FUT2 genotyping assays were performed. The cultures were also exposed to lipopolysaccharide (LPS) to determine its effect.
results: No evidence of NV replication was found by real-time PCR of viral RNA or by immunocytochemical detection of viral structural and nonstructural proteins. The 3-D cultures also showed no detectable presence of histo-blood group antigens that participate in NV binding and host tropism. Exposure to lipopolysaccharide concentrations consistent with contaminated stool samples resulted in morphologic features similar to CPE.
conclusions: The 3-D INT-407 model does not support NV replication. The CPE-like morphologic changes observed after NV inoculation were most likely a result of LPS within the virus inocula and not due to NV replication. The lack of HBGA carbohydrates on the surface of the intestinal cells further highlights that this model is likely not a sufficient model system to study NV replication.
relationships: Norovirus (NoV) has been identified as the primary etiologic agent of acute epidemic viral gastroenteritis in industrialized countries. Human-to-human transmission of NoV occurs primarily through the fecal-oral route, with the small intestine being the initial site of viral replication. Persons who lack a functional FUT2 gene cannot generate ABH antigens in secretions and, thus, are termed nonsecretors.
insights: The study suggests that the previously reported successful NV infection in the 3-D INT-407 model may have been due to contamination of the virus stocks with LPS. The absence of HBGA expression in the 3-D model indicates that it is not a suitable system for studying NV replication. Future attempts to develop in vitro systems to study NoV replication may include cultures derived from human primary intestinal cells and tissue explants, utilization of Caco-2 cells grown in RWV, use of 3-D intestinal immunocompetent coculture models, or human intestinal organoids derived from pluripotent stem cells.

title: Mimicking the host and its microenvironment in vitro for studying mucosal infections by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
objective: To analyze a range of Gram-negative Enterobacteriaceae for conservation of the low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) response using phenotypic assays, qPCR, and targeted mutations, and to analyze the role of the trp operon genes and the TrpR regulator in the LSMMG response.
methodology: Cultures were grown in a rotating wall vessel (RWV) in LB broth under LSMMG and control conditions. Stress assays (acid and oxidative) and qPCR were performed. Deletion mutations in trpR and trpDE genes were constructed using recombineering techniques in S. Typhimurium and E. coli.
results: LSMMG resulted in similar growth kinetics across Enterobacteriaceae. Acid stress resistance was decreased in LSMMG for S. Typhimurium but increased for E. coli. Oxidative stress resistance was decreased by LSMMG for all tested genera. qPCR analysis showed that a molecular response to LSMMG resulting in gene expression changes is conserved across Enterobacteriaceae, but the direction of gene expression change can vary. Deletion of TrpR had no effect on the acid and oxidative stress LSMMG responses.
conclusions: The response to the LSMMG growth environment is conserved across Enterobacteriaceae, but the direction of LSMMG-induced regulation of phenotypes and gene expression can vary depending on genus. The trp genes are not involved in the LSMMG response under the tested conditions.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between low fluid shear force environments and bacterial responses, particularly focusing on the conservation of this response across different members of the Enterobacteriaceae family. It also investigates the relationship between trp genes and the LSMMG/spaceflight response in bacteria.
insights: The LSMMG environment and related spaceflight conditions have the potential to be targeted to a range of Enterobacteriaceae genera. The variance in the direction of LSMMG regulation observed suggests that the underlying mechanisms for sensing this environmental signal are present in different cells, but their downstream effects can differ.

title: Mimicking the host and its microenvironment in vitro for studying mucosal infections by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
objective: To thoroughly understand the dynamic interplay between the host microenvironment and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and to recreate in vivo host-pathogen interactions in a physiologically relevant manner.
methodology: Review of existing in vitro cell and tissue culture model systems of increasing complexity, mainly focusing on lung models, and their respective advantages and limitations.
results: The review highlights that the choice of the model system, and the host characteristics that it mimics, can significantly impact the P. aeruginosa phenotype and outcome of the infection study.
conclusions: Continued improvements of in vitro models based on our expanding knowledge of host microenvironmental factors that participate in P. aeruginosa pathogenesis will help advance fundamental understanding of pathogenic mechanisms and increase the translational potential of research findings from bench to the patient’s bedside.
relationships: The host microenvironment affects virulence properties of P. aeruginosa. Mimicking the host microenvironment is essential for the development of in vitro infection models that better mimic in vivo phenotypes of P. aeruginosa, which will facilitate the design of novel efficacious antimicrobial treatments.
insights: Key host factors that protect the lung from P. aeruginosa infection and are altered during disease include physical factors (tight junctions, mucociliary escalator), chemical factors (antimicrobial substances, normoxia, low iron levels, neutral pH), and cellular factors (innate immune cells, epithelial cells, CFTR receptor, indigenous microbiota).

title: Hypotheses about sub-optimal hydration in the weeks before coronavirus disease (COVID-19) as a risk factor for dying from COVID-19
objective: To explore the link between chronic sub-optimal hydration and increased risk of COVID-19 mortality.
methodology: Review of experimental, clinical, and epidemiological evidence.
results: Sub-optimal hydration is associated with key risk factors for COVID-19 mortality, including older age, male sex, race-ethnicity and chronic disease. Chronic hypertonicity, total body water deficit and/or hypovolemia cause multiple intracellular and/or physiologic adaptations that preferentially retain body water and favor positive total body water balance when challenged by infection.
conclusions: Attention to hydration holds potential to reduce COVID-19 mortality and disparities via multiple pathways simultaneously.
relationships: Chronic sub-optimal hydration may lead to greater abundance of ACE2 receptors in the lung, exaggerated immune response, increased capillary leakage, and reduced fluid transport out of the airways, all contributing to increased COVID-19 mortality.
insights: Hydration may link risk factors and pathways in a unified mechanism for COVID-19 mortality. Strategies to limit COVID-19 mortality may need to account for multiple determinants of water retention, fluid entry into and fluid removal out of the lungs, simultaneously.

title: Three-dimensional organotypic co-culture model of intestinal epithelial cells and macrophages to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns.
objective: To evaluate the efficacy of a dynamic suspension bioreactor (RWV) in enhancing the recellularization of decellularized mouse lung scaffolds with bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) and alveolar type II epithelial cells (C10), and to assess the differentiation of MSCs within these scaffolds.
methodology: Decellularized mouse lung scaffolds were recellularized with MSCs or C10 cells and cultured under static or dynamic (RWV bioreactor) conditions. Recellularization efficiency was assessed by histology, total RNA quantification, and staining for apoptosis (Annexin V) and proliferation (PCNA). MSC differentiation was evaluated by gene expression analysis (qRT-PCR) and immunohistochemistry for lung epithelial, fibroblast, and osteogenic markers.
results: The RWV bioreactor enhanced recellularization efficiency and cell viability compared to static conditions for both MSCs and C10 cells. MSCs in the bioreactor exhibited increased expression of fibroblast markers (Fsp1, collagen I) and decreased expression of multipotency markers. Both static and bioreactor conditions induced expression of lung epithelial markers (AQP5, CCSP) in MSCs, but protein expression of CCSP was not confirmed. Static conditions promoted MSC cluster formation, while bioreactor conditions did not.
conclusions: Dynamic suspension culture in an RWV bioreactor improves the recellularization of decellularized lung scaffolds with MSCs and C10 cells. The bioreactor environment appears to promote MSC differentiation towards a fibroblast-like phenotype, potentially contributing to ECM remodeling. This approach holds promise for ex vivo lung tissue engineering and studying lung tissue homeostasis.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between culture conditions (static vs. dynamic bioreactor) and the recellularization efficiency and differentiation of MSCs and C10 cells in decellularized lung scaffolds. It also explores the relationship between MSC differentiation and ECM remodeling.
insights: Dynamic culture conditions can significantly enhance lung scaffold recellularization and influence stem cell differentiation. The RWV bioreactor provides a more favorable environment for cell survival and proliferation compared to static culture. MSCs may differentiate into fibroblast-like cells in the bioreactor, potentially contributing to ECM remodeling and scaffold regeneration.

title: Modeling Host-Pathogen Interactions in the Context of the Microenvironment: 3-D Cell Culture Comes of Age.
objective: To develop and validate a novel three-dimensional (3-D) co-culture infection model of colonic epithelial cells and macrophages to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns, mimicking the in vivo intestinal microenvironment.
methodology: A 3-D co-culture model was created using HT-29 colonic epithelial cells and U937 macrophages in a NASA Rotating Wall Vessel bioreactor. U937 cells were activated and bound to collagen-coated microcarrier beads before HT-29 cells were added. The model's characteristics were assessed using immunohistochemical profiling and bead uptake assays. Salmonella pathovars (Typhimurium SL1344 and D23580, Typhi Ty2) were used to infect the model under aerobic and microaerobic conditions. Colonization profiles were compared between the co-culture and epithelial models using a gentamicin protection assay.
results: The co-culture model exhibited in vivo-like structural and phenotypic characteristics, including 3-D architecture, apical-basolateral polarity, tight junctions, mucin, multiple epithelial cell types, and functional macrophages. All Salmonella strains exhibited decreased colonization in the co-culture model relative to the epithelial model, indicating antimicrobial function of macrophages. Pathovar-specific differences in colonization and intracellular co-localization patterns were observed. D23580 exhibited enhanced replication/survival following invasion.
conclusions: The 3-D co-culture model can discriminate between Salmonella pathovars and represents an innovative model for host-specific testing. It bridges knowledge gaps between 3-D epithelial models and in vivo studies to study host-pathogen interactions and unveil infectious disease mechanisms. The model is a step forward in mimicking the multicellular complexity of the parental tissue and its application to understand the synergistic contribution of different cell types to enteric host-pathogen interactions.
relationships: Macrophages exhibit antimicrobial function against Salmonella. Salmonella pathovars exhibit different colonization and intracellular co-localization patterns. D23580 exhibits enhanced replication/survival following invasion. Oxygen conditions influence invasion profiles.
insights: Incorporating macrophages into a 3-D intestinal epithelial model enhances its physiological relevance for studying Salmonella infections. The 3-D co-culture model provides a more accurate representation of the in vivo intestinal microenvironment compared to traditional 2-D monolayers or single-cell-type 3-D models. Microenvironmental factors, such as host multicellular complexity and oxygen levels, play important roles in regulating pathovar-specific invasion and host co-localization properties.

title: Evaluating the effect of spaceflight on the host‚Äìpathogen interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium
objective: To review selected 3-D models of human intestinal mucosa and highlight studies that have used these models to interrogate host-pathogen interactions and infectious disease mechanisms.
methodology: Review of literature on 3-D models of human intestinal mucosa, including organotypic cultures engineered in the rotating wall vessel (RWV) bioreactor, extracellular matrix (ECM)-embedded/organoid models, and organ-on-a-chip (OAC) models.
results: 3-D models provide a more physiologically relevant and predictive framework for investigating infectious disease mechanisms and antimicrobial therapies at the intersection of the host, microbe, and their local microenvironments. RWV models exhibit enhanced in vivo-like characteristics, including spontaneous differentiation into multiple cell types that self-organize into 3-D structures, polarization, and appropriate expression/localization of adherens/tight junctional complexes. Organoid models mimic endogenous tissues, including organization and spontaneous differentiation of multiple cell types into physiologically relevant 3-D structures. OAC models mimic key aspects of in vivo microenvironments, recreating a microscale model of the local 3-D architecture and spatial distribution of dynamic tissue interfaces to mimic tissue- and organ-level functions.
conclusions: 3-D intestinal models of increasing complexity better mimic the biological, chemical, and physical microenvironments of the endogenous tissue for studying host-microbe interactions. These models offer predictive in vitro translational platforms for infectious disease research. Continued model advancement will lead to increased translation of research discoveries to practical and significant outcomes.
relationships: The microenvironment includes 3-D tissue architecture, multiple cell types, ECM, innate immunity mediators, indigenous microbiota, and physical forces. These factors are regulatory signals for mucosal pathogens and may be beneficial or detrimental for infection. Bidirectional exchange of biological and physical signals between cells and their microenvironment regulates cell structure/function.
insights: Consideration of proper structure is essential for development of models that better mimic in vivo responses. Recreating host microenvironments is key, including 3-D tissue architecture, multicellular complexity, microbiota composition/localization, oxygen tension, transport processes, and biomechanical forces. The integration of biophysical forces across cells and tissues regulates a wide range of biological processes. Pathogen-ECM interactions play an important role in mediating infection.

title: Evaluating the effect of spaceﬂight on the host–pathogen interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium
objective: To investigate the impact of spaceflight on the interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells (HT-29) and Salmonella Typhimurium, focusing on transcriptomic and proteomic responses of both host and pathogen.
methodology: HT-29 cells were cultured in hollow fiber bioreactors and infected with Salmonella Typhimurium during spaceflight (STS-131 mission) and in ground controls. Dual RNA-seq and iTRAQ proteomic profiling were used to analyze gene and protein expression changes in both host and pathogen.
results: Spaceflight altered the transcriptional and proteomic profiles of both uninfected and infected host cells. Uninfected cells showed upregulation of genes related to IFN-I signaling and downregulation of bioenergetic pathways. Both flight and ground infections induced pro-inflammatory responses, but spaceflight also induced unique transcriptional and proteomic responses. Salmonella showed upregulation of metabolism and virulence related genes during spaceflight infection.
conclusions: Spaceflight modifies the host-pathogen interaction between intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium. The host cells exhibited a heightened response to infection during spaceflight, with increased expression of pro-inflammatory mediators and altered immune responses. These findings highlight the importance of considering infectious disease risks during spaceflight and suggest potential targets for countermeasures.
relationships: Spaceflight induced changes in the expression of structural proteins in uninfected cells, which may indicate an altered cytoskeletal landscape at the starting point for infection. The study also found that Salmonella infection induced a core set of pro-inflammatory responses in both conditions, but spaceflight culture also induced unique transcriptional and proteomic responses not observed in the identical ground controls.

title: Spaceflight enhances cell aggregation and random budding in Candida albicans.
objective: To investigate the impact of Candida albicans colonization on ethanol preference and related behaviors in mice, and to elucidate the role of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) in these effects.
methodology: Mice were colonized with C. albicans and subjected to two-bottle choice experiments (ethanol vs. water, saccharin vs. water). Serum PGE2 levels were measured. Some mice were injected with PGE2 derivatives or EP1/EP2 receptor antagonists. Gene expression in brain regions (dorsal striatum, prefrontal cortex, nucleus accumbens) was analyzed. Conditioned taste aversion (CTA), open field activity test (OFT), balance beam test, and loss of righting reflex (LORR) experiments were performed to assess behavioral effects.
results: C. albicans colonization reduced ethanol consumption and preference in mice. Colonized mice had elevated serum PGE2 levels. PGE2 injection reduced ethanol preference. EP1/EP2 receptor antagonism reversed the reduction in ethanol consumption. C. albicans colonization altered dopamine receptor expression in the dorsal striatum and accelerated ethanol-induced CTA. Colonized mice were more susceptible to ethanol-induced motor coordination impairment, which was reversed by EP receptor antagonism.
conclusions: C. albicans colonization influences ethanol preference and behavioral responses to ethanol in mice, mediated by PGE2 signaling and alterations in dopamine receptor expression. The gut fungal microbiome can impact host ethanol consumption and behavior.
relationships: C. albicans colonization elevates serum PGE2, which correlates with changes in EP and Drd receptor expression in the dorsal striatum. Altered dopamine receptor expression correlates with changes in ethanol consumption. C. albicans colonization and ethanol exposure synergistically affect motor coordination and sedation.
insights: The study reveals a novel link between the gut fungal microbiome, PGE2 signaling, and ethanol-related behaviors. It suggests that targeting the gut-brain axis and PGE2 pathways could offer new therapeutic avenues for alcohol use disorder.

title: Growth and antifungal resistance of the pathogenic yeast, Candida albicans, in the microgravity environment of the International Space Station: An aggregate of multiple flight experiences.
objective: To analyze the global transcriptional profile and phenotypic characteristics of Candida albicans grown in spaceflight conditions, comparing it to synchronous ground controls.
methodology: Candida albicans was cultured in spaceflight conditions on the International Space Station and in synchronous ground controls. Global transcriptional profiling via microarray analysis was performed. Phenotypic analysis included microscopy, flow cytometry, and virulence studies in mice via intraperitoneal injection.
results: Spaceflight-cultured C. albicans showed differential regulation of genes involved in cell aggregation, random budding, antifungal agent resistance, and oxidative stress resistance. Enhanced cell aggregation and random budding were observed. No increased virulence was observed in a murine infection model under the study's conditions.
conclusions: Spaceflight culture induces a self-aggregative phenotype in C. albicans and alters genes involved in stress and drug resistance. The low fluid-shear forces in spaceflight may mimic conditions in the human body, potentially revealing novel infectious disease mechanisms.
relationships: The study suggests a potential link between spaceflight conditions, gene expression changes, and virulence-related phenotypes in C. albicans. It also highlights the relevance of low fluid-shear forces to conditions encountered by pathogens during infection.
insights: Microgravity induces changes in gene expression that could lead to increased resistance to antifungals and environmental stressors. The study provides a basis for assessing the risk that commensal flora could pose during human spaceflight missions and identifies potential infectious disease mechanisms relevant to the general public.

title: Challenges and considerations for single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics sample collection during spaceflight.
objective: To develop a standardized pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments, promoting transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of data.
methodology: Development of a consensus pipeline (RCP) including quality control (FastQC, MultiQC), read trimming (TrimGalore), mapping (STAR), quantification (RSEM), and differential gene expression calculation/annotation (DESeq2).
results: The GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline (RCP) was developed and integrated into the GeneLab database. The pipeline processes data through distinct steps: data pre-processing, data processing, and differential gene expression computation/annotation. The RCP handles data preprocessing to trim sequencing adapters and to provide quality control metrics; data processing to map reads to the reference genome and quantify the number of read counts per gene; and differential gene expression calculation, which will provide a list of differentially expressed genes that can be sorted by adjusted p value and log fold-change.
conclusions: The RCP is specifically designed for RNA-seq data from short-read sequencers and has been developed in order to encourage and facilitate analysis of spaceflight multi-omic data. The creation of the RCP by a large community of scientists and the sharing of pipeline details in a peer-reviewed article provide analysis transparency and enable data reproducibility.
relationships: The pipeline integrates various software tools (FastQC, MultiQC, TrimGalore, STAR, RSEM, DESeq2) and databases (GeneLab, STRINGdb, PANTHER.db) to process and analyze RNA-seq data.
insights: The standardized pipeline allows for consistent processing of spaceflight-relevant multi-omics data, making it more accessible and reusable. It supports easier cross-analysis of experiments to identify effects resulting from the spaceflight environment, independent of confounding factors.

title: Direct RNA sequencing of astronaut blood reveals spaceflight-associated m6A increases and hematopoietic transcriptional responses
objective: To explore the growing importance of scRNA-seq and SRT in space biology and discuss challenges and considerations for robust experimental design to enable growth of these methods in the field.
methodology: Perspective piece discussing scRNA-seq and SRT experiments, tissue preservation protocols, and downstream computational tools. Analysis of existing scRNA-seq datasets from the Rodent Research Reference Mission-2 (RRRM-2) and NASA Twins Study.
results: Identified challenges in tissue collection and preservation for scRNA-seq and SRT in spaceflight. Highlighted the importance of rapid tissue preservation and potential of in-flight tissue dissection and live animal return (LAR) to improve data quality.
conclusions: Improved preservation protocols and innovative orbital lab solutions are needed to increase the quality of spaceflight multi-omic data. Results from scRNA-seq and SRT experiments conducted in spaceflight are expected to increase our understanding of life in space and facilitate the development of countermeasures against spaceflight-associated dysregulation and disease.
relationships: Explores the relationship between spaceflight conditions, molecular responses in the human body, and the potential of omics technologies to address health challenges in space.
insights: Spaceflight induces molecular responses in the body that can be robustly profiled using omics technologies. scRNA-seq and SRT have great potential for identifying dysregulated cell populations and enabling the development of more precise therapeutics and countermeasures.

title: Collection of biospecimens from the inspiration4 mission establishes the standards for the space omics and medical atlas (SOMA)
objective: To precisely describe the effects of spaceflight on human physiology at the molecular and cellular level, focusing on transcriptomic changes during a short-duration civilian spaceflight mission.
methodology: Long-read, direct RNA nanopore sequencing and Ultima high-coverage RNA-sequencing were performed on whole blood samples from four SpaceX Inspiration4 astronauts at seven timepoints (pre-flight, day of return, and post-flight recovery). Differential gene expression analysis (edgeR, DESeq2), gene set co-regulation analysis (GESECA), m6A modification analysis (methylKit), and de novo transcriptome analysis (StringTie, GffCompare) were conducted.
results: Key genetic pathways, including changes in erythrocyte regulation, stress induction, and immune changes, were affected by spaceflight. A significant spike in m6A methylation levels was observed immediately post-flight. Thousands of changes across several hundred specific genes were identified, recapitulating known stress markers of the vasculature and immune system, as well as signatures of m6A changes, isoform switching, and hematopoiesis regulation upon landing.
conclusions: Short-term spaceflight induces significant changes in the human transcriptome, particularly in hematological and immune systems. These changes include differential gene expression, m6A methylation, and isoform switching. The study provides a foundational functional genomics resource for human spaceflight and highlights the utility of long-read sequencing technologies in studying astronaut cohorts.
relationships: Identified relationships between spaceflight, gene expression, methylation patterns, and affected pathways (erythrocyte function, immune response). Showed correlation between nanopore and Ultima sequencing platforms. Linked observed changes to potential stressors of spaceflight (radiation, microgravity, circadian rhythm disruption).
insights: Spaceflight induces a unique signature of disrupted gene regulation, particularly in the hematological system. m6A methylation changes are most pronounced on the day of landing. Aberrant splicing in the crew was very low overall. The study identified novel transcript variants specific to certain timepoints, suggesting a specific response to spaceflight not previously observed.

title: Microfluidics-enabled method to identify modes of Caenorhabditis elegans paralysis in four anthelmintics.
objective: To establish standardized biospecimen sample collection and banking procedures for spaceflight, suitable for multi-omic and molecular analysis, to generate high-quality data across spaceflight investigations.
methodology: Longitudinal collection of biospecimens (venous blood, capillary dried blood spots, saliva, urine, stool, skin swabs, skin biopsies, environmental capsule swabs) from Inspiration4 crew members before, during, and after spaceflight. Samples were processed and biobanked at Weill Cornell Medicine. Multi-omic analyses were performed, including genomics, proteomics, metabolomics, microbiome, and transcriptomics.
results: Extensive biospecimen collection and processing were achieved. Data on sample yields (RNA, EVP, PBMC, plasma, serum, DNA from saliva and stool) were reported. The study generated comprehensive, multi-omic profiles of human responses to spaceflight.
conclusions: The study established a foundational set of methods for biospecimen collection and banking on commercial spaceflight missions. The SOMA protocols are robust and generalizable, applicable to future astronaut crews. Multi-omic datasets from spaceflight studies will advance understanding of human physiology, microbial adaptations, and environmental biology in space.
relationships: The study highlights the importance of standardized biospecimen collection for comparing data across different space missions. It emphasizes the need for longitudinal sampling and specimen aliquoting to address experimental variance. The study also discusses the potential for precision medicine applications in spaceflight.
insights: The study reveals novel responses across various omic measures in civilian astronauts during short-duration spaceflight. It underscores the importance of understanding the biological impact of spaceflight on individuals with diverse health profiles. Validating sample collection methodologies in short-duration commercial spaceflight is crucial for future long-duration missions.

title: Multiparameter behavioral analyses provide insights to mechanisms of cyanide resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.
objective: To characterize the modes of paralysis in C. elegans induced by anthelmintic drugs using a multi-parameter extraction method over an extended time period.
methodology: A microfluidic device with real-time imaging was used to expose C. elegans to four anthelmintic drugs (pyrantel, levamisole, tribendimidine, and methyridine) at equipotent concentrations (EC75). Worm behavior was quantified using parameters such as curls per second, types of paralyzation (crawling, curling, flailing), mode frequency, and number/duration of active/immobilization periods. A custom worm tracking software was used to analyze the movement.
results: Significant differences were observed in the manner with which worms paralyzed in different drug environments. Pyrantel and levamisole showed similar movement phenotypes with frequent curling. Methyridine induced a swimming-like motion. Tribendimidine resulted in shorter active periods and longer immobilization periods. Pyrantel was more effective than levamisole in immobilizing worms. Methyridine acts on a different subtype of nAChR receptors than the other three anthelmintics.
conclusions: The study highlights the need for assaying drug effects on small animal models with multiple parameters quantified at regular time points over an extended period to adequately capture the resistance and adaptability in chemical environments. The multi-parameter extraction method expands the repertoire of phenotypic characterization tools available in existing drug-based microfluidic devices.
relationships: Pyrantel and levamisole act on the same subtype of nAChR receptors (L-subtype). Tribendimidine affects C. elegans using a similar pathway as levamisole and hence belong to the same class of L-subtype nAChR agonists. Methyridine targets N-subtype nAChR receptors.
insights: The effectiveness of anthelmintic drugs can be differentiated by analyzing the patterns of worm adaptation, such as the frequency of body curls, mode transitions, and immobilization patterns. The number of active periods and time durations of immobilization could help compare the effectiveness of a single or a cocktail of multiple anthelmintics for single dose therapies where irreversible paralysis is desired.

title: Growth performance and root transcriptome remodeling of Arabidopsis in response to Mars-like levels of magnesium sulfate.
objective: To develop novel technologies to describe the effects of cyanide toxicity with high spatiotemporal resolution and examine the genetic underpinnings of cyanide resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans.
methodology: HCN gas exposure assays, microfluidic devices coupled to real-time imaging, RNA interference assays, and quantitative real-time PCR were used to assess worm motility and gene expression in response to cyanide.
results: egl-9-deficient animals were motile even after 2.5 h and foraged actively on the plates despite exposure to the toxicant. The cyanide resistance exhibited by egl-9 mutants is completely dependent on the HIF-1 hypoxia-inducible factor and is mediated by the cysl-2 cysteine synthase, which likely functions in metabolic pathways that inactivate cyanide. The expression of cysl-2 correlates with the degree of cyanide resistance exhibited in each genetic background.
conclusions: Mutations in egl-9 protect C. elegans from cyanide, and this resistance phenotype is dependent on the HIF-1 transcription factor. The expression of cysl-2 in each mutant correlates with the degree of cyanide resistance. The combination of C. elegans genetics and the microfluidics-enabled approaches and technologies developed here can be used to address many toxicological and biological questions.
relationships: The cyanide resistance exhibited by egl-9 mutants is completely dependent on the HIF-1 hypoxia-inducible factor and is mediated by the cysl-2 cysteine synthase.
insights: Multiparameter analyses of C. elegans behavior hold great potential as a means to monitor the effects of toxicants or chemical interventions in real time and to study the biological networks that underpin toxicant resistance. Microfluidics offered the opportunity to quantitate the responses to aqueous toxicants with superior spatiotemporal resolution, in a single and continuous plane of focus, at the individual worm level and in a much shorter period of time.

title: The 14-3-3 proteins of Arabidopsis regulate root growth and chloroplast development as components of the photosensory system.
objective: To understand the metabolic response of Arabidopsis plants to elevated magnesium sulfate levels, mimicking Mars-like soil conditions, and to identify genes that enhance tolerance to these conditions.
methodology:
1.  Grew Arabidopsis wildtype and mutant lines (mrs2-10, sel1-10, cax1-1, cax1/cax3) on soil with varying concentrations of magnesium sulfate.
2.  Measured shoot fresh weight biomass and leaf chlorophyll content.
3.  Conducted hydroponic experiments exposing Col-0 and cax1-1 roots to magnesium sulfate for varying durations.
4.  Performed microarray analysis to analyze root transcriptome remodeling.
5.  Used Q-PCR to validate gene expression changes.
results:
1.  mrs2-10 and sel1-10 lines showed no significant difference in growth compared to wildtype under magnesium sulfate stress.
2.  cax1-1 plants exhibited significantly higher shoot biomass and chlorophyll content than Col-0 at high magnesium sulfate concentrations.
3.  Transcriptome analysis revealed a large number of differentially expressed genes in Col-0 upon magnesium sulfate exposure, including hormone metabolism enzymes, transcription factors, calcium-binding proteins, and transporters.
4.  Only four unique transcripts showed significant differential expression between cax1-1 and Col-0 after 180 minutes of magnesium sulfate treatment.
conclusions:
1.  Knockout of Mg2+ and SO42- uptake transporters (mrs2-10, sel1-10) did not confer tolerance to magnesium sulfate.
2.  cax1 mutants exhibit partial tolerance to magnesium sulfate, suggesting a role for vacuolar Ca2+/H+ exchange in mitigating magnesium sulfate toxicity.
3.  The primary root transcriptome response involves a comprehensive set of genes related to hormone signaling, transcription, calcium regulation, and transport.
relationships:
1.  CAX1 knockout mutation leads to improved growth on MgSO4 enriched soil.
2.  Down-regulation of CAX1 expression in wildtype Arabidopsis is part of the natural response to elevated magnesium sulfate levels.
3.  ABA signaling may play a role in regulating the stress response to elevated magnesium sulfate.
insights:
1.  Magnesium toxicity, rather than sulfate toxicity, is the dominant factor limiting plant growth in Mars-like magnesium sulfate conditions.
2.  Vacuolar storage of excess magnesium and sulfate ions is a key defense mechanism against magnesium sulfate stress.
3.  The study identifies a subset of candidate genes for enhancing plant tolerance to magnesium sulfate, providing a basis for developing Mars soil-compatible plants.

title: 14-3-3 phosphoprotein interaction networks - does isoform diversity present functional interaction specification?
objective: To examine the roles of individual 14-3-3 isoforms in root elongation and chloroplast development, controlled by the photosensory system, using T-DNA insertion mutants of 14-3-3 l and t.
methodology: Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion mutants (14-3-3 l and t) were grown under various light conditions (constant light, red light, blue light, dark) on MS media. Root lengths were measured, and chloroplast development was visualized using fluorescent and confocal microscopy. Nitrate reductase activity was factored out by growing plants on nitrate-free media. Quantitative analysis of red tonal levels in root images was performed.
results: 14-3-3l-1 mutants exhibited shorter roots than wild-type under constant light, with root length influenced by light intensity. 14-3-3t mutants showed wild-type root length under constant light but shorter roots under red light. 14-3-3 T-DNA insertion mutants and CO mutants developed increased numbers of chloroplasts during early development. Blue light stimulated more root chloroplast development than red light. Decreased root length of 14-3-3l-1 was not due to altered nitrate reductase activity.
conclusions: 14-3-3 proteins play novel roles in root growth and chloroplast development. 14-3-3 l is important for root growth, while 14-3-3 t affects root length under red light. The photosensory system mediates the root development phenotypes exhibited by these 14-3-3 T-DNA insertion mutants. 14-3-3 proteins and CO are negative regulators of chloroplast development in the roots.
relationships: 14-3-3 proteins interact with nitrate reductase and components of the photosensory system, including phytochromes and cryptochromes. CO interacts with 14-3-3 proteins and is implicated in red-light signaling. PHYB influences root elongation and chloroplast development, similar to 14-3-3l-1.
insights: 14-3-3 isoforms have specific roles in root and chloroplast development. Light intensity and wavelength influence these roles. 14-3-3 proteins and CO are key components of the plant interactome, regulating light responses and developmental processes. The study identifies a novel role for CO in root chloroplast development.

title: Plant growth strategies are remodeled by spaceflight
objective: To examine the evolutionary and biochemical diversity of 14-3-3 proteins and question whether this diversity has any intrinsic biochemical, cellular, or physiological significance.
methodology: The study discusses key observations on both sides of the debate regarding functional diversity among 14-3-3 isoforms, presenting contrastable observations to address the theory that functional diversity exists among 14-3-3 isoforms. It involves sequence alignment of Arabidopsis 14-3-3 proteins, mapping amino acid conservation onto protein structure, and analyzing existing literature and experimental data.
results: The model suggests that there are functional specificities in the 14-3-3s of Arabidopsis. The study identifies phosphorylation events and dimerization patterns that could lead to increased functional specificity within 14-3-3s.
conclusions: True cellular and biochemical functional specificity exists among members of the 14-3-3 family. This specificity is amplified by phosphorylation and heterodimerization. Certain 14-3-3s in a given cellular context will have specific interactions not shared with others, leading to distinct functional phenotypes.
relationships: 14-3-3 proteins interact with phosphorylated peptide sequences through sequence-specific motifs. They also interact with client proteins, influencing their conformation, activity, localization, or association within larger protein complexes. Dimerization between different 14-3-3s is variable and depends on intrinsic affinities, expression levels, and phosphorylation status.
insights: The diversity in primary structure of 14-3-3s in plants, amplified by phosphorylation and heterodimerization, leads to biochemical, cellular, and physiological impacts. Functional specificity is context-dependent and can be revealed by TDNA mutations and biochemical assays. Subcellular localization is a powerful indicator of 14-3-3 specificity among isoforms.

title: Spaceflight transcriptomes: unique responses to a novel environment.
objective: To evaluate the effects of GTSs on intestinal microecological disorders and impaired immune function caused by simulated weightlessness.
methodology: A hindlimb suspension (HLS) rat model was used to simulate weightlessness. Rats were divided into control, HLS, and HLS treated with GTSs groups. Intestinal injury was assessed through pathological analysis, RT-PCR, transcriptome analysis, 16S rRNA gene sequencing to examine gut microbiome composition, and short-chain fatty acid analysis.
results: GTSs intervention improved intestinal injury caused by simulated weightlessness, including reducing pathological damage, increasing tight junction protein expression, and reducing inflammatory factor levels. GTSs treatment restored intestinal immunity-related gene levels and remodeled the gut microbiota, increasing the abundance of short-chain fatty acid metabolism-related bacteria and the levels of propionic acid, butyric acid, and isobutyric acid.
