conclusions: GTSs improved intestinal microecological disorders and impaired immune function caused by weightlessness simulation. The underlying mechanism may be related to the 'intestinal immune -microbiota-metabolic' pathway, providing a theoretical basis for developing GTSs for space-health products.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between microgravity, intestinal microecology, immune function, and the potential of GTSs to modulate these factors. It also explores the connection between gut microbiota composition, short-chain fatty acid production, and intestinal health.
insights: The findings suggest that GTSs can be a promising intervention to mitigate the adverse effects of spaceflight on intestinal health by modulating the gut microbiota, improving intestinal barrier function, and restoring immune homeostasis.

title: Fundamental plant biology enabled by the space shuttle.
objective: To understand the molecular and physiological responses of Arabidopsis thaliana to spaceflight environmental stress, specifically microgravity, using integrative transcriptomics and proteomics approaches.
methodology: Arabidopsis seedlings were germinated and grown in microgravity aboard the International Space Station (ISS) and on Earth as a ground control. RNA-seq transcriptomics and TMT-labeled LC-MS/MS proteomic analysis were performed on cellular fractionates from plant tissues. Data analysis included sequence quality checks, alignment to the TAIR10 assembly, differential expression determination using DESeq2, and protein identification using Proteome Discoverer 2.4.
results: Spaceflight altered the photosynthetic machinery (PSII and PSI), with plants shifting photosystem core-regulatory proteins in an organ-specific manner. There was significant abundance of transcripts and proteins involved in protease binding, nuclease activities, and mRNA binding in spaceflight, while those involved in tRNA binding, exoribonuclease activity, and RNA helicase activity were less abundant. CELLULOSE SYNTHASES and CELLULOSE-LIKE PROTEINS had reduced abundance in spaceflight, contrasting with increased expression of UDP-ARABINOPYRANOSE MUTASEs. Altered polar auxin redistribution, lipid, and ionic intracellular transportation were also observed. An increased metabolic energy requirement was suggested, leading to activation of shunt metabolic pathways.
conclusions: Plants adapt to the spaceflight environment by altering their photosynthetic machinery, cell wall composition, and intracellular transport mechanisms. The study provides insights into how plants respond to microgravity at the molecular level, contributing to the understanding of sustainable crop production in space.
relationships: The study highlights the complex interplay between transcriptomic and proteomic responses in plants adapting to spaceflight. It reveals organ-specific adaptations and the involvement of various metabolic pathways in the plant's response to microgravity.
insights: Plants in spaceflight exhibit significant molecular adaptations, including alterations in photosynthesis, cell wall structure, and intracellular transport. These adaptations are organ-specific and involve complex regulatory mechanisms. The findings contribute to the understanding of plant stress responses and have implications for developing resilient crops for both space and Earth environments.

title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To investigate and characterize the molecular phenotype of an Aspergillus niger strain isolated from surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS) and compare it to Earth isolates.
methodology: The study involved whole-genome sequencing, phylogenetic analysis, visual characterization, growth rate assessment, and proteomic analysis (TMT labeling and LC-MS/MS) of the ISS A. niger isolate (JSC-093350089) and a terrestrial reference strain (ATCC 1015).
results: The ISS isolate's genome was within the genetic variance of other A. niger strains. It exhibited increased growth rate and pigment distribution compared to the terrestrial strain. Proteomic analysis revealed increased abundance of proteins involved in starvation response, oxidative stress resistance, cell wall modulation, and nutrient acquisition in the ISS isolate.
conclusions: The ISS A. niger isolate exhibits a distinct molecular phenotype characterized by adaptations to the space environment, including increased melanin production, enhanced stress response, and efficient nutrient acquisition. These adaptations may be crucial for survival in the harsh conditions of the ISS.
relationships: The ISS isolate showed a close phylogenetic relationship to A. niger (phoenicis). Compared to ATCC 1015 and CBS 513.88, it differed by 37,548 and 39,433 variants, respectively.
insights: The study provides insights into the adaptive mechanisms of fungi in extreme environments and highlights the importance of understanding microbial responses to spaceflight for long-duration space missions. The increased melanin production and enhanced stress response suggest key traits necessary to withstand the ISS environment.

title: A method for preparing spaceflight RNAlater-fixed Arabidopsis thaliana (Brassicaceae) tissue for scanning electron microscopy.
objective: To investigate the effect of spaceflight on the growth, morphology, and transcriptome profiles of Brachypodium distachyon seedlings, a genetic model for monocots, under microgravity conditions on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Brachypodium distachyon seedlings (Bd21, Bd21-3, and Gaz8 accessions) were grown in a custom-designed APEX Growth Unit on the ISS and in ground controls. Seedling growth, root-hair length, and transcriptomic profiles (RNA-seq) were analyzed after a 4-day growth period. Differential gene expression was assessed using DEseq and EdgeR statistical packages. Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis was performed to identify biological processes affected by microgravity.
results: Microgravity-exposed seedling roots were shorter than ground controls. Bd21 shoots grew slower under microgravity, while Bd21-3 and Gaz8 shoots grew similarly in both conditions. Root hairs were longer in microgravity-exposed seedlings. Transcriptomic analysis revealed accession-specific responses to microgravity, with distinct gene expression profiles in shoots and roots. Photosynthesis-related genes were generally down-regulated under microgravity. Genes associated with oxidative stress response, cell wall remodeling, and hormone signaling were differentially expressed.
conclusions: Brachypodium distachyon seedlings exhibit accession- and organ-specific responses to the microgravity environment of the ISS. These responses involve oxidative stress, cell wall remodeling, photosynthesis inhibition, and altered expression of genes related to transcription and post-translational modifications. The study suggests the need to directly evaluate candidate-crop responses to microgravity to develop cultivation strategies for spaceflight.
relationships: The study suggests a connection between retrograde signaling, light response, and decreased expression of photosynthesis-related genes in microgravity-exposed shoots. It also indicates a potential role for PHYTOCHROME-INTERACTING FACTOR1 (PIF1) in mediating the effect of microgravity on photosynthesis-related processes.
insights: The findings highlight the importance of considering genetic variation and organ-specific responses when studying plant adaptation to spaceflight. The down-regulation of photosynthesis-related genes under microgravity suggests a potential challenge for bioregenerative life support systems in space, warranting further investigation into mechanisms to enhance photosynthetic efficiency in space-grown crops.

title: ARG1 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight
objective: To explore the possibility of using RNA later-fixed materials for standard SEM-based morphometric investigation to maximize usage of samples returned from spaceflight and other situations where recovery of biological resources is limited.
methodology: RNA later-fixed Arabidopsis thaliana samples were desalinated, dehydrated through graded methanol, plunged into liquid ethane, freeze-substituted, critical point dried, mounted, sputter-coated, and imaged using scanning electron microscopy (SEM).
results: The protocol resulted in acceptable SEM images from RNA later-fixed Arabidopsis thaliana tissue. The majority of the tissues remained intact, including general morphology and finer details such as root hairs and trichomes. Spaceflight materials and corresponding ground controls yielded images of acceptable quality, with minimal cell wrinkling and high retention of fine details.
conclusions: The protocol provides distinct advantages for both spaceflight and ground-based experimental applications, allowing for more morphological opportunities for samples that would have previously been wasted due to improper fixation. Field studies may also benefit from the use of one stable, safe chemical fixative for all desired studies.
relationships: The study demonstrates a method to bridge molecular and morphological studies by using a single fixative (RNA later) for SEM imaging, which is typically used for molecular analysis. It also compares the results with fresh-frozen tissues and dedicated morphologic means.
insights: RNA later, primarily used as a molecular fixative, can be adapted for SEM imaging with a modified protocol. This approach allows for the preservation of tissue morphology and fine details, enabling comprehensive analysis of samples, especially when resources are limited.

title: A Member of the CONSTANS-Like Protein Family is a Putative Regulator of ROS Homeostasis and Spaceflight Physiological Adaptation
objective: To understand the role of Altered response to gravity 1 (Arg1) in the physiological adaptation of undifferentiated plant cells to spaceflight, by comparing gene expression profiles of wild-type Arabidopsis thaliana and an ARG1 knock-out line in spaceflight and ground conditions.
methodology: Cultured Arabidopsis thaliana cell lines (wild-type and ARG1 knock-out) were grown in spaceflight and ground control conditions. Gene expression was analyzed using microarrays to identify differentially expressed genes between spaceflight and ground, and between the two genotypes. Functional gene categorization and real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) were used to validate the microarray data.
results: 78 genes were differentially expressed in wild-type cells in spaceflight, while 130 genes were differentially expressed in ARG1 knock-out cells. The majority of genes engaged in the physiological adaptation to spaceflight in ARG1 KO cells were fundamentally different than those engaged in WT cells. Arg1 mutation significantly affected the expression of genes related to the plasma membrane, membrane, and cell periphery.
conclusions: ARG1 plays a significant role in the physiological adaptation of plant cells to spaceflight. The absence of functional Arg1 leads to the engagement of a unique gene expression strategy, highlighting alternative pathways for spaceflight adaptation. The genotype of the cell significantly influences the genes involved in spaceflight adaptation.
relationships: ARG1 is connected to gravity perception in undifferentiated cells, suggesting a universal, cell-type independent tool for gravity sensing in plants. The endomembrane system, intracellular transport, and vesicle trafficking genes were also a large part of the WT physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment, although the individual representative genes differed from those engaged in the ARG1 KO cells.
insights: Spaceflight adaptation involves more than just changes in gene expression in wild-type cells; it also requires maintaining certain gene activities at specific levels. The study reveals that the genetic requirements for spaceflight adaptation are more complex than previously understood, with the physiological state of a cell significantly impacting the expression profile of genes needed for adaptation.

title: HSFA2 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight.
objective: To investigate the role of a previously uncharacterized gene (OMG1) in reactive oxygen species (ROS) related functions and its potential involvement in spaceflight physiological adaptation in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Analysis of spaceflight transcriptomes (APEX01, APEX03-2) using ROSMETER, qRT-PCR, histochemical GUS staining, fluorescent biochemical ROS assays (DCF-DA, luminol-based), phylogenetic analysis, protein structural modeling, and subcellular localization studies using transgenic plants and tobacco leaves.
results: OMG1 expression is upregulated in the WS ecotype of Arabidopsis thaliana during spaceflight. OMG1 promoter activity is observed in roots, pollen tubes, and upon wounding. OMG1 regulates the expression of MYB77 and GRX480, which are associated with the ROS pathway. ROS accumulation upon wounding and flg22 induction is altered in omg1 knockout leaves. OMG1 is identified as a member of the CONSTANS-Like protein family and localizes to the nucleus.
conclusions: OMG1 is a CCT domain transcriptional regulator of ROS homeostasis, important for the physiological adaptation of Arabidopsis ecotype WS to spaceflight. Spaceflight experiments are useful platforms to discover novel gene functions and provide insights into terrestrial plant biology. The response to spaceflight is genotype-specific. ROS homeostasis plays an important role as plants physiologically adapt to spaceflight. The CONSTANS-Like family contains members that function beyond clock and timing roles, including ROS signaling.
relationships: OMG1 regulates MYB77 and GRX480, genes associated with ROS pathways. OMG1 affects ROS production and is related to the COL11-12 lineage of CONSTANS-Like proteins.
insights: Spaceflight induces differential expression of ROS-producing genes in an ecotype-dependent manner. OMG1 transcript is consistently upregulated in the WS ecotype during spaceflight and is induced rapidly upon wounding. OMG1 is associated with the regulation of ROS and is a member of the CONSTANS-Like protein family.

title: Neutrophil to Lymphocyte ratio: A biomarker to monitor the immune status of astronauts.
objective: To ascertain whether the Heat Shock Factor (HSF) network functions in the adaptation to the novel environment of spaceflight, specifically focusing on the role of Heat Shock Factor A2 (HsfA2) in undifferentiated plant cells.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana cell cultures (wild type and HSFA2 knockout line) were grown aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Microarray gene expression data were analyzed using comparative approaches: (1) comparing gene expression between spaceflight and ground conditions within the same genotype, and (2) comparing gene expression between the two genotypes within the same environment.
results: HSFA2 KO cells showed endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and unfolded protein response (UPR) irrespective of the environment. HsfA2 has specific roles in adaptation to spaceflight through cell wall remodeling, signal perception and transduction, and starch biosynthesis. Disabling HsfA2 altered the physiological state of the cells and impacted the mechanisms induced to adapt to spaceflight.
conclusions: The HSF network, particularly HSFA2, plays a non-thermal role in spaceflight adaptation. Proficient spaceflight adaptation requires a functional HSF network. HSFA2 is involved in cell wall and plasma membrane signaling, as well as starch biosynthesis. Disabling HsfA2 leads to ER stress and alters adaptation to spaceflight.
relationships: HSFA2 KO cells exhibit ER stress regardless of the environment, suggesting a deficiency in chaperone-mediated protein folding. HSFA2 influences cell wall architecture, signal transduction, and starch biosynthesis in response to spaceflight. The study identifies genes required for spaceflight adaptation and genes whose expression is corrected in HSFA2 KO cells to match wild-type levels.
insights: Spaceflight adaptation requires de novo protein synthesis, maturation, and transport. HSFA2 is crucial for cellular protein homeostasis. HSFA2 KO cells activate the UPR as part of their adaptation strategy, indicating compromised protein folding ability. HSFA2 plays a role in cell wall remodeling, potentially influencing the cell's response to microgravity.

title: Beyond low-Earth orbit: Characterizing immune and microRNA differentials following simulated deep spaceflight conditions in mice.
objective: To evaluate the neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) as a potential biomarker for assessing in-flight astronaut immune health during long-duration space missions, and to understand the mechanisms involved in NLR elevation under simulated microgravity conditions.
methodology: Analysis of complete blood count (CBC) leukocyte differentials from spaceflight-treated rodents and astronauts. In vitro simulation of microgravity using high-aspect rotating wall vessels (HARV-RWV) with human leukocytes. In vivo simulation of microgravity using hindlimb unloaded (HU) mice, including wildtype and mitochondrial catalase-transgenic mice. Flow cytometry, qPCR.
results: Spaceflight increased NLR in rodents and granulocyte-to-lymphocyte ratio (GLR) in astronauts. HARV-RWV simulation increased granulocyte percentage and absolute counts, reduced lymphocyte percentage, and increased GLR and NLR in human leukocytes. HU mice displayed elevated neutrophils and NLR. Antioxidant treatment reversed the effects.
conclusions: Elevated NLR may be a suitable prognostic biomarker to monitor astronaut immune status and inflammation during long-duration missions. Modifying mechanisms involved in ROS-driven inflammation may provide a promising avenue to limit chronic inflammation and maintain homeostatic immunity during long-duration missions.
relationships: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity models caused elevated NLR, indicating this as a potential biomarker for future in-flight immune health monitoring. Elevated ROS and MPO inflammation, while antioxidants mitigated some of these outcomes.
insights: Spaceflight causes immune dysfunction that can lead to health risks for astronauts. Monitoring distinct biomarkers, such as elevated NLR, can determine when countermeasures can intervene to avert immune dysfunction, promote immune recovery, and prevent disease development.

title: Immunological and hematological outcomes following protracted low dose/low dose rate ionizing radiation and simulated microgravity
objective: To investigate the immediate-early immune effects following acute simulated galactic cosmic ray (GCR) and solar particle event (SPE) irradiation, singly or in combination with simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading, HU) in mice, and to describe the contributing role of circulating microRNAs (miRNAs) on the immune profile.
methodology: Mice were exposed to acute, 0.5-Gy simplified GCR simulation, 1-Gy SPE simulation, or 5Gy gamma irradiation, singly or in combination with HU (14 days total). Immune cell populations in blood and immune organs were analyzed using flow cytometry. Cytokine levels in whole blood were measured by qPCR. Circulating miRNA profiles in plasma were assessed using miRNA sequencing. Data from astronauts on International Space Station missions were re-purposed to characterize inflammation during spaceflight.
results: Simulated deep space exposures caused reduced immune organ weight and total leukocyte populations. Innate immune profiles revealed distinct populations following simulated deep space exposures. Adaptive immune profiles revealed select B, T helper, and T cytotoxic lymphocytes were negatively impacted by simulated deep space exposures. Lymphocyte surface expression of IL-7R was impacted by simulated deep space exposures, with elevated neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (NLR). Simulated deep space exposures induced unique cytokine profiles. miRNA profiling revealed a relationship to immune dysfunction in simulated deep space exposures. Elevated inflammation was observed in astronauts on ISS missions in LEO.
conclusions: Distinct immune profiles and miRNA signatures are produced by each irradiation exposure group, singly or in combination with HU in mice. These results demonstrate that differential immune profiles are probable throughout the course of long-duration, exploratory missions in deep space and describe circulating immune biomarkers (i.e., select cell types and miRNAs) as potential therapeutic targets to regulate immunity. Select countermeasures targeting distinct immune responses in crew members may be required during long-duration exploratory missions to the lunar surface and Mars.
relationships: The study establishes relationships between simulated deep space conditions (radiation and microgravity), immune system dysfunction, miRNA expression, and inflammation. It also draws parallels between the mouse model and astronaut data, suggesting that similar immune dysregulation may occur during spaceflight.
insights: Deep spaceflight exposures present immunologically complicated outcomes. Synergistic inflammatory or immunogenic responses were variable in some, but not all, measurements, and in some cases were non-productive. Circulating miRNAs contribute to unique immune profiles, therefore miRNAs may be important for immune-targeted therapies. Selective countermeasures targeting distinct immune responses in crew members may be required during long-duration exploratory missions to the lunar surface and Mars.

title: Epigenomic regulators elongator complex subunit 2 and methyltransferase 1 differentially condition the spaceflight response in Arabidopsis
objective: To assess the effects of simulated spaceflight conditions (low-dose radiation and hindlimb unloading) on the immune and hematological systems of mice, focusing on readaptation after exposure.
methodology: Mice were subjected to 21 days of simulated spaceflight (hindlimb unloading and low-dose gamma irradiation). Blood and spleen samples were collected 7 days post-exposure. Hematological analysis was performed on blood samples, and RNA sequencing was conducted on spleen tissue to analyze gene expression.
results: Simulated spaceflight resulted in distinct gene expression profiles in the spleen, with dysregulation of genes involved in signal transduction, metabolism, cell cycle, DNA repair, and chromatin organization. Hematological analysis revealed reduced red blood cell counts and hemoglobin levels, indicative of anemia, but minimal changes in white blood cell differentials. Specific genes related to blood disorders and inflammation were also identified.
conclusions: Recovery from simulated spaceflight induces systemic stress, leading to persistent inflammation and anemia. Altered gene expression in the spleen suggests dysregulation of key pathways involved in immune function and blood cell production. These findings highlight potential targets for therapeutic intervention to promote homeostasis during readaptation to Earth's gravity or reduced gravity environments.
relationships: Identified interconnected genes (Bcl11a, Aspn, and Nedd4l) regulate blood pressure, B cell differentiation, and TGF-βR signaling, suggesting potential countermeasures for immune and cardiovascular disparities during readaptation.
insights: The study provides insights into the immediate early immune and hematological pathways engaged post-simulated spaceflight, suggesting suitable time points for therapeutic intervention to promote homeostasis and restoration. The findings also highlight the importance of regulating specific biomarkers, such as RDW, for future spaceflight studies.

title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress-associated transcriptomes that inform prospects for lunar exploration
objective: Investigate the role of specific epigenomic changes, particularly DNA methylation, in determining the physiological adaptation of plants to the spaceflight environment.
methodology: Grew Arabidopsis thaliana (wild-type Col-0, and mutants met1-7 and elp2-5) on the International Space Station (ISS) and in ground controls. Analyzed growth patterns, genome-wide methylation profiles (WGBS), and differential gene expression profiles (RNASeq).
results: The elp2-5 plants showed impaired root development in spaceflight. The met1-7 plants morphology was similar to Col-0 controls. Spaceflight transcriptomes differed significantly between the mutants and Col-0. Spaceflight increased genome-wide DNA methylation levels in met1-7 and elp2-5, but not in Col-0. Changes in DNA methylation were associated with protein-coding gene regions.
conclusions: Genetic factors influencing DNA methylation directly impact physiological adaptation to spaceflight. Processes regulated by ELP2 are critical for root directional development in spaceflight. Epigenetic marking is a fundamental part of environmental responses, even during novel environmental stresses.
relationships: Spaceflight responses mimic terrestrial stress responses. MET1 and ELP2 affect methylation through different mechanisms, suggesting spaceflight affects methylation of specific genes more than genome-wide methylation status. There is a complex relationship between DNA methylation and gene expression in spaceflight, differing between leaves and roots.
insights: DNA methylation plays a crucial role in regulating stress responses and physiological adaptation in plants during spaceflight. ELP2 is important for root directional development and gravity perception. The spaceflight response utilizes mechanistic approaches employed during terrestrial environmental stress.

title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress-associated transcriptomes that inform prospects for lunar exploration
objective: To determine if plants can grow in lunar regolith and identify the metabolic strategies used to adapt to this environment.
methodology: Arabidopsis thaliana plants were grown in lunar regolith samples from Apollo 11, 12, and 17 missions, as well as a lunar simulant (JSC-1A) as a control. Plant growth was monitored, and transcriptome analyses were performed to assess gene expression.
results: Plants germinated and grew in lunar regolith, but exhibited slower development and stress morphologies compared to the control group. Transcriptome analyses revealed differential gene expression indicative of ionic, salt, metal, and reactive oxygen species stresses. The severity of stress responses varied depending on the lunar regolith source and plant morphology.
conclusions: Lunar regolith can support plant growth, but it is not a benign substrate and elicits stress responses in plants. The maturity of the regolith affects plant growth, with immature regolith being a better substrate than mature regolith. Further optimization is needed before lunar regolith can be considered a routine in-situ resource for plant production.
relationships: The study highlights the interaction between terrestrial plants and lunar regolith, revealing the challenges and potential for using lunar resources for life support in lunar habitats. It also demonstrates the importance of understanding plant stress responses in extraterrestrial environments.
insights: Plants can grow in lunar regolith, but they experience stress due to the regolith's composition and physical characteristics. The study provides insights into the genes and metabolic pathways involved in plant adaptation to lunar regolith, which can inform strategies for improving plant growth in lunar habitats.

title: Utilizing the KSC fixation tube to conduct human-tended plant biology experiments on a suborbital spaceflight
objective: To understand the effects of spaceflight on the fly nervous system and the value of artificial gravity (AG) as a countermeasure.
methodology: Behavioral analyses, brain immunohistochemistry, proteomics, and transcriptomics were performed on flies subjected to microgravity (SFμg), inflight artificially simulated Earth gravity (SF1g), and environmentally matched ground control (Earth).
results: Inflight and postflight behavioral changes and morphological alterations in the brain immediately postflight in response to μg were observed. Acclimation to Earth following spaceflight revealed brain morphological changes in both SF1g and SFμg flies, with pronounced phenotypes in SFμg. Metabolic pathways were altered in transcriptomic and proteomic studies.
conclusions: Artificial gravity partially protects the CNS from the adverse effects of spaceflight. Microgravity is an important but not an exclusive environmental factor contributing to neurobehavioral outcomes during long-term deep space missions. Oxidative stress during spaceflight leads to differential regulation of metabolic pathways, oxidative phosphorylation, and synaptic transmission resulting in neuronal deficits, glial changes, increased apoptosis, and behavioral impairments.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced oxidative stress leads to differential regulation of metabolic pathways, oxidative phosphorylation, and synaptic transmission, resulting in neuronal deficits, glial changes, increased apoptosis, and behavioral impairments in Drosophila.
insights: Gravity plays a key role in the LEO environment, causing neuronal and neurobehavioral deficits during spaceflight. Artificial gravity may provide a measure for short-term protection, but long-term solutions still need to be explored, especially for long-duration missions in deep space. Elevated CO2 levels and radiation contribute to long-term effects.

title: Post-Spaceflight (STS-135) Mouse Splenocytes Demonstrate Altered Activation Properties and Surface Molecule Expression.
objective: To develop a method for conducting human-tended plant biology experiments efficiently in a suborbital environment, broadening the platforms for space-related experiments.
methodology: Arabidopsis plants were grown on wire mesh coupons within KSC Fixation Tubes (KFTs). A simulated suborbital flight profile was used to investigate plant transcriptomic responses over time. RNA-seq analysis was performed on root and leaf tissues at different time points (Quiescent, coast start, coast end, and landing). A clinostat was used to simulate altered microgravity.
results: Plants grown in KFTs showed gene expression differences compared to Petri dish controls, particularly an upregulation of ethylene response in roots, indicating adaptation to the enclosed environment. Over time, different genes in root tissues were engaged or repressed to acclimate to the KFT environment, with hypoxia-related genes being enriched. Leaf tissues showed responses to fructose, light, and photosynthesis. The KFT setup successfully detected plant responses to gravity changes using the clinostat.
conclusions: KFTs can be adapted for carrying biological samples to space in a safely contained fashion. Changes in plant biology upon sealing within the KFTs are manageable within flight timelines, provided comprehensive ground controls are enacted. The method allows for capturing transcriptomic responses to high g and microgravity portions of a suborbital flight.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between plant gene expression and the simulated suborbital environment, including the effects of enclosure, altered gravity, and time. It also demonstrates the importance of appropriate controls in distinguishing gravity-related responses from other environmental factors.
insights: The study provides insights into the feasibility of using KFTs for plant biology experiments in suborbital space, demonstrating the importance of considering environmental factors and the potential for capturing transcriptomic responses to spaceflight conditions. It also suggests that pooling controls from multiple time points can be a successful strategy when well-coordinated controls are not feasible.

title: Changes in the distribution and function of leukocytes after whole-body iron ion irradiation.
objective: To analyze changes in mouse splenocyte composition and function immediately post 13 days of spaceflight, focusing on surface marker expression and response to stimulation parameters that mimic pathogen-induced activation events.
methodology: Mouse splenocytes from flight and ground control groups were analyzed via flow cytometry for surface marker expression (T-cells, dendritic cells). Stimulation assays were performed using TLR agonists (Zymosan, LPS, Flagellin) and T-cell stimulants (anti-CD3/CD28, ConA). Cytokine production was measured by ELISA. Bead uptake assay was used to assess phagocytic activity.
results: Flight mice splenocytes showed a distinct cell population with higher percentages of CD4+ and CD8+ cells. CD4 expression intensity decreased, while CD8 intensity increased. CD25 expression decreased in both CD4+ and CD8+ cells. The dendritic cell population (CD11c+) increased, with increased MHC I+ and decreased MHC II+ expression. Splenocytes from flight mice demonstrated increased bead uptake. ConA stimulation led to decreased CD4+ population but increased CD4+CD25+ cells compared to ground controls. TLR agonist stimulation generally decreased CD11c+ populations in flight mice splenocytes. IFN-γ production was decreased and IL-2 was increased from ConA stimulated flight splenocytes.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces changes in splenocyte populations and function, affecting both innate and adaptive immune responses. Alterations in surface marker expression, phagocytic activity, and cytokine production suggest immune dysregulation post-spaceflight. Specifically, dendritic cell function and T-cell activation are impacted, potentially affecting long-term immunity.
relationships: Spaceflight conditions alter the expression of surface molecules on splenocytes, influencing their ability to interact with other immune cells. The changes in dendritic cell antigen presentation (MHC I/II) affect T-cell activation. TLR stimulation modulates cytokine production, impacting the inflammatory response. The balance between CD4 and CD8 T-cell populations is also affected.
insights: Spaceflight-induced immune dysregulation involves complex changes in both innate and adaptive immunity. The observed alterations in splenocyte function may contribute to the increased risk of infection and immune-related health events during and after spaceflight. Further research is needed to understand the long-term effects of spaceflight on the immune system and develop countermeasures to mitigate these risks.

title: Is spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction linked to systemic changes in metabolism?
objective: To determine the effect of whole-body 56Fe26+ irradiation on leukocyte distribution and function at a relatively long time-point after exposure in a murine model.
methodology: C57BL/6 mice were exposed to 56Fe irradiation at varying doses (1, 2, and 3 Gy). Blood, spleen, thymus, liver, and lung samples were collected 40 days post-irradiation. Hematological analysis, flow cytometry, and blastogenesis assays were performed to assess leukocyte populations, function, and stem cell markers in bone marrow.
results: Radiation increased thymus mass. Red blood cell count, hemoglobin, hematocrit, and CD8+ T cytotoxic cell count decreased, while the CD4:CD8 ratio increased in irradiated groups. Splenic WBC, lymphocyte, and B cell counts were elevated, while Tc percentages decreased. Bone marrow showed a lower percentage of cells expressing stem cell markers.
conclusions: Significant immunological abnormalities persist more than a month after 56Fe irradiation, with differences dependent upon body compartment. The study suggests a continuing need to regenerate antibody-producing lymphocytes and highlights potential compromise in immune resistance due to reduced CD8+ Tc lymphocytes.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between radiation exposure, immune system dysfunction, and potential long-term health risks associated with spaceflight. It also suggests a link between hematopoietic stem cell depression and reduced red blood cell parameters.
insights: The research provides insights into the long-term effects of space radiation on the immune system, indicating that even after a month, significant abnormalities exist. The findings underscore the need for countermeasures to mitigate radiation-induced immune dysfunction during extended space missions.

title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the Proteasome in Mouse Liver
objective: To investigate the link between spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction and changes in metabolism in mice.
methodology: Female C57BL/6J mice were flown on the Space Shuttle Atlantis (STS-135) for ~13 days. Innate immune function (population distributions, oxidative burst capacity, phagocytosis), stress responses (adrenal catecholamine and corticosterone levels), metabolomics, and transcriptomics were assessed in the liver and spleen.
results: Spaceflight decreased major splenic leukocyte subset counts and lymphocyte subset counts. Splenic background ROS and oxidative burst increased, but phagocytosis decreased. Adrenal corticosterone levels tended to increase, while ACTH receptors decreased. Liver metabolite levels were altered, with changes in glutathione synthesis and osmolyte concentrations. Liver gene expression patterns related to viral infections, endocytosis, peroxisome formation, glycolysis, and lipid metabolism were also altered. Glycogen stores in the liver were reduced.
conclusions: Spaceflight causes transient changes in immune function that may be partially due to shifts in energy needs in space. The shifts in immune function may be related to shifts in energy needs in space, with a potential shift in priorities in phagocytic populations away from antigen processing toward lipid processing, potentially increasing risk for infection. The study also suggests spaceflight-induced alterations in the response to insulin that may correlate with insulin resistance.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced immune dysfunction is linked to systemic changes in metabolism. Corticosterone promotes fat breakdown, providing glycerol to the liver for gluconeogenesis. PPAR activity is altered in spaceflight, which can interfere with immune regulators and mediate macrophage responses.
insights: Spaceflight induces a complex interplay between immune function and metabolism. The observed changes in immune cell populations, oxidative stress, hormone levels, and gene expression suggest a coordinated response to the spaceflight environment. The study highlights the importance of considering metabolic factors when assessing the impact of spaceflight on the immune system.

title: Vive la radior√©sistance!: Converging research in radiobiology and biogerontology to enhance human radioresistance for deep space exploration and colonization.
objective: To perform unbiased, integrated analyses of metabolomics and transcriptomics datasets to determine the effects of exposure to the space environment on liver metabolism and cellular function in mice.
methodology: Unbiased Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (PLS-DA) using metabolomics data, Affymetrix Genechip 1.0 ST arrays for transcriptome analysis, Gene Ontology (GO) biological functions analysis, MetaboAnalyst for integrated analysis of transcriptomics and metabolomics datasets, Exploratory Gene Association Networks (EGAN), and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA). Histological analysis was performed using H&E staining.
results: Exposure to the space environment for 13.5 days resulted in significant alterations in hepatic metabolite profiles, altered betaine and glutathione metabolism, broad alterations in transcriptome profiles, enrichment of pathways involved in lipid membrane metabolism and protein biosynthesis, and upregulation of autophagy programs.
conclusions: Exposure to the space environment results in increased oxidative stress due to elevated ROS and impaired oxidative defense in the mouse liver. Accumulation of oxidized proteins coupled with mitochondrial dysfunction may lead to activation of hepatocyte senescence, resulting in hepatocyte lipid accumulation and steatosis.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced oxidative stress is linked to impaired oxidative defense, mitochondrial dysfunction, and activation of hepatocyte senescence, leading to hepatic steatosis. Altered autophagy pathways contribute to these processes.
insights: Short-term exposure to the space environment induces significant metabolic and transcriptional changes in the liver, potentially leading to long-term health risks such as liver damage and impaired regenerative capacity. These molecular changes may have important implications for the onset of obesity-related diseases and regenerative health in the course of long-duration space exploration.

title: Proteomic analysis of mouse brain subjected to spaceflight.
objective: To lay the foundations of a roadmap toward enhancing human radioresistance for deep space colonization and exploration. The review outlines future research directions toward enhancing human radioresistance.
methodology: The review synthesizes existing research in radiobiology, biogerontology, and related fields to identify potential strategies for enhancing human radioresistance. It considers various approaches, including upregulation of endogenous repair mechanisms, gene therapy, metabolic manipulation, and the use of deuterated compounds.
results: The review presents a comprehensive overview of the molecular and cellular effects of cosmic radiation, including DNA damage, oxidative stress, and immune system dysfunction. It highlights the importance of DNA repair mechanisms, antioxidant defenses, and cellular elimination pathways in mitigating radiation damage.
conclusions: Enhancing human radioresistance is likely to extend the healthspan of human spacefarers. The review concludes that a combination of strategies, including medical selection, small molecule interventions, gene therapy, and regenerative medicine, may be necessary to achieve sufficient radioresistance for long-duration space missions.
relationships: The review articulates the position that enhancing human radioresistance is likely to extend the healthspan of human spacefarers as well. It also explores the known associations between radioresistance and longevity.
insights: The review provides insights into the potential of genetic modifications, regenerative medicine, and pharmacological interventions to improve human radioresistance. It emphasizes the need for further research to optimize these strategies and address the specific challenges of space radiation exposure.

title: Transcriptomic effects on the mouse heart following 30 days on the International Space Station.
objective: To study spaceflight condition-induced changes in protein expression profiles in mouse gray matter and compare these changes to those in white matter regions.
methodology: Quantitative proteomic analysis of brain tissue collected from mice after a 13-day spaceflight mission. Protein extraction, trypsin digestion, and MS analyses were performed. Data was processed using Proteome Discoverer and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA).
results: Significant alterations in protein expression were observed in both white and gray matter after spaceflight. There was no overlap between the brain area data sets. Functional analysis revealed trends for changes in functionally related proteins in both brain regions, including synaptic function, intracellular communication, metabolism, oxidative stress, and tissue damage responses.
conclusions: Spaceflight conditions induce changes in neuronal structure, cellular function, oxidative response, mitochondrial function, and metabolism, which might lead to tissue injury and late neurodegeneration. The diverse changes in protein expression profiles in white and gray matter in response to spaceflight conditions warrants further investigation.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced changes in metabolism are likely related to increases in proteins involved with oxidative stress and inflammation. Changes in dendrite activity might be related to synaptic plasticity.
insights: Spaceflight poses risks to the central nervous system, inducing changes in protein expression related to neuronal structure and metabolic function. These changes might affect brain structural and functional integrity, potentially impacting the outcome of space missions.

title: Spaceflight-induced gene expression profiles in the mouse brain are attenuated by treatment with the antioxidant BuOE
objective: To analyze transcriptomic changes in the hearts of female C57BL/6J mice flown on the International Space Station (ISS) for 30 days to understand the impact of long-term spaceflight.
methodology: RNA was isolated from the hearts of flight and ground control mice. RNA sequencing was performed, and data was analyzed using Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA), STRING, and DAVID Gene Ontology to determine differentially expressed genes and affected pathways.
results: 1147 transcripts were significantly regulated after spaceflight. The MAPK, PI3K-Akt, and GPCR signaling pathways were predicted to be activated. Transcripts related to cytoskeleton breakdown and organization were upregulated. No significant change in ECM components or oxidative stress pathway transcripts occurred. Transcripts associated with the cell cycle were significantly upregulated. Cellular maintenance and survival processes were most affected.
conclusions: The cardiovascular transcriptome initiates an adaptive response to long-term spaceflight, involving activation of cell survival pathways and cytoskeletal reorganization. The heart adapts to the space environment, potentially mitigating oxidative stress and preventing cellular senescence.
relationships: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression related to cell proliferation, cytoskeletal rearrangement, and survival through cAMP, cGMP-PKG, and calcium signaling pathways. Upregulation of ERK1/2 and inhibition of SOS and BAD are predicted to prevent apoptosis. Hras promotes Pik3cd, leading to cell survival, cell-cycle progression, cell proliferation, and protein synthesis.
insights: Long-term spaceflight induces adaptive changes in the mouse heart, characterized by activation of cellular survival pathways and cytoskeletal reorganization, with limited impact on oxidative stress and cellular senescence. These findings suggest the heart can adapt to the space environment, highlighting the importance of understanding these molecular changes for future long-term space travel.

title: Basal signaling regulates plant growth and development
objective: To understand how spaceflight affects transcription spatially in the mouse brain and to investigate if the antioxidant BuOE can mitigate these effects.
methodology: GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiling of mouse brains subjected to spaceflight or grounded controls. Four brain regions (Cortex, Frontal Cortex, Cornu Ammonis I, and Dentate Gyrus) were analyzed with and without BuOE treatment. Differential gene expression analysis and pathway analysis were performed.
results: Spaceflight induced differential gene expression in all four brain regions, with the most significant changes in the hippocampal CA1 and DG regions. Metabolic pathways and pathways sensitive to oxidative stress were enriched. Several DEGs have known associations with Alzheimer's disease.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces region-specific gene expression changes in the brain, potentially increasing the risk of neurological disorders. BuOE treatment attenuates spaceflight-induced transcriptional changes, suggesting it may protect against oxidative stress-induced brain damage.
relationships: Spaceflight conditions are associated with oxidative stress, which contributes to cellular damage. BuOE, a superoxide dismutase mimic, can reduce oxidative stress damage to the brain.
insights: The hippocampus is particularly vulnerable to spaceflight. Spaceflight stressors could induce or accelerate neurodegenerative processes. BuOE may be a potential therapeutic candidate for CNS protection against brain injury and neurodegeneration induced by ionizing radiation and environmental stress.

title: Phosphoinositide-signaling is one component of a robust plant defense response
objective: To provide a comprehensive study of BnPERK genes, including exploration of evolutionary history, chromosome location, gene structure, tissue-specific expression, hormone treatment responses, and role in response to Plasmodiophora brassicae (clubroot disease).
methodology: Genome-wide analysis, phylogenetic analysis, gene structure analysis, conserved motif analysis, cis-element analysis, RNA-Seq analysis of gene expression across various tissues and hormone treatments, protein-protein interaction network analysis, Plasmodiophora brassicae inoculation experiments, disease index assessment, histocytological analysis, and qRT-PCR analysis.
results: Identified 50 PERK genes in Brassica napus. Genes were unevenly distributed across chromosomes and grouped into four classes. Phylogenetic analysis revealed purifying selection. Expression profiling showed diverse patterns across tissues and hormone treatments. Protein-protein interaction networks suggested involvement in multiple biological processes. Downregulation of four BnPERK genes upon Plasmodiophora brassicae infection implied a role in clubroot disease response. Arabidopsis perk9 mutant displayed relieved disease severity and enhanced basal immune response.
conclusions: BnPERK genes are involved in various physiological processes, including growth regulation, stress responses, and defense against pathogens. BnPERK09A1 and BnPERK09C1 are potential targets for disease management strategies and their putative role in signaling networks could contribute to the resistance improvement of Brassicaceae crops.
relationships: BnPERK proteins interact with various proteins involved in processes such as pentose and glucuronate interconversions, plant-pathogen interaction, starch and sucrose metabolism, cyanoamino acid metabolism, the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites, endoplasmic reticulum processing, and the MAPK signaling pathway.
insights: The study highlights the structural diversity and functional implications of the BnPERK gene family, suggesting their potential involvement in diverse physiological processes, including growth regulation, stress responses, and defense mechanisms. The identification of BnPERK09A1 and BnPERK09C1 as potential targets for disease management strategies could contribute to improved resistance in Brassicaceae crops.

title: Uncovering transcriptional responses to fractional gravity in Arabidopsis roots
objective: To investigate the function of phosphoinositide-mediated signaling in the plant defense network, specifically focusing on the role of InsP3.
methodology: Generated transgenic Arabidopsis plants expressing the human type I inositol polyphosphate 5-phosphatase (InsP 5-ptase) to reduce InsP3 levels.  These plants were then subjected to treatments with flagellin and virulent/avirulent strains of Pseudomonas syringae.  Measurements included root growth, Ca2+ induction, ROS production, gene expression (qRT-PCR), InsP3 levels, SA levels, and SAR assays. Petiole exudate experiments were also conducted.
results: InsP 5-ptase plants showed increased sensitivity to flagellin, attenuated Ca2+ elevation, decreased expression of defense-related genes, and delayed SAR.  They were more susceptible to virulent and avirulent strains of P. syringae. Basal SA levels were lower.  Exudates from InsP 5-ptase plants were effective in inducing PR-1 gene expression in wild-type plants, but InsP 5-ptase plants showed diminished PR-1 gene expression in response to exudates from either wild type or transgenic plants.
conclusions: Phosphoinositide signaling, specifically InsP3, is a component of the plant defense network involved in both basal and systemic responses. Dampening InsP3-mediated signaling affects Ca2+ release, modulates defense gene expression, and compromises plant defense responses.  InsP3 may act in an intracellular Ca2+ relay downstream of the initial Ca2+ influx.
relationships: InsP3-mediated signaling interacts with the MAPK cascade.  SA biosynthesis is linked to PI-metabolism.  Ca2+/calmodulin modulates SA biosynthesis.  NPR1, ER resident proteins, and protein folding are related to InsP3 signaling.
insights: The study suggests that InsP3 acts as an intracellular calcium relay, essential for propagating and maintaining calcium signals necessary for a robust defense response. The findings also highlight the interconnectedness of various signaling pathways in plant immunity, including phosphoinositide metabolism, calcium signaling, and SA biosynthesis.

title: Conserved plant transcriptional responses to microgravity from two consecutive spaceflight experiments.
objective: To investigate the effect of partial or fractional gravity on gene expression in Arabidopsis seedlings, relevant for plant growth on lunar and Martian surfaces.
methodology: Arabidopsis seedlings were grown for 5 days under continuous light in seed cassettes within the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS) onboard the International Space Station (ISS). Two rotors within a controlled chamber allowed for microgravity (stationary rotor) and simulated gravity in space. Transcriptional profiling of root samples exposed to microgravity or partial gravity (0.53 to 0.88 g) was performed using RNA-seq. Data were analyzed using DESeq2 with fractional g as a continuous variable.
results: A subset of 101 genes was identified whose expression correlates with changes in fractional g. These genes include transcription factors, defense, and cell wall-related proteins and heat shock proteins. Six different patterns of expression were identified: dose-dependent linear increase or decrease, peak up or peak down response, and threshold response.
conclusions: Select genes respond to a narrow gradient of fractional g, enriching biological functions related to transcription, cell wall modification, biotic interactions, and heat shock responses. Plant defense responses may be compromised in space. Understanding plant transcriptional response to altered gravity is important for Moon and Mars colonization.
relationships: The response of plants to gravitational stimuli, touch, and mechanical stimulation share overlapping signaling pathways. Limited overlap was detected between the fractional g responsive genes and touch responsive genes. HSP genes are highly responsive to gravitational perturbations.
insights: The study highlights the importance of understanding plant transcriptional responses to altered gravity for future space colonization efforts. The identification of specific genes and pathways affected by fractional gravity provides valuable targets for further research and potential manipulation to improve plant growth in space environments.

title: RNAseq analysis of rodent spaceflight experiments is confounded by sample collection techniques
objective: Compare the transcriptional response of Arabidopsis shoots from two independent spaceflight experiments conducted on the ISS to identify microgravity-specific differences in gene expression.
methodology: Two independent spaceflight experiments (Plant Signaling (PS) and Plant RNA Regulation (PRR)) were conducted on the ISS using the European Modular Cultivation System (EMCS). Arabidopsis seedlings were grown for 5-6 days in the EMCS under microgravity and onboard 1g control conditions. RNA-Seq analysis was performed on shoot samples to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs).
results: Significant overlap of genes differentially expressed in microgravity was observed between the two experiments. Genes involved in transcriptional regulation, shoot development, and response to auxin and light were upregulated in microgravity. Genes involved in defense response, abiotic stress, Ca++ signaling, and cell wall modification were downregulated. Three miRNAs (miR319c, miR398b, and miR8683) were upregulated in microgravity, while several of their corresponding target genes, enriched in those encoding chloroplast-localized enzymes and proteins, were downregulated.
conclusions: Microgravity induces unique transcriptional changes in Arabidopsis seedlings, including upregulation of genes related to shoot development and downregulation of stress response genes. The onboard 1g control is crucial for identifying microgravity-specific changes, as the space environment itself induces stress responses that are masked by microgravity.
relationships: Genes upregulated in microgravity are enriched for HY5 target genes, suggesting a role for HY5 in mediating the response to microgravity. Several gravitropism-related genes are also upregulated in microgravity, potentially related to their roles in regulating auxin flow.
insights: The developmental stage of the seedlings influences the transcriptional response to microgravity. The downregulation of stress-related genes in microgravity is in contrast to other spaceflight experiments that compare flight samples to ground controls, highlighting the importance of the onboard 1g control. The study uncovers microgravity-unique transcriptional changes and highlights the validity and importance of an onboard 1 g control.

title: Functional changes in the snail statocyst system elicited by microgravity
objective: To identify confounding factors in rodent spaceflight experiments that impact RNA sequencing (RNAseq) data and to determine optimal tissue preservation methods.
methodology: RNA sequencing was performed on liver samples from mice in spaceflight and ground control groups. Different euthanasia methods, tissue and carcass preservation protocols, and library preparation methods (polyA selection vs. ribodepletion) were compared. Gene set enrichment analysis was used to identify enriched gene ontology terms.
results: Preservation method (immediate vs. carcass) was the primary driver of gene expression variance, eclipsing differences between flight and ground samples. Carcass-preserved samples exhibited less uniform transcript coverage than immediate-preserved samples. Ribodepletion mitigated the impact of preservation method on gene expression changes. Carcass preservation by liquid nitrogen or RNAlater immersion most closely mimicked standard tissue preservation protocols. The impact of preservation method on gene expression was tissue-dependent (more pronounced in liver than quadriceps).
conclusions: Protocols used to preserve mouse carcasses on-orbit have large effects on gene expression patterns. Ribodepletion is recommended in place of polyA enrichment. Rapid freezing of carcasses in liquid nitrogen or segmentation of carcasses and immersion in RNAlater generated acceptable results.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between sample preservation techniques and gene expression results in spaceflight experiments. It also shows the relationship between RNA degradation and the choice of library preparation method.
insights: The study provides insights into the importance of careful sample handling and preservation in spaceflight experiments. It demonstrates that preservation methods can significantly impact gene expression data and that ribodepletion is a more robust method for degraded RNA samples.

title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK [natural killer] cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells
objective: To investigate the response of the snail gravisensing system to space mission conditions, focusing on the effects of microgravity exposure on statocyst function.
methodology: Exposure of terrestrial snails (Helix lucorum and Helix aspersa) to microgravity during unmanned orbital missions (Foton M-2 and M-3). Assessment of whole animal behavior (negative gravitaxis), statoreceptor responses to tilt (electrophysiology), and gene expression (HPep and FMRFamide) in neural structures post-flight. Control groups were maintained under similar conditions on Earth.
results: Postflight snails exhibited enhanced negative gravitaxis response, altered statoreceptor responses to tilt (independent of motion direction, increased sensitivity to acceleration), and increased mRNA expression of HPep in statoreceptors. FMRFamide expression showed no significant difference. Electrophysiological experiments showed increased neural sensitivity in statocyst hair cells, with a loss of directional selectivity.
conclusions: Microgravity exposure upregulates statocyst function in snails, paralleling observations in vertebrates, suggesting fundamental principles underlie gravi-sensing and adaptation to gravity changes. The snail model offers insights into subcellular mechanisms of the nervous system's response to conditions in space.
relationships: Upregulation of statocyst function in snails following microgravity exposure parallels that observed in vertebrates suggesting fundamental principles underlie gravi-sensing and the organism’s ability to adapt to gravity changes.
insights: The study suggests that microgravity induces adaptive changes in the snail's gravisensing system, potentially involving structural reformation, altered neural signaling, or a combination of both. The increased neural sensitivity in the snail was detected directly at the receptor level.

title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells
objective: To determine whether microgravity affects the body’s defenses against leukemogenesis by assessing the impact of simulated microgravity (sμG) on human Natural Killer (NK) cell cytotoxicity against leukemic cells.
methodology: Human NK cells were cultured under normal gravity and simulated microgravity (sμG) for 48 hours. Cytotoxicity against K-562 (CML) and MOLT-4 (T-ALL) cells was measured. RNA-seq was performed on NK cells to analyze gene expression changes. A modified workflow was used to maintain both NK cells and target tumor cells in a continuous state of microgravity throughout the assay period.
results: Exposure to sμG markedly reduced NK cytotoxicity against both K-562 and MOLT-4 leukemias. Continuous sμG further impaired NK cell function compared to traditional methods. RNA-seq analysis revealed alterations in multiple pathways related to NK cell function, including changes in the expression of CD1 isoforms, CD3D, CD5, CD55, CD84, CD200, CD47, LAIR1, NFATC1, CD34, KLRC3/NKG2E, NOTCH2NLR, TNFRSF10C and CD8A.
conclusions: Microgravity significantly impairs NK cell cytotoxicity against leukemic cells, and continuous microgravity exacerbates this effect. The combined exposure to space radiation and microgravity may increase the risk of leukemogenesis during prolonged space missions. Altered gene expression in NK cells provides potential targets for countermeasures to mitigate these risks.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between microgravity, NK cell function, and cancer risk in astronauts. It also connects changes in gene expression to the observed reduction in NK cell cytotoxicity. The research builds upon previous findings of space radiation-induced leukemia, suggesting a combined effect of radiation and microgravity.

title: Lab-on-a-chip approaches for space-biology research.
objective: To construct and test a microfabricated all-solid-state ion-selective electrode (ASSISE) for quantifying H+, Ca2+, and CO32- ions in lab-on-a-chip (LOC) applications for environmental, biomedical, agricultural, biological, and spaceflight research.
methodology: The ASSISE was constructed with a noble-metal electrode layer (Pt), a conductive polymer (PEDOT) transduction layer, and an ion-selective membrane (ISM) layer. Cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic deposition were used to electropolymerize the PEDOT films. The biochip was calibrated in test solutions to monitor pH, CO32-, and Ca2+ levels. Physiological measurements were performed to monitor the biological activity of Chlorella vulgaris.
results: The MAB can monitor pH (operational range pH 4-9), CO32- (measured range 0.01 mM - 1 mM), and Ca2+ (log-linear range 0.01 mM to 1 mM). The MAB for pH provides a near-Nernstian slope response after almost one month storage in algal medium. The carbonate biochips show a potentiometric profile similar to that of a conventional ion-selective electrode. Photosynthetic activity of Chlorella vulgaris was successfully monitored.
conclusions: The multi-analyte biochip (MAB) offers advantages in size, versatility, and multiplexed analyte sensing capability, making it suitable for confined monitoring situations on Earth or in space. The MAB is suitable for applications that require long-term monitoring in a complex biological liquid medium environment. Hence, it has the potential to be useful in in-vivo biomedical research and long-term monitoring of ions in drug screening.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between ion concentrations (H+, Ca2+, CO32-) and the electrical signal produced by the ASSISE. It also investigates the relationship between the photosynthetic activity of microalgae and changes in carbonate concentration.
insights: The performance of the ASSISE is influenced by the composition of the ion-selective membrane, the conductive polymer transduction layer, and the pH of the solution. The use of PEDOT as a transduction layer provides stable redox potential. The MAB technology can be extended to biosensing by functionalizing the CP conjugates with biomolecules.

title: Plant chemical genomics: gravity sensing and response.
objective: To examine the current and potential roles of lab-on-a-chip technology in space exploration and extreme environment investigation, reporting what has been tested so far, and clarifying the direction toward which the newly developed technologies of portable lab-on-a-chip sensors are heading for exploration in extreme environments and in space.
methodology: Reviewing existing literature and technologies related to lab-on-a-chip nanobiosensors, space exploration, and extreme environment research. Analyzing the features, applications, and limitations of current devices.
results: The review highlights the potential of lab-on-a-chip technology for space exploration and extreme environment analysis, emphasizing robustness, low cost, real-time capabilities, and small form factor. It presents examples of sensors for extreme temperatures, volcanics, environmental microbes, underwater applications, and pH measurement.
conclusions: Lab-on-a-chip-based sensors represent a promising choice for detecting and responding to harsh conditions in extreme environments and space exploration. Advances in engineering, nanomaterials, and electronics can improve the durability, reversibility, sensitivity, and selectivity of analytical devices, supporting the development of next-generation systems.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between life, extreme environments, and humans, aiming to design better technical strategies for deep space exploration. It also discusses the interaction between humans and microbes in the confined environment of space and the importance of monitoring astronaut health.
insights: Lab-on-a-chip technology offers a versatile platform for developing innovative sensors suitable for space exploration and extreme environment analysis. These sensors can be used for various applications, including monitoring astronaut health, detecting environmental pollutants, and studying microbial life in extreme conditions. The development of these technologies can contribute to more sustainable and efficient space exploration.

title: The interaction of vortical flows with red cells in venous valve mimics.
objective: To review the methods used to sequence zygomycete genomes, identify which genomes have been sequenced, and consider insights gained into genomic architecture, gene content, and evolutionary history.
methodology: Review of existing literature and genomic data from sequenced zygomycete fungi. Analysis of sequencing technologies, assembly methods, and genome statistics.
results: Genomic data revealed deep phylogenetic separation between Mucoromycota and Zoopagomycota. Studies provided insights into fungal evolution, adaptations to terrestrial life, genome architecture, gene content, and horizontal gene transfer events.
conclusions: Genomic information has helped resolve research questions related to the placement of zygomycetes on the evolutionary tree, their role in ecosystems, and biotechnological and medical applications. Continued research is expected to improve taxon sampling and genome quality.
relationships: Exploration of symbiotic relationships, including mycorrhizal associations, endobacteria within fungi, and parasitic interactions.
insights: Genomes have revealed insights into fungal evolution, adaptations to terrestrial life, genome architecture, gene content, and horizontal gene transfer events. The study of endobacteria and their role in fungal biology is a key area of interest.

title: Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses to Spaceflight
objective: To experimentally determine the effect of venous valve hydrodynamics on local red blood cell (RBC) distribution using microfluidics, micro-particle image velocimetry (μPIV), computational fluid dynamics (CFD), and microscopy to resolve the impact of local velocity fields and shear rates on RBC distributions in venous valve mimics.
methodology: A microfluidic device mimicking venous valves was designed and fabricated. Dilute RBC suspensions were perfused through the device at varying flow rates. RBC distribution was visualized using brightfield microscopy and quantified via image analysis. Fluid streamlines were traced using μPIV with fluorescent beads. CFD simulations were performed to model flow behavior. Statistical analysis was used to determine significance.
results: At low Reynolds numbers (Re), hematocrit distribution was uniform. As Re increased, RBC vortices appeared in the valve sinus regions, with local hematocrit levels increasing significantly compared to the feed hematocrit. RBCs remained within the vortex region for extended periods, following limit cycles. μPIV analysis revealed increased streamline separation and backflow into the valve pockets with increasing Re. Wall shear stress showed non-monotonic profiles with stagnation points.
conclusions: Vortical flows in venous valve pocket mimics result in anomalous local RBC distribution, differing significantly from bulk hematocrit. Shear rates determine RBC entry into microchannel pockets. Vortical flows lead to stasis and shear rate reversal on vessel walls, influencing factors implicated in thrombosis. The findings provide insights into inertial flow in sudden expansions, with applications in microfluidics-based cell separation.
relationships: The study demonstrates a relationship between flow rates, shear stress, and RBC distribution in venous valve mimics. It highlights the influence of vortical flows on local hematocrit and the potential impact on thrombosis. The research also suggests a connection between platelet margination and flow-driven phenomena.
insights: Local hematocrit in venous valve sinuses can be significantly different from bulk hematocrit. Platelet margination can occur independently of RBC collisions. A threshold shear rate is required to drive RBCs into vortices. Vortical flows can lead to stasis and reversal of shear rate directions on vessel walls, potentially influencing thrombosis.

title:
Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools
for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses
to Spaceﬂight
objective: To maximize scientific output from limited omics datasets from animal models and explore the utility of invertebrate models in anticipating mammalian responses to spaceflight.
methodology: Comparative analyses of transcriptomes of soleus and extensor digitorum longus (EDL) in mice that underwent 37 days of spaceflight. Comparison of transcriptomic data from the RR-1 quadriceps to the vastus lateralis from a human bed rest study, and transcriptomic data from the gastrocnemius from a space flown mouse study to matching HU samples. Comparison of RR-1 EDL and soleus muscle datasets with transcriptomic datasets of C. elegans and D. melanogaster.
results: Spaceflight leads to shared and discrete molecular responses between muscle types. Invertebrate models share select aspects of mammalian responses to spaceflight. The life stage of invertebrate models impacts the degree to which they recapitulate the responses of mammalian tissues to spaceflight.
conclusions: Spaceflight elicits both shared and discrete responses in slow and fast twitch muscle types. C. elegans molecular signature in response to spaceflight showed greater similarity to that of the EDL. The transcriptomic signature of the larval stage of D. melanogaster showed more similarity to the slow twitch muscle soleus, while adult D. melanogaster was more akin to fast twitch muscle EDL. Muscles from rodent spaceflight and human bedrest studies indicate alterations in glucose homeostasis and circadian rhythm.
relationships: Spaceflight and hindlimb unloading mice shared differential regulation of proliferation, circadian, and neuronal signaling. Shared gene regulation in muscles of humans on bedrest and space flown rodents suggest targets for mitigating muscle atrophy in space and on Earth. Spaceflight responses of C. elegans were more similar to EDL.
insights: Invertebrate datasets can potentially augment the limited quantity of vertebrate spaceflight omics datasets and may prove useful in anticipating mammalian responses to spaceflight. Discrete life stages of D. melanogaster have distinct utility in anticipating EDL and soleus responses.

title: Altered quorum sensing and physiology of Staphylococcus aureus during spaceflight detected by multi-omics data analysis
objective: To investigate the effects of simulated microgravity on Streptococcus mutans gene expression, physiology, oxidative stress resistance, and competence, using both culture-dependent and '-omic' (metabolomics and RNA-seq) approaches.
methodology: S. mutans was cultured in High Aspect Ratio Vessels (HARVs) under simulated microgravity and normal gravity conditions. Growth curves were generated, and metabolomics and RNA-seq analyses were performed on samples from different growth phases. Oxidative stress resistance was assessed by exposing cells to H2O2, and competence was measured by the ability to uptake plasmid DNA.
results: Simulated microgravity altered S. mutans metabolism in early stationary phase, leading to decreased glucose levels and changes in the expression of genes involved in carbohydrate metabolism and stress response. Late stationary-phase cells grown under simulated microgravity showed increased sensitivity to H2O2. Cell aggregation patterns also differed between the two conditions, with simulated microgravity cultures forming more compact structures. Competence was not affected.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity induces changes in S. mutans metabolism, physiology, and gene expression, impacting cell aggregation and oxidative stress resistance. These changes may be relevant to the low-fluid shear environment experienced by S. mutans in the oral cavity. Further research is needed to understand the regulatory circuits and contributions of differentially regulated genes to S. mutans' ability to survive and adapt to simulated microgravity and spaceflight environments.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between simulated microgravity, S. mutans physiology, and potential cariogenic potential. It also touches on the relationship between oxidative stress, biofilm formation, and competence in S. mutans.
insights: S. mutans exhibits altered metabolism and increased stress under simulated microgravity conditions. These changes suggest potential adaptations to the space environment or low-fluid shear conditions in the oral cavity, which could impact its virulence and cariogenic potential.

title: Altered quorum sensing and physiology of Staphylococcus aureus during spaceﬂight detected by multi-omics data analysis
objective: To investigate the virulence potential of Staphylococcus aureus in the spaceflight environment by analyzing multi-omics data (RNA-Seq, proteomics, and metabolomics) from the BRIC-23 GeneLab spaceflight experiment.
methodology: S. aureus cultures were grown in spaceflight and ground control conditions for 48 hours. RNA-Seq, cellular proteomics, secretomics, and metabolomics analyses were performed on the samples. Differential expression/abundance analysis was conducted to identify differences between spaceflight and ground control samples. Functional enrichment analysis was performed using PaintOmics and STRING.
results: The study found that S. aureus in spaceflight conditions exhibited increased quorum sensing, altered metabolism, and altered expression of virulence factors. Specifically, the agr operon and its regulated virulence factors were upregulated. Metabolic alterations included increased amino acid metabolism, TCA cycle activity, and transport of non-preferred carbon sources, along with decreased glycolysis/fermentation. Secretome analysis revealed increased abundance of secreted virulence factors.
conclusions: S. aureus experiences increased quorum sensing and altered expression of virulence factors in response to the spaceflight environment, which may impact its pathogenic potential. These changes could affect the ability of S. aureus to cause human disease during long-duration spaceflight missions.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight conditions, S. aureus quorum sensing, virulence factor expression, and metabolic alterations. It also suggests a potential link between altered metabolism and virulence potential in the spaceflight environment.
insights: The findings suggest that spaceflight conditions can significantly alter the physiology and virulence of S. aureus. The upregulation of the Agr quorum sensing system and virulence factors, along with metabolic shifts, indicates that S. aureus may pose an increased threat to astronaut health during long-term space missions. Further research is needed to fully understand the implications of these changes and develop strategies to mitigate the risks.

title: REGULATOR OF BULB BIOGENESIS1 (RBB1) Is Involved in Vacuole Bulb Formation in Arabidopsis.
objective: To characterize the roles of VPS41 and VPS33, subunits of the HOPS complex, in vacuole fusion and dynamics in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Reverse genetics, fluorescently tagged proteins, biochemical analyses (lipid-binding assays, coimmunoprecipitation), and genetic interaction studies using mutant alleles and inducible amiRNA silencing.
results: VPS41 and VPS33 partially colocalize with late endosomes, but only VPS41 is detected at the tonoplast. VPS41 tonoplast association is dependent on phosphoinositides. HOPS is essential for male fertility and important for plant development, specifically vacuole biogenesis and fusion. VPS41 and VPS33 interact in vivo with each other and with SYP22 in specific foci. VSP33 interacts directly with the Qa SNARE SYP22. The HOPS subunit VPS41 genetically interacts with the VTI11 SNARE.
