conclusions: HOPS complex mediates vacuole fusion in plants via interaction with SNAREs. Plant HOPS recruitment to liposomes is inhibited by phosphoinositides, defining rules for regulating fusion and fragmentation of dynamic vacuoles. VPS33 binding to the Qa-SNARE SYP22 is the first step for SNARE complex assembly.
relationships: VPS41 and VPS33 interact with each other and with SYP22. VPS41 localization at the tonoplast is phosphoinositide-dependent. VPS41 genetically interacts with VTI11. VPS33 directly interacts with SYP22, suggesting a conserved mechanism for HOPS-SNARE interaction.
insights: Plant vacuole fusion mechanisms differ from yeast, with phosphoinositides acting as negative regulators in plants. Membrane curvature and lipid content are key regulatory mechanisms for vacuole fusion events mediated by HOPS and SNAREs. A functional SNARE complex is required for the normal localization of VPS41 and VPS33.

title: Phosphoinositides control the localization of HOPS subunit VPS41, which together with VPS33 mediates vacuole fusion in plants.
objective: To investigate the role of REGULATOR OF BULB BIOGENESIS1 (RBB1) in vacuole bulb formation in Arabidopsis and its relationship to transvacuolar strands (TVS).
methodology: The study used a combination of genetic, cell biological, and biochemical approaches.  A mutant screen was performed to identify mutants with abnormal vacuole morphology.  The rbb1-1 mutant was characterized using confocal microscopy, RT-PCR, map-based cloning, genome sequencing, Western blotting, and chemical treatments (Brefeldin A and C834).  Complementation tests were performed using T-DNA insertion lines.  Fluorescent protein fusions were used to determine protein localization.
results: The rbb1-1 mutant exhibits an increased number of vacuolar bulbs and a decreased number of TVS compared to the parental control. RBB1 encodes a large, plant-specific protein of unknown function located in the cytosol and associated with cellular membranes. GFP-TIP2;1 trafficking to the vacuole is not altered in rbb1-1. The 3xYpet-RBB1 fusion complements the bulb phenotype of rbb1-2.
conclusions: RBB1 is involved in the regulation of vacuole morphology, specifically in the formation or stability of TVS. The increased number of bulbs in rbb1-1 may result from impaired formation of TVS. RBB1 may function in TVS formation and that increased bulb accumulation in rbb1-1 may result from impaired formation of TVS.
relationships: RBB1 is required to prevent the formation or accumulation of bulbs in the vacuole. RBB1 functions in the formation or stability of TVS. Bulbs may form when TVS initiates but fails to elongate.
insights: RBB1 is a novel plant-specific protein with unknown molecular function that plays a role in vacuole dynamics and morphology. The balance between bulb formation and TVS formation is important for vacuole function.

title: Microgravity enhances the phenotype of Arabidopsis zigzag-1 and reduces the Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion in root cells.
objective: To characterize the roles of VPS41 and VPS33, subunits of the HOPS complex, in vacuole fusion and dynamics in Arabidopsis thaliana.
methodology: Reverse genetics, fluorescently tagged proteins, biochemical analyses (lipid-binding assays, coimmunoprecipitation), and genetic interaction studies using mutant alleles and inducible amiRNA silencing.
results: VPS41 and VPS33 partially colocalize with late endosomes, but only VPS41 is detected at the tonoplast. VPS41 tonoplast association is dependent on phosphoinositides. HOPS is essential for male fertility and important for plant development and vacuole biogenesis and fusion. VPS41 and VPS33 interact in vivo with each other and with SYP22 in specific foci. VSP33 Interacts Directly with the Qa SNARE SYP22. The HOPS Subunit VPS41 Genetically Interacts with the VTI11 SNARE.
conclusions: The HOPS complex, specifically VPS41 and VPS33, plays a critical role in vacuole fusion and biogenesis in plants. VPS41's localization to the tonoplast is regulated by phosphoinositides, and HOPS interacts with SNARE proteins, particularly SYP22, to mediate membrane fusion at the vacuole. Plant vacuole fusion mechanisms differ from yeast, with phosphoinositides acting as negative regulators.
relationships: VPS41 and VPS33 interact with each other and with the SNARE protein SYP22, suggesting a direct role in HOPS-SNARE interactions during vacuole fusion. Genetic interactions between VPS41 and VTI11 further support the functional relationship between HOPS and SNARE complexes.
insights: Plant vacuole fusion mechanisms are distinct from those in yeast, particularly in the role of phosphoinositides. VPS41's localization and function are tightly regulated by phosphoinositides and membrane curvature, highlighting the complexity of vacuole dynamics in plants.

title: Hypergravity disruption of homeorhetic adaptations to lactation in rat dams include changes in circadian clocks
objective: To investigate the effect of microgravity on plant vacuole fusion and the association of vacuoles and plastids, and to demonstrate the feasibility of chemical treatments in plants on the ISS.
methodology: Using Arabidopsis seedlings (WT and zig-1 mutant with GFP-tagged vacuoles), a vacuole fusion assay was implemented with the BRIC-PDFU hardware on the ISS. Seedlings were treated with Wortmannin (WM) to induce vacuole fusion, then fixed with formaldehyde. Confocal microscopy was used to visualize and quantify vacuole morphology post-flight. Ground control experiments were conducted for comparison.
results: Microgravity enhanced the zig-1 phenotype, resulting in shorter hypocotyls and more vacuoles per cell in some root cells. WM-induced vacuole fusion was slightly delayed in the epidermis of flight-grown zig-1 roots compared to ground controls. The association of vacuoles and amyloplasts in hypocotyls did not appear to be altered by microgravity.
conclusions: Microgravity may slow down membrane fusion events in plants, detectable in the sensitized zig-1 genotype. The BRIC-PDFU hardware is feasible for chemical inhibitor treatments in space, but has limitations. Fixation protocols for fluorescently tagged proteins were optimized for spaceflight conditions, enabling post-flight microscopy.
relationships: Vacuole morphology and fusion are related to cell elongation, and disruptions in vacuole fusion could contribute to reduced hypocotyl elongation in microgravity. Vacuoles are associated with amyloplasts, potentially involved in gravity sensing.
insights: The study demonstrates the feasibility of conducting plant cell biology experiments involving chemical treatments and fluorescence microscopy in the microgravity environment of the ISS. The findings suggest that microgravity can subtly affect membrane fusion events in plants, highlighting the importance of studying cellular processes in space to understand plant adaptation to novel environments.

title: Intrauterine exposure to maternal stress alters Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length in the brain of adult rat offspring.
objective: To measure the effect of hypergravity exposure from mid-gestation throughout early lactation on metabolic activity of mammary, liver, and adipose tissue, circulating hormone and metabolite levels, and maternal behavior in relation to pup survival. To test whether hypergravity affects homeorhetic responses in the dam, thereby affecting lipid metabolism and pup survival. To examine the hypothesis that alterations to the dam’s circadian system induced by changes in gravitational force may limit homeorhetic adaptations needed for a successful lactation.
methodology: Pregnant rat dams were exposed to 2-g hypergravity from gestational day 11 through postnatal day 3. Metabolic activity of mammary, liver, and adipose tissue was measured. Circulating hormone and metabolite levels were analyzed. Maternal behavior was assessed using time-lapse videography. Gene expression of hormone receptors and enzymes regulating lipid metabolism, as well as core molecular clock genes, were measured in mammary and liver tissues.
results: Hypergravity exposure decreased fetal-pup body mass, reduced total body fat, and decreased pup survival. Maternal behavior was altered, with less digging/nesting and self-care. Mammary metabolic rate increased from pregnancy to lactation in both groups, but hypergravity decreased lipid synthesis and glucose oxidation. Adipose tissue metabolism and lipolysis were reduced in hypergravity. Plasma corticosterone and leptin levels were reduced in hypergravity dams. Expression of lipid metabolic genes and hormone receptors was altered in mammary and liver tissues. Hypergravity exposure impacted molecular clocks in mammary and liver.
conclusions: Hypergravity exposure causes a shift in maternal metabolism from reproductive to maternal survival at the expense of pup survival. Alterations in circadian clocks due to increased gravity load may contribute to the observed changes in dam metabolic capacity and behavior, ultimately affecting milk quality and quantity and decreasing pup survival.
relationships: Hypergravity exposure disrupts the normal homeorhetic response to lactation, impacting lipid metabolism in mammary, liver, and adipose tissues. This disruption is linked to alterations in maternal behavior, hormone levels, and the expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism and circadian rhythms. The study suggests a connection between the circadian system, metabolic adaptations, and reproductive success under altered gravitational conditions.
insights: The study highlights the vital role of environmental adaptation in long-term species survival. Disruptions in the circadian timing system may underlie gravity-related changes in maternal behavior and offspring development. The findings suggest that interventions targeting the circadian system could potentially mitigate the negative effects of altered gravity on maternal physiology and pup survival.

title: Influence of gonadectomy on muscle health in micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats.
objective: To characterize changes in Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length across multiple brain regions of adult rats following unpredictable variable prenatal stress (UVPS).
methodology: Sprague-Dawley rats were exposed to unpredictable variable prenatal stress (UVPS) during gestation. Offspring brains were analyzed at postnatal day 90 for Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length in the mPFC, ventral hippocampus, dorsal hippocampus, and central/basolateral amygdala. DNA methylation was measured using bisulfite-sequencing PCR. Telomere length was assessed using quantitative real-time PCR.
results: UVPS males had higher levels of Bdnf IV DNA methylation in the mPFC compared to control males and UVPS females. UVPS offspring exhibited shorter telomeres in the mPFC compared to controls. No significant differences were found in the dorsal hippocampus, ventral hippocampus or amygdala.
conclusions: Prenatal stress can induce epigenetic and telomeric changes in the brain of offspring, specifically increased Bdnf IV DNA methylation and shortened telomeres in the mPFC. These changes may have long-term behavioral consequences.
relationships: Prenatal stress is related to changes in DNA methylation and telomere length. Bdnf IV DNA methylation is related to neuroplasticity and cognition. Telomere length is related to cellular aging and survival.
insights: Unpredictable, variable gestational stress exerts sex-specific programming effects on the physical and behavioral health of the offspring, highlighting the capacity of in utero stress to leave its epigenetic and telomeric mark within specific regions of the brain.

title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats.
objective: To determine how biological sex and sex steroid hormones influence the progression of muscle atrophy after long-term exposure to simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in male and female rats.
methodology: Male and female Fisher rats underwent castration/ovariectomy or sham surgeries. After recovery, animals were divided into microgravity (0g), partial-gravity (0.4g), or full weight-bearing (1g) interventions for 28 days. Muscle size and strength were evaluated before and after interventions using grip strength tests, maximally stimulated muscle strength measurements (dorsiflexion and plantar flexion), peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT), and histological analysis of soleus muscles.
results: Females experienced greater relative loss in muscle size and strength compared to males in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments. Specifically, females lost more dorsiflexion strength, plantar flexion strength, overall leg girth, and muscle fiber area at 0.4g compared to males. Gonadectomy did not significantly influence these sex differences.
conclusions: Female rats are more susceptible to disuse atrophy than male rats in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments, and these differences are not primarily dependent on sex steroid hormones. Additional interventions may be necessary to mitigate musculoskeletal loss in female astronauts.
relationships: The study highlights the complex relationship between biological sex, gravity, and muscle health. It suggests that females may require more targeted interventions to prevent muscle loss during spaceflight. The findings also indicate that factors beyond sex steroid hormones contribute to sex differences in musculoskeletal pathologies.
insights: The study provides insights into the physiological differences between males and females in response to simulated spaceflight conditions. It suggests that partial weight-bearing models may be ideal for studying subtle nuances between males and females and susceptibility to disuse atrophy. The findings have implications for astronaut health and the development of sex-specific countermeasures to mitigate muscle loss during space missions.

title: Brassinazole resistant 1 (BZR1)-dependent brassinosteroid signalling pathway leads to ectopic activation of quiescent cell division and suppresses columella stem cell differentiation
objective: To determine if and how biological sex and sex steroid hormones influence the progression of muscle atrophy after long term exposure to simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in male and female rats.
methodology: Male and female Fisher rats underwent castration/ovariectomy or sham surgeries. After two weeks recovery, animals were divided into microgravity (0g), partial-gravity (0.4g), or full weight bearing (1g) interventions for 28 days. Measurements of muscle size and strength were evaluated prior to and after interventions, including grip strength, maximally stimulated muscle strength, peripheral quantitative computed tomography (pQCT), and histology.
results: Females lost more bodyweight compared to males, but had similar loss in rear paw grip strength during 28-day interventions. Females lost more muscle leg girth and corresponding muscle cross-sectional area compared to males. Females had similar losses in muscle fiber cross-sectional areas as males at 0g but greater muscle fiber area loss than males at 0.4g. Females had greater reductions in dorsiflexion and plantar flexion parameters compared to males at both 0g and 0.4g. Females tended to have greater loss in hindlimb muscle mass compared to males.
conclusions: Female rats have greater loss in muscle size and strength compared to male rats after exposure to long-duration partial or full unloading. These differences are conserved regardless of the presence or absence of sex hormones. Female astronauts are likely to experience greater relative musculoskeletal loss and likely prolonged recovery compared to male counterparts upon exposure to micro- and partial-gravity environments. Interventions to mitigate these losses may need to be sex-specific in order to ensure astronaut safety and future mission successes.
relationships: Sex differences in muscle loss are more pronounced during mechanical unloading. Sex differences were present regardless of the presence or absence of sex steroid hormones. Ovariectomy appeared to exacerbate musculoskeletal losses in females. The 0g intervention is a more severe stimulus, which will likely maximize musculoskeletal losses, regardless of sex. The partial weight-bearing model may be an ideal model to study the subtle nuances between males and females and susceptibility to disuse atrophy.
insights: Females appear more susceptible to disuse atrophy relative to males. Sex differences in musculoskeletal pathologies are more complex than simple differences in the sex steroid hormone milieu. Conditions, which result in changes to ovarian derived hormones, may in fact exacerbate sex differences between males and females. Partial weight-bearing may be a more relevant model for investigating musculoskeletal responses to disuse and how biological sex may interact with these responses.

title: Proteomic study of microsomal proteins reveals a key role for Arabidopsis Annexin 1 in mediating heat stress-induced increase in intracellular calcium levels.
objective: To investigate the role of BZR1, a BES1 homologue, in BR-regulated QC regulation and the effects of BR on the maintenance and differentiation of distal CSCs.
methodology: The study used wild-type Arabidopsis thaliana and various BR-related mutants. Plant materials were grown under controlled conditions and treated with chemicals like brassinolide (BL), brassinazole (BRZ), and auxin-related compounds. Histochemical staining, confocal microscopy, quantitative real-time PCR, and ChIP-qPCR assays were performed to analyze cell division, gene expression, protein localization, and DNA binding.
results: BZR1-mediated BR signaling promotes mitotic reactivation of QC cells independently of ethylene. BRs differentially regulate distal CSC differentiation in a concentration- and BZR1-/BES1-dependent manner. The BZR1-mediated BR signaling pathway partly acts on the auxin pathway, altering the expression/subcellular distribution of PIN proteins, resulting in proximal relocation of the auxin localization domain in roots. BR regulates transcriptional expression of diverse root-controlling genes in a BZR1-dependent manner.
conclusions: BZR1- and BES1-mediated BR signaling pathways act differentially in the regulation of the QC and CSC differentiation. Both pathways promote ectopic QC cell division. The BRI1/BZR1-mediated BR signaling pathway inhibits the differentiation of distal CSCs, delaying the development of starch-filled columella cells. The BZR1-mediated BR signaling pathway inhibits auxin-dependent distal stem cell differentiation in Arabidopsis roots through action that is antagonistic to the auxin/WOX5-dependent pathway.
relationships: BRs interact with multiple hormone signaling pathways, including auxin and ethylene, in the regulation of root growth and development. BZR1-mediated BR signaling and ETO1-promoted ethylene signaling pathways independently act on the QC reactivation event in a parallel manner.
insights: The study provides insights into the complex regulatory network involving BRs, auxin, and ethylene in controlling root stem cell division and differentiation. The findings suggest that BZR1 and BES1 play distinct roles in BR signaling, leading to differential effects on QC and CSC development. The study also highlights the importance of PIN proteins and auxin distribution in BR-mediated root development.

title: Apyrase inhibitors enhance the ability of diverse fungicides to inhibit the growth of different plant-pathogenic fungi
objective: To understand the early signaling steps in the response of plant cells to increased environmental temperature by studying microsomal proteins of Arabidopsis seedlings during heat stress.
methodology: 2-D difference gel electrophoresis (DIGE) was used to study microsomal proteins. Mass spectrometry was used to identify proteins with altered expression. Mutant analysis and overexpression studies were conducted to assess the role of Annexin 1 (AtANN1). Aequorin luminescence measurement was used to measure calcium levels.
results: 19 microsomal proteins showed altered expression within 5 minutes of heat treatment. AtANN1 was rapidly up-regulated after heat shock. Loss-of-function mutants for AtANN1 and AtANN2 were more sensitive to heat shock, while AtANN1 overexpressing plants were more resistant. Heat-induced expression of heat-shock proteins and factors was inhibited in ann1/ann2 double mutant, and heat-activated increase in cytoplasmic calcium concentration was impaired.
conclusions: AtANN1 is important in regulating the heat-induced increase in cytoplasmic calcium concentration and in the response of Arabidopsis seedlings to heat stress. AtANN1 and AtANN2 play redundant roles in regulating plant heat-shock responses. AtANN1 is a critical component of plants’ adaptive responses to environmental heat stress.
relationships: AtANN1 and AtANN2, but not AtANN6, are functionally redundant in regulating plant basal thermotolerance. Heat induced expression of HSFs and HSPs is attenuated in ann1–2/ann2 double mutant. The expression level of annexin is directly related to the basal thermotolerance of young Arabidopsis seedlings.
insights: AtANN1 plays a role in regulating the elevation of intracellular calcium induced by heat shock in whole seedlings. AtANN1 and AtANN2 are important components of the channel transport system that regulates heat-induced increase in cytoplasmic calcium concentration. An elevated environmental temperature is first perceived by membrane sensors like CNGCs, which allows for an initial calcium influx into the cytosol, activating AtANN1.

title: Apyrase inhibitors enhance the ability of diverse fungicides to inhibit the growth of different plant-pathogenic fungi
objective: To determine whether specific apyrase inhibitors enhance the potency of fungicides against plant-pathogenic fungal species.
methodology: Plate growth assays were conducted using five different pathogenic fungi treated with common fungicides (copper octanoate, myclobutanil, propiconazole) alone and in combination with four different apyrase inhibitors (AI.1, AI.10, AI.13, AI.15). Fungal growth inhibition was measured. Mass spectrometry was used to quantify propiconazole retention in fungal tissues. Apyrase activity in growth media was assayed with and without inhibitors. Extracellular ATP (eATP) levels were also measured.
results: Apyrase inhibitors significantly increased the sensitivity of fungi to fungicide treatments in most combinations tested. The effectiveness of inhibitors varied depending on the fungicide and fungal species. Some inhibitors increased propiconazole retention within fungal cells. Apyrase inhibitors suppressed apyrase activity released by fungi into growth media, resulting in increased eATP levels.
conclusions: Apyrase inhibitors enhance the potency of fungicides against plant-pathogenic fungi, possibly by reducing ATP-driven efflux of fungicides from fungal cells and disrupting the ATP concentration gradient across the plasma membrane. The inhibitors may also disrupt apyrase activity in the Golgi, affecting glycosylation of efflux transporters. This enhancement could lead to more effective fungicide formulations.
relationships: Apyrases and ABC transporters are linked in fungi, similar to plants, in herbicide resistance and auxin transport. Disruption of apyrase activity can inhibit ABC transport activity, blocking the efflux of toxic compounds. Apyrase inhibitors can reduce the activity of ATP-driven efflux transportation of fungicides out of the hyphae of several pathogenic fungi.
insights: The study suggests that apyrase inhibitors could be a valuable addition to fungicide formulations, potentially reducing crop losses due to fungal pathogens. The findings highlight the conserved functional relationship between apyrases and efflux transporters in both plants and fungi, offering a potential target for improving pesticide efficacy.

title: Mitochondria-targeted human catalase in the mouse longevity MCAT model mitigates head-tilt bedrest-induced neuro-inflammation in the hippocampus.
objective: To investigate the roles of Arabidopsis annexins ANN1 and ANN2 in post-phloem sugar transport to the root tip and their impact on primary root growth and development.
methodology: The study used Arabidopsis knockout mutants (ann1-2, ann1-3, ann2-1, and ann1-2/ann2-1) and an ANN1-overexpressing line (35S:ANN1).  Experiments included measurements of primary root length, hypocotyl length, growth rates, Lugol staining for starch detection in columella cells, starch quantification, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), reverse transcription quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR), chlorophyll autofluorescence detection, GC/MS analysis for soluble sugars, CFDA application for post-phloem transport detection, ROS detection using H2DCFDA, and aniline blue staining for callose accumulation.
results: ANN1 and ANN2 knockout mutants showed inhibited primary root growth, which was rescued by exogenous sucrose, glucose, or fructose, but not by mannitol or sorbitol. The mutants also exhibited root cap developmental defects, reduced starch levels in root tips, and enhanced expression of photosynthesis-related genes and chlorophyll accumulation in cotyledons.  Unexpectedly, the mutants had higher soluble sugar content in primary roots but impaired post-phloem transport in root tips, increased ROS levels, and callose accumulation.
conclusions: ANN1 and ANN2 play an important role in post-phloem sugar transport to the root tip, which indirectly influences photosynthetic rates in cotyledons.  The impaired sugar transport in the mutants leads to sugar starvation in the root apex, triggering an up-regulation of photosynthesis.  The study expands the understanding of annexin function in plants by linking ANN1 and ANN2 to the regulation of primary root growth and development through their role in post-phloem sugar transport.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between ANN1 and ANN2 function, post-phloem sugar transport, root tip sugar status, and photosynthetic rates in cotyledons. It also suggests a connection between ROS accumulation, callose deposition, and impaired sugar transport in the mutants.
insights: The findings suggest that root tips are sugar-sensing tissues, and their sugar status can affect photosynthesis capacity in leaves.  The study highlights the importance of post-phloem transport in regulating root growth and development and provides insights into the mechanisms by which plants monitor sugar levels in roots.

title: Structural and functional properties of bone are compromised in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice.
objective: To determine the role of microglia, reactive oxygen species (ROS) pathways, and behavior following head-tilt bedrest to elucidate the underlying molecular mechanism behind neuroimmune changes.
methodology: Wild-type and MCAT transgenic mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU) to simulate microgravity. Immunohistochemistry was used to quantify CD68 protein expression (a marker for microglial activation) in the hippocampus. Cytokine protein abundance was analyzed using a multiplex assay. Behavioral analysis was performed using video surveillance to assess exploratory, social, active, and rest/sleep behaviors.
results: HU increased activated microglia in the hippocampus of wild-type mice. MCAT mice showed reduced microglial activation compared to wild-type mice under HU conditions. Several hippocampal cytokines (IL-1a, IL-3, IL-10, IL-12, IL-13, IL-17, RANTES, and MIP-3a) showed a positive correlation with CD68 counts. Behavioral changes were observed during light and dark cycles, with MCAT HU mice showing altered social and exploratory behaviors.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity causes neuroinflammation, implicating microglial brain activation, and links this process to behavioral consequences. Microglial activation in the hippocampus caused by simulated microgravity is mitigated by ROS quenching, suggesting ROS as a potential therapeutic target.
relationships: Increased CD68 levels correlate with increased levels of several cytokines. Exploratory behavior was correlated positively with G-CSF and Mip3a and negatively with INF γ, IL-4, IL-10, IL-12p40, IL-12p70, M-CSF, Mip2, and EPO. Social interactions were positively correlated with IL-4, Mip2, and EPO and negatively with G-CSF, IL-1β, IL-6, and Mip3a.
insights: The study suggests that ROS plays an important role in HU-induced microglia activation and that it is a potential target for countermeasures. The correlations between molecular and behavioral changes could reveal biomarkers indicative of these responses and could also result in a potential target for the treatment/prevention of cognitive changes astronauts experience due to prolonged spaceflight.

title: Longitudinal time course of muscle impairments during partial weight-bearing in rats
objective: To investigate the longitudinal time course of muscle function in rats at three different partial weight-bearing (PWB) levels (70%, 40%, and 20% of normal loading) over a 4-week period.
methodology: Rats were subjected to three different PWB levels (70%, 40%, and 20% of normal loading) using a tail-suspension and pelvic harness system. Muscle function was assessed by measuring calf circumference, grip force, and nerve-stimulated plantar flexion force. Muscle tissues were harvested on days 7, 14, and 28 to assess muscle mass and fiber characteristics using histomorphometry.
results: Muscle mass and function were significantly impaired in reduced weight-bearing environments as early as 7 days of suspension. Muscular alterations correlated with the PWB level and did not reach a plateau during the 1-month exposure. Soleus muscle atrophied more than gastrocnemius, with a decrease in type 1 (slow-twitch, oxidative) fibers. A fiber-type switch was observed, with unloaded rats showing a higher percentage of type 1 fibers in the gastrocnemius muscle.
conclusions: Partial weight-bearing in rats effectively models the impact of reduced mechanical loading on muscle health, with dose-dependent alterations in muscle parameters. Early muscle deficits emphasize the need for mitigating strategies immediately after a reduction in mechanical loading. This model can be used to investigate the potential health impacts of partial mechanical unloading and to find solutions to protect astronauts during long-duration space missions.
relationships: Muscle impairment is correlated to the PWB level. Soleus muscle atrophy is greater than gastrocnemius muscle atrophy. There is a relationship between PWB level and muscle fiber type.
insights: Even a 30% decrease in mechanical loading induces substantial reductions in muscle force and size that do not recover after a month of suspension. The PWB model can be used to assess the impact of sequentially altering loading levels and the impact of the gradual mechanical reloading.

title: The partial weight-bearing rat model using a pelvic harness does not impact stress or hindlimb blood flow.
objective: To examine bone mass, microarchitecture, and biomechanics in ALS SOD1G93A mice compared to healthy controls, hypothesizing that bone microstructure and biomechanical outcomes will be lower in ALS mice.
methodology: 16-week-old ALS SOD1G93A female mice and littermate controls were used. Bone microarchitecture was assessed by microCT. Mechanical testing included three-point bending and fracture toughness testing on femurs, and cyclic reference point indentation on tibias. Statistical analysis used two-tailed student t-tests.
results: ALS mice showed significantly lower trabecular bone mass, thinner trabeculae, decreased cortical bone thickness and area, lower femoral bending stiffness and failure moment, and decreased fracture toughness compared to controls. Cortical micromechanical properties were similar between groups.
conclusions: ALS SOD1G93A mice exhibit skeletal fragility, indicated by reduced femoral bending properties and fracture toughness. This suggests that targeted therapies to prevent skeletal fractures should be considered in ALS patients, especially with treatments extending survival.
relationships: Impaired muscle function and reduced physical activity in ALS mice likely contribute to lower femoral bending properties. Clinical studies suggest skeletal deficits may occur independently of skeletal muscle deficits. Mitochondrial dysfunction in osteocytes may also contribute to skeletal fragility.
insights: The study highlights the importance of considering bone health in ALS patients, as skeletal fragility can significantly impact quality of life. Future studies should examine bone functional assessments at earlier time points and in different ALS mouse models.

title: Dose-dependent skeletal deficits due to varied reductions in mechanical loading in rats.
objective: To explore the basic sciences, safety/contraindications, application, and utility of Blood Flow Restriction Training (BFRT) in rehabilitation and injury prevention.
methodology: Review of existing literature and expert opinion on BFRT, including its mechanisms, application techniques, and safety considerations.
results: BFRT elicits gains in strength and hypertrophy at lower loads, accelerates recovery, and mitigates disuse atrophy. It also benefits cardiovascular fitness, pain attenuation, and bone density. BFRT can improve muscle strength, power, and endurance.
conclusions: BFRT has applications across the continuum of human performance, from immobilization and early rehabilitation to strength and conditioning and recovery. It is a progressive training stimulus that can be incorporated across a variety of populations to produce a more resilient individual.
relationships: BFRT enhances muscle hypertrophy through metabolic stress, muscle damage, and mechanical tension. It increases systemic anabolic signaling, improving growth hormone, insulin-like growth factor 1, and muscle protein synthesis.
insights: BFRT is a valuable tool for improving muscular strength and fostering hypertrophy, particularly in load-compromised individuals. It can be used in conjunction with conventional strength training to optimize mechanical tension, muscle damage, and metabolic stress.

title: Approaching Gravity as a Continuum Using the Rat Partial Weight-Bearing Model
objective: To evaluate the time course of changes in bone density, microarchitecture, and strength in rats exposed to varied weight-bearing levels, and to delineate the effects of partial weight-bearing (PWB) on bone metabolism at the cellular level.
methodology: 14-week-old male Wister rats were exposed to 20%, 40%, 70%, or 100% of body weight for 1, 2, or 4 weeks. In vivo pQCT was used to assess trabecular bone density at the proximal tibia. Ex vivo microcomputed tomography was used to measure trabecular microarchitecture in the distal femur. Histologic analyses of trabecular bone in the distal femur were performed. Three-point bending was used to assess femoral diaphysis.
results: Trabecular bone density at the proximal tibia declined in proportion to the degree of unloading and continued progressively with time. MicroCT revealed deficits in bone volume fraction in the distal femur after unloading. Histologic analyses revealed decreased osteoblast number and mineralizing surface in unloaded rats. Femoral stiffness and estimated modulus were modestly or not reduced due to PWB. Cortical bone density alterations were moderate.
conclusions: The rat model of PWB leads to trabecular bone deterioration that is progressive and generally proportional to the degree of PWB, with minimal effects on cortical bone. The skeletal deficits appear progressive, not reaching a plateau by 4 weeks of PWB.
relationships: Partial reductions in mechanical loading lead to proportional deteriorations in bone density, microarchitecture, and strength. Deterioration of trabecular microarchitecture is due in part to a decrease in osteoblast surface. Decreased osteoblast activity is likely due to increased sclerostin expression in osteocytes.
insights: The study demonstrates dose-dependent trabecular bone loss in rats following exposure to differing levels of quadrupedal PWB. The progressive nature of bone loss raises concerns for long-duration spaceflight in the absence of successful bone-sparing countermeasures. Further research is needed to elucidate mechanisms underpinning this dose response.

title: Hindlimb suspension in Wistar rats: Sex-based differences in muscle response
objective: To review the rat model of partial weight-bearing (PWB), from its conception to the current state of knowledge, and address how this model, used in conjunction with hindlimb unloading (HU), will help anticipate the physiological alterations and needs of astronauts. Also, to discuss outstanding questions and future perspectives in space research and propose potential solutions using the rat PWB model.
methodology: The review focuses on the rat model of PWB, detailing the establishment of the model, including housing environment, suspension apparatus, and the use of a pelvic harness. It also discusses the reliability of the model and its application in studying various physiological alterations. Studies involved exposing rats to different levels of partial weight-bearing (PWB20, PWB40, PWB70) and comparing them to fully loaded controls (PWB100). Measurements included body weight, food intake, muscle size (calf circumference, hindlimb muscle mass, myoﬁber cross-section area), muscle force (rear paw grip force, maximal torque during plantar or dorsi-ﬂexion), bone mineral density (BMD), and cardiovascular parameters (tail blood pressure, foot oximetry, heart rate).
results: The rat PWB model allows for the investigation of gravity as a continuum and mimics gravity shifts lower than 1g. Partial mechanical loading results in a dose-dependent muscular deconditioning in the hindlimbs, consistent with the physiological alterations observed during spaceflight and hypokinesia. Forelimb muscles also displayed atrophy during partial unloading. Skeletal impairments, including a dose-dependent decrease in tibial BMD, were observed. The use of a pelvic harness during normal loading did not impair indirect measures of blood flow nor did it modify blood pressure and heart rate over the course of the experiment. A moderate daily dose of resveratrol mitigates muscle deconditioning in a Martian gravity analog.
conclusions: The PWB model is a novel experimental method with extensive potential for the investigation of physiological alterations in response to both micro- and partial gravity. It can be adapted to any mechanical loading ranging from HLS to PWB100. The PWB model will play a critical role in unraveling the complex interactions between human physiology and spaceflight.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between partial weight-bearing and musculoskeletal health, cardiovascular function, and overall physiological adaptation. It also explores the potential of using the PWB model to investigate the effects of radiation and altered circadian rhythms on physiological outcomes. The model allows for the study of the coupled effect of mechanical loading and radiation, mimicking the conditions on the lunar surface. The study also emphasizes the importance of understanding sex-based differences in the adaptations to partial gravity to develop the best countermeasures for both males and females.
insights: The rat PWB model provides a valuable tool for studying the effects of partial gravity on various physiological systems. The model is reliable, adaptable, and allows for the investigation of gravity as a continuum. The findings suggest that partial mechanical loading results in dose-dependent muscular deconditioning and skeletal impairments. The use of a pelvic harness does not impact stress or hindlimb blood flow. The model can be used to investigate the effects of radiation and altered circadian rhythms on physiological outcomes. Understanding sex-based differences in the adaptations to partial gravity is crucial for developing effective countermeasures for both male and female astronauts.

title: Adaptation to full weight-bearing following disuse in rats: The impact of biological sex on musculoskeletal recovery
objective: To assess how biological sex impacts disuse-induced muscle deconditioning using the hindlimb suspension (HLS) model in adult Wistar rats.
methodology: 28 adult Wistar rats (14 males and 14 females) were subjected to 14 days of HLS or normal loading (NL). Muscle function was assessed via grip strength, calf circumference, and maximal tetanic force production. Muscle histology, immunohistochemistry, and RTqPCR were performed to analyze muscle mass, fiber size, satellite cell activity, and gene expression.
results: Females better maintained muscle function during HLS than males, exhibiting a more moderate reduction in grip strength. HLS resulted in muscle atrophy in both sexes, but males showed greater atrophy in the soleus and tibialis anterior muscles. Females experienced preferential atrophy in type 2 and hybrid myofibers in the gastrocnemius, while males showed preferential atrophy in type 1 myofibers. HLS led to a decrease in plasma testosterone in males, while estradiol levels in females remained relatively stable.
conclusions: Sex-based differences exist in the muscle response to simulated microgravity. Females better maintain muscle function during disuse compared to males. These findings emphasize the need to consider sex as a biological variable when developing countermeasures for muscle deconditioning in spaceflight.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between biological sex, muscle function, and the response to mechanical unloading. It also suggests a potential link between sex hormones (testosterone and estradiol) and muscle maintenance during disuse. The study also explores the relationship between satellite cell activity and muscle deconditioning.
insights: The study provides insights into the complex interplay between sex, muscle physiology, and adaptation to altered gravitational environments. The findings suggest that tailored, sex-specific countermeasures may be necessary to effectively mitigate muscle loss during spaceflight.

title: Effects of liquid cultivation on gene expression and phenotype of C. elegans.
objective: To correct a spelling error in the author's name in the article 'Adaptation to full weight-bearing following disuse in rats: The impact of biological sex on musculoskeletal recovery'.
methodology: A correction notice was issued and the online version of the article was updated.
results: The author's name was corrected from 'Rosa-Caldwell' to 'Megan E. Rosa-Caldwell'.
conclusions: The spelling error has been rectified in the article and online.
relationships: This correction relates to the original article concerning musculoskeletal recovery in rats following disuse, and the impact of biological sex.
insights: Ensuring accuracy in author names is crucial for proper citation and recognition in scientific publications.

title: Transcriptomic Signature of the Simulated Microgravity Response in Caenorhabditis elegans and Comparison to Spaceflight Experiments.
objective: To investigate the transcriptomic and phenotypic responses of C. elegans N2 and AB1 strains to liquid cultivation, mimicking environmental changes.
methodology: RNA-seq analysis was performed on N2 and AB1 strains of C. elegans across three generations (P0, F1, F2) subjected to different growth conditions: agar plates, axenic CeHR medium, and bacterial S-Medium. Differential gene expression analysis, gene ontology enrichment, and microscopy were used to identify and validate transcriptional and phenotypic changes.
results: Significant variations in gene expression were observed between N2 and AB1 strains in response to liquid cultivation. Genotype significantly impacts adaptive responses. Condition-specific gene expression was identified, including ncRNAs. N2 strain showed higher differential expression under environmental changes, with germline abnormalities observed in CeHR medium.
conclusions: Environmental changes cause significant alterations in transcriptional responses in C. elegans. Different strains exhibit unique transcriptional characteristics correlating with observed phenotypes. Laboratory environments can cause substantial differences in transcriptomic and phenotypic responses to abrupt environmental changes.
relationships: The study reveals relationships between genotype, environment, gene expression, and phenotype in C. elegans. It highlights the role of neuropeptide signaling in rapid adaptation and the impact of liquid cultivation on gene expression.
insights: The research provides insights into the adaptive mechanisms of C. elegans to environmental changes, emphasizing the importance of considering genetic background and environmental context in transcriptomic studies. It also identifies novel condition-specific genes and ncRNAs.

title: Enabling clonal analyses of yeast in outer space by encapsulation and desiccation in hollow microparticles.
objective: To analyze the transcriptomic response of Caenorhabditis elegans to simulated microgravity and observe the maintained transcriptomic response after returning to ground conditions.
methodology: RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) and mass spectrometry analyses were performed on C. elegans exposed to clinostat-simulated microgravity for four days and after returning to ground conditions for four, eight, and twelve days. Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified using Tuxedo pipeline and DESeq2 software. Functional and pathway enrichment analyses were conducted using DAVID, Cytoscape, and KEGG Mapper. Comparison of DEGs to the CERISE four-day spaceflight experiment was performed using GEO2R. Mass spectrometry was used for ceramide detection.
results: Exposure to simulated microgravity induced distinct gene expression patterns that were maintained even after 12 days of return to ground conditions. Downregulated genes were overrepresented in neuronal, epithelial tissues, and intestine, while upregulated genes were enriched in reproductive system-related tissues. Dorso-ventral axis formation was upregulated, and lysosome activity was downregulated during exposure. Sphingolipid signaling pathway was downregulated, leading to decreased ceramide levels. 134 common DEGs were identified between simulated microgravity and four-day CERISE spaceflight experiment.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity affects longevity-regulating pathways such as insulin/IGF-1 and sphingolipid signaling in C. elegans. The microgravity-responsive genes are potentially conserved between worms and humans. These findings provide valuable insights into the transcriptomic response to microgravity and its sustained effects after returning to ground conditions.
relationships: Downregulation of sphingolipid signaling pathway is related to an increase in longevity. Decreased ceramide levels may be related to increased telomere length. The microgravity-responsive genes are potentially conserved between worms and humans.
insights: Microgravity induces changes in gene expression related to longevity, stress response, and metabolism. The sphingolipid signaling pathway plays a crucial role in the response to microgravity. The effects of microgravity on the immune system carry over even after returning to ground conditions.

title: Caenorhabditis elegans in microgravity: An omics perspective
objective: To develop a method to desiccate PicoShells with encapsulated single Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells that maintains particle morphology and yeast health after storage and rehydration, making single-cell analyses more feasible for future space biology missions.
methodology: Fabricated hollow-shell hydrogel microparticles (PicoShells) using microfluidics to encapsulate S. cerevisiae. Desiccated particles using vacuum drying in Novec oil with Pico-Surf surfactant, with and without trehalose. Evaluated particle integrity via morphology and porosity, and yeast health via viability and growth potential over 8.5 weeks. Performed growth-based single-cell analyses on wild type and rad51∆ yeast populations.
results: Vacuum-based desiccation of PicoShells in Novec oil with Pico-Surf caused the least impact on particles and yeast. Rehydrated particles retained intact hollow-shell morphology, similar porosity, and high yeast viability over 8.5 weeks. +Trehalose PicoShells retained the highest viability and growth. Single-cell analysis showed heterogeneity in growth characteristics within and between WT and rad51∆ populations.
conclusions: Desiccated PicoShells provide a robust method for cell preservation before and during launch, promising a simple single-cell analysis method for studying heterogeneity in microbial populations in space. The method improves post-rehydration viability and preserves particle integrity and yeast health sufficiently well to enable single-cell analysis.
relationships: The study builds upon previous work introducing PicoShell technology and demonstrates its applicability for space biology missions. It relates to other space biology experiments involving microbial desiccation and single-cell analysis.
insights: Encapsulation improves yeast viability compared to non-encapsulated yeast after desiccation. Dextran and trehalose likely work together to preserve yeast health during desiccation. Single-cell analysis reveals heterogeneity in growth behavior that is masked in bulk population assays.

title: Caenorhabditis elegans in microgravity: An omics perspective
objective: To summarize the literature on the use of C. elegans as a model organism for spaceflight research, focusing on omics technologies to uncover the mechanistic basis of the microgravity phenotype.
methodology: Narrative review of publications applying omics technologies (transcriptomics, genomics, proteomics, multi-omics, and integrated omics) to study spaceflown C. elegans, including hyper-, micro-, and simulated gravity scenarios.
results: Identified robust metabolic and neuromuscular biological themes. Metabolic alterations primarily affected mitochondria and ATP generation. Muscular and neuromuscular changes included altered muscle development, declines in myosin heavy chain isoform gene expression, and locomotion-related genes. MicroRNAs are involved in developmental, DNA damage, apoptotic, and metabolic responses.
conclusions: C. elegans is a valuable model for studying microgravity adaptations. Omics analysis has identified key molecular responses to spaceflight, particularly in muscle locomotion and metabolism. Future work should use emerging omics approaches like multi-omics and spatial transcriptomics to unravel tissue-specific responses.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced changes in C. elegans gene expression are conserved in higher organisms and may explain muscle decline observed in astronauts. C. elegans transcriptional response to spaceflight demonstrates greater similarity with mouse fast-twitch muscle.
insights: Microgravity elicits transcriptional responses, robustly regulating genes related to muscle locomotion and metabolism. Epigenetic changes may occur with microgravity exposure. Dystrophin is important in the omics response to spaceflight, particularly with respect to neuromuscular/cytoskeletal changes.

title: Dietary countermeasure mitigates simulated spaceflight-induced osteopenia in mice
objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of various dietary interventions in mitigating cancellous bone loss caused by ionizing radiation and simulated space radiation in mice.
methodology: Mice were subjected to total body irradiation (TBI) with gamma rays or simulated space radiation (protons and heavy ions). Candidate interventions included an antioxidant cocktail (AOX), dihydrolipoic acid (DHLA), Ibuprofen, and dried plum (DP). Bone marrow gene expression was analyzed via qPCR, and bone microarchitecture was assessed using microcomputed tomography (microCT).
results: Dried plum (DP) supplementation was most effective in reducing the expression of genes related to bone resorption and preventing cancellous bone loss caused by both gamma and simulated space radiation. AOX, DHLA and Ibuprofen showed limited to no protection.
conclusions: Dietary supplementation with dried plum may prevent the skeletal effects of radiation exposures, both from gamma radiation and simulated space radiation, by modulating pro-osteoclastogenic cytokine expression and maintaining bone microarchitecture.
relationships: High levels of pro-resorption, pro-inflammation, and oxidative stress-related genes in bone marrow strongly correlated with cancellous bone loss. DP's radioprotective effects are linked to its polyphenol components, which promote osteogenesis and prevent osteoclastogenesis.
insights: Dried plum's ability to prevent radiation-induced bone loss suggests its potential as a countermeasure for bone loss during spaceflight and radiotherapy. Further research is needed to identify the active components of dried plum responsible for these protective effects and to assess its long-term effects on bone mechanical properties.

title: Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease
objective: To evaluate the potential of dried plum (DP) to protect against bone loss induced by simulated microgravity and ionizing radiation, independently and in combination.
methodology: Male mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU) to simulate microgravity and/or exposed to ionizing radiation (IR). A control diet (CD) or a DP-supplemented diet was administered. Bone microarchitecture (tibia and vertebrae) was assessed using micro-computed tomography (microCT). Mechanical properties of vertebrae were evaluated via compression testing. Osteoblastogenesis was assessed through ex vivo cell culture.
results: Mice fed the CD and exposed to HU and/or IR showed decreased bone volume, trabecular thickness, and vertebral strength. The DP diet prevented most of these detrimental effects. DP protected against HU-induced decrease in cortical thickness. DP also protected osteoblast progenitor cells from HU-induced damage, maintaining their growth and differentiation.
conclusions: Dietary supplementation with dried plum can mitigate bone loss and protect osteoprogenitors in mice exposed to simulated spaceflight conditions (microgravity and ionizing radiation). DP shows potential as a countermeasure against bone deficits observed in astronauts and individuals at risk of osteopenia.
relationships: The study demonstrates a relationship between simulated spaceflight conditions (microgravity and ionizing radiation), bone loss, and the protective effects of dietary dried plum. It also highlights the connection between osteoblast progenitor cell function and overall bone health.
insights: Dried plum's protective effects are likely due to its antioxidant properties and its ability to promote bone formation and inhibit bone resorption. DP may play an active role in protecting osteoprogenitors, possibly by maintaining the osteoblast's growth and differentiation.

title: Autophagy and its consequences for platelet biology
objective: To determine cardiac responses to extended microgravity exposure using the rat hindlimb unloading (HU) model, focusing on oxidative damage and gene expression changes.
methodology: Male and female Long-Evans rats (3 and 9 months old) underwent hindlimb unloading (HU) for up to 90 days, with some reambulating for 90 days post-HU. Hearts were analyzed for oxidative damage (8-OHdG levels), antioxidant gene expression (Sod1, Sod2, Nfe2l2, Sirt1), and transcriptomic changes (RNAseq).
results: Sex-dependent changes in oxidative damage and antioxidant gene expression were observed. Young females showed elevated 8-OHdG levels after 14 days of HU, while males showed no changes. RNAseq analysis revealed upregulation of pro-inflammatory signaling pathways and differential expression of genes associated with cardiovascular disease progression in older males after 14 days of HU.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity induces sex- and age-dependent changes in cardiac oxidative stress and gene expression. Targeting antioxidant and immune pathways, considering sex differences, may be crucial for developing countermeasures to maintain cardiovascular health in space.
relationships: Identified relationships between simulated microgravity, oxidative stress, immune response, circadian rhythm disruption, and cardiovascular disease-related gene expression in the rat heart.
insights: Prolonged spaceflight may upregulate pro-inflammatory signaling in cardiac tissue. Mitigating excessive inflammation and ensuring optimum antioxidant defenses may be a useful approach to ensure long-term cardiac health in astronauts during deep space missions.

title: A new role of NAP1L1 in megakaryocytes and human platelets
objective: To identify potential therapeutic targets for CKD through Mendelian randomization (MR) analysis of druggable genes.
methodology: MR analysis was performed using cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) of druggable genes as the exposure and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data for CKD from the FinnGen database as the outcome. Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) enrichment analyses were conducted. Colocalization analysis was performed to assess shared causal variants.
results: The expression of 12 genes (PTPN22, KSR1, MAP2K5, CASP9, MYLK4, CHSY1, TUBB, DHFR, GUCY1B2, CXCR1, CD96, and VAMP8) was significantly associated with CKD risk. Colocalization analysis suggested that CKD and the TUBB gene may share a causal variant.
conclusions: TUBB represents a promising pharmacological target for the treatment of CKD. Further research is warranted to elucidate the mechanisms and effects of TUBB on CKD.
relationships: TUBB expression is positively correlated with CKD risk. The identified genes are involved in the regulation of MAP kinase activity, regulation of protein serine/threonine kinase activity, Gap junction, Platelet activation and Oxytocin signaling pathway.
insights: This study identifies potential therapeutic targets and offers valuable insights for future drug development in the context of CKD. Targeting TUBB may reduce CKD risk.

title: A New Role of NAP1L1 in Megakaryocytes and Human Platelets
objective: To explore the expression pattern and functionality of nuclear assembly protein 1 like 1 (NAP1L1) in platelets (PLTs) and CD34+-derived megakaryocytes (MKs).
methodology: Molecular methods including RNAseq, co-IP, overexpression, and functional assays were used to analyze NAP1L1 expression and interactions with dihydrolipolylysine-residue acetyltransferase (DLAT encoded protein PDC-E2, ODP2). PDH activity was analyzed in PLTs from septic patients and MKs following an LPS-challenge. Proplatelet extension ability was assessed after NAP1L1 overexpression in MKs.
results: NAP1L1 is expressed in PLTs and MKs. NAP1L1 dynamically interacts with PDC-E2. Septic patients demonstrated increased PDH activity and NAP1L1 expression levels in PLTs. MKs PDH activity decreased following an LPS-challenge. Overexpression of NAP1L1 significantly altered the ability of MKs to form proplatelet extensions, diminishing thrombopoiesis.
conclusions: NAP1L1 performs in other than nucleosome-assembly functions in PLTs and MKs, binding a key mitochondrial protein as a potential chaperone and gatekeeper, influencing PDH activity and thrombopoiesis.
relationships: NAP1L1 interacts with PDC-E2, a subunit of the mitochondrial pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex. This interaction influences PDH complex activity and thrombopoiesis.
insights: NAP1L1 may have a role in regulating mitochondrial function and energy production in platelets and megakaryocytes, particularly in the context of sepsis.

title:
Evaluation of rodent spaceﬂight in the NASA animal enclosure module for an extended operational period
(up to 35 days)
objective: To determine if the NASA Animal Enclosure Module (AEM) can support rodents (mice and rats) for extended durations (up to 35 days) on the International Space Station with minimal modifications.
methodology: Mice and rats were housed in AEMs for 35 days. Animal health, body mass, food and water consumption, organ masses, and blood contents were monitored and compared to vivarium-housed controls. CO2 and ammonia levels within the AEM were also measured.
results: The AEMs supported 12 adult female mice and 5 adult male rats for 35 days. Body mass, food consumption, and overall health were comparable between AEM and vivarium groups. Water consumption was higher in AEM housed animals. CO2 and ammonia levels remained within acceptable limits. Blood analysis showed some statistically significant differences, but these were deemed not biologically significant.
conclusions: The AEM can support rodents for 35-day missions with minor hardware modifications, primarily focusing on food and water replenishment. The AEM life support systems functioned adequately. This supports the use of AEM for longer duration studies on the International Space Station.
relationships: The study compared AEM-housed animals to vivarium-housed controls to assess the impact of the AEM environment on various physiological parameters. The study also examined the relationship between AEM hardware capabilities and the requirements for long-duration rodent studies.
insights: The limiting factor for long-duration rodent housing in the AEM is the replenishment of food and water. The AEM environment can induce some physiological changes, but these are generally not biologically significant. The AEM is a viable platform for extended rodent studies in space.

title: Explainable machine learning identifies multi-omics signatures of muscle response to spaceflight in mice
objective: To understand the effects of microgravity on fungal biofilm morphology and growth of Penicillium rubens on spacecraft materials.
methodology: Spores of P. rubens were inoculated on seven different spacecraft-relevant materials and sent to the International Space Station (ISS) to form biofilms for 10, 15, and 20 days. The resulting biofilms were compared against matched ground controls using microscopy and quantitative image analysis.
results: Microgravity had mixed effects on biofilm growth depending on the material surface and incubation time. Nanograss was the most effective material at reducing fungal biofilm formation in both space and on Earth. Decreased biofilm growth was observed with increased incubation time in some cases, potentially due to nutrient depletion.
conclusions: Microgravity does not have a strong consistent effect on the shape and morphology of P. rubens biofilms up to 20 days. Nanograss shows potential as an anti-microbial material for spacecraft equipment. Long-term tests and further analyses are recommended.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between microgravity, material type, and incubation time on fungal biofilm formation. It also explores the potential of Nanograss as an anti-microbial surface.
insights: Fungal biofilms pose a risk to spacecraft and astronaut health. Understanding how microgravity and material surfaces affect biofilm formation is crucial for developing effective control strategies for long-term space missions. Nutrient availability and material properties play significant roles in biofilm development.

title: Explainable machine learning identiﬁes multi-omics signatures of muscle response to spaceﬂight in mice
objective: To identify molecular drivers of spaceflight effects on muscle physiology using spaceflight mouse muscle data and machine learning, focusing on calcium reuptake and multi-omics data.
methodology: Multi-omics data (transcriptomic, proteomic, and epigenomic) and calcium reuptake data from mouse soleus (SOL) and tibialis anterior (TA) muscles exposed to spaceflight were analyzed using the QLattice symbolic regression algorithm. The algorithm was used to predict calcium reuptake levels and to classify samples as either spaceflight or ground control. Key features contributing to the predictive capability of the models were identified as potential biomarkers.
results: In TA muscle, Acyp1 and Rps7 proteins were identified as key biomarkers predictive of calcium reuptake. Acyp1 protein expression was negatively correlated with calcium reuptake. In SOL muscle, Gm35576, Rspo3, Gpc4, Klhl31, Sox6, Auts2, Sobp, Mdga1, Aox1, Tle4, Klhl33, Eepd1, Rhbdl3, and Gm21955 genes were identified as critical genes playing an important role in calcium reuptake.  Actin protein was upregulated in TA FLT samples. Trak2 and Tle4 genes were also upregulated in FLT TA muscle.
conclusions: Machine learning identified multi-omics biomarkers predictive of changes in calcium reuptake capacity during spaceflight. Enhanced Ca2+ uptake in FLT TA is directly related to the combined interaction of Acyp1 protein downregulation and Rps7 protein upregulation; while decreased Ca2+ uptake in FLT SOL is related to interactions of upregulation of several different pairs of genes, including Gpc4, Tle4, Rspo3, and Klhl31. TA muscles are more resilient to space conditions, and Acyp1 and Rps7 seem to be good candidates to counteract weight losses and poor Ca2+ uptake observed in SOL muscles.
relationships: Acyp1 inhibits Ca2+ transporters in SERCA-1 (fast-twitch muscle fibers). Rps7 is downregulated by nitrosative stress, which is related to impaired calcium reuptake. Trak2 enables myosin binding activity for muscle contraction. Tle4 acts as a corepressor regulating muscle cell differentiation.
insights: Spaceflight induces distinct molecular responses in different muscle types (TA vs. SOL).  Acyp1 and Rps7 may play a mechanistic role in the dysregulation of calcium induced by spaceflight.  Mitochondrial regulation and perturbation of actin and myosin structural regulation are molecular responses to spaceflight in muscle.

title: Influence of the spaceflight environment on macrophage lineages
objective: To analyze the genomes of bacterial strains isolated on the International Space Station (ISS) to assess the role of bacteriophages in the spacecraft-built environment and correlate microbial adaptation in spaceflight to bacteriophage-encoded functions.
methodology: Genomes were sequenced from bacterial strains isolated on the ISS. Prophage regions were identified and compared between spaceflight strains and terrestrial counterparts using PHASTER and PhiSpy. Pangenome analysis was performed to compare the similarity within the flight strains for each species, compared to the pangenome for all strains of the same species.  Mitomycin C and UV treatment of ISS bacterial isolates was performed to elicit a lytic phenotype. Long-read genome sequencing was performed to explore the contribution of genome assembly level on the prophage predictions. Functional annotation of prophage regions was performed to assess the functional contribution of phages to their hosts.
results: Phage-associated genes are significantly different between spaceflight strains and their terrestrial counterparts.  A high number of novel prophages were identified in the flight genomes.  Spaceflight genomes were enriched for Mu-like phage structural proteins.  Complete prophage regions were clustered into bins of >90% similarity, with a portion classified as novel species and genera.  Mitomycin C and UV exposure showed a dose-response decrease in culture viability for some strains. Long-read assemblies provided more complete prophage analysis compared to short-read assemblies.
conclusions: Prophages are a primary mechanism of bacterial host gene transfer and are important for adaptation to the spaceflight environment. The association between genomic features enriched in ISS isolates and prophage regions suggest phage are important for adaptation to the spaceflight environment.
relationships: Microbial adaptation in spaceflight is correlated with bacteriophage-encoded functions. Prophages contribute to strain variation and diversity within bacterial species in the spaceflight environment.  Prophage-encoded proteins confer increased fitness in competitive environments.
insights: Bacteriophages play a significant role in microbial adaptation to the spaceflight environment, potentially impacting human health in spaceflight.  The study highlights the importance of understanding the interplay between microbial adaptation and human health during long-duration space missions.

title: Influence of the spaceflight environment on macrophage lineages
objective: To review current literature on macrophage responses to spaceflight and spaceflight analogs, and to highlight the importance of understanding how macrophages respond to the unique environment of space to safeguard crew members.
methodology: Literature review of studies on crew health, model organisms, space exploration vehicles, and the International Space Station (ISS).
results: Spaceflight and its analogs can alter immune phenotypes, specifically affecting macrophages. Altered leukocyte counts and function, as well as chronic low-grade inflammation, are observed in crew members who have flown in space. Macrophage differentiation and polarization processes may also be influenced by spaceflight risk factors.
conclusions: Understanding the impact of spaceflight-associated risks on macrophage phenotypes and functions is paramount for astronaut health monitoring and mitigation programs. Further research is needed to fully characterize unique phenotypes of monocytes and macrophages in spaceflight, including functional outcomes on lymphocyte populations.
relationships: Macrophages interact with the nervous and endocrine systems. They also play a role in antigen presentation and lymphocyte differentiation.
insights: Spaceflight-induced changes in macrophages can contribute to various physiological processes, including innate immunity, acquired immunity, host defense, and tissue remodeling. Combining spaceflight stressors in experiments would enable a more comprehensive understanding of the effects of the spaceflight environment on macrophage function.

title: In situ linkage of fungal and bacterial proliferation to microbiologically influenced corrosion in B20 biodiesel storage tanks.
objective: To understand microbial survival potential in Mars-like conditions by exposing fungal and bacterial samples to the middle stratosphere and measuring their survival and metabolic responses.
methodology: Fungal spores (Aspergillus niger) and bacterial cells (Salinisphaera shabanensis, Staphylococcus capitis subsp. capitis, and Buttiauxella sp. MASE-IM-9) were launched on a scientific balloon to the middle stratosphere (∼38 km altitude) inside the MARSBOx payload. Microorganisms were either exposed to full UV-VIS radiation or shielded from radiation. Survival and metabolic changes were assayed after 5-h stratospheric exposure.
results: Spores from A. niger and cells from S. shabanensis were the most resistant. Exposed Buttiauxella sp. MASE-IM-9 was completely inactivated, and S. capitis subsp. capitis only survived the UV-shielded experimental condition. Stratospheric sunlight reduced microbial survival.
conclusions: Pigmented fungi may be resistant to the martian surface if inadvertently delivered by spacecraft missions. Bacterial bioburden embedded deep inside spacecraft sent to Mars might remain viable for longer periods. A. niger spores are highly resistant to space radiation and Mars-like conditions.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between microbial characteristics, environmental conditions (radiation, desiccation, atmosphere), and survival potential in Mars-like environments. It also explores the relationship between spore concentration and survival outcomes.
insights: The middle stratosphere provides a robust Mars analog environment. Pigmented fungal spores are likely forward contaminants to Mars. Bacterial desiccation tolerance is influenced by Mars-like atmospheric conditions. The study underscores the importance of including fungal spores in planetary protection policies.

title: Identification of metagenome-assembled genomes containing antimicrobial resistance genes, isolated from an advanced water treatment facility.
objective: To characterize the microbial communities responsible for fouling of B20 biodiesel and determine whether their proliferation and bioﬁlms are associated with increased rates of corrosion of in-service B20 storage tanks.
methodology: A yearlong in situ study was conducted at two USAF bases with B20 biodiesel storage tanks. Corrosion coupons made of steel and polymeric O-rings were incubated in the tanks. Biofilms and fuel samples were collected periodically for DNA sequencing and microscopy. Biomass was estimated by weight difference of coupons. Corrosion was assessed by mass loss, microscopy, and pit depth measurements. Fuel acidity was also measured.
results: Microbial community composition varied significantly between bases and tanks. Acetobacteraceae and Clostridiaceae were abundant at one site, while Pannonibacter and Nitrospirillum were more abundant at the other. A filamentous fungus (Byssochlamys) and yeasts (Saccharomyces, Wickerhamomyces) were also identified. Coupons at one site had greater biomass and corrosion than the other. Increased fuel acidity corresponded to elevated corrosion rates. Biofilms were correlated with pitting corrosion.
conclusions: A mixed microbial community of filamentous fungi and acid-producing bacteria can proliferate in B20 biodiesel storage tanks, cause fouling, degrade fuel, produce organic acids, and accelerate steel corrosion under biofilms. The fungus Byssochlamys was a key contributor to biomass and corrosion. Operator vigilance in fuel quality and storage conditions is required to mitigate these issues.
relationships: The study established a direct link between fuel fouling, increased biofilm biomass, specific fungal and bacterial taxa, and pitting corrosion in operational B20 biodiesel tanks. The presence of Byssochlamys-like OTUs was strongly related to in situ corrosion.
insights: Microbial communities in B20 biodiesel tanks are spatially heterogeneous, with oxygen gradients influencing microbial metabolism and corrosion. Anaerobic conditions promote organic acid production, exacerbating corrosion. The study highlights the importance of preventing microbial biofilm establishment to control fouling, degradation, and corrosion in B20 biodiesel storage systems.

title: Nature of pre-earthquake phenomena and their effects on living organisms
objective: To identify metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) containing antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) from an advanced water treatment facility.
methodology: Water and bioﬁlm samples were collected from the Orange County Water District (OCWD) Advanced Water Puriﬁcation Facility (AWPF). Samples were ﬁltered, DNA was extracted, and libraries were prepared for sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq instrument. Sequence reads were error corrected and assembled into MAGs using bioinformatics tools like MEGAHIT and Anvi’o. MAGs were queried for ARGs using DeepARG.
results: Ninety-ﬁve MAGs containing 185 open reading frames putatively identiﬁed as antimicrobial resistance genes were selected. Two MAGs belonged to the “Candidatus Gracilibacteria” and “Candidatus Patescibacteria” lineages. No metagenomic sequence was identiﬁed after barrier ﬁltration.
conclusions: The study identified a variety of microbial lineages harboring ARGs within an ultrapuriﬁed water facility. These MAGs represent a useful resource to the water treatment community. Further research is needed to describe the ARGs and identify non-ARG-containing MAGs and determine how they impact the operation of the OCWD AWPF.
relationships: The study expands upon previous work characterizing microbial diversity and load decreasing across the water treatment system. It builds on prior research sampling bioﬁlms from the OCWD AWPF.
insights: Advanced water treatment facilities can harbor diverse microbial communities containing antimicrobial resistance genes. Metagenomic analysis is a valuable tool for identifying and characterizing these genes. Understanding the impact of these genes on water treatment processes is crucial for ensuring water quality.

title: The rapid diagnosis and effective inhibition of coronavirus using spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles
objective: To investigate the physical and chemical processes occurring before earthquakes and their potential impact on animal behavior, focusing on the role of positive hole charge carriers (h•).
methodology: Review of existing literature on pre-earthquake phenomena, animal behavior, electromagnetic emissions, air ionization, water oxidation, and the properties of positive hole charge carriers in rocks. Analysis of experimental data and field observations related to earthquake precursors and animal responses.
results: The study suggests that stress-activated h• charge carriers in rocks can generate electromagnetic waves, ionize the air, oxidize water, and release trace gases, all of which can act as stimuli for unusual animal behavior before earthquakes. The interaction of ULF/ELF waves with living organisms can interfere with fundamental biochemical reactions at the cellular level. Positive airborne ions are known to have physiological effects. Oxidation of water can produce hazardous toxins.
conclusions: Unusual animal behavior before earthquakes may be linked to physical and chemical changes caused by stress-activated h• charge carriers in the Earth's crust. These changes include electromagnetic emissions, air ionization, water oxidation, and trace gas release, which can affect animal physiology and behavior. Understanding these processes may provide insights into earthquake prediction and the interaction between animals and their environment.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between tectonic stress, positive hole charge carriers, electromagnetic emissions, air ionization, water oxidation, trace gas release, animal physiology, and unusual animal behavior before earthquakes.
insights: Positive hole charge carriers (h•) are activated in rocks under stress, leading to various physical and chemical phenomena that can influence animal behavior. Animals may respond to electromagnetic waves, air ionization, water oxidation, and trace gases released before earthquakes. The study highlights the importance of considering non-seismic factors in understanding earthquake precursors and animal behavior.

title: Blocking SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant (B.1.617.2) spike protein receptor-binding domain binding with the ACE2 receptor of the host cell and inhibiting virus infections using human host defense peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots.
objective: To develop and evaluate anti-spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles (GNPs) for rapid diagnosis and inhibition of SARS-CoV-2.
methodology: Synthesized anti-spike antibody attached GNPs using EDC/NHS chemistry. Characterized GNPs using TEM, DLS, UV-Vis spectroscopy, FTIR, and XRD. Used colorimetric assays and Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) for virus detection. Performed virus inhibition assays using HEK293T cells expressing ACE2 and pseudo SARS-CoV-2.
results: Developed a colorimetric assay for detecting COVID-19 antigen within 5 minutes, with a detection limit of 1 ng/mL.
