SERS-based assay detected COVID-19 antigen at 4 pg/mL and 18 virus particles/mL. Anti-spike antibody attached GNPs showed 100% inhibition of pseudo SARS-CoV-2 infection in HEK293T cells.
conclusions: Anti-spike antibody attached GNPs can be used for rapid and sensitive detection and inhibition of SARS-CoV-2. The colorimetric assay provides a rapid diagnostic tool, while SERS offers higher sensitivity. The GNPs effectively block viral entry and destroy the virus lipid membrane.
relationships: The study demonstrates the relationship between anti-spike antibody attached GNPs and their ability to bind to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, inhibiting its interaction with the ACE2 receptor on host cells. This interaction leads to both virus detection and inhibition of infection.
insights: The use of nanotechnology, specifically gold nanoparticles conjugated with anti-spike antibodies, offers a promising approach for combating viral infections like SARS-CoV-2. The dual functionality of these nanoparticles, enabling both rapid diagnostics and therapeutic intervention, highlights their potential for addressing future pandemics.

title: Safety and pharmacokinetics of intranasally administered heparin
objective: To investigate the potential of graphene quantum dots (GQDs) conjugated with human host defense peptides (HNP-1 and LL-37) to block SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant spike protein binding to the ACE2 receptor and inhibit viral infection.
methodology: Synthesis of GQDs, conjugation with HNP-1 and LL-37 peptides using carbodiimide coupling chemistry. Characterization using TEM, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, FTIR, and luminescence. Binding studies using a fluorescence spectrometer and ELISA-like assay. In vitro experiments using HEK293T cells and GFP-tagged Baculovirus pseudotyped with SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant spike protein to assess ACE2 binding inhibition and virus inhibition. Cell viability assays were also performed.
results: GQDs were successfully synthesized and conjugated with HNP-1 and LL-37 peptides. Characterization confirmed the formation of peptide-attached GQDs. Binding studies demonstrated the interaction between the peptide-conjugated GQDs and the SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant spike protein RBD. In vitro experiments showed that the peptide-conjugated GQDs could block ACE2 binding and inhibit viral infection. Cell viability assays indicated the biocompatibility of the materials.
conclusions: Human host defense peptides conjugated GQDs can effectively block the binding of the SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant spike protein to the ACE2 receptor and inhibit viral infection in vitro. This suggests a potential therapeutic application for these materials in combating SARS-CoV-2 infection.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between graphene quantum dots, human host defense peptides (HNP-1 and LL-37), the SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant spike protein, and the ACE2 receptor. It investigates how the conjugation of peptides to GQDs affects their ability to interact with the spike protein and block its binding to ACE2.
insights: The use of peptide-conjugated GQDs represents a promising approach for inhibiting SARS-CoV-2 infection. The biocompatibility and ability to block ACE2 binding suggest potential for further development as a therapeutic agent. The study highlights the importance of nanomaterials and peptide-based strategies in combating viral infections.

title: Inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) and Delta (B.1.617.2) strains by marine sulfated glycans.
objective: To measure the safety and pharmacokinetics of clearance of intranasally administered UFH solution from the nasal cavity in mice and humans.
methodology: Double-blinded daily intranasal dosing in C57Bl6 mice with UFH, blood coagulation measurements, adverse event monitoring, in vivo imaging of fluorescent-labeled UFH clearance in mice, and safety testing of intranasal UFH in healthy human subjects.
results: UFH showed no evidence of toxicity in mice or humans. No significant changes were observed in aPTT, INR, platelet count, or frequency of minor irritant events. In vivo imaging showed a single phase clearance of UFH from the nasal cavity, with 3.2% remaining after 12 hours and decaying to background levels by 48 hours.
conclusions: UFH showed no toxic effects for extended daily intranasal dosing in mice and humans. The clearance kinetics indicate potentially protective levels for up to 12 hours after dosing, suggesting intranasal heparin may have a high tolerance with a potentially large therapeutic window for preventing viral infections from respiratory viruses that use heparan sulfate as a co-receptor, including SARS-CoV-2.
relationships: SARS-CoV-2 entry into host cells is initiated by molecular interaction between the SARS-CoV-2 spike glycoproteins and heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPG) displayed on the host cell surfaces. Sulfated polysaccharides compete with cell surface HSPGs, disrupting virus entry.
insights: Intranasal administration of UFH is a safe and tolerable method for delivering heparin to the nasal passages, with potential for prophylactic use against SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory viruses. The extended retention of heparin in the nasal passages and lack of systemic bioavailability suggest a wide therapeutic window.

title: Inhibition of Cytomegalovirus by Pentacta pygmaea Fucosylated Chondroitin Sulfate Depends on Its Molecular Weight
objective: To evaluate the anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity of marine sulfated glycans (MSGs) against both the wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) and Delta (B.1.617.2) strains and examine if mutations in the Delta variant affect the anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity of MSGs.
methodology: Seven different MSGs were evaluated for their anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity using a virus entry assay. This assay utilized a SARS-CoV-2 pseudovirus coated with the S-protein of either the wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) or the Delta (B.1.617.2) strain. The structural integrity and molecular weights of the MSGs were confirmed using NMR spectroscopy and PAGE. Cytotoxicity assays were also performed.
results: All tested MSGs showed inhibitory activity against both SARS-CoV-2 strains. The inhibitory activities of the MSGs were generally similar and slightly weaker, respectively, against Wuhan and Delta strains compared to heparin. Most MSGs did not exhibit significant cell death at the tested concentrations, except for HfSF.
conclusions: MSGs maintain inhibitory activity against evolving SARS-CoV-2 strains. No direct correlation was observed between the structural features of the MSGs and their antiviral activity.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between the structure of MSGs and their ability to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 infection, focusing on the interaction between the viral S-protein and host cell receptors.
insights: MSGs can be considered as potential therapeutic molecules against SARS-CoV-2, even as the virus evolves. Further research is needed to understand the specific structural features that contribute to their antiviral activity.

title: Effect of simulated cosmic radiation on cytomegalovirus reactivation and lytic replication
objective: To investigate the inhibitory activity of native PpFucCS and its low molecular weight (LMW) fractions against Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) entry into cells.
methodology: Human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) were infected with HCMV in the presence of PpFucCS and its LMW fractions. Virus yield was assessed. Virus attachment and entry were visualized using R18 labeling. IC50 assays and virus yield reduction assays were performed. Cell viability was assessed using trypan blue exclusion and ATP release assays.
results: Native PpFucCS exhibited potent inhibitory activity against HCMV, specifically blocking virus entry. LMW PpFucCS derivatives showed inhibitory activities proportional to their chain lengths. PpFucCS and derived oligosaccharides did not exhibit significant cytotoxicity and protected infected cells from virus-induced lytic cell death. The inhibitory properties of PpFucCS against HCMV do not depend on the MOI.
conclusions: PpFucCS inhibits the entry of HCMV into cells, and the high MW of this carbohydrate is a key structural element to achieve the maximal anti-viral effect. PpFucCS is a promising candidate for development as a potential antiviral agent against HCMV infection.
relationships: HCMV attaches to host cells by interacting with cell surface heparan sulfate (HS). PpFucCS targets HS-virus interactions to prevent HCMV entry. The inhibitory activities of LMW PpFucCS derivatives were proportional to their chain lengths.
insights: PpFucCS, a marine sulfated glycan, shows promise as a prophylactic and therapeutic antiviral agent against HCMV infection due to its ability to block virus entry and protect cells from virus-induced cell death. The high molecular weight structure of PpFucCS is crucial for its antiviral activity.

title: A Tissue Retrieval and Postharvest Processing Regimen for Rodent Reproductive Tissues Compatible with Long-Term Storage on the International Space Station and Postflight Biospecimen Sharing Program
objective: To understand the role of galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) in reactivating latent cytomegalovirus (CMV).
methodology: Latently infected Kasumi cells with CMV were irradiated with various types of radiation (gamma rays, protons, carbon ions, iron ions, and simulated GCR). Viral load, cell viability, cell size, genomics, and transcriptomics were analyzed.
results: CMV copy number increased significantly in cells exposed to radiation compared to controls. Transcriptome analysis showed upregulation of transcription of the UL49 ORF. No significant nucleotide differences were found among the compared groups in viral genome sequencing.
conclusions: GCR may be a strong contributor to the reactivation of CMV infection seen in ISS crew members. The UL49 gene may play a role in GCR-mediated reactivation of CMV.
relationships: Spaceflight imposes stressors that can directly or indirectly cause herpes virus reactivation. Radiation track structure likely plays a role in CMV reactivation.
insights: Space radiation has a direct effect on the reactivation of herpesviruses, independent of immune dysregulation. The loss of cell viability resulting from cell transport from JSC to NSRL may have dampened the experimental findings from the logistics of travel.

title: Effects of sex and gender on adaptations to space: reproductive health
objective: To develop a strategy for optimal tissue harvest and preservation for spaceflight experiments, ensuring high-quality RNA and protein recovery from reproductive tissues after long-term storage on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Mice and gerbils were euthanized, and reproductive tissues (testes, epididymides, ovaries, uteri) were harvested at various time points post-euthanasia. Tissues were subjected to different fixation and storage methods, including Bouin's fixative, RNAlater, and various dehydration/rehydration protocols. Histological analysis, sperm motility assays, RNA integrity assessment, and Western blotting were performed to evaluate tissue quality and biomolecule preservation.
results: Optimal post-euthanasia harvest windows for maintaining histological integrity varied between tissues and species. Mouse testes maintained quality up to 2.5 hours post-euthanasia, while gerbil ovaries were more sensitive, requiring harvest within 1 hour. Slow rehydration-dehydration methods minimized tissue damage compared to rapid transitions. RNAlater effectively preserved RNA and protein quality in reproductive tissues for up to 10 months at -80°C, mimicking ISS storage conditions.
conclusions: The study established a comprehensive strategy for tissue harvest, fixation, and long-term storage suitable for spaceflight experiments. The findings provide guidelines for optimizing tissue processing logistics in multi-investigator Biospecimen Sharing Programs, ensuring high-quality data collection from animal tissues after prolonged storage on the ISS.
relationships: The study highlights the importance of considering tissue-specific degradation rates and optimizing post-harvest processing to maximize data quality in spaceflight experiments. It also demonstrates the effectiveness of RNAlater for long-term preservation of RNA and protein, enabling delayed sample return from the ISS.
insights: The research provides practical guidelines for researchers involved in spaceflight biology, particularly those utilizing animal models and participating in Biospecimen Sharing Programs. The optimized protocols for tissue harvest, fixation, and storage will enhance the reliability and reproducibility of spaceflight research, contributing to a better understanding of the effects of space on reproductive health.

title: Effects of spaceflight on the muscles of the murine shoulder.
objective: To examine the effects of spaceflight on insulin and estrogen signaling pathways across multiple tissues in rodents and humans, and to identify potential targets for countermeasures in future spaceflight missions.
methodology: Transcriptomic analysis (RNA-seq) was performed on various tissues from female mice flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days.  Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) were used to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs) and enriched pathways related to insulin and estrogen signaling and insulin resistance. Proteomics analysis was also performed on mouse tissues.  Human data from astronauts in the Japanese Space Agency (JAXA) Cell-Free Epigenome (CFE) Study mission and the Inspiration4 mission were analyzed to map genes of interest.
results: Spaceflight induced changes in insulin and estrogen signaling in both rodents and humans. In mice, the liver was the most impacted organ, with inhibition of insulin and estrogen receptor signaling, leading to hepatic insulin resistance and steatosis.  Skeletal muscles also showed alterations in insulin and estrogen signaling.  In humans, insulin signaling linked genes were dysregulated during and after spaceflight, with postflight upregulation of genes involved in insulin secretion and PI3K/AKT signaling. Estrogen signaling related genes were also altered postflight, with upregulation of genes involved in steroid hormone biosynthesis.
conclusions: Spaceflight alters insulin and estrogen signaling in both rodents and humans, impacting metabolism and potentially leading to comorbidities such as insulin resistance and hepatic steatosis. These findings highlight the need for further research on the metabolic and reproductive endocrinologic effects of space travel and suggest insulin and estrogen signaling as potential targets for countermeasures in future spaceflight missions.
relationships: The study reveals a complex interplay between insulin and estrogen signaling, insulin resistance, lipid metabolism, viral infection pathways, and immune responses during and after spaceflight. It also highlights the importance of considering sex differences in the response to spaceflight.
insights: The liver and soleus muscle in mice, and blood and skin in humans, are key tissues affected by spaceflight in terms of insulin and estrogen signaling.  Mitochondrial dysfunction, hepatic steatosis, and muscle atrophy are potential consequences of these alterations.  Circadian rhythm disruption may also play a role in the observed metabolic changes.

title: Multiscale effects of spaceflight on murine tendon and bone
objective: To investigate the effects of unloading on adult mouse shoulders at multiple hierarchical scales, focusing on the bone-tendon interface (enthesis). The hypothesis was that unloading would compromise mechanics and induce structural modifications at the nano-, micro- and macro-scales.
methodology: Adult mice shoulders were locally paralyzed via botulinum toxin A injections. Mechanical testing, spectroscopic (Raman), and imaging techniques (micro-computed tomography, synchrotron nano-X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy) were employed to examine the effects of extended unloading on the enthesis across a wide range of spatial scales.
results: Unloading led to compromised failure properties, including decreasing trends in strength and decreasing toughness of the attachment. Bone volume decreased, trabecular spacing increased, and trabecular thickness decreased. Mineral crystal size decreased, and crystallographic alignment was reduced. Carbonate levels in bone mineral were also decreased with unloading. Mineral was predominantly outside the collagen fibrils in regions of low mineralization.
conclusions: Unloading significantly increased the extent of failure of the enthesis, possibly due to structural changes across hierarchical scales. Trabecular bone volume in the humeral head was significantly decreased, leading to increased bending of the subchondral bone and subsequently increased failure area. Unloading led to decreases in crystal size and alignment, resulting in decreased energy absorption. Mineral carbonate content was decreased, increasing the stiffness of the crystals and thus the overall composite. Hierarchical changes at a variety of scales can affect the overall mechanical properties of the enthesis.
relationships: Unloading affects the enthesis at multiple scales. Millimeter-scale bone loss increases failure area. Micrometer-scale changes in crystal size and orientation decrease energy dissipation. Nanometer-scale compositional changes may increase compliant zone stiffness.
insights: The musculoskeletal system dynamically responds to its loading environment. Short durations of unloading can significantly increase the extent of failure of the enthesis due to structural changes across hierarchical scales. Treatments should consider structures at a variety of scales.

title: Reproducible changes in the gut microbiome suggest a shift in microbial and host metabolism during spaceflight
objective: To profile the gut microbiome of mice after a 37-day spaceflight and integrate the data with liver transcriptomic data to understand the effects of spaceflight on the gut microbiome and its interaction with host metabolism.
methodology: 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing was used to profile the microbiome in fecal samples from mice after a 37-day spaceflight. An analytical tool, STARMAPs, was developed to compare microbiome changes. Gut microbiome data was integrated with liver transcriptomic data for systems-level analysis.
results: Elevated microbiome alpha diversity and altered microbial community structure were associated with spaceflight. Microbiome changes shared similarity with previous space shuttle missions, suggesting reproducibility. Spaceflight led to altered taxon abundance and inferred microbial gene abundance, suggesting altered energy metabolism. Concordant changes in host liver genes and microbial gene content were identified, highlighting a relationship between host protein metabolism and microbial putrescine degradation.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces robust and reproducible changes in the gut microbiome, impacting mammalian metabolism. These findings contribute to understanding the role of the gut microbiome in mammalian health during spaceflight and provide a basis for developing microbiota-based countermeasures.
relationships: Identified correlations between the expression of host genes in the liver and inferred gene abundance of microbial metabolic pathways in the gut, suggesting potential interactions between microbial metabolic capability and host metabolism, particularly highlighting a relationship between host genes involved in protein metabolism and microbial genes involved in putrescine degradation.
insights: Spaceflight-associated changes in the gut microbiome may be attributed to specific space environmental factors, likely microgravity, and suggest an altered metabolic potential in the gut microbiota that was associated with the expression of metabolic genes in the host liver. Microgravity may lead to an altered metabolic environment for the microbes in the gastrointestinal tract via mechanisms such as lowered fluid shear dynamics, altered digesta movement, as well as other physiological and behavioral responses of the host, and the gut microbiota adapts to such changes by shifting community structure and associated gene content, which may in turn influence host biological functions.

title: Acute exposure to high dose gamma-radiation results in transient activation of bone lining cells
objective: To test the hypothesis that bone marrow fat contributes to the development of osteopenia by comparing the skeletal response to ovariectomy (ovx) in wild type (WT) and bone marrow adipocyte-deficient mice.
methodology: Ovariectomies were performed on wild type (WT) and bone marrow adipocyte-deficient mice. Body composition was measured using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. Cortical and cancellous bone architecture were evaluated by microcomputed tomography. Bone marrow adipocyte size and density, osteoblast- and osteoclast-lined bone perimeters, and bone formation were determined by histomorphometry.
results: Ovx resulted in an increase in total body fat mass in both genotypes, but the response was attenuated in the adipocyte-deficient mice. Adipocytes were present in bone marrow of WT mice and increased following ovx, but were not detected in either intact or ovx adipocyte-deficient mice. Ovx in both WT and adipocyte-deficient mice resulted in similar changes in cortical and cancellous bone mass, bone formation rate, and osteoblast and osteoclast-lined bone perimeters.
conclusions: The findings do not support a causal role for increased bone marrow fat as a mediator of ovx-induced osteopenia in mice. Absence of bone marrow adipocytes is not sufficient to lead to a net increase in bone mass.
relationships: Ovariectomy leads to increased body mass and total body fat mass and decreased cancellous and cortical bone mass. Increased bone marrow fat and increased cellular and dynamic indices of bone turnover are associated with these changes.
insights: Bone marrow adipose tissue is not required for the development of cortical or cancellous osteopenia following ovx in growing mice. Kit signaling is required for the ovx-induced increase in bone marrow adiposity in mice.

title: Morbid obesity attenuates the skeletal abnormalities associated with leptin deficiency in mice
objective: Evaluate the early effects of acute whole body γ-irradiation on bone metabolism in a mouse model and determine whether the anticipated detrimental effects of a challenging high-dose irradiation are attenuated by prior exposure to a relatively low dose of priming radiation. Also, investigate the efficacy of bone marrow transplantation in reversing the long-duration skeletal effects of high-dose whole body γ-irradiation.
methodology: Male and female C57BL/6 mice were used in irradiation experiments. Mice were divided into groups: untreated control, irradiated with a priming dose of 0.5 mGy, irradiated with a challenging dose of 6 Gy, or irradiated with 0.5 mGy followed by 6 Gy. Some mice underwent bone marrow transplantation after lethal irradiation (9 Gy). Bone architecture was assessed using micro-computed tomography (μCT) and histomorphometry. Cell populations were analyzed using fluorescence-activated cell sorting.
results: A 6 Gy dose of γ-radiation resulted in a rapid decline in bone marrow cell density, increased osteoblast and osteoclast activity, and decreased cancellous bone volume fraction. A priming dose of 0.5 mGy was ineffective in moderating these effects. Bone marrow transplantation normalized marrow cell density, bone turnover, and most indices of bone architecture following irradiation.
conclusions: High dose whole-body γ-radiation results in a dramatic bone turnover response in which both formation and resorption are increased, associated with bone marrow failure. Bone marrow transplantation, by restoring normal bone marrow function, is effective in restoring normal bone turnover following lethal irradiation.
relationships: Radiation-induced death of marrow cells is associated with a transient increase in bone formation and an increase in bone resorption. There is a strong association between radiation-induced marrow cell death and activation of bone lining cells to express the osteoblast phenotype.
insights: Bone marrow transplantation is effective in mitigating the detrimental effects of acute exposure to high dose whole body γ-radiation on bone turnover. The increased turnover is temporally associated with bone marrow failure and may result from disturbed regulation of osteoblast and osteoclast differentiation by hematopoietic cells.

title: Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces body weight without accelerating age-related bone loss
objective: To determine the specific actions of leptin in regulating bone mass, density, and architecture, and to assess the impact of morbid obesity on the skeletal phenotype of ob/ob mice.
methodology: Wild type (WT) mice, ob/ob mice fed ad libitum (ob/ob), and ob/ob mice pair-fed to WT mice (pair-fed ob/ob) were maintained at thermoneutral temperature (32°C) from 6 to 18 weeks of age. Bone mass, architecture, gene expression, and indices of bone turnover were evaluated using dual energy absorptiometry (DXA), microcomputed tomography (μCT), and histomorphometry. Serum osteocalcin and CTx levels were measured.
results: ob/ob mice exhibited decreased bone formation, defective osteoclast function, shorter femurs, thinner cortices, and higher cancellous bone volume fraction compared to WT mice. Pair-feeding accentuated many of these abnormalities. Morbid obesity in ob/ob mice partially protected against the skeletal effects of leptin deficiency.
conclusions: Leptin deficiency leads to decreased bone formation and defective osteoclast function. Morbid obesity attenuates the abnormal skeletal phenotype associated with leptin deficiency, suggesting that leptin's role in regulating postnatal bone growth may have been underestimated.
relationships: Leptin deficiency is associated with decreased bone formation and defective osteoclast function. Morbid obesity partially protects against these effects, potentially due to increased mechanical loading and changes in hormone levels. Leptin is required for normal osteoclast function, potentially serving as a counter-regulatory mechanism to prevent excessive bone loss during fasting.
insights: The study highlights the complex interplay between leptin, obesity, and bone metabolism. Preventing morbid obesity in leptin-deficient mice exacerbates skeletal abnormalities, suggesting that the role of leptin in bone regulation is more significant than previously thought. The findings suggest that both adequate energy availability and leptin play important roles in bone accrual in growing mice.

title: Hypothalamic Leptin Gene Therapy Reduces Bone Marrow Adiposity in ob/ob Mice Fed Regular and High-Fat Diets.
objective: To determine the long-term efficacy of increased hypothalamic leptin in reducing adult-onset associated weight gain and the impact this intervention has on bone mass, density, and architecture in skeletally mature female rats.
methodology: Nine-month-old female Sprague Dawley rats were divided into three groups: baseline control, rAAV-GFP control, and rAAV-Leptin. The rAAV-Leptin group received hypothalamic leptin gene therapy. Body weight, food consumption, serum chemistry, RNA analysis, dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA), and microcomputed tomography (μCT) were performed to assess the effects on energy balance and bone metabolism over 18 weeks.
results: rAAV-Leptin-treated rats experienced weight loss, reduced abdominal white adipose tissue (WAT) weight, lower serum leptin, and lower serum IGF1 compared to rAAV-GFP-treated rats. Food consumption was also lower in the rAAV-Leptin group. There were minimal long-term effects on bone mass, density, microarchitecture, or serum markers of bone turnover.
conclusions: Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy induced weight loss without negatively impacting bone mass, density, or microarchitecture in skeletally mature rats. This suggests that increasing hypothalamic leptin levels can overcome leptin resistance and lower body weight without detrimental effects on the skeleton.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between hypothalamic leptin, body weight, and bone metabolism. It investigates how leptin gene therapy affects weight loss and whether this weight loss has any adverse effects on bone health.
insights: Increasing hypothalamic leptin levels can be a potential strategy to combat obesity without negatively impacting bone health. This approach may overcome leptin resistance and offer a therapeutic avenue for weight management while preserving skeletal integrity.

title: Room temperature housing results in premature cancellous bone loss in growing female mice: implications for the mouse as a preclinical model for age-related bone loss.
objective: To determine the long-duration impact of increased hypothalamic leptin on marrow adipocytes and osteoblasts in ob/ob mice following recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV) gene therapy, and to evaluate the effects of a regular and high energy density (high fat) diet.
methodology: Two experiments were conducted. In Experiment 1, ob/ob mice were randomized into four groups: untreated, rAAV-GFP, rAAV-Lep, or pair-fed to rAAV-Lep, and maintained for 30 weeks. In Experiment 2, WT and ob/ob mice were used. WT mice were maintained on regular chow and then randomized into control or high-fat diet groups. Ob/ob mice were randomized into rAAV-Lep or rAAV-GFP groups, and then divided into regular or high-fat diet groups. Histomorphometry was used to evaluate bone and cell-based measurements.
results: rAAV-Lep treatment resulted in lower body weight compared to control groups. Trabecular thickness was lower in rAAV-Lep-treated mice. Marrow adiposity, adipocyte density, and adipocyte size were lower in rAAV-Lep-treated mice. Osteoblast and osteoclast perimeters were higher in rAAV-Lep-treated mice. High-fat diet increased body weight in both WT and ob/ob mice, but increased MAT and cancellous bone in WT mice only. rAAV-Lep treatment decreased MAT in ob/ob mice.
conclusions: Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy maintained low MAT levels in ob/ob mice fed regular or high-fat diet. The reduction in MAT was accompanied by an increase in osteoblast-lined bone perimeter but not an increase in cancellous bone volume fraction. Interventions targeted at reducing MAT may not be an effective strategy for increasing bone mass.
relationships: Leptin plays an important role in regulating the differentiation of MSCs to adipocytes and osteoblasts, a process that may be dysregulated by high-fat diet. High MAT levels in ob/ob mice are associated with low cancellous bone turnover.
insights: The physiological actions of leptin on MAT are primarily manifested at low hormone levels, and hyperleptinemia has little further effect on MAT. A deterministic model where reducing MAT will invariably lead to increased bone volume is not tenable.

title: Spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss in ovariectomized rats is associated with increased bone marrow adiposity and no change in bone formation
objective: Assess whether mitigating cold adaptation by thermoneutral housing influences bone growth, turnover, and microarchitecture in female mice.
methodology: Growing female C57BL/6J and C3H/HeJ mice were housed at either 22°C or 32°C for up to 18 weeks. Bone microarchitecture was assessed using microcomputed tomography. Static and dynamic bone histomorphometry was performed on distal femur metaphysis. Gene expression related to osteoblast and adipocyte differentiation was determined.
results: Mice housed at 22°C experienced cancellous bone loss, while those at 32°C showed unchanged or increased bone mass. Thermoneutral housing decreased Ucp1 gene expression in brown adipose tissue, increased bone marrow adiposity, higher rates of bone formation, higher expression levels of osteogenic genes and locally decreased bone resorption.
conclusions: Housing female mice at 22°C resulted in premature cancellous bone loss. Failure to account for species differences in thermoregulation may seriously confound interpretation of studies utilizing mice as preclinical models for osteoporosis.
relationships: Housing temperature significantly impacts bone metabolism in mice. Thermoneutral housing prevents premature cancellous bone loss. Bone formation is increased with thermoneutral housing. Leptin levels are affected by housing temperature and influence bone metabolism.
insights: Standard laboratory housing temperatures may induce cold stress in mice, confounding preclinical osteoporosis studies. Thermoneutral housing may minimize the impact of adaptive thermogenesis.

title: Role of oestrogen receptor signaling in skeletal response to leptin in female ob/ob mice.
objective: To evaluate the effects of a 14-day spaceflight on bone mass, bone resorption, bone formation, and bone marrow adiposity (MAT) in lumbar vertebrae of ovariectomized (OVX) rats.
methodology: Twelve-week-old OVX rats were randomly assigned to a ground control or flight group. Following flight, histological sections of the second lumbar vertebrae were stained to quantify cells and preflight fluorochrome label. Cancellous bone area, MAT, mineral apposition rate, osteoblast turnover, bone resorption, and osteoclast-lined bone perimeter were measured.
results: Rats flown in space had lower cancellous bone area and higher MAT compared to ground controls. The increased adiposity was due to an increase in adipocyte number and size. Bone resorption was increased during spaceflight, while indices of osteoblast kinetics were not altered.
conclusions: Spaceflight-induced cancellous bone loss in rat lumbar vertebrae is accompanied by increased bone resorption and MAT, but no change in bone formation. Increased MAT during spaceflight does not reduce osteoblast activity or lifespan. Bone formation during spaceflight was insufficient to balance increased resorption, indicating defective coupling. Mesenchymal stem cells may be diverted to adipocytes at the expense of forming osteoblasts.
relationships: Spaceflight leads to bone loss, increased bone resorption, and increased bone marrow adiposity. In the context of ovarian hormone deficiency, bone formation is insufficient to compensate for increased resorption. There is a potential link between increased MAT and defective coupling of bone formation to bone resorption.
insights: The study suggests that spaceflight may cause a shift in the differentiation program of stromal cells from osteoblasts to adipocytes, contributing to bone loss. The increase in MAT does not directly impair osteoblast activity but may contribute to defective coupling of bone formation to increased bone resorption in the context of ovarian hormone deficiency.

title: Effects of hypothalamic leptin gene therapy on osteopetrosis in leptin-deficient mice.
objective: To determine the role of estrogen receptors (ERs) in skeletal longitudinal growth of leptin-deficient mice and examine the effects on axial and appendicular growth.
methodology: Female ob/ob mice (leptin-deficient) and wild-type mice were used. Bone length was analyzed by X-ray. ER antagonists (MPP for ERα, PHTPP for ERβ) were administered. Histomorphometry, immunohistochemistry, TUNEL assay, real-time PCR, and Western blotting were performed on femur and spinal growth plates.
results: Ob/ob mice showed shorter femur length and longer spine length compared to wild-type. Femur growth plate was thinner, while spinal growth plate was thicker in ob/ob mice. ERα expression was decreased in femur growth plate and increased in spinal growth plate of ob/ob mice. ER antagonists had no regulatory effects on bone growth in ob/ob mice.
conclusions: Leptin deficiency results in region-specific expression of ERα in femoral and spinal growth plates, contributing to contrasting phenotypes in axial and appendicular bone growth. Leptin deficiency also disrupts the regulatory effects of ER antagonists on longitudinal bone growth.
relationships: Leptin deficiency influences ERα expression in axial and appendicular growth plates, contributing to skeletal growth differences. ERα expression is positively correlated with axial and appendicular length.
insights: The study suggests that region-specific ERα expression plays a role in the contrasting bone growth patterns observed in leptin-deficient mice. Leptin deficiency blunts the regulatory effects of ER antagonists on longitudinal bone growth, highlighting the complex interplay between leptin and ER signaling in skeletal development.

title: Leptin stimulates bone formation in ob/ob mice at doses having minimal impact on energy metabolism.
objective: To determine if osteopetrosis in ob/ob mice is self-limiting and reversible by leptin treatment.
methodology: Histomorphometric analysis of femurs in wild type (WT) and ob/ob male mice at 2, 4, and 6 months of age. Hypothalamic recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV) gene therapy was used in 2-month-old ob/ob mice to restore leptin signaling, and the bone response was evaluated 7 months later. Mice were divided into three groups: untreated control, rAAV-Leptin, and control vector rAAV-green fluorescent protein.
results: Cartilage matrix was present in the epiphysis, metaphysis, and diaphysis in untreated and rAAV-GFP-treated control mice. rAAV-Leptin treatment resulted in lower cartilage area fraction in the epiphysis, metaphysis, and diaphysis compared to untreated mice, and lower cartilage area fraction in the metaphysis compared to rAAV-GFP mice. Osteoclast and osteoblast perimeter were higher in rAAV-Lep-treated mice compared to untreated and rAAV-GFP-treated mice.
conclusions: Leptin is important for normal replacement of cartilage by bone. Osteopetrosis in ob/ob mice is site-specific and reversible by leptin at skeletal sites capable of undergoing robust bone turnover.
relationships: Leptin deficiency results in reduced bone resorption and formation, leading to prolonged retention of cartilage. Leptin treatment increases bone turnover and reduces cartilage matrix.
insights: Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy promotes maturation of cancellous bone in distal femur by increasing bone turnover and reducing cartilage matrix. Leptin acts on the skeleton to regulate bone growth and turnover.

title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Deficiency Increases Disuse-Induced Bone Loss in Male Mice
objective: To determine the dose-response effects of leptin on bone and energy metabolism in leptin-deficient ob/ob mice, modeling leptin production by adipose tissue.
methodology: A 12-day dose-response study was performed in 6-week-old female ob/ob mice, infusing leptin at various concentrations (0, 4, 12, 40, 140, or 400 ng/h) using osmotic pumps. Bone growth and turnover were assessed via microcomputed tomography, histomorphometry, and serum chemistry. Gene expression in tibia and hypothalamus was analyzed using PCR arrays.
results: Leptin increased osteoblast perimeter, mineralizing perimeter, and bone formation rate at an infusion rate of 4 ng/h, and mineral apposition rate and longitudinal growth rate at an infusion rate of 12 ng/h. Leptin increased UCP-1 gene expression and decreased food intake and rate of body weight gain at an infusion rate of 12 ng/h. Bone formation parameters were increased at EC50 ranging from 7–17 ng/h whereas higher leptin levels (EC50 of 40–80 ng/h) were required to similarly impact indices of energy metabolism.  Gene expression analysis showed differential expression of genes related to Jak/Stat signaling and bone cell function in tibia, with minimal effects in hypothalamus at lower leptin doses.
conclusions: Leptin acts on the skeleton at dose rates having minimal impact on energy metabolism. Bone formation is positively regulated by leptin through peripheral signaling. The saturable transport system, which limits delivery of leptin from the hormone’s origin in peripheral adipose tissue to the hypothalamus, may function to guarantee that adequate energy is available for important anabolic processes such as bone growth and turnover and that these actions are dissociable from the actions of the hormone to reduce appetite and increase thermogenesis.
relationships: Leptin deficiency leads to skeletal abnormalities. Leptin acts peripherally to stimulate bone formation. Leptin's effects on bone are dissociable from its central nervous system-mediated effects on energy metabolism due to limited transport across the blood-brain barrier. Leptin influences Jak/Stat signaling in both bone and hypothalamus, with differential gene expression patterns.
insights: Osteoblasts and growth plate cartilage cells are exquisitely sensitive to low circulating levels of leptin. Peripheral leptin signaling plays a crucial role in regulating bone formation, independent of central leptin's effects on energy balance. The study highlights the importance of considering peripheral leptin actions in understanding bone metabolism and potential therapeutic interventions.

title: Metabolic Coupling Between Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue and Hematopoiesis
objective: To determine if the absence of bone marrow adipose tissue (MAT) reduces bone loss in hindlimb-unloaded (HU) mice, and to investigate the role of MAT in disuse-induced bone loss.
methodology: Male MAT-deficient KitW/W−v mice and wild-type (WT) mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU) for 2 weeks. Bone microarchitecture was evaluated using micro-computed tomography, histomorphometry, and targeted gene profiling. Adoptive transfer of WT bone marrow-derived hematopoietic stem cells was used to reconstitute c-kit but not MAT in KitW/W−v mice.
results: MAT-deficient mice experienced a greater reduction in bone volume fraction after HU compared to WT mice. HU MAT- mice had elevated cancellous bone formation and resorption, along with a unique profile of differentially expressed genes. Adoptive transfer of WT bone marrow-derived hematopoietic stem cells did not prevent cancellous bone loss following HU in MAT-deficient mice. HU resulted in higher blood glucose levels, accentuated in MAT- mice.
conclusions: MAT deficiency was not protective against disuse-induced bone loss and was associated with exaggerated cancellous bone loss. Increased MAT may not be a prerequisite for HU-induced cancellous bone loss, and may actually attenuate disuse-induced osteopenia by limiting the magnitude of increased bone turnover. The underlying mechanisms mediating cancellous bone loss in HU MAT- and WT mice are not identical.
relationships: MAT is negatively associated with bone mass. Osteoblasts and adipocytes are derived from the same precursor cells. HU model produces skeletal changes similar to those observed in astronauts following spaceflight.
insights: The study suggests that MAT deficiency exacerbates disuse-induced bone loss, potentially due to unbalanced bone turnover. The skeletal response to HU differs between MAT-deficient and WT mice, indicating distinct underlying mechanisms. The role of c-kit signaling and the impact of MAT on blood glucose regulation may contribute to the observed differences in bone loss.

title: Maintenance of near normal bone mass and architecture in lethally irradiated female mice following adoptive transfer with as few as 750 purified hematopoietic stem cells.
objective: To investigate the role of the mannose receptor (Mrc1) in the bone marrow during obesity development and its relationship with systemic inflammation.
methodology: Mrc1−/− mice and wild-type (WT) mice were fed a high-fat diet (HFD) for 20 weeks. Weight gain, glucose and insulin tolerance were assessed. Flow cytometry, histological, and proteomic analyses were performed on bone marrow, blood, adipose tissue, and liver samples.
results: Mrc1 deficiency resulted in reduced myelopoiesis and increased adipocyte count in the bone marrow. Circulating neutrophils and pro-inflammatory monocytes were reduced in Mrc1−/− mice. Macrophage infiltration in visceral adipose tissue and liver was also decreased. Mrc1−/− mice showed reduced weight gain, liver steatosis, and improved glucose and insulin response compared to WT mice.
conclusions: Mrc1 deficiency promotes a medullary rewiring in mice with diet-induced obesity, reflected in changes to circulating immune subsets and systemic inflammatory status, leading to protection from obesity-related dysfunctions.
relationships: Mrc1 deficiency impacts hematopoietic stem cell differentiation and release. It reduces the number of activated immune cells in circulation and their infiltration in tissues. The soluble mannose receptor stimulates tissue macrophage activation towards inflammation.
insights: The mannose receptor plays a role in the immunometabolic response associated with diet-induced obesity. Mrc1 deficiency leads to a protective bone marrow phenotype and reduces leukocyte infiltration, dampening obesity development.

title: Effect of leptin deficiency on the skeletal response to hindlimb unloading in adult male mice.
objective: To establish an approach for reconstituting bone marrow using small numbers of purified donor-derived hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) without negatively affecting bone metabolism after lethal total-body irradiation (TBI). Also, to evaluate the efficacy of adoptive transfer using purified HSCs on animal survival and on bone growth, mass, density, architecture, and turnover after lethal TBI.
methodology: Four experiments were conducted using different strains of mice (WBB6F1, B6, KitW/W-v). Mice were lethally irradiated and then transplanted with either bone marrow cells or purified HSCs. Various techniques were used to analyze the effects of transplantation, including flow cytometry, ex vivo cell differentiation assays (osteoclasts and adipocytes), densitometry (DXA), microcomputed tomography (lCT), histomorphometry, serum biomarker analysis (osteocalcin, CTX-1), and gene expression analysis.
results: Adoptive transfer of bone marrow cells or purified HSCs was effective in reconstituting hematopoietic lineage cells in spleen and bone marrow. HSCs give rise to cells of both lymphoid and myeloid lineages.  Both methods of adoptive transfer were effective in reconstituting osteoclast precursors from donor cells, but neither method successfully reconstituted bone marrow adipocyte precursors from donor cells, and neither method prevented radiation-associated suppression of linear bone growth or reduction in bone volume. WBB6F1 mice engrafted with 750 HSCs after fractionated exposures (2 x 5 Gy) had near-normal bone mass and microarchitecture eight weeks after engraftment. Adoptive transfer of purified HSCs after 5 Gy irradiation was as effective as 2 x 5 Gy irradiations in restoring Kit gene expression in bone marrow.
conclusions: Bone marrow can be effectively reconstituted by engrafting purified HSCs after fractionated lethal TBI. This approach minimizes TBI-induced collateral damage to bone mass and architecture, making it valuable for skeletal biology studies. Adoptive transfer of purified HSCs selectively reconstitutes hematopoietic lineage cells.  Fractionating TBI also has a bone-sparing effect.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, bone marrow reconstitution, and bone metabolism following radiation exposure. It explores how different cell populations (osteoclasts, adipocytes) are affected by the transplantation process and how these changes influence bone growth and architecture.
insights: The use of purified HSCs for bone marrow reconstitution after irradiation offers a refined approach for studying the interactions between the hematopoietic system and the skeleton. The findings suggest that MSCs may not be essential for survival and normalization of bone formation after lethal TBI. Fractionated radiation may have a bone-sparing effect compared to single-dose radiation.

title: Thermoneutral housing attenuates premature cancellous bone loss in male C57BL/6J mice
objective: To evaluate the skeletal response of wild type (WT) and ob/ob mice to hindlimb unloading (HU) to determine if leptin deficiency attenuates bone loss induced by unweighting.
methodology: Male WT and ob/ob mice were housed at thermoneutrality and subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU) for two weeks. Bone parameters were assessed using DXA, micro-CT, and histomorphometry. Food intake was controlled through pair-feeding. Statistical analysis involved two-way ANOVA.
results: ob/ob mice had lower femur length and total bone area, mineral content (BMC) and density (BMD), and higher cancellous bone volume fraction in lumbar vertebra (LV). HU resulted in lower BMC and BMD in total femur, and lower BV/TV in distal femur and LV in both genotypes. Cancellous bone loss in femur in both genotypes was associated with increases in osteoclast-lined bone perimeter. Leptin deficiency did not attenuate HU-induced osteopenia.
conclusions: Leptin deficiency does not prevent HU-induced cancellous bone loss in male mice, suggesting that leptin is not essential for the skeletal response to unweighting. HU-induced bone loss is primarily due to increased bone resorption.
relationships: Leptin deficiency results in shorter femora, lower femoral bone mass and density, alterations in cortical bone microarchitecture, site- and bone-specific alterations in cancellous bone architecture, and greatly increased MAT levels. These results indicate that leptin plays a critical role in normal bone growth, maturation, and turnover.
insights: The study challenges the hypothesis that leptin deficiency would diminish bone loss in response to HU. The findings suggest that other factors besides leptin play a more significant role in skeletal adaptation to unloading in male mice.

title: Effects of Spaceflight on Cancellous and Cortical Bone in Proximal Femur in Growing Rats
objective: To determine if the effects of housing temperature on bone in female mice were generalizable to male mice, focusing on premature cancellous bone loss.
methodology: Male mice were housed at either standard room temperature (22°C) or thermoneutral conditions (32°C) from 5 to 16 weeks of age. Bone volume and architecture were evaluated using microcomputed tomography and histomorphometry. Serum markers of bone turnover and leptin were measured. Gene expression in brown adipose tissue was assessed.
results: Mice housed at room temperature exhibited reductions in cancellous bone volume fraction in the distal femur and lumbar vertebra. Thermoneutral housing prevented this bone loss and increased bone formation. Thermoneutral housing also resulted in higher abdominal white adipose tissue and serum leptin.
conclusions: Housing mice at thermoneutral temperature attenuates premature cancellous bone loss by increasing bone formation and reducing bone resorption. Housing temperature is a critical experimental variable in studies investigating bone metabolism in mice.
relationships: Housing temperature influences bone metabolism through neuroendocrine pathways related to adaptive thermogenesis and sympathetic nervous system activity. Increased catecholaminergic activity inhibits osteoblast function and enhances osteoclast function, contributing to premature bone loss at room temperature.
insights: Premature cancellous bone loss in mice is influenced by housing temperature, with thermoneutral conditions preventing bone loss. This effect is linked to adaptive thermogenesis and sympathetic nervous system activity, highlighting the importance of considering environmental factors in bone metabolism studies.

title: Evidence for increased thermogenesis in female C57BL/6J mice housed aboard the international space station
objective: To evaluate the effects of spaceflight on bone microarchitecture in the femoral head of rats, considering factors like sex and strain, by assessing archived bone specimens from previous spaceflight experiments.
methodology: X-ray microtomography/microcomputed tomography (μCT) was used to assess cancellous microarchitecture and cortical thickness in proximal femora from rats flown on 10-day (STS-57) and 14-day (STS-62) missions. Statistical analysis involved ANOVA models and Dunnett’s procedure to compare spaceflight, flight control, and baseline groups.
results: Spaceflight resulted in lower cancellous bone volume fraction in the femoral head of male Fisher 344 rats (STS-57) and ovariectomized female Fisher 344 rats (STS-62). Cortical thickness did not significantly differ among groups. Cancellous osteopenia was detected in femur and lumbar vertebra, but not humerus, in rats and in the femur head in mice.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces cancellous osteopenia in the proximal femoral head of growing rats, potentially due to reduced bone accrual or increased bone resorption. The magnitude of the response may vary based on strain, age, and flight duration. Significant bone loss during long-duration spaceflight in astronauts occurs in the proximal femur.
relationships: Spaceflight affects bone microarchitecture differently depending on the skeletal site (appendicular vs. axial) and compartment (cancellous vs. cortical). Mechanical strain and endocrine status influence bone turnover, with bone loss occurring preferentially at sites experiencing low mechanical strain energies.
insights: Microgravity-induced reduction in bone volume fraction at the femoral head may increase fracture risk during spaceflight. Future studies should evaluate this clinically relevant site in skeletally mature animals to understand the long-term effects of spaceflight on bone health.

title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice
objective: To determine if spaceflight increases non-shivering thermogenesis in mice by measuring the effect of spaceflight on expression of genes related to energy metabolism in brown adipose tissue (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT).
methodology: Sixteen-week-old female mice were flown to the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days. Gene expression in BAT and WAT was analyzed via RT-qPCR. Temperatures were monitored during the mission.
results: Mice housed aboard the ISS had higher levels of Ucp-1 in BAT, indicating elevated non-shivering thermogenesis. Several genes associated with adipogenesis and/or thermogenesis were differentially expressed in BAT during spaceflight. In WAT, genes related to fatty acid oxidation, thyroid hormone action, glucose transport, and fatty acid synthesis were upregulated. Ucp-1 expression was induced in WAT, suggesting browning.
conclusions: Adaptive thermogenesis is increased in BAT of mice housed aboard the ISS compared to ground controls, despite comparable housing temperatures. Increased thermogenesis may influence physiological responses to spaceflight in mice.
relationships: Adaptive thermogenesis influences multiple physiological processes including bone loss, immune suppression, glucocorticoid production, blood pressure, heart rate, and tissue response to ionizing radiation. Leptin and sympathetic nervous system activity are key factors in adaptive thermogenesis.
insights: Spaceflight may reduce the ability of mice to minimize adaptive thermogenesis, leading to increased dependence on it to maintain core body temperature. Increased thermogenesis in mice during spaceflight may introduce confounding variables into spaceflight studies.

title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice
objective: To understand the role of leptin as a mediator of bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) response to changes in environmental temperature.
methodology: Two experiments were performed on female mice housed at room temperature (22°C) and near thermoneutral temperature (32°C). Experiment 1 involved leptin supplementation in wild-type mice. Experiment 2 evaluated BMAT response in wild-type and leptin-deficient ob/ob mice with and without leptin treatment. BMAT was measured after two weeks. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) was used to measure body composition. Serum leptin, osteocalcin, and CTX-1 were measured using ELISA kits. Histomorphometry was performed on distal femora to assess bone formation and marrow adiposity. Gene expression analysis was conducted on brown adipose tissue (BAT), white adipose tissue (WAT), and tibia.
results: Leptin supplementation in wild-type mice decreased food intake, body fat, WAT mass, and BMAT. Bone area and mineral content were higher in leptin-supplemented mice. In ob/ob mice, increased housing temperature increased body fat and BMAT. Leptin treatment in ob/ob mice reduced BMAT increase.
conclusions: Increased housing temperature and increased leptin have independent but opposing effects on BMAT in mice. Alleviation of cold stress by housing mice at thermoneutral temperature increases BMAT compared to room temperature housing, whereas increasing leptin signaling decreases BMAT.
relationships: An inverse relationship between bone formation rate and BMAT levels was observed in the distal femur of mice following leptin supplementation. Leptin and environmental temperature may influence BMAT levels by regulating overlapping pathways.
insights: Leptin signaling and environmental temperature independently regulate BMAT levels. Leptin inhibits BMAT accrual at lower levels than required to inhibit WAT accrual. Growing mice fed a normal diet are highly leptin sensitive.

title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Is Not Required for Reconstitution of the Immune System Following Irradiation in Male Mice
objective: To determine how small differences in temperature (4°C) or heat loss (individual versus group housing with nestlets) influence bone microarchitecture in growing female mice.
methodology: Five-week-old female C57BL/6J mice were randomized into four groups: baseline, single housed at 22°C, single housed at 26°C, and group housed at 22°C with nestlets. Bone volume and architecture were measured using microcomputed tomography. Gene expression analysis was performed on brown adipose tissue.
results: Mice single housed at 26°C and group housed at 22°C had lower Ucp1 expression in brown adipose tissue compared to mice single housed at 22°C. Mice single housed at 26°C had higher cancellous bone volume fraction and trabecular number, and lower trabecular separation in distal femur metaphysis compared to mice single housed at 22°C. Group housing with nestlets also moderated the effect of room temperature housing.
conclusions: Modest differences in housing conditions can influence bone mass and architecture. A 4°C increase in environmental temperature, as well as group housing mice with nestlets, attenuated the skeletal response to chronic cold stress associated with housing mice individually at standard room temperature.
relationships: Cold stress induces bone loss. Increased housing temperature or group housing attenuates bone loss. Ucp1 expression in brown adipose tissue is related to housing temperature and bone health. Thermoregulation impacts bone microarchitecture.
insights: Maintaining mice at standard room temperature induces cold stress, leading to cancellous bone loss. Small increases in housing temperature or group housing with nestlets can mitigate this bone loss. Housing conditions can significantly influence experimental results in bone research.

title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Is Not Required for Reconstitution of the Immune System Following Irradiation in Male Mice
objective: To assess the importance of bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) following severe injury in (1) supporting hematopoiesis and (2) maintaining bone turnover balance.
methodology: Lethally irradiated wild type (WT) and BMAT-deficient mice were given adoptive transfers of purified hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs). Immune reconstitution was assessed by detecting GFP-positive cells. Bone microarchitecture, turnover, and cell populations were compared between WT and BMAT-deficient mice.
results: Adoptive transfer of HSCs effectively reconstituted the immune systems of both WT and BMAT-deficient mice. BMAT deficiency did not prevent equalization of most bone parameters between WT and BMAT-deficient mice. Normalization of kit signaling equalized many of the divergent bone parameters typically observed between WT and KitW/W-v mice.
conclusions: BMAT is not required for skeletal recovery from injury and energy deficit following exposure to high-dose radiation. Kit signaling plays an important role in bone turnover balance in mice.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between bone marrow adipose tissue, hematopoiesis, and bone metabolism, particularly in the context of injury and recovery.
insights: The findings suggest that defective HSC differentiation is a primary cause for skeletal abnormalities in kit signaling-deficient mice, but do not rule out a role for BMAT in supporting hematopoiesis.

title: Understanding the Complexities and Changes of the Astronaut Microbiome for Successful Long-Duration Space Missions
objective: To understand the degree of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) activity that could occur in space, specifically focusing on the transfer of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes between bacteria under simulated microgravity (SMG).
methodology: Co-cultured donor (Acinetobacter pittii) and recipient (Staphylococcus aureus) bacteria under simulated microgravity (SMG) and normal gravity (1G) using high-aspect-ratio vessels (HARVs). Tracked the transfer of two AMR genes (blaOXA-500 and ISAba1) from A. pittii to S. aureus using polymerase chain reaction (PCR).  Measured the biomass of each strain after 20 hours under both SMG and 1G conditions.  Sub-cultured resistant S. aureus colonies to assess the stability of the acquired genes.
results: Significantly higher numbers of S. aureus isolates co-cultured with A. pittii under SMG acquired the blaOXA-500 and ISAba1 genes compared to 1G.  The acquisition of these genes induced resistance to oxacillin in the recipient S. aureus strains.  The efficiency of gene transfer was significantly higher under SMG compared to 1G.  The acquired resistance and the presence of the transferred genes remained stable after multiple sub-cultures.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity promotes increased horizontal gene transfer of antimicrobial resistance genes between bacteria. This could pose a significant health threat to astronauts on long-duration space missions, as susceptible bacteria could become resistant to antibiotics.
relationships: The study examines the relationship between simulated microgravity and the rate of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes between Acinetobacter pittii (donor) and Staphylococcus aureus (recipient). It also explores the relationship between the acquisition of AMR genes and the resulting phenotypic change (oxacillin resistance) in S. aureus.
insights: The space environment, specifically microgravity, may promote increased gene dissemination within bacterial communities.  Commensal bacteria can act as reservoirs for AMR genes that can be transferred to opportunistic pathogens.  Increased HGT under SMG could be due to increased competence in recipient cells or increased transduction.

title: Toward sustainable space exploration: a roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms.
objective: To review the impact of long-term space exploration on the astronaut microbiome and discuss its role in promoting or ameliorating conditions caused by spaceflight, as well as space-related factors that impact microbiome composition.
methodology: Review of existing literature and studies pertaining to spaceflight, ground-based simulations, and the human microbiome.
results: Spaceflight conditions, such as microgravity and radiation, can induce changes in microbiome composition (dysbiosis), altering host-microbe interactions and affecting immune function and metabolism. Specific changes include alterations in the gut microbiome, skin microbiome, and oral microbiome. These changes can impact astronaut health, potentially increasing the risk of infection, disease onset, and mental health impairments.
conclusions: Modifications in the astronaut microbiome occur during spaceflight and analog missions, impacting human health and performance. Changes to gut microbiome composition are reversible, but extended exploration missions may lead to longer-lasting effects. Maintaining a healthy microbiome is crucial for astronaut health, and personalized countermeasures, including dietary interventions and probiotics, may be necessary.
relationships: The review explores the connections between spaceflight, the host, and the microbiome, highlighting the significance of these interactions for successful long-term space missions. It also discusses the brain-gut-microbiome axis and its impact on mental health, as well as the influence of the space dietary regime on the microbiome.
insights: Understanding the complexities of the astronaut microbiome is essential for developing effective countermeasures to mitigate health risks during long-duration space missions. Personalized microbiome monitoring, dietary interventions, and built environment material design are crucial considerations for future space travel.

title: Roll maneuvers are essential for active reorientation of Caenorhabditis elegans in 3D media
objective: To highlight microbial biotechnologies for sustainable space exploration, focusing on in situ resource utilization and loop-closure to reduce reliance on terrestrial resources and minimize space waste.
methodology: The paper proposes a roadmap based on current terrestrial biotechnologies, adapted to meet the specific requirements of the space environment. It considers habitat air bioremediation, human waste processing, food production, pharmaceutical synthesis, biomining, structural biomanufacturing, energy collection and storage, recycling of waste streams, and soil remediation.
results: The paper presents various microbial biotechnologies that can be applied to create sustainable processes in space, including CO2 removal, waste recycling, food production, drug manufacturing, metal extraction, bioconcrete production, energy generation, and soil remediation. It also highlights the need for developing space-ready bioreactors and improving water recovery systems.
conclusions: Microbial biotechnologies are essential for sustainable human space exploration, enabling reduced supply chain dependency and loop-closure for life support systems. Further research and innovation are needed to mature these technologies, with benefits for both space exploration and terrestrial environmental issues.
relationships: The paper emphasizes the interconnectedness of various microbial processes within a life support system, where waste from one process can be used as a resource for another, creating a closed-loop system. It also highlights the potential for space biotechnologies to address terrestrial environmental issues and support the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
insights: Microbial biotechnologies offer a promising path towards sustainable space exploration by enabling in situ resource utilization and loop-closure. These technologies can reduce reliance on terrestrial resources, minimize space waste, and provide essential resources for long-duration missions and settlements. Furthermore, advancements in space biotechnologies can also benefit terrestrial environmental issues and contribute to a more sustainable future on Earth.

title: Microfluidic Device for Studying Nematodes
objective: To quantitatively analyze how the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans reorients itself in 3D media and to identify specific behavioral patterns associated with 3D reorientation maneuvers.
methodology: The study combines experimental observations of C. elegans locomotion in bulk media with geometrical analysis and hydrodynamic simulations. Stereoscopic images of burrowing nematodes were analyzed, and a piecewise harmonic curvature model was generalized to include curve torsion. A bead-based model was used for hydrodynamic calculations.
results: A unique behavioral state—a roll maneuver—was identified as an essential component of 3D locomotion. The rolls, associated with nonzero torsion of the nematode body, result in rotation of the plane of dorsoventral body undulations. Hydrodynamic viscous forces can enhance 3D reorientation in undulatory locomotion. A three-mode torsional roll model accurately describes observed 3D motion of burrowing C. elegans.
conclusions: C. elegans explore their 3D environment by combining planar turns with roll reorientation maneuvers. The roll maneuvers constitute an important behavioral pattern that is an essential component of 3D locomotion. The modeling approach provides a powerful tool for investigating 3D locomotion of C. elegans.
relationships: The study reveals a relationship between the geometry of nematode motion, hydrodynamic forces, and the resulting reorientation maneuvers. It demonstrates how hydrodynamic resistance forces can both hinder planar turns and enhance roll rotation in swimming.
insights: The research provides insights into the neuromuscular actuation of body movements in 3D and suggests that a 3D proprioceptive feedback mechanism may be involved in generating the torsional wave in the nematode body. The findings can be used to develop better assays for locomotion phenotype analysis and to investigate chemotaxis strategies and escape responses.

title: NemaFlex: A microfluidics-based technology for standardized measurement of muscular strength of C. elegans.
objective: To develop and optimize a method for isolating C. elegans embryos using mesh filters as an alternative to traditional bleach synchronization.
methodology: Sequential filtration using 40 µm and 20 µm mesh filters to separate embryos from adults and larvae. Optimization of pre-filtration conditions (bacterial strain, embryo density) and post-filtration washes (PEG concentration). Comparison with bleach synchronization in terms of embryo yield, larval development, and drug response.
results: Filtration yielded a higher number of embryos per plate compared to bleach synchronization. Embryos obtained by filtration developed comparably or better than those obtained by bleach synchronization. Filtration did not negatively impact the response of C. elegans to the anthelmintic drug albendazole.
conclusions: Mesh filtration is a robust and efficient alternative to bleach synchronization for isolating C. elegans embryos, offering higher yields and reduced chemical stress. The technique can be adapted for other Caenorhabditis species and potentially for isolating embryos of different sizes by adjusting mesh sizes.
relationships: The study compares mesh filtration with bleach synchronization, demonstrating the advantages of filtration in terms of embryo yield and larval development. It also explores the relationship between embryo collection method and drug response.
insights: Mesh filtration offers a less harsh and more efficient method for synchronizing C. elegans populations compared to bleach synchronization. Optimization of pre- and post-filtration conditions can further improve embryo yield and quality. The method is adaptable and can be applied to other species and embryo sizes.

title: Swim exercise in Caenorhabditis elegans extends neuromuscular and gut healthspan, enhances learning ability, and protects against neurodegeneration
objective: To define a microfluidics-based system ('NemaFlex') for standardized measurement of muscle strength in C. elegans, enabling identification of molecular mechanisms causing muscle strength loss and development of interventions.
methodology: Developed a microfluidic system with micropillars ('NemaFlex') to measure the maximum exertable force (MEF) of C. elegans by quantifying pillar deflection as the nematode crawls through the pillar forest. Optimized micropillar forest design and measurement conditions. Validated the system using muscle contracting agents and mutants. Analyzed force-velocity correlations and gait parameters.
results: Established 'NemaFlex' as a quantitative and reproducible system for measuring muscle strength in C. elegans. Identified robust measurement conditions that define MEF as a measure reproducible and insensitive to animal locomotion and behavior. Reported a scaling factor to correct MEF for animal size. Demonstrated that MEF is independent of locomotory gait and time-variation of behavior. Showed that MEF before and after drug-induced muscle contractions is the same. MEF detects muscle strength weakness in mutants. Muscular strength depends strongly on body diameter but not length.
conclusions: The NemaFlex technology provides a robust analog of maximum voluntary force (MVF) in vertebrates, addressing the gap in standardized muscle force investigations in C. elegans. It enables targeted investigations on disease conditions modeled in C. elegans and may help in defining molecular and cellular circuits of neuromuscular function.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between muscle strength, body size (diameter), and pillar spacing, showing that MEF scales with the cube of the worm's body diameter. It also demonstrates that MEF is independent of body length.
insights: The study reveals the existence of different regimes of resistance to locomotion based on the size of the nematode relative to the gap between pillars (non-resistive, moderately resistive, and highly resistive). NemaFlex needs to operate in the highly resistive regime to score MEF.

title: Molecular muscle experiment: Hardware and operational lessons for future astrobiology space experiments
objective: To optimize a long-term swim exercise protocol for Caenorhabditis elegans and demonstrate its benefits to diverse aging tissues, even if exercise occurs only during a restricted phase of adulthood.
methodology: Long-term swim exercise protocol was optimized for C. elegans. Multiple daily swim sessions were conducted, and their impact on muscle gene expression, locomotory performance, mitochondrial morphology, whole-animal health parameters, pharyngeal and intestinal functions, and neuronal functions were assessed. Microfluidic devices were used to differentiate between the effects of liquid exposure and locomotor activity. Oxygen consumption rates were measured using a Seahorse XFe24 Analyzer. Various assays, including burrowing, Smurf, learning, chemotaxis, and touch-sensitivity assays, were performed to assess different aspects of healthspan.
results: Multiple daily swim sessions are essential for exercise adaptation, leading to improvements in muscle gene expression, locomotory performance, and mitochondrial morphology. Swim exercise training enhances whole-animal health parameters, such as mitochondrial respiration and midlife survival. Functional healthspan of the pharynx and intestine is increased, and nervous system health is enhanced by increasing learning ability and protecting against neurodegeneration in models of tauopathy, Alzheimer’s disease, and Huntington’s disease. Swim training only during early adulthood induces long-lasting systemic benefits that are still detectable well into midlife.
conclusions: Swim exercise in C. elegans promotes extended healthspan of multiple tissues and underscores the potency of early exercise experience to influence long-term health. The study establishes the foundation for exploiting the advantages of this genetic model for the dissection of the exercise-dependent molecular circuitry that confers system-wide health benefits to aging adults.
relationships: Exercise promotes health benefits to multiple tissues in the body, including neuromuscular, intestinal, and cognitive levels, and protects against neurodegeneration. Swim exercise performed exclusively in early adulthood promotes long-lasting systemic benefits that are still detectable in midlife.
insights: C. elegans serves as a valuable model for dissecting the molecular mechanisms underlying the systemic health benefits of exercise. Early exercise can have long-lasting effects on healthspan, even in tissues not directly involved in the exercise. The study highlights the importance of exercise for promoting healthy aging and preventing age-related diseases.

title: Tart Cherry Increases Lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by Altering Metabolic Signaling Pathways
objective: To develop and validate hardware and operational procedures for conducting C. elegans experiments on the International Space Station (ISS), focusing on spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy.
methodology: C. elegans worms were cultured in different plastic bags (polyethylene, JAXA PE blend, and fluorinated ethylene propylene) with either OP50 bacteria or chemically defined media (CeMM). Oxygen consumption rates were measured using a Seahorse XFe24 Analyzer. Culture volume was optimized. Experiment cassettes (ECs) were designed and validated for gas exchange. Upload scenarios with varying temperatures and durations were tested to simulate launch delays.
results: Polyethylene and JAXA bags supported worm growth, while FEP bags did not. Worms grown in CeMM had lower oxygen consumption rates than those grown in OP50. Optimal culture volume was 6-7 mL. Cage design 2 allowed for sufficient worm growth inside ECs. Short and long cold stowage upload scenarios produced viable cultures.
conclusions: The study successfully updated flight hardware and upload conditions for C. elegans experiments on the ISS. Gas exchange in culture bags is critical for worm viability, and the choice of diet (OP50 vs. CeMM) affects oxygen consumption. Passive cold stowage using NASA's 10°C phase change materials provides a viable upload scenario.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between gas exchange, diet, and worm viability in spaceflight experiments. It also demonstrates the importance of hardware design and validation for successful biological experiments on the ISS.
insights: Proper ground testing is essential for spaceflight experiments, even with previously flown hardware. The choice of culture bag material and diet significantly impacts worm growth and oxygen consumption. Passive temperature control during upload is a viable option, but the temperature profile must be carefully considered.

title: A region of UNC-89 (obscurin) lying between two protein kinase domains is a highly elastic spring required for proper sarcomere organization
objective: To determine the mechanisms by which tart cherry extract (TCE) extends lifespan in C. elegans.
methodology: Using microfluidic devices for whole-life culture studies, the lifespan of wild-type N2, daf-16 mutant, and aak-2 mutant C. elegans worms were assessed with and without TCE supplementation. Gene expression analyses using qRT-PCR and mitochondrial respiration analysis using the Seahorse XFe24 analyzer were also performed.
results: TCE supplementation increased the mean lifespan of wild-type N2 worms in a dose-dependent manner. TCE upregulated the expression of longevity-related genes such as daf-16 and aak-2 and genes related to oxidative stress such as sod-2. TCE also increased spare respiration in N2 worms. However, TCE did not change the mean lifespan of daf-16 and aak-2 mutant worms.
conclusions: TCE confers healthspan benefits in C. elegans through enhanced mitochondrial function and reduced oxidative stress, mainly via the DAF-16 pathway. TCE acts as a calorie restriction mimetic.
