relationships: TCE extends lifespan mainly through the IIS and DAF-16 signaling pathways. AAK-2 is also involved in TCE-mediated longevity effects. TCE regulates components in the IIS pathway, reducing daf-2 expression and increasing daf-16 expression. SKN-1 gene expression was also upregulated by TCE treatments.
insights: Montmorency tart cherry is a potentially effective nutraceutical for promoting healthy aging in C. elegans. TCE increases lifespan in a DAF-16-dependent manner, potentially due to genetic regulation in the IIS and DAF-16 pathway, partial involvement of AAK-2 signaling, increased antioxidant activity, and spare respiratory activity.

title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
objective: To examine the nature of the interkinase (IK) regions of UNC-89, obscurin, and SPEG, and to determine the in vivo consequences of removing the IK from UNC-89 in C. elegans.
methodology: Single molecule force spectroscopy (SMFS) was used to examine the mechanical properties of the IK region. CRISPR/Cas9 was used to create an in-frame deletion of the IK region in C. elegans. Western blots, immunofluorescence microscopy, structured illumination microscopy (SIM), nematode locomotion assays, and polarized light microscopy were used to characterize the resulting mutant strains.
results: The IK region of UNC-89 behaves as a random coil and acts as an entropic spring. Deletion of the IK region results in disorganized sarcomeres in body wall muscle, the formation of extra, short A-bands, and defects in whole animal locomotion and muscle force generation. The HA tag reduces the level of expression of the giant UNC-89 isoforms and results in a defect in thick filaments in the terminal bulb of the pharynx.
conclusions: The IK region of UNC-89 is required for proper sarcomere organization and stability, and for normal muscle function. The length or elasticity of the IK region is important for the proper spacing between A-bands. The HA tag at the N-terminus of the large UNC-89 isoforms reduces the stability of pharyngeal-specific UNC-89 mRNA or protein isoforms, or interferes with interaction with binding partners found only in pharyngeal muscle.
relationships: UNC-89 interacts with CPNA-1, which in turn interacts with PAT-6, a member of the 4-protein complex that interacts with the cytoplasmic tail of PAT-3 (β-integrin).
insights: The C. elegans pharynx is often considered analogous to the vertebrate heart, suggesting that cardiomyopathy-causing mutations in human obscurin might be studied in C. elegans by creating the analogous mutations in UNC-89.

title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans
objective: To develop and validate a microfluidic device (NemaLife Chip) for whole-life studies of C. elegans, addressing limitations of agar-based approaches and microfluidic swim-chambers, and to investigate the impact of spaceflight on neuronal morphology and degradation of neuronal debris.
methodology: The NemaLife Chip was designed with a micropillar arena for crawling, sieve channels for progeny removal, and ports for feeding and reagent introduction.  Different micropillar geometries were tested to optimize locomotion and lifespan.  Culture conditions (washing, feeding frequency, and food concentration) were optimized.  Lifespan assays were conducted on wild-type and mutant C. elegans, comparing results with agar plate assays. RNAi was used to knockdown age-related genes. Healthspan measures (pharyngeal pumping, stimulated locomotion) were scored manually.  Fluorescence imaging was used to assess DAF-16 localization.
results: The optimized NemaLife Chip allowed for whole-life culture of C. elegans with efficient progeny removal and mimicked plate-like crawling behavior.  Specific micropillar geometry (Device III) resulted in locomotion gait similar to agar plates and consistent lifespan.  The NemaLife Chip eliminated animal loss due to desiccation and burrowing.  Mutant lifespan extensions and reductions were consistent with previous reports. RNAi knockdown of age-1 and daf-16 genes altered lifespan.  Age-dependent decline in pharyngeal pumping rate was observed.  Stimulated reversal speed declined with age.
conclusions: The NemaLife Chip provides a reliable platform for C. elegans lifespan and healthspan studies, offering advantages over agar-based assays and swim-chamber microfluidics. It allows for controlled culture conditions, efficient progeny removal, and assessment of various healthspan metrics. The device is suitable for genetic and environmental regulator studies of healthy aging and can be adapted for automated high-throughput analysis.
relationships: The study demonstrates the relationship between the microenvironment (pillar vs. no pillar), locomotion (crawling vs. swimming), and lifespan/healthspan outcomes in C. elegans. It also highlights the connection between genetic interventions (mutants, RNAi) and lifespan, as well as the correlation between age and physiological markers like pharyngeal pumping and stimulated locomotion.

title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station.
objective: To explore how spaceflight affects adult neurons in vivo using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans.
methodology: Cultured C. elegans, including strains with fluorescently labeled neurons, exposed them to spaceflight conditions on the ISS for 5 days, and compared them to ground control samples using confocal microscopy. Quantified neuronal morphology and proteostasis markers.
results: Spaceflight induces morphological remodeling of adult PVD sensory neurons, including hyperbranching and disorganization. Touch receptor neurons showed modest morphological changes. Spaceflight also altered the transcellular degradation of neuronal debris, leading to accumulation of mCherry in the hypodermis in animals with proteotoxic stress.
conclusions: Spaceflight can significantly affect adult neuronal morphology and clearance of neuronal waste. Hyperbranching may be a common neuronal response to spaceflight. Impaired neuronal proteostasis/clearance pathways may have health implications for long-duration spaceflights.
relationships: PVD dendritic morphology in space-flown C. elegans may be indirectly affected by changes at the body wall muscle level. Spaceflight has also been suggested to reduce insulin signaling in C. elegans, whereas the insulin/IGF-1 receptor daf-2 mutant exhibits an increase in PVD 2 branches and self-avoidance defects.
insights: Spaceflight induces remodeling of the PVD dendritic tree in adult C. elegans relative to ground control animals, whereas touch receptor neurons exhibit modest morphological changes in response to spaceflight. Hyperbranching is a consistent response to spaceflight between different adult neuron types. Adults that aged on the ISS exhibited accumulated extruded neuronal garbage outside the neurons, distributed in neighboring tissues.

title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight.
objective: To address technical challenges for conducting multi-generational C. elegans strength measurements in microgravity, including culturing, age-synchronization, imaging, and on-orbit protocols.
methodology: Development of a reconﬁgured spaceﬂight ready NemaFlex device (NemaFlex-S), new protocols for experimentation with C. elegans, and custom-designed hardware for on-orbit operation on the ISS. This includes culturing worms in chemically deﬁned liquid media (CeMM) within Fluorinated Ethylene Propylene (FEP) bags, using a worm loading apparatus (WLA) for safe and efficient loading, and optimizing protocols for animal density and health.
results: Successful development and validation of the NemaFlex-S device and associated protocols for culturing, loading, and imaging C. elegans muscle strength across multiple generations. The integrated technology and protocols enabled its successful operation by astronauts on the ISS, producing visual data of C. elegans across multiple generations. Ground studies showed consistent muscle strength measurements over 8 weeks.
conclusions: The microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware makes the technology amenable to C. elegans muscle strength investigations on the ISS. The developed hardware and protocols address key challenges in conducting multi-generational studies in space, paving the way for future space biology investigations using C. elegans.
relationships: The study investigates the relationship between microgravity and muscle strength in C. elegans across multiple generations. It also explores the relationship between culture methods (NGM vs. CeMM) and C. elegans development and physiology.
insights: The study provides insights into the technical challenges of conducting biological experiments in space and demonstrates the feasibility of using microfluidic devices for in vivo physiological data capture. It also highlights the importance of crew-compatible hardware and optimized protocols for successful spaceflight experiments.

title: Mitochondrial sulfide promotes life span and health span through distinct mechanisms in developing versus adult treated Caenorhabditis elegans.
objective: To report a small foot-print smart-device imaging system called Compact Imaging Platform (CIP) that can acquire videos of C. elegans in agar plates, liquid droplets on a glass slide and microfluidic devices and to validate the system by performing standard behavioral assays on plates, liquid drops and microfluidic chips.
methodology: The CIP was designed and built using 3D printing. C. elegans were cultured and placed on different substrates (agar plates, liquid drops, microfluidic chips). Videos were recorded using the CIP, and behavioral assays were performed. ImageJ with the wrMTrck plugin was used for data analysis.
results: The CIP was compatible with different C. elegans substrates. Adequate temperature control was achieved. Validation with behavioral assays showed results consistent with literature. Mutant studies revealed phenotypic differences.
conclusions: The CIP is a simple, versatile, low-cost, and small-footprint phenotyping tool for C. elegans assays, suitable for research and educational settings. It presents a proof of concept for future setups for space biology research and could be adapted for ISS-compatible hardware.
relationships: The study demonstrates the relationship between the design of a compact imaging system and its applicability for C. elegans phenotyping in various environments, including potential spaceflight applications. It also explores the relationship between genetic mutations and behavioral phenotypes.
insights: The CIP offers a practical solution for C. elegans phenotyping, especially in resource-constrained environments like the ISS. The ability to conduct parallel experiments and integrate with existing software tools enhances its utility. The study also highlights the importance of whole-organism phenotypic data in understanding the effects of microgravity and radiation on C. elegans physiology.

title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.
objective: To investigate the efficacy of a mitochondrion-targeted sulfide delivery molecule (mtH2S), AP39, for promoting health span via mitochondrion-mediated effects versus untargeted H2S donors in C. elegans, and to examine the health span effects of adult-onset H2S treatments.
methodology: Using C. elegans as an aging model, the study compared the effects of untargeted H2S (NaGYY4137) and mtH2S (AP39) on life span, neuromuscular health span, and mitochondrial integrity.  RNAi pharmacogenetic interventions and transcriptomics/network analysis were used to explore molecular events governing mtH2S donor-mediated health span.  Movement rates were measured using wMicroTracker, and neuromuscular strength was assessed using the NemaFlex device. Mitochondrial structure was assessed using GFP-tagged transgenic animals, and citrate synthase activity was measured as a marker of mitochondrial health.  Next-generation sequencing was performed on animals treated with mtH2S from L1 larvae or from day 0 of adulthood.  Transcription factor-binding site analysis was used to identify transcription factors predicted to regulate gene clusters.
results: mtH2S (AP39) significantly increased life span at lower doses compared to untargeted H2S. mtH2S also increased total animal movement rates and improved strength production. mtH2S sustained mitochondrial integrity and increased citrate synthase activity.  The positive effects of mtH2S on life span and health span were prevented by knockdown of H2S metabolism enzymes and FoxO/daf-16. Adult-onset mtH2S treatment increased health span but not life span, and rejuvenated aging transcriptomes by minimizing expression declines of mitochondria, cytoskeletal components, and peroxisome metabolism hub components. A GATA transcription factor regulatory circuit (elt-6/elt-3) was found to underpin the positive aging effects of mtH2S.
conclusions: mtH2S extends C. elegans health span, associating with improved mitochondrial integrity. Multiple elements of H2S metabolic pathways and FoxO transcription factors govern both life span and health span, while the Nrf2 antioxidant system is dispensable for mtH2S-induced health span extension. Adult mtH2S treatments increase health span and rejuvenate key features of the aging transcriptome, controlled by a GATA transcription factor circuit. mtH2S is a potential translational antiaging therapy.
relationships: H2S health span extension likely acts at the mitochondrial level, with mechanisms dissociating from life span across adult vs. developmental treatment timings. The elt-6/elt-3 transcription factor circuit governs cytoskeletal and peroxisomal gene clusters to modify health span. Peroxisome and mitochondrial function have cross-talk.
insights: Augmentation of mitochondrial sulfide may represent a druggable target and translatable therapeutic approach to maintaining health with advancing age.  mtH2S can target early mitochondrial metabolic perturbations during aging, attenuating later changes in neuromuscular performance and health.  Postdevelopmental, aging-induced increases in FoxO expression are harmful to health span, and interventions like mtH2S that lower this response improve health while having minimal effect on longevity.

title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
objective: To determine the bone-independent effects and mechanisms of bisphosphonates on sarcopenia progression using Caenorhabditis elegans as a genomic model of aging muscle decline.
methodology: Caenorhabditis elegans were treated with zoledronic acid (ZA) at varying concentrations. Lifespan and healthspan (movement rates) were assessed using a microfluidic chip device. The effects of ZA on sarcopenia were examined using GFP-tagged myofibers or mitochondria. RNAi gene knockdown was used to determine mechanisms of ZA-mediated healthspan extension.
results: ZA at 100 nM and 1 μM increased lifespan and healthspan. ZA improved myofibrillar structure and increased well-networked mitochondria. Genes required for ZA-mediated healthspan extension included fdps-1/FDPS-1 and daf-16/FOXO. Knockdown of igdb-1/FNDC5 and sir-2.3/SIRT-4 extended life/healthspan. let-756/FGF21 and sir-2.2/SIRT-4 were dispensable for ZA-induced healthspan.
conclusions: ZA delays sarcopenia in Caenorhabditis elegans, improving neuromuscular function. Bisphosphonates may be an anti-sarcopenia therapy.
relationships: ZA-mediated healthspan extension requires fdps-1/FDPS-1 and daf-16/FOXO. agxt-2/BAIBA is necessary for the positive healthspan effects of ZA. igdb-1/FNDC5 knockdown extends worm lifespan and healthspan, similar to ZA co-treatment. let-756/FGF21 is dispensable for ZA-induced lifespan and healthspan extension. sir-2.3 knockdown extends lifespan and healthspan, which remains with combined ZA treatment.
insights: Bisphosphonates extend C. elegans lifespan and healthspan, delaying muscle sarcomere and mitochondrial decline. The mevalonate-FOXO system, muscle-centric myokines (agxt-2 and igdb-1), and mitochondrial sirtuin (sir-2.3) regulate bisphosphonate effects on aging muscle health. Bisphosphonates act at least partially through mitochondrial mechanisms to lessen the effects of sarcopenia.

title: Metabolic model predictions enable targeted microbiome manipulation through precision prebiotics.
objective: To understand and counter the negative health consequences of spaceflight, focusing on neuromuscular strength loss and potential therapeutic interventions.
methodology: Using Caenorhabditis elegans as a model organism on the International Space Station (ISS), combined with 'NemaFlex-S' microfluidic devices to assess animal strength. Wild-type and dys-1 strains were cultured in chemically defined media. Neuromuscular strength was measured, and transcriptomic analysis was performed via next-generation sequencing.
results: Neuromuscular strength was lower in flight versus ground controls. Transcriptional gene ontology signatures indicated upregulated stress response pathways and downregulated mitochondrial and cytoskeletal processes. Functional gene cluster analysis implicated decreased neuronal function, including abnormal calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling, in space-induced strength declines.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces neuromuscular strength loss, associated with increased stress response and reduced mitochondrial/cytoskeletal gene pathways. Perturbed calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling within neurons are primary candidates causing impaired neuromuscular strength in space.
relationships: Identified relationships between gene expression changes, muscle strength, and neuronal function in response to spaceflight. Highlighted the potential for altered acetylcholine signaling from nerve to muscle as a contributor to strength decline.
insights: Spaceflight-related health decline is underpinned by specific molecular features. Targeted therapeutics can be developed against maladaptations to space habitation. The study provides an in vivo model of space-induced strength loss for missions beyond low Earth orbit and to the Moon.

title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
objective: To identify key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation as potential drivers for skin health risks during spaceflight, and to guide future research on developing countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.
methodology: Systems biology approach utilizing NASA’s Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) on space flown murine transcriptomic datasets focused on the skin, biochemical profiles of NASA astronauts, human transcriptomic datasets generated from blood and hair samples of JAXA astronauts, data from the NASA Twins Study, and skin and blood samples from the Inspiration4 mission. Explainable AI modeling approach to construct interpretable machine learning models to identify synergistic effects between pairs of genes.
results: Key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation are identified as potential drivers for skin health risks during spaceflight. Alterations in genes associated with skin barrier function and collagen formation were observed. Machine learning models identified gene pairings associated with spaceflight response in the skin. The study also highlighted the remarkable ability for organisms to re-adapt back to Earth via post-flight re-tuning of gene expression.
conclusions: Spaceflight induces dysregulation in skin-related biological processes, including DNA damage, mitochondrial function, and skin barrier integrity. However, organisms possess a capacity to re-adapt post-flight. These findings can inform the development of countermeasures to mitigate spaceflight-associated skin damage.
relationships: Identified synergistic effects between gene pairs, suggesting potential biological interactions affected by spaceflight. Correlation between rodent skin gene expression changes and astronaut data, including JAXA hair follicle data, skin data from the i4 mission, and blood gene expression data from the NASA Twins, JAXA Cell-Free Epigenome (CFE), and i4 studies.
insights: Spaceflight-induced skin issues are linked to changes in DNA damage, skin barrier health, and mitochondrial function. The study suggests potential targets for pharmaceutical interventions and highlights the importance of exercise countermeasures for maintaining skin health during spaceflight. Radiosensitivity of mouse strains impacts DNA damage response in the skin following spaceflight.

title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
objective: To identify and characterize the skin microbiome of C. elegans and investigate its role in cuticle protection.
methodology: The study used microbiological methods, including a novel micro-swabbing tool, 16S rRNA gene sequencing, and physiological assays to analyze bacteria on the C. elegans cuticle. Animals were reared on a modified CeMbio (mCeMbio), and the skin and gut microbiomes were compared after surface sterilization.
results: A distinct skin microbiome was identified on C. elegans, different from the gut microbiome and the surrounding environment. Enterobacter sp. JUb101 was found predominantly on the skin, while Stenotrophomonas indicatrix JUb19 and Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71 were mainly in the gut. The skin microbiome promotes host cuticle integrity in harsh environments.
conclusions: C. elegans possesses a skin microbiome that contributes to cuticle integrity and host fitness. The study highlights the importance of considering the skin microbiome in host-microbe interaction studies and suggests its potential role in protecting against environmental stressors.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between C. elegans and its skin microbiome, demonstrating that specific bacterial strains adhere to the cuticle and provide protection. It also investigates the interactions between different bacterial species within the mCeMbio consortium and their combined effects on cuticle integrity.
insights: The research reveals that the C. elegans skin microbiome is a dynamic community that can influence host physiology and adaptation. It suggests that the skin microbiome may play a crucial role in protecting the nematode from environmental toxins and pathogens, highlighting the importance of studying ecologically relevant microbial communities.

title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments
objective: To investigate the role of UNC-89 PK2, a protein kinase domain, in muscle function and mitochondrial morphology in C. elegans.
methodology: CRISPR/Cas9 was used to create C. elegans mutants expressing UNC-89 with an inactivated PK2 kinase domain (KtoA mutation).  Bioinformatic analysis, western blotting, immunostaining, confocal and structured illumination microscopy, electron microscopy, crawling assays, force measurements, ATP level measurements, mitochondrial purification and respirometry, and glycolysis assays were performed.
results: UNC-89 PK2 KtoA mutants exhibited normal sarcomere structure and muscle function but displayed fragmented mitochondria. These mutants showed increased ATP levels, increased complex I respiration, decreased complex II respiration, and increased glycolysis.  DRP-1, a protein involved in mitochondrial fission, was found to be more associated with mitochondria in the PK2 KtoA mutants. Overexpression of wild-type PK2 increased mitochondrial clumping and decreased DRP-1 association.
conclusions: Inactivation of UNC-89 PK2 leads to mitochondrial fragmentation and altered mitochondrial function, suggesting a signaling pathway between the sarcomere and mitochondria.  This communication helps match the energy requirements of muscle contraction with energy production by mitochondria. The increased level of UCP-4 likely explains the uncoupled state of PK2 KtoA mutants.
relationships: UNC-89 PK2 affects mitochondrial morphology and function. DRP-1 is involved in mitochondrial fragmentation in PK2 KtoA mutants. UCP-4 levels are elevated in PK2 KtoA mutants, leading to mitochondrial uncoupling.
insights: UNC-89 PK2 plays a key role in the communication between sarcomeres and mitochondria, influencing mitochondrial structure, function, and energy production in muscle cells. The study reveals a potential mechanism for matching energy needs to energy production in muscle.

title: Microbial existence in controlled habitats and their resistance to space conditions
objective: To assess the viability of cells in low-biomass environmental samples and correlate differential viability with phylogenetic affiliation in spacecraft assembly cleanrooms.
methodology: Coupled pre-PCR propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment with downstream pyrosequencing and PhyloChip DNA microarray analyses. Samples were collected from cleanroom floors and ground support equipment (GSE) in two ISO 8 certified cleanrooms: one housing spacecraft hardware (SAF) and another without (Bldg 144). DNA was extracted, PMA-treated, and analyzed via qPCR, PhyloChip G3, and tag-encoded FLX amplicon pyrosequencing (bTEFAP). Statistical analyses, including PCoA, were performed to compare PMA-treated and untreated samples.
results: PMA treatment significantly reduced the detection of total bacteria and MOTU. The SAF cleanroom floor, which housed spacecraft hardware, showed a lower viable bacterial burden compared to the Bldg 144 cleanroom floor. Recalcitrant bacteria (Actinobacteria, Acidobacteria, Firmicutes) were found in the SAF floor samples. PhyloChip analysis showed a decrease in bacterial genera after PMA treatment, with Firmicutes being more prevalent in PMA-treated samples.
conclusions: The breadth of diversity within the viable fraction of spacecraft-associated microbial communities has been overestimated. PMA treatment coupled with molecular methods can differentiate between total and viable-only portions of microbial communities in cleanroom environments. Spore-forming microorganisms like Bacillus, Clostridium, and Nocardia spp. persist in cleanrooms due to their resilience.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between cleaning regimens, environmental conditions, and the survival of specific microbial taxa in cleanrooms. It also shows the relationship between viable microbial populations and the potential for contamination in spacecraft assembly environments.
insights: Stringent cleaning and maintenance limit the number of bacterial taxa capable of persisting in cleanrooms, but hardy spore-forming microorganisms capitalize on their selective advantage. GSE materials need more rigorous cleaning. Gram-positive bacteria are more tolerant of cleanroom conditions than Gram-negative bacteria. The findings have implications for planetary protection practices and the prevention of extraterrestrial contamination.

title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft assembly facilities
objective: To examine whether the wild mouse gut microbiota alters the immunopathology of tuberculosis (TB) in BALB/c mice.
methodology: Conventional BALB/c mice (LabC) and mice born to germ-free BALB/c mothers reconstituted with the wild mouse gut microbiota (WildR) were infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). Bacterial load in organs, lung histopathology, microbiome changes via 16S rRNA sequencing, cytokine profiles, and T cell responses were assessed.
results: WildR mice controlled initial TB infection better than LabC mice, showing lower bacterial burden in the lungs during the acute phase. The gut microbial communities of LabC and WildR mice differed significantly in composition. TB infection induced dysbiosis in both cohorts. WildR mice had a less pronounced T cell response in the lungs during acute infection.
conclusions: The wild mouse gut microbiota impacts early events of TB infection in BALB/c mice, potentially through enhanced innate immunity. However, this advantage fades during chronic infection. TB infection causes dysbiosis of the gut microbiome regardless of the initial community structure.
relationships: The study highlights the crosstalk between the gut microbiota and the lung in the context of TB infection. The gut microbiota influences the host's immune response and the course of TB infection.
insights: The composition of the gut microbiome can influence the early stages of TB infection, suggesting that manipulating the gut microbiota could be a potential strategy for improving TB control. WildR mice may serve as a better model for human immune responses.

title: Draft genome sequences of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To characterize the viable microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) built environment and to determine if Earth-based cleanrooms are an appropriate model of the ISS environment.
methodology: Samples from the ISS and cleanrooms were analyzed using cultivation, ATP, and PMA-qPCR assays to estimate viable microbial populations. 16S rRNA gene Illumina iTag sequencing was used to elucidate microbial diversity and explore differences between ISS and cleanroom microbiomes. Statistical analyses were performed to compare microbial compositions.
results: Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria were dominant, but varied in abundance. Actinobacteria predominated in ISS samples, while Proteobacteria dominated in cleanroom samples. Viable bacterial populations decreased with PMA treatment, but bacterial composition was not significantly affected. The ISS HEPA filter had the highest bacterial density, but a low percentage of viable bacteria. The ISS Debris sample had a higher percentage of viable bacteria.
conclusions: Human skin-associated microorganisms contribute substantially to the ISS microbiome, unlike Earth-based cleanrooms. Corynebacterium and Propionibacterium are dominant on the ISS. Measuring viable cell diversity and population size can identify sites for more stringent cleaning and facilitate future improvements on the ISS to ensure astronaut health.
relationships: The ISS microbiome is distinct from Earth-based cleanroom microbiomes, with human-associated bacteria being more prevalent on the ISS. The study highlights the importance of understanding the unique microbial ecology of closed habitats like the ISS.
insights: The ISS environment fosters a unique microbiome influenced by human habitation. Monitoring viable microbial populations is crucial for maintaining astronaut health and preventing degradation of ISS components. Stringent cleaning practices are essential to reduce microbial burden in closed habitats.

title: Characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolates from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
objective: To determine the draft genome sequences of Aspergillus fumigatus strains ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), and to investigate their virulence characteristics compared to clinical strains.
methodology: Whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed on an Illumina HiSeq2500 instrument with paired-end reads. The NGS QC Toolkit was used to filter the data for high-quality reads. Assembly was performed with the MaSuRCA genome assembler.
results: Draft genome sequences of A. fumigatus strains ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4 were assembled. The final assembly of ISSFT-021 contains 301 scaffolds with a total size of 28,526,023 bp. The final assembly of IF1SW-F4 strain contains 208 scaffolds with a total size of 28,240,437 bp.
conclusions: The draft genome sequences of the ISS A. fumigatus isolates were successfully determined, providing a basis for further investigation of their unique characteristics, including increased virulence and resistance to UV radiation compared to clinical isolates.
relationships: Comparison of the ISS isolates to clinical isolates Af293 and CEA10. Virulence assessment in a larval zebrafish model.
insights: The genomics of these ISS isolates might reveal the molecular mechanisms of the increased virulence. Enhanced virulence may be attributed to the microgravity environment of the ISS, suggesting a need for countermeasures to protect astronaut health.

title: Draft genome sequences of biosafety level 2 opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station.
objective: To characterize the proteomic differences between Aspergillus fumigatus strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and clinical isolates, to understand how the ISS environment affects the fungal proteome.
methodology: Proteomic analysis using LC-MS/MS was performed on ISS-isolated A. fumigatus strains (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4) and clinical isolates (Af293 and CEA10). Proteins were extracted, digested, labeled with tandem mass tags (TMT), fractionated, and analyzed. Differentially abundant proteins were identified using a protein database and statistical analysis.
results: Significant differences were observed in the proteomes of ISS-isolated strains compared to clinical isolates.  ISS strains showed increased abundance of proteins involved in secondary metabolism (including trypacidin biosynthesis and Asp-hemolysin), stress response (including oxidative stress), and carbohydrate metabolism.  Decreased abundance was noted in some heat shock proteins.
conclusions: The distinct environment of the ISS (enhanced radiation, microgravity, and scarce nutrients) induces proteomic changes in A. fumigatus, potentially leading to adaptation.  Observed changes include increased production of toxins, enhanced stress response, and altered carbohydrate metabolism, which may contribute to increased virulence and survival in the space environment.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the ISS environment and the molecular adaptation of A. fumigatus. It suggests that the unique conditions of spaceflight can alter the proteome of this opportunistic pathogen, potentially impacting its virulence and posing risks to astronaut health.
insights: The findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms by which filamentous fungi adapt to the space environment. The increased abundance of proteins involved in stress response, secondary metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism suggests that A. fumigatus may be adapting to the low-nutrient, high-radiation conditions of the ISS. This adaptation could have implications for astronaut health and the biodeterioration of closed habitats.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station.
objective: To present the draft genome sequences of 20 biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) was performed on an Illumina NextSeq instrument with a paired-end module. The A5 assembly pipeline was used to generate draft assemblies, and annotation was performed using the Rapid Annotations using Subsystems Technology (RAST).
results: The draft genomes of 20 BSL-2 strains from the ISS were sequenced. Assembly statistics, including the number of contigs, total genome size, N50 size, median coverage, and G+C content, were determined. The G+C content ranged from 31.5 to 38.7% for Staphylococcus species and A. pittii, and from 55.2 to 55.8% for other strains.
conclusions: The genomic sequences obtained will aid in understanding the influence of microgravity on the pathogenicity and virulence of these strains by comparison with Earth strains.
relationships: The study identifies the prevalence and characteristics of several bacterial species, including Acinetobacter pittii, Enterobacter sp., Pantoea conspicua, Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus haemolyticus, and Staphylococcus hominis, found on the ISS.
insights: The genomic data provides a foundation for investigating the adaptation and potential risks associated with opportunistic pathogens in the unique environment of the International Space Station.

title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat.
objective: To determine the whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains selected for exposure to microgravity at the International Space Station.
methodology: Shotgun sequencing was performed on an Illumina HiSeq2500 platform with a paired-end module. The NGS QC toolkit version 2.3 was used to filter the data for high-quality vector- and adaptor-free reads for genome assembly. High-quality vector-filtered reads were used for assembly with the MaSuRCA genome assembler.
results: The whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains were obtained. Data from the final assembly of the strains, including number of scaffolds, total size, N50 contig length, G+C content, and GenBank accession numbers, are provided.
conclusions: Baseline sequences will help to understand the observed production of novel bioactive compounds. The genomic sequences coded for secondary metabolism pathways or displayed positive radiotropism.
relationships: Fungal strains were isolated from environments associated with the Chernobyl nuclear power plant (ChNPP) accident.
insights: Aspergillus niger contains a sequence resembling the fumonisin gene cluster, suggesting the potential to produce carcinogenic fumonisins. Aspergillus terreus is used to produce organic acids or enzymes, including the cholesterol-lowering molecule lovastatin. Aureobasidium pullulans is an important producer of pullulan. Beauveria bassiana is an entomopathogenic fungus used to produce bioinsecticides. Cladosporium cladosporioides produces antifungal secondary metabolites. Cladosporium sphaerospermum is a plant endophyte and allergen. Fusarium solani is a plant pathogen that produces phytotoxins. Trichoderma virens is a rhizosphere fungus beneficial to plants.

title: Whole metagenome profiles of particulates collected from the International Space Station
objective: To characterize and understand the changes and succession of fungal species in a simulated closed habitat (Inflatable Lunar/Mars Analog Habitat - ILMAH) during human occupation, mimicking International Space Station (ISS) conditions, and to assess the impact of human presence on the fungal diversity and potential risks to inhabitants and the habitat itself.
methodology: Surface samples were collected from the ILMAH at various time points during a 30-day human occupation. Both traditional culture-based methods (potato dextrose agar plate counts) and molecular techniques (internal transcribed spacer region-based iTag Illumina sequencing) were used. Samples were treated with propidium monoazide (PMA) to differentiate between viable and non-viable fungal populations. Statistical analyses were performed to compare fungal community structures and abundances.
results: The overall fungal diversity in the closed habitat changed during human presence. Viable fungal community structure changed over the occupation time. Samples collected at day 20 showed distinct fungal profiles. Viable fungal families like Davidiellaceae, Teratosphaeriaceae, Pleosporales, and Pleosporaceae increased during the occupation time. The most abundant phylum was Ascomycota. Epicoccum, Alternaria, Pleosporales, Davidiella, and Cryptococcus showed increased abundance over the occupation time.
conclusions: Human presence impacts the fungal diversity in closed habitats. Proper maintenance protocols are crucial to preserve closed habitats from deteriorating and to ensure the safety of their inhabitants. The study highlights the importance of monitoring and controlling fungal populations in closed environments like the ISS and future space habitats.
relationships: The study reveals a relationship between human presence and changes in the fungal community structure within a closed habitat. It also suggests a potential link between the accumulation of certain fungal genera (Alternaria, Epicoccum) and the development of allergy and asthma symptoms in occupants of confined spaces due to decreased immunity.
insights: The use of PMA treatment is crucial for accurately determining the viable mycobiome in environmental samples. The fungal genera present in closed habitats, such as Epicoccum, Alternaria, and Pleosporales, are environmental organisms rather than human commensals. The study provides insights into the dynamics of fungal populations in closed environments and the potential risks they pose to human health and habitat integrity.

title: Microbial Characteristics of ISS Environmental Surfaces
objective: To analyze the microbial gene pathways present in samples collected from the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Whole metagenome sequencing was performed on particulate samples collected from the ISS. Reads were assigned to KEGG orthologies based on a 0.9 identity threshold.
results: Microbial gene pathways were identified and their abundance was quantified in ISS samples.
conclusions: The study provides insights into the microbial composition of the ISS environment.
relationships: The study examines the relationship between microbial gene functions and their abundance in the ISS environment.
insights: The analysis of metagenomes reveals the diversity and abundance of microbial life on the ISS.

title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station.
objective: To characterize the phenotypes of microbial isolates from the International Space Station (ISS) potable water system over several years, focusing on antibiotic resistance, metabolism, biofilm formation, and species interactions.
methodology: The study analyzed archived ISS potable water isolates collected between 2009 and 2015.  Researchers profiled isolates for antibiotic susceptibility, metabolic characteristics (preferred energy source), biofilm formation (using Congo red and crystal violet staining, air-liquid interface assays, and confocal microscopy), and interspecies interactions (co-culture assays).
results: The predominant bacterial genera in the ISS water system were Ralstonia and Burkholderia.  Isolates exhibited resistance to multiple antibiotics.  Most species preferred casein amino acids over carbohydrates as an energy source.  Several isolates were strong biofilm formers. Interspecies interactions varied, with some isolates showing positive, negative, or neutral relationships depending on the year of isolation. Hemolytic activity was observed in some Burkholderia isolates.
conclusions: Microbial communities in the ISS potable water system exhibit dynamic interactions and adaptations over time.  Observed variations in antibiotic resistance, biofilm formation, and interspecies relationships highlight the potential for microbial adaptation to the spaceflight environment.  The presence of hemolytic Burkholderia subpopulations suggests a potential risk for opportunistic infections in astronauts.
relationships: Interspecies interactions between the paired isolates over a progressive time course were rated as negative, positive, or neutral, based on migration of the cultures during growth in close proximity. Neutral relationships were deﬁned when two strains did not show a visible sign of interaction. Positive relationships were deﬁned when one strain grew out toward and in some cases surrounded the other strain. We found two types of negative behaviors. For example, Methylobacterium and S. epidermidis were either killed or their growth inhibited by Burkholderia, while R. insidiosa grew away from Burkholderia.
insights: Long-term polymicrobial interactions in the ISS potable water system can lead to the formation of new relationships over time. The study suggests that the spaceflight environment may influence microbial coevolution, potentially impacting crew health and system performance. The findings emphasize the importance of considering temporal dynamics in microbial risk assessments for closed environments.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
objective: To determine and analyze the draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: The genomes of six Bacillus strains were sequenced using Illumina MiSeq and PacBio RSII platforms. The reads were assembled using iMetAMOS with IDBA_UD and SPAdes. Low confidence bases were masked using FreeBayes. PacBio reads were assembled with Celera Assembler and polished with Quiver and Pilon. The assembled genomes were aligned against members of the B. cereus sensu lato group using NUCmer and Parsnp.
results: The six ISS isolates exhibited a high degree of genomic similarity to the B. cereus sensu lato group. Genome size estimates were between 5.2 to 5.3 Mb, with approximately 99.9% average pairwise nucleotide identity. None of the commonly known B. anthracis signature elements were identified.
conclusions: The six ISS isolates represent a novel Bacillus species located within the B. cereus sensu lato group. The isolates do not possess the typical pathogenicity markers associated with B. anthracis.
relationships: The study highlights the genomic similarity between the ISS isolates and the B. cereus sensu lato group, while also emphasizing their distinction from B. anthracis.
insights: The genomic analysis provides insights into the adaptation and evolution of Bacillus strains in the unique environment of the International Space Station. The absence of B. anthracis pathogenicity markers suggests these strains pose a low risk.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
objective: To determine and analyze the draft genome sequences of four bacterial strains (Bacillus horneckiae 1P01SCT, Bacillus nealsonii FO-92T, Acinetobacter radioresistens 50v1, and Acinetobacter proteolyticus 2P01AA) isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces.
methodology: The strains were sequenced using a shotgun sequencing approach on the Illumina HiSeq paired-end platform. Reads were de novo assembled using CLC Genomics Workbench. Annotations were produced using the Rapid Annotations using Subsystems Technology server and the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline, and visualized using the SEED viewer.
results: The draft genome sizes were 5,500,894 bp, 4,699,376 bp, 3,174,402 bp, and 4,328,804 bp for strains 1P01SCT, FO-92T, 50v1, and 2P01AA, respectively. The Bacillus strains had genes coding for dormancy and sporulation. Acinetobacter strains possessed genes coding for persister cell formation, stress responses, and resistance to various compounds.
conclusions: The study provides the first draft genome sequences of these Bacillus and Acinetobacter strains isolated from spacecraft hardware. The genomic information reveals potential mechanisms for survival under stress conditions encountered in spacecraft environments.
relationships: The study highlights the genomic characteristics of bacteria isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces and their potential adaptation to extreme environments.
insights: The identified genes related to stress resistance, sporulation, and dormancy suggest that these bacteria have adapted to survive the harsh conditions associated with spacecraft assembly and space travel. This information is relevant for planetary protection and understanding microbial survival in extreme environments.

title: Draft genome sequence of a clinical isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi isolated from a male patient with acute myeloid leukemia.
objective: To develop and validate KatharoSeq, a high-throughput protocol for analyzing low-biomass microbiome samples, and to demonstrate its utility in various environments.
methodology: The KatharoSeq protocol combines high-throughput DNA extraction, positive and negative controls, amplicon sequencing or shotgun metagenomics, and bioinformatic sample exclusion. The protocol was tested on samples from a spacecraft assembly facility (SAF), a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and an abalone-rearing facility.  Various DNA extraction kits were benchmarked using Bacillus subtilis, and the Mo Bio PowerMag with ClearMag bead cleanup was selected.  16S rRNA amplicon sequencing and shotgun metagenomics were performed, and data was analyzed using QIIME, deblur, and Kraken.
results: KatharoSeq can differentiate true positive signals in samples with as few as 50 to 500 cells.  The protocol was successfully applied to the SAF, NICU, and abalone-rearing facility, revealing distinct and interpretable spatial patterns of microbial communities.  In the SAF, Acinetobacter lwoffii was identified as a common contaminant related to human foot traffic.  In the NICU, environmental exposure related to patient infectious disease was discriminated.  In the abalone facility, microbial communities reflected the marine environment.  The success rate of samples processed through the 16S rRNA amplicon pipeline was generally higher than the success rate of the shotgun metagenome analysis.
conclusions: KatharoSeq is a sensitive and specific method for probing low-biomass microbiomes, enabling investigations in a wide range of areas. It integrates controls, optimized DNA extraction and cleanup, library construction, and bioinformatic analysis. The protocol can be scaled for high-throughput analysis and is valuable for applications such as monitoring pathogen occurrences in hospitals and understanding the impact of built environments on host microbiomes.
relationships: The study demonstrates relationships between microbial communities and environmental factors such as human exposure, cleaning practices, and water sources.  In the SAF, A. lwoffii abundance correlated with human foot traffic.  In the NICU, higher acuity pods had larger proportions of Staphylococcus.  In the abalone facility, abalone species had species-specific microbiomes shared with their environment.
insights: The study provides insights into the composition and dynamics of microbial communities in low-biomass environments.  It highlights the importance of using controls to differentiate true signals from contaminants.  The findings suggest that built environments can influence the composition of microbial communities and that monitoring these communities can be useful for preventing disease outbreaks and understanding host-microbe interactions.

title: Draft Genome Sequence of a Clinical Isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi Isolated from a Male Patient with Acute Myeloid Leukemia
objective: To determine the draft whole-genome sequence of Fusarium fujikuroi strain COH1152, isolated from a patient with refractory acute myeloid leukemia.
methodology: The COH1152 genome was sequenced using the Illumina HiSeq platform with paired-end sequencing (2 x 100 bp) and a 350-bp insert size. Sequencing adaptors were removed using Trimmomatic, and de novo assembly was performed with ABySS version 2.0.2, using a k-mer size of 88.
results: The COH1152 genome assembly resulted in a genome size of 48 Mb, with an N50 value of 1,212,708 bp. The assembly generated 4,495 scaffolds, with a max scaffold length of 6,034,165 bp. The number of scaffolds over 1 kb was 501.
conclusions: The draft genome sequence of F. fujikuroi COH1152 was successfully determined, providing a resource for further research on this emerging human pathogen.
relationships: The Fusarium isolate was cultured from a 68-year-old male undergoing chemotherapy for refractory acute myeloid leukemia, who developed a lesion and nodules with invasive hyphal elements.
insights: Fusarium fujikuroi is an emerging global opportunistic human pathogen. The genome sequence provides insights into its genetic makeup and potential virulence factors.

title: Draft genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station.
objective: To characterize the microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) surfaces over time, focusing on species presence, stability, antimicrobial resistance, and microbial interactions.
methodology: Sampling of eight ISS surfaces over 14 months, DNA extraction, shotgun metagenomics sequencing, taxonomic classification, alpha and beta diversity analysis, differential abundance analysis, antimicrobial resistance profiling using DeepARG, co-occurrence analysis, and metagenome-assembled genome (MAG) construction and annotation.
results: The ISS surface microbiome is dominated by human-associated bacteria and fungi, with Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. being the most represented. Temporal differences in microbial profiles were observed, but spatial differences were minimal. Twenty-nine antimicrobial resistance genes were detected, with macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin resistance being the most widespread. Co-occurrence analysis revealed strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera. Functional assessment of MAGs showed a propensity for amino acid utilization over carbohydrate metabolism.
conclusions: The ISS surface microbiome is a dynamic environment influenced by crew members and exhibits a stable resistome despite changes in community composition. Microbial interactions, such as those between Aspergillus and Fusarium, may have implications for astronaut health and spacecraft integrity. The study provides insights for informing policies for future space missions to ensure a healthy ISS surface microbiome.
relationships: Strong positive co-occurrence observed between Aspergillus and Fusarium, potentially enhancing aflatoxin production. Positive association between Aspergillus and Staphylococcus, where S. aureus inhibits A. fumigatus biofilm development. Astronaut-ISS surface exchange influences microbial composition.
insights: The ISS microbiome exhibits spatial uniformity, suggesting microbial movement occurs readily. Viable fungal cells are more readily captured than bacteria during sampling. The ISS resistome is relatively stable, alluding to genetic redundancy. Amino acid utilization is more prevalent than carbohydrate utilization in the ISS microbiome compared to unrestricted built environments.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from Infected Zinnia hybrida Plants Grown on the International Space Station
objective: To characterize the whole-genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Paired-end sequencing on the Illumina HiSeq platform. De novo assembly with ABySS. Comparison of assembled genomes to other F. oxysporum isolates using phylogenetically informative loci and effector protein presence/absence.
results: Whole-genome sequences of two F. oxysporum isolates (VEG-01C1 and VEG-01C2) were obtained. VEG-01C1 assembly resulted in a genome size of 49.3 Mb, and VEG-01C2 assembly resulted in a genome size of 48.9 Mb. Both isolates were closely related to F. oxysporum IMV-00293 (Chernobyl strain).
conclusions: Comparative genomics of the Z. hybrida leaf and root fungal strains with the Chernobyl strain could provide insight into genes allowing for growth in extreme environments, such as radiation resistance.
relationships: The isolates VEG-01C1 and VEG-01C2 are closely related to the Chernobyl strain IMV-00293 and similar to the clinical strain FOSC 3-a.
insights: F. oxysporum strains from the ISS share similarities with strains from extreme environments (Chernobyl) and clinical settings, suggesting potential adaptations for survival in harsh conditions.

title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains
objective: To report the secondary metabolite (SM) production of Aspergillus niger JSC-093350089, an isolate from the International Space Station (ISS), and compare it to the experimentally established strain ATCC 1015. Also, to assess the UV resistance potential of pyranonigrin A.
methodology: Cultivation of A. niger strains on GMM agar, followed by secondary metabolite extraction and analysis using HPLC-DAD-MS. Genetic variant analysis was performed using Illumina sequencing and alignment to the ATCC 1015 reference genome. Gene deletion experiments were conducted to identify genes involved in pyranonigrin A biosynthesis. UVC resistance analysis was performed by exposing strains to varying doses of UVC radiation.
results: The ISS isolate (JSC-093350089) exhibited significantly altered SM production compared to ATCC 1015, including increased production of pyranonigrin A, bicoumanigrin, and kotanin. Genetic analysis identified variations in SM cluster regions and regulators. Deletion experiments confirmed the involvement of pyrA, pyrB, pyrC, and pyrE in pyranonigrin A biosynthesis. Pyranonigrin A deficiency reduced the viability of UV-exposed strains.
conclusions: The ISS environment appears to select for A. niger strains with enhanced production of therapeutically relevant SMs, including pyranonigrin A. Genetic variations in SM clusters and regulators may contribute to these differences. Pyranonigrin A plays a role in conferring radiation resistance in A. niger.
relationships: The study establishes a relationship between the spaceflight environment, altered secondary metabolite production in A. niger, and the potential for identifying fungal strains with optimized levels of specific therapeutics. It also highlights the connection between genetic variations and increased production of bioactive compounds.
insights: Spaceflight conditions can induce changes in the metabolomic profile of A. niger, leading to enhanced production of antioxidant and UV-protective compounds. The pyranonigrin A biosynthetic gene cluster in A. niger has a different genetic architecture than in P. thymicola. Variations in the promoter region of flbA, a regulator of G-protein signaling, may contribute to the increased production of pyranonigrin A.

title: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces
objective: To characterize the antimicrobial resistance (AMR) properties, multiple drug resistance (MDR) gene profiles, and genes related to potential virulence and pathogenic properties of Enterobacter bugandensis strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), and compare them with clinical strains.
methodology: Whole genome sequencing (WGS) using Nanopore and Illumina reads, multilocus sequence typing (MLST) analysis, agar diffusion discs assay for antibiotic susceptibility, and comparative genomic analyses with publicly available Enterobacter genomes. SNP-based phylogenetic tree was generated using CSIPhylogeny. Digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) was performed using the Genome-to-Genome Distance Calculator 2.0 (GGDC 2.0).
results: ISS strains were identified as Enterobacter bugandensis, similar to clinical isolates. Comparative genomic analyses revealed genes associated with carbohydrate metabolism, amino acid metabolism, protein metabolism, cofactors, membrane transport, and RNA metabolism. Genes involved in virulence, disease, defense, and resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds were also identified. Multiple antibiotic resistance (MAR) locus was observed in the ISS strains.
conclusions: ISS Enterobacter strains pose potential health considerations for future missions due to their MDR and increased chance of pathogenicity. Thorough genomic characterization can help understand their pathogenic potential and inform future missions. Further in-vivo analysis is required to discern the influence of microgravity on their pathogenicity.
relationships: ISS isolates showed close genetic relatedness to nosocomial earth isolates. MLST and whole genome SNP tree placed ISS and nosocomial isolates to a separate clade when phylogenetically aligned with other member of genus Enterobacter.
insights: The ISS isolates have a 79% probability of being a human pathogen and share similar antimicrobial resistance patterns with clinical strains, making them relevant for future missions and crew health considerations. Genes associated with MDR efflux pump, belonging to RND, which are reported to be the major contributors of resistance to antibiotic and other toxic compounds to the bacteria, were found in all strains.

title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans.
objective: To correct a typographic error in the original article regarding the number of reads associated with microorganisms.
methodology: Correction of scientific notation in the number of reads obtained from PMA and non-PMA treated samples.
results: The corrected number of reads is approximately 7.3 × 10^8 reads associated with microorganisms after high-quality trimming. After normalization, the total reads yielded 3.1 × 10^8, with 7.4 × 10^6 assigned to each sample.
conclusions: The authors corrected the error to ensure the accuracy of the data presented in the original publication.
relationships: The correction relates to the original study on the succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces.
insights: The correction clarifies the metagenomics data, ensuring accurate representation of microbial reads from the International Space Station samples.

title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.
objective: To investigate the genomic, proteomic, and metabolomic changes in Aspergillus nidulans under International Space Station (ISS) conditions to understand its adaptation mechanisms.
methodology: Multi-omic characterization of wild-type A. nidulans and mutant strains grown on the ISS and on Earth. This included whole genome sequencing, proteomic analysis using tandem mass tag labeling and LC-MS, and secondary metabolite extraction and analysis using HPLC-DAD-MS.
results: ISS conditions altered the A. nidulans genome in specific regions, with missense mutations clustered within a few protein-coding genes. Proteins involved in stress response, carbohydrate metabolic processes, and secondary metabolite biosynthesis were differentially expressed. ISS conditions significantly decreased prenyl xanthone production in the wild-type strain and increased asperthecin production in DNA repair deficient strains.
conclusions: The spacecraft environment induces specific genomic and proteomic changes in A. nidulans, leading to altered secondary metabolite production. Asperthecin production may serve as a protective mechanism against radiation. A. nidulans shows potential as a therapeutic production host in space.
relationships: Genomic and proteomic data correlated in strains genetically engineered to increase secondary metabolite production. The laeA overexpression strain showed a point mutation resulting in loss of the laeA stop codon, curtailing enhanced SM production. Proteins involved in SM biosynthesis pathways regulated by laeA exhibited decreased and increased abundance in ISS-grown CW12001 and LO8158, respectively.
insights: Fungi adapt to the spacecraft environment through specific genetic mutations and altered protein expression. Asperthecin may confer radiation resistance, and A. nidulans has potential as a small molecule production host in space. Curtailing laeA overexpression may be favored in ISS conditions to reduce energy expenditures in a stressful environment.

title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station
objective: To investigate the molecular adaptation of Aspergillus fumigatus to the unique environment of the International Space Station (ISS) by comparing the proteomes of two ISS-isolated strains with those of clinical isolates.
methodology: Two A. fumigatus strains isolated from the ISS (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4) and two clinical isolates (Af293 and CEA10) were cultured. Proteins were extracted, digested into peptides, labeled with tandem mass tags (TMT), fractionated, and analyzed via LC-MS/MS. Protein abundance ratios were normalized to Af293. Differentially expressed proteins were identified using ANOVA and GO term enrichment analysis.
results: Compared to clinical isolates, ISS-isolated strains showed altered abundance of proteins involved in secondary metabolism, stress response, and carbohydrate metabolism. Specifically, proteins involved in trypacidin biosynthesis, oxidative stress response, and ethanol fermentation were more abundant in ISS strains. Some heat shock proteins were less abundant.
conclusions: The distinct ISS environment induces molecular adaptations in A. fumigatus, including increased abundance of proteins related to stress response, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolism. These adaptations may contribute to the increased virulence observed in ISS-isolated strains and represent responses to the unique conditions of space, such as enhanced irradiation and low nutrient availability.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the ISS environment and the molecular adaptations of A. fumigatus. It suggests that the unique conditions of space can induce changes in the proteome of this fungus, potentially affecting its virulence and metabolic capabilities.
insights: The proteomic changes observed in ISS-isolated A. fumigatus strains provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying fungal adaptation to space. The increased abundance of proteins involved in stress response and secondary metabolism suggests that these pathways are important for survival in the harsh conditions of the ISS. The study also raises questions about the potential impact of these adaptations on astronaut health and the biodeterioration of closed habitats.

title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces.
objective: To isolate and characterize Fusarium oxysporum isolates from the International Space Station (ISS) and compare their genomes to other F. oxysporum isolates to understand their potential impact on crew health and the environment.
methodology: Culturing F. oxysporum isolates from the ISS dining table, whole-genome sequencing, phylogenetic analysis using EF-1α sequences, effector protein profiling, k-mer comparison, single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) analysis, gene prediction and annotation using AUGUSTUS and BLAST2GO, identification of polyketides and secondary metabolites using antiSMASH, and virulence testing using an immunocompromised Caenorhabditis elegans model.
results: Two F. oxysporum isolates (ISS-F3 and ISS-F4) were identified as genomically unique strains, closely related to the non-plant-pathogenic biocontrol strain Fo47 but distinct based on k-mer and SNP analysis. They possess genes for producing multiple polyketides and exhibit virulence in a C. elegans model, with ISS-F4 showing significantly greater virulence than other strains.
conclusions: The F. oxysporum isolates from the ISS represent a unique strain that has adapted to the space environment. While unlikely to be plant pathogens, they exhibit virulence in an immunocompromised animal model, suggesting a potential risk to immunocompromised individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand their potential impact and mechanisms of survival in space.
relationships: ISS-F3 and ISS-F4 are clonal derivatives of each other. They are phylogenetically related to Fo47, a non-plant-pathogenic soil isolate with biocontrol properties, but are genomically distinct. They are also compared to other Fusarium species and isolates from extreme environments like Chernobyl.
insights: The study provides insights into the genomic characteristics of F. oxysporum isolates in the ISS environment, highlighting their potential adaptation to space-related stressors and their virulence potential. The findings suggest the importance of monitoring and characterizing microbial communities in closed environments like the ISS to assess potential risks to human health.

title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions.
objective: To characterize the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station (ISS) surfaces using molecular and culture-based methods.
methodology: Samples were collected from eight locations on the ISS over three flight missions spanning 14 months. Culture-based techniques, qPCR, and amplicon sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene and internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region were used. Propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment was used to differentiate between intact/viable cells and compromised/dead cells.
results: Cultivable bacterial and fungal populations varied by location, with Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria being the dominant bacterial phyla, and Ascomycota and Basidiomycota being the dominant fungal phyla. Amplicon sequencing detected more bacterial phyla than culture-based analyses. Bacterial community composition changed over time, while fungal community composition remained stable. Approximately 46% of intact/viable bacteria and 40% of intact/viable fungi could be cultured.
conclusions: The ISS harbors a diverse population of bacteria and fungi that changes over time but remains similar between locations. The dominant organisms are associated with the human microbiome and may include opportunistic pathogens. This study provides a comprehensive catalog of both total and intact/viable bacteria and fungi found on surfaces in closed space systems.
relationships: The ISS environmental microbiome resembles that of animal skin surfaces more than soil, likely due to cleaning protocols. The ISS microbiome is similar to other built environments on Earth, shaped by human occupation.
insights: The presence of opportunistic pathogens highlights the importance of further genomic and transcriptomic studies to examine how these ISS microbes function in space and how they may impact astronauts’ health. Understanding biofilm formation on ISS surfaces is important for long-term space missions to maintain structural stability.

title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities
objective: To evaluate the survival and molecular adaptation mechanisms of extremophilic fungi, specifically Chernobyl-associated and ISS-isolated strains, under simulated Mars conditions (SMC).
methodology: Fungal conidia monolayers were exposed to UV-C irradiation and SMC. Survival rates were assessed. Proteomic and metabolomic changes in selected strains (Aspergillus fumigatus and Cladosporium cladosporioides) were analyzed using HPLC-DAD-MS and TMT-labeling LC/MS, respectively. Genome annotation was performed to identify relevant genes.
results: Several fungal strains survived UV-C exposure, with some exhibiting higher resistance than bacteria. Aspergillus fumigatus ISSFT-021 and Cladosporium cladosporioides IMV 00236 survived 30-minute exposure to SMC. Proteomic analysis revealed differential expression of proteins involved in translation, ribosome biogenesis, carbohydrate metabolism, and stress response in both species. SMC-exposed Aspergillus fumigatus showed increased UV-C resistance.
conclusions: Filamentous fungi exhibit a remarkable ability to adapt to extreme conditions, including SMC. Proteomic changes suggest specific adaptation mechanisms related to translation, carbohydrate metabolism, and stress response. The increased UV-C resistance of SMC-exposed fungi highlights their potential for forward contamination during space missions.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between extremophilic fungi, their survival mechanisms in extreme environments like Chernobyl and the ISS, and the implications for planetary protection and space exploration.
insights: Fungal adaptation to SMC involves complex proteomic changes that are species-specific. Increased UV-C resistance after SMC exposure suggests an adaptive response to irradiation. Fungi should be considered as a potential source of forward contamination during space missions, necessitating further research into their survival and adaptation mechanisms.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
objective: To develop a scalable software tool, MetaMiner, for the discovery of ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs) from microbial communities by integrating genome mining and computational mass spectrometry.
methodology: The MetaMiner pipeline analyzes paired genome/metagenome assemblies and tandem mass spectra. It identifies putative biosynthetic gene clusters and precursor peptides, constructs target and decoy RiPP structure databases, matches tandem mass spectra against these databases using a modified Dereplicator algorithm, and enlarges the set of described RiPPs via spectral networking. It uses both motif-ORF and all-ORF approaches for genome mining.
results: MetaMiner identified 31 known RiPPs and discovered seven unknown RiPPs in various datasets, including those from Actinomyces strains, Bacillus strains, Cyanobacteria strains, sponge microbiome, microbial isolates from the International Space Station, and human microbiome. The discovery of wewakazole was confirmed through isolation and NMR analysis.
conclusions: MetaMiner is a high-throughput method for RiPP structure elucidation that combines metagenomics, genome mining, and peptidomics. It extends previous tools to a broader range of RiPP classes and enables blind searches for RiPPs with unusual modifications. It can potentially make RiPP identification as robust as peptide identification in traditional proteomics.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between biosynthetic gene clusters and their corresponding metabolites, emphasizing the need for computational tools to link these elements. It also demonstrates the connection between microbial communities and the production of RiPPs with potential applications in pharmaceutical and food industries.
insights: The integration of computational mass spectrometry and genome mining can accelerate the discovery of novel RiPPs. MetaMiner's ability to handle unknown post-translational modifications and search large datasets makes it a valuable tool for exploring the chemical diversity of microbial communities and identifying potential drug leads.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To assemble and analyze the draft genome sequences of three Sphingomonas strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Genomic DNA was extracted from Sphingomonas strains isolated from the ISS. Whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed using the NovaSeq 6000 platform. The data were filtered for high-quality reads and assembled using the SPAdes genome assembler. Genome annotation was performed using the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline (PGAP). Phylogenetic affiliations were confirmed based on 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity and average nucleotide identity.
results: The draft genome sequences of two Sphingomonas sanguinis strains and one S. paucimobilis isolate were assembled. Key metrics such as the number of scaffolds, genome size, N50, GC content, and number of coding sequences were determined for each strain.
conclusions: The genomic sequences obtained will aid in understanding the impact of microgravity conditions on the strains' potential for bioactive compound production and other characteristics, compared to their Earth counterparts.
relationships: Comparative genomic characterization of ISS Sphingomonas species with their Earth counterparts may lead to the identification of genetic determinants potentially responsible for their important characteristics due to microgravity and elevated radiation conditions.
insights: Sphingomonas species have diverse capabilities, including pollutant degradation, biofilm formation, bioactive compound production, and plant-pathogenic characteristics. This study contributes to understanding the adaptation and potential functions of these bacteria in the unique environment of the ISS.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To assemble and characterize the draft genome sequences of six eukaryotic microbial strains belonging to the class Tremellomycetes isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). The goal is to understand the influence of microgravity on their potential pathogenicity.
methodology: Samples were collected from the ISS, processed, and plated onto potato dextrose agar. DNA was extracted, and libraries were prepared using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol. Whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed on a NovaSeq 6000 S4 platform. The data were filtered for high-quality reads and assembled using the SPAdes genome assembler. Species were identified based on internal transcribed spacer (ITS) sequences.
results: Draft genome sequences of six strains belonging to the class Tremellomycetes were obtained. The ITS sequence of Naganishia sp. strain IF7SW-B1 did not show ≥98% identity to any Naganishia species.
conclusions: The isolation of Naganishia and Papiliotrema species from the ISS is significant, and their persistence during space flight needs to be further studied. Further characterization of these sequences will aid in understanding the influence of microgravity conditions on these organisms’ potential pathogenicity.
relationships: This study builds upon previous work characterizing microbial communities on the ISS. It contributes to understanding the potential risks and adaptations of microorganisms in space environments.
insights: The genomic data provides a foundation for investigating the genetic determinants of pathogenicity in Tremellomycetes strains under microgravity conditions. The unique Naganishia sp. strain IF7SW-B1 warrants further taxonomic characterization.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Enterobacteriales Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To generate and identify the whole-genome sequences (WGS) of isolates from the International Space Station (ISS) as Rhodotorula mucilaginosa, and to enable the identification of genes responsible for synthesizing compounds with biological implications.
methodology: Samples were collected from ISS surfaces, processed, and plated on potato dextrose agar. Genomic DNA was extracted, and shotgun libraries were prepared using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol. Paired-end sequencing was performed on a NovaSeq 6000 S4 platform.
