Quality control, adapter trimming, and quality filtering were performed using fastp software. Cleaned sequences were assembled using SPAdes. Assembly quality was assessed using QUAST.
results: The whole-genome sequences of 28 isolates from the ISS were generated and identified as Rhodotorula mucilaginosa. Genome statistics, including the number of contigs, N50 values, median coverage, and genome size, were calculated. The G+C content ranged between 60.53% and 60.55%.
conclusions: The study provides draft genome sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa strains isolated from the ISS, which can be used to study the genes responsible for synthesizing compounds with biological implications and to develop countermeasures to eradicate this potential threat.
relationships: Rhodotorula mucilaginosa is the most abundant yeast isolated from surfaces of the ISS. Its ability to produce biofilms makes it important to study ISS strains, as the harsh conditions of the ISS can enhance antimicrobial resistance and biofilm formation.
insights: Characterization of the whole-genome sequences of R. mucilaginosa would allow for the development of countermeasures to eradicate this potential threat to life support systems on the ISS.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Lactobacillales Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To generate and characterize the whole-genome sequences of 26 bacterial strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and identified as members of the order Enterobacteriales.
methodology: Bacterial isolates were collected from various locations on the ISS. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) was performed using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol and the NovaSeq 6000 system. Raw sequencing data was validated using FastQC, and adapter trimming and quality filtering were carried out using fastp. Cleaned sequences were assembled using SPAdes. Genome quality was assessed using QUAST. The NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline (PGAP) was used for genome annotation.
results: The whole-genome sequences of 26 bacterial strains isolated from the ISS were generated. The strains were identified as members of the order Enterobacteriales, including Pantoea brenneri, Pantoea agglomerans, Kalamiella piersonii, and Enterobacter bugandensis. Genome statistics, including N50 values, numbers of contigs, and total genome lengths, were generated.
conclusions: Characterization of these whole-genome sequences may enable the identification of potential pathogenic bacteria that have been adapting to the space environment. Analyses of draft genome assemblies for these species might pave the way to identify the genetic processes responsible for potential pathogenicity.
relationships: The study highlights the potential health risks associated with human-pathogenic Enterobacteriales on the ISS, especially during long-duration missions where astronauts may be immunocompromised. The identified bacteria can adapt to extreme conditions like microgravity and radiation, necessitating countermeasures.
insights: The genomic analysis of ISS-isolated bacteria provides insights into their adaptation mechanisms to the space environment and their potential pathogenicity. This information is crucial for developing strategies to control and mitigate the risks associated with these microorganisms during space missions.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To characterize potentially pathogenic Lactobacillales bacteria isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and commercial resupply vehicles (CRV) using whole-genome sequencing (WGS). The goal is to understand how these bacteria adapt to the extreme conditions of space.
methodology: Nineteen strains of Lactobacillales were isolated from ISS and CRV surfaces. Genomic DNA was extracted, and WGS libraries were prepared using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol. Sequencing was performed on the NovaSeq 6000 S4 platform. Raw sequencing data was validated using FastQC, and adapter trimming and quality filtering were performed using fastp. Cleaned sequences were assembled using SPAdes, and assembly quality was assessed using QUAST. Average nucleotide identity (ANI) was calculated to determine taxonomic affiliations. Genome annotation was performed using the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline.
results: WGS data was generated for 19 bacterial isolates, including Enterococcus faecalis, Enterococcus faecium, and Aerococcus urinaeequi. Genome statistics, including the number of contigs, genome size, N50 values, and GC content, were determined for each strain. The average nucleotide identity was calculated by comparing all strains with their respective type strains.
conclusions: The study provides draft genome sequences of Lactobacillales isolated from the ISS, which can be used to further characterize their potential pathogenicity and adaptation mechanisms to the space environment. Further characterization of the WGS of these ISS environmental strains, including virulence genes, and subsequent conﬁrmation in animal models are required to decipher their potential pathogenicity.
relationships: Identified strains are related to species known for antibiotic resistance and potential pathogenicity, posing health concerns for astronauts. The study aims to understand the genomic basis of these traits in space-isolated strains.
insights: The genomic makeup of these potential pathogens will help the development of suitable countermeasure and mitigation strategies. Decreased immune response allows bacteria to take growth advantage due to their adaptability potential in the space environment.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Bacillaceae Strains Isolated from the International Space Station.
objective: To compare 10 bacterial strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) using whole-genome sequencing analysis and phylogenetically identify them as Klebsiella, in order to gain insight into their adaptation to space conditions.
methodology: Whole-genome sequencing was performed on 10 Klebsiella strains isolated from various locations on the ISS. DNA was extracted, and genomes were sequenced using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol. Quality control was performed using FastQC and fastp. Sequences were assembled using SPAdes, and quality was assessed using QUAST. Average nucleotide identity (ANI) was calculated using the EZBioCloud calculator.
results: Ten bacterial strains were identified as Klebsiella species, including K. aerogenes, K. pneumoniae, and K. quasipneumoniae. The genome sizes, N50 values, and GC contents were determined for each strain. The 16S rRNA gene sequences were compared to find the nearest neighbor, and phylogenic characterization was determined by calculating the average nucleotide identity (ANI).
conclusions: The whole-genome sequences of Klebsiella strains isolated from the ISS will aid in comparative genomic studies with Earth counterparts to understand their adaptation to space conditions. Genetic comparison is necessary to provide more details on the survival of Klebsiella species, especially concerning their increasing resistance to antibiotics.
relationships: This study compares Klebsiella strains isolated from the ISS with their Earth counterparts to understand the impact of space conditions on their genetic makeup and virulence.
insights: Klebsiella species found on the ISS might become immunogenic and pose a risk to astronauts due to microgravity and radiation inducing genetic adaptations. Understanding these adaptations is crucial for astronaut safety during space travel.

title: Assessing the risk of transfer of microorganisms at the International Space Station due to cargo delivery by commercial resupply vehicles
objective: To analyze the draft genome sequences of Bacillaceae isolates collected from the ISS to understand their roles in space and biotechnological applications.
methodology: Bacterial isolates were collected from ISS surfaces, and their genomic DNA was extracted. Whole-genome sequencing was performed using the Illumina NovaSeq platform. Sequence quality control, adapter trimming, and quality filtering were conducted using FastQC and fastp. SPAdes was used for genome assembly, and QUAST was used to assess assembly quality. Average nucleotide identity (ANI) was calculated using OrthoANIu.
results: Draft genome sequences of 29 bacterial isolates belonging to the family Bacillaceae were assembled and identified. The ANI range was 93.98% to 94.17% for Bacillus amyloliquefaciens, and the ANI was 98% for both Bacillus cereus and Paenibacillus polymyxa. Genomic statistics are available.
conclusions: Further analysis of the genome sequences will provide insights into the roles of these Bacillaceae strains in space and their potential for biotechnological applications.
relationships: The study identifies the presence of Bacillaceae strains on the ISS and provides genomic data for further research.
insights: The spore-forming property of Bacillaceae is important for NASA planetary protection purposes because spore-forming bacteria are more likely to survive sterilization procedures and the harsh environments of outer space, making them a potential threat for forward contamination.

title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To decipher the role of Commercial Resupply Vehicle (CRV) systems in potentially transporting microorganisms to the International Space Station (ISS) and to understand if CRVs could be a source of microbial contamination of the ISS.
methodology: Sampling of CRV surfaces (CRV1, CRV2, and CRV3) prior to launch and corresponding in-flight sampling of the ISS was conducted. Microbial burden was estimated using traditional techniques (colony counts), ATP assay, and qPCR assays (16S rRNA gene for bacteria and ITS region for fungi). Cultivable microbial diversity was characterized using Sanger sequencing. A shotgun metagenome sequencing approach was used to analyze CRV samples, and the microbial diversity was compared with the ISS environmental microbiome.
results: The internal surfaces of CRVs were generally cleaner than ground support equipment. CRV1 had a larger microbial population than subsequent CRV missions. Cultivation assays showed the presence of Actinobacteria, Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Ascomycota, and Basidiomycota. Metagenome analysis revealed more microbial taxa than cultivation-based assays. CRV microbiomes showed differences from the ISS microbiome.
conclusions: The metagenome sequence comparison of the CRV microbiome with the ISS microbiome revealed significant differences, showing that CRV microbiomes were a negligible part of the ISS environmental microbiome. The maintenance protocols in cleaning CRV surfaces are highly effective in controlling the contaminating microbial population during cargo transfer to the ISS via the CRV route, posing a very low risk of transferring microorganisms to the ISS.
relationships: The study compared the microbial diversity of CRV systems with the ISS microbiome to assess the potential for microbial transfer. It also examined the relationship between cleaning protocols and microbial contamination levels.
insights: CRV cleaning protocols are effective in minimizing microbial transfer to the ISS. While some microbial overlap exists between CRV and ISS, the overall impact of CRV microbiomes on the ISS environment is negligible. The study highlights the importance of maintaining stringent cleaning procedures to limit forward contamination of the ISS.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Aspergillus and Penicillium Species Isolated from the International Space Station and Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule
objective: To generate whole genome sequences (WGS) and define the phylogenetic novelty of Methylobacterium strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) using polyphasic taxonomic analyses, and to predict biotechnologically useful genetic determinants.
methodology: Sample collection from ISS surfaces, DNA extraction, whole genome sequencing using Illumina NovaSeq platform, genome assembly using SPAdes, annotation using NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline and RAST, phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing and MLSA, phenotypic characterization using standard protocols and API kits, and chemotaxonomic analysis of fatty acids, polar lipids, and quinones.
results: Three ISS strains (IF7SW-B2T, IIF1SW-B5, IIF4SW-B5) were identified as novel species of Methylobacterium, closely related to M. indicum. A fourth strain (I1-R3) was identified as M. rhodesianum. The novel species exhibited unique phenotypic and chemotaxonomic characteristics. Genome analysis revealed genes related to nitrogen metabolism, phosphate transport, stress tolerance, and plant growth promotion.
conclusions: The three ISS strains represent a novel species of the genus Methylobacterium, named Methylobacterium ajmalii. The genomic and phenotypic distinctiveness supports their classification as a new species. The presence of genes involved in plant growth promotion suggests potential applications for developing self-sustainable plant crops for long-term space missions.
relationships: The three novel Methylobacterium strains are closely related to M. indicum, while strain I1-R3 is closely related to M. rhodesianum. The study also explores the potential interactions of the novel strains with plants, particularly in the context of plant growth promotion under microgravity conditions.
insights: The study provides insights into the genomic and phenotypic characteristics of Methylobacterium species isolated from the ISS. It highlights the potential of these microorganisms for plant growth promotion and their adaptation to the space environment. The findings contribute to the understanding of microbial diversity in closed environments and the development of sustainable life support systems for space exploration.

title: Advances in Space Microbiology
objective: To assemble and characterize the draft whole-genome sequences (WGS) of 30 fungal strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) belonging to the Penicillium and Aspergillus genera.
methodology: Surface samples were collected from the ISS using polyester wipes and resuspended in sterile phosphate-buffered saline. Samples were concentrated, plated onto potato dextrose agar, and incubated. DNA was extracted, and shotgun libraries were prepared. Paired-end sequencing was performed on a NovaSeq 6000 S4 platform. Raw reads were assessed using FastQC, and cleaned sequences were assembled with SPAdes. Assembly quality and genome size were calculated using QUAST. Species were identified based on internal transcribed spacer (ITS), calmodulin, and b-tubulin sequences.
results: The draft whole-genome sequences of 30 fungal strains from the Penicillium and Aspergillus genera were assembled. The genome sizes, number of scaffolds, N50 values, median coverage, and G+C content were determined for each strain. Species identification was performed based on ITS, calmodulin, and β-tubulin gene sequences.
conclusions: The WGS data will enable detailed genomic characterization of the isolated fungal strains. This characterization will help determine their potential applications and importance for space and biotechnological industries. The ISS-isolated species are significant for investigating the effects of microgravity and irradiation on fungi compared to their ground counterparts.
relationships: The study identifies relationships between the isolated fungal species and their potential applications in biotechnology and bioremediation, such as the production of antibiotics (Penicillium chrysogenum), maturation of cheeses (Penicillium camemberti), production of citric acid (Aspergillus niger), and removal of lead from polluted water (Penicillium polonicum).
insights: Characterization of WGS of Penicillium and Aspergillus species is critical due to their versatile applications. Fungi are excellent models for studying evolution and adaptation, making the ISS-isolated species uniquely significant for investigating the effects of space conditions.

title: MHC Diversity Across Time and Space
objective: To review the geographic and temporal patterns of MHC diversity in wild populations and how they are shaped by selective and demographic processes, and to propose integrating immunogenetic, environmental, and parasite data for conservation efforts.
methodology: Review of existing literature and theory exploring MHC diversity patterns, selective pressures, and demographic influences. Synthesis of information on latitudinal and altitudinal gradients, habitat fragmentation, and climate change impacts.
results: MHC diversity is often lower at the edges of species distributions, particularly in high-latitude and high-altitude regions. Climate change and emerging parasites threaten wildlife populations with reduced immunogenetic diversity. Habitat fragmentation leads to loss of genetic and immunogenetic diversity.
conclusions: Understanding the mechanisms maintaining genetic diversity, especially MHC, is crucial for local adaptive processes and conservation. Integrating multidisciplinary data sets is essential for predicting population susceptibility to climate change and infectious diseases. Monitoring MHC genetic diversity is vital for species preservation.
relationships: MHC diversity is related to host-parasite interactions, climate change, habitat fragmentation, and geographic location. Parasite-mediated balancing selection maintains genetic variation at the MHC. Genetic drift impacts MHC diversity in fragmented and small populations.
insights: Immunogenetic diversity is critical for resisting infectious diseases. Reduced immunogenetic diversity can severely threaten wildlife populations facing climate change. Integrating immunogenetic data with environmental and parasite data can help develop effective conservation measures.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Various Bacterial Phyla Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To characterize the response of the black fungus Knuﬁa chersonesos to simulated microgravity (LSSMG) and evaluate the role of cell-wall melanization in stress survival.
methodology: Knuﬁa chersonesos wild type and a melanin-deficient mutant were exposed to LSSMG using high-aspect-ratio vessels (HARVs). Qualitative and quantitative proteomic analyses were performed on mycelia and culture supernatant (secretome). Scanning electron microscopy and fluorescence microscopy were used to assess morphological changes and cell viability.
results: LSSMG induced hyphae formation earlier in the wild type. Proteomic analysis revealed differential expression of proteins involved in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, transport, ribosome biogenesis, and translation. Scytalone dehydratase, involved in melanin synthesis, was upregulated in the wild type secretome and downregulated in the mutant. No significant changes in cell size or viability were observed.
conclusions: Black fungi can cope with microgravity conditions. Cell wall melanization influences the metabolic response to microgravity. The wild type showed increased energy metabolism, while the mutant primarily downregulated protein expression.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between melanization, metabolic adaptation, and survival in extreme environments. It also suggests potential links between microgravity, membrane lipid composition, and transporter activity.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the extremotolerance of black fungi and their adaptability to space conditions. It also raises questions about the role of non-classical protein secretion and the potential for strain-specific responses to microgravity.

title: Evaluating the lettuce metatranscriptome with MinION sequencing for future spaceflight food production applications
objective: To characterize the microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) by generating whole-genome sequences from bacterial strains isolated from ISS surfaces.
methodology: Samples were collected from ISS surfaces using premoistened wipes. The samples were then processed to concentrate the bacterial content, followed by plating on agar. Genomic DNA was extracted from isolated colonies, and whole-genome shotgun sequencing was performed using the Illumina NovaSeq platform. The resulting sequences were quality filtered, trimmed, and assembled using SPAdes. Species identity was confirmed using OrthoANIu, and genomes were annotated using the NCBI Prokaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline.
results: Draft genomes of 96 bacterial strains from 14 species isolated from the ISS were generated. Eleven of the 14 species are common members of the human microbiome, and most can act as opportunistic human pathogens. The identified species belong to the phyla Actinobacteria (Pseudoclavibacter, Kocuria, and Micrococcus), Proteobacteria (Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas), and others (Cytobacillus, Methylobacterium).
conclusions: The study provides genomic data of bacterial strains isolated from the ISS, contributing to the understanding of the ISS microbiome and its potential impact on astronaut health. The identification of opportunistic pathogens highlights the importance of monitoring the microbiome in closed habitats like the ISS.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the closed environment of the ISS, the human microbiome, and the potential for opportunistic pathogens to thrive. It also touches upon the relationship between bacterial survival mechanisms and the conditions within the ISS.
insights: The research provides insights into the microbial diversity present on the ISS and the potential risks associated with opportunistic pathogens in a closed environment. The genomic data generated can be used for further studies on microbial evolution, adaptation to space conditions, and the development of strategies to maintain a healthy environment for astronauts.

title: Investigation of Spaceflight Induced Changes to Astronaut Microbiomes
objective: To develop a method for analyzing the metatranscriptome of microbial communities associated with lettuce crops using nanopore sequencing, and to understand the complexity of plant-microbe relationships in space.
methodology: Microbial RNA was enriched from lettuce leaves grown under International Space Station (ISS)-like conditions.  The RNA was converted to cDNA and sequenced using the Oxford Nanopore MinION platform. Bioinformatic analysis was performed to identify and quantify microbial taxa and their functional activity.
results: A method was developed to enrich microbial RNA from plant-microbe total RNA.  The lettuce leaf microbiome was characterized, revealing a diverse range of bacterial and fungal taxa. Key metabolic pathways in both bacterial and fungal populations were identified. The dominant bacterial metabolisms observed were the glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism and oxidative phosphorylation. The dominant fungal pathways observed were thermogenesis and oxidative phosphorylation.
conclusions: The study demonstrates the feasibility of using nanopore sequencing for on-orbit monitoring of plant microbiomes.  The developed methodology can be used to identify potential drivers of change during plant growth and development in spaceflight, enabling preventative and proactive care of crops for sustainable space agriculture.
relationships: The study focuses on the complex and dynamic relationships between plants and their microorganisms, which are influenced by environmental factors, including spaceflight. It investigates how spaceflight and microgravity analogs alter plant-microbe interactions at the genetic and physiological levels.
insights: The research provides insights into the diversity and transcriptional activity of the lettuce leaf microbiome grown under ISS-like conditions. It highlights the importance of regular monitoring of the transcriptional and metabolic activity of taxa within plant growth habitats during spaceflight to ensure crew safety and maximize crop production.

title: Genomic Characterization of Potential Plant Growth-Promoting Features of Sphingomonas Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To investigate the molecular mechanism of microgravity-induced intestinal flora dysbiosis on liver and brain metabolism abnormalities using a simulated microgravity environment.
methodology: 3D-Clinostat to simulate microgravity in mice. Hematoxylin-eosin (HE) staining, 16S sequencing technology, non-targeted metabolomics analysis, PICRUST 2 for functional prediction, fecal microbiota transplant (FMT), MetaMapp analysis, and Pearson correlation analysis.
results: Simulated microgravity (SMG) induced gut tissue abnormalities and imbalanced gut microbiota and serum metabolite profiles in mice. Liver metabolism and brain tissue functions were disrupted. FMT from SMG mice to wild-type mice replicated gut microbiota and serum metabolite profiles similar to SMG mice, leading to liver and brain tissue abnormalities.
conclusions: Microgravity induces imbalances in the gut microbiota, triggering abnormalities in liver and brain metabolism and function. Valeric acid, a gut microbiota metabolite, is likely a key metabolite relating to these microgravity-induced abnormalities.
relationships: Microgravity -> Gut Microbiota Imbalance -> Liver Metabolic Dysfunction & Brain Dysfunction; Gut Microbiota -> Valeric Acid -> Liver & Brain Disorders

title: Genomic Characterization of the Titan-like Cell Producing Naganishia tulchinskyi, the First Novel Eukaryote Isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To identify genetic determinants related to plant growth-promoting features (PGPF) in Sphingomonas strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and highlight those that may be adaptive to growth on spaceflight-relevant environments and surfaces.
methodology: Comparative genomic analyses were performed on Sphingomonas strains isolated from the ISS and the Kennedy Space Center (KSC), including whole-genome sequencing (WGS), metagenomic data analysis, BLAST-based genome comparisons, pangenome comparisons using Anvi'o, and functional annotation using EggNOGv5 database. Metabolomic characterization using high-performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection-mass spectrometry (HPLC-DAD-MS) was used to confirm the production of indole-3-acetic acid (IAA).
results: Sphingomonas species persisted across multiple flights on the ISS, with S. sanguinis being abundant. The spaceflight Sphingomonas strains shared high functional identity with Sphingomonas sp. LK11, a well-characterized plant growth-promoting endophyte. Pathways associated with phosphate uptake, metabolism, and solubilization in soil were conserved across the tested strains. Several pathways promoting plant resistance to abiotic stress, including heat/cold shock response, heavy metal resistance, and oxidative and osmotic stress resistance, were also identified. IAA production was confirmed in the ISS strains.
conclusions: Sphingomonas strains present in spaceflight environments possess factors that may result in the production of several PGPFs and aid in plant growth. These strains hold potential to contribute to space exploration by promoting and controlling plant growth as part of an integrated bio-regenerative life support system.
relationships: The study highlights the potential for conserved functional characteristics between the spaceflight and type strains of S. paucimobilis and S. sanguinis genomes but with some distinctions. Spaceflight isolates showed the presence of tra genes involved in pilus assembly and conjugal transfer, indicating the existence of conjugal transfer under space conditions that might also be responsible for acquiring genetic materials from related bacterial species.
insights: The study suggests that the tested Sphingomonas species contain several pathways likely to confer resistance to a variety of abiotic stressors, especially with respect to several antioxidant enzymes and metabolites. The presence of these features supports the potential role of these newly sequenced Sphingomonas strains to promote plant growth and increase plant stress tolerance.

title: Metabolic modeling of the International Space Station microbiome reveals key microbial interactions.
objective: To characterize Titan-like cells of a novel Naganishia species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) environment, identify genetic determinants related to cold adaptation and radiation resistance, and determine the phylogenetic novelty of the ISS Naganishia strains.
methodology: Sample collection from ISS surfaces, whole-genome sequencing (WGS) and phylogenetic analyses using multi-locus sequence typing (MLST), morphological characterization under simulated microgravity conditions using confocal, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), gene annotation using MAKER, and functional annotation using InterProScan and REVIGO.
results: Isolation of a novel yeast species, Naganishia tulchinskyi, from ISS surfaces. Phylogenetic analyses confirmed its novelty and close relation to N. diffluens. Under simulated microgravity and 5% CO2 conditions, N. tulchinskyi formed Titan-like cells with increased size and cell wall thickness. Genomic analyses revealed genes related to cell morphogenesis, UV resistance, cold resistance, and microgravity tolerance.
conclusions: Naganishia tulchinskyi, a novel yeast species isolated from the ISS, produces Titan-like cells under simulated microgravity. The thicker cell wall and presence of genes related to stress resistance may help it withstand the harsh conditions of space. The study highlights the adaptive mechanisms of microorganisms in extreme environments.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between environmental stressors (microgravity, CO2), morphological changes (Titan-like cell formation), and genetic adaptations in Naganishia tulchinskyi. It also investigates the phylogenetic relationship of the novel species with other members of the Tremellomycetes class.
insights: The formation of Titan-like cells in N. tulchinskyi under simulated microgravity suggests an adaptive mechanism for survival in space. The presence of genes related to cold and radiation resistance indicates the potential for this species to withstand extreme conditions. Further research is needed to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying these adaptations and their implications for space exploration.

title: Microbial Burden Estimation of Food Items, Built Environments, and the International Space Station Using Film Media
objective: To predict possible metabolic interactions in the International Space Station (ISS) microbiome and shed further light on its organization, focusing on Klebsiella pneumoniae and its coexisting species.
methodology: A combination of a systems-based graph-theoretical approach (MetQuest) and a constraint-based community metabolic modeling approach (SteadyCom) was used. Metagenomic data from ISS surfaces were analyzed to predict metabolic dependencies.  Microbial growth rates were predicted individually and in communities to gauge the nature of their interactions.  Scanning electron microscopy was used to observe the interaction between K. pneumoniae and Aspergillus fumigatus under normal and simulated microgravity.
results: Enterobacteriaceae family members were often the most beneficial to the ISS microbiome. Pantoea species were highly dependent on their coexisting microorganisms. K. pneumoniae was beneficial to many coexisting microorganisms, especially Pantoea species.  Constraint-based modeling suggested a domination of amensalistic and parasitic interactions. K. pneumoniae had a detrimental effect on Aspergillus fumigatus, especially under simulated microgravity.
conclusions: Klebsiella and other Enterobacteriaceae play a key role in mediating metabolic interactions in the ISS microbiome. The study underscores the importance of complementary modeling approaches in dissecting complex microbiomes. The methodology can be extended to predict microbial interactions in other environments.
relationships: K. pneumoniae exhibits parasitic and amensalistic interactions with Aspergillus and Penicillium species, respectively, while showing beneficial interactions with Pantoea.  Enterobacteriaceae family members are generally beneficial for the survival of other microorganisms in the ISS microbiome.
insights: The study highlights the importance of K. pneumoniae in the ISS microbiome and its potential positive and negative interactions with other microbes, including potential pathogens.  Metabolic interactions are key drivers in shaping microbial communities, and understanding these interactions can be instrumental in understanding the interplay between various microorganisms in diverse communities.

title: Multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter pittii is adapting to and exhibiting potential succession aboard the International Space Station.
objective: To compare the performance of agar plates, Petriﬁlm, and Easy Plates for bacterial enumeration in food items and built environments, and to test the efficacy of Easy Plates for bacterial and fungal bioburden estimation on the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Cultivable microbial counts were compared between agar media and film media (Easy Plates and Petriﬁlm) using food items, surfaces in built environments on Earth, and environmental surfaces of the ISS. Samples were processed using standard microbiological techniques, and statistical analyses were performed to assess correlations and mean differences between media types.  Isolates were identified using 16S rRNA gene sequencing for bacteria and ITS region sequencing for fungi.
results: For food items and built environments, film media performed comparably to agar media for bacterial counts. Fungal counts for built-environment samples had a lower correlation between film and agar counts. Samples from the ISS had varying bacterial and fungal counts, with Easy Plates showing comparable performance to agar. Species compositions of isolates picked from agar vs. film media plates were similar, but some differences were observed in the isolation of specific species.
conclusions: Film media such as Easy Plates and Petriﬁlm are viable alternatives to agar plates for low-biomass built environments as well as for food samples. Easy Plates may be a suitable method for both food and environmental safety testing for future space habitats.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between different microbial enumeration methods (agar plates vs. film media) and their effectiveness in various environments (food, built environments, ISS). It also examines the relationship between media type and the species composition of isolated microorganisms.
insights: Film media offer advantages over agar plates in terms of cost, inoculation speed, preparation time, and incubator space.  Easy Plates, in particular, may be suitable for environmental monitoring in micro- or low-gravity settings.  The study highlights the importance of using appropriate methods for microbial enumeration in low-biomass environments, such as the ISS.

title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station.
objective: To characterize a novel bacterial species, Cohnella hashimotonis, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), and to determine its phylogenetic placement within the genus Cohnella.
methodology: Polyphasic taxonomic characterization including phenotypic, chemotaxonomic, phylogenetic (16S rRNA, gyrB, and genome-based trees), comparative genomic analyses (ANI, dDDH), and functional genome prediction (RAST, antiSMASH, dbCAN3).  Whole-genome sequencing of Cohnella ginsengisoli and Cohnella rhizosphaerae were also performed for comparison.
results: The isolated strain, F6_2S_P_1T, is a novel species within the genus Cohnella, named Cohnella hashimotonis.  It is phylogenetically related to Cohnella rhizosphaerae and Cohnella ginsengisoli, forming a distinct clade associated with plant tissue or rhizosphere environments.  Genomic analysis revealed unique genes related to carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. The strain does not appear to have nitrogen fixation capabilities.  The genome contains biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) potentially producing secondary metabolites, including lassopeptides similar to paeninodin.
conclusions: Cohnella hashimotonis is a novel species likely introduced to the ISS as a plant commensal. It can survive in the extreme conditions of the ISS and is closely related to rhizosphere bacteria, making it a promising candidate for plant-growth-promoting consortia in space. Further research is needed to explore its potential applications in plant growth experiments in outer space.
relationships: Cohnella hashimotonis is closely related to Cohnella rhizosphaerae and Cohnella ginsengisoli, all of which are associated with plant tissue or rhizosphere environments. It forms a distinct clade within the genus Cohnella. It may have mutualistic relationships with plant roots or other plant tissue.
insights: The study provides insights into the microbiome of the ISS and the potential for plant-associated bacteria to survive and potentially benefit plant growth in space environments. The identification of unique genes and BGCs in Cohnella hashimotonis suggests potential applications in plant growth promotion and biocontrol.

title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station
objective: To retrieve near full-length genomes from metagenomes generated from ISS environmental samples and perform in-depth functional and phylogenetic analyses.
methodology: Metagenomic sequencing, genome assembly using metaSPAdes and metaWRAP, phylogenetic analysis, comparative genomics, functional annotation, and gene-based AMR and biofilm study.
results: 46 MAGs were assembled, identifying 18 bacterial species including novel species. Fungal genomes were assembled for the first time from ISS metagenomes. Phylogenetic analyses showed ISS-specific evolution. Variations in AMR and virulence genes were characterized. Comparative analyses revealed insights into microbial evolution under microgravity.
conclusions: ISS genomes exhibit monophyletic phylogeny, suggesting a shared common ancestor. Cell membrane-related molecules are highly frequent, indicating ISS-specific bacterial evolution. SNP changes in MAGs and ISS genomes may be an adaptation strategy in AMR and biofilm formation. Enterobacterial species are more susceptible to microgravity changes.
relationships: Analysis of relationships between bacterial isolates, MAGs, and Earth-origin genomes to pinpoint the origin and evolution of ISS microorganisms.
insights: The study provides insights into the microbial diversity, functional properties, and potential evolutionary adaptations of microorganisms in the ISS environment, highlighting the impact of spaceflight conditions on microbial populations.

title: Genomic analysis reveals the presence of emerging pathogenic Klebsiella lineages aboard the International Space Station
objective: To characterize a novel bacterial species, Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), and to determine its phylogenetic placement within the genus Cohnella. The study also aimed to explore the functional traits predicted by the genome of strain F6_2S_P_1T and its closely related clade.
methodology: The study employed a polyphasic taxonomic characterization, including phenotypic, chemotaxonomic, phylogenetic (using taxonomic marker genes), and comparative genomic analyses. Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) of Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T, Cohnella ginsengisoli, and Cohnella rhizosphaerae was performed. Phylogenetic analyses were conducted using 16S rRNA and gyrB genes. Pangenomic analysis was used to identify shared and unique genes. Phenotypic characterization included growth temperature, pH, salt tolerance, oxidase and catalase activity, and carbon substrate utilization. Metagenomic reads from ISS surfaces were mapped to the genome of Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T.
results: Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T was identified as a novel species, closely related to Cohnella rhizosphaerae and Cohnella ginsengisoli. ANI values between Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T and other Cohnella species were below 79.4%. Phylogenetic analyses placed strain F6_2S_P_1T within a clade containing C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli. The genome of strain F6_2S_P_1T contained genes for carbohydrate and amino acid transport and metabolism, transcription, cell wall/membrane/envelope biogenesis, and signal transduction mechanisms. The strain did not encode for N2 fixation. The C. ginsengisoli clade contained 322 gene clusters not found in any other Cohnella genome. Metagenomic reads from ISS surfaces showed minimal mapping to the genome of strain F6_2S_P_1T.
conclusions: Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1T is a novel species, named Cohnella hashimotonis, closely related to plant/rhizosphere-associated Cohnella species. It likely originated from plant commensals introduced to the ISS during plant growth experiments. C. hashimotonis can survive in the extreme conditions of the ISS and is a promising candidate for testing as a member of plant-growth-promoting consortia for future plant experiments in outer space.
relationships: Cohnella hashimotonis is closely related to Cohnella rhizosphaerae and Cohnella ginsengisoli, forming a distinct clade within the genus Cohnella. All members of this clade are associated with plant tissue or the rhizosphere environment, suggesting a mutualistic relationship with plant roots. The study suggests that C. hashimotonis may have been introduced to the ISS as a plant commensal.
insights: The study provides insights into the microbial diversity of the ISS and the potential for plant-associated bacteria to survive and adapt in extreme space environments. The identification of Cohnella hashimotonis as a novel species highlights the importance of characterizing microbial communities in closed habitats like the ISS. The functional traits predicted for C. hashimotonis and its closely related clade suggest potential applications in plant growth promotion and bioremediation in space.

title: Phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits of five novel (Earth-derived) bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station and their prevalence in metagenomes
objective: To generate complete genomes and circular chromosomal maps of 10 Klebsiella strains isolated from the ISS, investigating their antimicrobial resistance, virulence, thermotolerance, heavy metal resistance, and mobile genetic elements. Also, to employ large-scale population genomics to understand the evolutionary paths and potential divergences of the ISS Klebsiella isolates from the Earth-based lineages.
methodology: Hybrid assembly methods using Illumina and ONT sequencing platforms were used to obtain circular plasmid and closed chromosomal genomes. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing was performed using the Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method. Bioinformatic analysis included quality filtering, adapter trimming, genome assembly, and annotation. Comparative genomics was conducted using ANI analysis and phylogenetic analysis.
results: Klebsiella isolates exhibited resistance to ampicillin and rifampicin. Four different sequence types (STs) were identified. K. pneumoniae ST101 was found to carry a conjugative plasmid encoding for heavy-metal resistance and thermoresistance. K. quasipneumoniae ST138 showed spatio-temporal persistence on the ISS. The ISS strains carried an average of 22.70 antimicrobial-resistance genes (ARGs) and 54.20 virulence factors (VFs) each.
conclusions: The study highlights the presence of Klebsiella isolates associated with human pathogenic lineages on the ISS, including a yersiniabactin-encoding K. pneumoniae ST101. The persistence of K. quasipneumoniae ST138 suggests its adaptability to the ISS environment. The presence of resistance and hypervirulence determinants in mobile genetic elements poses a risk for dissemination across the ISS microbiome. Ongoing surveillance of problematic STs is feasible and could help mitigate associated risks.
relationships: Klebsiella species play a key role in the ISS microbiome, benefiting co-existing microorganisms. K. pneumoniae displays parasitic interactions with Aspergillus species and amensalistic interactions with Penicillium species.
insights: The unique environmental pressures of the ISS may drive genomic divergence in Klebsiella species. Targeted screening of cargo and crew for potential opportunistic pathogens could mitigate pathogen-associated risks. The hypervirulent, multimetal resistance, and thermotolerant genomic profile of K. pneumoniae F3-2P (2) strain could possibly allow it to evade the existing disinfecting protocols aboard the ISS.

title: Genomic, functional, and metabolic enhancements in multidrug-resistant Enterobacter bugandensis facilitating its persistence and succession in the International Space Station
objective: To characterize novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), establish six strains as novel species through chemotaxonomic, phenotypic, physiological, and phylogenetic analyses, quantify the abundance of these species in ISS metagenomes, generate metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs), and analyze secondary metabolite biosynthesis gene clusters (BGCs).
methodology: Sample collection from ISS surfaces, bacterial isolation and cultivation, whole genome sequencing (WGS) using Illumina and Nanopore, Average Nucleotide Identity (ANI) and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) analyses, phylogenetic analysis using 16S rRNA gene sequences and whole-genome-based phylogenies, metagenomic read mapping, genome annotation using RAST, antibiotic resistance gene identification using CARD, and secondary metabolite BGC prediction using antiSMASH.
results: Six strains were identified as belonging to five novel bacterial species: Arthrobacter burdickii, Leifsonia virtsii, Leifsonia williamsii, Paenibacillus vandeheii, and Sporosarcina highlanderae. Genomic analysis revealed unique characteristics, including varying GC content, coding sequences, and phylogenetic relationships. Metagenomic analysis showed low abundance of these species on the ISS. Functional characterization identified genes related to virulence, antibiotic resistance, and secondary metabolite production.
conclusions: The study identified and characterized five novel bacterial species from the ISS, expanding the genomic database of space-relevant microbes. These species exhibit unique genomic and phenotypic traits, including potential antibiotic resistance and secondary metabolite production. The findings contribute to understanding microbial adaptation and survival in space habitats, crucial for ensuring the safety and success of future space missions.
relationships: The novel species show varying degrees of relatedness to known bacterial species, with 16S rRNA gene similarities >99% but ANI/dDDH values below species identity thresholds. Phylogenetic analyses revealed distinct clustering patterns, highlighting the limitations of 16S rRNA gene sequencing for species differentiation. The species interact with their environment through metabolic processes, stress responses, and potential antibiotic resistance mechanisms.
insights: Rare microbial species on the ISS possess unique genetic and metabolic capabilities, potentially impacting astronaut health and spacecraft functionality. The study underscores the importance of comprehensive genomic and phenotypic characterization for accurate microbial identification and risk assessment in space habitats. Further research is needed to explore the biotechnological potential of these species and their role in maintaining ecosystem stability in space.

title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis
objective: To characterize novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and assess their prevalence in ISS metagenomes.
methodology: Whole genome sequencing, phylogenomics, phenotypic characterization (biochemical tests, fatty acid profiling, polar lipid analysis), metagenomic analysis of ISS samples, and antiSMASH analysis for secondary metabolite biosynthesis gene clusters.
results: Identification of five novel bacterial species from ISS: Arthrobacter burdickii, Leifsonia virtsii, Leifsonia williamsii, Paenibacillus vandeheii, and Sporosarcina highlanderae. Genomic and phenotypic characterization revealed unique traits and metabolic potentials. Metagenomic analysis showed these species are rare in the ISS environment. Antibiotic resistance genes and secondary metabolite biosynthesis gene clusters were identified.
conclusions: The study expands the genomic database of space-relevant microbes, aiding in species identification, microbial dispersion tracking, and potential threat assessment in space habitats. Characterization of rare microbial species is crucial for ensuring the safety and success of future space missions.
relationships: The novel species exhibit unique relationships with their environment, including potential roles in bioremediation, plant growth promotion, and resistance to space-related stresses. Interactions with other microbes on the ISS are also suggested by the presence of specific genes and metabolic pathways.
insights: Rare microbial species on the ISS possess untapped biotechnological potential, including novel bioactive compounds, enzymes, and metabolic pathways. Understanding their genetic and functional capabilities is crucial for developing strategies to combat antibiotic resistance and improve space habitat management.

title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity
objective: To analyze the genomic adaptations of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) compared to their closest Earth-based relatives, focusing on genes related to stress response, DNA repair, and metabolism.
methodology: Whole-genome sequencing and comparative genomics were performed on five novel Gram-positive bacteria isolated from the ISS. Functional annotation was conducted using DeepFRI, PGAP, and eggNOG. Comparative analysis focused on identifying unique genes and mutations in the ISS isolates relative to their closest terrestrial relatives. Metabolic tests were also conducted to assess the bacteria's ability to utilize various carbon sources.
results: The study identified unique genetic traits in the ISS microorganisms, including adaptations for managing hypoosmotic stress, increased DNA repair activity, and the presence of mobile genetic elements enhancing metabolism. Novel biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) encoding secondary metabolites were also found. Proteome analysis revealed glycine enrichment in metallopeptidases, suggesting a role in universal adaptive mechanisms.
conclusions: Microorganisms isolated from the ISS have adapted to life in space through convergent evolution, as evidenced by mechanosensitive channel proteins, increased DNA repair activity, and novel S-layer oxidoreductases. Common genes facilitating adaptation to the ISS environment may enable bioproduction of essential biomolecules during future space missions or serve as potential drug targets.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the space environment and microbial adaptation, showing how extreme conditions on the ISS drive the evolution of unique genetic traits in microorganisms. It also explores the potential for these adapted microorganisms to interact with each other within the microbiome.
insights: Deep learning-based annotations, particularly using DeepFRI, are crucial for identifying and characterizing novel genes and adaptations in extremophilic microorganisms. The study underscores the importance of understanding microbial adaptations in space for safeguarding astronaut health, preventing contamination, and exploring biotechnological applications for space colonization.

title: Recent advances in the genome mining of Aspergillus secondary metabolites (covering 2012‚Äì2018).
objective: To investigate the tissue-specific production of aspulvinone E, a precursor in both aspulvinone and melanin pathways in Aspergillus terreus, and to understand the molecular mechanisms regulating this spatial control.
methodology: Heterologous expression of NRPS-like genes in A. nidulans, gene deletion experiments using direct repeat strategy, recycling of AfpyrG marker, tissue-specific extraction, Real-Time qRT-PCR, LC-MS analysis, fluorescence microscopy, and genetic manipulation to replace coding regions of genes.
results: Two NRPS-like genes, apvA and atmelA, are responsible for the formation of aspulvinone E. AtmelA is involved in melanin biosynthesis in conidia, while ApvA is involved in aspulvinone biosynthesis in hyphae. A single trans-prenyltransferase, AbpB, prenylates both aspulvinones and butyrolactones. Tissue-specific expression of atmelA and apvA is regulated by their respective promoters.
conclusions: Metabolite diversity can be expanded by spatial regulation of the same precursor biosynthesized by two distinct genes. Tissue-specific expression of biosynthetic genes results in the production of the same compound in different fungal tissues, allowing it to be modified into different products. Tailoring enzymes can modify compounds with different chemical scaffolds.
relationships: ApvA and AtmelA share a common ancestral gene. ApvA is inserted in a conserved genomic region consisting of genes that code for life-essential proteins. AbpB interacts with both aspulvinones and butyrolactones.
insights: Spatial regulation of secondary metabolite production is a key mechanism for expanding chemical diversity in fungi. Promoters of genes like atmelA can be used to direct the expression of genes specifically inside of conidia. Tailoring enzymes can modify multiple secondary metabolites, expanding diversity.

title: Recent advances in the genome mining of Aspergillus secondary metabolites (covering 2012–2018)
objective: To examine advances made in Aspergillus SM genome mining efforts since 2012, focusing on Aspergillus nidulans, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus niger, and Aspergillus terreus.
methodology: Review of literature on genetic identification and molecular characterization of SM biosynthetic gene clusters, along with proposed biosynthetic pathways in Aspergillus species.
results: Summarized the status of linking predicted SM core backbone synthase enzymes to downstream products in A. nidulans, A. fumigatus, A. niger, and A. terreus. Discussed specific advances in the genetic characterization and biosynthetic pathway elucidation of SMs produced by these four species.
conclusions: Fungal sequencing initiatives have accelerated the ability to link SMs to their biosynthetic gene clusters, enhancing the understanding of fungal SM biosynthetic processes. Genetic engineering can be used to optimize SM production levels or generate useful second-generation analogs.
relationships: SMs are organic small molecules that confer selective advantage to the organism despite not being directly required for survival. They function as weapons to eliminate neighboring competition, chemical signals in microbial cell communication, agents of symbiosis and transportation, sexual hormones, or differentiation effectors. SMs also possess various characteristics that make them great drug candidates.
insights: Genome mining of 'cryptic' pathways offers a promising source for new drug discovery. Linking known therapeutically-relevant SMs to their biosynthesis genes facilitates genetic manipulation efforts to optimize product yields of first-generation compounds and engineer second-generation compounds.

title: Knee and Hip Joint Cartilage Damage from Combined Spaceflight Hazards of Low-Dose Radiation Less than 1 Gy and Prolonged Hindlimb Unloading.
objective: To determine if rapid deterioration of bone occurs in vertebrae post-irradiation (IR) in non-human primates (NHPs), assessing longitudinal architectural and density changes using cortical thickness and dose mapping.
methodology: Sixteen male rhesus monkeys were exposed to uniform total chest irradiation (10 Gy). CT scans were taken before and after irradiation (2, 4, 6, and 8 months). Bone mineral density (BMD) and cortical thickness (Ct.Th) were calculated. Pathologic analysis of bone samples was performed. Statistical analysis included repeated measures ANOVA and paired t-tests.
results: Younger NHPs (<50 months) were more prone to pulmonary toxicity. Significant loss of Ct.Th in the in-field T9 occurred by 2 months post-IR, persisting to 8 months. No Ct.Th loss was observed in out-of-field vertebrae (L2, L4). Reduced BMD was observed by 4 months post-IR for T9 and by 6 months for L2 and L4. Histologically, regions with cortical thinning showed increased cortical porosity.
conclusions: Rapid cortical thinning and loss of BMD occurred post-RT. Younger age at IR was associated with greater sensitivity to radiation. Bone is a radiosensitive tissue, and patients with osteoporosis or pre-existing VCF may be at increased risk of fractures. Osteoclast inhibitory therapies may provide bone radioprotection.
relationships: Younger animals experienced more significant bone turnover and were more sensitive to radiation. The study highlights the dependence of radiation-induced bone changes on both dose and skeletal maturity. There was a correlation between cortical thinning observed in CT scans and increased cortical porosity observed histologically.
insights: High-dose radiation therapy can lead to rapid bone loss, particularly in younger individuals. Monitoring bone health and considering prophylactic interventions, such as osteoclast inhibitors, may be beneficial for patients undergoing radiation therapy. The dose threshold for bone damage may be very low.

title: The individual and combined effects of spaceflight radiation and microgravity on biologic systems and functional outcomes
objective: To determine if prolonged periods of reduced weight-bearing with or without exposure to spaceflight-relevant low doses of radiation causes or enhances knee and hip joint damage, focusing on the effects on cartilage.
methodology: Eighty mice were divided into eight groups: ground-sham, ground-0.1 Gy, ground-0.5 Gy, ground-1.0 Gy, HLU-sham, HLU-0.1 Gy, HLU-0.5 Gy, and HLU-1.0 Gy. Hindlimb unloading was performed via tail suspension. Irradiation was performed using a clinical linear accelerator. Cartilage volume and thickness were analyzed using micro-computed tomography. Histology and molecular probing were used to assess cartilage composition and damage. Serum cartilage oligomeric matrix protein (sCOMP) was measured. Proteomics and pathway analysis were performed on femoral head cartilage.
results: Significant radiation and load effects were identified on cartilage volume and thickness. Cartilage volume was reduced in all treatment groups compared to ground-sham. Cartilage thickness was significantly thinner at the tibial-femoral cartilage-cartilage contact point after HLU and/or irradiation. Collagen area was reduced within the medial tibial plateau articular cartilage after HLU and/or irradiation. MMP-13 concentration was higher in HLU and ground-0.1 Gy relative to ground sham. Circulating serum COMP was significantly more in the irradiated groups compared to ground-sham. Pathway analysis identified decreased levels of protein biomarkers suggestive of cartilage matrix damage.
conclusions: HLU and exposure to low-dose radiation cause degradation and an arthritic phenotype in the knees and hips of mice. Reduced weight-bearing and low-dose radiation cause an early, catabolic response. Both radiation and reduced weight bearing represented individual challenges to joint health. Low-dose radiation during prolonged spaceflight could contribute to accelerated arthritis induction in astronauts.
relationships: HLU and radiation exposure both independently contribute to cartilage degradation. There was a significant interaction between load and radiation on cartilage thickness, collagen staining, MMP-13 concentration, and circulating serum COMP. The greatest decrease in collagen in ground occurred at lower radiation doses, while in HLU this occurred at higher radiation doses.
insights: Cartilage is sensitive to radiation injury at low doses. The effects of HLU and radiation manifest to the greatest degree within the joint at the anatomic location of greatest weight bearing. The study provides evidence that radiation present in the spaceflight environment may negatively affect the joint health of astronauts during periods of reduced weight bearing.

title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces an arthritic phenotype in knee articular cartilage and menisci of rodents
objective: To describe biologic and functional outcomes from ground-based analogue models for microgravity and radiation, specifically highlighting the combined effects of radiation and reduced weight-bearing from rodent ground-based tail suspension via hind limb unloading (HLU) and partial weight-bearing (PWB) models.
methodology: Review of existing literature and ground-based analogue models using rodent studies, including hind limb unloading (HLU) and partial weight-bearing (PWB) models, in vitro studies, and spaceflight results.
results: Combined exposure to microgravity and radiation can lead to additive bone loss, skeletal impairments at the cellular level, and altered vasodilation. Ocular damage and retinal degeneration can be promoted by altered gravitation changes and ionizing radiation. Space radiation exposure impairs performance in many cognitive processes. Space radiation combined with microgravity-induced weightlessness has a synergistic impact on degenerative cardiovascular disease. Spaceflight stressors have extensive effects on progenitor cell populations and stem cell differentiation capabilities.
conclusions: Spaceflight environmental conditions, particularly microgravity and low-dose radiation, represent a risk to astronaut health. Combined exposure to spaceflight factors can perturb signaling mediated by bone-derived hormones. More studies are needed to understand the role of bone crosstalk with other organs in mediating the physiological changes attributed to spaceflight. Further research is needed to validate findings using improved radiation exposure paradigms and to standardize methodologies for conducting HLU and partial weight-bearing studies.
relationships: The skeleton is an endocrine organ that can crosstalk with other tissues to maintain health and homeostasis. Bone-derived hormones regulate a variety of physiological processes including glucose metabolism, appetite suppression, cognition, and behavior.
insights: Understanding the combined effects of spaceflight hazards is necessary to determine health risks and develop countermeasures. The HLU model has limitations and factors such as room temperature, social housing, and stress responses should be considered when performing and interpreting individual and combined hazard investigations. Further studies are needed to investigate the response of multiple organ systems to reduced weight-bearing.

title: Œ±Klotho decreases after reduced weight-bearing from both spaceflight and hindlimb unloading
objective: To evaluate how actual and simulated spaceflight conditions with reduced weight-bearing affect both the cartilage and the meniscus of the medial knee compartment.
methodology: Male mice were subjected to: (1) ~35 days on the International Space Station (ISS); (2) 13 days aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis; or (3) 30 days of HLU, followed by a 49-day weight-bearing readaptation with/without exercise. Cartilage and meniscal degradation were measured via microCT, histology, and proteomics.
results: Cartilage degradation post-ISS and HLU occurred at the tibial-femoral cartilage-cartilage contact point, with meniscal volume decline. Cartilage and meniscal glycosaminoglycan content decreased in unloaded mice, with elevated catabolic enzymes and oxidative stress responses in menisci. Exercise promoted recovery of cartilage volume and thickness during readaptation.
conclusions: Reduced weight-bearing from either spaceflight or HLU induces an arthritic phenotype in cartilage and menisci. Exercise promotes recovery of cartilage volume and thickness upon return to joint loading.
relationships: The study draws parallels between joint degradation observed in spaceflight and clinical scenarios of reduced weight-bearing. It highlights the potential for exercise to mitigate arthritic responses in both scenarios.
insights: The findings suggest that targeted exercise programs may alleviate and recover articular cartilage damage resulting from reduced weight-bearing, offering potential therapeutic strategies for both astronauts and individuals with sedentary lifestyles or orthopedic conditions.

title: Prolonged exposure to particulate chromate inhibits RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins.
objective: To determine if plasma αKlotho was reduced after both spaceflight aboard the ISS and hindlimb unloading (HU), and if deficiency could be reversed with exercise.
methodology: Plasma αKlotho levels were measured in mice after exposure to microgravity aboard the ISS and after hind limb unloading (HU). Some mice were subjected to exercise (running or climbing) after HU to assess recovery. ELISA was used to detect αKlotho and FGF23. Statistical analysis included t-tests and ANOVA.
results: Plasma αKlotho was reduced after both spaceflight and HU. Exercise after HU led to partial (running) or full (climbing) recovery of αKlotho levels. Gastrocnemius muscle mass was also lower in flight mice. FGF23 levels were not significantly altered.
conclusions: Reduced weight-bearing conditions result in lowered αKlotho levels. Exercise, particularly climbing, can improve αKlotho levels after HU. αKlotho may be a relevant biomarker for bone status during spaceflight and recovery.
relationships: The study suggests a relationship between weight-bearing, exercise, muscle mass, and αKlotho levels. It also highlights the interplay between αKlotho and FGF23 in skeletal homeostasis.
insights: αKlotho could serve as a circulating biomarker for bone status, both in-flight and upon return to weight-bearing. HU mice may provide an appropriate terrestrial analog for examining the relationship between αKlotho and health along the musculoskeletal tissue-kidney axis.

title: Transcriptomics, NF-Œ∫B Pathway, and Their Potential Spaceflight-Related Health Consequences.
objective: To investigate the effect of prolonged hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) exposure on the RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins, RAD51C and BRCA2, focusing on their interaction with RAD51 and their subcellular localization.
methodology: The study used WTHBF-6 cells (human bronchial fibroblasts) and Chinese hamster lung fibroblast cell lines (V79, irs3, irs3#6). Cells were treated with zinc chromate for varying durations (24, 72, and 120 hours). Immunofluorescence staining, proximity ligation assay (PLA), and Western blot analysis were performed to assess protein localization, interactions, and levels.
results: Prolonged Cr(VI) exposure (120h) increased the cytoplasmic localization of RAD51C, while acute exposure (24h) did not. RAD51C deficiency induced RAD51 cytoplasmic accumulation. Cr(VI) exposure did not inhibit the interaction between RAD51 and RAD51C or BRCA2, but altered their subcellular distribution. BRCA2 showed a slight increase in cytoplasmic mislocalization after prolonged Cr(VI) exposure.
conclusions: Prolonged Cr(VI) exposure inhibits RAD51 nuclear import regulation by inducing the mislocalization of RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins, RAD51C and BRCA2. The inhibition of nuclear import could play a role in Cr(VI)-induced carcinogenesis.
relationships: RAD51C and BRCA2 are RAD51 nuclear import mediators. RAD51C deficiency induces RAD51 cytoplasmic accumulation. Cr(VI) exposure affects the subcellular localization of RAD51/RAD51C and RAD51/BRCA2 interactions.
insights: Cr(VI) inhibits RAD51 nuclear import, potentially by binding to the nuclear localization signal (NLS) or altering post-translational modifications. RAD51C is more adversely affected by prolonged Cr(VI) exposure than BRCA2.

title: Interplay of space radiation and microgravity in DNA damage and DNA damage response.
objective: To summarize transcriptomics studies identifying NF-κB as a responsive pathway to simulated microgravity or spaceflight, and studies focusing on the NF-κB pathway in specific cell types or organ tissues related to spaceflight-related health risks.
methodology: Review of existing literature and omics studies conducted in space or using ground-based microgravity simulators, focusing on the NF-κB pathway.
results: The NF-κB network is commonly affected across different cell types under simulated or true spaceflight conditions. Whether the NF-κB pathway is activated or inhibited depends on the cell type, but the potential health impact appears to be negative.
conclusions: Sufficient evidence indicates that the NF-κB pathway is altered by microgravity or space radiation. Altered NF-κB activities in the space environment potentially impact health negatively. Manipulation of NF-κB pathways may reduce associated risks.
relationships: NF-κB is associated with spaceflight-related health risks including immune dysfunction, bone loss, muscle atrophy, CNS dysfunction, and risks associated with space radiation.
insights: Omics data can be applied to address spaceflight-related health risks by identifying pathways responsive to the space environment and developing countermeasures at the molecular level. Targeting key genes involved in relevant pathways may contribute to the development of countermeasures.

title: Synergistic Effects of Weightlessness, Isoproterenol, and Radiation on DNA Damage Response and Cytokine Production in Immune Cells
objective: To review the interplay of space radiation and microgravity in the DNA damage response (DDR) and discuss potential synergies between radiation and microgravity, as well as investigations of DNA damage induced in space.
methodology: Review of existing literature and studies, including both spaceflight experiments and ground-based simulations using microgravity analogs like rotating wall vessels (RWV) and clinostats. Analysis of DNA damage markers, DDR pathways, and cellular responses.
results: Space radiation can induce DNA damage in cultured cells and astronauts' blood cells. Simulated microgravity can affect the DDR, with some studies showing increased sensitivity to radiation and decreased DNA repair. Spaceflight experiments have yielded conflicting results regarding the effects of spaceflight on DNA repair capacity.
conclusions: Space environmental factors can cause DNA damage, potentially leading to detrimental health consequences. The effects of microgravity on the DDR are complex and require further investigation in the true space environment. Other environmental factors during space travel, such as dust particles and elevated CO2, may also contribute to DNA damage.
relationships: Microgravity and space radiation can interact synergistically to affect DNA damage and repair. Inflammatory mediators can also influence the DNA repair process.
insights: The combined effects of space radiation, microgravity, and other space-related factors on DNA damage and repair are complex and not fully understood. Further research is needed to determine the exact magnitude and characteristics of these effects and their impact on human health during space travel.

title: Synergistic Effects of Weightlessness, Isoproterenol, and Radiation on DNA Damage Response and Cytokine Production in Immune Cells
objective: To investigate the synergistic effects of isoproterenol (a sympathomimetic drug), radiation, and simulated microgravity on DNA damage response and cytokine production in nonstimulated immune cells.
methodology: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were treated with isoproterenol, exposed to γ-radiation (0.8 or 2 Gy), and incubated in rotating-wall vessels (RWVs) to simulate microgravity. Apoptosis, DNA strand breaks, gene expression (ADRB2, AKT1, APEX1, BAX, CASP3, LIG4, MDM2, OGG1, PARP1, PCNA, PTEN, TP53, XRCC5), and cytokine production (GM-CSF, IL-10, IL-12p70, IL-13, IL-1B, IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-7, IL-8, TNFα) were measured after 24 hours.
results: Radiation alone increased ADRB2 expression. Cells incubated in simulated microgravity had more DNA strand breaks than cells incubated in normal gravity. Radiation-induced cytokine production was observed only in simulated microgravity. Pretreatment with isoproterenol prevented most of the microgravity-mediated effects. Synergistic effects between gravity, radiation, and isoproterenol were observed on apoptosis, gene expression, and cytokine release.
conclusions: Simulated microgravity, radiation, and adrenergic receptor stimulation have synergistic effects on DNA damage response in quiescent human primary lymphocytes. Isoproterenol prevents radiation-induced expression of LIG4 and XRCC5 in 1g as well as CASP3, PTEN, and XRCC5 in µg for cells irradiated with 0.8 Gy. In cells irradiated with 2 Gy isoproterenol prevented radiation-induced XRCC5 gene expression in µg. Radiation-induced cytokines were only detectable in cells incubated in simulated microgravity, and the concentration of cytokines was higher after irradiation with 2 Gy than 0.8 Gy.
relationships: Expressions of BAX, CASP3, PCNA, LIG4, and MDM2 were positively correlated with all 13 cytokines studied. Conversely, expressions of AKT1, TP53, PARP1, OGG1, and APXE1 were negatively correlated with these cytokines.
insights: Activation of adrenergic receptor and DNA damage response can be relevant in cancer patients undergoing chemo- and/or radiotherapy. Drugs based on the manipulation of cAMP/PKA activity could be an option for space medicine.

title: Spaceflight induces novel regulatory responses in Arabidopsis seedling as revealed by combined proteomic and transcriptomic analyses.
objective: To determine the ability of RNAlater to preserve Arabidopsis thaliana tissue for downstream ‘omics-level analyses and to compare the effects of RNAlater on RNA, protein, and post-translational modification stability.
methodology: Etiolated Arabidopsis seedlings were either snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen or incubated in RNAlater. RNAseq and LC-MS/MS were performed to analyze transcriptomic and proteomic responses. Differential gene expression and protein abundance were assessed. Post-translational modifications were also analyzed.
results: RNAlater treatment altered transcript levels, with 5770 gene transcripts differentially expressed. Proteomic analysis showed 84 soluble and 120 membrane-bound proteins were differentially expressed. The abundance of post-translational modifications, particularly phosphorylation, was also altered by RNAlater fixation.
conclusions: RNAlater fixation can induce a transcriptomic response in plant tissues, potentially due to osmotic stress. While it preserves protein integrity, it can alter gene expression, protein expression, and post-translational modifications. Researchers should exercise caution when using RNAlater for plant omics-level experiments.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between RNAlater fixation and changes in gene expression, protein abundance, and post-translational modifications in Arabidopsis seedlings. It also relates osmotic stress to the observed transcriptomic response.
insights: RNAlater, while effective for preservation, is not inert and can induce cellular responses that affect transcriptomic and proteomic profiles. The rate of tissue infiltration by RNAlater allows a short-term alteration in transcription, but the RNAlater successfully inhibits the translational machinery before a substantial amount of protein is produced or degraded.

title: Mitigation and use of biofilms in space for the benefit of human space exploration
objective: To understand the molecular mechanisms behind plant adaptation to microgravity by simultaneously quantifying protein and transcript differential expression in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings grown on the International Space Station.
methodology: Proteomic (iTRAQ-labelled LC-MS/MS) and transcriptomic (RNA-seq) analyses were performed on three-day old, etiolated Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings grown aboard the International Space Station and on Earth. Protein extracts were fractionated to isolate soluble and membrane proteins and analyzed to detect differentially phosphorylated peptides. RNA-seq reads were aligned to the TAIR10 assembly. Differential expression was determined using the generalized linear model likelihood test within the EdgeR package.
results: 968 RNAs, 107 soluble proteins, and 103 membrane proteins were identified as differentially expressed. 16 differential phosphorylation events were also identified. There was a sweeping shift in post-transcriptional mechanisms of gene regulation. Cell wall adaptations were observed, with AHA2 and FERONIA, as well as CESA1 and SHOU4, playing central roles. Dysregulation of plastid gene transcription was also observed.
conclusions: Microgravity exposure significantly impacts post-transcriptional regulation, cell wall synthesis, redox/microtubule dynamics, and plastid gene transcription in Arabidopsis seedlings. Addressing the effects of microgravity on AHA2, CESA1, and alpha tubulins has the potential to enhance cytoskeletal organization and cell wall composition, thereby enhancing biomass production and growth in microgravity. Understanding and manipulating the dysregulation of plastid gene transcription has further potential to enhance plant growth in stressful microgravity conditions.
relationships: The study highlights the complex interplay between transcription, translation, post-translational modifications, and protein turnover in plant adaptation to microgravity. It reveals the importance of post-transcriptional regulation and the limitations of relying solely on transcriptomic data to understand plant responses to spaceflight.
insights: The research provides insights into potential targets for engineering plants optimized for spaceflight, including cell wall synthesis, microtubule stability, and plastid gene regulation. The altered redox state and ROS signaling suggest a mechanism for specific compensatory adaptation to space. The study also emphasizes the need for further research into the role of phosphoenriched proteomics in characterizing plant responses to microgravity.

title: Toward sustainable space exploration: A roadmap for harnessing the power of microorganisms.
objective: To review the impact of long-term space exploration on the astronaut microbiome and discuss its role in promoting or ameliorating conditions caused by spaceflight, as well as space-related factors that impact microbiome composition.
methodology: Review of existing literature and research on the astronaut microbiome, spaceflight hazards, and ground-based simulations.
