results: Spaceflight conditions, such as microgravity and radiation, can induce changes in microbiome composition (dysbiosis), altering host-microbe interactions and affecting immune function and metabolism. The gut microbiome composition becomes more similar between astronauts over the course of a mission, mostly due to a drop in the abundance of a few bacterial taxa. Changes in the skin, oral, and nasal microbiome also occur as a consequence of spaceflight conditions.
conclusions: Modifications in the astronaut gut microbiome occur during spaceflight and analog missions, with implications for human health and performance. Changes to gut microbiome composition are reversible, with at least partial reversal occurring in the order of days to weeks following return to Earth or completion of an analog mission. Personalized nutritional approaches and probiotics-based countermeasures may be helpful in mitigating unwanted neurobehavioral effects.
relationships: The review explores the connections between spaceflight, the host, and the microbiome, and the significance of these interactions for successful long-term space missions. It also discusses the brain-gut-microbiome axis and its impact on mental health.
insights: Understanding the impact of spaceflight on the astronaut microbiome is crucial for assessing health risks and developing countermeasures for long-term missions. Maintaining a healthy microbiome may help mitigate unwanted neurobehavioral effects and promote overall astronaut health.

title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight potable water
objective: To identify and highlight microbial biotechnologies suitable for establishing sustainable processes for in situ resource utilization and loop-closure in space exploration, reducing reliance on terrestrial resources.
methodology: The paper proposes a series of microbial biotechnologies based on processes and technologies currently implemented on Earth at different technology readiness levels (TRL), adapted to meet the specific requirements and challenges of the space environment.
results: The paper presents various microbial biotechnologies that can be used for habitat air bioremediation, human waste processing and reclamation, food production, pharmaceutical synthesis, biomining, structural biomanufacturing, biological collection and storage of energy, recycling of electronics, plastics and other waste streams, and soil remediation.
conclusions: Microbial biotechnologies can support several processes that decrease supply chain dependency from Earth on long-duration deep-space exploration missions and help close the loop on life support systems, preserving resources and extra-terrestrial environments, enabling sustainable space exploration.
relationships: Microbial processes can be integrated into life support systems and in situ resource utilization compartments to enhance loop-closure and reduce waste. Synergies exist between different microbial processes, such as using waste from one process as feedstock for another.
insights: Microbial biotechnologies offer a promising pathway towards sustainable space exploration by enabling in situ resource utilization, waste recycling, and the creation of closed-loop life support systems. These technologies also have potential benefits for terrestrial applications, addressing environmental issues and promoting a circular economy.

title: Designing a Novel Monitoring Approach for the Effects of Space Travel on Astronauts‚Äô Health
objective: To characterize the phenotypes of microbial isolates from the International Space Station (ISS) potable water system over several years, focusing on characteristics that could negatively impact astronaut health and life-support systems. The study aims to determine if bacterial water isolates changed their interactions and community properties over time.
methodology: The study involved profiling archived microbial isolates from the ISS potable water system for antibiotic resistance, metabolism, hemolysis, and biofilm structure/composition. Sixteen isolates collected over several years were examined for phenotypes, including biofilm formation and susceptibility to antimicrobials. Various techniques were used, including antimicrobial susceptibility testing, energy-metabolism tests, biofilm formation assays, confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM), and interspecies interaction testing.
results: The analysis of ISS potable water microbiota revealed that Burkholderiales, including Burkholderia, Ralstonia, and Cupriavidus, were the predominant order. All strains were resistant to multiple drugs. Most species preferred casein amino acids over carbohydrates as an energy source. Several strains, including R. pickettii, S. sanguinis, Bradyrhizobium spp., Mesorhizobium spp., and S. epidermidis, were strong EPS producers and formed biofilms. Intraspecies variations were observed, including hemolytic activity in select Burkholderia isolates.
conclusions: The study suggests that microbial populations in the ISS potable water system exhibit dynamic changes over time, with potential implications for astronaut health and life-support systems. The observed interspecies relationships and phenotypic variations highlight the importance of long-term monitoring and functional assessments of microbial communities in closed environments like the ISS. The findings also suggest a potential coevolutionary model for microbial interactions in spaceflight.
relationships: Interspecies interactions between the isolates were examined, revealing positive, negative, or neutral relationships. Some isolates displayed interactions dependent on the year of isolation, suggesting a common history of coexistence may influence their interactions. A hypothetical microbial coevolutionary model was proposed to explain the observed interspecies interactions.
insights: The study provides insights into the long-term effects of the spaceflight environment on microbial physiology and functional species' interactions. The findings highlight the potential for polymicrobial interactions to contribute to biofouling of onboard life-support systems and impact human health in space and on Earth. The observation of hemolytic Burkholderia subpopulations suggests an additional risk for opportunistic infections.

title: Draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain Sph5, isolated from tap water filtration membrane
objective: To develop a rapid and effective assay to monitor astronauts’ health in space by reanalyzing a publicly available microarray dataset and identifying key genes and correlation patterns affected by space travel.
methodology: Microarray dataset E-GEOD-74708 was downloaded from the NASA GeneLab Database. Gene expression profiles were analyzed for 10 astronauts (8 male and 2 female) at Pre-flight, In-flight, and Post-flight stages. Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified using the DEGseq package in R. Signaling pathway analysis was performed using the InnateDB tool. Gene pair correlation matrices were calculated and visualized. Protein-protein interaction and disease networks were constructed using BioGrid and DisGeNET databases. Drug and miRNA screenings were conducted using Drugbank and miRTARBase databases.
results: Identified 218 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between In-flight and Pre-flight. No DEGs were detected between Post-flight and In-flight. Space travel decreased genome regulation and gene correlations across the entire genome and individual signaling pathways. Developed a shortlist of 32 genes that could be used to monitor astronauts’ health during space travel.
conclusions: Space travel has a comprehensive effect on the human system, affecting gene expression, gene coordination, and various biological processes. Loss of gene expression coordination may contribute to the increased risk of cancer development in astronauts. The identified 32 genes can be used to develop a rapid assay for monitoring astronauts' health in space. Extended care is necessary for astronauts to minimize the risk of disease development after returning to ground.
relationships: Identified relationships between DEGs and various signaling pathways (signal transduction, immune system, gene expression, metabolism, etc.). Established connections between DEGs and diseases/disorders, including neoplasia/carcinoma, neurological disorders, and liver function issues.
insights: Space travel significantly affects gene expression and homeostasis, leading to a loss of coordination among genes. This loss of coordination, along with cosmic radiation and compromised immune function, may contribute to the development of various health problems in astronauts, including cancer. Monitoring gene pair correlations can provide valuable insights into the effects of space travel on human health.

title: Draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain Sph5, isolated from tap water filtration membrane
objective: To report the draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas spp. Sph5, a prevalent isolate from a biofilm on a microfiltration membrane used for drinking water biofouling studies, and to uncover strain-specific traits associated with membrane biofouling.
methodology: Sphingomonas spp. Sph5 was isolated and cultured. Genomic DNA was extracted, and sequencing libraries were generated using Kapa’s Hyperplus kit and IDT adapters. Sequencing was performed on a NovaSeq (Illumina). Assembly was performed with SPADES. Completeness was estimated using BUSCO proteobacteria marker genes. Species identification was performed using average nucleotide identity (ANI) with PYANI and MUMMER.
results: The draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis Sph5 was obtained. ANI scores between Sph5 and S. paucimobilis ranged from 99.77%–99.95%. The WGS phylogeny confirms that Sph5 is closest to S. paucimobilis. Re-annotation with Prokka predicts 4,321 CDS, 3 rRNAs, 54 tRNAs, 1 tmRNA, and 1 repeat region. Of the CDS, 3,342 could be functionally annotated. The genome size is 4680620 bp with a G + C content of 65.30%.
conclusions: The draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis Sph5 provides valuable insights into the genetic characteristics of this strain, which is commonly found in drinking water biofilms. This information can be used to better understand and manage biofouling in membrane filtration systems.
relationships: Sphingomonas spp. Sph5 is phylogenetically closest to Sphingomonas sanguinis strains BAB-7166 and NBRC 13937 based on 16S rRNA sequencing. WGS phylogeny confirms that Sph5 is closest to S. paucimobilis while related to S. sanguinis.
insights: WGS analysis is critical to uncover strain-specific traits associated with membrane biofouling. Sphingomonas paucimobilis is a common initial colonizer and biofilm former in drinking water membrane filtration systems.

title: Overexpression of CupB5 activates alginate overproduction in Pseudomonas aeruginosa by a novel AlgW-dependent mechanism
objective: To identify novel regulators of alginate production in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
methodology: A transposon library was screened in the non-mucoid reference strain PAO1.  Mutants were analyzed for alginate production.  Genetic deletions and complementation assays were performed.  AlgW cleavage of MucA was assayed in vitro using synthetic peptides.  MucA-resin assays were used to test competition for MucB binding.
results: Overexpression of CupB5 induces mucoidy through the AlgU pathway. A peptide signal in CupB5 enhances OMP-activated cleavage of MucA by AlgW, even in the presence of MucB. CupB5 peptides stimulate OMP-activated AlgW cleavage of MucA and partially relieve MucB inhibition in vitro.  MucB overproduction decreases alginate production in CupB5 overexpressing strains.
conclusions: CupB5, a protein normally secreted through the outer membrane by a chaperone-usher system, activates alginate production. Excess periplasmic CupB5 stimulates proteolytic cleavage of MucA by AlgW. The AlgU system integrates multiple signals, each reporting on potential dysfunction in outer-membrane assembly, structure, and/or secretion.
relationships: CupB5 overexpression leads to AlgW activation and MucA cleavage, resulting in AlgU activation and alginate production.  MucB inhibits AlgW cleavage of MucA. OMP peptides activate AlgW.  LPS binds MucB and releases MucA.
insights: CupB5 allows AlgW to compete more efficiently with MucB for MucA binding and cleavage. Simultaneous expression of CupB5 and MucE results in higher levels of alginate, indicating that these signals activate the alginate pathway through synergistic mechanisms. Stresses that compromise the transport to and outer-membrane assembly of OMPs and LPS, or that slow usher-mediated CupB5 secretion, would all lead to the periplasmic accumulation of these molecules and activation of the AlgU pathway.

title: CubeSats for microbiology and astrobiology research
objective: To examine changes in immune cell populations associated with mesenteric lymphatic dysfunction in a rat burn model and to assess the ability of serum from these animals to increase permeability in lymphatic endothelial monolayers and disrupt cellular junctions. Also, to observe the effects of doxycycline treatment on immune cell populations, morphometry, and lymphatic endothelial permeability.
methodology: A rat model of burn injury was utilized. Rats were subjected to a 30% body surface area burn. The number and characteristics of MHCII+ immune cells around mesenteric lymphatic vessels were examined using immunohistochemistry. Lymphatic endothelial cell (LEC) permeability was assessed using FITC-BSA leakage assays. VE-cadherin staining was used to assess cellular junction integrity. Doxycycline was used as an inhibitor of microvascular permeability.
results: Burn injury increased the number and size of MHCII+ immune cells along lymphatic vessels and increased lymphatic endothelial permeability. Serum from burn animals increased lymphatic endothelial permeability and induced breaks in VE-cadherin staining. Doxycycline treatment blocked the accumulation of immune cells along the vessel and prevented the increase in lymphatic endothelial permeability induced by burn serum. The morphology of cells already present on the lymphatic vessels changed despite doxycycline treatment.
conclusions: Factors produced during burn injury can induce lymphatic endothelial barrier disruption, and lymph produced during traumatic injury can influence the attraction and morphology of immune cell populations along the vessel. Doxycycline can mitigate some of these effects.
relationships: Burn injury leads to increased intestinal permeability and cytotoxic lymph. This toxic lymph contributes to secondary injuries in distal tissues. Immune cells are attracted to the perilymphatic space due to leakage of lymph from lymphatic vessels. The density of immune cells correlates with lymphatic dysfunction.
insights: Lymphatic vessels play a significant role in the systemic inflammatory response following burn injury. The accumulation of immune cells around lymphatic vessels contributes to lymphatic dysfunction and the development of toxic lymph. Doxycycline, by inhibiting lymphatic endothelial permeability, can reduce the accumulation of immune cells and mitigate some of the detrimental effects of burn injury.

title: In situ resource utilisation: The potential for space biomining
objective: To identify key topics and recommendations for developing and implementing future space experiments, focusing on in situ measurements, experimental parameters, exposure scenarios, and orbits. The goal is to advance the scientific utilization of future space-exposure platforms for astrobiology and astrochemistry research.
methodology: The ESA Topical Team Astrobiology and Astrochemistry reviewed the 2021 “ESA SciSpacE Science Community White Paper” and consulted with the broader scientific community. They identified key topics, summarized recommendations, and discussed various aspects of space experiments, including in situ measurements, experimental parameters, and exposure scenarios.
results: The review identified key topics in astrobiology and astrochemistry: (A) Understanding the origins of life, (B) Understanding habitability and the limits of life, and (C) Understanding the signs of life. Recommendations were made for the development and implementation of future experiments on platforms like CubeSats, SmallSats, and the Lunar Orbital Gateway.
conclusions: Space experiments are crucial for addressing key questions in astrobiology and astrochemistry. Future space platforms offer new opportunities to conduct experiments that can address topics such as the origins of life, habitability, and the search for biosignatures. A complementary approach, combining in situ experimentation and ground-based research, is essential for a complete understanding.
relationships: The research highlights the interconnectedness of understanding the origins of life, habitability, and the signs of life. It emphasizes the importance of studying extremophiles and their adaptation mechanisms to understand the limits of habitability. The study also underscores the need for planetary protection and decontamination procedures to prevent forward contamination.
insights: Space-based experiments provide unique environments for studying the combined effects of microgravity and radiation on biological samples. Miniaturization of technology and the use of SmallSats and CubeSats are opening new possibilities for space experiments. In situ analyses and sample return missions are both valuable for gathering comprehensive data and advancing our understanding of astrobiology and astrochemistry.

title: The smallest space miners: Principles of space biomining
objective: To explore the principles and feasibility of space biomining for in-situ resource utilization on the Moon, Mars, and asteroids, focusing on extracting essential elements and molecules for establishing self-sufficient settlements.
methodology: Review and analysis of existing literature and space experiments, including BioRock and BioAsteroid, to assess the potential of microbial-based biotechnologies for extracting resources from extraterrestrial regolith and rocks. Consideration of various factors influencing biomining, such as space conditions, rock types, and microbial metabolisms.
results: Demonstrated the feasibility of biomining in space using heterotrophic microorganisms and basalt or meteorite substrates. Showed that space microbial biotechnologies, including biomining, could be indifferent to gravitational conditions. Identified elements of high interest for space biomining, including water, oxygen, essential mineral nutrients, structural metals, and elements useful for electronic devices.
conclusions: Space biomining holds promise for achieving independence from terrestrial resources and enabling sustainable exploration and settlement of space. However, further research is needed to understand the effects of space conditions on biomining and bioremediation, expand knowledge on organotrophic and community-based bioleaching mechanisms, and investigate the use of synthetic biology to overcome limitations.
relationships: Space biomining can be integrated with Biological Life-Support Systems (BLSS) to supply basic chemical requirements and recycle waste materials. Consortia of microorganisms, including heterotrophic biomining microorganisms and cyanobacteria, can be used to produce organic compounds and oxygen for growth and organic acid production.
insights: Careful selection of biomining mechanisms and microorganisms is needed when planning for space applications, considering factors such as rock composition, atmosphere, pressure, gravity, and temperature. Bioengineering and synthetic biology approaches can enhance microbial resistance to toxic compounds and improve metal extraction.

title: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in spaceflight is minimized on lubricant impregnated surfaces.
objective: To characterize growth dynamics, phenotypic changes, and antibiotic sensitivity of Escherichia coli strains under simulated micro-, lunar, and Martian gravities.
methodology: Inclined clinostats were used to simulate different gravitational conditions. Three E. coli strains were cultured in specific media and exposed to antibiotics. Growth dynamics, cell size, aggregation, and minimum inhibitory concentrations (MIC) were measured.
results: Growth dynamics varied depending on the strain and gravitational condition.  Simulated microgravity often resulted in increased growth and altered cell size.  Antibiotic sensitivity also varied, with some strains showing increased resistance under certain simulated gravity conditions.
conclusions: Simulated reduced gravity environments can alter bacterial growth, phenotype, and antibiotic sensitivity. These findings suggest potential implications for astronaut health during space missions, particularly regarding urinary tract infections.
relationships: Motility appears to correlate with lag phase duration.  Non-motile strains showed reduced growth in simulated microgravity, while motile strains showed increased growth.  Lower concentrations of Ciprofloxacin were needed to inhibit E. coli AMG1 growth under simulated reduced gravities with respect to the 1 g control.
insights: The study highlights the importance of understanding how altered gravity environments affect bacterial behavior.  Clinostats can be used to simulate some aspects of reduced gravity, but further validation is needed.  The observed changes in antibiotic sensitivity suggest that current treatment protocols may need to be adjusted for spaceflight conditions.

title: Competitive Growth Assay of Mutagenized Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Compatible With the International Space Station Veggie Plant Growth Chamber.
objective: To understand how Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms behave in microgravity and to test lubricant-impregnated surfaces (LIS) as a potential biofilm control strategy for spacecraft.
methodology: Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms were grown on stainless steel (SS316), passivated SS316 (pSS316), and LIS on the International Space Station (ISS) and on Earth (1g) for 1, 2, or 3 days. Biofilm morphology was analyzed using confocal microscopy, and gene expression was analyzed using RNA sequencing.
results: Biofilms grown in microgravity had significantly lower biomass, thickness, and surface area coverage compared to those grown on Earth. LIS strongly inhibited biofilm formation compared to SS316, and this effect was even greater in microgravity. Gene expression analysis revealed differences in virulence factors and stress responses between biofilms grown in microgravity and on Earth, and between biofilms grown on LIS and SS316.
conclusions: Microgravity reduces Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm formation. LIS is a promising option for spacecraft use to control biofilms, especially in microgravity. The thin layer of nucleic acids observed on LIS may contribute to attachment inhibition. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms behind biofilm inhibition on LIS and to assess the long-term effects of LIS on virulence and antimicrobial resistance.
relationships: LIS surfaces exhibit reduced biofilm formation in microgravity compared to stainless steel. Biofilm formation is affected by the presence of nucleic acids on LIS surfaces. Gene expression related to virulence factors is altered in microgravity and on LIS surfaces.
insights: LIS surfaces show promise for biofilm control in space environments. The presence of nucleic acids on LIS surfaces may play a role in biofilm inhibition. Microgravity conditions alter gene expression related to biofilm formation and virulence.

title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
objective: To develop methods for and verify the testing of genes required for Chlamydomonas growth in spaceflight conditions, using a competitive growth assay of mutagenized cells.
methodology: Batch culture protocol using commercial FEP tissue culture bags adapted to Veggie plant growth chambers on the ISS. Shortwave ultraviolet (UVC) light mutagenesis and full genome sequencing were used to detect new mutations in two microalgae strains (CC-5082 and CC-1883). Competitive growth assays were performed, and mutations were analyzed to identify genes under selection.
results: FEP tissue culture bags support robust microalgae growth. UVC mutagenesis induces DNA damage, primarily via errors in translesion synthesis and double-strand break repair.  Mutations in genes related to DNA repair, RNA processing, translation, cytoskeletal motors, kinases, and ABC transporters were identified as potentially important for adaptation to the culture system.
conclusions: The experiment validated a strategy for identifying genes required by Chlamydomonas during log phase growth in spaceflight. Commercial FEP tissue culture bags can be used for batch culture of microalgae. Cellular information processing genes are likely required for Chlamydomonas to adapt to batch culture in breathable plastic bags.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between microalgae growth, genetic mutations, and adaptation to spaceflight-like conditions within a closed culture system.
insights: Modifications of DNA repair, signal transduction, and metabolite transport may be needed to improve growth rates in spaceflight production systems.  The type of mutations induced by UVC light suggests the involvement of translesion synthesis and double-strand break repair mechanisms.

title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
objective: To characterize and compare the bioburden and composition of microbial communities within Veggie plant growth units on the ISS, including plant tissues, roots, Veggie facility surfaces, and plant pillow materials.
methodology: Culture-based and culture-independent methods (16S rRNA amplicon sequencing) were used to identify bacteria and fungi in red romaine lettuce, mizuna mustard, and green leaf lettuce grown in Veggie systems on the ISS. Samples were collected from leaves, roots, plant pillows, and Veggie facility surfaces. Microbial counts, diversity analysis, and community characterization were performed.
results: Leafy greens were safe for consumption based on pathogen screening. Microbial diversity was higher in roots and rooting substrate than in leaves. Dominant bacterial genera included Burkholderia, Pseudomonas, and Staphylococcus. Fungal genera included Aspergillus, Fusarium, Penicillium, and Rhodotorula. Microbial communities varied between plant species and Veggie growth chamber components.
conclusions: The study demonstrated simultaneous multi-species leafy green growth on the ISS and characterized the influence of plant and root-associated microbial communities. The microbial communities in Veggie are influenced by factors such as plant species, growth environment, and interactions with the ISS environment. Understanding these microbial dynamics is crucial for ensuring food safety and developing sustainable crop production systems for space exploration.
relationships: The phyllosphere and rhizosphere microbial communities are influenced by plant species, growth substrate, and the surrounding environment (ISS). There is potential for microbial transfer between plant tissues, growth substrates, and Veggie facility surfaces. Human interaction and the ISS environment contribute to the microbial composition of the Veggie system.
insights: The Veggie plant growth units on the ISS provide a platform for growing leafy greens for astronaut consumption. Understanding the microbial dynamics within these systems is crucial for ensuring food safety and developing sustainable crop production systems for space exploration missions. Monitoring and controlling external contamination sources, such as irrigation water, air, and human handling, is essential. Strategies such as introducing beneficial microbes to enhance plant growth and prevent pathogen invaders may need to be evaluated.

title: Editorial: Revisiting the limits of plant life - plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments relating to astrobiology and space biology.
objective: To evaluate the effect of simulated space radiation (GCR and SPE protons) on dry and hydrated seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana and Mizuna mustard.
methodology: Seeds were exposed to simulated GCR and SPE radiation at the NASA Space Radiation Laboratory (NSRL). Irradiated and control seeds were planted in phytogel and grown in a controlled environment. Morphological parameters were measured after 5-7 days to evaluate radiation-induced damage.
results: Hydrated Arabidopsis seeds showed dose- and quality-dependent responses to charged particles, with heavier ions causing more severe defects. Seeds exposed to simulated GCR (dry seeds) and SPE (hydrated seeds) had less damage than seeds exposed to heavier particles. The extent of damage depended on the seed type. Mizuna seeds showed increased abnormality rates in seedlings developed from both GCR2 and SPE irradiated dry seeds.
conclusions: Space radiation impacts plant seeds, with the severity depending on dose, dose rate, radiation quality, and seed type. Hydrated seeds are more sensitive than dry seeds. The effects observed in Arabidopsis may not be directly transferable to other crop species, highlighting the need to study relevant space crops.
relationships: Heavier ions cause more severe damage. Hydrated seeds are more sensitive to radiation exposure than dry seeds. The extent of damage depends on the seed type.
insights: Ground-based simulation of GCR and SPE has an impact on Arabidopsis and Mizuna seeds. Space radiation exposures affect both dry and imbibed seeds. Further research is needed to understand the cellular and molecular mechanisms behind these findings, including DNA damage and repair responses.

title: Metagenomic interrogation of urban Superfund site reveals antimicrobial resistance reservoir and bioremediation potential.
objective: To explore plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments in relation to astrobiology and space biology, and to identify valuable adaptive mechanisms for genetically engineering space food plants.
methodology: Review of existing research and experimental studies focusing on plants in extreme environments, including simulated deep space environments. Analysis of plant responses to cosmic ionizing radiation, varying growth mediums, and different light spectrums.
results: Plants exhibit remarkable resistance to high radioactivity and can be used for shielding or pharmaceutical countermeasures. Co-culturing crops with endophytic fungi from extreme environments enhances plant performance under simulated deep space conditions. Seedling emergence is promoted by high porosity and low compactness of the growth medium. Cyanobacteria can acclimate to the light spectrum of M-dwarf stars and maintain photosynthetic activity.
conclusions: Plants possess diverse adaptive mechanisms that enable survival in harsh environments, making them essential for deep space missions and the search for extraterrestrial life. Understanding these adaptations can inform the selection and genetic engineering of plants for space exploration.
relationships: The study explores the symbiotic relationships between plants and fungi, and the impact of environmental factors such as radiation, gravity, and light spectrum on plant growth and survival.
insights: Terrestrial plants from extreme environments define the limits for terrestrial life and can guide the search for life beyond Earth. Plant scientists' knowledge and ideas are crucial for deploying plants to perform mission-critical functions in space.

title: In situ monitoring of barrier function on-chip via automated, non-invasive luminescence sensing.
objective: To investigate the bioremediation potential of the microbiome of the Gowanus Canal, a Superfund site, focusing on its ability to degrade contaminants, map antimicrobial resistance (AMR), and mitigate heavy metals.
methodology: Metagenomic analysis of Gowanus Canal sediment, including longitudinal and depth-based studies. DNA extraction, sequencing, and bioinformatic analysis were performed to characterize species diversity, assess bioremediation potential, and discover novel biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs).
results: The microbiome includes 455 species, encoding 64 metabolic pathways related to organic contaminant degradation and 1171 genes related to heavy metal utilization and detoxification. An environmental reservoir of antimicrobial resistance markers falling within 8 different classes of resistance was identified, along with 2319 biosynthetic gene clusters and diverse groups of secondary metabolites.
conclusions: The microbiome of the Gowanus Canal is a biotechnological resource of novel metabolic functions that could aid in efforts for bioremediation, AMR reservoir mapping, and heavy metal mitigation. The co-occurrence of ARGs and bioremediation metabolisms suggests a need to study the impact of industrial contaminants on the persistence of antimicrobial resistance genes in environmental reservoirs.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between the canal's microbiome and its contaminated environment, influenced by industrial waste, runoff, sewage overflows, and tidal influx. It also reveals the presence of species associated with the human gut, reflecting sewage inputs.
insights: The Gowanus Canal, despite being a Superfund site, harbors a thriving microbial community with potential for biotechnological applications. These microbes possess bioremediation functions, degrade complex hydrocarbons, fix heavy metals, and produce novel secondary metabolites. The study suggests redefining our relationship with these lifeforms and considering the ethics of interventions on non-human organisms.

title: 37-day microgravity exposure in 16-week female C57BL/6J mice is associated with bone loss specific to weight-bearing skeletal sites.
objective: To provide a detailed assembly and operational guide for a fiber photometry platform used for real-time, non-invasive barrier function sensing on-chip.
methodology: The platform utilizes LEDs, optical filters, fiber optic cables, and CMOS cameras. The assembly process involves connecting optical components in a specific sequence, aligning the beam path, and using an Arduino microcontroller for automated light delivery and image capture. Data is normalized by subtracting control values from experimental data and adjusting to a baseline.
results: The platform enables independent readout of apical and basal flow compartments. The system allows for dual-color sensing on-chip, with emitted light from each fluorophore directed to independent CMOS cameras. The distribution of light intensity across sensing fibers was measured. Relative fluorescence was measured at known concentrations of lucifer yellow.
conclusions: The described fiber photometry system provides a functional platform for real-time, non-invasive optical sensing on-chip, suitable for monitoring barrier function and other biological processes.
relationships: The system allows for the study of relationships between different experimental conditions and the measured fluorescence signals, reflecting changes in barrier function or other cellular activities.
insights: The platform offers insights into dynamic biological processes by enabling continuous monitoring of fluorescence signals, allowing researchers to observe real-time changes and responses to stimuli.

title: Effects of Space Flight on Inflammasome Activation in the Brain of Mice.
objective: To test the hypothesis that bone loss during spaceflight in Low Earth Orbit is primarily associated with site-specific microgravity unloading of weight-bearing sites in the skeleton.
methodology: Microcomputed tomography and histological analyses of bones from female C57BL/6J mice space flown on ISS for 37 days in the NASA Rodent Research-1 experiment. Ground controls were housed in standard vivarium cages and Rodent Habitats.
results: Significant site-specific cancellous and cortical bone loss occurred in the femur, but not in L2 vertebrae. Spaceflight is associated with accelerated progression of femoral head endochondral ossification. Mice housed in the NASA ISS Rodent Habitat during 1g ground controls maintained or gained bone relative to mice housed in standard vivarium cages.
conclusions: Mechanical unloading of weight-bearing sites is the major cause of bone loss in microgravity in female mice approaching skeletal maturity. Early-onset of femoral head epiphyseal plate secondary ossification is a novel spaceflight skeletal unloading effect that may lead to premature long bone growth arrest in microgravity.
relationships: Bone loss in the weight-bearing femoral head and distal epiphysis cancellous bone regions depends on housing type and spaceflight in microgravity. Long bone cortical tissues undergo degenerative changes in space. Load-bearing vertebrae do not show μCT parameter changes related to age, housing, or spaceflight in microgravity. Decreased mechanical loading during spaceflight in microgravity only causes significant bone loss in weight-bearing skeletal sites. Secondary endochondral ossification is accelerated during spaceflight in microgravity.
insights: Spaceflight-induced bone loss is localized to direct weight-bearing skeletal locations in the femoral head and distal epiphyses. The absence of significant bone loss in the L2 lumbar vertebra after 37 days of spaceflight is consistent with previous scans. Increased activity and microgravity have opposite effects on bone health parameters only at specific locations within weight-bearing bone and no significant effects in bones primarily loaded by muscle tension, as long as the habitat used, such as RH, is permissive of physical activity in space. Mechanical unloading due to weightlessness in microgravity, not radiation or other systemic factors, is the primary effector of spaceflight-related bone loss in LEO.

title: Immunization induces inflammation in the mouse heart during spaceflight.
objective: To determine the levels of inflammasome activation in the brains of mice that were housed in the International Space Station (ISS) for 37 days.
methodology: C57BL/6 mice were launched to the ISS as part of NASA’s Rodent Research 1 Mission. Dissected mouse brains were analyzed by immunoblotting of inflammasome signaling proteins and Electrochemiluminescence Immunoassay (ECLIA) for inflammatory cytokine levels. Ground control and baseline groups were used for comparison. Statistical analyses included t-tests and Mann-Whitney tests.
results: Data indicate decreased inflammasome activation (caspase-1, ASC, IL-1β) in the brains of mice housed in the ISS compared to ground control. No significant changes were detected in the expression levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines TNF-α, IL-2, IFN-γ, IL-5, IL-6, IL-12p70 and IL-10 between the ground control and the flight groups.
conclusions: Spaceflight results in a decrease in the levels of innate immune signaling molecules that govern inflammasome signaling in the brain of mice. The innate immune response mediated by the inflammasome is not weakened by space flight, but it does not develop as it normally does on Earth.
relationships: Space flight exposes astronauts to stressors that alter the immune response. Inflammasomes play a significant role in the regulation of the inflammatory response. Space radiation affects hippocampus-dependent cognitive tasks.
insights: Conditions experienced during a mission to low Earth orbit result in a significant decrease in levels of inflammasome proteins in the brain. The decrease in inflammasome signaling proteins after spaceflight may be the result of a protective attempt to dampen the innate immune response in the brain following the stress experienced in space in the ISS.

title: Analyzing the relationship between gene expression and phenotype in space-flown mice using a causal inference machine learning ensemble.
objective: To investigate the impact of immunization during spaceflight on the mouse heart transcriptome and identify potential inflammatory responses.
methodology: RNA-seq analysis was performed on heart tissue from space-flown mice immunized with tetanus toxoid and CpG adjuvant, compared to saline controls. RT-qPCR was used to validate transcriptomic findings. Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) and Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) were used to analyze pathway activation and biological function changes.
results: Immunization during spaceflight induced significant transcriptomic changes in the heart, including upregulation of inflammatory and immune response genes. NF-κB signaling pathway was activated, leading to increased expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IFNγ, IL-17, and IL-6. Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and receptors for interleukins were also upregulated. Cytoskeletal rearrangement transcripts were induced, and transcripts protecting the heart from oxidative stress were elevated.
conclusions: Spaceflight environment, combined with immunization, can induce inflammation and cytoskeletal remodeling in the mouse heart. Protective transcripts are also induced to reduce oxidative stress. These findings provide insights into the cardiovascular response to immune challenges in space.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between spaceflight, immunization, and cardiac inflammation. It suggests that the spaceflight environment exacerbates the inflammatory response to vaccination in the heart. The activation of NF-κB and the upregulation of pro-inflammatory cytokines are key components of this relationship.
insights: The study reveals that immunization in space can lead to cardiac inflammation, potentially increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease in astronauts. The activation of NF-κB and the induction of pro-inflammatory cytokines are important factors in this process. The induction of protective transcripts suggests a potential mechanism for maintaining homeostasis in the cardiac environment.

title: Sex-specific cardiovascular adaptations to simulated microgravity in Sprague-Dawley rats
objective: To identify genes robustly correlated with a lipid density phenotype in space-flown mice liver tissue using a machine learning ensemble of causal inference methods (CRISP).
methodology: Using transcriptomic and histological data from the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR), CRISP was used to identify genes potentially causal of a high lipid density phenotype in space-flown mice liver tissue. Data preprocessing included binarizing the target variable (ORO positivity), data augmentation via multiple transformations (Log scale, Square root, Median of ratios, Centered log ratio, Box-Cox, Z-score), and accounting for technical batch effects (library preparation). The CRISP ensemble consists of Invariant Causal Prediction (ICP) and Invariant Risk Minimization (IRM) algorithms. Results were validated using gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA), pathway analysis (ShinyGO), and the Scalable Precision Medicine Open Knowledge Engine (SPOKE).
results: CRISP identified a biologically relevant set of genes uniquely predictive of a high lipid density response in space-flown mice. Mup11 gene was found in the top genes most predictive of lipid density in all models. Gene set enrichment and pathway analyses revealed that the dysfunctional regulation of the genes identified by CRISP is implicated in the spectrum of diseases caused by non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
conclusions: The CRISP platform identified a set of genes predictive of high and low lipid density, significantly associated with gene sets and genetic pathways consistent with NAFLD or similar liver dysfunction. The use of data augmentation and environment invariance modeling approach is crucial for identifying robust correlations. The identified genes constitute potential biomarkers of NAFLD for targeted monitoring or therapeutics development.
relationships: Identified genes (Apoc1, Apoc3, Cyp2e1, Fasn, Scd1, Star, Apoe) are linked to lipid metabolism and NAFLD. Overexpression of Apoc1 and Apoc3 may lead to hyperlipidemia and NAFLD-like features. Cyp2e1 is implicated in the development of NASH. Fasn inhibition reduces triglyceride content and markers of fibrosis and inflammation. Scd1 causes excessive lipid accumulation and promotes progression of NAFLD. Star overexpression reduces hepatic lipid accumulation.
insights: Spaceflight induces significant changes in gene expression profiles related to lipid metabolism in the liver, even after short-term exposure. Machine learning methods, particularly those employing causal inference and data augmentation, can effectively identify key genes and pathways involved in spaceflight-induced liver dysfunction. The identified genes represent potential therapeutic targets for mitigating the adverse effects of spaceflight on liver health.

title: NASA open science data repository: Open science for life in space.
objective: To investigate sex-specific mechanisms of aortic stiffening in male and female Sprague Dawley rats exposed to simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading - HLU) for 14 days.
methodology: 20-week-old male and female Sprague Dawley rats were subjected to 14 days of hindlimb unloading (HLU) to simulate microgravity. Aortic pulse wave velocity (PWV) was measured to assess arterial stiffness. Aortic tissue samples were analyzed for smooth muscle actin, myosin, collagen, elastin, GPER, PPARγ, oxidative stress markers (8-OHdG, p47phox), and inflammatory markers (COX-2, eNOS, CD68). A subset of HLU females were treated with the GPER agonist G1. Body composition was assessed using EchoMRI. Statistical analyses included ANOVA and DCS analysis.
results: HLU increased aortic PWV in females but not males. HLU females showed lower aortic GPER and PPARγ, increased oxidative stress markers, and diastolic dysfunction compared to controls. G1 treatment prevented the increase in PWV and 8-OHdG in HLU females. Male rats exposed to HLU had lower heart weight compared to the male control group. Multivariate data analysis revealed sex differences in relationships between oxidative stress markers, ECM characteristics, and arterial stiffness.
conclusions: Female Sprague Dawley rats exhibit greater arterial stiffness in response to simulated microgravity compared to males. This is associated with lower aortic GPER and PPARγ, and increased oxidative stress. GPER activation reverses HLU-induced arterial stiffening in females, suggesting a protective role. The SD female rat is a suitable model to study mechanisms underlying the development of arterial stiffness in females in response to simulated microgravity.
relationships: The study highlights sex-specific vascular adaptations to simulated microgravity. It identifies GPER as a potential therapeutic target for preventing arterial stiffening in females exposed to spaceflight conditions. The multivariate analysis reveals complex relationships between body composition, arterial stiffness, oxidative stress, and ECM components, suggesting potential targets for countermeasures against spaceflight-induced cardiovascular changes.

title: Artificial gravity attenuates the transcriptomic response to spaceflight in the optic nerve and retina
objective: To describe the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) database architecture and features that enable the submission, hosting, retrieval, and analysis of diverse data types from spaceflight and analog missions, promoting open science principles.
methodology: Review of the new OSDR database architecture, the Biological Data Management Environment (BDME), controlled data access features, GeneLab Sample Processing Laboratory (SPL) capabilities, metadata standards, search functionalities, API, and visualization tools. Analysis Working Groups (AWGs) and training initiatives are also discussed.
results: The OSDR houses over 500 studies, including close to 1000 spaceflight or space-analog datasets, with data from over 80 different assays. It has enabled 92 publications, representing an 88% return on investment. The BDME streamlines data submission, and the OSDR offers expanded search features and an enhanced API. Visualization tools and training programs enhance data accessibility and engagement.
conclusions: OSDR serves as a central community hub for global space life sciences data, promoting FAIR principles and engagement. It facilitates broader public access to life science and biomedical data, empowering the global community to actively engage in space exploration and discovery, aligning with NASA’s goals for the ‘Moon to Mars’ and Artemis campaigns.
relationships: The OSDR integrates data from NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and GeneLab. It collaborates with the European Space Agency (ESA) and commercial space sectors. It partners with AWS for cloud access and UC San Francisco for knowledge graph analysis. It also works with the Department of Energy to create the NASA EDGE Bioinformatics platform.
insights: Open science in space biology and aerospace medicine is essential for developing health countermeasures and conducting space biological research. Centralizing and standardizing data, along with strategic tissue reuse, maximizes the value extracted from available data and tissues. OSDR's expansion and community engagement are key to advancing spaceflight science.

title: Effect of simulated cosmic radiation on cytomegalovirus reactivation and lytic replication.
objective: To investigate the inhibitory activity of native PpFucCS and its low molecular weight (LMW) fractions against Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV) entry into cells, and to establish a structural activity relationship and the influence of MW distribution on its anti-viral activity against HCMV.
methodology: Human foreskin fibroblasts (HFF) were infected with HCMV in the presence of PpFucCS and its LMW fractions. Virus yield was assessed. Virus attachment and entry were visualized using R18 labeling. IC50 assays and virus yield reduction assays were performed. Cell viability was assessed using trypan blue exclusion and ATP release assays.
results: Native PpFucCS exhibited potent inhibitory activity against HCMV, specifically blocking virus entry. LMW PpFucCS fractions showed decreased activity proportional to their chain lengths. PpFucCS and derived oligosaccharides did not exhibit significant cytotoxicity and protected infected cells from virus-induced lytic cell death. The inhibitory properties of PpFucCS against HCMV do not depend on the MOI.
conclusions: PpFucCS inhibits the entry of HCMV into cells, and a high MW of this carbohydrate is a key structural element to achieve the maximal anti-viral effect. PpFucCS is a promising candidate for further evaluation and development as a potential antiviral agent against HCMV infection.
relationships: PpFucCS targets HS–virus interactions, preventing HCMV entry. The inhibitory activities of the LMW PpFucCS derivatives were proportional to their chain lengths. The native high MW structure is necessary to achieve maximum HMCV inhibition.
insights: Marine sulfated glycan Pp-FucCS demonstrates antiviral activities against HCMV. A native PpFucCS structure with a large MW is essential for achieving the greatest anti-HCMV activity. The retained effective inhibitory potential of high MW structures derived from PpFucCS suggests this marine glycan is a promising candidate for further evaluation and development as a potential antiviral.

title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function.
objective: To identify and characterize the skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans and investigate its role in cuticle protection.
methodology: Microbiological methods combined with a micro skin-swabbing tool were used to describe skin-resident bacteria. 16S rRNA gene sequencing was conducted to identify shifts in the proportion of mCeMbio bacteria upon surface-sterilization. Colony-forming unit (CFU) assays were performed to assess surface-adherent microbes. A cuticle resistance assay was used to test the protective effects of bacteria against a harsh bleach solution.
results: C. elegans harbors a skin microbiome distinct from its gut microbiome. Enterobacter sp. JUb101 is primarily found on the nematode skin, while Stenotrophomonas indicatrix JUb19 and Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71 are predominantly found in the animal’s gut. The skin microbiome promotes host cuticle integrity in harsh environments. Surface sterilization alters the relative proportion of mCeMbio bacteria.
conclusions: C. elegans possesses a skin-resident microbiome that contributes to cuticle integrity and host fitness. The composition of this microbiome differs from the gut microbiome and the surrounding environment. Specific bacterial species exhibit varying degrees of attachment to the cuticle, influencing their protective capabilities.
relationships: The study explores the relationship between C. elegans, its skin microbiome, and environmental stressors. It highlights the interactions between different bacterial species within the microbiome and their combined effect on host cuticle protection. The research also investigates the impact of specific bacterial strains on cuticle integrity in wild-type and mutant C. elegans.
insights: The discovery of a skin microbiome in C. elegans provides a new avenue for understanding host-microbe interactions. The study reveals that ecologically relevant bacterial communities play a crucial role in protecting the host from environmental stressors. The findings suggest that C. elegans can serve as a valuable model for skin research and for studying the complex dynamics of host-microbiome interactions.

title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: Spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants.
objective: To review published alleles naturally found in human cohorts that have a likely protective effect, linked to decreased cancer risk and improved bone, muscular, and cardiovascular health, and to explore how these protective mechanisms could translate into improved nutrition, exercise, and health recommendations for crew members during deep space missions.
methodology: Review of published literature on human alleles with protective effects, focusing on studies of human cohorts (individuals, families, isolated populations, and populations adapted to extreme environments). Analysis of omics technologies and their potential for improving health countermeasures in space.
results: Identified alleles linked to health-protective effects, including those related to radiation tolerance (TP53), hematopoiesis (EPOR), bone density (LRP5), and immune function (HLA alleles and cytokines). Growing evidence indicates that spaceflight can elicit stressful and adaptive physiological responses, impacting various systems and increasing risks of cancer, diabetes, and aging traits.
conclusions: Omics-based recommendations can be integrated alongside other countermeasures to sustain human health in space. Basic research into the protective mechanisms of identified alleles may translate into improved therapeutic compound discovery and better-informed nutrition, exercise, and lifestyle recommendations for space explorers and those in challenging conditions on Earth. Ethical considerations and technical challenges need to be addressed for safe and effective implementation.
relationships: Identified relationships between specific alleles and protective mechanisms related to bone health (LRP5, SOST), cardiovascular health (APOA1, PCSK9), muscle retention (MSTN, MAFBX, MURF1), oxygen regulation (EGLN1, EPAS1, EPOR), cancer risk (CDKN2A, TERT), and insulin resistance (GHR, SIRT1). Highlighted the potential for nutrition and exercise interventions to target these pathways.
insights: Spaceflight poses unique health risks, including radiation exposure and microgravity-induced bone demineralization. Precision healthcare, guided by molecular data, can improve therapy and mission recommendations. Studying human adaptation to extreme environments and isolated populations can reveal alleles with health implications applicable to spaceflight. Pharmacogenomics can optimize drug prescribing in space to enhance astronaut safety and performance.

title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis.
objective: To characterize novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and assess their prevalence in ISS metagenomes. This includes establishing six strains as novel species through chemotaxonomic, phenotypic, physiological, and phylogenetic analyses, quantifying their abundance in ISS metagenomes, attempting to generate metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs), and analyzing secondary metabolite biosynthesis gene clusters (BGCs).
methodology: Sample collection from ISS surfaces, followed by bacterial isolation and cultivation. Characterization involved whole-genome sequencing (WGS), 16S rRNA gene sequencing, Average Nucleotide Identity (ANI) and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) analyses, phylogenetic analysis, phenotypic characterization (biochemical tests, fatty acid profiling, polar lipid analysis), metagenomic read mapping, and genome annotation using RAST and antiSMASH.
results: Six strains were identified as five novel bacterial species: Arthrobacter burdickii, Leifsonia virtsii, Leifsonia williamsii, Paenibacillus vandeheii, and Sporosarcina highlanderae. Genomic analysis revealed unique characteristics for each species, including varying GC content, gene numbers, and phylogenetic placements. Metagenomic analysis showed low abundance of these species on the ISS. Functional annotation identified genes related to amino acid metabolism, carbohydrate metabolism, virulence, antibiotic resistance, and secondary metabolite production.
conclusions: The study successfully identified and characterized five novel bacterial species from the ISS, expanding the genomic database of space-relevant microbes. These species exhibit unique genomic and phenotypic traits, including potential for antibiotic resistance and secondary metabolite production. Their low abundance in ISS metagenomes suggests they are rare members of the ISS microbiome. Further research is needed to understand their roles in the ISS environment and their potential impact on astronaut health and spacecraft systems.
relationships: The study explores the phylogenetic relationships of the novel species with closely related bacteria, revealing that 16S rRNA gene sequencing alone is insufficient for accurate species identification. Whole-genome sequencing and comparative genomics are necessary to resolve the taxonomic placement of these organisms. The study also investigates the interactions of these species with the ISS environment and their potential impact on human health and spacecraft systems.
insights: The findings highlight the importance of comprehensive genomic and phenotypic characterization for understanding the microbial diversity of the ISS. The discovery of antibiotic resistance genes and secondary metabolite biosynthesis gene clusters in these novel species raises concerns about potential risks and opportunities associated with the ISS microbiome. Further research is needed to assess the ecological roles of these species and their potential applications in biotechnology and space exploration.

title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA space life sciences data.
objective: To review the effects of microgravity and other spaceflight environmental factors on Homo sapiens and Mus musculus, based on microarray studies and experiments in the NASA GeneLab repository, determining affected functionalities at the gene, cellular, or organ levels.
methodology: The study involved a review and comparative meta-analysis of gene expression datasets from microarray studies in the NASA GeneLab repository. Data was analyzed from Mus musculus and Homo sapiens exposed to actual or simulated microgravity. Pearson correlation coefficients were computed for genes across experiments evaluating comparable factors. Gene Ontology functions were evaluated for significantly up and downregulated genes.
results: The review found that altered gravity conditions affect multiple physiological systems in both mice and humans, including musculoskeletal, immune, cardiovascular, vestibular, integumentary, and nervous systems. Specific effects include alterations in muscle metabolism, bone formation, immune response, and cell proliferation. Comparative analysis showed some overlap in differentially expressed genes within musculoskeletal tissues in each species, but limited overlap between species. Correlation analysis revealed higher coefficients between datasets studying subjects of the same sex under similar experimental conditions.
conclusions: Altered gravity environments induce various physiological changes in both mice and humans, impacting multiple systems and biological processes. While there is some reproducibility in gene expression changes within species, the limited overlap between species highlights the need for further research to understand the human response to altered gravity. The study emphasizes the importance of comprehensive data analysis and the consideration of factors such as sex and experimental conditions in interpreting gene expression results.
relationships: The study highlights the relationships between altered gravity and various physiological systems, including musculoskeletal, immune, cardiovascular, vestibular, integumentary, and nervous systems. It also explores the relationships between gene expression patterns in different tissues and species under varying experimental conditions.
insights: The study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of altered gravity on mammalian physiology. It identifies key genes and biological processes that are affected by spaceflight conditions and highlights the importance of considering individual factors and experimental conditions in interpreting gene expression data. The findings contribute to a better understanding of the challenges of long-duration space missions and the development of effective countermeasures.

title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.
objective: To determine the similarities and differences between microbial communities and their growth under elevated moisture conditions in occupied spaces on Earth and the International Space Station (ISS).
methodology: Dust samples from ISS vacuum bags and Earth-based residential homes were collected and incubated under varying relative humidity (ERH) conditions (50%, 85%, and 100%). DNA was extracted, sequenced using Illumina MiSeq, and analyzed using the QIIME2 bioinformatics pipeline to identify fungal and bacterial taxonomy. Statistical analyses were performed to compare microbial diversity and abundance between the two locations.
results: Fungal and bacterial communities differed significantly between Earth and ISS dust. Earth samples showed higher diversity compared to ISS samples. Under elevated moisture conditions, fungal communities in ISS dust changed more rapidly, with Aspergillus becoming dominant. Bacterial communities also differed, with specific families being more abundant in each location. Elevated moisture led to clear differences in bacterial communities at 100% ERH.
conclusions: The microbiome of dust from Earth is more diverse than that of the ISS. These community differences result in changes in microbial growth upon exposure to moisture. Understanding these differences is important for maintaining a healthy indoor microbiome on spacecraft, promoting crew health, spacecraft integrity, and planetary protection, especially with the advent of commercial space stations and increased human activity in space.
relationships: The study highlights the relationship between moisture levels and microbial growth, and how environmental factors in space versus Earth influence microbial community composition. It also suggests a link between microbial diversity and potential health impacts.
insights: Microbial communities in the ISS are less diverse and more susceptible to changes in moisture conditions compared to Earth-based environments. This suggests that controlling moisture and understanding microbial responses are crucial for maintaining healthy indoor environments in spacecraft.

title: Spaceflight alters host-gut microbiota interactions.
objective: To correct the author byline and affiliation line in the original publication regarding microbiome metadata standards.
methodology: This is a correction notice, so the methodology involves reviewing and correcting the original publication's metadata.
results: The corrected author byline and affiliation line are provided.
conclusions: The correction ensures accurate attribution and contact information for the original research.
relationships: This correction relates to the original publication on microbiome metadata standards and the National Microbiome Data Collaborative's workshop.
insights: Accurate metadata is crucial for proper attribution and reproducibility in microbiome research.

title: Discoveries from human stem cell research in space that are relevant to advancing cellular therapies on Earth.
objective: To explore murine gut microbiota and host gene expression in the colon and liver after 29 and 56 days of spaceflight using multiomics, in order to understand host-microbiota interactions during spaceflight.
methodology: Species-resolved 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing and de novo co-assembled WMS were employed to capture metagenomic changes in the murine gut microbiome associated with spaceflight. Intestinal and hepatic transcriptomics were then used to assess the associated gene expression response of mice to spaceflight. Four treatment groups from a single cohort of 32 weeks-old female mice were used: FLT_LAR, FLT_ISS, GC_LAR and GC_ISS.
results: Spaceflight increased total body weight in mice. Metagenomics revealed significant changes in microbiome species, including relative reductions in bile acid and butyrate metabolizing bacteria. Functional prediction indicated over-representation of fatty acid and bile acid metabolism, extracellular matrix interactions, and antibiotic resistance genes. Host gene expression described corresponding changes to bile acid and energy metabolism, and immune suppression. Differential abundance analysis of amplicon data identified 45 ESVs that were significantly different in relative abundance between spaceflight and ground control mice. Differential abundance analysis of WMS identified 13,996 contigs that were significantly different in relative abundance between spaceflight and ground control mice.
conclusions: Host-gut microbiome interactions during spaceflight are likely to underlie widespread changes to host physiology which could pose a risk to health. Spaceflight-associated changes in bacteria linked to bile and fatty acid metabolism were identified. The microbiome changes coincided with substantial changes to gene expression at the host-gut microbiome interface which are critical to barrier function, microbe interactions and bile acid transport in the intestine. These interactions suggest disruption of the signals, metabolites, and immune factors exchanged across the gut-liver axis which are likely to drive glucose and lipid dysregulation.
relationships: Spaceflight-associated pathologies, notably disrupted glucose metabolism characterized by insulin resistance and lipid metabolism dysregulation, pose significant risks to astronaut health. Gut microbiota play an essential role in mediating healthy human metabolic function on Earth. Changes in the gut microbiome can influence lipid and bile acid homeostasis, and the immune system of the murine host.
insights: Spaceflight induces changes in gut microbiota composition and function, leading to alterations in host metabolism and immune function. These changes may contribute to spaceflight-associated health risks, such as insulin resistance, lipid dysregulation, and immune suppression. The gut-liver axis is significantly disrupted during spaceflight, potentially driving glucose and lipid dysregulation.

title: Simulated microgravity impairs human NK [natural killer] cell cytotoxic activity against space radiation-relevant leukemic cells.
objective: To investigate the response of the snail gravisensing system to space mission conditions, focusing on the effects of microgravity on statocyst function.
methodology: Exposure of terrestrial snails (Helix lucorum and Helix aspersa) to microgravity during unmanned orbital missions (Foton M-2 and M-3). Assessment of whole-animal behavior (negative gravitaxis), statoreceptor responses to tilt (electrophysiology), and gene expression (HPep and FMRFamide) in neural structures after return to Earth.
results: Postflight snails exhibited enhanced negative gravitaxis response (faster re-orientation). Statoreceptor responses to tilt were independent of motion direction, with increased sensitivity to acceleration. mRNA expression of HPep, linked to ciliary beating, increased in statoreceptors. FMRFamide expression showed no significant difference.
conclusions: Microgravity exposure upregulates statocyst function in snails, paralleling observations in vertebrates. This suggests fundamental principles underlie gravi-sensing and adaptation to gravity changes. The snail model offers insights into subcellular mechanisms of the nervous system's response to conditions on Earth and in space.
relationships: The study draws parallels between the snail statocyst system and vertebrate vestibular systems, highlighting similarities in gravi-sensing mechanisms and responses to microgravity. It also explores the relationship between gene expression (HPep) and statocyst function.
insights: Microgravity induces functional changes in the snail statocyst system, including enhanced sensitivity to tilt and altered gene expression. These changes suggest an adaptive response to the altered gravitational environment, providing insights into the fundamental mechanisms of gravi-sensing and adaptation in living organisms.

title: Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease.
objective: To evaluate the potential of dried plum (DP) supplementation to protect against bone loss induced by simulated microgravity and ionizing radiation, independently and in combination.
methodology: Male mice were subjected to hindlimb unloading (HU) to simulate microgravity and/or exposed to ionizing radiation (IR). They were fed either a control diet (CD) or a DP-supplemented diet. Bone microarchitecture and mechanical properties were assessed using micro-computed tomography (microCT) and compression testing. Osteoblastogenesis was also evaluated.
results: In mice fed the CD diet, HU and IR, alone or combined, led to bone loss in the tibia and vertebrae. DP supplementation prevented most of these detrimental effects. DP protected against decreases in bone volume, trabecular thickness, and cortical thickness. DP also improved vertebral stiffness and protected osteoblast progenitor cells from HU-induced damage.
conclusions: Dietary supplementation with dried plum can be an effective countermeasure against bone loss induced by simulated spaceflight conditions, including microgravity and ionizing radiation. DP protects bone microarchitecture, mechanical properties, and osteoblast function.
relationships: Simulated microgravity and ionizing radiation induce bone loss. Dried plum supplementation mitigates these effects. DP may act by quenching ROS, decreasing pro-inflammatory signaling, and promoting osteoblast activity.
insights: Dried plum shows promise as a nutritional countermeasure for bone loss in astronauts during spaceflight and potentially for individuals with osteoporosis or those undergoing radiation therapy. Further research is needed to determine the long-term effects and optimal formulations of DP.

title: Environmental dependence of competitive fitness in rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis.
objective: To review eukaryotic mechanosensing and mechanotransduction in microgravity, observe prokaryotic analogs, update evidence of prokaryotic mechanosensing, and propose a mechanotransduction model for prokaryotes.
methodology: Literature review and hypothesis development, drawing parallels between eukaryotic and prokaryotic mechanotransduction mechanisms.
results: The review highlights the current understanding of eukaryotic mechanotransduction and identifies analogous structures and mechanisms in prokaryotes. It proposes a model for how mechanical signals may be transduced to the gene expression apparatus in prokaryotes.
conclusions: Prokaryotes possess complex intracellular structures and signal transduction networks comparable to eukaryotes. The prokaryotic cytoskeleton may play a key role in transducing mechanical changes to the nucleoid, altering its architecture and the global transcriptional apparatus. Further experiments in space are needed to test this hypothesis.
relationships: Explores the relationship between mechanical forces, cellular structures, and gene expression in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes, particularly in the context of microgravity.
insights: Microgravity can influence gene expression in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes. Prokaryotes possess mechanosensing and mechanotransduction mechanisms analogous to those in eukaryotes. DNA supercoiling and epigenetic modifications are linked to nucleoid architecture and transcription in prokaryotes.

title:
Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools
for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses
to Spaceﬂight
objective: To maximize scientific output from a limited number of omics datasets from traditional animal models and to explore the utility of omics data from invertebrate models in anticipating mammalian responses to spaceflight.
methodology: Comparative analyses of transcriptomes of soleus and extensor digitorum longus (EDL) in mice that underwent 37 days of spaceflight. Comparison of transcriptomic data from the RR-1 quadriceps to the vastus lateralis from a human bed rest study, and transcriptomic data from the gastrocnemius from a different space flown mouse study to matching HU samples from that same study. Comparison of RR-1 EDL and soleus muscle datasets with transcriptomic datasets of C. elegans and D. melanogaster that were flown in the ICE-FIRST experiment and STS-121 mission, respectively. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) and overrepresentation analysis (ORA) were used.
results: Spaceflight leads to shared and discrete molecular responses between muscle types. Invertebrate models share select aspects of mammalian responses to spaceflight. The life stage of invertebrate models appears to impact the degree by which they recapitulate the responses of mammalian tissues to spaceflight. Spaceflight elicited both shared and discrete responses in representative slow and fast twitch muscle types (soleus and EDL respectively). The shared responses between these muscle types include altered expression of genes involved in GC stress responses and the circadian rhythm. These two muscle types displayed differences in transcriptomic signatures pertaining to immune function and cellular growth, with the EDL exhibiting a greater degree of differential regulation of these processes.
conclusions: Spaceflight elicits both shared and discrete responses in slow and fast twitch muscles. Invertebrate models show promise in anticipating select spaceflight responses of specific muscles. Rodents continue to have major advantages from a physiology perspective versus classic non-mammalian genetic model systems. The muscle specific Ubiquitin E ligase Fbxo40 was downregulated across models for muscle atrophy (bedrest and spaceflight), suggesting a possible target for countermeasures development.
relationships: Spaceflight and hindlimb unloading mice shared differential regulation of proliferation, circadian, and neuronal signaling. Shared gene regulation in muscles of humans on bedrest and space flown rodents suggest targets for mitigating muscle atrophy in space and on Earth. Spaceflight responses of C. elegans were more similar to EDL. Discrete life stages of D. melanogaster have distinct utility in anticipating EDL and soleus responses.
insights: Spaceflight results in discrete transcriptomic signatures between representative slow and fast twitch muscles (soleus and EDL respectively), consistent with their opposing roles in flexion and differential sensitivities to unloading. In addition, transcriptomic analysis revealed that invertebrate models share select aspects of mammalian responses to spaceflight. The life stage of invertebrate models appears to impact the degree by which they recapitulate the responses of mammalian tissues to spaceflight.

title: Reproducible changes in the gut microbiome suggest a shift in microbial and host metabolism during spaceflight.
objective: To determine how spaceflight affects the composition, structure, mechanics, and gene expression of the humerus-supraspinatus and calcaneus-Achilles entheses in mice.
methodology: Mice were sent to space on three separate missions (STS-131, STS-135, and Bion-M1). After spaceflight, the composition, structure, mechanics, and gene expression of the humerus-supraspinatus and calcaneus-Achilles entheses were examined using Raman spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), microcomputed tomography (µCT), mechanical testing, and quantitative RT-PCR.
results: Spaceflight resulted in decreased carbonate levels in bone mineral, a shift in collagen fibril size towards smaller diameters in tendons, and changes in gene expression related to osteoclastogenesis and collagen degradation. However, there were no significant changes in bone volume, trabecular structure, failure load, or stiffness with spaceflight.
conclusions: Spaceflight had significant effects on bone composition, tendon microstructure, and gene expression, but the tendon enthesis may be insensitive to short durations of spaceflight.
relationships: Spaceflight-induced changes at the nanoscale (mineral composition and collagen fibril diameters) and in gene expression did not translate into significant micro- and milliscale structural or mechanical changes in the tendon enthesis.
insights: The tendon enthesis appears to be relatively robust to spaceflight conditions, but longer durations of spaceflight may result in structural and mechanical changes driven by the observed early nanoscale and gene expression effects. Fluid redistribution in microgravity may increase local pressure in the upper extremities, potentially counteracting the effects of microgravity.

title: Simulated micro-, lunar, and Martian gravities on Earth‚Äîeffects on Escherichia coli growth, phenotype, and sensitivity to antibiotics.
objective: To find viable approaches to achieve independence from terrestrial resources by extracting structural metals, essential mineral nutrients, water, oxygen, and volatiles from extraterrestrial regolith and rocks using microbial-based biotechnologies.
methodology: Review of space biomining principles, feasibility, and possible applications, including limitations and the necessity to expand knowledge on organotrophic, cyanobacteria, and community-based bioleaching mechanisms.
results: Microbial-based biotechnologies and biomanufacturing approaches have demonstrated their high efficacy in several applications and may become a key component of future ISRU strategies. Growth, and in some cases bioleaching, of diverse microorganisms on extraterrestrial rocks or simulants have been demonstrated.
conclusions: Space biomining is generating increasing interest as the goal for space exploration expands toward establishing permanent settlements in space. Terrestrial biomining is considered a sustainable approach in both economic and environmental terms. The use of bioleaching microorganisms could also be applied to bioremediation, recycling of waste, and to support Biological Life-Support Systems (BLSS).
relationships: The addition of a biomining/bioleaching compartment could be a beneficial addition to supply basic chemical requirements for a BLSS, and vice versa.
insights: A careful selection of the most appropriate techniques and microorganisms will be required for any given application, and the optimal solution could include complementary systems. It is pivotal to invest in terrestrial and space-based research of specific methods for space applications.
